column1: questions

A 4-month-old child is brought to the Emergency Department with breathlessness. She has epicanthic folds and single palmar creases. Cytogenetic testing reveals an autosomal trisomy.
What is the most common cardiac abnormality found in children with this condition?

A. Atrial septal defect
B. Mitral stenosis
C. Patent ductus arteriosus
D. Ventricular septal defect
E. Atrioventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old lady who is 28 weeks pregnant with her second child presents in a very anxious state. She has just been at a friend’s party and has discovered that one of the children there had just developed a rash suggesting chickenpox. She is terrified the disease is going to harm her unborn child. She cannot recall if she had chickenpox as a child. Her medical record does not shed any light on the situation, and it is unclear if she has had vaccination against varicella. She does not have a rash herself and feels well. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated to date.
What is the most appropriate next course of action?

A. Arrange immediate administration of varicella-zoster immunoglobulin
B. Urgently test for varicella antibodies (varicella-zoster IgG)
C. Reassure that, even if she contracts chickenpox, it will not cause harm to the unborn baby at this stage of gestation
D. Arrange immediate immunisation against varicella-zoster
E. Advise that no immediate action is needed, but she should return immediately if she develops a rash, so that varicella-zoster immunoglobulin can be administered

Correct Answer: B

An ST1 doctor working in Scotland issues an emergency detention certificate for an inpatient being treated for acute Crohn’s disease who was demanding to go home because voices were telling him that everyone in the hospital may kill him, and was making threats of harm towards his girlfriend. He is not delirious. You have contacted a psychiatrist, who initially told you that she would be there within the 6 hours, but has since contacted you to say that due to unforeseen circumstances she cannot attend until the next day. The patient consented to taking a sedative, which was administered 3 hours ago. He is making no attempts to leave, and there has been a marked reduction in his responses to apparent auditory hallucinations and threats towards his partner.
Can you revoke the Emergency Detention Order?

A. Yes, since you made the order, you can revoke it
B. Yes, since it only applies whilst there is an urgent need for detention
C. No, only a psychiatrist can revoke it after examining the patient
D. No, it must run for the entire 72 hours
E. No, it must go to a Mental Health Tribunal

Correct Answer: C

A full-term male neonate has bilateral palpable flank masses and oliguria and is in respiratory distress. The mother had little prenatal care, but a third-trimester ultrasound right before delivery showed severe oligohydramnios. An ultrasound of the neonate now shows multiple renal cysts and hepatic fibrosis.
What is the most likely cause of these findings?

A. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
B. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
C. Renal agenesis
D. Potter syndrome
E. Nephroblastoma

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old woman presented to her general practitioner (GP) with a 2-year history of painless blurring and distortion of central vision and difficulty with night vision. She complains of days when vision is poor and other days when it is better.
On examination with a direct ophthalmoscope, there are some yellow deposits at the macula.
What is the first-line management for this patient’s eye condition?

A. Anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) intravitreal injection
B. Focal laser photocoagulation
C. Pan-retinal photocoagulation
D. Photodynamic therapy
E. Vitamin supplementation

Correct Answer: E

A 43-year-old man develops sudden-onset high fever and dyspnoea. He has a harsh, pan-systolic murmur at the apex. Echocardiography reveals a large vegetation on his mitral valve.
What findings would you expect to be present to confirm your suspicions for the most likely infective organism?

A. Gram-negative coccus, maltose fermenter
B. Gram-negative coccus, maltose non-fermenter
C. Gram-positive coccus, catalase −ve, partial haemolysis
D. Gram-positive coccus, catalase +ve, coagulase +ve
E. Gram-positive coccus, catalase +ve, coagulase −ve

Correct Answer: D

An 84-year-old man with advanced adenocarcinoma of the colon and extensive pulmonary metastases complains of recent onset of breathlessness. He has noted this when he walks 2–3 steps from his bed. He has tried controlled breathing techniques. This, however, does not alleviate his difficulty in breathing.
Which of the following is the next appropriate step for the management of dyspnoea in this patient?

A. Benzodiazepines
B. Continuous non-invasive ventilatory support
C. Heliox®
D. Nebulised opioid
E. Systemic opioids (oral/subcutaneous/intravenous)

Correct Answer: E

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department by her mother because of right-sided lower abdominal pain, on and off for 3 days. There is no vomiting or diarrhoea. The patient’s menstrual cycle is regular, 28 days long, with the last menstrual period being 14 days ago. She has never been sexually active. Her blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse 85 bpm and temperature 37.7 oC. On examination, the abdomen is soft, without distension and no rebound or guarding present. Tests show haemoglobin level to be 118 (115–155 g/l), white cell count 7.8 (4–11.0 × 109/l), C-reactive protein 4 (<5) and serum b-human chorionic gonadotropin level of zero. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows a small amount of free fluid in the pouch of Douglas, in addition to normal ovaries and a normal appendix.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute appendicitis
B. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
C. Incarcerated hernia
D. Mittelschmerz
E. Pelvic inflammatory disease

Correct Answer: D

A 76-year-old man feels something ‘give’ in his right arm while lifting a heavy bag of garden rubbish. The arm is bruised, and on flexing the elbow a lump appears in the middle of the anterior aspect of the arm. A rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii is diagnosed.
To which of the following bony points does this tendon normally attach?

A. Coracoid process of the scapula
B. Greater tuberosity of the humerus
C. Lesser tuberosity of the humerus
D. Infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula
E. Supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old alcoholic with known cirrhotic liver disease is admitted to the Gastroenterology Ward with a distended abdomen, jaundice and confusion. On examination, he is clinically jaundiced and has a massively distended abdomen with evidence of a fluid level on percussion. An aspirate of fluid is taken from his abdomen and sent for analysis. Results indicate the fluid is an exudate.
Which of the following is an exudative cause of ascites?

A. Portal hypertension
B. Cardiac failure
C. Fulminant hepatic failure
D. Budd–Chiari syndrome
E. Malignancy

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old man presents with an acutely red right eye. He also has dull aching pain affecting the eye, and he is photosensitive, with light severely worsening the pain in the eye. There is no mucopurulent discharge and he has mild blurring of vision. The left eye is not affected. Other past history of note includes intermittent diarrhoea, which he says looked bloody on a couple of occasions, but he put this down to food poisoning. On examination, his blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg; he looks thin, with a body mass index of 19.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 204 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 35 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Intraocular pressure: reduced in the affected eye, with numerous cells seen within the aqueous.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Conjunctivitis
B. Acute glaucoma
C. Anterior uveitis
D. Anterior scleritis
E. Herpetic ulcer

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old patient, with advanced liver cirrhosis and a diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma, complains of severe back pain.
Given his liver impairment, which of the following medications is the most suitable for analgesia?

A. Codeine
B. Fentanyl
C. Ibuprofen
D. Pethidine
E. Tramadol

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old, asymptomatic man comes to see you as his father died of colorectal cancer when he was 35. The patient is unaware of any other family history of cancer, but is concerned that he may develop the condition himself.
What would be the most appropriate management of this patient?

A. Reassurance
B. Arrange colonoscopy
C. Arrange FBCs, UEs and LFTs and review if abnormal
D. Digital rectal examination
E. Arrange to review with view to colonoscopy at aged 30

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old woman presents for review of her chronic kidney disease.
Her investigation results show:
Investigation Result Normal range
Calcium 1.70 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Potassium 6 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Phosphate 2.5 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Urea 80 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 400 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
What is the mechanism for the low calcium?

A. Increased parathyroid secretion
B. Increased tubular loss of calcium
C. Reduced vitamin D binding of calcium
D. Reduced vitamin D hydroxylation
E. Parathyroid tumour

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old woman is admitted to the Gastroenterology Ward with abdominal distension due to ascites. On examination, there is symmetrical distension of the abdomen and a palpable pelvic mass in the left iliac fossa. On closer questioning, she also admits to being ‘off her food’ and has lost a stone in weight over the last 3 weeks.
Which one of the following types of ovarian mass is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Brenner tumour
B. Mucinous cystadenoma
C. Teratoma
D. Clear cell carcinoma
E. Serous adenocarcinoma

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman presents with a history of facial pain and diplopia. Clinical examination reveals CN III, CN IV and CN VI palsies, a Horner’s syndrome, and facial sensory loss in the distribution of the V1 (ophthalmic) and V2 (maxillary) divisions of the trigeminal cranial nerve.
Where is the causative abnormality located?

A. Superior orbital fissure
B. Inferior orbital fissure
C. Dorello’s canal
D. Cavernous sinus
E. Meckel’s cave

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old solicitor complains of right upper quadrant pain and has deranged liver function tests. An ultrasound scan of the abdomen demonstrated a dilated common bile duct. He proceeds to endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). While observing the procedure the Consultant asks you the location of the Ampulla of Vater, which is cannulated during the procedure.
Where does the ampulla of Vater enter the bowel?

A. Jejunum
B. Ascending (fourth part) duodenum
C. Descending (second part) duodenum
D. Inferior (third part) duodenum
E. Superior (first part) duodenum

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the Acute Gynaecology Ward with per vaginum bleeding. She is 14 weeks pregnant and has had a scan confirming an intrauterine pregnancy. She reports lower abdominal cramping and bleeding for the last two days, which prompted admission to await an ultrasound scan. You are an FY1 doctor and are called to see her as she has increasing pain and is crying in distress. On examination, she is sweaty and uncomfortable. Abdomen is soft in the upper region, but firm and very tender suprapubically. Observations show temperature 38.7 °C, heart rate 130 bpm, blood pressure 95/65, respiratory rate 22 and oxygen saturations 97% on air. Checking her pad shows fresh bleeding and speculum examination is difficult due to pain, but there is a smelly discharge and you think you see tissue sitting in the os. You manage to get IV access and starts fluid resuscitation.
What is the most important next step in management?

A. Bloods and blood cultures
B. Transvaginal ultrasound scan
C. Ultrasound abdomen
D. Give analgesia and try to repeat the speculum examination
E. Call your registrar

Correct Answer: E

A 17-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) complaining of painful lesions on his face, neck and upper back. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications. On examination, the patient has multiple pustules on erythematous bases. The lesions express serosanguinous fluid and occasional pus. The GP makes a presumptive diagnosis and prescribes topical benzoyl peroxide daily.
Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for the development of this patient’s dermatological condition?

A. Apocrine glands
B. Sebaceous glands
C. Eccrine glands
D. Stratum corneum
E. Hemidesmosomes

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old welder presents with a metal splinter in his eye.
What is the single best management option you can offer in the Emergency Department setting?

A. Eye wash
B. Immediate ophthalmology referral
C. Removal of the foreign body under a slit lamp
D. Retinoscopy
E. Topical antibiotic

Correct Answer: B

A 3-year-old boy attends the GP with his mother for an asthma review. He was diagnosed with asthma six months ago. Since then, he has been on a low-dose clenil (beclometasone 100 μg BD) inhaler and salbutamol inhaler as required, both inhaled via a spacer. He has a nocturnal cough and is using his salbutamol inhaler 3–4 times per day since the weather has been very cold, with good effect. On examination, there are no signs of respiratory distress, his oxygen saturation is 98% and his chest is clear.
What would be the next step in this patient’s management plan?

A. Add montelukast
B. Change salbutamol to ipratropium
C. Increase the dose of clenil
D. Refer to paediatrician
E. Stop clenil

Correct Answer: A

A patient’s family buys the ward a box of chocolates but gives you a separate card with a £50 voucher in it for all your help.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Say nothing, you deserve it
B. Share the voucher with the ward
C. Donate the voucher to charity
D. Give the voucher back to the family and thank them
E. Ask the family for a bigger voucher, as £50 is not enough

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old woman sees her General Practitioner for a follow-up appointment. She has recently been diagnosed with depression. She is taking citalopram and has started a course of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT).
Which of the following is used to monitor response to treatment in patients with depression?

A. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT)
B. Generalised Anxiety DisorderQuestionnaire (GAD-7)
C. Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
D. Modified Single-Answer ScreeningQuestion (M-SASQ)
E. Patient HealthQuestionnaire (PHQ-9)

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old man, with a known abdominal aortic aneurysm presents for his annual review.
What size abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) would indicate the need for urgent elective surgery of the aneurysm?

A. AAA between 2.5–3.5 cm
B. AAA between 3.5–4.5 cm
C. AAA between 4.5–5.4 cm
D. An increase of 0.5–1 cm per year
E. An increase of >1 cm per year

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old man is receiving a 2 units of blood transfusion for anaemia of unknown cause – haemoglobin (Hb) 65 g/l (normal 135–175 g/l). During the third hour of the blood transfusion he spikes a temperature of 38.1°C (normal 36.1–37.2°C). Otherwise the patient is asymptomatic and his other observations are normal.
Given the likely diagnosis, what should you do?

A. Stop blood transfusion and switch to iv fluids
B. Temporarily stop transfusion, repeat clerical checks. Then treat with paracetamol and repeat observations more regularly (every 15 minutes)
C. Treat with adrenaline (im, 1:1000 strength)
D. Treat with an antihistamine
E. Treat with furosemide

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man presents to the upper gastrointestinal surgeon with a 9-month history of difficulty swallowing both liquids and solid foods. He also complains of regurgitating food. He has been eating smaller and smaller meals given the above symptoms. He has a past medical history of depression for which he takes citalopram. He has never smoked or drank alcohol. He has trialled over-the-counter proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) medication without any symptom relief.
Physical examination is normal. A recent chest radiograph also appears to be normal. His electrocardiogram (ECG) is also normal.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.8 °C
Blood pressure 127/79 mmHg
Heart rate 75 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
A diagnosis of achalasia is likely.
Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management for this condition?

A. Botulinum toxin A injections
B. Gastrostomy
C. Pneumatic dilation
D. Sublingual isosorbide dinitrate
E. Sublingual nifedipine

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman presents to her GP with lethargy, weakness and increasing itching. Examination is largely unremarkable. Blood tests are performed:
Test Result
Full blood count Normal
Renal profile Normal
Alkaline phosphatase Raised
γ-glutamyl transferase Raised
Alanine and aspartate aminotransferase Normal
Bilirubin Slightly raised
Antimitochondrial antibody M­2 (AMA) Positive
Anti-smooth muscle antibody (ASMA) Negative
Anti-liver/kidney microsomal antibody (anti-LKM) Negative
Hepatitis screen Negative
HIV virus type 1 and type 2 RNA Negative
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
B. Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)
C. Hepatitis C
D. Pancreatic head tumour
E. Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old woman has chronic pancreatitis. She has lost weight and has diarrhoea that has become troublesome. She reports that she has had diarrhoea daily and it has a strong, malodorous smell. The unintentional weight loss is 9 kg over the last year and she has had a general decrease in energy.
Which preparation would be most suitable to decrease her diarrhoea?

A. Colestyramine
B. Co-phenotrope
C. Loperamide
D. Pancreatin
E. Psyllium (ispaghula)

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old man has been suffering with significant chronic back pain for years. For analgesia, the patient takes paracetamol 1000 mg orally (PO) four times daily (QDS), ibuprofen 400 mg PO three times daily (TDS) and fentanyl 25 µg/hour patch every 72 hours. They are attending their general practitioner (GP) as they are suffering from episodes of acute pain a few times a day and are asking for some medication to take when this happens. They are intolerant to morphine and have a past medical history significant for chronic kidney disease, hypertension, osteoarthritis and gallstones.
Which is the following is an acceptable regimen for their breakthrough pain?

A. Morphine sulphate PO 5–10 mg as required (PRN)
B. Oxycontin 5–10 mg PRN
C. Oxynorm PO 2.5–5 mg PRN
D. Oxynorm PO 5–10 mg PRN
E. Sevredol® PO 10 mg PRN

Correct Answer: C

A 61-year-old, non-smoking woman with no previous cardiac history, has a total cholesterol of 9.0 mmol/l. She is overweight and has sleep apnoea. On examination you notice her skin is particularly dry and there appears to be some evidence of hair loss. Her blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg and pulse rate 60 bpm.
Which of the following would be the most useful next step in her management?

A. Check her fasting blood glucose level
B. Check her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) level
C. Measure her 24-hour urinary free cortisol
D. Prescribe a statin
E. Screen family members for raised cholesterol

Correct Answer: B

A 57-year-old woman is referred to Gynaecology as she has been suffering from unexplained abdominal bloating and pain for several months. She has no other symptoms and examination is normal, asides from her obesity. She recently began experiencing menopausal symptoms, and started on hormone replacement therapy. She had a right-sided salpingo oophorectomy for polycystic ovaries when she was 23 years old, and has never had children.
Which cancer is this woman most likely to be at risk of having?

A. Endometrial cancer
B. Breast cancer
C. Cervical cancer
D. Normal menopause
E. Vaginal cancer

Correct Answer: A

A gynaecologist is performing a pelvic examination on a 25-year-old woman in the lithotomy position. To palpate the patient’s uterus, the index and middle fingers of the right hand are placed inside the vagina, while the fingers and palm of the left hand are used to palpate the abdomen suprapubically. While palpating the patient’s abdomen with her left hand, the doctor feels a bony structure in the lower midline.
Which one of the following bony structures is the doctor most likely to feel with the palm of her left hand?

A. Ilium
B. Coccyx
C. Sacrum
D. Ischium
E. Pubis

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a lump in the left testicle that he noticed on self-examination while in the shower. He is asymptomatic from the lump, with no lower urinary tract symptoms or pain. He is worried, as his father had some similar problems as he found a lump on his testicle when he was younger. On examination, there is a nodule in the left testicle which is firm and non-tender. An ultrasound scan of the testis was carried out which showed an irregular mass lesion on the left testicle. His serum a-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels are not elevated.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Epididymo-orchitis
B. Seminoma
C. Testicular teratoma
D. Varicocele
E. Epididymal cyst

Correct Answer: B

A 5-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with his parents after they noticed a high-pitched sound associated with his breathing. The child was playing with toy cars at the time. On examination, the patient is in respiratory distress, and a chest X-ray demonstrates a hyperinflated right lung.
Where is the most likely site of obstruction?

A. Trachea
B. Left main bronchus
C. Right main bronchus
D. Left lower lobe
E. Oesophagus

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old banker notices that chronic pain over the lateral aspect of his right elbow is aggravated when he plays tennis, especially when he does a backhand. Examination reveals that the pain is reproduced with resisted wrist extension while the elbow is fully extended.
What is the muscle attachment most likely to be involved?

A. Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB)
B. Extensor carpi radialis longus
C. Extensor carpi ulnaris
D. Extensor digitorum
E. Anconeus

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman has been feeling tired and lethargic for three weeks, with abdominal discomfort in the left upper quadrant. She recently had a urinary tract infection (UTI), which was treated with amoxicillin. However, she developed a widespread rash on her body and so stopped taking the tablets.
What is the most likely reason for her tiredness?

A. Chronic fatigue syndrome
B. Chronic renal failure
C. Chronic depression
D. Glandular fever
E. Iron deficiency

Correct Answer: D

A patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency visits her General Practitioner (GP) for her regular blood test.
Which of the following results would you expect?

A. Elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and no other changes
B. Elevated levels of chylomicrons and low levels of very low-density lipoproteins (VLDLs)
C. Elevated levels of both chylomicrons and VLDLs
D. Low VLDL levels and no other changes
E. Low levels of both chylomicrons and VLDLs

Correct Answer: C

A 37-year-old patient was being tested for prolonged fever. Initial blood tests were all normal and a peripheral blood examination revealed:
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
What is the most common explanation for the abnormality marked here (red arrow)?

A. A hereditary red blood cell (RBC) membrane disorder
B. Virus-induced RBC damage
C. Drug-induced RBC damage
D. Iron deficiency anaemia
E. Malignancy

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old woman, with a history of fibromyalgia, presents to her General Practitioner with a 4-month history of a constant soreness in the pelvic and perineal area. She reports it is there most of the time, and she struggles to carry on with her daily activities and sleep. She is tearful and fatigued. She tried paracetamol and ibuprofen, but these have not worked. She denies any post-menopausal bleeding or vaginal discharge.
Examination is unremarkable. She had a recent abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan for investigation of acute diverticulitis that revealed no abnormality in the uterus and ovaries.
Which of the following is the next step in the patient’s management?

A. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
B. Amitriptyline
C. Gabapentin
D. Referral to the Gynaecology team
E. Referral to the Pain team

Correct Answer: B

A 14-year-old is brought to her General Practitioner by her parents after they noticed her eating habits had become irregular. The parents report that the patient eats large volumes of foods and is sometimes found vomiting shortly after eating dinner. This behaviour has been occurring for the past 6 months. On examination, the patient’s vital signs are normal and she has a body mass index (BMI) of 23. She has excoriations on the knuckles of her right hand. She also has erosions on her teeth and swelling bilaterally on the lateral aspects of the face along the mandibular rami.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anorexia nervosa
B. Binge eating disorder
C. Bulimia nervosa
D. Gender dysphoria
E. Avoidant personality disorder

Correct Answer: C

A 52-year-old man was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and commenced on methotrexate. After six months there was no improvement. He was changed to a combination of methotrexate and sulfasalazine with no improvement after a similar period of therapy.
What is the best treatment at this stage?

A. Azathioprine
B. Combination of gold plus penicillamine
C. Combination of gold, leflunomide and methotrexate
D. Infliximab plus methotrexate
E. Leflunomide

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old patient, who presented with headaches, palpitations and periodic increases in blood pressure, was diagnosed to have phaeochromocytoma and, as a result, 2 years ago underwent laparoscopic removal of an adrenal tumour. Recently he noticed a lump in his neck while shaving. On physical examination, the patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. Investigations show an increased serum calcitonin level and also a pentagastrin-induced rise in the secretion of calcitonin. A biopsy sample is analysed and confirms the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma. The patient is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy.
Which one of the following is the most likely potential complication of this treatment?

A. Acromegaly
B. Cretinism
C. Hypertension
D. Hypoparathyroidism
E. Renal osteodystrophy

Correct Answer: D

An 86-year-old woman has been taken to Accident and Emergency from her residential home after there was increasing concern from staff there. She has been increasingly confused over the last few days, which staff initially put down to her Alzheimer’s dementia. She has known chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), but no other long-term medical conditions. She was administered intravenous (IV) paracetamol in the ambulance en route to the hospital. You are unable to take any useful history; however, she is responding to voice only, with some minor abdominal tenderness found on examination and little else. She appears shocked, and her observations are as follows:
Temperature 37.6 °C
Blood pressure 88/52 mmHg
Heart rate 112 bpm
Saturations 92% on room air
An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed which shows first-degree heart block and nil else.
What type of shock is this woman likely to be demonstrating?

A. Anaphylactic
B. Hypovolaemic
C. Cardiogenic
D. Septic
E. Neurogenic

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man attends your General Practice (GP) Surgery with concern over an event which happened earlier in the day. He vaguely describes a feeling of epigastric discomfort, followed by a tingling sensation down his arms and the smell of cooking bacon. Alongside this, he describes generally ‘not feeling right’. At no point did he lose consciousness. On further enquiry, he mentions that he feels this has happened to him before. You note he has a past medical history of ischaemic heart disease and has had a stroke four months ago.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Focal impaired awareness seizure
B. Gastritis
C. Malingering
D. Focal aware seizure
E. Psychotic hallucination

Correct Answer: D

The following statement was written in an abdominal surgery report: ‘The patient’s abdominal aortic aneurysm was repaired using an endovascular graft, where the centre of the graft was in line with the subcostal plane.’
Based on this information, to which of the following vertebrae was the centre of the graft most likely anterior?

A. L1 vertebra
B. L2 vertebra
C. L3 vertebra
D. L4 vertebra
E. L5 vertebra

Correct Answer: C

It has been clearly documented that the rate of serious infections declined over the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this decline?

A. Better sanitation
B. Antibiotics
C. Immunisation programmes
D. A decline in the virulence of organisms
E. Invention of disposable facial tissues

Correct Answer: A

A 53-year-old woman is referred for an ultrasound scan of the abdomen and pelvis following a 6-month history of abdominal discomfort and bloating. She feels generally tired and has lost approximately 6 kg in weight over this time.
The ultrasound scan shows a 4 cm × 4 cm multilocular and highly vascular solid mass arising from the left ovary.
Which of the following tumour markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?

A. Ca-125
B. Ca 19-9
C. Calcitonin
D. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
E. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) antigen

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department. He took an overdose 48 hours ago after he had an argument with his girlfriend. He was drunk at the time and cannot remember what he took. The General Practitioner had recently started him on antidepressants. Blood tests show:
Investigations Results Normal Values
Haemoglobin (Hb) 140 g/l 135–175 g/l
Platelets 150 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Prothrombin time 40 s 10–15 s
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 700 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 100 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 400 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Urea 10 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
pH 7.31 7.35–7.45
Which of the following drugs is he most likely to have taken?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Paracetamol
C. Aspirin
D. Benzodiazepine
E. Fluoxetine

Correct Answer: B

An 84-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department, having suffered from a fall in her home. She has bruising to her face and legs and a ‘dinner fork’ deformity of her left wrist. Her pulse is 65 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 100/86 mmHg, temperature 37.5 °C and oxygen saturations 96%. Her plan includes an occupational therapy and risk assessment for falls, with a view to modification of her home and lifestyle to prevent future recurrence.
Approximately what percentage of people aged over 80 suffer from falls?

A. 15%
B. 25%
C. 30%
D. 50%
E. 65%

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old woman is admitted to the Intensive Therapy Unit. She presented with multiple seizures to the Emergency Department and is 8 months pregnant. She is intubated and ventilated; her blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 108 g/dl 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 30 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 134 U/l 10–40 IU/l
Urine analysis protein ++
Which of the following fits best with this clinical picture?

A. The treatment of choice is delivery of the fetus
B. She should remain intubated and ventilated for at least 5 days
C. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain is not indicated     
D. Hydralazine is not appropriate for blood pressure control
E. Less than 25% of patients suffer from a transient neurological deficit

Correct Answer: A

An 18-year-old man presents to his GP with the regular occurrence of watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, flatulence and nausea. Stool analysis reveals and increased osmotic gap, with a pH < 6. Hydrogen breath test is positive.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cows’ milk protein allergy
B. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
C. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
D. Lactose intolerance
E. Bowel malignancy

Correct Answer: D

A 12-year-old boy presents with right femur pain for 3 months which has been getting progressively worse. It is especially painful at night and he now notes a painful lump in his right thigh. He denies any fever or weight loss, but has noted a recent cough. A radiograph shows a typical blastic and destructive intramedullary lesion with periosteal reaction and a large soft tissue mass.
What is the most appropriate next step in his management?

A. Order a whole-body bone scan, computed tomography (CT) chest and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the entire femur
B. Proceed to perform a core biopsy of the lump under local anaesthesia
C. Offer the patient and his family an amputation of the affected limb
D. Repeat the radiographs in 3 months to look for progression to rule out a benign lesion
E. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by a wide excision of the lesion

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old woman has presented to the Rheumatology Clinic with a 3-week history of increasing bilateral shoulder pain and stiffness, associated with fatigue and general malaise. She notices that the stiffness tends to be worse upon waking in the morning, when it usually lasts three hours. Additionally, she has lost approximately 3.5 kg in weight over these past three weeks, which she feels is due to her recent lack of appetite.
Her past medical history includes depression, for which she takes regular fluoxetine 20 mg once daily (od). She is a non-smoker and drinks six units of alcohol a week. On systemic enquiry, she denies any focal lower back pain and headaches. A general examination reveals no stigmata of chronic disease. A GALS examination reveals stiffness and elicited pain in the shoulder girdle. Full blood count (FBC), urea and electrolytes (U&Es) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), as well as urinalysis, are carried out by the General Practitioner.
FBC, U&Es and ESR:
Investigations Results Normal Values
Haemoglobin (Hb) 123 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 86 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets (Plt) 200 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
ESR 105 mm in first hour 0–10 mm in first hour
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.6 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 5.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 86 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Creatine kinase 61 IU/l 23–175 IU/l
Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibody Negative Negative
Urinalysis:
Result
Leukocytes Negative
Nitrites Negative
Protein Negative
Blood Negative
Glucose Negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Polymyositis
B. Multiple myeloma
C. Rheumatoid arthritis
D. Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR)
E. Osteoarthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old man has this lesion on his right arm that has been present for 3 weeks and is now 2 cm in diameter. It is not painful or tender and has not bled. It does not itch. There is no regional lymphadenopathy.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Basal cell carcinoma
B. Keratoacanthoma
C. Molluscum contagiosum
D. Prurigo nodularis
E. Squamous cell carcinoma

Correct Answer: B

An 87-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe pain in his right leg, below the knee. This pain came on suddenly an hour ago, after walking to his kitchen. He knows that he gets claudication on walking over 200 metres, and is unsure if this pain is the same. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, controlled with rivaroxaban 20 mg od. On examination, his right leg below the knee is pale, cold and numb, with absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present pulses on his left leg.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Thrombolysis
B. Amputation below right knee
C. Embolectomy
D. High dose warfarin
E. Angiography and stenting

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman student presents to her general practitioner (GP) with menstrual irregularity. Her last menstrual period was 4 months ago. On examination, the GP notes an increased body mass index (BMI) and coarse dark hair over her stomach. There are no other relevant findings. The GP makes a referral to a gynaecologist.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s menstrual irregularity?

A. Turner syndrome
B. Hyperprolactinaemia
C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
D. Premature ovarian failure
E. Virilizing ovarian tumour

Correct Answer: C

A normally fit and well 30-year-old man is admitted to Emergency Department (ED) with a 4 hour history of palpitations. He has no chest pain, a National Early Warning Score (NEWS) score of 0, and the only finding on examination is an irregularly irregular pulse. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms that the patient is in atrial fibrillation. The patient has no significant past medical history.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. DC cardioversion
B. Medical cardioversion (amiodarone or flecainide)
C. Anticoagulation therapy with warfarin
D. Radiofrequency ablation
E. Send home with 24-h three lead ECG tape and review in 1 week.

Correct Answer: B

A 12-year-old Afro-Caribbean boy has been brought to the paediatric Emergency Department by his parents, both of whom are known to suffer from sickle cell disease. They have brought him in to see you because they are worried he has developed ‘septicaemia’. Upon further questioning, he reveals that he has developed extreme fatigue, shortness of breath on exertion, coryzal symptoms and bleeding gums, all over the last two days.
Upon examination, you note an erythematous rash on both cheeks, a small purpuric rash on the left arm, pale conjunctivae, pale skin and well-perfused peripheries. Brudzinski’s sign is negative.
You take some basic observations, which are as follows:
Temperature: 37.8 ˚C
Heart rate: 100 bpm (normal 55–85 bpm)
Respiratory rate: 20 breaths/min (normal 12–18 breaths/min)
Blood pressure: 130/86 mmHg (lying), 132/84 mmHg (standing)
Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air
His initial investigation findings are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal
White cell count (WCC) 11.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 3800 × 106/l 3000–5800 × 106/l
Lymphocytes 7200 × 106/l 1500–3000 × 106/l
Haemoglobin (Hb) 84 g/dl 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume
(MCV) 94 fl 76–98 fl
Platelets 200 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Given the likely diagnosis, how should the patient be managed?

A. Cross-match, giving blood as soon as it is available
B. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)
C. IV ceftriaxone, 500ml 0.9% saline over a maximum of 15 minutes, and carry out a lumbar puncture
D. Oral benzylpenicillin and transfer to a paediatric ward
E. Take blood cultures, measure blood lactate and urine output, give 500ml Hartmann’s solution over a maximum of 15 minutes, give IV empirical antibiotics and titrate oxygen levels to 94–98%

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old woman in her second pregnancy presents at 11 weeks with a 1-day history of vaginal bleeding. Bleeding started as a light brown discharge on wiping and was accompanied by period-like pains. Symptoms have now resolved. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender, the cervical os is closed and there is some dark brown discharge in the vagina.
Which of the following ultrasound findings will confirm the diagnosis?

A. Bleeding seen within the uterus
B. An empty uterus
C. Gestational sac small for dates; no fetal heart rate demonstrated
D. Gestational sac seen within the uterus; fetal heart rate present
E. Products of conception seen in the uterus; absent fetal heart rate

Correct Answer: D

A 38-year-old factory worker has telephoned his general practitioner (GP), as he has been unwell for the past eight days, having experienced back pain that he attributes to bending over at work.
Just five days ago, he attended the Emergency Department due to the pain. The patient is concerned about his ability to return to work.
Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

A. Certify the patient as being unfit for work
B. Inform the patient that he can certify his own inability to work for the first two weeks
C. Certify the patient as maybe being fit for work if his employer can amend his duties
D. Inform the patient that you cannot certify him as being unfit because you did not treat him initially
E. Inform the patient that you are unable to issue a fit note until he comes in for an examination

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old woman presents to the Surgical Admissions Unit with right upper quadrant colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. It came on while eating but is starting to subside. On examination, she is restless and sweaty with a pulse rate of 100 bpm and blood pressure of 125/86. Abdominal ultrasound confirms the presence of gallstones.
What is the most common composition of gallstones?

A. Cholesterol
B. Uric acid
C. Palmitate
D. Bilirubin
E. Calcium

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old man has been referred to colonoscopy having suffered persistent rectal bleeding following 3 months of unexplained weight loss. His GP felt a rectal mass during direct rectal examination. Unfortunately a mass was confirmed in the most distal portion of his rectum, involving the anal sphincter.
Which surgical procedure would be best for this patient?

A. Hartmann’s procedure
B. Abdominoperineal resection
C. Anterior resection
D. Right hemicolectomy
E. Left hemicolectomy

Correct Answer: B

A 64-year-old woman is under assessment on the medical ward following increasing episodes of dyspnoea, mostly on exertion. The dyspnoea has been associated with increasing fatigue over the last few months. On examination, you find her to be slightly wheezy. She has bilateral pitting ankle oedema.
Her past medical history consists of type I diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and hypothyroidism.
Her medications include: insulin, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin and amlodipine.
Social history: never smoked, drinks two units of alcohol per week, no recreational drug use.
Blood results:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 152 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.6 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 5.4 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine (Cr) 69 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide
(NT-proBNP) 350 pg/ml < 100 pg/ml
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Asthma
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Cor pulmonale
E. Left ventricular failure

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old teacher is tested for compatibility to donate a kidney to his older brother, who has end-stage renal failure. To his joy, he is found to be a suitable match. The patient is then thoroughly counselled regarding the operative procedure, short- and long-term risks, and the implications of living with one healthy kidney. He is particularly interested to learn how his body will adapt to having only one kidney.
Which one of the following will be decreased in the donor after the kidney transplant?

A. Creatinine clearance
B. Creatinine production
C. Serum sodium
D. Plasma creatinine concentration
E. Serum potassium

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old woman gives a history of dysphagia for both solids and liquids. Occasionally food gets stuck, but the patient overcomes this by taking a large drink. Achalasia of the oesophagus is suspected.
Which of the following nerves supplies the muscularis externa of the oesophagus?

A. Glossopharyngeal nerves
B. Greater splanchnic nerves
C. Intercostal nerves
D. Phrenic nerves
E. Vagus nerves

Correct Answer: E

A 37-year-old newly immigrated woman with multiple skin blisters presents for evaluation. Some of the blisters have ruptured, leaving a painful, denuded area. Scrapings from the base of one of the erosive lesions are prepared for Tzanck test. Under the microscope, acantholytic keratinocytes with large hyperchromatic nuclei are observed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Herpes simplex infection
B. Chickenpox
C. Cytomegalovirus infection
D. Pemphigus vulgaris
E. Bullous pemphigoid

Correct Answer: D

You are an FY2 doctor working at an inpatient psychiatry unit. You have been asked to assess a patient by the nursing staff as they are currently occupied by a distressed patient and relative. The patient you've been asked to review has known schizophrenia and wishes to leave the unit. However, following consultation with the patient, you are concerned they are exhibiting features of an acute psychotic episode.
Which section of the Mental Health Act (2007) could be used to detain the patient?

A. Section 2
B. Section 5(4)
C. Section 3
D. Section 5(2)
E. Section 7

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman on the Stroke Ward has been found to have a grade 2 pressure ulcer over her sacrum.
Which of the following options correctly describes a grade 2 pressure ulcer?

A. Extensive destruction (with possible damage to muscle, bone or supporting structures)
B. Full-thickness skin loss involving damage/necrosis of subcutaneous tissue
C. Non-blanching erythema of intact skin and skin discolouration
D. Partial-thickness skin loss and ulceration
E. Focal loss of skin integrity ± pus/blood

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old woman attends Accident and Emergency with a productive cough, dyspnoea and shivering for 5 days. Examination reveals bronchial breathing at the left lower lung base. Inflammatory markers are raised. A chest radiograph demonstrates left lower zone consolidation.
Which of the following is the most common pathogen associated with community-acquired pneumonia?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
C. Haemophilus influenzae
D. Streptococcus pneumoniae
E. Neisseria meningitides

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old man presents to the clinic with three positive faecal occult blood specimens. He has had no significant symptoms, apart from mild fatigue over the past few months.
On examination, he has pale conjunctiva, but there are no other specific findings.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 105 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 79 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 4.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 275 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 11 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 35 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 46 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Flexible colonoscopy: abnormal vessels visualised on the right side of the colon
Which of the following is the initial therapy of choice?

A. Right hemicolectomy
B. Review colonoscopy in 6 months
C. Endoscopic ablation of abnormal vessels
D. 2 units of blood transfusion
E. Iron sulfate supplementation

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman is admitted unresponsive to the Emergency Department. She is not breathing and has no pulse. The ambulance crew had initiated cardiopulmonary resuscitation before arrival. She is known to have hypertension and takes ramipril.
She had routine bloods at the General Practice surgery three days ago:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 134 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 134 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 9.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine (Cr) 83 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) > 60
The Ambulance Crew hand you an electrocardiogram (ECG) strip which shows ventricular fibrillation (VF).
What is the most likely cause of her cardiac arrest?

A. Hyperkalaemia
B. Hypernatraemia
C. Hypovolaemia
D. Hypoxia
E. Pulmonary thrombus

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old patient presents with severe abdominal pain. He describes a sudden-onset pain that comes in waves, running from his left loin into his left testicle. His blood tests are all normal.
What is the most sensitive next investigation for diagnosis?

A. Abdominal X-ray
B. Computerised tomography of the kidneys, ureters and bladder (CT KUB)
C. Flexible cystoscopy
D. Retrograde urethrogram
E. Urinalysis

Correct Answer: B

A 73-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner complaining of intermittent blood in his stools for the past six months. He denies any weight loss and reports no change in the frequency or consistency of his stools and no abdominal pains. The patient is referred for an urgent colonoscopy which shows a bleeding point in the ascending colon without any mass.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon
B. Angiodysplasia
C. Carcinoid tumour
D. Diverticular disease
E. Ischaemic colitis

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old woman presents with gastroenteritis. She is unable to tolerate oral fluids and has been written up for IV replacement.
What is the maximal flow rate through a 16G cannula?

A. 33 ml/min
B. 54 ml/min
C. 80 ml/min
1C. 80 ml/min
E. 270 ml/min

Correct Answer: D

A baby is due his measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine. The baby’s mother wants to have a bit of information regarding the vaccine.
What type of vaccine is the MMR?

A. A live attenuated vaccine
B. An inactivated vaccine
C. A toxoid vaccine
D. A subunit vaccine
E. A conjugate vaccine

Correct Answer: A

A 51-year-old man with known chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the Emergency Department with an acute exacerbation. He is very short of breath and his oxygen saturations are 76% on room air. He is started on 15 litres high-flow oxygen and is then switched to controlled oxygen supplementation through a 28% venturi mask. An ABG from a previous hospital episode last month shows type 2 respiratory failure with significantly raised bicarbonate.
What is the most appropriate target for his oxygen saturations?

A. No oxygen targets
B. 80%
C. 94–98%
D. 90–94%
E. 88–92%

Correct Answer: E

A 52-year-old woman presents with back and flank pain affecting both sides. She has been diagnosed some years ago with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome and has suffered from a previous deep vein thrombosis. On assessment, temperature is 36.7oC, heart rate is 76 bpm, blood pressure 128/80 mmHg and she is still passing urine.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.3 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 17.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 325 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urine proteinuria +++
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical scenario?

A. Bilateral renal artery stenosis
B. Bilateral ureteric obstruction
C. Bilateral pyelonephritis
D. Bilateral renal vein thrombosis
E. Medullary sponge kidney

Correct Answer: D

A 16-year-old boy is seen in general practice surgery with symptoms of thirst and polyuria. There is a history of type I diabetes in the family and the general practitioner strongly suspects this as a diagnosis. He performs a urinalysis, which showed high osmolality. Blood results report plasma osmolality of 310 mmol/kg.
Approximately what percentage of diabetes cases in the United Kingdom (UK) are type I?

A. 90%
B. 50%
C. 35%
D. 20%
E. 10%

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old mechanic comes to the general practitioner (GP) concerned about his risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. His mother has been diagnosed with an advanced form of the condition, and although he has no symptoms, the patient is anxious, as he has heard recently that the condition can be inherited.
Which one of the following statements regarding Alzheimer's disease is true?

A. It accounts for 30–40% of all cases of dementia
B. The onset is rare after the age of 75
C. The familial variant is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
D. It is more common in women than men
E. It cannot be inherited

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman is seen in the Gastroenterology Clinic for a follow-up appointment following a liver biopsy. She was first seen in clinic two weeks ago after being referred by her General Practitioner due to fatigue, myalgia, abdominal bloating and significantly deranged aminotransferases. The results of her liver biopsy and blood tests confirm a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH).
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

A. Azathioprine and prednisolone
B. Cholestyramine
C. Liver transplantation
D. Peginterferon alpha-2a
E. Tenofovir

Correct Answer: A

A 31-year-old man presents to clinic with fresh blood per rectum. He had previously been diagnosed with haemorrhoids and treated with dietary advice, rectal analgesics and haemorrhoid banding. His symptoms persist.
Which one of these is the next step in this man’s management prior to having an examination under anaesthesia?

A. Barium follow-through
B. Colonoscopy
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
D. Flexible sigmoidoscopy
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man is involved in a car-on-car road traffic collision. Upon arrival at the Emergency Department he is found to have suffered a right humeral shaft fracture.
Which of the following neurovascular structures is most likely to have been damaged, given this man’s injury?

A. Axillary nerve
B. Brachial artery
C. Median nerve
D. Radial nerve
E. Ulnar nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 29-year-old woman with gestational diabetes delivered at 38+6 weeks’ gestation by an uncomplicated elective Caesarean section for macrosomia. The baby weighed 4.6 kg at delivery. The Apgar score at 1 and 5 minutes was 10. Six hours later, she pulls the emergency alarm because her baby became lethargic and started shaking.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn’s lethargy and seizure activity?

A. Neonatal sepsis
B. Hypoglycaemia
C. Hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy
D. Intracranial haemorrhage
E. Benign familial neonatal seizures

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old patient presents with acute pain in his right calf, from the knee downwards, causing him great difficulty in walking. Of note, pulses are not palpable in the right limb below the knee. While standing, the right limb appears more erythematous than the left, but this colour quickly fades on laying the patient flat.
Which one of the following statements is correct?

A. Chronic arterial insufficiency is likely to be an underlying factor in the above presentation
B. On examination, sensation would likely be increased
C. Ankle–brachial pressure index measurement would be a useful tool in the above patient
D. A Fogarty catheter cannot be used to treat the above condition
E. Lumbar sympathectomy is indicated in the above condition

Correct Answer: A

A 49-year-old woman has been admitted with haemoptysis and epistaxis. Her chest X-ray shows multiple rounded lesions with alveolar shadowing. Her serum is positive for cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Carcinoma of the lung
B. Echinococcosis
C. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: C

A patient attends their general practitioner (GP) having been discharged from hospital the day before. They are due to fly to Venice in three days’ time for a friend’s wedding and have asked for a letter saying they are fit to fly.
Which of the following reasons for admission would be a contraindication to them flying?

A. Asthma attack
B. Colles fracture
C. Colonoscopy
D. Hypoglycaemic episode
E. Pneumothorax

Correct Answer: E

A patient has returned to the ward, following a neurosurgical procedure to remove a large benign cyst. Over the next few hours, she becomes less alert and the neurosurgeon is recalled. The patient is unable to deviate her right eye medially. At rest, her eye appears to point downwards and laterally and the right pupil appears to be dilated.
Which nerve has been affected?

A. Optic
B. Oculomotor
C. Trochlear
D. Abducens
E. Ciliary nerve

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old healthy pregnant woman is about to give birth to her first child at 9 months’ gestation. The obstetrician decides to perform a Caesarean section.
Which of the following abdominal surgical incisions will the obstetrician most likely use to perform the procedure?

A. Right subcostal incision
B. Median longitudinal incision
C. Transverse incision just below the umbilicus
D. McBurney’s point incision
E. Suprapubic incision

Correct Answer: E

A 19-year-old student presents to his General Practitioner with intermittent watery diarrhoea and lower colicky abdominal pain. He has experienced these symptoms for two years and during this time has lost over a stone in weight. Recently he has noticed a strange red rash on his shins. Past medical history includes a diagnosis of a fissure-in-ano three years ago.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Infective colitis
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Ulcerative colitis
D. Irritable bowel syndrome
E. Appendicitis

Correct Answer: B

A 2-year-old child presents with a history of an itchy rash within minutes of drinking milk.
What is the most appropriate investigation?

A. Elimination diet
B. Allergy skin-patch test
C. Skin prick test
D. Oral food challenge
E. Multiplex allergen testing

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner because she is concerned about patches of depigmentation on her skin. There are patches on the back of her hands and her elbows, but she is particularly concerned about depigmentation around her mouth and affecting her breasts. Her only other past history of note is a tendency to gain weight over the past few months. Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 115–155 g/l
Platelets 320 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 80 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) 6.0 µU/l 0.17–3.2 µU/l
Depigmented skin areas fluoresce bright blue-white on Wood’s lamp inspection.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lichen planus
B. Leprosy
C. Pityriasis vesicolor
D. Vitiligo
E. Idiopathic hypomelanosis

Correct Answer: D

A 12-year-old boy is brought to the Accident and Emergency department by his parents. On a background of high-grade fever and lethargy over the last 12 hours, the child had an episode of jerking of the limbs, frothing at the mouth and incontinence of urine. He has failed to recover full consciousness after the episode. At presentation, he is poorly responsive to name-calling, but responsive to pain. He is however maintaining his airway and oxygen saturation is 95% on air. Limited neurological examination is unremarkable. Non-contrast computerised tomography (CT) scan of the brain is normal. Lumbar puncture is performed and reveals a slightly raised opening pressure, moderately increased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein, CSF lymphocytosis and normal glucose.
What is the most important step in management?

A. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
B. IV aciclovir
C. IV cefotaxime
D. Intubation and ventilation
E. IV mannitol

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man, who had been working abroad in the hard metal industry, presented with progressive dyspnoea. A chest X-ray showed diffuse interstitial fibrosis bilaterally.
What is the typical cellular component found in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) of this patient?

A. Neutrophils
B. CD4 cells
C. Giant cells
D. Eosinophils
E. Haemosiderin-laden macrophages

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old woman with Crohn’s disease (CD) attends her general practice for a routine check-up. The General Practitioner carries out an examination and notes clubbing, hepatomegaly and episcleritis. He explains to the patient that these are recognised signs associated with CD.
Which of the following is an additional extra-intestinal feature of CD?

A. Pyoderma gangrenosum
B. Necrobiosis lipoidica
C. Palmar erythaema
D. Erythema multiforme
E. Lichen planus

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain of a few hours’ onset. She has Charcot’s triad, a raised white cell count, deranged liver function tests (LFTs) and raised conjugated bilirubin.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Carcinoma of the bile duct
B. Renal stones
C. Acute cholangitis
D. Chronic pancreatitis
E. Liver cirrhosis

Correct Answer: C

A 79-year-old retired shopkeeper is brought to the general practitioner (GP) by his concerned daughter. She tells you that her father had got lost when returning home from shopping yesterday, a trip that he had been carrying out with no problems for over 20 years. She also notes that he has had a general decline in his memory function over the past year or so, frequently repeating stories, and not being able to remember if he had eaten a meal or not that day when questioned. The daughter would like to know if her father could be tested for Alzheimer’s disease, a condition that also affected her paternal grandmother.
Deposition of which of the following is associated with the development of Alzheimer’s disease?

A. TARDBP-43
B. Amyloid precursor protein (APP)
C. Huntingtin
D. Alpha-synuclein
E. Bunina bodies

Correct Answer: B

A 20-year-old man returns from a trip to India suffering from nausea, anorexia and fatigue. His General Practitioner notes that he is clinically jaundiced and both his liver and spleen are moderately palpable. Blood tests and viral markers lead to a diagnosis of hepatitis A.
What is the route of spread for hepatitis A?

A. Sexual
B. Vertical
C. Blood products
D. Saliva
E. Faeco-oral

Correct Answer: E

You suspect your friend Stacey has been taking more ‘sick days’ than needed. You happened to see one of her social media posts of her out for lunch when she was allegedly at home because she was sick.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Speak to your friend in private about what is really going on
B. Report your friend to her educational supervisor
C. Report your friend to her clinical supervisor
D. Start spreading rumours about your friend
E. Share your concerns with another friend who knows Stacey well

Correct Answer: A

A medical registrar is obtaining consent from a 39-year-old patient with longstanding ulcerative colitis who is listed for a surveillance colonoscopy that afternoon.
Regarding consent, which one of the following statements is correct?

A. You do not need to inform patients of a certain complication of a procedure if the risk of it occurring is less than 1%
B. A patient cannot sue for negligence following a complication of medical treatment, if he/she has signed a consent form
C. Therapeutic privilege can allow you to withhold information from a patient in certain, very specific situations
D. You need consent to perform an emergency appendicectomy on an 11-year-old child
E. A heavily inebriated patient refusing life-saving treatment cannot be overruled by the treating doctor

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old boy is found after being stabbed during a street fight. He has a stab wound on the left side of his chest to the fifth intercostal space, mid-clavicular line. His blood pressure (BP) reads 70 mmHg systolic; his heart sounds are muffled, and his jugular veins are distended, with a prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
Which of the following is best to describe the condition of the above?

A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
B. Beck’s triad
C. Virchow’s triad
D. Cushing syndrome
E. Kussmaul’s sign

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man was investigated for vague abdominal discomfort of 6 months’ duration. His clinical examination was negative for lymphadenopathy, abdominal masses or organomegaly. Bowel sounds were audible. A stool specimen tested for occult blood was negative. Abdominal computerised tomography (CT) showed a 20-cm retroperitoneal soft tissue mass obscuring the left psoas muscle.
Which of the following neoplasms is this man most likely to have?

A. Melanoma
B. Hamartoma
C. Adenocarcinoma
D. Lymphoma
E. Liposarcoma

Correct Answer: E

A 39-year-old African-Caribbean woman is referred to Gynaecology Outpatients with heavy periods. She has always had heavy periods, but for the last few years, things have been getting worse and she now has to change a pad every hour and sometimes has accidents with leaking and clots. The bleeding can last for 10 days and she often needs a day or two off work. There is mild abdominal cramping, but no bleeding after sex. She is feeling increasingly lethargic and miserable, particularly as she was hoping to have another baby. She has one child aged 6, which was a vaginal delivery. Her periods are regular and she is on no contraception. On examination, she is well, with a soft abdomen, and vaginal examination reveals a 10-week-size uterus. Blood tests show haemoglobin of 9 and the result of a pelvic ultrasound scan is pending.
Given the clinical information and likely ultrasound result, what is the best option for management?

A. Myomectomy
B. Tranexamic acid
C. Laparoscopic hysterectomy
D. Endometrial ablation
E. Mirena® intrauterine system

Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old woman who is well known to the community mental health team is brought into the psychiatric hospital by her worried friends. She has not been eating more than a few mouthfuls of food a day for the last two weeks and refuses to speak more than a few words. She remains awake all night and rocks in her chair. She even refuses to drink more than a cupful of water per day despite numerous attempts by her friends, doctors and psychiatrists. She is refusing all oral medications. After a brief conversation, you feel she has capacity to make decisions. You learn she has a long history of depression which has been very severe at times.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Emergency anti-depressants
B. Lithium
C. Cognitive behavioural therapy
D. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
E. NG tube insertion

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old woman, who was previously in good health, presents for review. For the past 2–3 months, she has suffered from increasing pain and stiffness, particularly in the early part of the day, affecting her shoulders and, most recently, her hips. There has also been low-grade fever and she has lost 4 kg in weight. Examination reveals normal proximal muscle strength.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 111 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 96 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 345 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 75 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Creatine kinase 31 IU/l 23–175 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 45 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Chest X-ray (CXR) Slight cardiomegaly, otherwise normal
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Temporal arteritis
B. Polymyositis
C. Dermatomyositis
D. Polymyalgia rheumatic (PMR)
E. Rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-week history of productive cough with green sputum and a one day history of palpitations. She also had some rigors and fever. On examination:
Result Normal
Respiratory rate (RR) 26 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Sats 96% on air 94–98%
Blood pressure (BP) 92/48 mmHg <120/80 mmHg
Heart rate (HR) 130 bpm 60–100 beats/min
Some bronchial breathing at left lung base, heart sounds normal however with an irregularly irregular pulse. electrocardiogram (ECG) showed fast atrial fibrillation (AF). She was previously fit and well.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Digoxin
B. Bisoprolol
C. Oral antibiotics
D. Intravenous fluids
E. Flecainide

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner as he would like to be signed off from work over the winter period. He has a history of cystic fibrosis and is worried about being at increased risk of secondary bacterial infections in the colder months. He is particularly concerned as he has to take overcrowded public transport to work and back every day. He works for a publishing company, and although he may not be able to go into the office every day, he agrees that he may be able to work from home.
Which of the following recommendations may be the most appropriate when filling in this man’s ‘fit note’?

A. Altered hours of working
B. Amended duties
C. Not fit for work
D. Phased return to work
E. Workplace adjustments

Correct Answer: E

A 39-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner complaining of weight gain and abnormal menstrual cycles. She reports feeling depressed and weak. There are multiple purplish striae on her abdomen and bruises over her lower extremities. Laboratory testing reveals normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroid hormone levels, and elevated cortisol secretion.
If the patient has adrenal hyperfunction, which of the following may also be present?

A. Enhanced glucose uptake
B. Hirsutism
C. Hypoglycaemia
D. Hypotension
E. Hypocalciuria

Correct Answer: B

A 22-year-old woman slipped and fell on her left hand. She sustained injury to her left anatomical snuffbox. An injury involving the anatomical snuffbox is more likely to damage the:

A. Radial nerve
B. Median nerve
C. Radial artery
D. Ulnar nerve
E. Ulnar artery

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old woman presents with a 5-week history of bloody diarrhoea and abdominal pain. On further questioning, she reveals she has had unintentional weight loss over this period also. She undergoes a colonoscopy which shows abnormal, inflamed mucosa in the rectum and sigmoid and descending colon. Multiple biopsies are taken, and a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is suspected.
Which of the following findings is most suggestive of ulcerative colitis?

A. Crypt abscesses
B. Skip lesions
C. Transmural involvement
D. Non-caseating granulomata
E. Stricturing of bowel wall

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old man with known alcohol dependence attends the Emergency Department with a several-week history of productive cough, weight loss, fever and haemoptysis. He smokes 30 cigarettes per day.
A chest X-ray shows multiple nodules 1–3 mm in size throughout both lung fields and is shown.
Originally created by James Heilman, M.D., CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
Which of the following options is most likely to treat the underlying cause of this man’s symptoms most effectively?

A. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Systemic chemotherapy
C. Anti-tuberculous (TB) chemotherapy
D. Tranexamic acid
E. Aciclovir

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old primiparous woman has been referred at 35+5 weeks’ gestation to the Antenatal Assessment Unit by her community midwife because of a raised blood pressure. On arrival, her blood pressure is 162/114 mmHg despite two doses of oral labetalol and her heart rate is 121 bpm. Examination reveals non-specific abdominal tenderness predominantly in the right upper quadrant; the uterus is soft and fetal movements are palpated. Urine dipstick reveals 3+ protein only. The cardiotocograph is normal.
Initial blood tests are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 95 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.8 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 32 × 109/l 150–450 × 109/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 140 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 129 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 28 μmol/l 2–17 μmol/l
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 253 IU/l 100–190 IU/l
Which of the following is the most definitive treatment in this patient?

A. Immediate delivery of the fetus to improve blood pressure
B. Intramuscular betamethasone
C. Intravenous hydralazine
D. Intravenous infusion of labetalol
E. Intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) for a check-up. He feels healthy today but has a history of chronic lung and respiratory tract infections. He is an immunocompetent patient.
On examination, he is afebrile and normotensive. His heart rate is regular and his respirations are unlaboured. The GP notices a diastolic murmur, with a snap loudest at the right fifth intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Congestive heart failure
B. Asthma
C. Squamous cell lung cancer
D. Idiopathic pulmonary hypertension
E. Primary cilia dyskinesia

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with left eye pain for the third time. This is associated with blurred vision on each occasion and a feeling that there is something stuck in her eye. She usually wears contact lenses and admits to accidentally scratching her eye several times.
Investigations:
Slit lamp examination: epithelial defect with surrounding corneal oedema
Fluorescein examination: area of increased uptake
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Corneal ulcer
B. Traumatic corneal abrasion
C. Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy
D. Keratitis sicca
E. Bacterial conjunctivitis

Correct Answer: A

An obstetrician administered anaesthesia to a 30-year-old pregnant woman in labour. The doctor palpated the ischial spine transvaginally and then injected a local anaesthetic.
Injection of a local anaesthetic at this location anaesthetises a nerve that contains fibres from which of the following vertebral segments?

A. S1, S2, S3
B. S2, S3, S4
C. S3, S4, S5
D. L4, L5, S1
E. L5, S1, S2

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old builder is admitted to the Emergency Department, having received a blow to the back of the neck by a bucket from a JCB.
On examination, his neck is held in spasm and he is complaining of severe pain. There is no demonstrable distal neurology.
An X-ray of the cervical spine reveals a stable fracture of the spinous process of C6.
Which of the following is the management of choice for this patient?

A. Traction with cervical tongs
B. Surgical fixation of fracture
C. Immobilisation in a hard neck collar
D. Application of a halo brace
E. Immobilisation in a soft neck collar

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient clinic with complaints of involuntary muscle movements of her tongue, fingers and trunk for the past 2 months. She was diagnosed with schizophrenia 5 years ago and has been on flupenthixol and then haloperidol, with good compliance. On examination, her temperature is 37.7 °C, blood pressure 115/80 mmHg and pulse 92 bpm. Her respiratory rate is 14 cycles/min. There is pronounced choreoathetoid movement of the hand and fingers.
What is the next line of management of this patient?

A. Give anticholinergics
B. Stop the haloperidol and start olanzapine
C. Supportive therapy
D. Stop the haloperidol and start chlorpromazine
E. Decrease the dose of haloperidol

Correct Answer: B

An 86-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) complaining of an increased frequency of urination for the past month. The patient has found this very distressing and also complains of having to strain to pass urine recently. He denies any haematuria and has not lost any weight recently. The patient also suffers from chronic obstructive respiratory disease (COPD) and ischaemic heart disease. He takes ramipril for his hypertension and a budesonide and formoterol combination inhaler for his COPD.
The GP performs a digital rectal examination which reveals a prostate which is not enlarged and smooth. Blood tests are unremarkable, and the patient’s random capillary blood glucose is 5.8 mmol/l. A prostate specific antigen (PSA) is also requested which comes back as 4.4 ng/ml.
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

A. Brachytherapy
B. Chemotherapy
C. Offer the patient a long-term catheter
D. Transurethral resection of the prostate
E. Watchful waiting with symptom relief

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance after his partner reported he ingested multiple tablets of paracetamol after an argument. The patient is currently medically stable and can give a history to the attending emergency physician. He reports that he regrets taking the tablets and that this is the first time he has committed such an act. He claims that he acted in a moment of anger after the argument and never planned for this to happen. He suffers from moderate depression which has been managed by his general practitioner with sertraline. He consumes a moderate amount of alcohol and denies any abuse of recreational drugs. He has no family history of mental illness.
Which one of the following is an important dynamic risk factor to consider when managing this patient?

A. Gender
B. History of alcohol misuse
C. History of drug abuse
D. History of self-harm
E. Self-harm plans

Correct Answer: E

A man has some blood tests taken by his general practitioner (GP). The results show a Hb of 10.0, MCV of 69 and a ferritin of 9.
Which is the most appropriate management plan for this patient according to the guidance of the British National Formulary (BNF)?

A. Treat with 5 mg folic acid and repeat bloods in eight weeks
B. Treat with ferrous sulphate 200 mg once a day and repeat bloods in three months
C. Treat with ferrous sulphate 200 mg once a day plus folic acid and repeat bloods in three months
D. Treat with ferrous sulphate 200 mg three times a day and repeat bloods in three months
E. Treat with ferrous sulphate 200 mg twice a day plus folic acid and repeat bloods in three months

Correct Answer: D

A 42-year-old patient presents with excessive thirst and abdominal pain.
Bloods show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Calcium (Ca2+) 3.02 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate (PO43–) 0.42 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 324 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Looking at these blood results, which of the following is the most likely cause?

A. Excessive vitamin D
B. Renal failure
C. Primary hyperparathyroidism
D. Bone metastases
E. Hypoparathyroidism

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man with known squamous-cell lung cancer presents with facial swelling, shortness of breath and a headache. On examination, he has a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) and inspiratory stridor when he raises his hands above his head for one minute. Chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest confirm superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction.
Which of the following treatments will provide the best long-term symptom relief?

A. Inhaled daily steroid
B. Inhaled beta-agonist
C. Dexamethasone infusion
D. Superior vena cava (SVC) stenting
E. Brachytherapy

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old teacher has a long history of menorrhagia. She has been investigated previously by the Gynaecology team, and no pathological cause was found. She would now like a longer-term solution and has heard that some types of contraception may help manage her symptoms.
She has had no previous pregnancies and is currently in a stable relationship but does not plan to start a family.
