Her only other medical history to note is that she has the occasional migraine, during which she loses vision in the left eye.
Which of the following methods would be the most appropriate method of contraception in this patient?

A. The levonorgestrel intrauterine system (IUS)
B. The copper intrauterine device
C. Hysterectomy
D. The combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
E. Barrier methods such as the condom

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman presents to the general practitioner (GP) with a painful, red left breast for the past two days. Since the birth of her first daughter six weeks ago, she has been exclusively breastfeeding. The patient has also experienced fever and chills over the last 24 hours. She does not have any other medical problems.
Physical examination reveals a warm, erythematous and tender left breast with no signs of masses or purulent discharge. There is a small fissure present. Her observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.8 °C
Blood pressure 126/59 mmHg
Heart rate 67 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 15 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Advise patient to cease breastfeeding
B. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories
C. Oral antibiotics and cease breastfeeding
D. Oral antibiotics and continue breastfeeding
E. Referral for incision and drainage

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman with known asthma presents to the Emergency Department with severe breathlessness and wheeze.
Which of the following is the most worrying finding on examination and initial investigations?

A. Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) 35% predicted
B. Respiratory rate 30 breaths per minute
C. PaCO2 5.5 kPa
D. Heart rate 140 bpm
E. Inability to complete sentences in one breath

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe back pain, ongoing for 2 weeks.
Which of the following features should prompt urgent radiological imaging?

A. Positive straight leg raising test
B. Sacral pain
C. Thoracic pain
D. Unilateral leg pain and paraesthesiae
E. Unilateral leg pain worse than low back pain

Correct Answer: C

You are a junior doctor working in general practice. Mrs Rogers, who is one of the receptionists, has recently had some blood tests performed in hospital. She is anxious to find out the results. Mrs Rogers calls in to your office one lunch-time and politely asks if you would mind looking up the results so that she does not have to bother her consultant.
Select the most appropriate action to take in this case:

A. Look up the results and write them down for your colleague
B. Agree to look at the results but only advise your colleague whether you think further action is required before she sees her consultant, rather than telling her the results
C. Decline your colleague’s request to look up the results and explain that only her own consultant or general practitioner has a legitimate reason to look up the test results
D. Decline to look up the results and make a formal complaint to the practice manager regarding your colleague’s request, which has put you in a difficult position
E. Look up the results, write them down and spend some time with your colleague explaining what the results mean

Correct Answer: C

You are the Foundation Year 2 doctor on a general practice (GP) attachment when a 60-year-old man presents, complaining of malaise, cough and breathlessness. He says these symptoms have been present for 2 days, and he has brought up some yellow-coloured sputum on a few occasions. He reports no pain and no palpitations and is coping at home, although he has taken 2 days off work. He has no long-standing conditions but smokes five cigarettes a day and has done so for the last 10 years. He has no known allergies. On examination, he is alert and orientated, and has a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 126/84 mmHg and a temperature of 38.1 °C. There is bronchial breathing and crepitations on auscultation, particularly on the right-hand side of the chest, and heart sounds are normal.
What would be the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Admission to hospital
B. Safety-netting advice only
C. 5-day course of amoxicillin
D. 5-day course of flucloxacillin
E. Salbutamol inhaler

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old sexually active, single man presents with a painful ulcer on the glans of the penis. He also complains of bilateral groin pain and swelling. Examination reveals a tender ulcer with well-defined, undermined borders that bleeds easily on examination. Bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is also found on examination; a small sinus is seen superficial to one of the lymph nodes and pus is easily expressed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Syphilis
B. HIV
C. Chlamydia
D. Chancroid
E. Gonorrhoea

Correct Answer: D

An 18-month-old baby girl has been brought into the general practice by her mother with the presenting complaint of a new rash around the lips, gumline and tongue. The mother reports that the rash is new, approximately three days old, and has become significantly worse. She finds that her daughter is not eating or drinking and is very difficult to settle. The mother comments that she had a normal delivery, with no post-delivery complications, and the daughter has been up-to-date with her vaccination protocol. Moreover, you assess that the baby has normal growth and development. There is no family history of oral lesions.
On general examination, the baby is visibly upset, although interacting appropriately with her mother. Temperature is recorded as 38.1 °C. Heart rate is 110 bpm, blood pressure 84/60 mmHg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 100% on air. On inspection of the oral cavity, multiple vesicular lesions are present on the lips, gum and anterior aspect of the tongue. You notice a small number of these have become ulcerated. There are no further rashes observed on the trunk and upper and lower limbs.
What is the most likely organism which has given rise to this clinical picture?

A. Parvovirus B19
B. Coxsackie A16
C. Herpes simplex virus
D. Molluscum contagiosum
E. Varicella-zoster

Correct Answer: C

A 5-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of an itchy rash, initially on his abdomen and now spreading across the rest of his torso and limbs. He is usually fit and well and is on no other medications, and the rest of his family is well. There is a widespread vesicular rash with some papules and crusting, as well as newer papules. His temperature is 37.5 °C and his other observations are within normal limits.
What is the next best step in management?

A. Zoster immunoglobulin
B. Ibuprofen
C. Paracetamol
D. Oral aciclovir
E. Intravenous flucloxacillin and aciclovir

Correct Answer: C

The following results were obtained from a 43-year-old female:
Serum:
Na+ 154 mmol/l (135–145 mmol/l)
K+ 3.7 mmol/l (3.5–5 mmol/l)
Aldosterone: elevated
Renin: low
With which of the following are these results consistent?

A. Conn’s syndrome
B. Addison’s disease
C. Renal artery stenosis
D. Bartter syndrome
E. Furosemide treatment

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old woman attends her general practitioner (GP) regarding contraception advice. She is keen to begin taking the progesterone-only pill as her method of contraception. The GP talks her through the benefits and risks associated with this contraceptive method, one of which is an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy if they were to become accidentally pregnant while on this method.
Which of the following is also a recognised risk factor for ectopic pregnancy?

A. Subserosal fibroids
B. Use of intrauterine device
C. Combined oral contraceptive pill
D. Corpus luteal cyst
E. Previous miscarriage

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man has been called in to see his General Practitioner (GP) due to abnormal renal function tests over the last two months.
His glomerular filtration rate (GFR) reading has been consistently 35 ml/min.
What stage of chronic kidney disease (CKD) is this patient presenting with?

A. Stage 1
B. Stage 3a
C. Stage 3b
D. Stage 4a
E. This patient does not meet the criteria for CKD

Correct Answer: E

A young man presents with persecutory delusions and auditory hallucinations. His expression appears to have a reduced affect. He has disorganised speech and thinking.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Frontotemporal dementia
B. Agoraphobia
C. Early-onset dementia
D. Endogenous depression
E. Schizophrenia

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman went to see her general practitioner (GP) as she had been experiencing low mood, weight gain and irregular menses. The GP decided to carry out some investigations, referring to the hospital:
Sodium 150 mmol/l (135–145 mmol/l)
Potassium 2.5 mmol/l (3.5–5 mmol/l)
Blood glucose (fasting) 7.7 mmol/l (5–7.2 mmol/l)
24-hour urinary cortisol excretion 840 nmol/24 hours (<300 nmol/24 hours)
Plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH): undetectable
Dexamethasone suppression test:
0800 h serum cortisol after dexamethasone 0.5 mg/6 hours orally (po) for 2 days:
880 nmol/l (<50 nmol/l)
0800 h serum cortisol after dexamethasone 2 mg/6 hours po for 2 days:
875 nmol/l (<50 nmol/l)
What is the most likely clinical diagnosis?

A. Cushing’s disease
B. Conn’s syndrome
C. Acromegaly
D. Paraneoplastic syndrome secondary to small cell carcinoma of the lung
E. Adrenocortical tumour

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old woman originally from Japan with hypertension presented to the Emergency Department with several days of fevers, arthralgia and hyperhidrosis. On examination, it was impossible to measure her blood pressure using a brachial sphygmomanometer. She had impalpable pulses in her upper limbs; femoral and pedal pulses were normal.
What is the most likely cause of her presentation?

A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
B. Infective endocarditis
C. Kawasaki’s disease
D. Mycotic aortic aneurysm
E. Takayasu’s arteritis

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old woman with type II diabetes mellitus presents to the Emergency Department. She was found to be confused at home by her daughter. According to her daughter, the patient is independent and able to take care of herself. On examination she has a temperature of 38.1 °C. Her blood pressure is 136/74 mmHg, and her heart rate is 110 bpm. She is disorientated and not able to provide any history. Physical examination is unremarkable except for tenderness elicited at the right lower back.
Urine dipstick results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Colour Turbid Clear
pH 6.7 7.35–7.45
Glucose 2+ Negative
Bilirubin Negative Negative
Ketone 1+ Negative
Nitrite 2+ Negative
Leukocytes 3+ Negative
Blood 1+ Negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cystitis
B. Renal stones
C. Acute pyelonephritis
D. Acute appendicitis
E. Prolapsed intervertebral disc

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old hospitalised man with a urinary tract infection and an indwelling bladder catheter (due to a bladder outlet obstruction) has developed episodic fever, chills and a fall in systemic blood pressure since yesterday. The episodes occur irregularly and last almost an hour, during which time he becomes delirious.
Which of the following factors plays a key role in the pathogenesis of this condition?

A. Tumour necrosis factor
B. Interleukins
C. Lactic acid
D. Nitric oxide
E. Lipopolysaccharide

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old man visits his General Practitioner (GP) for an annual mental health review. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia five years ago. He has been on medication since diagnosis and takes this daily without any side-effects. He has regular contact with the community mental health team. He is working part-time as a shop assistant, which he enjoys. He has a good appetite, sleeps well and exercises regularly.
Which of the following is true regarding the treatment of schizophrenia?

A. All patients with schizophrenia must remain solely under the care of a psychiatrist lifelong
B. All patients with schizophrenia require an electrocardiogram (ECG) before starting antipsychotic medication
C. Olanzapine is always used as first-line treatment for schizophrenia
D. People with a first episode of psychosis can be managed adequately in primary care by the GP alone
E. People with a first episode of psychosis should be offered oral antipsychotic treatment, along with psychological interventions

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with her partner. She wants to start trying for a baby and is asking for advice regarding nutritional supplementation. She is not currently on any contraception, and her diabetes is well controlled, with her most recent HbA1c being 32 mmol/mol (recommended by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists < 48 mmol/mol).
Which of the following is the most appropriate advice regarding folic acid supplementation?

A. Commence folic acid 400 micrograms daily now and continue throughout pregnancy
B. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily now and continue throughout pregnancy
C. Commence folid acid 400 micrograms daily now and continue until week 12 of gestation
D. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily now and continue until week 12 of gestation
E. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily now and discontinue once pregnant

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman presents complaining of ‘flashbacks’. Seven months earlier, she had been standing at a bus stop when a car swerved off the road into the queue, killing instantly a child standing near to her. Every day she experiences intrusive images of the child’s face as it saw the car mount the curb. She has not been able to go to that part of town since the day and she has avoided taking the bus anywhere. She feels she is always on edge and jumps at the slightest noise around the house. She thinks things are getting worse, rather than better, and asks you whether there are any psychological treatments that might help her.
Which one of the following approaches is indicated?

A. Psychodynamic therapy
B. Trauma-focused cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
C. Supportive therapy
D. Hypnotherapy
E. Watchful waiting

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old paediatric nurse complains of tiredness, generalised joint discomfort and a facial rash. She has recently returned from Portugal and states that the rash is worse.
On examination: no active small joint synovitis; prominent erythematous facial rash.
Blood tests reveal: haemoglobin 103 g/l, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 88.8 fl, platelets 99 × 109/l, white cell count (WCC) 2.8 × 109/l.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate at this stage?

A. Methotrexate
B. Sun avoidance
C. Infliximab
D. Hydroxychloroquine
E. Azathioprine

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old known alcoholic is brought by ambulance after being found unconscious on the road on a Sunday afternoon. He has a superficial laceration in the right frontal region. He is admitted for observation over the bank holiday weekend. The admission chest X-ray is normal. Before discharge on Tuesday morning, he is noted to be febrile and dyspnoeic. Blood tests reveal a neutrophilia and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). A chest X-ray demonstrates consolidation in the lower zone of the right lung.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
B. Tuberculosis (TB)
C. Aspiration pneumonia
D. Staphylococcal pneumonia
E. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia

Correct Answer: C

A 33-year-old mother had a natural birth at home. Seven days later, she brought her newborn to the Emergency Department, complaining of a musty odour of the skin and urine. Examination reveals hypopigmentation and eczema. Genetic testing revealed an autosomal recessive genetic disorder.
Which of the following is most likely linked to the condition of the newborn?

A. Defect in the transporter for cysteine
B. Decreased α-ketoacid dehydrogenase
C. Defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase
D. Deficiency in homogentisic acid oxidase
E. Defect in tyrosinase

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old male patient is referred to the renal physicians after several episodes of frank haematuria. He does not recall any abdominal or loin pain. He had an upper respiratory tract infection a few days ago. Urine dipstick shows blood, and blood tests are normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
B. Minimal change disease
C. Sexual transmitted infection
D. Bladder cancer
E. IgA nephropathy

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with pyrexia of 40 °C, vomiting and diarrhoea, and is very agitated. He has hyperthyroidism but is known to be non-compliant with his medication. The ED registrar suspects that he is having a thyroid storm.
Which of the following regarding a thyrotoxic crisis (thyroid storm) is most likely to be correct?

A. Women are more commonly affected than men
B. Myocardial infarction is not a precipitant of a thyroid storm
C. Active warming helps to prevent associated hypothermia
D. Fluid resuscitation, propranolol and carbimazole are used in the management of a thyroid storm
E. Levothyroxine is given to prevent peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department (ED) with fever and a painful lump felt around the anus. On examination, there is a 4 cm peri-anal swelling, with surrounding erythema. It is very tender and fluctuant.
What is the best treatment option?

A. Amoxicillin and metronidazole
B. Flucloxacillin
C. Incision and drainage
D. Biopsy first
E. Paracetamol and a review in the clinic in 1 week

Correct Answer: C

A 67-year-old retired caretaker with a well-documented history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted, for his fourth time this year, with shortness of breath and a cough productive of green sputum. Examination findings are: respiratory rate (RR) 32 breaths/min, temperature 37.4 °C, SpO2 86% on room air, asterixis and coarse crepitations at the left base. A chest X-ray (CXR) confirms left basal consolidation.
Which arterial blood gas (ABG) picture is likely to belong to the above patient?

A. pH: 7.27, pa (O2): 7.1, pa (CO2): 8.9, HCO3–: 33.20, base excess (BE) 4.9 mmol
B. pH: 7.28, pa (O2): 10.4, pa (CO2): 6.4, HCO3–: 17.95, BE –5.8 mmol
C. pH: 7.35, pa (O2): 9.0, pa (CO2): 3.8, HCO3–: 21.90, BE +1.4 mmol
D. pH: 7.47, pa (O2): 9.6, pa (CO2): 3.5, HCO3–: 27.40, BE +3.0 mmol
E. pH: 7.33, pa (O2): 12.8, pa (CO2): 5.4, HCO3–: 21.80, BE –4.0 mmol

Correct Answer: A

A 63-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of pain in her wrist as well as her fingers. The pain is more pronounced on the right than left and has been around for the past year. She also complains of stiffness in her wrist and fingers in the morning but which resolves throughout the day. She denies pain in any of her other joints and there are no other associated symptoms. The patient has been taking over-the-counter painkillers including ibuprofen and paracetamol which relieve the pain to some extent, but she feels she cannot tolerate the pain anymore. She has no significant family history or past medical history. The GP requests for an X-ray hands and wrists.
Which of the following radiological findings would you expect in this patient?

A. Localised joint space narrowing
B. Subchondral cysts
C. Osteophytes
D. Subchondral sclerosis
E. Peri-articular osteopenia

Correct Answer: E

During a histopathology tutorial, medical students are asked to examine images of tissues samples taken from various systems.
What is the chief secretory product of the tissue sample shown in the image?

A. Catecholamine
B. Thyroxine
C. Mineralocorticoid
D. Glucocorticoid
E. Follicle-stimulating hormone

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man presents to the Acute Medical Unit complaining of mucus and bloody diarrhoea. He has had milder episodes intermittently in the past three years but never sought medical attention. He complains of left lower abdominal pain. He also occasionally suffers from right hip pain. On examination, the patient is tender in the lower left abdominal region which does not radiate. The patient has never travelled outside the UK and has not come into contact with anyone with similar symptoms. There is no significant family history of note.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute diverticulitis
B. Crohn's disease
C. Irritable bowel syndrome
D. Ulcerative colitis
E. Colon carcinoma

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) after being found unconscious in his apartment by his girlfriend. The patient had called his girlfriend to tell her that he had taken a large number of various tablets but that he now regretted doing so. It is not known what tablets the patient has ingested.
Which one of the following drugs that is toxic in overdose is correctly paired with its antidote?

A. Benzodiazepines and naloxone
B. Paracetamol and bicarbonate
C. Ethylene glycol and fomepizole
D. Digoxin and calcium
E. Beta-blockers and adrenaline

Correct Answer: C

A 61-year-old post-menopausal woman with a history of chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents with mild vaginal bleeding. Bimanual pelvic examination reveals a relatively large mass on the right side of the pelvis. The patient undergoes an abdominal and pelvic computed tomography scan with contrast injection. The scan shows multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the pelvis, along the iliac arteries. The para-aortic lymph nodes appear normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ovarian cancer
B. Vulval cancer
C. Cervical adenocarcinoma
D. Cervical squamous cell carcinoma
E. Uterine leiomyosarcoma

Correct Answer: D

Antibody transfer from a mother to infant during breastfeeding is most likely an example of which of the following types of immunity?

A. Naturally acquired; active
B. Artificially acquired; active
C. Naturally acquired; passive
D. Artificially acquired; passive
E. None of these

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old carpet layer presented with acute pain and swelling affecting his left knee. There is no history of trauma. Past medical history includes haemochromatosis for which he receives regular venesection.
Examination reveals a hot, tender, swollen left knee.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 135 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.0 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 200 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 12 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Knee aspirate: 12 000 white blood cells/ml (majority neutrophils); rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent crystals. No growth on culture.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Gout
B. Pre–patellar bursitis
C. Septic arthritis
D. Pseudogout
E. Osteoarthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 76-year-old man with advanced prostate cancer is referred by his GP to hospital as today’s blood test shows an elevated calcium level.
Which of the following is the next most appropriate action?

A. Insulin dextrose
B. IV 0.9% normal saline
C. Alendronic acid
D. Calcium Resonium
E. Calcium gluconate

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old woman presents with abrupt onset of abdominal pain since 6 hours previously. The pain is rapidly progressive and is more severe in the right upper quadrant. Her past medical history is unremarkable. She denies any recent illness or similar episodes previously. She is sexually active and takes an oral contraceptive pill. On examination, her blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg, pulse rate 80 bpm, respiratory rate 15/min and body temperature 37.4 ºC. The sclera is icteric. Tender hepatomegaly and shifting abdominal dullness are noted. Blood tests reveal elevated total and direct bilirubin, alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase. Partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time are within normal limits. Mild to moderate abdominal ascites is found on an ultrasound study.
What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A. Ruptured hepatic adenoma
B. Occlusion of the portal vein
C. Occlusion of the hepatic vein
D. Fulminant viral hepatitis
E. Drug-induced hepatic necrosis

Correct Answer: C

A 59-year-old obese man presents to his general practitioner with complaints of numbness, weakness and pain in the lower leg that occurs after he walks a short distance; however, the pain is relieved with rest. Examination shows non-healing ulcers on the feet. He has no other complaints. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, his pulse 83 bpm and his respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. After further questioning, he admits to smoking two packs of cigarettes per day.
Which of the following types of vessels is most likely involved in the pathologic process surrounding this patient’s symptoms?

A. Arteries
B. Arterioles
C. Capillaries
D. Veins
E. Venules

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with worsening right foot drop over two months. He also states that he has begun to drop objects that he was previously able to lift with ease and feels that both of his hands are constantly shaking. He does not have any other medical conditions. He recalls that his brother and father passed away from a neurological disease, of which he does know the name.
Examination reveals bilateral lower limb weakness. There is hyperreflexia on examination of the knees and ankles. Plantars are upgoing. Examination of the upper limb is pertinent for left arm weakness, in particular in the median and ulnar nerve-innervated hand muscles. Sensation is normal in both upper and lower limbs. A diagnosis of motor neurone disease (MND) (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) is being considered.
Which of the following medications is most likely to improve the life expectancy of this patient?

A. Baclofen
B. Carbocisteine
C. Citalopram
D. Memantine
E. Riluzole

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia. She has a history of iron-deficiency anaemia. On examination, you note she has an erythaematous smooth tongue.
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on endoscopy?

A. Inflammation
B. Oesophageal webs
C. Dysplasia
D. No changes
E. Ulceration

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old woman is reviewed in the Gastroenterology Clinic. She presents with diarrhoea, weight loss and an intensely itchy rash affecting her buttocks and the tops of both legs.
An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy reveals villous atrophy.
Which of the following is the most important intervention to manage her underlying condition?

A. Gluten-free diet
B. Lactose-free diet
C. Oral cyclophosphamide
D. Oral mesalamine
E. Oral prednisolone

Correct Answer: A

A patient attends the Emergency Department after being involved in a pub brawl. During the incident he was stabbed in the arm. Fortunately, the knife wound is superficial. He states that he does not want you to talk to the police about the incident and does not know the assailant.
Select the most appropriate action to take in this case:

A. Report the incident to the police but do not pass on the patient’s name or address without the patient’s consent
B. Report the incident to the police, including the patient’s name and address
C. Try to persuade the patient to speak to the police himself but do not report the incident without his consent
D. Do not report the incident to the police as doing so would be a breach of patient confidentiality
E. At a later date, advise the police that a knife crime has been committed to assist them with collation of crime statistics but do not provide any patient information

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman complained of a 3-day history of gradual loss of vision in her right eye, describing the sensation of a 'curtain' coming from the right inferotemporal side towards the centre. She also describes seeing flashes of lights at the right inferotemporal side, and an increase in the number of floaters in her right eye.
On examination, her vision is 6/18 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Inferonasal retinal detachment
B. Inferior retinal detachment
C. Inferotemporal retinal detachment
D. Superonasal retinal detachment
E. Superotemporal retinal detachment

Correct Answer: D

The results of a phase 3 study on a new anti-hypertensive is published (n = 16 000). Compared with placebo, there is a mean reduction of 6 mmHg in favour of the treatment group when added to medication in patients who have failed to achieve blood pressure control on an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi). The 95% confidence interval for the difference in blood pressure lies between 1.9 mmHg and 10.1 mmHg.
Which of the following is most accurate regarding this medication?

A. It is likely to offer superior reduction in blood pressure, compared with other agents
B. The difference in blood pressure is not clinically significant
C. The difference in blood pressure is statistically significant at the 5% significance level
D. Over time, this difference in blood pressure will not result in improved outcomes
E. This medication should not be licensed

Correct Answer: C

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with periorbital pain with associated ascites and oedema. He has no previous medical history to note and is usually fit and well, with no recent episodes of ill health.
Tests reveal that serum urea is increased and protein in urine is +++.
What is the most likely cause?

A. Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis
B. Minimal change glomerulonephritis
C. Membranous glomerulonephritis
D. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis
E. IgA nephropathy glomerulonephritis

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of abdominal bloating, early satiety, pelvic pain and frequency of urination. Blood results revealed CA-125 of 50 u/ml (<36 u/ml).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ovarian cancer
B. Irritable bowel syndrome
C. Colorectal cancer
D. Genitourinary prolapse
E. Diverticulosis

Correct Answer: A

A 63-year-old man was admitted to hospital for a work-up of a suspected cholangiocarcinoma. He underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). After this, he complains of chills, nausea, vomiting and upper-right abdominal pain. He has also spiked a fever of 38.9 °C.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Disseminated intravascular coagulation
B. Fatty-liver disease
C. Hepatitis
D. Liver abscess
E. Liver metastases

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman, who is a nursing home resident, presents to the Emergency Department, complaining of a one-week history of a red swollen calf, nausea and ‘ants on her arm’. She is noted to be unsteady on her feet and cannot remember what medications she is on. Observations find her temperature is 38.6 °C, oxygen saturation 98%, blood pressure 90/60 mmHg, heart rate 90 bpm and respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute.
What is the most likely cause of her hypotension?

A. Hypovolaemia
B. Myocardial infarction
C. Pulmonary embolus
D. Sepsis
E. Anaphylaxis

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man has a right inguinal mass. On examination, the left testis is palpated in the scrotum and is of normal size, but the right testis cannot be palpated in the scrotum. An ultrasound scan shows that the inguinal mass is consistent with a cryptorchid testis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option to deal with this patient’s testicular abnormality?

A. Put it into the scrotum surgically (orchidopexy)
B. Remove it (orchidectomy)
C. Remove it along with the opposite testis (bilateral orchidectomy)
D. Start the patient on testosterone
E. Perform a chromosome analysis

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old man is recently returned from holiday in Kenya. One week since returning he has developed a productive cough, with blood-stained sputum, and has had a fever and general malaise.
A sputum sample confirms the diagnosis of tuberculosis. He is started on the initial phase of treatment with isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide and ethambutol. After two months, he begins the continuation phase of treatment for another four months.
Which drugs make up the continuation phase?

A. Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol
B. Rifampicin alone
C. Rifampicin + Ethambutol
D. Rifampicin + Isoniazid
E. Rifampicin + Pyrazinamide

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with anorexia, fatigue, nausea and generalised pain. He has a medical history notable for palliate prostate cancer for which he has refused treatment, and remains independent. Routine blood results confirm your suspicions:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 91 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 125 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 3.2 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
You commence treatment with intravenous fluid and the recommended intravenous drug infusion.
In which way will this medication principally correct the biochemical abnormality?

A. Bind calcium in the bloodstream to enhance excretion
B. Decrease gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
C. Decrease renal reabsorption of calcium
D. Increase renal secretion of calcium
E. Inhibit the release of calcium from bones

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old high-school student wishes to have a seborrheic wart removed from her right upper arm as it frequently catches on clothes and she finds it unsightly.
Regarding consent in minors in England and Wales, which one of the following statements is correct?

A. A 16-year-old is unable to give consent for treatment
B. A doctor must not discuss consent to treatment by a competent 16-year-old with the parents of the patient in question without the express permission of the patient
C. The father of a patient must be married to the mother at the time of birth of the patient (minor) in question to give consent regarding treatment
D. Children with learning difficulties are not Gillick competent
E. Gillick competent 16-year-olds cannot have their decisions regarding medical treatment overruled by the legal courts

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old man complains of numbness in his feet and is finding it difficult to walk. On examination, he has normal pain and temperature sensation in his lower limbs, but decreased appreciation of light touch and proprioception.
Which one of the following is the most likely site of a neurological lesion?

A. Spinocerebellar tracts
B. Dorsal column
C. Dorsal horn
D. Lateral spinothalamic tracts
E. Lateral corticospinal tracts

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) complaining of painful, swollen lymph nodes around his groin. He had recently visited friends in the Caribbean and tells you that he had unprotected sex with two local women. A couple of weeks before the painful lymph nodes began, he noticed a small, painless ulcer on his penis.
On examination, he has a number of very large, painful, inguinal lymph nodes.
A lymph node biopsy shows stellate lymph node abscess.
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive for Chlamydia.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Granuloma inguinale
B. Uncomplicated Chlamydia infection
C. Lymphogranuloma venereum
D. Genital herpes with secondary Chlamydia infection
E. Mycobacterial infection

Correct Answer: C

A 57-year-old woman, who has recently started radiotherapy treatment for breast cancer, presents with redness and peeling of the skin over the left breast.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 36.4 °C. Her pulse is 80 bpm, and her blood pressure is 110/78 mmHg. Examination of the left breast reveals a sharply demarcated 7 cm × 5 cm area of faint erythema and mild patchy desquamation of the skin of the right upper quadrant.
The right breast appears normal, and the patient has no other skin changes affecting the rest of the body.
Which of the following statements regarding this patient is correct?

A. The skin changes are unlikely to be connected to her current treatment
B. Radiation therapy must be discontinued to avoid further damage to the skin
C. The patient should be reassured that any skin changes are always temporary
D. Radiation therapy is usually side-effect-free
E. Topical therapy and supportive measures to address skin changes

Correct Answer: E

A 43-year-old man presented with a 4-week history of intermittent burning epigastric pain associated with vomiting. His father has recently been treated for gastric cancer.
Gastric biopsies taken on upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy were positive for Helicobacter pylori. The patient is penicillin allergic.
What would be the most appropriate first-line treatment for eradication of H. pylori in this patient?

A. Omeprazole 20 mg twice daily, amoxicillin 1 g twice daily, clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily for one week
B. Lansoprazole 30 mg twice daily, metronidazole 400 mg once daily, clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily for one week
C. Lansoprazole 30 mg twice daily, metronidazole 400 mg twice daily, levofloxacin 250 mg twice daily for one week
D. Omeprazole 20 mg twice daily, clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily and metronidazole 400 mg twice daily for one week
E. Omeprazole 20 mg twice daily, bismuth subcitrate 120 mg four times daily, tetracycline 500 mg four times daily, metronidazole 400 mg twice daily for two weeks

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old woman has a 6-month history of pain in her hands and fingers, which is worse in the morning, improved by exercise and partially relieved by NSAIDs. A X-ray of her hands indicates a likely diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.
What raised blood test is most specific for a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis?

A. ANA
B. Rheumatoid factor
C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
D. Anti-CCP
E. CRP

Correct Answer: D

A 72-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with deteriorating health. He complains of extreme tiredness and lethargy. Past medical history of note includes hypertension and an ejection systolic murmur that was thought to be insignificant. He had some teeth removed a few weeks earlier.
On examination, he is pale and clubbed. Splinter haemorrhages are also noted. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Auscultation reveals a harsh ejection systolic murmur and signs of mild left ventricular failure.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 100 g/l 135–175 g/l
Platelets 185 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 10.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 105 mm/hr 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 6.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 195 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Echocardiogram Aortic stenosis with vegetations

Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in this case?

A. Streptococcus viridans
B. Staphlococcus aureus
C. Staphylococcus epidermidis
D. Streptococcus pneumoniae
E. Enterococcus faecalis

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a rapidly enlarging, painful ulcer on the right shin. The patient first noticed a small blister on the area a few days ago which broke down into an ulcer. which is continuing to enlarge.
The doctor suspects that the skin lesion may be pyoderma gangrenosum.
Which one of the following conditions is most commonly associated with pyoderma gangrenosum?

A. HIV infection
B. Coeliac disease
C. Osteoarthritis
D. Rheumatoid arthritis
E. Multiple myeloma

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man is married to a 26-year-old woman who had conceived a child with another partner. The couple have been unable to conceive a child despite the fact that they have been having unprotected sex regularly for 2 years. The man was found to have a low sperm count owing to a lack of androgen-binding protein.
Which cell in the body produces androgen-binding protein?

A. Leydig cell
B. Myoid cell
C. Sertoli cell
D. Pituitary gonadotrope
E. Spermatogonium

Correct Answer: C

A 58-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of ‘tingling’ in his wrists and hands at night, more so in the right than the left. When you examine him, you note wasting of the thenar eminence of his hand on the right side. He has subtle weakness of thumb opposition. He has reduced sensation to light touch on the palmar surface of his right hand on the lateral three digits as well as the lateral half of the fourth digit. When you tap immediately distal to the wrist joint of his right hand for about 30 s, it reproduces his symptoms.
Which nerve is involved in this man’s presentation?

A. Median nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Ulnar nerve
D. Musculocutaneous nerve
E. Long thoracic nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old boy is diagnosed with Marfan syndrome following presenting to the optometrist with a right sided lens dislocation. The optometrist noted that the patient also had some other features suggestive of the condition and referred him to the paediatric team for further investigation.
Which of the following statements best describes Marfan syndrome?

A. It is associated with short a stature
B. X-linked pattern of inheritance is typical
C. Aortic stenosis commonly occurs
D. Scoliosis commonly occurs
E. Patients have a normal life expectancy

Correct Answer: D

Amy Cameron, a 19-year-old student, presents to her general practitioner with generalised itching. On questioning, she is taking no medications and has no allergies and there has not been any recent change in cosmetic or detergent products. Examination shows multiple widespread excoriation marks, but nothing else. On further questioning, she admits to recent weight gain and fatigue.
What is the most likely cause of her systemic pruritus?

A. Cholestasis
B. Hypothyroidism
C. Iron deficiency anaemia
D. Lymphoma
E. Widespread dermatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old man is referred to the Vascular Clinic, as he is complaining of leg pain. He says the pain arises in both calves and is slightly worse on the left side than on the right and comes on following periods of exertion. It begins after he walks a few metres and gets better when he sits and rests for a short while. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolaemia, hypertension and glaucoma. He has a 40 pack-year history but gave up smoking when he was diagnosed with diabetes ten years ago.
What is the most useful initial investigation to perform for this patient?

A. Ankle–brachial pressure index (ABPI) measurement
B. Duplex ultrasound arteriogram
C. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
D. Duplex ultrasound venogram
E. Serum glucose measurement

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. She suffers with osteoarthritis in both her knees and often takes codeine and ibuprofen. She admits that she often consumes an excessive amount of alcohol. On examination, she appears unwell and is tachycardic. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness with guarding and reduced bowel sounds. The computerised tomography (CT) scan of her abdomen is shown below.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, given the clinical scenario?

A. Acute appendicitis
B. Perforated peptic ulcer
C. Gastritis
D. Acute cholecystitis
E. Small bowel obstruction with strangulation

Correct Answer: B

A woman with known renal cell cancer presents with bilateral swollen legs from the groin downwards, she also has dilated veins surrounding the umbilicus.
What mechanism is causing this?

A. Inferior vena cava obstruction
B. Hypoalbuminaemia
C. Hyponatraemia
D. Deep venous thrombosis
E. Heart failure

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old woman visits her dermatologist with a 5-year history of acne on her back, chest and face. Comedones, pustules and scars are evident. She has not responded to previous treatment and the dermatologist prescribes isotretinoin.
What else should be prescribed in conjunction with this?

A. Topical retinoid
B. Oral oxytetracycline
C. Topical erythromycin
D. Topical benzoyl peroxide
E. Combined oral contraceptive

Correct Answer: E

A 57-year-old woman presents to the Oncology Ward with vomiting three days after receiving chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NHL). She is also experiencing muscle spasms in her hands and feet and has severe muscle weakness.
The patient’s blood test results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal range
Sodium 144 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 6.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Uric acid 600 µmol/l 140–360 µmol/l
Creatinine 168 µmol/l 68–98 µmol/l
Calcium 1.60 mmol/l 2.05–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate 2.4 mmol/l 0.8–1.50 mmol/l
Creatine kinase 65 U/l 25–200 U/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Dehydration
B. Chemotherapy-induced vomiting
C. Rhabdomyolysis
D. Sepsis
E. Tumour-lysis syndrome (TLS)

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old man presents with generalised pruritus, right upper quadrant pain and jaundice for the past month. He has a history of recurrent bloody bowel movements and painful defecation and is now being treated with sulfasalazine. His previous colonoscopy has shown superficial mucosal ulceration and inflammation, with many pseudopolyps involving the distal rectum up to the middle third of the transverse colon. On abdominal examination, the liver is slightly enlarged and tender. Total bilirubin level is 102.6 μmol/l and indirect bilirubin level 47.9 μmol/l. Alkaline phosphatase and γ-glutamyltransferase concentrations are moderately increased. Alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase levels are mildly elevated.
Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be positive in this patient?

A. Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA)
B. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)
C. Anti-smooth muscle antibody (ASMA)
D. Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA)
E. Anti-dsDNA antibody

Correct Answer: A

An 81-year-old retired landscape gardener presents to clinic with his daughter, who is concerned about a lesion on his scalp.
The lesion is 45 mm × 30 mm, irregular, and she feels it has changed colour to become darker over recent months. He states it has occasionally bled and is more raised than before. He has a history of travel with the armed forces in South-East Asia.
You suspect malignant melanoma.
Which of the following features is most likely to be associated with a poor prognosis in this patient?

A. Bleeding
B. Change in colour
C. Depth of lesion on biopsy
D. Diameter
E. Irregular border

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP) because of pain and stiffness in her hands.
On examination, the small joints of the hand are warm and inflamed.
What is the most specific blood test for this condition?

A. Rheumatoid factor
B. C-reactive protein (CRP)
C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
D. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP)
E. White cell count

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset compressive chest pain radiating to the left upper limb. Past medical history includes obesity, hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. He is a smoker. After the initial history and examination, you conclude that there is a 40% chance that this patient is experiencing an acute myocardial infarction. You request an ECG and cardiac enzymes to further evaluate.
What does the 40% estimate represent?

A. Odds ratio
B. Prior probability
C. Posterior probability
D. Likelihood ratio
E. Prevalence

Correct Answer: B

A 43-year-old man presents with severe pain in the right upper quadrant, nausea and vomiting. On examination, he is tender in the right upper quadrant without evidence of peritonism. Liver function tests (LFTs) reveal an elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase (ALP), but normal alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Inflammatory markers are normal. Chest and abdominal X-rays are unremarkable.
What is the next investigation required?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen
B. CT scan of the pelvis
C. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
D. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
E. Ultrasound scan of the biliary tree

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old woman presents with headaches and nosebleeds and is found to have a raised platelet count. She is diagnosed with essential thrombocytosis by the haematologist.
Which of the following might be used to treat essential thrombocytosis?

A. Interferon gamma
B. Cromoglycate
C. Hydroxyurea
D. Interferon β
E. Ranitidine

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old man attends the Neurology Clinic with his brother. He describes episodes of amnesia and confusion, usually lasting several minutes. On several occasions, his brother has witnessed him suddenly stopping what he is doing and staring into the distance. He shows you a video of one such episode, where lip-smacking and chewing is evident. The patient does not recall these events; however, he does state that he has noted the smell of burning on more than one occasion, in addition to an unusual feeling of déjà vu. There is no evidence of tongue biting or limb jerking. He is otherwise well, though does regularly smoke cannabis.
What is the most likely cause of these events?

A. Absence seizures
B. Cannabis usage
C. Narcolepsy
D. Non-epileptic seizures
E. Temporal lobe epilepsy

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year old man is seen on the Surgical Assessment Unit with acute abdominal pain.
Which of the following examination findings is most suggestive of a diagnosis of appendicitis?

A. Murphy’s sign
B. Tenderness over McBurney’s point
C. Grey–Turner’s sign
D. Tinkling bowel sounds
E. Absent bowel sounds

Correct Answer: B

This 13-year-old boy, in addition to the lesions shown, has similar lesions on the buccal mucosa, on the palms and the soles and around the anus and genitalia. He has had several episodes of severe abdominal pain that have resolved without intervention. His father had similar mucocutaneous lesions as a boy, but these became less obvious as he grew older.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which condition are sufferers from this disorder most at risk of developing?

A. Cancer
B. Cirrhosis of the liver
C. Chronic kidney disease
D. Dementia
E. Ischaemic heart disease

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old man with metastatic colorectal cancer is admitted to the hospice for end-of-life care. The patient is prescribed ondansetron for management of his nausea symptoms.
Ondansetron is an antiemetic that acts on which of the following receptors?

A. Muscarinic
B. Acetylcholine
C. Serotonin
D. Dopamine
E. Nicotinic

Correct Answer: C

A 38-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with dizziness and headache. Her blood pressure is found to be 190/120 mmHg. She said that she had been diagnosed with hypertension on two previous occasions but discontinued drugs both times. She is a computer analyst and drinks 3–5 units of alcohol every day. Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal Value
Potassium (K+) 3.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Calcium 3.03 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Albumin 38 g/l 35–55 g/l
Magnesium 0.60 mmol/l 0.75–1.00 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Sipple syndrome or MEN 2a
B. Wermer syndrome or MEN 1
C. Wagenmann–Froboese syndrome or MEN 2b
D. Phaeochromocytoma
E. Conn syndrome

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with painless gradual loss of vision in his eyes.
On examination, he has bitemporal hemianopia.
What is the location of the lesion causing this visual field defect?

A. Left occipital visual cortex
B. Left temporal lobe optic radiation
C. Optic chiasm
D. Right optic tract
E. Right parietal lobe optic radiation

Correct Answer: C

A 10-year-old boy presents to the General Practitioner with itching, severe right ear pain and swelling. He is accompanied by his father who says that it all started with his continued swimming lessons for the past two months. On examination, tenderness is elicited by pulling the right ear upwards. Otoscopy is difficult because of the painful, swollen ear canal and purulent white discharge. Examination also reveals tender cervical lymph nodes on the right side below the ear. The boy also complains of pain when the clinician asks him to move his jaw sideways. He has mild fever (38.3 °C), but the rest of the examination is unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate management for this condition?

A. Cleaning and irrigation of the external auditory canal
B. Oral aminoglycosides
C. Oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
D. Topical acetic acid 2% spray
D. E. Topical acetic acid 2% spray (with wick placement) and oral antibiotics

Correct Answer: E

A patient with a past history of abdominal surgery develops abdominal pain. A plain abdominal X-ray shows dilated bowel loops. There are lines on the dilated parts of the bowel which cross it.
What is the most likely underlying cause?

A. Gallstones
B. Inguinal hernia
C. Adhesions
D. Caecal carcinoma
E. Sigmoid carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

A patient who is seen in the Renal Outpatient Department for glomerulonephritis presents to the Emergency Department with a swollen, erythematous right leg with a 4-cm difference in circumference between the right and left leg. Routine blood tests show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 143 mmol 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.2 mmol 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 10.1 mmol 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol 50–120 µmol/l
eGFR 60ml/min/1.73m2
Corrected calcium (Ca2+) 2.25 mmol 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Bilirubin 7 μmol 2–17 µmol/l
Albumin 32 g/l 35–55 g/l
Alkaline phosphatase 32 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Aspartate transaminase (AST) 15 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Gamma-Glutamyl transferase (γGT) 32 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 15 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Haemoglobin 108 g/l
Males: 135–175 g/l
Females: 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 92 fl 76–98 fl
Platelets 302 x 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.5 x 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Which of the following should be commenced after confirmation of the diagnosis?

A. Warfarin
B. Apixaban
C. Low molecular weight heparin
A. D. Warfarin and unfractionated heparin
A. E. Warfarin and low molecular weight heparin

Correct Answer: B

A 53-year-old patient complains of shortness of breath on exertion. Chest X-ray shows fibrosis. He also complains of progressive malaise and fatigue and appears ashen. Additional tests reveal an elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level.
Which one of the following drugs is he taking?

A. Amiodarone
B. Flecainide
C. Lidocaine
D. Procainamide
E. Quinidine

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old lifeguard presents with a lesion on the ear. The lesion had been present for a number of months and he claims it is slowly growing. On examination, there is 1 cm red, ulcerating exophytic nodule with heaped up margins. Excision of the lesion is performed and histology reveals a completely excised lesion containing irregular masses of anaplastic epidermal cells proliferating down to the dermis with keratin pearls.
Which of the following is true regarding this lesion?

A. It is the second commonest skin cancer after melanoma
B. It is more commonly found on the upper lip than lower lips
C. It may arise from actinic keratosis
D. Spread to regional lymph nodes is very rare
E. There is a link to preceding dermatophyte infection

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old retired doctor is found to have a 5.7 cm aortic aneurysm, following his abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) ultrasound screening test.
He is referred to the vascular surgeon to discuss surgical repair of the aneurysm.
Which of the following is correct regarding surgical repair of AAAs?

A. The risk of immediate post-operative complications is higher for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) when compared to open repair
B. The graft attachment is less likely to be secure following an open repair than by EVAR
C. EVAR cannot be performed for aneurysms that occur above the renal arteries
D. Long-term mortality rates are significantly improved in patients undergoing EVAR, compared to open repair
E. EVAR is the preferred method currently used in the event of a ruptured aortic aneurysm

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man visits with complaints of difficulty initiating the flow of urine, with increased frequency and urgency for the past six months. His serum prostate-specific antigen is 1.2 ng/ml (normal < 2.5 ng/ml) and a prostatic biopsy is done. It showed glandular and stromal hyperplasia with an increased number of epithelial and stromal cells.
What is the most appropriate treatment for the patient’s condition?

A. Dutasteride
B. Prazosin
C. Propranolol
D. Ephedrine
E. Testosterone replacement

Correct Answer: B

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the Paediatric Outpatient Department by his mother with symptoms of bloating, mild fever, abdominal pain, lack of appetite, generalised feeling of being unwell and easy bruising for the past two weeks. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy (non-tender, firm, rubbery) and patches of petechiae and purpura are noted on both lower limbs.
The child is referred to the Oncology Department where complete laboratory investigations, including full blood count (FBC), differential count and a review of the peripheral smear, were performed. The findings are indicative of acute lymphocytic leukaemia (ALL).
Which of the following would be the most likely finding with the suspected diagnosis?

A. Expanded population of myeloid cells – t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome)
B. Highly proliferative monomorphic medium-sized cells – starry sky appearance
C. Hypocellular bone marrow with pancytopenia
D. Immature cells with large nucleoli, myeloperoxidase (MPO)-positive
E. Positive staining for B-cell antibodies (CD19, cytoplasmic CD79a, CD22) and MPO-negative

Correct Answer: E

An 84-year-old woman, with a history of recurrent falls, had a recent fall on her outstretched right hand.
An X-ray revealed a fracture of the distal radius with volar displacement. She has multiple risk factors for osteoporosis, and a DEXA scan was requested.
Which score is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis?

A. T score >2.5
B. T score: 1–2.5
C. T score: 0–1
D. T score: −1 to −2.5
E. T score: < −2.5

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old known intravenous drug user presents to your GP clinic complaining of new onset fatigue, night sweats and aching joints. Upon examination you notice a new early-diastolic murmur.
What is the most likely causative organism for this patient’s condition?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Streptococcus viridans
C. Group B streptococci
D. Group D streptococci
E. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old man presents with oral and genital ulcers and a red rash, parts of which have started to blister. On examination, he is noted to have red eyes. He had been treated with antibiotics ten days ago for a chest infection.
What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?

A. Herpes simplex
B. Bullous pemphigoid
C. Pemphigus vulgaris
D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome
E. Graft versus host disease

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old man of African descent, who was diagnosed with lupus nephritis 3 years ago, is admitted with complaints of pain in both groins that is radiating down to the thighs and buttocks. Movements around the hip are severely restricted and he has a limp while walking. The pain developed insidiously and has gradually worsened. There is no history of trauma. He is currently on 30 mg prednisone/day and cyclophosphamide. An X-ray of the pelvis and hips shows no abnormality.
Which one of the following is the most likely aetiology of this hip pain?

A. Steroid-induced avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head
B. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)
C. Septic arthritis of the hip due to immunosuppression
D. Pathological fracture due to osteomalacia
E. Steroid-induced osteoporosis

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old man with known cystic fibrosis is diagnosed with aspergillus infection following presenting to his clinician with worsening respiratory symptoms.
Which of the following is typically a pulmonary manifestation of Aspergillus infection?

A. Lower zone emphysema
B. Allergic asthma
C. Interstitial fibrosis
D. Prominent mediastinal lymphadenopathy
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: B

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents after he fell off a skateboard. He reports that he was able to brace his fall with his right hand. In the Emergency Department, the patient’s vitals are stable. Examination of the right upper extremity demonstrates tenderness above the elbow, with evidence of soft tissue swelling. A plain film demonstrates a supracondylar fracture of the right humerus.
Which of the following structures is most at risk?

A. Brachial artery
B. Radial collateral artery
C. Radial nerve
D. Median nerve
E. Ulnar artery

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old man with chronic kidney disease has recently received a renal transplant. After three months he starts to feel unwell with flu-like symptoms, fever, and pain over the transplant area.
What is the most likely type of reaction that has occurred in the patient?

A. No reaction
B. Chronic graft failure
C. Wound infection
D. Acute graft failure
E. Hyperacute rejection

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old man attends pre-operative assessment clinic for elective hernia repair. He has had type 1 diabetes for 35 years.
Blood results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 134 g/l 135–175 g/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/litre 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatine 97 µmol/litre 50–120 µmol/l
eGFR 55 ml/min/1.73 m2 > 90 ml/min
HbA1c 58 mmol/mol (7.5%) < 53 mmol/mol (<7.0%)
How would you stage his degree of renal impairment?

A. Stage 1
B. Stage 2
C. Stage 3
D. Stage 4
E. Stage 5

Correct Answer: C

A neurosurgeon assesses a young woman with injuries she received in an explosion. She has numerous lacerations over her trunk, both front and back, and has bruising of the craniofacial region. On neurological examination, he finds that she has absent movement in her right lower limb, with hyperreflexia. She also has loss of proprioception and fine touch in this limb, but pain and temperature sensations are intact. However, he notes that pain and temperature sensations are absent in the left lower limb, and proprioception and fine touch are intact. Movement and reflexes are normal in the left lower limb.
What is the most likely site of this neurological lesion?

A. Hemisection of the left side of the spinal cord at the level of the fourth sacral segment of the cord
B. Hemisection of the left side of the spinal cord at the level of the first lumbar segment of the cord
C. Hemisection of the right side of the spinal cord at the level of the first lumbar segment of the cord
D. Hemisection of the right side of the spinal cord at the level of the fourth sacral segment of the cord
E. Lesion to the ventroposterior nuclei of the right thalamus

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old man is discharged from hospital after an episode of meningitis. The organism was diagnosed as being Streptococcus pneumoniae after a lumbar puncture and the patient was treated with ceftriaxone. On discharge, his observations were normal. He has a past medical history of asthma treated with salbutamol and low-dose inhaled corticosteroids. He has no known drug allergies.
A few days following his discharge, he started experiencing postural headaches that were worse when sitting upright. He grades his pain as 7/10. He has been feeling nauseated, although has had no vomiting episodes. He also has some minor neck stiffness and is not confused. He attends A&E, as he is worried about his new symptoms. There is evidence of extrathecal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Diagnosis is confirmed on a computed tomography (CT) myelogram.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s headache?

A. Aseptic meningitis
B. Insufficiently treated meningitis
C. Spontaneous intracranial hypotension
D. Subdural haematoma
E. Subarachnoid haemorrhage

Correct Answer: C

A healthcare assistant presents to her general practitioner (GP) for a routine check-up. She states that she received a needlestick injury at work over one month ago; however, she never reported this to occupational health, as she felt the patient to be low risk. She is now wondering about her infection status. Viral serology is undertaken:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) PCR Negative
Hepatitis C antibody Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) Negative
Immunoglobulin M (IgM) anti-hepatitis B core (HBc) antigen Negative
Anti-HBc (hepatitis B core antigen) Negative
Anti-HBs (hepatitis B surface antibody) Positive
Which of the following most accurately reflects her hepatitis status?

A. Current acute infection
B. Current chronic infection
C. Resolved infection
D. Susceptible to infection
E. Vaccinated against infection

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with epigastric pain and vomiting. He has a history of excessive alcohol intake. His serum amylase level is 1020 u/l, and the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is made.
Which of the following parameters is NOT used in the modified Glasgow severity scoring?

A. Age
B. Serum albumin
C. Corrected calcium
D. White cell count
E. Serum amylase

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old man presented with a 4-day history of increasing pain, blurry vision and lacrimation in the right eye. He also felt a foreign body sensation in the affected eye. He had been doing some DIY work at home without wearing any goggles for the past few days prior to the onset of pain.
On examination, his visual acuities were 6/18 in the right and 6/6 in the left. The conjunctiva in the right was red. The cornea was tested with fluorescein and it showed an uptake in the centre of the cornea, which looked like a dendrite. You examined his face and noticed some small vesicles at the corner of his mouth as well.
What is the first-line treatment for this patient’s eye condition?

A. Topical antibiotic drops such as ofloxacin
B. Topical antibiotic ointment such as chloramphenicol
C. Topical artificial tears
D. Topical antiviral ointment such as aciclovir
E. Topical steroid drops such as prednisolone

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) with unsteadiness on her feet and frequent falls of two days’ duration.
On examination, she is noted to have loss of sensation and weakness of the proximal and distal muscles of the right lower limb. Her upper limbs and face have no weakness or sensory deficit.
Her GP refers her to the nearest Stroke Unit for assessment and management. Computed tomography (CT) scan confirms a thromboembolic cerebrovascular accident.
Which vessel is most likely to have been involved?

A. The right anterior cerebral artery distal to the anterior communicating branch
B. The left anterior cerebral artery distal to the anterior communicating branch
C. Main stem occlusion in the left middle cerebral artery
D. The right posterior cerebral artery proximal occlusion
E. The left posterior cerebral artery proximal occlusion

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old woman presented with worsening constipation. One month previously she had been discharged from hospital following an acute coronary syndrome and atrial fibrillation. She was treated with several new drugs in hospital and was adherent to all of them.
Which one of her medications is most likely to have caused her constipation?

A. Aspirin
B. Nicorandil
C. Ramipril
D. Simvastatin
E. Verapamil

Correct Answer: E

A 66-year-old man presented with tiredness and dyspnoea. He was found to be pale and blood tests revealed a haemoglobin level of 61 g/l with mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 65 fl. He had no apparent bleeding manifestations, but a stool occult blood test (OBT) was positive on two separate occasions. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy, colonoscopy and small bowel contrast study were all reported to be normal.
What is the best next step in investigating this patient?

A. Small bowel angiography
B. Scintiscan
C. Capsule endoscopy
D. Double balloon endoscopy
E. Blind biopsy of small intestine

Correct Answer: C

A 63-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-week history of a swollen painful first metatarsophalangeal joint. The patient says that the symptoms started last night and describes the pain as being excruciating. He denies any fever or injuries to the toe. Upon examination, the patient’s joint appears red, swollen and is warm to touch. He has a history of peptic ulcer, gout and is on allopurinol 300 mg once a day for gout prophylaxis.
What is the most appropriate next management?

A. Increase allopurinol dose
B. Stop allopurinol and recommence two weeks after acute inflammation settled
C. Stop allopurinol and start non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
D. Continue allopurinol and start oral colchicine
E. Stop allopurinol and recommence at a higher dose after acute inflammation has settled

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old woman presents to Accident and Emergency feeling generally unwell, with fever and a cough. She had chemotherapy for her breast cancer 4 days ago. There are no known drug allergies. On examination:
Investigation Result Normal value
Blood pressure (BP) 108/70 mmHg <120/80 mmHg
Heart rate (HR) 101 bpm 60–100 bpm
Respiratory rate (RR) 26 breaths/minute 12–18 breaths/minute
Sats 96% on air 94–98%
Temperature 38.7°C 36.1–37.2°C
There is some scattered crepitations at the right lung base. You check on the system and see that bloods were done 2 days ago and showed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/dl 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 0.8 × 109/l 1.7–7.5 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.5 × 109/l 1.0–4.5 × 109/l
Eosinophils 0.6 × 109/l 0.0–0.4 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate next-step management?

A. Wait for today’s blood results and call the haematology team for advice
B. Start intravenous (IV) piperacillin with tazobactam (Tazocin®)
C. Start IV meropenem
D. Urgent chest X-ray
E. Start filgrastim (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, G-CSF) injection

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old woman who is 28 weeks pregnant with her first child presents to the Emergency Department after being electrocuted by a faulty power socket in her flat. Her echo cardiogram shows no abnormalities and after eight hours of cardiac monitoring, her conduction system is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A. Cardiotocography (CTG)
B. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
C. Foetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
D. Foetal ultrasound
E. Reassurance and discharge

Correct Answer: A

An infant, born to a 24-year-old woman immigrant who did not receive prenatal care, is found to have a midline lesion on his lower back. Examination reveals a fluid-filled cystic mass that is continuous with the spinal canal.
With which one of the following could this anomaly have been prevented by supplementation?

A. A vitamin that is necessary for pyruvate dehydrogenase function
B. A vitamin that prevents keratinised squamous metaplasia
C. A vitamin necessary for synthesis of a high-energy electron carrier
D. A vitamin necessary in nucleic acid synthesis
E. A vitamin necessary in fatty acid synthesis

Correct Answer: D

A 69-year-old man presents with symptoms including poor sleep. He reports an itching and crawling sensation affecting his legs with an overwhelming urge to move them. His wife reports that he tosses and turns all night, often pacing the room, and constantly rubs his legs. Things only improve with the break of dawn. He seems tired all day as a consequence of the disturbed sleep at night. The only past medical history of note is diverticular disease, from which he has been troubled by periodic iron deficiency anaemia. Neurological examination is unremarkable.

Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 101 g/l (microcytic) 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 285 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 124 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Fasting glucose 5.8 mmol/l < 7 mmol/l
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Primary restless legs syndrome
B. Alcohol related neuropathy
C. Secondary restless legs syndrome
D. Nocturnal cramps
E. Diabetic neuropathy

Correct Answer: C

A young man is brought into the Emergency Department in an unresponsive state. He was found lying in the street by a passer-by who called the ambulance. Upon initial assessment, he is not communicating with you meaningfully, only muttering swear words occasionally. He is not responding to commands but reaches up to push your hand away when you squeeze his trapezius muscle. When you do this, he does not open his eyes.
What is this patient’s Glasgow Coma Score (GCS)?

A. 6
B. 8
C. 9
D. 10
E. 12

Correct Answer: C

In the complement cascade, which component comprises the membrane attack complex (MAC)?

A. C5, E. C6, C7, C8, C9
B. C3a
C. C3b
D. C5a
E. C6

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old semi-professional rugby player is admitted with a red, hot, swollen left knee. No trauma has occurred. He had a recent negative sexual health check and has had no new partners since.
On examination: temperature 38.1 °C, large left knee effusion, unable to fully extend the left knee. The clinical suspicion is of a septic arthritis.
What is the most likely causative organism?

A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
B. Staphylococcus aureus
C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae
D. Streptococcus viridans
E. Salmonella typhi

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the Emergency Department with acute exacerbation and breathlessness. He is intubated (with suxamethonium and etomidate) and is placed on mechanical ventilation. His blood pressure on arrival was 150/95 mmHg but, following intubation, has decreased to 80/72 mmHg. He has a prolonged expiratory phase; he has an audible wheeze but does not make spontaneous respiratory effort. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral breath sounds; distended neck veins can be seen and the trachea appears to be central.
What is the next best step in managing the hypotension of this patient?

A. Bronchodilators and corticosteroids
B. Expiratory pause of the ventilator and decreasing the respiratory rate
C. Increasing the dose of sedation medication
D. Increasing the respiratory rate or the tidal volume
E. Needle thoracocentesis

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner. She complains of progressive weakness for the previous few months. She has noted difficulty rising from a chair and climbing upstairs; this worsens noticeably through the day and especially if she attempts to walk continuously for more than a few minutes. She has no significant past medical history, but she smokes 15 cigarettes a day. During a general systems review, you learn that she has also lost weight due to a loss of appetite and has had a cough. The cough has been worsening over the last few weeks and she had one episode of haemoptysis 2 weeks ago. On examination, there are no clear signs of ptosis, diplopia or dysarthria. You consider a list of differential diagnoses.
Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be implicated?

A. Antibodies to acetylcholine receptors
B. Antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels
C. Anti-RNP
D. c-ANCA
E. Thyrotropin receptor antibody

Correct Answer: B

You are called to see a 70-year-old man who was admitted for an anterior resection for sigmoid cancer. His operation was uncomplicated, and he is now three days post operation. He has hypercholesterolaemia and hypertension, but was otherwise fit before diagnosis. You find that the man is in atrial fibrillation. Nursing staff report that he is increasingly confused and appears to be in pain despite post-operative pain relief. They also report decreased urine output and tachycardia when they last took observations.
What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?

A. Hospital acquired pneumonia
B. Anastomotic leak
C. Consequences of having just had major abdominal surgery
D. Pulmonary embolus
E. The result of a pre-existing cardiac condition

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old white woman with no past medical history presents with pallor, shortness of breath, palpitations and difficulty balancing.
On examination, her vitals are heart rate 110 bpm at rest and 140 bpm on ambulation, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute, temperature 37 ° C and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. She is pale. Her lungs are clear to auscultation; her heart rate is regular without murmurs, rubs or gallops; her abdomen is soft and non-tender; she is moving all extremities equally, and a stool guaiac test is heme-negative. Her gait is wide and she has difficulty balancing. She has decreased sensation to fine touch in her feet. Her mini-mental status exam is normal.
Blood work shows:
Haematocrit: 0.19 (0.35–0.55)
Mean cell volume: 110 fl (76–98 fl)
White blood cell count: 5 × 109/l (4–11 × 109/l)
Which one of the following findings would most likely lead to the correct diagnosis?

A. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies
B. Intestinal tapeworm
C. Destruction of the anterior and lateral horns of the spinal cord
D. Enlargement of the ventricles on head computerised tomography (CT)
E. Haemoglobin A1c 12.2%

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old man complains of numbness in his lower extremities. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination shows loss of proprioception on his right side below the umbilical line. At the umbilical line, there was loss of all sensation. Additionally, loss of thermal and pain sensation in the groin area and below, on the left side, was noted. Radiological examination reveals a mass on the spine.
Where is most likely the location of the mass?

A. Lumbar level 1 on the left side
B. Thoracic level 10 on the right side
C. Thoracic level 10 on the left side
D. Thoracic level 11 on the right side
E. Thoracic level 11 on the left side

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old woman is admitted to hospital with fever, dyspnoea and consolidation at the left lower base. She is commenced on antibiotics. A few days later, she deteriorates and a chest X-ray reveals a large pleural effusion, with consolidation on the left side.
What is the most important investigation to perform next?

A. Blood culture
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan
C. Pleural aspiration
D. Bronchoscopy
E. Thoracoscopy

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old woman complains of infrequent periods, weight loss and sweating. She feels her symptoms have gradually worsened over several months. She also feels itchy. On examination, she has a blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg and a resting pulse of 100 bpm.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?

A. Full blood count and ferritin levels
B. Midnight cortisol level
C. Plasma renin and aldosterone levels
D. Test the urine for 24-hour free catecholamines
E. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and T4 levels

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old woman is been seen by her General Practitioner (GP) for her osteoarthritis. She complains of extreme pain at night and this has been disturbing her sleep. The patient has been suffering from osteoarthritis for ten years and last year she has a total knee replacement of her right knee which greatly improved her pain.
