However, in the last two months her left knee has been causing her much pain. She has a past medical history of hypertension and peptic ulcer disease. The patient currently takes regular paracetamol at a dose of 4 g a day. Last month her GP prescribed some topical capsaicin which provided some relief. The patient would like to have something else to manage her pain. Liver functions tests are normal, and the patient has no history of any liver disease.
What is the best next step in the management of this patient’s pain?

A. Add aspirin
B. Add codeine
C. Add ibuprofen
D. Offer morphine modified-release
E. Refer the patient for a left knee replacement

Correct Answer: B

You are a Foundation Year 2 in general practice and a 42-year-old lady comes in who is pregnant with her first child. She feels unwell, has upper abdominal pain near her epigastrium, and thinks that her ankle swelling has been much worse over the last few days. You assess her and your findings are as follows:
Symphysis–fundal height (SFH): 39 cm
Presentation: breech
Lie: longitudinal
Blood pressure (BP): 152/93
Fetal movements: not palpable
Which of these investigations is most likely to lead you to a diagnosis?

A. Ultrasound of the abdomen
B. Cardiotocography (CTG)
C. Urine dipstick
D. Blood tests for liver function
E. Doppler auscultation of the fetal heart beat

Correct Answer: C

A patient is admitted with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. The following investigation results are obtained:
Investigation Result Normal range
Bilirubin 154 µmol/l 3–17 µmol/l
Conjugated bilirubin 110 mmol/l 3 mmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 10 IU/l 1–21 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 200 IU/l 50–160 IU/l
Prothrombin time 55 s 25–41 s
Ultrasound report: ‘A dilated bile duct is noted, no other abnormality seen’
Urine: bilirubin +++
What is the most likely cause of the jaundice?

A. Stone in common bile duct
B. Haemolytic anaemia
C. Hepatitis
D. Liver cirrhosis
E. Paracetamol overdose

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of left groin pain, associated with a lump that seems to come and go.
Following examination, the clinician deduces that the swelling is most likely to be an indirect inguinal hernia.
Indirect inguinal hernias can be controlled at:

A. 1.3 cm above the mid-point of the inguinal ligament
B. The pubic tubercle
C. Hasselbach’s triangle
D. The inferior epigastric vessels
E. The scrotum

Correct Answer: A

A mother gives birth to her first baby. The baby begins vomiting persistently during the third week of life. The paediatrician performs a physical examination of the baby and feels a small mass about the size of an olive in the epigastrium.
Which of the following is this child likely to exhibit?

A. Pancreas divisum
B. Biliary stenosis
C. Pyloric stenosis
D. Duodenal atresia
E. Pancreatitis

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with symptoms of shortness of breath, nocturnal cough and wheezing for one week. He mentions that these symptoms started after he was accidentally exposed to a large amount of hydrochloric acid fumes last week while working in a chemical laboratory. He has no history of respiratory conditions and no other relevant past medical history. He is a non-smoker.
Which of the following investigations may initially be the most helpful to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Chest X-ray
B. Full blood count
C. Methacholine challenge test
D. Peak flow
E. Skin prick test

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old man underwent gastric endoscopy for suspected gastritis. The endoscope reached the oesophagogastric junction and entered the stomach.
Which of the following regions of the stomach is closest to this junction?

A. Body
B. Cardia
C. Fundus
D. Pyloric antrum
E. Pyloric canal

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old nurse takes an intentional overdose of paracetamol. A suicide note was discovered at the scene. Her only past health problem is long-standing, well-controlled epilepsy, for which she takes carbamazepine. She is believed to have taken approximately 30 tablets. When she reached hospital, blood samples were taken. From a collateral history, this is 6 h after ingestion.
Blood investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 141 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 321 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 134 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.6 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 4.6 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 76 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Bilirubin 12 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 45 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 86 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
GGT 74 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 53 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Paracetamol level 110 mg/l
Which one of the following is the ideal treatment for this patient?

A. Intravenous (iv) saline + 4-hourly liver function tests (LFTs) and prothrombin time
B. Give activated charcoal and repeat LFTs after 4 h
C. Repeat paracetamol levels at 8 h post-ingestion before deciding on treatment
D. Give oral methionine
E. Give iv acetylcysteine

Correct Answer: E

A mother brings her 3-month-old baby to the out-patient’s clinic. The baby has a soft, poorly compressible mass in the neck. It transilluminates brilliantly.
Choose the anatomical region in which this mass is most likely to lie:

A. The region of the neck bordered by: the sternocleidomastoid, the midline and the lower border of the mandible
B. The region of the neck bordered by: the sternocleidomastoid, the trapezius and the clavicle.
C. Under the jaw, in a region bordered by: the anterior belly of the digastric muscle, the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the lower border of the mandible
D. The region of the neck bordered by: the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the superior belly of the omohyoid muscle
E. The region of the neck bordered by: the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the trapezius and the omohyoid muscle

Correct Answer: B

A woman presents to the Emergency Department 15 days after giving birth by Caesarean section. She complains of persistent vaginal bleeding. Her temperature is 38.5 ºC, pulse 88 bpm and blood pressure 110/76.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Mastitis
B. Endometritis
C. Retained products of conception
D. Wound infection
E. Wound haematoma

Correct Answer: B

A patient is having an emergency laparotomy for a likely sigmoid perforation secondary to diverticular disease. She is 86, has known ischaemic heart disease under medical management, and was in new atrial fibrillation (AF) pre-operatively. You find that she has two quadrant peritonitis and despite fluid resuscitation her blood pressure is becoming low. You start Noradrenaline. She is going to intensive care unit (ICU) post-operatively.
Which scoring system is generally used in this context to predict outcome?

A. APACHE
B. P-POSSUM
C. SOFA
D. SAPS
E. TISS

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old girl presents with a 1-day history of abdominal pain. Her last period was 2 weeks ago, and her cycle is usually regular. She has had several sexual partners over the last 6 months, with deep dyspareunia recently. She has had some increased vaginal discharge over the last few days and the pain is not eased with paracetamol. On examination, her temperature is 37.8 °C, otherwise stable in the normal range. Her abdomen is soft but generally tender, and internal examination shows cervical excitation +++ with right adnexal tenderness and some thick yellow/green discharge from the cervical os; swabs are taken. There is no bleeding. Urine beta human chorionic gonadotropin (β-HCG) is negative.
What would you do next?

A. Pelvic ultrasound scan
B. Bloods to check inflammatory markers and serum β-HCG
C. Analgesia and observe
D. Give intramuscular (im) ceftriaxone stat and a 14-day course of doxycycline and metronidazole
E. Give oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 2 weeks

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old woman presents with a painful left hip and groin and is struggling to weight-bear. She completed therapy for acute myeloblastic leukaemia some six months earlier.
On examination, she walks with a limp and there is limitation of hip flexion, internal and external rotation.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal Value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 191 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 12 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
The left hip X-ray shows joint sclerosis with collapse of the femoral head.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Avascular necrosis
B. Gout
C. Osteoarthritis
D. Pseudogout
E. Septic arthritis

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old pharmaceutical representative is admitted to the Emergency Department after collapsing, while making a presentation at the hospital about one of his company’s medicines. He became short of breath, with acute stridor and swollen lips and throat suggestive of angio-oedema. He responds to treatment with hydrocortisone and adrenaline. On further questioning, it transpires he has just recently started treatment with a new anti-hypertensive.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following medications is most likely to have caused his presentation?

A. Amlodipine
B. Atenolol
C. Ramipril
D. Bendroflumethiazide
E. Indapamide

Correct Answer: C

A scientist is conducting a screening assay for a cardiac endocrine biomarker.
What hormone does the heart produce under stretched conditions?

A. Angiotensin II
B. B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP)
C. C-type natriuretic peptide
D. Nitric oxide
E. Renin

Correct Answer: B

According to the monophyletic model of haematopoiesis, the haematopoietic stem cell (HSC) can form either the common lymphoid progenitor (CLP) or the common myeloid progenitor (CMP).
Which mature cell in the peripheral circulation is a derivative of the CMP?

A. Natural killer (NK) cell
B. T cell
C. B cell
D. Plasma cell
E. Monocyte

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman in her first pregnancy presents at 30 weeks’ gestation with an episode of antepartum haemorrhage. She noticed fresh red blood on wiping this morning and followed by spotting since. She denies any pain, and the abdomen is soft and non-tender on examination. The baby is moving well. This is the first episode of bleeding in this pregnancy. She is under midwifery-led care but tells you she has a scan booked for 32 weeks. Urinalysis is unremarkable, and her observations are stable.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s antepartum haemorrhage?

A. Concealed placental abruption
B. Genitourinary infection
C. Placenta praevia
D. Premature labour
E. Revealed placental abruption

Correct Answer: C

A 64-year-old woman, whose children rang for an ambulance after they were concerned about her breathing, has an arterial blood gas (ABG) performed. She is a regular attender at Accident and Emergency and has a 5-day history of worsening cough and green sputum production. She is on long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) at home. Her ABG reads as follows and was taken while on controlled oxygen therapy through a Venturi system:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.232 7.35–7.45
CO2 8.9 kPa 3.5–4.5 kPa
O2 9.4 kPa 8.0–10.0 kPa
HCO3– 33 mmol/l 22.0–28.0 mmol/l
SaO2 89%
Lactate 2.1 0.1–2.2
Which of the following statements best describes this ABG?

A. Respiratory acidosis with complete metabolic compensation
B. Metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation
C. Respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation
D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation
E. Respiratory acidosis without compensation

Correct Answer: C

A 53-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a distended abdomen and abdominal pain for the last two days. He has presented to the same hospital in the past for alcohol intoxication and variceal bleeding. He has known liver cirrhosis secondary to long-term alcoholism. He has failed alcohol detoxification on multiple occasions and currently drinks 4–5 pints of strong lager per day. He has no history of drug use. He states that he occasionally takes propranolol which was prescribed for him in the past for prophylaxis against variceal bleeding. He has no drug allergies.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.9 °C
Blood pressure 156/99 mmHg
Respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute
Heart rate 75 beats per minute
Sp(O2) 99% (room air)
Physical examination is significant for hepatomegaly and shifting dullness on percussion. The abdomen is also distended and there is mild tenderness throughout the abdomen. There is no guarding or peritonism. A diagnostic paracentesis is performed and analysis of the ascitic fluid confirms a neutrophil count >250 cells/mm3.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Amoxicillin
B. Erythromycin
C. Levofloxacin
D. Piperacillin and tazobactam
E. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

Correct Answer: D

A 39-year-old woman presents to Accident and Emergency with extensive cellulitis of her right lower limb. She is otherwise fit and well, has no known drug allergies, and is not currently pyrexial or tachycardic. She is accepted by medics and in the meantime is commenced on intravenous (IV) antibiotics. Shortly afterwards, she is found to be hypoxic, struggling to breathe, with harsh upper airways noises and a widespread rash.
Which of the following options would be the treatment of choice?

A. Adrenaline 0.5 mg, 1 in 1000 intramuscularly (IM)
B. Adrenaline 1 mg, 1 in 10 000 IV
C. Adrenaline 1 mg, 1 in 1000 IM
D. Adrenaline 1 mg, 1 in 1000 IV
E. Adrenaline 1 mg, 1 in 10 000 IM

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old patient is referred to the Outpatient Clinic with raised prostate-specific antigen (PSA), but a normal prostate on physical examination. He is later diagnosed with prostate cancer on biopsy.
What is the most common area of the prostate where this disease develops?

A. The central zone
B. The transition zone
C. The peripheral zone
D. The anterior fibromuscular stroma
E. The posterior capsule

Correct Answer: C

A 39-year-old woman presents to the Neurology Clinic after experiencing painful unilateral visual disturbance, ataxia and sensory deficit.
After magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), she is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS), and commenced on steroid treatment, followed by disease-modifying therapy.
Six months later, her disease is stable, and she is able to manage activities of daily living without major issues. She previously drove a car, but has not driven since her diagnosis, and is wondering about driving.
What are the most appropriate next steps for her driving circumstances?

A. She must inform the DVLA and cannot drive for one year since her most recent relapse
B. She must inform the DVLA and cannot drive for six months since her most recent relapse
C. She must inform the DVLA and her licence must be revoked
D. She must inform the DVLA and may continue to drive
E. No requirement to inform DVLA

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old retired shopkeeper presents with acute-onset confusion. The patient lives with her husband and is usually fit and well. She has had no problems with her memory previously, but over the past two days, her husband has noticed that the patient has become increasingly confused; this morning she did not recognise him. When taking the history from the husband, he mentions that the patient had been experiencing urinary symptoms over the past week. A dipstick of the patient’s urine is positive for blood, leukocytes and nitrites. A provisional diagnosis of delirium secondary to a urinary tract infection (UTI) is made, and empirical treatment for UTI is commenced.
Which of the following tests is usually abnormal during delirium, regardless of the cause?

A. Serum glucose
B. Computed tomography (CT) of the head
C. Electroencephalogram
D. Electrocardiogram
E. Lumbar puncture

Correct Answer: C

A 31-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner at three weeks postpartum. She is mostly breastfeeding but tops feeds up with formula milk when she is out with her baby, as she feels uncomfortable breastfeeding in public. She wants to discuss contraception. She is the only caretaker of the new born during day time and also feels difficult to manage her sleeping hours and daily routine. There is no other medical history of note.
Which of the following contraceptive methods are the most practical for this patient?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill
B. Copper coil
C. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system
D. Progesterone implant
E. Progesterone-only pill

Correct Answer: D

A 57-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with right upper quadrant pain, fever and chills for the last two days. His past medical history is significant for gallstone disease which has not been followed up for some time. He is febrile, but his other observations are normal.
Physical examination is remarkable for jaundice, scleral icterus and right upper-quadrant pain. There is no abdominal rigidity, and bowel sounds are present.
His blood test results are shown below.
Investigation Results Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 18.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 97 mg/dl 0–10 mg/l
Bilirubin 40 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Which of the following is the best next step in management?

A. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Exploratory laparotomy
C. Percutaneous cholecystostomy
D. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen
E. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl presents to her General Practitioner (GP) because she has never had a menstrual period. On examination, the GP notes normal female external genitalia and a vagina that ends as a blind pouch. No uterus or ovaries are palpable. There is no axillary or pubic hair growth.
What finding will be present on this patient’s karyotype?

A. 45,XO
B. 46,XX
C. 47,XXY
D. 46,XY
E. 47,XYY

Correct Answer: D

A woman with mild dementia has just been admitted to the Emergency Department unit in Scotland following a fall. She has total external rotation of her left leg, indicating that she has a fractured neck of femur. She refused to be taken into the ambulance at home, and the GP successfully applied to a Justice of the Peace for a warrant to remove her to hospital. She still does not want any treatment, and will not allow examination of her hip.
What is the best legal option to take?

A. An Emergency Treatment Certificate under the Mental Health (Care and Welfare) (Scotland) Act 2003
B. A section 47 certificate under Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000
C. Common law principle of necessity
D. Short-term detention certificate under the Mental Health (Care and Welfare) (Scotland) Act 2003
E. Compulsory treatment order under the Mental Health (Care and Welfare) (Scotland) Act 2003

Correct Answer: B

You are asked by nursing staff to review a patient in recovery overnight. As you arrive, the nurse looking after the patient informs you that she is just going to get a bag of fluid for him. On examination, the patient is unresponsive with an obstructed airway (snoring). You notice on the monitor that his heart rate is 33 bpm and blood pressure 89/60 mmHg. His saturation probe has fallen off.
What is your first priority?

A. Call for help and maintain the airway with a jaw thrust and deliver 15 l of high-flow oxygen
B. Give atropine 500 micrograms intravenously (iv)
C. Start an isoprenaline infusion
D. Get a second iv access
E. Re-intubate the patient

Correct Answer: A

You have watched the anaesthetist anaesthetise a patient for a laparoscopic appendicectomy using thiopentone and suxamethonium. She has never had an anaesthetic before. The patient is transferred from the anaesthetic room into theatre and you notice that she becomes difficult to ventilate with high airway pressures. She has an endotracheal tube (ETT) in situ, with equal chest rise and sats of 95% on 15 l of oxygen. On examining her cardiovascular system, she has a heart rate of 110 bpm with a blood pressure of 68/45 mmHg. She has an erythematous rash across her chest and face.
What is your first line of action?

A. 0.5 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline intramuscularly (im)
B. 0.5 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline intravenously (iv)
C. 1 ml of 1 : 10 000 adrenaline im
D. 1 ml of 1 : 10 000 adrenaline iv
E. 10 mg of chlorphenamine and 200 mg of hydrocortisone iv

Correct Answer: A

An elderly man presents with an intermittent frontal headache associated with pain around his right eye which looks slightly red. He describes episodes occurring while he watches television in the evening, during which he sees haloes around lights in the room. On examination, there is no tenderness around his temporal artery and his eye appears normal. He has normal visual acuity.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Closed angle glaucoma
B. Anterior uveitis
C. Migraine
D. Tension headache
E. Giant cell arteritis

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old law student, with a history of cyclical pelvic pain and dysmenorrhoea not responding to paracetamol is attending her follow-up appointment to receive the histology results of her diagnostic laparoscopy. She does not want to conceive at present and uses barrier methods of contraception. She has asthma, which is well controlled with inhalers but was made worse in the past when she took some painkillers.
The histology report concludes that: ‘The peritoneal deposits, submitted in their entirety, contain evidence of endometrial glands and stroma surrounded by red blood cells and a mixed chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate’. The operation notes say that all deposits seen were removed.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. A trial of ibuprofen for three months
B. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
C. Further laparoscopy for ablation
D. Hysterectomy
E. Ovarian cystectomy

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old woman presents with increasing early-morning bilateral knee pain and stiffness and generalised fatigue. On examination, she is noted to have flat erythema over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Multiple painless oral ulcers are also noted. Examination of the knee joints reveals tenderness and suprapatellar effusions bilaterally.
Which of these is most specific for the underlying condition?

A. Anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody
B. Anti-La antibodies
C. Rheumatoid factor IgG
D. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)
E. Scl70

Correct Answer: A

You are the F2 in the Surgical Outpatient Clinic and have been asked to see Mr Smith by the consultant. Mr Smith is a 58-year-old gentleman who presents with trouble defecating, and although he still passes his motions normally, over the past month, he has noticed the uncomfortable feeling of still wanting to defecate after passing his motions. During the past 2 weeks, he has noticed he has been passing mucus and some blood but no change in colour. Examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following does the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance recommend as an initial investigation?

A. Colonoscopy
B. Barium enema
C. Faecal occult blood testing
D. Rigid sigmoidoscopy
E. Computerised tomography (CT) abdomen

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, recurrent urinary tract infections and stress incontinence. She is found to have a cystocoele. The woman had five children, all vaginal deliveries. She also suffers from rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. Her body mass index (BMI) is 34 and she smokes 10 cigarettes per day.
What would your first line treatment be for this woman?

A. Insert a ring pessary
B. Advise smoking cessation, weight loss and pelvic floor exercises
C. Topical oestrogen
D. Per vaginal surgery
E. Hysterectomy

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man attends the Emergency Department, having eaten some mushrooms given to him by a friend. He ate them just over 1 h ago and is now complaining of abdominal pain and muscle cramps. In addition, he has slurred speech and is unsteady on his feet. On further questioning, he tells you that various objects in the room are moving where you can see that they are stationary. While in the Emergency Room, he begins to vomit.
Investigations:52 bpm, sinus rhythm
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 132 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 240 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
ECG 52 bpm, sinus rhythm
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Gastric lavage
B. Activated charcoal
C. Intravenous (iv) isoprenaline
D. iv atenolol
E. Ipecac

Correct Answer: B

A 68-year-old woman visited the clinic complaining of hearing difficulty. After examination, the doctor did not notice any obstruction in her ear canals, and no tympanic inflammation or rupture was observed. A vibrating tuning fork (256 Hz) was placed on the forehead and the sound was louder in the left ear. When a vibrating tuning fork (512 Hz) was placed on the patient’s mastoid bone, the air conduction was greater than the bone conduction on the right and bone conduction greater than air on the left.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
B. Sensorineural hearing loss in both ears
C. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
D. Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
E. Conductive hearing loss in both ears

Correct Answer: C

A 44-year-old man is transferred to the Intensive Care Unit after accidental drowning in the sea. He was a fisherman who fell overboard. He was rescued from the sea after approximately 15 minutes. He was pulseless and apnoeic when rescued, and his colleagues immediately began cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) while awaiting rescue services. On arrival to the Intensive Care Unit, he is intubated and ventilated and his vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 86/55 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, oxygen saturations 88%, and temperature 32.4 °C.
In which of the following circumstances is extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) indicated as treatment in cases of drowning?

A. Altered level of consciousness
B. Good response to conventional mechanical ventilation
C. Good response to high-frequency ventilation
D. Haemodynamic instability
E. Persistent hypothermia from cold water drowning

Correct Answer: E

You review a 54-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes. He was diagnosed 1 year ago and is currently managed with diet and exercise, and additional medication includes ramipril 10 mg po daily, atorvastatin 10 mg and aspirin 75 mg/day. On examination, his blood pressure is measured at 129/75 mmHg. Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol is 2.1, HbA1c 62 mmol/mol and creatinine 110 μmol/l.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next treatment step in this case?

A. Commence pioglitazone
B. Increase atorvastatin to 20 mg
C. Commence gliclazide
D. Commence amlodipine
E. Commence metformin

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her partner due to increasing confusion and abdominal distension. Collateral history indicates increasing forgetfulness over the last 12 months and that other members of the family have had similar symptoms although further details are not available. Examination identifies hepatomegaly and ascites. The patient is noted to have a shuffling gait and tremor. Ultrasound of the liver confirms the presence of cirrhosis.
Which one of the following tests would most likely confirm the suspected diagnosis?

A. AST:ALT ratio
B. Serum α-1-antitrypsin
C. α-fetoprotein
D. Serum ceruloplasmin
E. Serum anti smooth muscle antibodies

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old man with tall stature comes to the hospital with complaints of enlarged breasts. On examination, sparse hair with poor development of secondary sexual characteristics with small soft testes was noted. Chromosomal analysis reported as 47XXY karyotype.
What is the hormonal profile of this patient most likely to reveal?

A. Elevated adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and cortisol levels
B. Elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinising hormone (LH) and testosterone
C. High FSH and LH but low testosterone
D. Low cortisol and high ACTH levels.
E. Low FSH and LH, high testosterone

Correct Answer: C

In recent months, a 21-year-old woman has gained weight and developed excess facial hair, and a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome is suspected. A set of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans are being examined.
Which one of the following structures would lie posterior to the left suprarenal (adrenal) gland on the images?

A. Crus of diaphragm
B. Psoas major muscle
C. Quadratus lumborum muscle
D. Transversus abdominis muscle
E. Thoracolumbar fascia

Correct Answer: A

An 11-year-old girl is referred to the paediatrics team with a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain, associated with fever, nausea and vomiting. The pain started centrally but has now localised to the right lower quadrant.
Which of the following is the most common surgical diagnosis in children in this patient’s age group?

A. Intussusception
B. Mesenteric adenitis
C. Appendicitis
D. Cholecystitis
E. Ovarian torsion

Correct Answer: C

A 54-year-old man has the following investigations carried out by his General Practitioner (GP).
Plasma:
Investigations Results Normal Value
Total Ca2+ 1.80 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Albumin 40 g/l 35–55 g/l
PO43- 2.0 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 170 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) 75 ng/l 10–65 ng/l
Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

A. Primary hyperparathyroidism
B. Malignant hyperparathyroidism
C. Chronic renal failure
D. Primary hypoparathyroidism
E. Secondary hypoparathyroidism

Correct Answer: C

A 9-year-old boy tripped while playing outside. He suffered a fall on an outstretched hand and immediately grabbed his right elbow in pain. He was taken to Accident and Emergency and an X-ray revealed a right humeral supracondylar fracture. The skin is intact and there is only minor swelling below the elbow, with normal distal pulses.
Which of the following problems is this child most likely to suffer?

A. Atrophy of the extensor muscles of the forearm
B. Loss of sensation to the palmar aspects of the first and second fingers of the right hand and weakened right wrist flexion
C. Loss of cutaneous sensation over the area over the shoulder
D. Loss of sensation to the right fifth finger
E. Volkmann’s contracture (flexion contracture of the hand and wrist)

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man with type II diabetes, is having his annual diabetes review. During this review it is noticed that the man has a heart rate between 38–48 beats/min. On questioning, he mentions that he has noticed occasional palpitations, but otherwise has been asymptomatic.
An ECG is performed, which shows that on every fourth beat there is a non-conducted P-wave (a P-wave with no QRS complex). Otherwise there are no other abnormalities and the PR interval is constant.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atrial flutter
B. Ectopic beats
C. Second degree heart block – Mobitz type I
C. D. Second degree heart block – Mobitz type II
E. Third degree heart block

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman presents with increasing shortness of breath, weakness, lethargy and has recently experienced a syncopal episode after running to catch a bus. She has known atrial flutter, for which she takes regular bisoprolol. On examination, you discover a high-pitched, diastolic decrescendo murmur which is accentuated on inspiration. She has moderate peripheral oedema. Chest X-ray is normal.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Diuretics, oxygen therapy, bosentan
B. Salbutamol inhaler and an ipratropium inhaler
C. Salbutamol nebuliser and supplemental oxygen
D. Aortic valve replacement followed by aspirin, clopidogrel and simvastatin
E. Increase her dose of bisoprolol and commence low-dose calcium-channel blocker

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man with cystic fibrosis (CF) and advanced lung disease is being considered for lung transplantation.
Which of the following respiratory pathogens associated with CF is a contraindication to lung transplantation, if present?

A. Burkholderia cenocepacia
B. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
D. Aspergillus fumigatus
E. Haemophilus influenzae

Correct Answer: A

A stab wound to the anterior right thorax, 2.5 cm lateral to the right sternal border at the level of the fifth intercostal space, enters the right lung at the:

A. Upper lobe
B. Middle lobe
C. Lower lobe
D. Lingula
E. Cupola

Correct Answer: B

A 68-year-old man is brought to the Neurology clinic by his wife because he has had 3 months of progressively worsening dysarthria, gait instability, intention tremor and memory loss. Electroencephalography (EEG) is performed and is significant for triphasic spikes, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is obtained, which shows an elevated 14-3-3 protein. The patient’s clinical course continues to deteriorate, and he dies 6 months after his initial presentation. A researcher obtains permission to procure a brain biopsy specimen to confirm the diagnosis and contribute to a repository of similar diseases.
What secondary structure would the researcher expect to find in the abnormal brain tissue?

A. Proteinaceous β sheets
B. Proteinaceous α helices
C. Nucleic acid pseudoknots
D. Proteinaceous α sheets
E. Nucleic acid hairpin loops

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) with a 2-month history of pain and difficulty swallowing when eating solid foods and now also has trouble swallowing liquids. He states that his trousers now feel looser around his waist and he no longer looks forward to his meals. His past medical history is significant for reflux disease for which he takes over-the-counter Gaviscon. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and drinks approximately 15 pints of beer per week. His family medical history is unremarkable.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.4°C
Blood pressure 155/69 mmHg
Heart rate 66 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 13 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 99% (room air)
Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the best next step in management?

A. Continue treatment with Gaviscon
B. Histamine-2 receptor antagonist therapy
C. Immediate referral for oesophageal manometry
D. Immediate referral to upper gastrointestinal surgeon
E. Proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old nulliparous patient attends the Gynaecology Clinic, complaining of severe menstrual pain and pain on intercourse. She states that the symptoms have worsened with time. A pelvic ultrasound demonstrates a 4-cm cyst in the right ovary. The serum CA-125 is 225 (0–34 iu/ml).
Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

A. Ectopic endometrial tissue
B. Obstructive appendiceal fecalith
C. Granulosa cell tumour of the right ovary
D. Epithelial ovarian neoplasm
E. Mittelschmerz

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old patient with hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with central chest pain described as ‘heavy’. There is no radiation. There are no other risk factors for atherosclerosis. On examination, vital signs are pulse, temperature and oxygen saturation is normal. The patient looks sweaty, but cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are normal. The patient is tender over the sternum at the site of his chest pain. His resting electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A. Discharge the patient with a diagnosis of costochondritis
B. Discharge the patient if serial resting ECGs are normal
C. Arrange a 12-h troponin T assay before deciding whether or not to discharge the patient
D. Admit the patient to the Coronary Care Unit for monitoring and further assessment
E. Discharge the patient and arrange an outpatient exercise tolerance test

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with his friend after having collapsed during a rugby match. He was reported to have fallen to the ground suddenly, apparently losing consciousness. He was witnessed to have jerking movements of his limbs and to have been incontinent before the episode self-terminated after a few minutes.
He has a past medical history of psoriasis, for which he takes methotrexate once weekly. He is referred urgently to a Neurology Clinic for review. Physical examination is normal, and investigations are detailed as below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 145 g/l 135-175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4.0–11.0 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 4.2 mIU/l 0.27–4.2 mIU/l
24-hour electrocardiogram (ECG) No abnormal rhythms detected
Electroencephalogram (EEG) No abnormality detected

What is the most likely cause of his presentation?

A. Epilepsy
B. Head injury
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Methotrexate toxicity
E. Psychogenic seizure

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old woman presents to the Neurology clinic complaining of multiple headaches. These normally begin above the left eye area, slowly spreading across the head, becoming diffuse and then lasting for a number of hours. Mostly, these are preceded by a period of abnormal vision, characterised by blurring or bending of lines in her vision. She takes the oral contraceptive pill and has no past medical history of note. Her body mass index is 28 and blood pressure 128/78 mmHg. Neurological examination in the clinic is entirely normal.
Investigations:
Investigation
Result
Normal value
Haemoglobin 128 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 342 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 7 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Inflammatory arteritis
B. Benign intracranial hypertension
C. Migraine
D. Space occupying lesion
E. Intra-cerebral aneurysm

Correct Answer: C

A 80-year-old woman with renal failure attends hospital for dialysis three times per week. She presents to the Emergency Department with acute shortness of breath and is found to have suffered from a large anterior myocardial infarct. The medical team decides to discuss a ‘do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation’ (DNACPR) decision with her.
When should a DNACPR order be considered?

A. Where it would result in a lengthy and costly intensive care unit (ICU) stay
B. Where cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is not in accord with the family’s wishes in a mentally competent patient
C. Where successful CPR is likely to be followed by a length and quality of life that are not in the best interests of the patient to sustain
D. Where the local hospital policy advises DNACPR orders in patients over 80 years old
E. Where the patient is in a ventricular fibrillation rhythm

Correct Answer: C

A 10-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the clinic. She has noticed progressive difficulty in eating. She reports that, when she swallows, the food becomes ‘stuck’ behind her chest and that it takes some time for it to pass. She often vomits undigested food. Subsequent barium study shows a ‘bird’s beak’ appearance.
Loss of which of the following mediators may be contributing to her symptoms?

A. Cholecystokinin
B. Nitric oxide
C. Motilin
D. Somatostatin
E. Gastrin

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old woman is found unconscious at home. She had fallen over and is noted to have been incontinent. It is thought that she may have been on the floor for several hours. She is normally fit and well and has no medical conditions to note.
Blood tests showed:
Investigation Results Normal range
Haemoglobin (Hb) 110 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 200 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Potassium 6 mmol/l 3.5–5 mmol/l
Sodium 130 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Calcium 2.2 mmol/l 2.2–2.6 mmol/l
Urea 23 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 289 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Creatine kinase 15 246 IU/l 23–1115 IU/l
Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm, heart rate 105 bpm.
What is responsible for the biochemical abnormalities?

A. Rhabdomyolysis
B. Myocardial infarction (MI)
C. Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
D. Addison’s disease
E. Renal tubular acidosis

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old woman is on the Orthopaedic Ward following a compound fracture of her tibia. She is day three post-op and has had a relatively uncomplicated post-operative period despite a complex medical history. Her past medical history includes remitting breast cancer (responding to treatment), asthma and rheumatoid arthritis.
She has a body mass index (BMI) of > 30 kg/m2, hypertension and is currently using a salbutamol inhaler, abemaciclib, hydroxychloroquine and the combined oral contraceptive pill. She smokes five cigarettes per day and drinks seven units of alcohol per week. She manages her activities of daily living independently.
Blood results from yesterday:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 128 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Chloride (Cl) 109 mmol/l 98-106 mmol/l
Urea 8.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine (Cr) 80 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
You are crash-paged to her bedside in response to her having a cardiac arrest.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Give adrenaline 1 : 1000
B. Initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and continue for at least 30 minutes before ceasing
C. Initiate CPR and have someone call Cardiology regarding pericardiocentesis
D. Initiate CPR, give a fibrinolytic and continue for at least 60 minutes
E. Phone the family and inform them of the events to determine if CPR is appropriate

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old woman presented to her general practitioner with a fractured humerus following a minor injury. She relates that she has been feeling weak, tired and depressed. The following investigations were carried out:
Total Ca2+ 3.22 mmol/l (2.12–2.65 mmol/l)
Albumin 40 g/l (35–50 g/l)
PO43− 0.45 mmol/l (0.8–1.5 mmol/l)
Alkaline phosphatase 165 iu/l (30–150 iu/l)
These results are consistent with the diagnosis of which of the following?

A. Bone metastases
B. Primary hyperparathyroidism
C. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
D. Excess vitamin D
E. Myeloma

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner 7 days after giving birth to her first child. The patient has been complaining of feeling ‘down’ for the last 4 or 5 days. She also describes being tearful and tired. She denies loss of interest in her hobbies, difficulty concentrating, guilt, change in appetite, sluggishness and suicidal thoughts. She also denies hallucination.
Which of the following statements concerning this patient’s likely condition is most accurate?

A. She has postpartum depression
B. She has postpartum psychosis
C. Her condition occurs in about 10% of women after giving birth
D. Her condition will probably improve within 10–14 days following birth
E. The condition must last at least 2 weeks before a diagnosis can be made

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old woman is admitted to the Emergency Department with a paracetamol overdose following a recent breakdown of her long term relationship. She says she now regrets her actions, does not feel suicidal, and wishes to go home. She has supportive parents and a friend who all arrive shortly after she is admitted. Paracetamol levels at 4 hours are below the treatment threshold.
What is the next step in her management?

A. Discharge without follow up
B. Arrange Section 5(4)
C. Prescribe course of N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC)
D. Arrange emergency admission to inpatient psychiatric unit
E. Arrange review by mental health liaison team prior to discharge

Correct Answer: E

De Quervain’s syndrome is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus of the thumb.
Which one of the following conditions is strongly associated with De Quervain’s syndrome?

A. Diabetes
B. Malignancy
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Rheumatoid arthritis
E. Cirrhosis

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with unintentional weight loss and night sweats. He has a history of axillary lymphadenopathy. It is suspected that he has non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
What is the most likely investigation to confirm this diagnosis?

A. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest, neck, abdomen and pelvis
B. Core needle biopsy of an enlarged lymph node
C. Excisional biopsy of an enlarged lymph node
D. Full blood count
E. Protein electrophoresis and urine Bence-Jones protein

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman was assaulted with a cricket bat during a domestic altercation. The attack caused an oblique fracture in the middle of the humerus.
Which nerve is most likely to be damaged during a mid-shaft humeral fracture?

A. Ulnar nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Axillary nerve
D. Median nerve
E. Musculocutaneous nerve

Correct Answer: B

You are an FY2 doctor in General Practice and have been asked to examine a lady who is 32 weeks pregnant as part of a routine antenatal check-up. She appears comfortable and her pregnancy has been uneventful so far.
Which of these should be part of a routine antenatal examination?

A. Symphysis-fundal height
B. Abdominal palpation for fetal presentation
C. Ultrasound scan
D. Fetal movement number
E. Fetal heart rate with hand-held doppler ultrasound

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with blood-stained urine and haemoptysis. Obs: heart rate 88 bpm; blood pressure 170/110 mmHg; respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute; temperature 37.8 °C. Urine testing is positive for protein and red cell casts. Antibodies to the glomerular basement membrane are found on serum testing. A renal biopsy is performed.
Which one of the following is likely to be seen?

A. ‘Wire looping’ of capillaries
B. Splitting of the basement membrane
C. Linear immunofluorescence
D. A ‘lumpy bumpy’ appearance of the glomeruli
E. Immune complex deposition in the basement membrane

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old male presents in clinic, demanding that you figure out what is wrong with his colon. He complains of vague sensations of incomplete stool passage and is concerned he has a malignancy causing obstruction. He reports normal bowel patterns and the absence of diarrhoea or constipation. There is no history of melaena, haematochezia, weight loss or loss of appetite. He has no family history of cancer. Upon discussing your negative findings, he abruptly leaves the office saying, ‘You’re just like the other three doctors I saw, all incompetent and ready to watch me die’.
Which of the following best describes his gastrointestinal (GI) complaints?

A. Hypochondriasis
B. Conversion disorder
C. Somatisation disorder
D. Splitting
E. Acute stress disorder

Correct Answer: A

You are working at a General Practice surgery, and a 25-year-old office worker presents with abdominal discomfort and frequent episodes of diarrhoea with blood and mucus mixed in. He reports feeling as though he needs to empty his bowels, even after he has just done so. Symptoms have worsened over the past 2 months. He has no nausea or vomiting and has not been abroad in the last year. He has not lost weight. His only recent medications are paracetamol and loperamide. On examination, his abdomen is soft, but there is mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant. There is blood on the glove after digital rectal examination.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Clostridium difficile infection
B. Colorectal cancer
C. Diverticulitis
D. Irritable bowel syndrome
E. Ulcerative colitis

Correct Answer: E

An 8-year-old girl presents to the GP surgery with her mother for an asthma review. She is currently taking Clenil® Modulite® (beclometasone) 100 μg twice daily as a preventer inhaler, but is finding she still needs to use her salbutamol inhaler at least 2–3 times per day. On examination, she is able to complete sentences, is not using any accessory muscles of respiration, her oxygen saturation is 99%, her chest is clear, and PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) is 85% of her predicted.
What should be the next step in this patient’s management plan according to the latest BTS guidelines?

A. Increase dose of Inhaled corticosteroids
B. Add formoterol a long-acting beta agonist (LABA)
C. Refer to a paediatrician
D. Stop clenil and start montelukast a LTRA
E. Stop clenil and start salmeterol a LABA

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old nulliparous woman presents to Accident and Emergency, accompanied by her partner. She complains of right iliac fossa pain that started yesterday and has progressively got worse. She feels nauseated and had one episode of diarrhoea. Her last menstrual period was seven weeks ago; she takes the combined oral contraceptive pill for contraception, but is not always compliant.
She is mildly tachycardic at 106 bpm. Pelvic examination reveals a scanty brown discharge and cervical excitation. She mentions she had her left tube removed, aged 18, for torsion.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Laparotomy
B. Laparoscopic salpingectomy
C. Laparoscopic salpingotomy
D. Referral to the Surgical team to rule out appendicitis
E. Single intramuscular dose of methotrexate

Correct Answer: C

You are called to the Labour Ward to review a 28-year-old woman who is under consultant-led care for gestational diabetes. She was induced at 38+5 weeks’ gestation and was started on oxytocin for augmentation one hour ago. She is now having regular contractions, six to seven every ten minutes, each lasting at least 45 s. The cervix is 5 cm dilated. The cardiotocograph (CTG) shows a fetal heart rate baseline of 130 bpm, variability of 20 bpm, accelerations and variable decelerations lasting > 60 s, with a reduced baseline variability in up to 50% of contractions for 30 minutes or more.
Which of the following should be the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Continue with augmentation, increasing the oxytocin infusion, as per protocol
B. Emergency Caesarean section
C. No action required at present
D. Reduce the oxytocin infusion rate
E. Urgent forceps delivery

Correct Answer: D

A 69-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department (ED) by ambulance with sudden-onset severe central chest pain. The pain radiates to his back and down his left arm. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus (diet-controlled) and hypercholesterolaemia. On examination, he is pale and sweaty:
heart rate 120 bpm
blood pressure 100/60 mmHg on the right arm and 80/50 mmHg on the left arm
early diastolic murmur.
A chest X-ray reveals a slightly widened mediastinum, with a normal-sized heart, no consolidation or pleural effusions. Electrocardiogram (ECG) – shows ST elevation in leads I, II and aVF.
What should immediate management include?

A. Thrombolysis
B. Aggressive fluid resuscitation, computed tomography (CT) scan, urgent referral to cardiothoracic surgery
C. Urgent referral to cardiothoracic surgery
D. Limited fluid resuscitation, CT scan, urgent referral to cardiothoracic surgery
E. Immediate treatment as per acute coronary syndrome (ACS) protocol, urgent referral to cardiology

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old patient in the Intensive Care Unit has been on ventilatory support for the last two weeks after a significant traumatic brain injury. A decision has to be made about whether they are taken off life support and whether or not the patient has irreversible brain damage.
Which of the following circumstances is a criterion for the diagnosis of brain death?

A. A ventilator-supported patient
B. Encephalopathy secondary to hepatic failure
C. Hypothermia
D. Hypophosphataemia
E. Sedation

Correct Answer: A

A study is carried out to compare the effectiveness of a new blood test for diagnosing TB, compared to the current gold standard investigation of sputum microscopy. The study involved 400 patients with suspected TB. During the study the sputum microscopy was unavailable for ten of the patients, resulting in them only having the new blood test.
As all patients did not receive both investigations, what bias is this study most at risk from?

A. Spectrum bias
B. Work up bias
C. Loss to follow up bias
D. Reporting bias
E. Publication bias

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old man presented to his GP, his daughter has insisted he goes because she feels he drinks too much. He reports drinking two bottles of wine (750ml capacity) a night with six pints of 5% beer.
(A bottle of wine contains around 12% alcohol)
How many units is this man drinking a night?

A. 18
B. 36
C. 40
D. 45
E. 24

Correct Answer: B

A 5-year old child presents to the general practitioner (GP) with symptoms of coryza. On reviewing the patient’s history, the GP notes that the patient has had frequent upper and lower respiratory tract infections, along with numerous gastrointestinal infections also. She is concerned that the patient may have an immunoglobulin deficiency and would like to investigate further.
Which of the following investigations is required to confirm a primary immunoglobulin deficiency?

A. Patch test
B. Flow cytometry
C. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) typing
D. Polymerase chain reaction
E. Measurement of IgG, IgA and IgM

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old woman presents with acute right upper quadrant abdominal pain and vomiting, which started earlier today.
On examination, the patient is not jaundiced and there is mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastrium. The blood results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 135 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 16 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 6.5 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 65 μmmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Bilirubin 30 mmol/l 2–17 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 112 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 35 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Amylase 210 U/l < 200 U/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Analgesia, intravenous (iv) fluids, iv antibiotics, ultrasound (US) abdomen
B. Analgesia, iv fluids, nasogastric (NG) tube, US abdomen
C. Analgesia, iv fluids, antiemetics, US abdomen
D. Analgesia, iv fluids, iv antibiotics, oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD)
E. Analgesia, iv fluids, iv antibiotics, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Correct Answer: A

A renal surgeon is excising the right kidney of a 58-year-old patient. He makes an incision that extends from the region of the right twelfth rib at the lateral border of the erector spinae muscle downwards and laterally towards the right anterior superior iliac spine.
Which one of the following structures is most at risk in this incision?

A. Azygos vein
B. Costodiaphragmatic recess
C. Inferior vena cava
D. Lung base
E. Thoracic duct

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old man is referred to the Nephrology Department with haematuria. He reports that he has had similar episodes over the last 3 years. However, there are no other symptoms. There is no family history of similar symptoms, but his sister was once found to have haematuria by a dipstick test. He used to work as a DJ but had stopped recently due to hearing problems. He is pretty sure that the continuous exposure to loud music was causing harm.
What is the likely pattern of inheritance of this disease?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Autosomal recessive
C. X-linked dominant
D. No inheritance; spontaneous mutation
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department after falling from her horse. She fell onto her left-hand side and complains of left elbow pain and left-sided thoracic back pain. She is able to walk without any difficulty. She is able to straighten her elbow, but there is tenderness over the olecranon. There is no spinal tenderness. Neurological examination of the lower limbs is normal. Chest examination is normal. She has some mild tenderness paraspinally in the lower thoracic region, but no renal angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals: blood + but no other abnormality. X-rays of the left elbow and chest are both normal.
What is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Arrange an urgent non-contrast computerised tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis
B. Arrange an urgent CT abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast
C. Discharge and ask the patient’s GP to arrange urinalysis at 1 week from discharge
D. Admit for observation under urology
E. Refer to the on-call urologist for surgical exploration of the abdomen and pelvis

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old cyclist, involved in a collision with a car, requires placement of a central venous line (CVL).
Which one of the following is the most accurate?

A. CVL placement is required for the administration of adrenaline infusion
B. A femoral CVL is the site of choice
C. A CVL cannot be used for parenteral feeding
D. A CVL should be routinely replaced fortnightly
E. A check radiograph is required on removal of a CVL

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old woman has been admitted for treatment of lower extremity cellulitis. During your examination, you hear three heart sounds present across all four auscultation sites. You note that the latter two heart sounds become further apart on inspiration.
What is the physiologic mechanism for this phenomenon?

A. Increased return to the right heart during inspiration, which prolongs closure of the pulmonary valve
B. Right-to-left shunting, which prolongs closure of the aortic valve
C. Blood is being pumped against a stiff left ventricle, leading to a third heart sound
D. A patent atrial septal defect likely exists
E. The patient likely has severe hypertension

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man was brought into the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe back pain lasting 20 min. The pain was constant and not exacerbated by coughing or sneezing. On examination, the patient was in shock, with a palpable 8-cm mass deep in the epigastrium above the umbilicus. His past medical history includes a 6-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosed 2 years ago at the time of cholecystectomy. The patient is a non-smoker and drinks 2 pints of beer a week.
Which is the most probable diagnosis?

A. Acute cholecystitis
B. Acute pancreatitis
C. Herniated lumbar disc
D. Aortic dissection
E. Rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm

Correct Answer: E

You are the foundation year 1 (FY1) on the ward with a patient who has suffered a recent trauma. You are concerned about the patient and ask the surgical registrar on call to review them. When she arrives, she is rude, states it is not her problem and refuses to see the patient. She does not document anything in the patient’s notes.
Who is the most appropriate person to report this to in the first instance?

A. The General Medical Council (GMC)
B. The consultant in charge of this patient’s care
C. The hospital oversight board
D. Another FY1
E. The ward nurses

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man with a long-standing history of hypertension sees his general practitioner for a routine follow-up. He comments that he occasionally feels a painful, burning sensation in his legs when he walks long distances and that his lower extremities sometimes feel cold. He has no history of dyslipidaemia. On examination, his temperature is 37.1 °C; the blood pressure in his left arm is 174/96 mmHg, heart rate 78 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He is noted to have 1+ dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally, and the lower extremities were cool to touch. Cardiac auscultation does not reveal any murmurs, rubs or gallops. His abdominal examination is benign and no bruits are heard on auscultation. Renal function tests show a creatinine level of 71 μmol/l (50–120 μmol/l), which is the patient’s baseline.
Which of the following defects is most likely present in this patient?

A. Patent ductus arteriosus
B. Renal artery stenosis
C. Atrial septal defect
D. Bilateral lower extremity deep vein thrombosis
E. Coarctation of the aorta

Correct Answer: E

A 73-year-old woman presents with weight loss and is found to have a serum calcium concentration of 3.22 mmol/l (normal range 2.1-2.8 mmol/l). A skeletal survey is normal. Non-metastatic hypercalcaemia is suspected.
What is the most likely substance that the tumour is producing?

A. Calcitonin
B. Calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol)
C. Osteoclast-activating cytokines
D. Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
E. Parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP)

Correct Answer: E

A 63-year-old computer programmer mentioned numerous recent headaches to his general practitioner (GP). His GP noted papilloedema and pupillary dilation and referred the patient to a neurologist and for further radiological studies, which ultimately revealed a mass resulting in non-communicating hydrocephalus.
In which location would the tumour most likely be found?

A. Internal arcuate fibres
B. Cerebellum
C. Pineal gland
D. Optic nerve
E. Lateral geniculate nucleus

Correct Answer: C

The parents of a child born with a genetic condition are informed that the condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Which one of the following conditions is the child most likely to have?

A. Homocystinuria
B. Myotonic dystrophy
C. Sickle-cell anaemia
D. Phenylketonuria
E. Cystic fibrosis

Correct Answer: B

An 8-year-old girl presents to her GP with recurrent head lice. The GP notices that the child has had several attendances to the Emergency Department with asthma exacerbations, but has not attended an asthma review for several years and her inhalers have not been ordered for several months.
When would a social services referral be indicated in the first instance?

A. If the child has disclosed a recent sexual assault
B. If you feel a child needs to be removed from premises immediately for their safety
C. If you suspect a child is being maltreated or you feel the family could benefit from some extra support
D. Only after discussion with the safeguarding lead
E. Only with consent of the parent and/or the patient

Correct Answer: C

A 77-year-old man presents to the Neurology Clinic with worsening dysphagia. You notice that he has some difficulty speaking, and when questioned, he admits that this has also seemingly been getting worse for some time. He denies any difficulty chewing. On examination, you find that he has an absent gag reflex and had atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue.
What is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

A. Nerve conduction studies, computed tomography (CT) head, ophthalmology review, speech and language therapy
B. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain, routine bloods, speech and language therapy, electrocardiogram (ECG)
C. MRI brain, syphilis serology, poliomyelitis serology, lumbar puncture
D. MRI brain, CT head, lumbar puncture, viral polymerase chain reaction (PCR), fasting glucose
E. MRI brain, ophthalmology review, speech and language therapy

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man is stabbed in the left side of his chest, close to the sternum. He arrives in the Emergency Department looking pale. He has distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds and a low blood pressure of 75/30 mmHg. He is tachycardic with a heart rate of 162 bpm. There is bilateral air entry. The patient becomes unresponsive. You are a trained cardiothoracic surgeon.
What is the best intervention?

A. Bilateral chest drain insertion
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan of his chest
C. Sternotomy
D. Thoracotomy
E. Unilateral chest drain insertion

Correct Answer: D

Examine the picture below:
This 32-year-old man presents with a 1 month history of the above condition.
Which of the following is the most consistent with the picture shown?

A. Klinefelter’s syndrome
B. Gynaecomastia
C. Right breast cancer
D. Left breast cancer
E. Fibroadenoma of the breast tissue

Correct Answer: B

A 64-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with chest pain that has worsened over the past 2 days. She also reported feeling ‘a little run down’ with a sore throat a week ago. She has history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. She reports diffuse chest pain that feels better when she leans forward. On examination, she has a temperature of 37.94 °C and a blood pressure of 140/84 mmHg. Her heart rate is 76 bpm. A friction rub is heard on cardiac auscultation, and an electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST segment elevation in nearly every lead. Her physical examination and blood tests are otherwise within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of her chest pain?

A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
B. Uraemia
C. Post-viral complication
D. Post-myocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome)
E. Chest radiation

Correct Answer: C

An 82-year-old female patient is admitted with confusion and dysuria. Urine dipstick for leukocytes is positive.
Which of the following is the most likely infecting organism?

A. Proteus species
B. Klebsiella species
C. Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
D. Enterococci
E. Escherichia coli

Correct Answer: E

A 61-year-old man presented with progressive dyspnoea and cough over two years. He was previously employed in a ceramic factory as chief supervisor.
Which of the following radiological findings is most likely in this patient?

A. Rounded nodules in upper zones with lower zone emphysema
B. Small numerous opacities in upper lung zones with hilar lymphadenopathy
C. Interstitial fibrosis
D. Lung cavitation
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: B

A patient is bought into the Resuscitation Room. Paramedics were called after he was found face down, unconscious on the road. He smells strongly of alcohol. He has a nasopharyngeal airway in situ (inserted by the ambulance service). There are no visible injuries, except for a small abrasion on his left knee and another on his left shoulder. He is currently on 15 l of high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreathe mask.
In which of the following scenarios is a nasopharyngeal airway indicated?

A. Patients with large nostrils
B. Patients with a normal Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score
C. Patients with a patent airway
D. Seizures
E. Base of skull fractures

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man reports that he has severe headaches behind his right eye that persist for 1–2 hours at a time. The headaches can occur on a daily basis for up to 6 weeks, but then he can go for months without experiencing one. Alongside his headaches, he also experiences reddening of his eyes, and rhinorrhoea. He has tried treatment with paracetamol and with tramadol (prescribed by another doctor). However, they have given him no relief. The pain is so severe that he is unable to get to sleep and if he gets a headache during the day, he is unable to work or socialise.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Tension-type headache
B. Cluster headache
C. Migraine headache
D. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
E. Meningitis

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old woman presents with shiny, flat, red papules over her anterior wrists and forearms. The papules are extremely pruritic and some of them have a central depression. Similar papules are seen along the scratch line at the volar surface of the forearm. The patient is an Emergency Department nurse and has had at least three needlestick injuries during the past 2 years. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay is negative. Hepatitis B surface antigen and anti-HBc antibody are negative, but anti-HBs antibody is positive. Anti-hepatitis C (HCV) antibody is positive.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Chronic hepatitis B
B. Dermatitis herpetiformis
C. Essential mixed cryoglobulinaemiasis
D. Dermatomyositis
E. Lichen planus

Correct Answer: E

A 59-year-old patient is referred to the Urology Clinic after an episode of visible haematuria. Two suspicious papillary lesions are subsequently excised from the bladder wall at cystoscopy, and histopathology confirms high-grade papillary transitional cell carcinoma (stage Ta) on both subsequent biopsies.
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Transurethral resection of bladder tumour followed by a single dose of intravesical chemotherapy
B. Transurethral resection of bladder tumour, followed by a 6-week course of intravesical chemotherapy
C. Transurethral resection of bladder tumour, followed by a 6-week course of intravesical bacille Calmette–Guerin (BCG)
D. Transurethral resection of bladder tumour combined with chemo-radiotherapy
E. Radical cystectomy and prostatectomy combined with chemo-radiotherapy

Correct Answer: C

A woman aged 58 presents with a unilateral ovarian mass, accompanied by a large omental metastasis.
Which of the following post-operative treatments is the most appropriate?

A. Cisplatin alone
B. Carboplatin and Taxol®
C. Bleomycin, cisplatin and etoposide
D. Taxol® alone
E. Carboplatin alone

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year-old is brought in by her friend to the Emergency Department (ED). She is intoxicated, and you understand that she has taken an overdose of a yet unknown drug. Her friend leaves before you can take any collateral history from her.
Despite adequate resuscitation efforts, the patient later dies. You review the patient’s notes and find that she does not suffer from any medical or psychiatric illness and has never been admitted to the hospital before.
From a medicolegal perspective, who should you inform first in this case?

A. The coroner
B. The police
C. The on-call registrar
D. The registrar for births and deaths
E. The pathologist

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old primiparous woman, who is a smoker and has been diagnosed with pre-eclampsia, presents to the Antenatal Assessment Unit at 34 weeks’ gestation with sudden-onset lower abdominal pain, associated with a small amount of dark red vaginal bleeding. The pain has gradually worsened and is constant. On examination, she looks a bit pale; her heart rate is 106 bpm, and blood pressure 104/86 mmHg. The uterus feels hard; she is tender on abdominal examination, and there is some brown discharge on the pad.
Which of the following is the cause of this woman's symptoms?

A. Concealed placental abruption
B. Placenta accreta
C. Placenta praevia
D. Premature labour
E. Revealed placental abruption

Correct Answer: E

An 86-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is referred to the Palliative Care team for assessment and planning of further care.
Which of the following best describes the role of palliative care?

A. Curative care
B. Disease-modifying care
C. Life-prolonging care
D. Pain management
E. Symptom control

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman presents with a four-month history of finding it more difficult to get out of her chair. She also complains of a right-sided temporal headache, which is often triggered when she brushes her hair. A diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica with temporal arteritis is suspected.
Which of the following blood tests is most useful in supporting the diagnosis?

A. Plasma viscosity
B. Positive monospot test
C. Raised creatine kinase
D. Raised whole cell count (WCC)
E. Bence Jones proteins

Correct Answer: A

An 89-year-old woman attends her GP with her husband to discuss advance care planning. She has a background history of a stroke five years ago with dense hemiplegia, ischaemic heart disease and bronchiectasis on home oxygen. She has had multiple recent hospital admissions for pneumonia. She has a very poor quality of life and wishes to be managed palliatively at home for future infections.
Which of the following is needed to make an advance directive legally binding?

A. A list of specific medical treatments the person wishes to have if needed
B. A request for assisted suicide
C. A nominated third party to make decisions on behalf of the person
D. A witnessed signature
E. Written refusal for treatment of mental health conditions

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old girl has presented with acute appendicitis and is undergoing surgery to remove her appendix. The peritoneal cavity has been opened by an appropriate approach. The caecum is visible.
To find the appendix, which one of the following features would be the most appropriate to follow?

A. Appendices epiploicae
B. Haustrations
C. Ileocolic artery
D. Right colic artery
E. Taeniae coli

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man visits you with a very severe sunburn-type reaction affecting his face. He had been working in the garden for a few hours the previous afternoon. You understand he was started on an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection a few days earlier. On examination, he has a very severe erythematous reaction, with formation of a number of vesicles affecting all sun-exposed areas. Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 125 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.1 × 109/l (neutrophils 6.7) 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 345 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 138 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Skin biopsy Necrotic keratinocytes
Which of the following is the most likely antibiotic to cause this problem?

A. Amoxicillin
B. Co-amoxiclav
C. Cefalexin
D. Trimethoprim
E. Cefaclor

Correct Answer: D

A man has been hospitalised for severe psychiatric disease. The patient is unable to form new memories and, as such, is stuck in 1982, believing that the Falklands War is ongoing. He has been hospitalised since 1983. He is unaware of his memory problem and confabulates his story when you try to point out the discrepancies between his stories and reality. He is able to remember everything up until 1982 without any problem.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of his disorder?

A. Conversion disorder
B. Vitamin B1 deficiency
C. Vitamin B6 deficiency
D. Vitamin B12 deficiency
E. Vitamin C deficiency

Correct Answer: B

A 66-year-old man is reviewed in the Cardiology Clinic. He has been taking a cardiac glycoside for atrial fibrillation for years. The cardiologist is keen to use a different medication due to the risks of toxicity.
Which feature of this medication is the cardiologist most concerned about?

A. High protein binding
B. Narrow therapeutic index
C. Pulmonary toxicity when used long term
D. Variable first-pass metabolism
E. Zero order kinetics

Correct Answer: B

A 7-year-old patient is seen in Immunology Clinic. History is notable for recurrent staphylococcal abscesses, particularly affecting the axilla and chest wall, often requiring hospitalisation. Family history is remarkable for two elder brothers dying from infections as infants, but both parents and two elder sisters are healthy. He now takes prophylactic co-trimoxazole and an antifungal agent.
What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

A. B-cell disorder
B. Combined B- and E. T-cell disorder
C. Complement disorder
D. Neutrophil disorder
E. T-cell disorder

Correct Answer: D

A 38-year-old woman with hypertension is planning to get pregnant. She attends for pre-pregnancy planning. She is currently treated with losartan 50 mg daily and her blood pressure (BP) is 132/86 mmHg.
What is the best advice to give this patient in this situation?

A. She needs better BP control prior to attempting to get pregnant
B. She requires no special measures and is safe to attempt to get pregnant currently
C. She should reduce her losartan dosage to 25 mg daily and then attempt to get pregnant
D. She should stop her anti-hypertensive medications for 6-weeks prior to attempting to get pregnant
E. She should switch losartan to labetolol and ensure her BP is well controlled prior to attempting to get pregnant

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old man is seen in your clinic six months after he was assaulted on his way home from work. He was mugged and punched in the stomach by his attacker before he fled. Six months later, the patient continues to have profound and debilitating periumbilical pain where he was punched. He denies any GI symptoms or any other problems. Previous workup and imaging have been negative for any underlying anatomical, neurologic or vascular abnormality.
Which of the following best describes the patient’s complaints in the clinic today?

A. Conversion disorder
B. Pain disorder
C. Somatization disorder
D. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
E. Acute stress disorder

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old healthy man presents because he and his wife have been repeatedly unsuccessful in achieving pregnancy, even after three years of actively attempting to conceive. They are not using any method of contraception. The wife has been tested and determined to be fertile. The husband’s past medical history is significant for being treated for repeated upper respiratory tract infections and ear infections, as well as him stating ‘they told me my organs are all reversed’. He also complains of a decreased sense of smell. His prostate is not enlarged on examination. His blood test results are within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology for the patient’s infertility?

A. Failure of the testicles to descend into the scrotum
B. Age-related increase in oestradiol with possible prostate dihydrotestosterone sensitisation
C. Familial disease causing early atherosclerosis leading to erectile dysfunction
D. Autosomal recessive dysfunction of a chloride ion channel
E. Lack of dynein arms in microtubules of cilia

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman has presented with recurrent respiratory distress over the last 4 years. She has also complained of wheezing at night and coughing up of tenacious sputum, which was occasionally black. Blood reports showed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 112 g/dl 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 12 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophil count 6.0 × 109/l 2.5–7.58 × 109/l
Eosinophil count 1.5 × 109/l 0–0.4 × 109/l
Lymphocyte count 4.1 × 109/l 1.0–4.5 × 109/l
Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) 2800 IU/l 1–87 IU/l
Which of the following is the most likely finding on a chest computerised tomography (CT) scan?

A. Central cystic/varicose bronchiectasis in multiple lobes
B. Bronchiectasis mainly in upper lobes
C. Central bronchiectasis in mainly a single lobe
D. Lower lobe fibrosis in both lungs
E. Diffuse bronchiectasis involving mid-lung fields

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with recent-onset fever and an erythematous, pruritic rash on the trunk and extremities. The rash is predominantly macular, with a lacy (reticular) appearance. She has pain in the knees, elbows, and wrists. The left wrist is slightly swollen.
What is the most likely infectious cause?

A. Human herpes virus 6
B. Staphylococcus aureus
C. Rubella
D. Measles
E. Parvovirus B19

Correct Answer: E

During the Cardiology Ward round, a medical student is asked to examine a 69-year-old woman who was admitted with worsening shortness of breath on minimal exertion. While examining the patient’s jugular venous pressure (JVP), he notices that the patient has giant v-waves.
