Which of the following is most likely to be the cause of a large JVP v-wave (giant v-wave)?

A. Atrial fibrillation
B. Cardiac tamponade
C. Obstruction of the superior vena cava
D. Tricuspid regurgitation
E. Ventricular tachycardia

Correct Answer: D

You are a Foundation Year 2 in general practice. A 37-year-old diabetic woman presents with numbness and tingling in some of her fingers in her right hand. On examination, you find that she has reduced sensation in her thumb, index and middle fingers in this hand. She also has some weakness in these fingers when she tries to flex them and make a fist, and there is some thenar muscle wasting. Her pulse is 80 bpm with a normal volume, and otherwise her skin, joints and bones appear totally normal.
Which of the following conditions is she most likely to be suffering from?

A. Radial nerve palsy
B. Peripheral neuropathy
C. Carpal tunnel syndrome
D. Cubital tunnel syndrome
E. Rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: C

An 87-year-old woman with advanced Parkinson’s disease and dementia is admitted with aspiration pneumonia. She is under the care of your team. You are the FY2. You saw this patient yesterday on the ward round with your consultant. Her pneumonia has not responded to antibiotic treatment, and the decision to palliate was made by the consultant after discussion with the family. The patient passes away peacefully, with her family around her, and you verify her death. You have been asked to fill in the death certificate after your ward round. Her family wish to have her cremated.
In England, which of the following is correct with regard to completing this patient’s death paperwork?

A. Complete the death certificate and the form Cremation 4
B. Complete the death certificate and advise the family this is also sufficient for cremation
C. Refuse to complete the death certificate as you did not see the patient just before death
D. Refuse to complete the death certificate as it should be completed by the consultant
E. Refer to the coroner as this patient was in hospital less than one week

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old law student complains that she cannot fall asleep until 0330 h. She sleeps through morning classes, frequently waking up at about 1100 h.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Advanced sleep phase syndrome
B. Delayed sleep phase syndrome
C. Myoclonus
D. Narcolepsy
E. Sleep apnoea

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old woman comes to you after her honeymoon, complaining of dysuria, right flank pain and suprapubic discomfort.
Which of the following is the most likely organism causing her symptoms?

A. Serratia marcescens
B. Staphylococcus saprophyticus
C. Enterobacter cloacae
D. Proteus mirabilis
E. Escherichia coli

Correct Answer: E

A 67-year-old retired head teacher undergoes a right hemicolectomy for a colonic carcinoma. The mechanism of action of the neuromuscular blocking agent used during intubation and surgery is competitive inhibition at the receptor site.
Which one of the following drugs is a neuromuscular blocking agent that acts by competitive inhibition?

A. Succinylcholine
B. Suxamethonium
C. Neostigmine
D. Edrophonium
E. Pancuronium

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old Afro-Caribbean woman presents with bilateral ankle and wrist pain that has been gradually worsening over the past 5 days. She complains of fatigue and feelings of lack of energy. She mentions a dry cough and shortness of breath on exertion, lasting for more than a year. On examination, her vital signs are within normal limits, except for the presence of a mild fever. There are several reddish, painful, and tender lumps on the anterior of the lower legs. A chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar masses of ~1 cm in diameter.
Which of the following test results is most likely to be found in this patient?

A. Elevated cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (c-ANCA)
B. Hyperuricaemia
C. Elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)
D. Elevated double-stranded (ds) DNA antibody
E. Hyperglycaemia

Correct Answer: C

An 8-year-old boy is referred to the neurologist by his general practitioner (GP). He has a passion for football, but is concerned as his team-mates have been bullying him about his appearance. They have been making fun of him in the changing room due to the spots that he has under his armpits and around his groin. They have also been making fun of his height, as he is the shortest boy on the team. On examination of his skin, there is evidence of inguinal and axillary freckling, as well as 9 coffee-coloured spots on his arms, legs and chest. An eye examination demonstrates iris hamartomas.
What is the inheritance pattern of the underlying disease?

A. It is inherited in an autosomal-recessive fashion; all cases are familial
B. It is inherited in an autosomal-recessive fashion; de novo presentations are common
C. It is inherited in an autosomal-dominant fashion; all cases are familial
D. It is inherited in an autosomal-dominant fashion; de novo presentations are common
E. It is inherited in an X-linked dominant fashion; all cases are familial

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old actress presents with an area of redness on her left hand. The area of redness has grown in size over the past day and is warmer than the surrounding normal skin. The patient mentions that the area is also tender to touch.
Following taking a history and examining the patient, the physician suspects a diagnosis of cellulitis.
Which of these terms is best used to describe ‘cellulitis’?

A. Spread of inflammation around a surgical wound site
B. Inflammation surrounding a malignant tumour
C. Localised inflammation and cellular debris accumulation
D. Inflammation of the epidermis
E. A pus-containing collection at the skin’s surface

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man presented to the outpatient clinic with complaints of involuntary muscle movements of his tongue, fingers and trunk for the past 2 months. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia 25 years ago and has been on haloperidol, with good compliance. On examination, his temperature was 37.7 °C, blood pressure 115/80 mmHg and pulse 92 bpm. Respiratory rate was 14 cycles/min. There was pronounced choreoathetoid movement of his hands and fingers.
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A. Serotonin syndrome
B. Akathisia
C. Tardive dyskinesia
D. Acute dystonia
E. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman attends her regular antenatal check at 16 weeks gestation. It is her second pregnancy and she has had no complications.
The nurse is discussing the results of previous tests, checking her urine and measuring her blood pressure. The patient has no protein in her urine and her blood pressure is 101/72 mmHg.
Which of the following describes a normal physiological change in this patient?

A. An increase in heart rate and stroke volume lead to an increase in cardiac output
B. Blood pressure drops throughout pregnancy
C. A drop in red cell volume causes a mild anaemia, and an increase in clotting factors II, VII, IX and X cause hypercoagulability
D. Functional residual capacity (FRC) increases in pregnancy causing more rapid breathing, and smaller tidal volumes
E. Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) decreases secondary to progesterone, facilitating an increase in fluid retention and an increase in plasma volume

Correct Answer: A

A 42-year-old woman is reviewed by her General Practitioner (GP). She has a background of systemic lupus erythematosus and has recently been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage G3a (glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 45 ml/min/1.73 m2). Her GP notes that the patient has a blood pressure (BP) of 152/90 mmHg. Two further readings taken on separate occasions by the practice nurse also reveals persistently elevated BP. The patient has no past history of hypertension.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for the patient's hypertension?

A. Lisinopril
B. Amiloride
A. C. Lisinopril and losartan
D. Dietary modification and exercise advice
E. Bendroflumethiazide

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old man has been admitted to a General Surgical Ward, following an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for acute cholangitis. The procedure took place approximately two hours ago and went well, with no complications. The patient is now complaining of central abdominal pain, radiating to the back.
His observations are normal. Examination is significant for central abdominal pain. His blood tests are significant for an amylase level of 814 u/l. His pre-ERCP amylase level was 89 u/l.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute pancreatitis
B. Anaphylaxis
C. Duodenal pneumostosis
D. Oesophageal perforation
E. Papillary stenosis

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old woman presents with acne vulgaris. On examination there are mixed comedones and pustules. She has two slight acne scars to her left cheek. The lesions are multiple and prominent but do not extend beyond the face. She has not tried any medications for the acne to date and is requesting your advice on treatment. You note that she last attended for an emergency contraception prescription, which was in the last 4 weeks. She does not use any regular contraception and does not want to commence contraception as she indicates she is no longer sexually active. She says that she does not feel overly self-conscious about her acne but wants something to help improve the appearance of the spots.
Which treatment plan is most appropriate?

A. Topical application of clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide
B. Topical application of benzoyl peroxide alone
C. Referral to dermatology for treatment with isotretinoin
D. Oral tretinoin
E. Trial of oral antibiotics for an 8 week period

Correct Answer: A

A 75-year-old man with a cigarette habit of 30 per day is diagnosed with carcinoma of the lung. The surgeon tries to determine whether the tumour is operable by assessing a number of parameters, among which is the angle of bifurcation of the trachea at the carina.
At which level is the usual location of the carina in the cadaveric position?

A. T6–T7 intervertebral disc
B. The sternoclavicular joints
C. T4–T5 intervertebral disc
D. The joint between the body and xiphoid process of the sternum
E. The first rib

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia and weight loss. Endoscopy shows an oesophageal malignancy of the lower third of the oesophagus.
Which of the following conditions has a recognised association with oesophageal adenocarcinoma?

A. Barrett’s oesophagus
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Duodenal ulceration
D. Partial gastrectomy
E. Ulcerative colitis

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old man, who was previously well, presents with headaches, pain in his back and urinary frequency. On examination, he is found to have high blood pressure. He is suspected to have autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (PDK) after a CT scan.
Autosomal-dominant PKD is most likely to present in which age group?

A. At birth
B. <20 years
C. 40–50 years
D. 30–40 years
E. 60+ years

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old patient presents with a painful lump on their eyelid. This has been present for around 3 days and is slowly enlarging. On examination, there is a smooth, tender lump measuring approximately 3 mm across, arising from the outside edge of the right upper eyelid. The eye is not red; there is no orbital or periorbital erythema, and visual acuity is normal.
What is the most appropriate management strategy?

A. Incise and drain the lesion using a sterile needle in the Minor Surgery Suite
B. Refer the patient to Eye Casualty for incision and drainage
C. Provide advice on application of hot compresses and simple analgesia
D. Prescribe a 10-day course of oral flucloxacillin
E. Prescribe a 7-day course of fusidic acid eye drops

Correct Answer: C

You are asked to review a 35-year-old hairdresser who has visited clinic today. The patient has undergone blood tests after presenting with a variety of unexplained symptoms. One of the tests results for anti-GBM antibodies has come back markedly elevated.
Which of the following is commonly associated with anti-GBM antibody?

A. Antiphospholipid syndrome
B. Coeliac disease
C. Goodpasture’s syndrome
D. Mixed connective tissue disease
E. Primary biliary cholangitis

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man presents, having recently noticed a lump in his right groin, as seen in the picture below. He smokes heavily, has a persistent cough and works as a builder.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Rectus sheath haematoma
B. Femoral hernia
C. Direct Inguinal hernia
D. Indirect Inguinal hernia
E. Spigelian hernia

Correct Answer: C

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents. They give a history of an upper respiratory tract infection over the past few days. At presentation, he is complaining of increased headache. Clinical examination reveals neck stiffness and positive Kernig’s sign.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 18.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 147 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Creatinine 109 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Lumbar puncture Gram-negative diplococci –
What is the next step in management?

A. Urgent CT brain to rule out raised intracranial pressure
B. Intubation and mechanical ventilation
C. Correction of electrolyte abnormalities
D. Stat dose of cefotaxime
E. MRI brain

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old patient with asthma presents to the General Practitioner with a 2-day history of increasing shortness of breath and wheeze. She has no chest pain, no history of fever and has a cough that is non-productive. She takes Salbutamol as required and Clenil Modulite BD. She has not been admitted to hospital with her asthma in the past. Her best peak expiratory flow (PEF) was around 600 (last checked at her asthma review 3 months previously). Today she is unable to talk in full sentences and is short of breath and wheezy at rest. Her temperature is 37.9 °C; heart rate is 90; respiratory rate is 26, oxygen saturation on room air is 96%, blood pressure is 110/84. Her PEF is 180. There is good air entry to both lungs and percussion of the chest is normal.
How should she be managed?

A. Commence a 7-day course of oral prednisolone and continue regular salbutamol, with an Asthma Clinic review in 2 weeks’ time and clear advice on seeking further help, including measurement of peak flow at home
A. B. Commence a 7-day course of oral prednisolone and continue regular salbutamol, with an Asthma Clinic review in 2 weeks’ time and clear advice on seeking further help, including measurement of peak flow at home. Also give antibiotics in view of the low-grade pyrexia
C. Give a salbutamol nebuliser in the surgery and review after treatment. Allow home if her peak flow has improved with a 7-day course of oral prednisolone and regular salbutamol, with an Asthma Clinic review in 2 weeks’ time and clear advice on seeking further help, including measurement of peak flow at home
A. D. Commence a 7-day course of oral prednisolone and continue regular salbutamol, with an Asthma Clinic review in 2 weeks’ time and clear advice on seeking further help, including measurement of peak flow at home. Commence a long-acting β-agonist, in addition to her inhaled corticosteroid
E. Give a dose of oral prednisolone; commence a salbutamol nebuliser with high-flow oxygen, and call an ambulance for immediate transfer to hospital

Correct Answer: E

A 26-year-old woman complains of intermittent abdominal distension and bloating. These symptoms are interspersed with bouts of loose motions that relieve the symptoms. There has been no rectal bleeding or weight loss. Her symptoms have been present for the last 6 months. She works as a manager in a busy office and finds work stressful. She has a previous history of taking a course of fluoxetine for depression/anxiety. Examination of the abdomen is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anxiety disorder
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Diverticulitis
D. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
E. Ulcerative colitis

Correct Answer: D

You went away for the weekend and are driving back to work on the Monday morning. You are involved in a minor accident but are okay although very shaken. You will miss the morning ward round because of the delay caused by the accident.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Go in to work and hope you get over it
B. Telephone a team member to inform them what has happened
C. Telephone the rota co-ordinator
D. Tell no one
E. Hope that your absence in the morning will not be noticed and turn up late

Correct Answer: B

A woman attends at six weeks post-delivery with her baby for the general practitioner (GP)’s 6-week postnatal test. She had an elective Caesarean section for breech presentation and is currently breastfeeding.
Which of the following should be deferred until three months after delivery?

A. Assessing surgical wound healing and/or the perineum if the patient required repair of episiotomy or tears
B. Assessment of mood
C. Blood pressure reading
D. Discussion of contraceptive options
E. Performing a smear test if this was delayed because of pregnancy

Correct Answer: E

A patient with known long-term human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection presents to Accident and Emergency. The ambulance was called by their neighbour who was worried that they did not ‘look right’. When you are speaking to them, they are clearly not orientated to time or place and have weakness in their right arm. They are moving their head freely and are not photophobic. Observations are normal and they are not febrile. They have not recently been travelling abroad. Aside from HIV, they have no significant past medical history.
You notice their most recent CD4+ count was 122 cells/μl.
Computed tomography (CT) head shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.
Which of the following is the most likely central nervous system (CNS) infection occurring in this patient?

A. Cryptococcal meningitis
B. Toxoplasmosis
C. Tuberculous meningitis
D. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) encephalitis
E. Lymphoma

Correct Answer: B

During an ultrasonographic examination of a pregnant woman, the technician obtains a median scan of the 7-week-old embryo and, using the ultrasound machine, places a mark on the most superior point of the embryo’s head and another on the most inferior point of the embryo. The technician then measures the distance between the marks.
What has the technician calculated?

A. Greatest length
B. Crown–heel length
C. Greatest width
D. Crown–rump length
E. Crown–elbow length

Correct Answer: D

A final-year medical student is taking a history from a 62-year-old patient as a part of their general practice attachment. The patient informs her that she has a longstanding heart condition, the name of which she cannot remember. The student decides to review an old electrocardiogram (ECG) in her notes, and from it she is able to see that the patient has atrial fibrillation (AF).
Which of the following ECG findings is typically found in AF?

A. Absent P waves
B. Long PR interval
C. T wave inversion
D. Bifid P wave (p mitrale)
E. ST segment elevation

Correct Answer: A

A 22-year-old university student presents to the Emergency Department after an injury from fireworks. She is complaining of severe pain on her forearm. On examination, her left forearm is pale pink in colour and very tender; you also notice some blisters. You palpate the affected area, and she has no loss of sensation throughout the region.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. First-degree burn
B. Third-degree burn
C. Second-degree, superficial
D. Second-degree, deep
E. Mixed-depth burn

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man has had a 2-day history of passing urine painfully and having heavy penile discharge. He returned from holiday from a neighbouring city three days ago where he admitted to having had unprotected sex.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Ciprofloxacin
B. Doxycycline
C. Metronidazole
D. Fluconazole
E. Penicillin v

Correct Answer: B

This 32-year-old man had a laparotomy for a perforated duodenal ulcer 3 years previously. The resulting scar is shown in the picture.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which of the following is most commonly recognised as a significant factor in the development of this abnormality?

A. Abdominal wounds
B. Family history
C. Increasing age
D. Race
E. Sex

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old accountant presents to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of tenderness in the left breast, associated with generalised redness and swelling over the affected area. She has a fever and has also felt generally unwell.
She is normally fit and well, is not pregnant and does not have any children. Her blood pressure is128/86 mmHg; her pulse is 80 bpm and regular. Her temperature is 37.9 °C.
Examination reveals a wedge-shaped area of diffuse swelling and erythema of the left upper quadrant of the left breast.
Which of the following statements is correct?

A. Mastitis can be excluded as a condition which only affects lactating women
B. Skin changes are not associated with breast cancer
C. Breast changes associated with this condition are likely to be permanent
D. The most likely cause is trauma to the affected area
E. Treatment with co-amoxiclav is indicated

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with abdominal pain, fever and two episodes of vomiting. She states that she has had previous episodes of right upper-quadrant pain with radiation to the right shoulder blade but has never sought medical attention for this.
Her past medical history is significant for obesity and hypertension.
Examination reveals an obese abdomen with tenderness in the right upper quadrant and epigastric region. No jaundice is evident.
Observations are as follows:
Temperature 38.5°C
Heart rate 87 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 19 breaths per minute
SpO2 98% (room air)
Blood pressure 145/86 mmHg
Laboratory results reveal an elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein. An abdominal ultrasound reveals multiple gallstones in the body of the gallbladder. The gallbladder is thickened, with the largest stone measuring 17 mm.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Exploratory laparotomy
B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C. Intravenous (IV) pantoprazole
D. Percutaneous cholecystostomy
E. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old man visits his general practitioner (GP) with a 6-month history of erectile dysfunction. He has noticed his morning erection has been much weaker for a while and he is unable to maintain an erection for sexual activity. He is feeling very down as a result of his symptoms. On further questioning he tells you that though his morning erection is weaker than usual, it is maintained. He also states that he drinks around 50 units of alcohol per week and has been gaining weight recently. He says that he is hopeful about improvement in his current condition.
Which of the following features would suggest a psychological cause for his symptom?

A. Drinking 50–60 units of alcohol per week
B. Feeling tired all the time, low in mood, gaining weight and hopefulness
C. Stress leading to performance anxiety
D. Tenderness and enlargement of breast tissue
E. Previous transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for prostate cancer

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman who attained menopause 1 year ago was found to be hypertensive at a health check. She was prescribed a thiazide diuretic to lower her blood pressure and a statin for dyslipidaemia. After 1 week, she presented to the Emergency Department, complaining of redness, swelling and severe pain in her right big toe. She was diagnosed to have acute gouty arthritis and was treated with colchicine to terminate the gout attack, but she could not tolerate the high doses and developed diarrhoea. Indomethacin was given and her gout attack terminated. She was sent home and advised to take allopurinol for uric acid control. Three days later, she was admitted due to severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and pyrexia. On examination she was peritonitic. Chest X-ray showed pneumoperitoneum.
Which one of the following drugs given to this patient is associated with the most likely presenting complaint?

A. Allopurinol
B. Colchicine
C. Thiazide (diuretics)
D. Indometacin
E. Statins

Correct Answer: D

Following a recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) a patient is started on medication to manage their hypertension, however, they are unable to continue the medication due to experiencing the common side effect of a dry cough.
Which of the following medications is the likely cause?

A. Losartan
B. Bisoprolol
C. Ramipril
D. Nifedipine
E. Bendroflumethiazide

Correct Answer: C

An 86-year-old man who lives alone presents to his General Practitioner with an extensive itchy, red rash over the trunk, arms and legs, which has been worsening over the preceding three days. He has a past medical history of psoriasis, hypertension and high cholesterol. On examination, he has an extensive erythematous rash covering much of his body, with evidence of scaling. He has a normal temperature, a blood pressure (BP) of 110/88 mmHg and a heart rate of 101 bpm.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient, given the likely diagnosis?

A. Admit to hospital
B. Oral antibiotics
C. Topical emollient and steroid
D. Topical steroid with vitamin D analogue
E. Urgent outpatient Dermatology appointment

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old woman comes to the Genito-urinary (GU) Clinic with genital warts. She recounts unprotected sexual intercourse with a number of male partners over the past 2 years. On examination, you can see a number of genital warts around the vulval area.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets (PLT) 204 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) Negative
Which of the following virus strains is most commonly associated with the patient’s condition?

A. HPV 16
B. HPV 18
C. HSV 1
D. HSV 2
E. HPV 11

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man has a history of intermittent constipation and diarrhoea and progressive weight loss over the previous 3 months. On examination, he appears cachectic and has nodular hepatomegaly. He is not jaundiced and his liver function tests are normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cirrhosis
B. Hepatoma
C. Liver metastases
D. Lymphoma
E. Myelofibrosis

Correct Answer: C

A 47-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient’s car was parked in the street when a small car hit her vehicle from behind. She was seated and restrained in the driver’s seat and was not ejected from the vehicle. The airbags did not deploy. The ambulance staff reported that the patient did lose consciousness at the scene but now is alert and orientated.
Her primary and secondary surveys are normal. Her neurological examination is also normal and she has full cervical spine range of motion. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 15/15.
Her observations and blood tests results are shown below.
Temperature 36.9 °C
Blood pressure 121/59 mmHg
Heart rate 67 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
Her computed tomography (CT) scan of the head, cervical spine, chest, abdomen and pelvis is normal. She is still complaining of diffuse, muscular pain throughout her body which was not present before the accident. She is able to mobilise slowly around the ward. She states that prior to the accident she was able to mobilise independently without difficulty and with no pain.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cervical spine injury
B. Fibromyalgia
C. Pneumothorax
D. Rib fracture
E. Soft tissue injuries

Correct Answer: E

A 30-year-old G1P0 woman is brought to the hospital at 39 weeks of gestation by her husband because she is experiencing strong uterine contractions. She delivers a healthy baby with an Apgar score of 8, 5 min after birth. However, she experiences significant bleeding with an estimated blood loss of six litres and is hypotensive with a BP of 60/24mmHg despite aggressive resuscitation. The placenta appears to be adherent to the uterine wall and the surgeons are unable to separate it. It is noted that she was treated with ceftriaxone for a gonococcal infection 4 years ago, although she had lower abdominal pain for some time after.
What is the definitive treatment for this patient’s present condition?

A. Immediate transfusion
B. Oxytocin
C. Hysterectomy
D. Phenylephrine
E. Dinoprostone

Correct Answer: C

A 3-month-old Caucasian baby girl is brought to her general practitioner, as her parents are concerned about a skin lump that has appeared on the left side of her neck. It is non-tender and does not seem to bother her, but it is growing in size. She is feeding well and is otherwise healthy. On examination, there is a 2 x 2 cm, firm and well-demarcated lesion in the left posterior triangle of the neck, with visible telangiectasia. There are no other skin lesions. The abdomen is soft, with no masses.
What would be the next step in management?

A. Medical photography and review again in 3 months
B. Oral steroids
C. Surgery
D. Oral propanolol
E. Topical timolol

Correct Answer: A

An 11-year-old boy complains of tinnitus and pain in both ears, along with decreased hearing. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals bilateral acoustic neuromas as the cause of his progressive decline in hearing.
By which of the following modes is this disease inherited?

A. X-linked recessive
B. Mitochondrial inheritance
C. Autosomal dominant
D. Autosomal recessive
E. Somatic mutation

Correct Answer: C

A 77-year-old man is referred to the Elderly Medicine Clinic with a 6-month history of changed behaviour. He has been hoarding newspapers and magazines around the house and refuses to change his clothes for weeks on end. His wife has noticed that he tells the same stories repeatedly, often just minutes apart. He has a new taste for potato crisps and has gained 4 kg in weight. On examination, his mini-mental state examination (MMSE) is 27/30.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Diogenes syndrome
B. Lewy body dementia
C. Fronto-temporal dementia (FTD)
D. Alzheimer’s dementia
E. Vascular dementia

Correct Answer: C

A 61-year-old man, a bus driver, with a history of angina, is admitted to hospital with chest pain. He is diagnosed and successfully treated for a STEMI, and discharged one week later.
Which of the following activities is permitted during the first month of his recovery?

A. Bus driving
B. Sexual intercourse
C. Operating heavy machinery
D. Vigorous exercise
E. Drinking alcohol (up to 14 units)

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old electrician is referred to the Neurology Clinic with visual problems and facial weakness. He has recently had to take extended sick leave from his job, as he has found himself unable to concentrate for significant periods of time when working with wires at work.
He describes pain and blurred vision in his left eye, which was of sudden onset some weeks ago, and which he had delayed being seen for.
On examination, there is a right facial droop without forehead sparing. There is also evidence of ataxia, and when his head is bent forward onto his chest, he experiences a sudden sensation resembling an electric shock. He has had a past medical history of asthma and previous exposure to tuberculosis (TB).
What is the most likely cause for this presentation?

A. Lead poisoning
B. Motor neuron disease (MND)
C. Multiple sclerosis (MS)
D. Syphilis
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man with known type 1 diabetes is admitted to hospital with abdominal pain, drowsiness and severe dehydration. On examination he has a temperature of 38.2 degrees, and crackles at the bases of both lungs. Investigations show the following results:
Urinary ketones: 3+
Serum ketones: 3.6 mmol/l
Serum glucose: 21.8 mmol/l
pH 7.23
What is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Amoxicillin 500 mg po TDS for 5 days
B. Clarithromycin 500 mg po bd for 5 days
C. Insulin 0.1 units/kg/h via fixed rate insulin infusion
D. 1 litre 0.9% normal saline over 1 h
E. 1 litre 10% dextrose over 8 h

Correct Answer: D

Following a spiral fracture of the humerus playing football, a 25-year-old man develops a wrist drop. He is unable to extend his wrist and his hand hangs flaccidly.
Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged?

A. Axillary
B. Median
C. Musculocutaneous
D. Radial
E. Ulnar

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old man with Down syndrome is brought to see the General Practitioner (GP) by his mother to discuss his acne. His mother takes care of all his medications, as he cannot understand the instructions. He lives with his parents and depends on them to do all his cooking and washing. He does not work but attends a day centre a few days per week, where he enjoys craft activities and has a number of close friends. The staff report he is always very polite and interacts well with everyone at the centre. His mother says he is unable to be left alone in the house and cannot go out on his own without the support of another adult.
Which one of the following conditions does he have?

A. Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
B. Autism spectrum disorder
C. Learning difficulty
D. Learning disability
E. Oppositional defiant disorder

Correct Answer: D

A patient has been diagnosed with a chlamydial infection following a recent sexually transmitted infection (STI) screen. The patient has agreed to treatment of the infection and has no known allergies, however, you are concerned about compliance.
Which of the following would be most appropriate?

A. Doxycycline
B. Azithromycin
C. Erythromycin
D. Ofloxacin
E. Amoxicillin

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old woman is seen by the GP on a home visit. She is approaching the end of life due to metastatic cervical cancer. She is on a syringe driver containing diamorphine. Her family are concerned that over the past few days she has been becoming increasingly confused and still in a lot of pain. Her recent full blood count (FBC), liver function test (LFT), calcium and C-reactive protein (CRP) are normal. Her renal function has deteriorated significantly since her last blood test two weeks ago.
On examination, she has small pupils; her respiratory rate and oxygen saturations are normal. Her preferred place of care and death is home and she does not want to go back into hospital under any circumstances.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate management plan?

A. Admit to hospital: phone 999
B. Continue the current regime and advise the family her symptoms are due to her deteriorating condition
C. Reduce the dose of diamorphine and add haloperidol to the syringe driver
D. Stop the syringe driver immediately and advise her to take only paracetamol and NSAIDs for the pain
E. Stop the current syringe driver and prescribe alfentanil via syringe driver for her pain

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old man is brought in by air ambulance following a crush injury while working on his farm. He became sandwiched between two pieces of equipment at the level of the umbilicus. He has been stabilised by the team on the field and has good pedal and femoral pulses, with no sign of any acute pelvic damage. A bedside ultrasound-focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) scan is positive.
What is the most important initial step in the management of this patient?

A. Angiogram of pelvic arteries
B. Computerised tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis
C. Crossmatch two units of red blood cells
D. Erect chest X-ray
E. Full blood count

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after being involved in an altercation, during which he was stabbed in his lower back. On examination, he has right leg weakness in all muscle groups. Further examination reveals that he has loss of vibration and proprioception on the same side. In his left leg, there is loss of pain and temperature sensation, but preserved motor strength. He has no problems with bladder or bowel retention. His motor strength is preserved in his upper limbs.
With which one of the following spinal cord syndromes is his presentation consistent?

A. Central cord syndrome
B. Anterior cord syndrome
C. Posterior cord syndrome
D. Hemisection of the cord
E. Cauda equina syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 90-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-week history of malaise and severe unilateral frontal headache and jaw pain. She had breast cancer 15 years ago and she suffered from frequent debilitating migraines until the age of 50. She last saw her GP 2 months previously following a fall.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Temporal arteritis
B. Herpes zoster infection of the first division of the trigeminal nerve
C. Space-occupying lesion
D. Tension headache
E. Subdural haematoma

Correct Answer: A

A 66-year-old male in-patient on the gastroenterology ward is noted by the consultant on the ward round to have features which raise suspicion of Parkinson's disease. The consultant goes on to examine the patient and discovers he has all three components of the triad of Parkinson's disease.
Which symptoms are most associated with the triad of Parkinson's disease?

A. Resting tremor, shuffling gait, stooping posture
B. Shuffling gait, bradykinesia, resting tremor
C. Stooped posture, rigidity, bradykinesia
D. Bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor
E. Reduced arm swing, bradykinesia, resting tremor

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old woman, with a previously negative HPV smear, is asked to attend her General Practice Surgery in Birmingham to discuss the results of her most recent smear.
The results letter states 'human papillomavirus negative'.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management, according to NICE guidelines?

A. HPV test of cure in six months
B. Refer back to routine screening, repeat in three years
C. Refer back to routine screening, repeat in five years
D. Referral to colposcopy for an appointment within two weeks
E. Referral to colposcopy for an appointment within six weeks

Correct Answer: B

A patient is anaesthetised for an exploratory laparotomy. They were found to have perforated from a septic appendix. This has resulted in part of their bowel being removed and a stoma formation. The patient has been on the table for two and a half hours. Their core temperature at the end of the operation is 35.1 °C.
Which mechanism accounts for most heat lost?

A. Convection
B. Conduction
C. Evaporation
D. Radiation
E. Respiration

Correct Answer: D

A 56-year-old woman undergoes a radical mastectomy of the left breast for treatment of breast cancer. Following the procedure, her left scapula appears very prominent and has some weakness in arm abduction.
Which muscle was most likely denervated during this procedure?

A. Deltoid
B. Latissimus dorsi
C. Pectoralis minor
D. Serratus anterior
E. Pectoralis major

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) for his routine diabetes assessment. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes one month ago. He also has a history of hypertension, obesity and hyperlipidaemia and smoking. He was recently commenced on metformin, ramipril, atorvastatin and aspirin. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal. The following laboratory results are obtained:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.6 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Glucose 8 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Urea 5 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 78 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s hyperkalaemia?

A. Stop metformin and recheck in one week
B. Stop ramipril and recheck in one week
C. Admit to hospital and administer intravenous (IV) insulin and dextrose
D. Admit to hospital and administer bicarbonate
E. Prescribe a loop diuretic and recheck in one week

Correct Answer: B

You have been asked to calculate the fluid resuscitation for a man who has been admitted with burns, using the Parkland formula. He is a 70 kg man, with 15% of burns as a proportion of his body surface area (BSA).
What would be the correct volumes of intravenous (IV) fluid you would administer to this man?

A. 1050 ml given over the first 8 hours, followed by 1050 ml given over the next 16 hours
B. 2100 ml given over the first 8 hours, followed by 4200 ml over the next 16 hours
C. 2100 ml over the first 8 hours, followed by 2100 ml over the next 16 hours
D. 1050 ml given over the first 6 hours, followed by 1050 ml given over the next 18 hours
E. 1050 ml given over the first 12 hours, followed by 2100 ml given over the next 12 hours

Correct Answer: C

You see an 87-year-old lady who has been admitted following a fall. She had been discovered lying on the floor of her home by a neighbour. She has a diagnosis of dementia and cannot recall how long ago she had fallen. Her observations are normal and she is apyrexial. A pelvic X-ray, including both hips, shows no evidence of bony injury. A full blood count is normal.
Her biochemistry results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Creatinine 210 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urea 22.0 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Sodium 133 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 8 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
What is the most appropriate investigation to request next?

A. Catheter urine specimen
B. Liver function tests
C. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
D. Plain chest X-ray
E. Creatine kinase

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old man has been resuscitated following a cardiac arrest. However, he suffers from hypoxic brain injury, and following stabilisation of cardiopulmonary parameters, he is transferred to the Neuro-Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for further management. His immediate family is anxious and wants to know about the prognosis.
Which of the following could provide the most reliable information regarding his prognosis?

A. Absent pupillary or corneal reflexes at three days after cardiac arrest
B. Bilaterally absent somatosensory evoked responses (SSEPs) at 24–72 hours
C. Complete generalised suppression of electroencephalographic (EEG) waves on day three
D. Extensor motor response on day three
E. Myoclonic status epilepticus (MSE) — persistent bilaterally synchronous myoclonus in the face, limbs and axial musculature

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old woman is admitted to hospital with acute overdose of her lithium medication, which she takes for bipolar affective disorder and self-harming behaviour. On admission, she was suffering from emesis, tremor and first-degree heart block. Her lithium levels were recorded as 3.6 mmol/l and eight hours later, the serum level was 3.0 mmol/l.
How long will it take for lithium levels to become undetectable in the serum from the admission value (<0.25 mmol/l)?

A. 12 hours
B. 24 hours
C. 48 hours
D. 72 hours
E. 96 hours

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man with moderate learning difficulty attends your clinic with his mother. His mother reports that he struggles to sleep at night and often wakes at all hours, disturbing her sleep and resulting in him being excessively sleepy during the day.
He often ends up napping late afternoon, which is affecting his ability to engage with local community services. They have already tried standard sleep hygiene advice.
What would be the most appropriate medication to help with his poor sleep, given the history of learning difficulty?

A. Diazepam
B. Melatonin
C. Promethazine
D. Trazodone
E. Zopiclone

Correct Answer: B

A patient presents to the Emergency Department with palpitations and weakness. The junior doctor finds the arterial blood gas is as follows:
pH 7.5
pO2 12.6 kPa
pCO2 5.0 kPa
HCO3− 35 mmol/l
Which of the following could be the underlying cause?

A. Chronic renal failure
B. The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
C. Addison’s disease
D. Prolonged vomiting
E. Hyperventilation

Correct Answer: D

Healing of wounds is the final stage of tissue response to injury, comprising regeneration and repair.
Which of the following definitions would best encapsulate healing by secondary intention?

A. Healing here involves epithelial cells from the dermal edges, hair follicles and sebaceous glands replicated to cover the exposed area
B. Wounds that are clean, with clear-cut edges that are closely approximated
C. Wounds close by contraction and epithelialization due to tissue loss
D. Healing in wounds that are frequently contaminated or poorly delineated. The skin and tissues are left open for a short period of time before then being approximated
E. Excessive growth of scar tissue to form a smooth, hard layer

Correct Answer: C

A 70-year-old woman attends a spirometry clinic, having suffered with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the last six months on hurrying or walking uphill.
Which of the following results is suggestive of a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in this patient?

A. FEV1: < 30% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio: < 0.70
B. FEV1: < 30% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio: > 0.70
C. FEV1: < 80% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio: < 0.70
D. FEV1: > 80% predicted, FVC < 80%
E. FEV1: > 80% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio: > 0.70

Correct Answer: C

A 5-year-old boy walks with a limp due to right hip pain, which is relieved by rest and made worse by walking or standing. His vital signs are normal. The Trendelenburg sign presents when he stands on his right leg.
X-rays reveal periarticular right hip swelling in soft tissue. A bone scan reveals reduced activity in the anterolateral right capital femoral epiphysis.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. A slipped capital femoral epiphysis
B. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
C. Septic arthritis
D. Epiphyseal dysplasia
E. Synovitis

Correct Answer: B

A newborn baby boy is brought into the Emergency Department by his parents due to his projectile vomiting and failure to thrive. You arrange a blood gas reading.
What is the metabolic disorder likely to develop in this patient?

A. Hypochloraemic acidosis
B. Hypochloreamic metabolic alkalosis
C. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
D. Hyperchloraemic acidosis
E. Hyperchloraemic alkalosis

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old patient is reviewed in clinic. She originally presented to the Emergency Department following a road traffic accident and was surgically treated for a fractured tibia and fibula. She is still complaining of moderate background aching pain at the fracture site and is only taking paracetamol 1 g four times a day.
What would be the most appropriate analgesic to use next?

A. Ibuprofen
B. Morphine
C. Codeine phosphate
D. Pethidine
E. Diclofenac

Correct Answer: A

A 42-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP), complaining of lethargy, fatigue, syncopal episodes and flu-like myalgias. Her mood has been low. Investigations included the following results:
Serum:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 127 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Short adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test:
Plasma cortisol:
0900 h 145 nmol/l
30 min after ACTH 210 nmol/l
60 min after ACTH 350 nmol/l
0900 h ACTH: 4 pg/ml (<5 pg/ml low)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hypopituitarism
B. Conn’s syndrome
C. Tuberculosis
D. Anorexia nervosa
E. Cushing’s disease

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old insurance broker presents to the general practitioner (GP) with concerns that he is having progressive difficulty climbing the stairs. He first noticed the onset of symptoms around six months ago and he has been finding it increasingly difficult to go up stairs, although he has no problems in coming down stairs. He has also noticed that he often trips up and that he feels rather clumsy of late. He has been looking up his symptoms on the internet and is worried that he may have motor neurone disease (MND).
With regard to MND, which of the following statements is correct?

A. MND commonly affects young men
B. Mild sensory loss is common
C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) occurs as a result of degeneration of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and upper motor neurones in the motor cortex
D. Fasciculation is rarely a feature
E. Only lower motor neuron signs are seen in affected individuals

Correct Answer: C

Following investigation for worsening memory problems and episodes of getting lost on his way home from the shops, a 78-year-old retired pharmacist is diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease.
Which of the following is associated with a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease?

A. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) >100 mm/hour
B. Hb 85 g/l, MCV 112 fl
C. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein = 0.5–1.0 g/l
D. CSF white cells = 100–150 neutrophils/mm3
E. Computed tomography (CT) brain scan = dilatation of the sulci and ventricles

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old man presents with a one-day history of a red, hot and swollen left ankle.
On examination, there is an obvious joint effusion.
Which investigation would be most important to guide the immediate management of this patient?

A. Ankle X-ray
B. Full blood count
C. Serum uric acid
D. C-reactive protein level
E. Joint aspiration

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old man, who has a history of modest alcohol intake (15 units/week), presents complaining of arthralgia and erectile dysfunction that has worsened over the past 6–9 months. On examination, he has a deep tan and evidence of chronic liver disease. On investigation:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 145 g/l 135–175 g/l
White Cell Count 8.3 x 109/l 4–11 x 109/l
Platelets 164 x 109/l 150–400 x 109/l
Urea 6.0 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Sodium 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 4.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 95 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST) 65 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) 82 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline Phosphatase 135 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Bilirubin 23 mmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 326 IU/l 100–190 IU/l
Serum iron 45 μmol/l 0.74–30.43 μmol/l
Total iron-binding capacity 6.2 μmol/l 10.74–30.43 μmol/l
Ferritin 623 μg/ 20–250 µg/l
Glucose 8.8 mmol/l <7.0 mmol/l
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute viral hepatitis
B. Alcoholic cirrhosis
C. Excess iron ingestion
D. Haemochromatosis
E. Wilson’s disease

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old woman presents with lethargy and poor exercise tolerance. She also mentions that, over the last month, she has had excessive thirst and polyuria.
Initial investigations show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 78 g/l 115–155 g/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 109 mm/h 0–10 mm in the first hour
Sodium (Na+) 134 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 26.5 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 268 µmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Corrected calcium (Ca2+) 3.02 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Glucose 5.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Which of the following tests is the most appropriate to confirm the underlying diagnosis?

A. Oral glucose tolerance test
B. Chest X-ray
C. Abdominal computerised tomography (CT) scan
D. Serum and urine electrophoresis
E. Serum PTH level

Correct Answer: D

A 5-month-old girl is referred to the Urgent Paediatric Clinic with a urinary tract infection (UTI) that resolved after 7 days of treatment in the community. She was born at term and has been otherwise well throughout infancy, with no history of UTI other than this one episode. There is no family history of note. Development is age-appropriate and there have been no concerns regarding growth. It took 3 days for the antibiotics to take effect and she is now doing well. Physical examination (including vital signs) is normal. Height and weight are both around the 50th centile. Review of her microbiology results indicates a proven UTI due to Enterococcus.
What is the most appropriate imaging strategy that should have been done/ordered?

A. Routine ultrasound scan (USS) and routine DMSA scan plus micturating cystourogram (MCUG)
B. Urgent USS followed by DMSA; perform MCUG also if significant abnormality on USS
C. Urgent USS during the acute infection with routine DMSA and MCUG
D. Urgent USS with routine DMSA; MCUG not indicated
E. Routine USS and DMSA; MCUG not indicated

Correct Answer: C

An 81-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-month history of progressively worsening jaundice. His wife says that she noticed it a while ago, but her husband has been reluctant to come to see the GP. The man does not complain of any abdominal pain and on examination no masses are felt. He agrees when asked by the GP that he has lost quite some weight recently. The patient has a strong alcohol history and has been smoking 20 cigarettes daily since he was in his twenties. The GP refers the patient to secondary care.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Pancreatic cancer
B. Chronic cholecystitis
C. Chronic pancreatitis
D. Cholangiocarcinoma
E. Chronic liver disease

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman who was born and lives in England has received her invitation to attend for her first cervical screening test. She has read the leaflet and has some questions regarding the population targeted for cervical screening.
Which of the following statements best applies to the cervical screening programme?

A. Women who have had a partial hysterectomy do not require cervical screening
B. Cervical screening is offered to women aged 25–64 every five years
C. Cervical screening is offered to women aged 50–64 every five years
D. Women over the age of 65 are ineligible for cervical screening
E. Women cannot opt out of the screening programme

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old student visits the General Practitioner (GP), complaining of intermittent bleeding after intercourse. She also has a yellow mucoid vaginal discharge and occasional pain on passing urine. There is a history of unprotected sex on three previous occasions with different partners over the past few months.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 125 g/l 115–155 g/l
Platelets 175 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Culture of endocervical scrapings: Gram negative intracellular rods
Mid-stream urine (MSU) Occasional red blood cells
Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gonorrhoea
B. Chlamydia
C. Trichomoniasis
D. Mycoplasma genitalium
E. Herpes simplex infection

Correct Answer: B

A 58-year-old man presents with shortness of breath on exertion that has become progressively worse over the last year. On examination, there are signs of early finger clubbing and bibasal fine crackles on auscultation. You suspect a diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis.
Which of the following is the gold standard imaging modality for pulmonary fibrosis?

A. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)
B. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chest
C. X-ray chest
D. Ventilation–perfusion (V/Q) chest scan
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) chest

Correct Answer: B

A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman with a 2-year history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast with axillary lymph node involvement presents with confusion and lethargy. She had nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria and polydipsia for 1 week. Investigations show:
Investigation Result Normal values
Sodium (Na+) 144 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Bicarbonate (HCO3-) 23 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
PaCO2 5.6 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Corrected Ca2+ 3.47 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate (PO43-) 0.55 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Magnesium (Mg2+) 1.9 mmol/l 0.75–1.00 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely cause of these manifestations?

A. Excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) production
B. Bone metastasis and release of osteoclast activating factor
C. Tumour release of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP)
D. Tumour production of 1-hydroxylase
E. Excess calcium and vitamin D intake

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old male with known Ulcerative colitis (UC) reports a generalised itching, fatigue and abdominal pain. On examination, he is found to be jaundiced and his blood tests show a markedly raised bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. An MRCP shows multiple strictures in the biliary tree.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cholangitis
B. Cholecystitis
C. Primary biliary cholangitis
D. Primary sclerosing cholangitis
E. Wilson’s disease

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman presents to the General Practice with lethargy and fatigue. She was recently discharged from hospital after abdominal surgery for ulcerative colitis and is awaiting reversal of a stoma. She has been suffering from profuse diarrhoea and high output from the stoma. Routine bloods are normal, except for a significantly low magnesium level.
What is the most appropriate management to correct her magnesium levels?

A. Intravenous (IV) magnesium sulfate
B. Loperamide
C. Oral magnesium aspartate
D. Oral magnesium glycerophosphate
E. Oral magnesium sulfate

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman is seen in the Surgical Assessment Unit. She has been experiencing mild abdominal pain on and off for several weeks, but now the pain has worsened and is making her feel nauseated, and she lacks appetite. She last emptied her bowels 3 days ago. She has not passed any blood in her stool. On examination, her temperature is 38.2 °C, heart rate 110 bpm and blood pressure 124/82 mmHg. Her abdomen is soft, but tender in the left lower quadrant. Bowel sounds are present but reduced. Rectal examination reveals tenderness only. Other than the abdominal pain, she has no history of gastrointestinal problems and only sees her general practitioner for osteoarthritis. She has had no sexual partner since her husband passed away 2 years ago.
What is the most likely diagnosis from the information obtained so far?

A. Pelvic inflammatory disease
B. Inflammatory bowel disease
C. Colorectal cancer
D. Bowel perforation
E. Diverticulitis

Correct Answer: E

An elderly man presents to the Emergency Department with probable community acquired pneumonia (CAP). The consultant asks you to refer to the CURB-65 score to determine the next management plan.
Which of the following statements is part of the CURB-65 score?

A. Confusion, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of < 8
B. Urea > 7 mmol/l
C. Respiratory rate > 24 breaths per minute
D. Blood pressure < 120 systolic or diastolic < 60 mmHg
E. Age 70 years or older

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year-old previously healthy woman presents with a 9-month history of persistent non-bloody diarrhoea and central abdominal pain. She also gives a history of unintentional weight loss. The patient is not yet menstruating. On examination, she has slight conjunctival pallor. Blood tests reveal a macrocytic anaemia.
What is the likeliest diagnosis?

A. Crohn’s disease
B. Ulcerative colitis
C. Irritable bowel syndrome
D. Coeliac disease
E. Carcinoid syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A morbidly obese 36-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner for review. His main reason for attendance is that his wife is concerned about his loud snoring and the fact that he stops breathing during the night for periods of up to 8–10 seconds, followed by coughing, snoring or waking. Recently he has become hypertensive and is also on treatment for impotence. His 24-hour urinary free cortisol level is normal.
Which diagnosis best fits this picture?

A. Cushing’s disease
B. Essential hypertension
C. Obstructive sleep apnoea
D. Simple obesity
E. Simple snoring

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old woman has had trouble sleeping for three years. She goes to sleep but wakes soon after. Her husband says she does not snore, and she does not claim to feel sleepy during the day. Her body mass index (BMI) is 23, and Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score 27. There are no neurological signs or symptoms.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Depression
B. Dementia
C. Narcolepsy
D. Sleep apnoea
E. Age related change in sleeping pattern

Correct Answer: E

A 18-year-old footballer presents to the Emergency Department after playing a friendly game against a neighbouring club. He put his right lower limb to the ground awkwardly and felt a pop. His knee swelled immediately and he is unable to bear weight.
Examination of the right knee reveals a tense swelling, associated with a positive anterior drawer sign (ie the tibia slides forward relative to the femur).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Medial collateral ligament injury
B. Posterior cruciate ligament injury
C. Anterior cruciate ligament injury
D. Lateral meniscus tear
E. Medial meniscus injury

Correct Answer: C

You are evaluating a new angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for lowering blood pressure. The half-life of the agent is 16 hours.
Which of the following reflects the likely dosing schedule for this agent?

A. Three times per day
B. Four times per day
C. Twice per day
D. Once per day
E. Once every 2 days

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old woman presents with difficult-to-manage diabetes mellitus. She was diagnosed with gallstones a year earlier. She also complains of steatorrhoea and diarrhoea. There has been some weight loss over the past 6 months.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 179 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glucose 9.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Somatostatin 105 pg/ml 10–22 pg/ml
T1-weighted gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): 4-cm pancreatic tumour
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Glucagonoma
B. Insulinoma
C. Somatostatinoma
D. Gastrinoma
E. VIPoma

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old man is admitted at the request of his family due to a 2-month history of increasing confusion and unsteady gait. They have also noted intermittent jerking movements of both upper limbs. He was previously healthy and till the onset of symptoms, had continued to work part-time as a carpenter. On examination, he is not orientated to time, person or place. Myoclonic jerks of both upper limbs are noted together with non-specific cerebellar signs. CT brain and blood work-up for common causes of dementia is normal.
Which of the following tests will help in diagnosis?

A. Echocardiography
B. Muscle biopsy
C. MRI of the brain
D. Bone marrow biopsy
E. Renal biopsy

Correct Answer: C

A 57-year-old man brings himself to the Emergency Department after several episodes of vomiting bright red blood over the last four hours. He has presented many times in the past for alcohol intoxication and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. He currently drinks 4–5 pints of beer per day. He is not compliant with his medication regimen and has been discharged from outpatient follow-up as he has missed many appointments.
His vital signs are as follows:
Temperature 36.6 °C
Blood pressure 113/67 mmHg
Respiratory rate 21 breaths per minute
Heart rate 100 beats per minute
Sp(O2) 99% (room air)
Physical examination is significant for dry mucous membranes, palmar erythema and hepatomegaly. The patient is resuscitated with aggressive intravenous fluids. The gastroenterology team is consulted and they are concerned about bleeding oesophageal varices. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed which confirms the diagnosis of bleeding varices. The varices are banded and bleeding is considerably slowed down.
Which of the following medications is most likely to prevent further cases of oesophageal varices in this patient?

A. Atenolol
B. Ciprofloxacin
C. Omeprazole
D. Propranolol
E. Ranitidine

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old woman presents with an 8-day history of fever, sinus pain and fullness, bilateral yellow nasal discharge and difficulty smelling. Prior to this episode she describes having a minor cold, with sore throat and clear nasal discharge. She has no past medical history. On examination, her temperature is 38 °C and there is mild tenderness to palpation over the maxillofacial area. There are no nasal polyps. Her throat appears normal.
Management of this patient’s condition should involve which of the following?

A. High-dose intranasal corticosteroid
B. IV antibiotics
C. Oral antibiotics
D. Paracetamol
E. Topical antibiotics

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old man died of a large middle cerebral artery stroke. He had no prior medical history. Autopsy revealed his heart weighed 400 g, with normal valves and coronary arteries. The atria and ventricles were not dilated. The right ventricular walls were normal and the left ventricular wall was uniformly hypertrophied to 20-mm thickness.
What is the most likely cause of these autopsy findings?

A. Atrial fibrillation
B. Essential hypertension
C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
D. Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy
E. Tuberculous pericarditis

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man with known long-term chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with increasing breathlessness and wheeze. He states that a week ago, he could get to the shop and back without becoming breathless, but it has got worse to the point where now he cannot leave the house. He has been coughing up thick green sputum over the last 48 hours and currently he is hypoxic - 90% on oxygen saturations, in respiratory distress and deteriorating rapidly. An ambulance is called and he is sent to the Emergency Department for treatment.
Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?

A. Pulmonary function testing
B. Intravenous (IV) hydrocortisone
C. Await arterial blood gas before commencing medical management
D. Physiotherapy to aid sputum expectoration
E. Nebulised bronchodilators

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old woman with known alcohol dependence is admitted to the Emergency Department following a 32-hour history of worsening confusion. She complains of excessive sweating and feeling hot; she is also distressed as she says that ants are crawling on her body – although nothing is visible on her skin. She states that over the last few days she has completely stopped drinking alcohol in an attempt to become sober.
On examination she is clearly agitated, with a coarse tremor. Her temperature is 38.2°C, blood pressure is 134/76 mmHg and pulse is 87 beats per minute. She has no focal neurological deficit. A full blood count and urinalysis is taken which reveals the following:
Full blood count:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 144 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 105 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 6.8 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 220 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
There are no abnormalities detected on urine and electrolytes (U&Es) and liver function tests (LFTs).
Urinalysis:
Investigations Results
Leukocytes Negative
Nitrites Negative
Protein Negative
Blood Negative
Glucose Negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Delirium tremens
B. Korsakoff's psychosis
C. Wernicke's encephalopathy
D. Hepatic encephalopathy
E. Focal brain infection

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her friends after she took multiple paracetamol tablets as a suicide attempt. She has a past medical history of depression and said that she roughly took 20 500 mg paracetamol tablets about 9 h ago. She is feeling nauseated but otherwise denies any abdominal pain or any other symptoms. On examination:
Investigation Result Normal value
Respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Sats 98% On air 94–98%
Heart rate (HR) 80 beats/min 60–100 beats/min
Blood pressure (BP) 128/78 < 120/80 mmHg
Temperature 36.8°C 36.1–37.2°C
Weight 62 kg. Nil else remarkable on examination. The nurse has already taken some bloods including paracetamol level while you examined her.
What is the most appropriate next-step action?

A. Wait for paracetamol level and liver function test results
B. Commence intravenous N-acetylcysteine immediately
C. Contact liver transplant unit urgently
D. Urgent psychiatry referral
E. Explain no treatment required and admit for 24 h observation

Correct Answer: B

A 22-year-old woman was assaulted with a bat during a domestic altercation. The attack caused an oblique fracture in the middle of the humerus.
Which nerve is most likely to be damaged during a mid-shaft humeral fracture?

A. Ulnar nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Axillary nerve
D. Median nerve
E. Musculocutaneous nerve

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old visits her GP complaining of feeling very hot and sweaty. On examination, there is no significant thyroid nodule seen. Her blood tests show the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) < 0.05 µU/l 0.5–5.5 µU/l
Free thyroxine (T4) 28 pmol/l 9–18 pmol/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Graves’ disease
B. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
C. Toxic multi-nodular goitre
D. De Quervain’s thyroiditis
E. Thyroid adenoma

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old man is seen on a GP home visit. He has an inoperable brain tumour and continues to vomit frequently despite regular cyclizine tablets 50 mg, three times daily. For the past few days, he has developed blurred vision and a headache which worsens on lying down.
Which is the most appropriate medication to prescribe?

A. Dexamethasone
B. Domperidone
C. Haloperidol
D. Metoclopramide
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: A

A mother brings her 6-year-old son to the Emergency Department following three events which occurred earlier in the day. The mother describes multiple events throughout the day whereby her son has been sitting on the floor and suddenly stops what he is doing, becoming somewhat vacant. He would not respond to anything that she said. She describes the events lasting for around five seconds and they end quite rapidly. He is not aware of these events and cannot recall any odd feelings. The mother is very worried and is sure that this is not normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atypical absence seizure
B. Daydreaming
C. Focal dyscognitive seizure
D. Tonic–clonic seizure
E. Typical absence seizure

Correct Answer: E

A 19-year-old student has been diagnosed with schizophrenia.
Which is the most common hallucination in schizophrenia?

A. Auditory
B. Visual
C. Olfactory
D. Gustatory
E. Tactile

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old woman who works in a factory presents with lower back pain. She says that she has had the pain for past two years and that it started gradually. The patient has no past medical history. There is no evidence or history of trauma. Upon examination the patient has normal power in the lower and upper limbs, and sensation is intact. She denies any fever or weight loss and has no significant family history. She is discharged with analgesia.
What is the most appropriate next step?

A. Bed rest
B. Lumbar X-ray
C. Mobilisation
D. Referral to physiotherapy and sign off work
E. MRI lumbar spine

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP), complaining of feeling very anxious, avoiding going out and having very disturbed sleep. Her relationship has broken down as a result of her symptoms. She was sexually assaulted 18 months ago, and her symptoms seem to have become problematic since that incident. She has flashbacks of the assault she was subjected to when she is in a closed space with an individual even there is no physical contact. You refer the patient for cognitive behavioural therapy. She also wishes to commence a trial of drug treatment.
Which one of the following medications should be recommended to manage this patient?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Buspirone
C. Diazepam
D. Mirtazapine
E. Venlafaxine

Correct Answer: E

A 43-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. An intravenous urogram is undertaken.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Large staghorn calculus
B. Ureteric obstruction by stone
C. Ureteric obstruction by tumour
D. Pelvi-ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction
E. Vesicoureteric junction (VUJ) reflux

Correct Answer: D

A screening test for a disease is performed on 500 people. A total of 444 people do not have the disease. Of those with the disease, 50 had a positive screening test result. A total of 445 patients had a negative screening test result.
What is the positive predictive value of the screening test?

A. 89.3%
B. 90.9%
C. 98.7%
D. 98.9%
E. 99.8%

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old man presents with chest pain, 5/10 in intensity, which is aggravated by breathing deeply and improved by leaning forward. The chest pain is not radiating. He has a mild fever but denies nausea, vomiting, cough or haemoptysis. He has self-medicated for a common cold and sore throat 5 days previously. On the electrocardiogram (ECG), there is diffuse, mild ST segment elevation (on leads II, aVF and V2–V6) and PR depression.
Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on physical examination?

A. High-pitched apical pan-systolic murmur radiating to the axilla
B. Continuous systolic and diastolic murmur obscuring S2 sound and radiating to the back
C. Triphasic systolic and diastolic rub
D. Apical opening snap and diastolic rumble
E. Soft-blowing early diastolic decrescendo murmur, loudest at the third left intercostal space

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year old man with severe learning disabilities and a known low IQ is reviewed with respect to his asthma by his GP. The GP thinks that his asthma medication could be changed slightly to help management. The patient lives in Scotland.
Could this patient consent this minor change in treatment?

A. Yes – the patient is an adult and can therefore consent to treatment
B. Yes – it is only a small change of treatment
C. Maybe – it depends on an assessment of their capacity to consent
D. No – only a person with responsibility for the patient can consent
E. Maybe – it depends on whether or not they live alone

Correct Answer: C

A young female presents with worsening fatigue and daytime tiredness that is now impacting on her job as a sales assistant. She has recently been referred to the gynaecology outpatient clinic due to menorrhagia.
What would you expect to find on her full blood count (FBC)?

A. Haemoglobin - normal, MCV - normal
B. Haemoglobin - low, MCV - normal
C. Haemoglobin - low, MCV - raised
D. Haemoglobin - low, MCV - reduced
E. Haemoglobin - normal, MCV - reduced

Correct Answer: D

You are due to transfer a critically unwell patient from theatre to intensive care. The oxygen cylinder is size D (contains 340 l of oxygen when full) and has been running for 6 minutes. The oxygen is running at 10 l/min.
How long do you have to transfer the patient before the oxygen cylinder is empty?

A. 22 minutes
B. 28 minutes
C. 30 minutes
D. 34 minutes
E. 36 minutes

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old woman presents with acute onset of upper abdominal pain and anorexia. On examination, she is found to have firm hepatomegaly, abdominal swelling and bipedal oedema. Some prominent veins are found on the back, with direction of flow upwards.
Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this condition?

A. Alcoholism
B. Sarcoidosis
C. Hyperthyroidism
D. Hyperlipidaemia
E. Acute infection

Correct Answer: B

A 78-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department from a nursing home with fever and a non-healing infected ulcer in his leg. He has a background history of obesity and type 2 diabetes. He reports that his leg was extremely painful but now is no longer painful. On clinical examination, his temperature is 38.6 °C, heart rate 110 bpm and blood pressure 104/69 mmHg. On examining his legs, peripheral pulses are palpable. There is tense oedema, dusky blue/purple plaques and haemorrhagic bullae on his right leg, with an underlying venous ulcer. Palpation reveals crepitus. After taking blood cultures, treatment is commenced with intravenous (IV) antibiotics and fluids.
What is the next and most important step in management?

A. Bedside wound debridement
B. Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) treatment
C. IV immunoglobulin (IVIG)
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the affected limb
E. Surgical debridement in theatre

Correct Answer: E

A woman of 72 presents with four episodes of post-menopausal bleeding over the last 6 months. She is otherwise fit and well, although her body mass index is 38 kg/m2.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Submucosal fibroid
B. Ovarian cancer
C. Endometrial cancer
D. Cervical ectropion
E. Vaginal cancer

Correct Answer: C

A 10-year-old boy presents to his general practitioner with severe pain in the right elbow region. He gives a history of falling from his bicycle onto his outstretched arm.
Examination of the affected limb reveals a normal radial pulse. There is weakness of finger flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joints in all digits, with the index and middle fingers demonstrating particular weakness. The patient has no sensation over the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger and middle finger. Finger extension and abduction are unaffected.
Which of these findings is most likely to be associated with this injury?

A. Loss of sensation over the medial border of the hand
B. Loss of flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint of the little finger
C. Loss of function of the hypothenar muscles
D. Persistent extension of the index and middle fingers when the boy attempts to make a fist
E. Loss of thumb adduction

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old man presents with nausea, vomiting, epigastric discomfort and weight loss over the last 2 months. On questioning, he describes postprandial fullness and loss of appetite. He denies any dysphagia, melaena or haematemesis. He has a long-standing history of heartburn. He has no other relevant past medical history. Investigations reveal iron deficiency anaemia. Endoscopy confirms gastric cancer.
Which of the following is a risk factor for gastric cancer?

A. Helicobacter pylori
B. Blood group B
C. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
D. Higher social class
E. Diet high in citrus fruits

Correct Answer: A

A 37-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP), accompanied by her husband, complaining that she has been feeling her heart racing for the past year. She finds herself to be feeling sweaty and can sometimes experience shortness of breath. She has previously been seen by a cardiologist who did not find anything abnormal with the patient’s heart. The woman says that she finds herself worrying about several things and this has been affecting her relationship with her husband and friends. She has also been experiencing insomnia 3–4 nights every week. The patient has no significant past medical history and has one cousin who suffers from depression.
On examination, the patient has a heart rate of 89 bpm and the GP notices that the patient’s palms are sweaty. Blood tests reveal no abnormalities, including normal thyroid function tests and normal calcium levels.
Which one of the following neuroendocrine axes is implicated in the patient’s condition?

A. Hypothalamic–pituitary–thyroid (HPT)
B. Hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal (HPG)
C. Hypothalamic–pituitary–prolactin (HPP)
D. Hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA)
