E. Hypothalamic–pituitary–somatotropic (HPS)

Correct Answer: D

This 46-year-old woman has a smooth sore tongue and a dry mouth that she says makes it difficult to swallow. She has painful, inflamed cracks at the corners of her mouth. Her hair is dry and brittle, and she has noticed she is shedding it excessively. The appearance of her nails is shown in the picture.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
A deficiency of which of the following nutrients is the most likely cause of these symptoms and signs?

A. Calcium
B. Iron
C. Magnesium
D. Selenium
E. Zinc

Correct Answer: B

A 68-year-old woman with a recent diagnosis of hypertension and atrial fibrillation developed gingival hyperplasia.
Which of her medications is most likely to be responsible for this?

A. Carvedilol
B. Digoxin
C. Lisinopril
D. Nifedipine
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman with bipolar affective disorder is brought to casualty by her son after being found at home with two empty bottles of her prescribed medication (lithium) by her side. She is believed to have taken the tablets several hours ago. No other tablets were found at the scene.
She is Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) 14/15 and is haemodynamically stable.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Serum lithium level 5.9 mmol/l Therapeutic range: 0.4–1.0 mol/l
Haemoglobin 123 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 199 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 28 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 550 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Which one of the following is the treatment of choice?

A. Oral charcoal
B. Intravenous (IV) sodium bicarbonate
C. Set up IV infusion (IVI) of furosemide
D. Commence haemodialysis
E. Commence IVI of human immunoglobulin (IgG)

Correct Answer: D

An otherwise healthy 64-year-old woman with an unremarkable medical history has had increasing back pain and right hip pain for the last 3 years. The pain is worse at the end of the day. On physical examination, bony enlargement of the distal interphalangeal joints is noted. A radiograph of the spine reveals the presence of prominent osteophytes involving the vertebral bodies. There is sclerosis with narrowing of the joint space at the right acetabulum seen on a radiograph of the pelvis. No biochemical abnormalities were detected on blood tests.
Which of the following conditions is most likely to be affecting this patient?

A. Rheumatoid arthritis
B. Gout
C. Osteomyelitis
D. Osteoarthritis
E. Pseudogout

Correct Answer: D

You are on call in the Emergency Department when an ambulance brings in a homeless man who was found unconscious in an alley, clutching an empty bottle of vodka. On physical examination, he is febrile with a heart rate of 110 bpm, blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg and pulse oximetry of 89% on room air. You hear crackles in the right lower lung base and note dullness to percussion in those areas. His breath is intensely malodorous, and there appears to be dried vomit in his beard.
What is the most likely organism causing his pneumonia?

A. Streptococcus pneumoniae
B. Staphylococcus aureus
C. Mixed anaerobes
D. Legionella pneumophila
E. Chlamydia pneumoniae

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old woman is referred to hospital for severe recurrent chest pain related to mealtimes. She had had these episodes during the last 3 years, especially when ‘food got stuck in her chest’. They were not related to activity or exertion. She also complained of occasional nocturnal coughs and regurgitation. A chest X-ray done during one of the episodes of chest pain showed a widened mediastinum. There were no other bowel problems and no abdominal pain. She was given a trial of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), but there was no relief.
What is the best test to confirm the diagnosis of the underlying disease?

A. Endoscopy with biopsy
B. Baruim swallow study
C. Oesophageal pH monitoring
D. Oesophageal manometry study
E. Computer tomography (CT) scan of the thorax

Correct Answer: D

A 14-year-old presents with a tender, pea-sized lump in the upper pole of his left testis. He says it has developed gradually over the last 24 hours. His mum states that his grandfather died of testicular cancer at just 45 years of age. Other than pain from the lump, he says he feels generally well in himself. On examination, the lump does not transilluminate and feels regular. There is no associated oedema or erythema.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Testicular torsion
B. Varicocele
C. Testicular teratoma
D. Epididymal cyst
E. Torsion of the testicular appendage

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old woman is to undergo splenectomy for an enlarged spleen. The consultant warns his registrar that, while performing splenectomy, he must identify the tail of the pancreas to avoid postoperative pancreatic fistula.
At the time of splenectomy, where must the tail of the pancreas be identified?

A. Transverse mesocolon
B. Gastrocolic ligament
C. Gastrosplenic ligament
D. Phrenicocolic ligament
E. Splenorenal ligament

Correct Answer: E

A mother attends the eye casualty with her 12-year-old son who has developed a red eye. The mother says that the red eye started about a day ago. The child does not have decreased visual acuity but claims that his eyes feel itchy. He recently had a cold sore with runny nose and mild temperature. The boy is otherwise healthy and has been developing normally, and he does not have any swallowing difficulties. He does not suffer from any other conditions and does not have any allergies. There is no discharge seen and the eye lids are not sticky.
Which of the following medication is the most appropriate to treat this patient’s condition?

A. Warm compresses and lubricating eye drops
B. Oral aciclovir
C. Chloramphenicol
D. Sodium cromoglycate
E. Prednisolone drops

Correct Answer: A

A 43-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-month history of post-coital bleeding, vaginal discomfort and intermittent vaginal discharge. She feels lethargic and reports unintentional weight loss. She is a single mother of two children and lives in shared accommodation with one other family. She is a smoker of 30 cigarettes a day. She has not engaged with the cervical screening programme.
Examination reveals a white lump on the cervix, associated with surface ulceration.
Cervical carcinoma is suspected.
Which of the following is a risk factor for developing cervical carcinoma?

A. Late menopause
B. Nulliparity
C. Obesity
D. Progesterone-only contraceptive pill
E. Smoking

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old male patient is admitted complaining of severe abdominal pain. He is diagnosed with mesenteric vascular occlusion. The small bowel becomes gangrenous and resection is performed.
Which one of the following is a complication of this procedure?

A. Constipation
B. Scurvy
C. Weight gain
D. Nephrolithiasis
E. Achlorhydria

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old woman presents for review, complaining of pain in her knees. There is also stiffness in her fingers and she finds it difficult to use her computer. There is a history of hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine 10 mg, and type II diabetes, for which she takes metformin. She had been given a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis some years ago but has had no recent symptoms. On examination, she has a body mass index (BMI) of 36; blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, and she has swelling and bony deformity of both knees. There is crepitus and anterior knee pain on flexion. Examination of the hands reveals Heberden’s nodes.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/dl 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 231 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 14 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Rheumatoid factor Negative
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 125 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
X-ray of both knees reveals reduced joint space, subchondral sclerosis and cyst formation and osteophytes within the joint space.
Which of the following fits best with the diagnosis?

A. Rheumatoid arthritis
B. Seronegative arthritis
C. Enteropathic arthropathy
D. Osteoarthritis
E. Osteoporosis

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a severe exacerbation of asthma. Despite full intervention, being intubated and ventilated, she fails to respond to treatment and continues to steadily deteriorate. It is believed that the patient is now brain dead.
The patient is unconscious, fails to respond to outside stimulation and it is believed that her heart rate and breathing are only being maintained by the ventilator. The patient has agreed in the past to be an organ donor, and brainstem death verification is sought. The consultant with seven years’ experience is present to certify brainstem death; however, a further person is needed for the process.
Which of the following people is most appropriate to certify brainstem death along with the consultant?

A. The foundation year 2 (FY2) doctor on ICU
B. A nurse who has been practising for seven years
C. An ST4 doctor with five years full GMC registration
D. The next of kin of the patient
E. The coroner

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old street cleaner presents to your Vascular Outpatient Department with a 3-week history of two large ulcers above the medial malleolus of the right leg. They have a sloping edge and normal sensation. The surrounding skin is pigmented and oedematous. There is no calf tenderness. Foot pulses are normal. There is normal sensation and motion of the foot.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Arterial ulcers
B. Curling’s ulcers
C. Marjolin’s ulcers
D. Neuropathic ulcers
E. Venous ulcers

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old boy with a thalassaemia major, treated with regular blood transfusions, was put on the transplant waiting list for a cardiac transplant for chronic heart failure.
What is the most likely cause of heart failure in this boy?

A. Acute haemolytic transfusion reaction
B. High-output cardiac failure secondary to anaemia
C. Pulmonary oedema
D. Transfusion haemosiderosis
E. Tranfusion-related bacterial endocarditis

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of heavy menses since she started menstruating at the age of 12. She has regular periods every 28 days, which last for six days, during which time she works from home as she needs to change pads every 1–2 hours.
She is in a relationship and does not wish to conceive at present. A full blood count and a pelvic ultrasound are abnormal.
You offer her the levonorgestrel intrauterine system (IUS), as per the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines.
Which of the following is a contraindication to the insertion of levonorgestrel IUS?

A. Breastfeeding
B. Nulliparity
C. Distorted fibroid uterus
D. Migraine with aura
E. History of venous thromboembolism

Correct Answer: C

A 53-year old presents with shortness of breath. A high-resolution computerised tomography (CT) scan of the chest is performed and an air-crescent sign is seen.
Which of the following organisms is typically associated with this sign?

A. Aspergillus
B. Mycobacterium avium intracellulare
C. Staphylococcus aureus
D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
E. Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Correct Answer: A

A 57-year-old woman has become hypotensive and tachycardic, 2 hours following a laparoscopic partial gastrectomy for a distal gastric tumour. Her blood gases reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.28 7.35–7.45
pCO2 7.1 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
pO2 8.0 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
Bicarbonate 29 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Base excess 5 mmol/l –2.0 to +2.0 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis which fits these results?

A. Hypoventilation
B. Pulmonary embolus
C. Pulmonary oedema
D. CO2 absorption from pneumoperitoneum
E. Lung atelectasis

Correct Answer: A

You work in A&E in a hospital located in Scotland. A 9-year-old boy is brought in by ambulance with a stick lodged in his upper thigh, very close to the femoral artery. He is accompanied by his father, who reports that they were riding bikes through woodland and the boy fell off into a pile of wood. The boy confirms this. On examination, it is clear that surgery will be needed to remove the stick. Whilst talking to the boy and his father, it becomes clear that the father and mother are divorced, though both live locally, and the boy’s main residence is with the mother. However, the boy is staying at his father’s house for two weeks whilst his mother is in Singapore for a conference. The mother is uncontactable for the next ten hours whilst on an aircraft. With discrete questioning, you find out that they were married for ten years and divorced two years ago. Surgery is needed urgently due to the risk of perforating the femoral artery, and to reduce the risk of serious infection.
Both the patient and his father are consenting. Is this sufficient consent?

A. Yes – the father, having been married to the boy’s mother, has parental responsibility and can therefore give consent
B. Yes – the father can give consent because he is looking after the boy with permission from the mother
C. No – the boy spends more time with his mother, so she is his legal guardian
D. No – the consent of both parents is required
E. Consent is irrelevant – it is in the boy’s best interest to perform the surgery

Correct Answer: A

A 34-year-old woman presents with severe vomiting to the Emergency Department. She was given a course of antibiotics a few days earlier (ampicillin and metronidazole) for a tooth abscess. You understand that she has had a few glasses of wine earlier in the day for a friend’s birthday.
Investigations: Urine 1+ blood, no protein
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 160 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 10.4 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her vomiting?

A. Acute alcohol intoxication
B. Disulfiram reaction
C. Viral gastroenteritis
D. Bacterial gastroenteritis
E. Gram negative sepsis

Correct Answer: B

A 3-year-old girl presents her General Practitioner accompanied by her parents. They are worried that she has been experiencing excessive thirst and needing to go to the toilet to urinate a lot more often than usual. There is suspicion this may be a case of diabetes insipidus. When investigating the type of diabetes insipidus, it is found that her symptoms are unresponsive to a vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone (ADH)) analogue.
Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate in the management of this child?

A. Bumetanide
B. Chlorothiazide
C. Desmopressin
D. Insulin
E. Terlipressin

Correct Answer: B

A 71-year-old pet shop owner presents with a long-standing cough and exertional dyspnoea. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest shows a ground-glass appearance.
What is the most commonly associated mechanism underlying this reaction?

A. Type I hypersensitivity reaction
B. Type II hypersensitivity reaction
C. Type III hypersensitivity reaction
D. Type IV hypersensitivity reaction
E. Anaphylaxis

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department after consuming 30 tablets of warfarin which belonged to her mother. She has diarrhoea but has no mucosal bleeding. She admits to previously attending a psychiatric unit for self-harming behaviour. She has no remarkable medical history. Her mother has a history of recurrent venous thrombosis for which she is taking warfarin.
What will the patient’s coagulation screen likely be?

A. Decreased factor VIII levels
B. Elevated prothrombin time, international normalised ratio, activated partial thromboplastin time and normal platelet counts
C. Elevated activated partial thromboplastin time and normal prothrombin time, international normalised ratio, platelet counts
D. Elevated fibrinogen levels
E. Thrombocytopenia with normal prothrombin time, international normalised ratio, activated partial thromboplastin time

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year-old woman attends your GP clinic with her mother to discuss contraceptive options. She is experiencing heavy periods but does not wish to have an invasive method. Other medical history includes migraine with aura.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice?

A. Combined oral contraceptive (COC) pill
B. Intrauterine system (IUS)
C. Progesterone only contraceptive pill (POCP)
D. Contraceptive implant
E. Condoms

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old man is undergoing coronary bypass surgery. To gain access to his thoracic cavity, the surgeon divides the patient’s sternum in the midline.
Which of the following vessels lies closest to the posterior aspect of the manubrium of the sternum at the midline and so is vulnerable when this bone is divided?

A. Brachiocephalic trunk
B. Left brachiocephalic vein
C. Left common carotid artery
D. Right internal thoracic vein
E. Superior vena cava

Correct Answer: B

With which of the following signs is the X-ray shown of a 75-year-old patient most likely to be associated?

A. Crepitus on hip movement
B. External rotation of the left leg
C. Numbness and tingling of the distal left leg
D. Open fracture of the left hip  
E. Blood loss and hypovolaemic shock

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old man with known eczema presents with patches of erythematous, pruritic skin to his antecubital fossae, lateral thighs and popliteal fossae. The skin on his left thigh is red and weeping. There are no vesicles present. He says he has been tired of late and wonders if he has had a fever. His vital signs are normal. You decide he has moderately severe eczema on the basis of your examination.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Regular Diprobase® ointment and once-daily hydrocortisone 1% cream plus 10 days of oral flucloxacillin
B. C. Regular Diprobase® ointment and once-daily betamethasone valerate 0.025% cream plus 10 days of oral flucloxacillin
C. Regular Diprobase® ointment and once-daily betamethasone valerate 0.025% cream
D. Regular Diprobase® ointment and once-daily betamethasone valerate 1% cream
E. Oral flucoxacillin alone for 10 days with regular Diprobase® ointment

Correct Answer: B

A 48-year-old woman has diabetes controlled by diet. Her sugars have been running at 13 mmol/l; HbA1c is 63 mmol/mol, and she has a body mass index of 32.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Metformin
B. Gliclazide
C. Further dietary advice
D. Insulin
E. Pioglitazone

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with epigastric discomfort of sudden onset. He has a significant past medical history of hypercholesterolaemia and type II diabetes mellitus, and he is a heavy smoker. On examination, his pulse is 30 bpm; he is hypotensive and has distended neck veins. The chest is clear to auscultation. Initial blood tests reveal an elevated troponin level, and an electrocardiogram (ECG) shows hyperacute T-waves in leads II, III and aVF.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anterior myocardial infarction (MI)
B. Right/inferior MI
C. Anterolateral MI
D. Acute pulmonary oedema
E. Acute pulmonary embolism (PE)

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man with a long history of arthritis complains of progressive gait problems. He has multiple neurological abnormalities on examination of the lower limbs. The upper limbs are neurologically intact, and cranial nerve assessment is unremarkable. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan reveals intrusion of a ruptured intervertebral disc at the level of L3–4. Cauda equina syndrome is diagnosed.
Which of the following is a feature of this syndrome?

A. Urinary incontinence
B. Bradycardia
C. Upper motor neurone lesion in the lower limbs
D. Lower motor neurone lesion in the upper limbs
E. Positive Babinski reflex

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old builder presents to the GP with large itchy silvery white scaly patches on his elbows and knees. He has no previous dermatological problems although his father had psoriasis.
Which of the following is most appropriate to prescribe as initial management?

A. Topical calcipotriol alone
B. Topical steroid and topical calcipotriol
C. Topical steroid alone
D. Topical dithranol alone
E. Topical coal tar

Correct Answer: B

A patient presents with typical symptoms and signs of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). On Hallpike-Dix testing, there is nystagmus to the left when the patient is laid down with their head turned toward the left. You decide to do the Epley manoeuvre.
Which of the following is the correct sequence of movements?

A. With the patient sitting, turn their head 45° to the left, lie the patient down with their head maintained in a position looking 45° to the left with 20-30° of neck extension, turn the patient's head through 90° to the right, turn the patient's head a further 90° to the right so that they are now rolled over and lying on their right side facing the floor and then sit the patient up with the head still turned to the right
B. With the patient sitting, turn their head 45° to the right, lie the patient down with their head maintained in a position looking 45° to the right with 20-30° of neck extension, turn the patient's head through 90° to the left, turn the patient's head a further 90° to the left so that they are now lying on their right side facing the floor and then sit the patient up with the head still turned to the left
C. With the patient sitting, turn their head 45° to the right, lie the patient down with their head maintained in a position looking 45° to the right with 20-30° of neck extension, sit the patient up and repeat with the head turned 45° to the left on this occasion
D. With the patient sitting, turn their head 45° to the left, lie the patient down on their right hand side with the head maintained in this position, sit the patient up and rotate their head through 90° so they are now facing to the right, lie the patient on their left hand side with the head maintained in this position, sit the patient up and ask them to sit facing straight ahead
E. With the patient sitting, turn their head 90° to the left, lie the patient down with their head maintained in a position looking 90° to the left, turn the patient's head through 180° to the right, turn the patient's head a further 90° to the right so that they are now lying on their right side facing the floor and then sit the patient up with the head still turned 90° to the right

Correct Answer: A

An 82-year-old former solicitor is brought in to the general practitioner (GP) by his wife, who is concerned that he may be developing Alzheimer’s disease. She is familiar with the condition, as her mother suffered from it; she feels that her husband is now showing similar symptoms as her mother first did. The patient, however, feels that he is perfectly well and cannot understand why his wife is concerned.
Which of the following is commonly associated with a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease?

A. Word-finding problems
B. Festinating gait
C. Loss of concern for others
D. Increased sensitivity to neuroleptics
E. Personality changes

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with lower abdominal pain. On questioning, he admits that the pain started 6 hours ago as a vague periumbilical discomfort, but in the past hour has localised as a sharp pain in the right iliac fossa, worse on walking and coughing. He has lost his appetite and has vomited twice. The examining surgeon makes a working diagnosis of appendicitis.
In this condition, the periumbilical pain is relayed by afferents to the spinal cord at the level of which of the following dermatomes?

A. L1
B. T6
C. T8
D. T10
E. T12

Correct Answer: D

A 15-year-old boy is found after being stabbed during a street fight. He has a stab wound on the left side of his chest to the 5th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line. His blood pressure reads 70 mmHg systolic, his heart sounds are muffled and his neck veins are distended.
Which of the following is best to describe the condition of the above?

A. Courvoisier’s law
B. Beck’s triad
C. Meigs syndrome
D. Cushing’s syndrome
E. Charcot’s triad

Correct Answer: B

A 48-year-old Caucasian man was diagnosed with diabetes a few years ago. Today he presented to his physician, complaining of palpitations. Physical examination reveals a diffuse darkening of his skin and also testicular atrophy. Blood work reveals elevated liver function tests and elevated blood sugar levels. A liver biopsy is undertaken and reveals significantly elevated iron levels. A diagnosis of hereditary haemochromatosis is made.
Which one of the following laboratory findings is seen in hereditary haemochromatosis?

A. Decreased serum caeruloplasmin levels
B. Decreased serum ferritin
C. Decreased serum iron
D. Decreased total iron-binding capacity
E. Decreased transferrin saturation

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old primiparous woman has her first health visitor appointment. She is currently exclusively breastfeeding; however, she explains that she has sore, cracked nipples. She has been using nipple shields, and these have not improved her symptoms. The woman also reports she is worried her baby is not feeding enough, as she often has to stop the feed due to tenderness.
On examination of the nipples, you notice small surface cracks, but no exudate or erythema.
Which of the following should be the first step in this patient’s management?

A. Advise the patient to continue the use of nipple shields
B. Advise the patient to consider expressing breast milk and feeding the baby from the bottle until the cracks heal
C. Advise the patient to reduce the duration of feeds
D. Prescribe miconazole topical cream
E. Prescribe topical fusidic acid

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old woman presents for her routine anatomy ultrasound scan at 20 weeks’ gestation. The ultrasound shows severe fetal structural abnormalities, including holoprosencephaly, cleft palate, short limbs, polydactyly, bilateral club feet, enlarged kidneys and polyhydramnios.
What is the likely underlying diagnosis of the fetus?

A. Cystic fibrosis (CF)
B. Down syndrome
C. Klinefelter syndrome
D. Patau syndrome
E. Potter syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of increasing pain, blurry vision and lacrimation in the right eye. He also feels a foreign body sensation in the affected eye. He has recently been swimming in an indoor swimming pool with his friends with his contact lenses on.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/24 in the right and 6/6 in the left. The conjunctiva in the right is red. There is a white dot on the cornea, and with fluorescein, it shows an uptake in the centre of the cornea.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Corneal abrasion
B. Corneal foreign body
C. Fungal keratitis
D. Microbial keratitis
E. Viral keratitis

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old woman comes to see you with fatigue, weight gain and constipation. Examination reveals cool and dry hands, bradycardia and slow-relaxing reflexes. You ask her about medication and she states she has been taking a tablet for her mental health disorder for a long time.
Which of the medications below is most likely to cause her presenting symptoms?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Clonazepam
C. Clozapine
D. Lithium
E. Olanzapine

Correct Answer: D

A 43-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP) to discuss the possibility of starting tamoxifen treatment to prevent breast cancer. Although the patient is well and has no history of breast disease, she is concerned that her maternal grandmother has recently been diagnosed with the condition.
The patient has recently read that taking tamoxifen can help reduce the risk of developing the disease.
Which of the following most accurately describes the mode of action of tamoxifen?

A. Progesterone receptor antagonist
B. Oestrogen receptor agonist
C. Selective oestrogen receptor modulator
D. Aromatase inhibitor
E. Progesterone receptor agonist

Correct Answer: C

A 39-year-old woman presents complaining of an intolerance to cold, constipation, weight gain, hair loss and menstrual irregularities. Her thyroid function tests show a decreased level of both serum T4 and serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Administration of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) fails to bring about the expected increase in TSH.
Which one of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s hypothyroidism?

A. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
B. Iodine deficiency
C. Secondary hypothyroidism
D. Tertiary hypothyroidism
E. T4 receptor insensitivity

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old woman presents with fatigue, pallor and shortness of breath. She has been struggling with an indolent colon carcinoma for the past 4 years. She also suffers from insulin-dependent diabetes, hypertension, coronary artery disease and rheumatoid arthritis. She has been feeling unwell for the past few weeks. She denies any history of melaena or haematochezia and has been amenorrhoeic for decades. A bedside stool guaiac test is negative for any blood in the stool. She is well nourished, reports taking daily supplements and is not a vegetarian. She reports that her haematocrit is 0.27 (0.35–0.55) and haemoglobin level 99 g/l (115–155 g/l).
Which of the following findings would you expect to see alongside a full blood count?

A. Reticulocytosis
B. Decreased serum transferrin receptor
C. Increased ferritin
D. Increased TIBC
E. Macrocytosis

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old fair-skinned woman has a facial rash. She wonders if it is acne. She is upset that it has appeared now because she did not have it very badly during her teenage years. She has erythema on the cheeks, nose and centre of the forehead. The differential diagnosis you form for this patient includes rosacea and acne. You note that there are other lesions present within the area of erythema.
The presence of which one of the following skin lesions would favour a diagnosis of acne vulgaris over roseacea?

A. Comedone
B. Telangiectasias
C. Papules
D. Pustule
E. Crusting

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old woman, widowed for 5 years, has insomnia, anhedonia, frequent tearfulness when talking about her husband and weight loss. She complains of numerous vague somatic symptoms and worries about recurrence of breast cancer that was successfully treated many years ago. She denies substance abuse and says that she has not contemplated suicide but would be relieved by dying.
Which form of psychotherapy/treatment is most appropriate in this case?

A. Psychoanalytic psychotherapy
B. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
C. Breast cancer support group
D. Interpersonal therapy
E. Immediate hospitalisation

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old man with type I diabetes mellitus presents to his General Practitioner (GP). His glycaemic control is getting worse and his GP is getting worried about his compliance with diet and medication.
What is the best method to improve his compliance in a short consultation?

A. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
B. Motivational interview
C. Self-help materials
D. Psychotherapy
E. Supportive counselling

Correct Answer: B

A man presents to Accident and Emergency with a decreased level of consciousness. His conscious state is formally assessed. He withdraws to a painful stimulus and is mumbling incoherent words randomly, irrespective of people attempting to speak to him in conversation, and his eyes open only in response to painful stimuli.
What is the breakdown of this patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. Motor response 4/6, verbal response 3/5, eye opening response 3/4
B. Motor response 3/6, verbal response 4/5, eye opening response 2/4
C. Motor response 4/6, verbal response 3/5, eye opening response 2/4
D. Motor response 3/6, verbal response 3/5, eye opening response 2/4
E. Motor response 4/6, verbal response 4/5, eye opens in response 3/4

Correct Answer: C

This 70-year-old woman presented with sudden unilateral, painless loss of vision that was present on waking that morning. She is known to be hypertensive, controlled by ramipril and amlodipine. Her current blood pressure is 155/80 mmHg. Her pulse is 84 bpm and regular. She takes simvastatin for primary prevention and her lipid levels have been satisfactory. The changes found now on fundoscopy in the affected eye are shown.
Select from the list the single correct diagnosis:

A. Hypertensive retinopathy
B. Retinal artery occlusion
C. Retinal detachment
D. Retinal vein occlusion
E. Vitreous haemorrhage

Correct Answer: D

You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor in Psychiatry. During the ward round, you are asked to perform a mental state examination of a patient who has been on the ward for a week.
In which part of the mental state examination would you report neologisms, pressure, or poverty?

A. Appearance and behaviour
B. Insight
C. Mood and affect
D. Speech
E. Thought content

Correct Answer: D

A 38-year-old woman diagnosed with gestational diabetes that was treated with a combination of metformin and insulin is on day three postpartum. Her medication has been discontinued, and she is ready to be discharged. You are asked to see her to discuss follow-up post-discharge.
Which of the following best describes the follow-up of women with gestational diabetes?

A. A fasting plasma glucose test should be performed by the general practitioner (GP) at 6–13 weeks postpartum
B. A fasting plasma glucose test should be performed every two years due to the increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus
C. A 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) should be performed at 24–28 weeks in future pregnancies
D. A 2-hour glucose tolerance test should be performed at the 6-week postnatal check
E. Blood glucose should not be tested before discharge, as medication has been discontinued

Correct Answer: A

A 34-year-old man presents to A&E with an electrocardiogram (ECG) showing:
He reports leaning forward relieves the pain.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pneumonia
B. Pulmonary embolism (PE)
C. Anterior ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
D. Pericarditis
E. Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old man, who had recently received a full bone marrow transplantation for acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), presented with progressive dyspnoea over the past 2 weeks. There was an associated dry cough, but no fever. Examination revealed scattered wheeze and some expiratory high-pitched sounds. C-reactive protein (CRP) level was normal. Mantoux test was negative. Spirometry revealed the following report:
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) 51%
Forced vital capacity (FVC) 88%
FEV1/FVC 58%
What is the most probable diagnosis?

A. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
B. Bronchiolitis obliterans
C. Drug induced lung disorder
D. Fungal infection
E. Pneumocystis pneumonia

Correct Answer: B

It is Monday lunchtime and you make a home visit to a 72-year-old patient with metastatic colon cancer. She has been getting more unwell each week for the past 2 months and has extensive disease with liver and peritoneal metastatic deposits. She has type II diabetes mellitus and moderately severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). For pain, she takes ibuprofen 400 mg three times daily (tid), paracetamol 1 g four times daily (qds), morphine sulfate modified-release tablets (MST) 30 mg twice daily (bd) and Oramorph® 10 mg as required (prn). Over the weekend, her abdominal pain has become worse, and she has needed three doses of Oramorph® per day, in addition to her other analgesia. The dose is reported to be effective, but the pain returns after about 2–3 h. She is managing small quantities of food and fluid but looks much less well with jaundice and quick, shallow breathing.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her pain?

A. Add in amitriptyline 10mg at night, for neuropathic pain
B. Increase her dose of ibuprofen to 600 mg tid to combat liver capsule pain
C. Increase her MST dose to 45 mg bd, but leave her Oramorph® dose at 10 mg prn in view of co-morbidities
D. Increase her MST dose to 45 mg bd and Oramorph® dose to 15 mg prn
E. Commence a continuous subcutaneous infusion of morphine sulfate 45 mg per 24 h, with subcutaneous morphine for breakthrough pain

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a mass on his tongue. He has a history of poorly controlled human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and is non-compliant with his medication regimen. Examination reveals shaggy, poorly-defined, hardened, slightly raised and rough plaques on the lateral aspect of the tongue. The plaques cannot be scraped with a tongue blade.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aphthous ulcer
B. Oral candidiasis
C. Oral discoid lupus erythematosus
D. Oral hairy leukoplakia
E. Oral lichen planus

Correct Answer: D

A 14-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department following an overdose of alcohol and paracetamol. He was found by his friend, unconscious in the park, after sending a worrying text message. His parents were both at work. When he regains consciousness, he is very embarrassed and states he had had an argument with his girlfriend, now regrets his actions and wants to go home. His bloods are all normal and he is declared medically fit.
What is the most appropriate immediate management plan?

A. Admit onto the paediatric ward to await an urgent Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services (CAMHS) assessment prior to discharge
B. Discharge home with outpatient CAMHS follow up within a week
C. Discharge home with advice to book an urgent appointment to see his GP the same day
D. Start citalopram 10 mg and discharge home
E. Start fluoxetine 10 mg and discharge home

Correct Answer: A

A 37-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 4-hour history of gradual-onset right loin pain. She has a temperature of 38.6 °C, heart rate of 110 bpm and blood pressure of 107 mmHg. On examination, there is tenderness in her right loin on palpation.
Her urine dipstick results are as follows: Blood 3+; Prot +; Leuc ++; Nitrites –ve; Glucose –ve. An intravenous urogram (IVU) is performed and shown here.
Which of the following treatment options is best suited for this patient?

A. Retrograde stenting
B. Nephrostomy tube insertion
C. Intravenous antibiotic therapy
D. Shockwave lithotripsy
E. Cranberry juice and oral rehydration

Correct Answer: C

A 51-year-old man with an acute kidney injury has developed fluid overload and treatment has been initiated. An ABCDE assessment is performed, and the findings are below:

Airway Patent, speaking but confused in conversation
Breathing Respiratory rate (RR) 24/min, SaO2 96% on 4 litres of O2/min, bi-basal crackles heard on auscultation in the lower zones (up to mid-zones on admission)
Circulation Heart rate (HR) 112 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 107/68 mmHg, heart sounds disturbed by a friction rub, ECG shows sinus tachycardia
Disability Pupils equal and reactive to light, normal upper and lower limb neurology, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) 14 (E4 V4 M6)
Exposure Temperature 36.8°C
On initial bloods, the C-reactive protein (CRP) is within normal limits.
The results of initial arterial blood gas and serum urea and electrolytes are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.28 7.35–7.45
pO2 10.7 kPa > 11 kPa
pCO2 5.7 kPa 4.5–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate 20 mmol/l 22–26 mmol/l
Lactate 1.8 mmol/l < 2 mmol/l
Urea 53 mmol/l 2.5–7.8 mmol/l
Creatinine 729 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which one of the following is an indication for urgent dialysis in this patient?

A. K+ of 6.3
B. pH of 7.28
C. Creatinine of 729 µmol/l
D. Urea of 53 mmol/l
E. Bibasal crackles

Correct Answer: D

A 59-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with acute-onset severe epigastric pain for the last eight hours. The pain radiates to the back and has been poorly controlled with paracetamol. The patient has not had this type of pain before. He also has associated nausea and five episodes of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting. He last moved his bowels this morning. His past medical history is significant for alcoholism, epilepsy and depression, for which he is not compliant with treatment. The patient has been drinking approximately 25 pints of beer per week for the last 15 years. He has had no previous surgeries.
His observations and blood tests results are shown below. Examination reveals tenderness in the epigastrium, with no rigidity.
Investigation Result Normal value
Temperature 37.0 °C
Blood pressure 151/81 mmHg
Heart rate 81 bpm
Respiratory rate 19 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation (SpO2) 99% (room air)
C-reactive protein 102 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
White cell count 18.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Amylase 992 U/l < 200 U/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute mesenteric ischaemia
B. Acute pancreatitis
C. Perforated peptic ulcer
D. Pyelonephritis
E. Small bowel obstruction (SBO)

Correct Answer: B

An 8-month-old girl with a fever is waiting with her mother to be seen in the Emergency Department. Suddenly the mother shouts out that her baby has stopped breathing.
What is the correct ratio of chest compressions : ventilations when there are two heathcare rescuers in an infant?

A. 3 : 1
B. 15 : 2
C. 5 : 1
D. 30 : 2
E. 15 : 5

Correct Answer: B

A 36-year-old man is referred by his General Practitioner (GP) to the endocrine clinic after a blood test revealed hypercalcaemia. The man originally presented to his GP following episodes of abdominal pain and loin pain.
A thorough history from the patient reveals that his father had similar symptoms which started at the age of 50 but he later passed away from a pancreatic tumour. The patient’s grandfather also had a high calcium level, but the patient does not remember what happened to him. The Endocrinologist explains to the patient that he suffers from a disease which runs in the family and part of his treatment would involve the surgical removal of the majority of the parathyroid glands.
Which of the following should this patient also be considered at risk of?

A. Germ cell tumour of the testis
B. Pineal gland tumour
C. Phaeochromocytoma
D. Pancreatic islet cell tumour
E. Thyroid medullary carcinoma

Correct Answer: D

A 66-year-old man, who has had diabetes for the past seven years, presents to the Endocrine Clinic with abdominal fullness and occasional pain. He had anorexia and often had acid reflux. He also complained of belching and a bloating sensation. He was treated with glimepiride, metformin and exenatide. He generally had good control of blood sugar, but the last two tests have shown a trend of increasing fasting glucose levels.
What is the next appropriate step in management?

A. Intensify diabetic medication
B. Change diabetic medication
C. Convert to insulin
D. Add a prokinetic agent
E. Treat for Helicobacter pylori infection

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year-old youth presents to the clinic with gross haematuria. He is currently suffering from a respiratory tract infection. Apparently he had a previous episode of haematuria some 2 years earlier which was put down by the general practitioner to a urinary tract infection. Examination of notes from a previous Casualty attendance after a rugby game revealed microscopic haematuria on urine testing. On examination, his blood pressure is 132/71 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 231 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 115 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urine Blood ++, protein +
C3 Normal
Serum IgA Slight increase
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
B. IgA nephropathy
C. Lupus nephritis
D. Henoch–Schönlein purpura
E. Alport syndrome

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old man is found to have an 8 mm polyp in the ascending colon during colonoscopy, following a positive faecal immunochemical test (FIT) screening result. There are two further lesions present in the transverse colon, measuring 4 mm and 7 mm, respectively. All lesions are biopsied and removed.
Biopsy results show that all three lesions are adenomatous polyps.
What would be the most appropriate next management step in this patient?

A. List the patient for total colectomy
B. Arrange a computed tomography (CT) staging scan
C. Discharge the patient as the polyps have been removed
D. Arrange further surveillance colonoscopy at three years
E. Repeat the colonoscopy at six months to check for complete removal

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old woman is currently being treated palliatively for metastatic lung cancer. She has been admitted to hospital with worsening back pain and lower limb neurological symptoms. Prior to admission, her pain was controlled with paracetamol orally (PO) 1000 mg four times daily (QDS), codeine PO 60 mg QDS and ibuprofen PO 400 mg three times daily (TDS). She is found to have metastatic deposits in her bony spine, causing compression, and has been scheduled for radiotherapy. The specialist pain team has prescribed Zomorph 30 mg PO twice daily (BD) and have asked you to prescribe appropriate breakthrough analgesia.
Which of the following represents an appropriate breakthrough analgesia regimen?

A. Morphine sulphate PO 2.5–5 mg when required (PRN)
B. Morphine sulphate PO 5–10 mg PRN
C. Oxycontin PO 10 mg PRN
D. Zomorph PO 5 mg PRN
E. Zomorph PO 10 mg PRN

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old patient is admitted with vomiting and abdominal pain. She was noted to have marked buccal pigmentation.
Examination reveals dehydration, pulse 100 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 90/60 mmHg. Initial blood tests show: glucose 2.9 mmol/l, sodium (Na+) 126 mmol/l, potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l, urea 8.2 mmol/l, creatinine 117 µmol/l.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Insulinoma
B. Cushing syndrome
C. Conn syndrome
D. Addison’s disease
E. Peutz–Jeghers syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old patient presents with the injury shown. Carefully analyse the X-ray provided and subsequently answer the question below.
Which of the following statements is TRUE?

A. The patient will undergo external fixation
B. The patient will undergo internal fixation
C. Manipulation under anaesthesia is indicated
D. Immobilisation with a cast is the treatment of choice
E. Strapping, elevation and rest is adequate treatment for this fracture

Correct Answer: B

A 6-year-old girl is brought to the paediatric assessment unit, after her parents witnessed her having a seizure. She has no history of seizures. The seizure lasted 30 seconds, and her parents described both her arms and legs shaking. There was no incontinence or tongue biting. For the last week she has had a flu-like illness, and the parents have recorded temperatures of 39.1°C (normal 36.1–37.2°C). You suspect a diagnosis of febrile seizures.
What advice should you give the parents about the risk of future seizures?

A. The child is less likely to develop epilepsy
B. The child will not have any more seizures if treated with regular paracetamol
C. The child could seize again, but the risk of developing epilepsy is low
D. The child could seize again, but has no increase risk of epilepsy in the future
E. Febrile seizures will cause epilepsy

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old cleaner complains of progressive left-sided numbness in her hand and forearm. On examination, there is no evidence of wasting, but mild weakness of finger adduction and finger flexion. Reflexes are intact. Sensory examination reveals a reduction to pinprick in the tips of the ring and little fingers and over the hypothenar eminence.
Where is the lesion?

A. C6/C7 root lesion
B. Carpal tunnel syndrome
C. Radial neuropathy
D. Ulnar neuropathy
E. A peripheral neuropathy

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old primigravida, at 39+3 weeks’ gestation, presented to the Labour Ward in spontaneous labour. The midwife has asked you to review the patient, as the latter has only dilated 2 cm in the last six hours. She is now at 4 cm of cervical dilatation at 10 hours since onset of labour. Cardiotocography shows no evidence of fetal distress; uterine contractions are palpable, but irregular and not very strong, and the patient’s observations are stable.
Which is the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Amniotomy and augmentation with Syntocinon®
B. Amniotomy and reassess by vaginal examination in two hours
C. Caesarean section
D. Instrumental delivery
E. No action required at present, reassess in one hour

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old type I diabetic patient is having an emergency appendicectomy at lunchtime. She normally takes 20 units of Lantus® at night-time. She carbohydrate-counts at mealtimes but usually takes 8–14 units of Humalog® (short-acting insulin) before each meal.
How would you best manage her insulin on the day of the operation (assuming she will be nil by mouth from 0300 h)?

A. Give her night-time Lantus® to cover the stress response. Start the sliding scale after this, and stop just before the operation starting
B. Give lower doses of Humalog® (4 units) as she will not be eating
C. Give her night time Lantus® and set up a sliding scale. Keep it running for one hour after the patient is able to eat and drink and she has recommenced her usual Humalog®
D. Set up a fixed-rate infusion
E. Set up a sliding scale. Stop it once the patient is able to eat and drink again

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner complaining of pain in his back and in his hip. He reports that he has been suffering from pain for a few months and has been taking paracetamol for it. However, the pain has worsened now and is affecting his quality of life. The patient also suffers from type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolaemia for which he takes regular metformin and simvastatin. He has never been admitted to the hospital in the past. Blood biochemistry results show normal calcium and phosphate levels. Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level is significantly raised while the other hepatic aminotransferases are normal. There are no other blood abnormalities detected.
Which one of the following conditions is the most consistent with this patient blood test results?

A. Osteoporosis
B. Paget’s disease
C. Primary hyperparathyroidism
D. Osteoarthritis
E. Osteomalacia

Correct Answer: B

During a night shift on labour ward, the emergency cord is pulled by the nursing staff for a patient who is bleeding following a recent delivery. Blood loss and time from delivery can be used to distinguish both, primary and secondary, and major or minor post partum haemorrhage.
Which of the following parameters defines a major primary post partum haemorrhage (PPH)?

A. Blood loss >500mls, 36 hours following delivery
B. Blood loss <1000mls, within 24 hours of delivery
C. Blood loss > 1000mls, within 24 hours of delivery
D. Blood loss > 500mls, within 24 hours of delivery
E. Blood loss <500mls, 36 hours following delivery

Correct Answer: C

A local guideline on use of drugs in palliative care includes the following statement:
‘Haloperidol is effective in relieving nausea in patients with end-stage renal failure and should be considered the first-line agent in these patients.’
The guideline states that this recommendation is based on Level 3 evidence.
Which statement best describes the type of evidence that supports this recommendation?

A. Systematic review of randomised controlled trials
B. Case series
C. Expert consensus using mechanism-based reasoning
D. Non-randomised cohort study (good quality)
E. Randomised, placebo-controlled trial

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man develops painless jaundice 2 months after returning from a holiday in Thailand. He has no known previous history of liver disease. Blood tests show:
Bilirubin 210 µmol/l, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 1206 iu/l, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 405 iu/l, prothrombin time (PT) 10 s, albumin 41 g/dl.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute hepatitis C
B. Acute hepatitis B
C. Primary biliary cholangitis
D. Acute alcoholic hepatitis
E. Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)

Correct Answer: B

A 61-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department complaining of severe pain on the middle of his left shin. He said the pain started after he fell last week and he has a minor wound to his left shin and has since been worsening. He attended his general practitioner clinic where a dressing was put on the wound.
On examination, there is local erythema with purulen discharge from the wound and sloughy edes. The patient is now febrile and unable to bear weight on his left leg. The patient suffers from poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. A plain X-ray of the left leg shows no fracture, but magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the patient reveals bone marrow oedema.
Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

A. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics alone
B. Oral antibiotics alone
C. Intravenous antibiotics and surgical debridement
D. Surgical debridement alone
E. Intravenous followed by oral antibiotics

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a 4-week history of a painful right breast. This has worsened over the last seven days, despite following her midwife’s advice.
She is exclusively breastfeeding but had some problems with attachment in the first few days. This is her first baby.
On examination, you notice she is sweaty; her temperature is 38.4 °C, heart rate 113 bpm, and there is a very tender, palpable, fluctuant lump in the right outer lower quadrant, with erythema and oedema of the overlying skin.
Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

A. Admit to hospital for intravenous antibiotics
A. B. Admit to hospital for intravenous antibiotics and aspiration
C. Commence oral antibiotics and review in three days
D. Commence oral antibiotics and regular analgaesia and advise to stop feeding until symptoms settle
E. Reassure the patient that if she continues breastfeeding, the symptoms should settle

Correct Answer: B

Your consultant undertakes private cosmetic work alongside her NHS commitments, which you are occasionally asked to assist her with.
Based on the most recent guidance regarding cosmetic surgery from the General Medical Council, (GMC), which of the following statements is true?

A. Cosmetic procedures must not be undertaken on patients under the age of 18 years
B. The procedure must be discussed with the patient’s GP, irrespective of whether the patient gives their consent for you to do so
C. It is acceptable to provide your services as a prize for a competition
D. It is acceptable to prescribe injectable cosmetic medicines by telephone
E. The person undertaking the procedure must not delegate the responsibility of discussing it with the patient and seeking their consent

Correct Answer: E

A 49-year-old woman with a background history of hypothyroidism collapses while exercising at her yoga class. She has been complaining of intermittent exertional chest pains and dyspnoea over the preceding weeks. Her physical examination reveals an ejection systolic murmur at the right upper sternal edge. The second heart sound is soft and she has a slow-rising pulse.
Which of the following is most likely causing her symptoms?

A. Bicuspid aortic valve
B. Aortic valve regurgitation
C. Calcific aortic stenosis
D. Mitral valve regurgitation
E. Mitral valve prolapse

Correct Answer: A

A 69-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after several episodes of vomiting bright red blood. He has presented to the same hospital in the past for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, alcohol intoxication and peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The gastroenterology team review the patient and perform an urgent gastroscopy, which reveals several oesophageal varices.
Which of the following medications should be prescribed to this patient to reduce his chance of future variceal bleeding?

A. Erythromycin
B. Atenolol
C. Omeprazole
D. Propranolol
E. Ranitidine

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman presented to the Oncology Clinic with chronic cough with haemoptysis, she has a long standing heavy smoking history. A bronchoscopy was performed which showed a tumour confined to the left main bronchus. A biopsy was taken and showed small cell lung cancer. She then had a staging computed tomography (CT) scan which showed a TNM grading of T2, N1, M0. She does not have any other medical co-morbidities and is usually independent in all daily activities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy
B. Surgery
C. Radiotherapy
D. Interferon-alpha
E. Palliative chemotherapy

Correct Answer: A

A 51-year-old woman, with no past medical history, is referred by her General Practitioner to a Lipid Clinic. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 31 kg/m2. She has a background history of sleep apnoea and complains of weight gain, fatigue and constipation.
On examination, you notice that her skin is dry and she has scalp hair loss. Her laboratory results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Total cholesterol 8.5 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
Low density-lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol 5.5 mmol/l < 3.5 mmol/l
High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol 2 mmol/l > 1.0 mmol/l
Triglycerides 1 mmol/l 0–1.5 mmol/l
What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A. Commence fibrate therapy
B. Commence statin therapy
C. Measure thyroid-stimulating hormone and free T4
D. Measure random blood glucose
E. Diet and lifestyle advice

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old woman is admitted with complaints of severe pain in her neck, shoulders and hips over the past 24 hours. She also complains that she is not able to move her shoulder and hips in the morning and that they feel very stiff. She feels weak. She was unable to get up from her bed this morning. On examination, you notice that the power in her shoulder muscles and hip muscles is normal. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is 112 mm/h. Creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) enzyme levels are not elevated.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Fibromyalgia (FM)
B. Polymyositis
C. Rheumatoid arthritis
D. Myasthenia gravis
E. Polymyalgia rheumatica

Correct Answer: E

A trauma call is put out in the Emergency Department after a cyclist is brought in who is injured following a road traffic collision. He was riding on a dual carriageway when a car collided with him side-on, and he landed in the middle of the road severely injured, short of breath and suffering from chest pain. A passer-by called an ambulance which brought him to the Emergency Department. The anaesthetist in the trauma team assesses him, diagnoses him with a tension pneumothorax and inserts a grey cannula into his second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line. Within a couple of minutes, the patient is more comfortable and expresses relief at being able to breathe more easily.
What signs would the anaesthetist have found on examination?

A. Normal trachea, normal chest expansion, reduced resonance on percussion, absent breath sounds
B. Normal trachea, reduced chest expansion, reduced resonance on percussion, normal vesicular breath sounds
C. Tracheal tug, reduced chest expansion, increased resonance on percussion, normal vesicular breath sounds
D. Ipsilateral tracheal deviation, reduced chest expansion, increased resonance on percussion, absent breath sounds
E. Contralateral tracheal deviation, reduced chest expansion, increased resonance on percussion, absent breath sounds

Correct Answer: E

Thomas is a 4-year-old overweight boy brought in by anxious parents who are worried about his loud snoring and frequent interruptions in breathing which have been getting progressively worse. Although he has difficulty getting up from sleep, he does not have any daytime somnolence. However, his parents have been receiving complaints from the school teachers about his disruptive and inattentive behaviour in class. They have done a lot of research on the Internet and are demanding that Thomas has his tonsils removed. On examination, Thomas has a short, thick neck and grade III tonsils, but no other abnormalities.
Which of the following is the next best step in management?

A. Reassure his parents that snoring loudly is very normal in children his age and that his behaviour pattern will improve as he matures
B. Book the child for an elective adenotonsillectomy as a day procedure
C. Order an overnight polysomnographic study
D. Advise the parents to purchase a dental splint for their child to use overnight
E. Treat the child with intranasal budesonide

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old man is stabbed in his arm and presents to the Emergency Department with an ‘ape hand’ deformity. On examination, he is unable to abduct his thumb and he is diagnosed with median nerve damage.
Which of the following will also likely be impaired in this patient?

A. Extension of the wrist
B. Sensation to the fifth digit
C. Sensation to the second and third digits
D. Abduction of the arm at the shoulder joint
E. Adduction of the fingers

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance following a fall from a ladder where he was cleaning a second-floor window. He is conscious and complains of back and neck pain. He is breathing spontaneously and has a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 70 bpm. He has deformity in the left thigh, which he says does not hurt. He is managed as a multiple trauma and is noted to have priapism as a urinary catheter is inserted. Initially, he has no movement, reflexes or sensation in his lower limbs, but when examined several days later, he is found to have spastic paresis and hyperreflexia in the lower limbs affecting all muscle groups. The lower limbs remain insensate. The upper limbs move normally both proximally and distally, and reflexes are normal.
What is the most likely level of his spinal cord injury?

A. C3
B. C8
C. T8
D. L4
E. S5

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old man presents in a severely unwell state. He is unrousable and, on examination, has a blood pressure of 85/40 mmHg with a tachycardia of 110 bpm. His respiratory rate is 35 breaths per minute. There is a past medical history of type II diabetes. A neighbour who attends with the ambulance tells you that the man’s wife died two months earlier. You arrange some investigations.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Hameolgobin 122 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 10.3 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 205 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Chloride 102 mmol/l 98-106 mmol/l
Bicarbonate 14 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Creatinine 190 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glucose 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Lactate 7 mmol/l 0.5–2.2 mmol/l
pH 7.19 7.35–7.45
pO2 10.1 kPa (on oxygen) 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 3.9 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Respiratory alkalosis
B. Metabolic alkalosis
C. Lactic acidosis
D. Diabetic ketoacidosis
E. Hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma

Correct Answer: C

An 18-month-old girl is admitted to the ward with difficulty breathing. Her mother reports a 3-day illness with cough and cold symptoms, low-grade fever and increasing difficulty breathing this morning. She has had no similar episodes. The family are all non-smokers and there is no history of atopy. Her immunisations are up-to-date and she is otherwise growing and developing normally.
In the Emergency Department, she was given burst therapy and is now on one-hourly salbutamol inhalers. On examination, she is alert and playing. Heart rate (HR) 150 bpm, respiratory rate (RR) 40 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 94% on air. There is mild subcostal recession, and her chest shows good air entry bilaterally, with mild wheeze throughout.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Start oxygen via nasal cannulae
B. Add prednisolone for 3 days
C. Add montelukast for 5 days
D. Stretch to 2-hourly salbutamol and add 10 mg soluble prednisone for 3 days
E. Add Atrovent® nebulisers

Correct Answer: D

A 66-year-old woman was recently admitted to hospital with small bowel obstruction. A nasogastric (NG) tube was inserted, and she has been prescribed intravenous (IV) fluids. Three days later, she reports feeling short of breath, and on examination, she has widespread fine crackles and pitting sacral oedema. Her notes show that she has been receiving 2 litres of fluid a day and that she weighs 48 kg. You treat her, and once her symptoms have resolved, you re-calculate her daily maintenance fluid requirements.
Which of the following options is the most suitable amount of daily fluid to give to the patient?

A. 1000–1500 ml
B. 1500–2000 ml
C. 2000–2500 ml
D. 2500–3000 ml
E. 3000–3500 ml

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presents to the Emergency Department vomiting copious amounts of blood. His haemoglobin on admission is 99 g/l. Other blood tests reveal urea of 21.5 mmol/l, creatinine 190 μmol/l, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 102 u/l and bilirubin of 153 μmol/l. The bleeding settles, and an endoscopy the following day reveals extensive large oesophageal varices.
Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term management for his varices, apart from asking him to cease alcohol?

A. Repeat endoscopy in 3 months
B. Terlipressin
C. Band ligation of large varices
D. Injection sclerotherapy for large varices
E. Referral for transjugular intrahepatic porto-systemic shunting (TIPSS)

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with an arm fracture and bruising around her neck and on her abdomen. She is 12 weeks pregnant. While assessing her, you suspect that she may be a victim of domestic abuse. You enquire about this, but she quickly denies any issues at home with her husband, with whom she lives in a rural area. She instead tells you that these injuries were a result of her falling over at work.
Which of the following factors would make her more likely to be a victim of domestic violence?

A. Aged over 25
B. Employed
C. Living in a rural area
D. Married
E. Pregnancy

Correct Answer: E

You are on your general practice placement, and a pregnant woman attends for a routine antenatal check-up. You examine her abdomen and find that her abdomen is distended up to her umbilicus. Your general practitioner asks you how many weeks you think she is, but you do not have a measuring tape.
How many weeks would you estimate her gestation to be?

A. 16
B. 18
C. 20
D. 22
E. 24

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old woman attends her GP with lethargy, concerned as to whether she has reached the menopause. A screen of blood tests was performed with the positive findings being a Hb of 101 g/l, MCV 108.2 fl and a B12 of 46 ng/l. Her only other complaint is occasional altered bowel habit.
Which one of the following investigations would best help distinguish pernicious anaemia from other causes of malabsorption as the cause of her low B12?

A. PABA test
B. Folic acid level
C. Intrinsic factor antibodies
D. Serum gastrin level
E. C14 breath test

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old pregnant woman has presented for her 36-week antenatal care check. On the ultrasound scan (USS), there is a possibility of oesophageal atresia. The patient has been having an uneventful pregnancy so far and this is her first pregnancy. Her blood tests have all been normal, with no signs of any infections or diabetes. Her blood pressure at the antenatal care check was 124/87 mmHg and she is not obese.
What finding would you expect on fetal USS?

A. Macrosomia
B. Oligohydramnios
C. Polyhydramnios
D. Fetal oedema
E. Microcephaly

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with a 1-day history of blurring of vision and headache. He does not complain of any pain when touching the scalp or any pain when eating and chewing food.
Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin.
On further history taking, he tells you that he has a family history of brain cancer and he is afraid that this could be relevant to his symptoms.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/18 in both eyes. On dilated fundoscopy, you could see some arterioles narrower than others. You also see venules being compressed by arterioles. There are also some dot-and-blot and flame-shaped haemorrhages, as well as some cotton-wool spots.
His vital observations are as follows:
Heart rate 80 bpm
Blood pressure 221/119 mmHg
Oxygen saturation 98% on room air
Respiratory rate 14 per minute
Temperature 37 °C
According to the Keith-Wagener-Barker classification of hypertensive retinopathy, what grade of hypertensive retinopathy is this?

A. Grade 1
B. Grade 2
C. Grade 3
D. Grade 4
E. Grade 5

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old patient presents with a lump in the neck. On examination, there is a 2-cm smooth, round lump at the anterior border of the upper third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Branchial cyst
B. Goitre
C. Acute parotitis
D. Cystic hygroma
E. Thyroglossal cyst

Correct Answer: A

You are asked to take over a patient halfway through a case to relieve the consultant anaesthetist for a comfort break. The patient has an endotracheal tube (ETT) in situ and is maintained on sevoflurane and ventilated at a rate of 14 breaths per minute, with a tidal volume of 600. You notice that the carbon dioxide (CO2) trace is high (ET 6.9) and increasing quite rapidly. The maxillofacial surgeon remarks that the patient’s jaw is quite tight and asks for more muscle relaxant. You check the patient’s temperature and find that it is high at 39.6 °C.
Which one of the following is your priority?

A. Actively cool the patient, give paracetamol and treat with antibiotics
B. Actively cool the patient, increase the respiratory rate and give antibiotics
C. Actively cool the patient, stop sevoflurane and give dantrolene
D. Give more muscle relaxant, treat with paracetamol and give antibiotics
E. Discuss with the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)

Correct Answer: C

A 58-year-old man presents to his GP. He has metastatic lung cancer. He is currently taking 1 g of paracetamol four times daily as well as codeine 60 mg four times daily, but says he is still struggling with pain.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Stop codeine and start co-codamol 30/500 mg two tablets four times daily
B. Stop codeine and start dihydrocodeine 60 mg four times daily
C. Stop codeine and start morphine sulphate modified release 15 mg twice daily with view to titrate dose
D. Stop codeine and start morphine sulphate modified release 60 mg twice daily with view to titrate dose
E. Stop codeine and start tramadol 50 mg four times daily

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-year history of restricting food intake and self-induced vomiting. She attends her GP for the first time with her sibling reporting a recent worsening of her symptoms. The GP suspects anorexia nervosa.
Which is the most appropriate investigation to determine whether the patient requires urgent hospital admission?

A. 24-hour Holter monitor
B. Chest X-ray
C. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
D. Serum prolactin
E. Transthoracic echocardiography

Correct Answer: C

An 80-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 1-hour history of sudden-onset left leg and foot pain. On examination, he appears distressed, and his heart rate is 95 bpm and irregular. The left leg is cold and pale from the knee downwards. There are no pulses palpable below the femoral artery on the left lower limb and full pulses on the right-hand side. An immediate angiogram is performed and shown.
Which of the following is the correct initial management for this patient?

A. Immediate warfarinisation to prevent further occlusions
B. Thrombolysis
C. Femoro-popliteal bypass surgery
D. Angioplasty and stenting
E. Fogarty embolectomy

Correct Answer: E

A 71-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a headache after being referred by his General Practitioner (GP). The GP referral letter mentions that the patient presented with a history of fluctuating consciousness levels for the past week. The wife reports that her husband had a fall about a week ago and since then, he seemed to be a different man. The patient mentions that he has been experiencing a dull headache which did not respond to regular paracetamol. He denies nausea, vomiting and photophobia.
On examination, the vital signs are stable, the patient is apyrexial and there are no rashes. The patient has a past medical history of alcohol dependence, liver cirrhosis, gout and hypertension. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the patient’s head shows a crescent-shaped area of haemorrhage with midline shift of the brain structures.
What is the best next management step for this patient?

A. Burr hole drainage
B. Nimodipine
C. Endovascular coiling
D. Mannitol
E. Aspirin

Correct Answer: A

A patient presents with pain and discharge from the right ear, which has been present for 4 days. There is no history of trauma or fever. On examination there is marked tenderness on tragal pressure and the right ear canal is red and swollen with purulent exudate present. The left ear is normal. Both tympanic membranes are intact and normal in appearance.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Amoxicillin three times daily (tid) orally for 5 days
B. Antibacterial ear drops for 7 days
C. Combined steroid and antibacterial ear drops for 7 days
D. Simple analgesia alone with advice on self care
C. E. Combined steroid and antibacterial ear drops for 7 days and amoxicillin tid orally for 5 days

Correct Answer: C

A 54-year-old man, known to have human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), presents to the Emergency Department with reducing vision in his left eye. His last CD4 count, measured in clinic, was <50 mm3.
Which is the most likely cause?

A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis
B. Molluscum contagiosum of eyelids
C. Uveitis
D. Acute glaucoma
E. Age-related macular degeneration

Correct Answer: A

A university student reports to her general practitioner that she has noticed recent changes in her strength and endurance. Although she was an athlete in high school, she now reports weakness in her arms following formerly simple tasks. She no longer runs regularly because of difficulty catching her breath on exertion. Her eyelids are droopy and she experiences difficulty holding her head upright.
What is the most likely disease?

A. Mitochondrial myopathy
B. Nemaline myopathy
C. Poliomyelitis
D. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
E. Myasthenia gravis

Correct Answer: E

A 15-year-old girl attends the Emergency Department (ED) with her mother. They are both heavily intoxicated with alcohol. The girl’s records show that this is the third time in six months that she has attended the ED with alcohol-related problems. The safeguarding lead has advised you to contact social services.
Which of the following is the single most appropriate action?

A. Advise the mother to contact social services following her daughter’s discharge
B. Advise the patient to contact social services following her own discharge
C. Refer urgently to social services without informing the patient or her mother
D. Inform the patient and her mother you are referring them to social services
E. Write a letter to social services following patient’s discharge

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old male presents with a history of a sore area on his tongue, which has failed to heal for over three months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. The patient is otherwise well, with a history of mild osteoarthritis of the knees, but nil else of note. He is a builder, and smokes 30 cigarettes a day for the past 30 years. He drinks around 30 units of alcohol a week.
Following examination, the patient is referred urgently as a case of suspected cancer of the tongue.
Which one of the following statements is correct about tongue cancer?

A. It commonly metastasises to the lower cervical nodes
B. Adenocarcinoma is most common
C. It may be associated with human papillomavirus (HPV)
D. It may be caused by coconut ingestion
E. Smoking is not a known cause

Correct Answer: C

A 20-year-old athlete presents to the Emergency Department after training complaining of mild left-knee pain after falling on a flexed knee. On examination, there is mild swelling and tenderness over the patellar region without crepitus. There is no ecchymosis or deformity. Active and passive range of motion testing was full and painful with terminal knee flexion. Ligamentous testing was normal.
Which of the following best describes the main feature of the patient's condition?

A. Bursa helps in thermal regulation
B. Bursa is a fluid-filled sac found between the skin and subcutaneous tissues
C. Bursae may be of two types – anatomical or adventitious
D. There are five primary bursae which communicate with the synovial cavity of the knee joint
E. Tuberculosis does not lead to bursitis

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of right-sided iliac fossa pain, right tip shoulder pain and a scanty brown per vaginum (PV) bleed. She missed her last menstrual period which was due six weeks ago. She has an intrauterine device (IUD) in situ.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Appendicitis
B. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
C. Femoral hernia
D. Ovarian cyst
E. Pelvic inflammatory disease

Correct Answer: B

Following a difficult childbirth complicated by placental abruption, a 32-year-old woman complains to her community midwife of failure to lactate, lethargy, dizziness upon standing, and weight loss.
Which of the following blood test results are expected?

A. Increased cortisol; increased aldosterone
B. Decreased cortisol; decreased aldosterone
C. Increased cortisol; decreased aldosterone
D. Decreased cortisol; increased aldosterone
E. Decreased cortisol; normal aldosterone

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old man was found to have a tumour that originated from the lining of the urinary bladder. During transurethral resection to remove the tumour, the cystoscope entered the urinary bladder.
Which of the following structures did the cystoscope traverse immediately prior to entering the urinary bladder?

A. Intramural part of the urethra
B. Intermediate part of the urethra
C. Prostatic urethra
D. Spongy urethra
E. Paraurethral part

Correct Answer: A

A 73-year-old gentleman presents to his general practitioner after suffering from frequent falls over the last few months. His wife mentions that he has also been very slow and often seems to be depressed. Examining him, you find that he has a unilateral resting tremor and his face appears expressionless. He agrees with his wife’s observations and has been feeling rather low about all of this. Recently, he has also turned to alcohol to help alleviate his tremor; however, it does not seem to be helping. His Geriatric E. Depression Scale is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Parkinson’s disease
B. Stroke
C. Cerebellar injury
D. Essential tremor
E. Depression

Correct Answer: A
