A 21-year-old woman presents with a painless, firm lump over the right upper eyelid. She reports it has been there for around two weeks and started off as a small, painful swelling. There are no signs of infection and vision is not affected.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Blepharitis
B. Epidermal inclusion cyst
C. Hordeolum
D. Meibomian cyst
E. Stye

Correct Answer: D

A B. 40-year-old motorcyclist was rushed into the Emergency Department. He has been involved in a road traffic accident and was found alone on the road. On examination, he appears drowsy and is making some grunting sounds, pupils are equal and reactive to light, eyes open to pain and he withdraws his hand while the nurses try to insert a cannula.
What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. 8
B. 4
C. 9
D. 5
E. 10

Correct Answer: A

A young teenager attends the fracture clinic for review of a fracture to his tibia and fibula. He has his plaster of Paris cast removed, and it is noted that he is unable to dorsiflex his foot.
Which nerve has been damaged?

A. Tibial nerve
B. Obturator nerve
C. Sural nerve
D. Common peroneal nerve
E. Femoral nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-month history of general lethargy. She has no other family history to note. A routine blood investigation is sent and reveals the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 109 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 74 fl 76–98 fl
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her anaemia?

A. Alcohol excess
B. Vitamin B12 deficiency
C. Cirrhosis
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Iron deficiency

Correct Answer: E

A 30-year-old male patient (undergoing chemotherapy treatment for Hodgkin’s lymphoma) complains of severe mouth pain. On examination, you see white plaques over his tongue.
Which of the following treatments is most appropriate?

A. Oral fluconazole for 7–14 days
B. Nystatin mouth wash for 10 days
C. Intravenous amphotericin B for 7 days
D. Oral voriconazole for 7–14 days
E. Oral mycafungin for 7–14 days

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old practising solicitor attends the Neurology Clinic with his wife. She is deeply concerned regarding his worsening memory. Over the past three months, he has become increasingly forgetful, to the point where he has had to take sick leave from work. He has had two recent presentations to the Emergency Department following falls, though a computed tomography (CT) head scan did not demonstrate any abnormality. On examination, there is an ataxic gait and you notice fasciculations and involuntary jerking movements of the upper limbs. He has had no family history of neurological disease and was previously fit and well.
What is the most likely underlying cause of this presentation?

A. Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD)
B. Huntington’s disease
C. Lewy body dementia
D. Motor neuron disease
E. Vascular dementia

Correct Answer: A

A 12-year-old Caucasian boy is brought to the Emergency Department with complaints of colicky abdominal pain and nausea. The patient had similar complaints 2 months previously. Abdominal ultrasound done at the time revealed multiple gall bladder stones. The patient is a known case of cystic fibrosis on treatment with antibiotics, mucolytics and pancreatic enzyme supplements. Abdominal ultrasound is repeated and shows inflammation of the gall bladder, multiple calculi and dilated bile ducts.
Which one of the following reasons best explains the hepatobiliary dysfunction (cholestasis) seen in a patient with cystic fibrosis?

A. Defective cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein on bile duct epithelial cells
B. Defective CFTR protein on pancreatic duct epithelial cells
C. Defective CFTR on canalicular membranes
D. Recurrent infections of the bile duct with Burkholderia cepacia
E. Congenital malformation of bile ducts

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man presented with 1-week history of acute onset, pruritic violaceous papular rash.
Around three months ago, he was started on ramipril for his hypertension.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Stevens–Johnson syndrome
B. Psoriasis
C. Lichenoid eruption
D. Erythema multiforme
E. Contact dermatitis

Correct Answer: C

This 40-year-old woman complains of roughness of the lining of the mouth and a sensitivity of the oral mucosa to hot or spicy food. She has noticed this problem for about 6 weeks. The inner aspect of the other cheek is similarly affected, as is, slightly, the side of the tongue. She is otherwise well with no significant past medical history. She does not have a rash.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the single most likely diagnosis?

A. Aphthous stomatitis
B. Leukoplakia
C. Lichen planus
D. Squamous cell carcinoma
E. Pemphigus vulgaris

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old woman, a known type 1 diabetic, attended the GP Surgery.
You were asked by your GP placement supervisor to perform a dilated direct fundoscopy on her eyes. You saw a few dot haemorrhages and hard exudates.
What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient’s eye condition?

A. Background diabetic retinopathy
B. Diabetic maculopathy
C. Pre-proliferative diabetic retinopathy
D. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
D. E. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy with maculopathy

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old African-American man undergoes a pre-employment health check. Chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. More detailed history and examination reveals painful red papules on both shins of recent onset. He is otherwise well. Basic blood tests are normal.
What rash does the patient have?

A. Kaposi’s sarcoma
B. Tinea corporis
C. Erythema multiforme
D. Steven–Johnson’s syndrome
E. Erythema nodosum

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old man presents to his Emergency Department complaining of blood in his urine. He reports that this has been happening over the past three days. He denies any pain or fever.
Physical examination revealed bilateral wheezes but is otherwise unremarkable. He does not have any problem passing urine. He has always lived in the UK and has not travelled anywhere outside the country recently. The patient is retired but used to work in a textile factory where he was responsible for working in the dye plants producing different coloured fabric. He has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension. He takes losartan for his hypertension and a budesonide and formoterol combination inhaler for his COPD. The man is an ex-smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Bladder cancer
B. Benign prostatic hyperplasia
C. Nephrolithiasis
D. Prostate cancer
E. Renal cancer

Correct Answer: A

Below is a list of intravenous (iv) fluids and their approximate compositions:
Fluid Na+ Cl- K+ Ca2+ HCO3-
Normal (0.9%) saline

You are asked to write up fluids for the first 24 hours of a 70-kg man’s stay on the ward after an appendicectomy. He is not eating or drinking.
What is the most appropriate regime?

A. 3 litre bags of 5% dextrose with 60 mmol K+ in each bag
B. 3 litres of normal saline
C. 2 litres of Hartmann’s solution
D. 3 litre bags of dextrose saline with 60 mmol K+ in each bag
E. 1 litre of normal saline and 2 litres of 5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium added to each bag

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman is admitted to hospital for a hysterectomy for treatment of fibroids.
Which of the following are routine prophylactic measures for all women undergoing a total abdominal hysterectomy?

A. Co-amoxiclav ® intravenous (iv) intraoperatively
B. Subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin intraoperatively
C. Penicillin V given iv intraoperatively
D. Oral trimethoprim 3 day oral course prior to surgery
E. Oral amoxicillin 7-day oral course post-operatively

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old professional bodybuilder presents with a lump in the left groin, which he describes as present intermittently. The patient explains that the lump is affected by posture and coughing but is not painful. The doctor examines the area further and confirms a hernia is present.
Which of the following statements is true about groin hernias?

A. An inguinal hernia usually emerges lateral to the pubic tubercle
B. Femoral hernias are more common in men
C. A direct inguinal hernia lies medial to the inferior epigastric vessels
D. Direct inguinal hernias almost always become incarcerated, leading to bowel obstruction
E. All groin hernias should be repaired because of the risk for strangulation

Correct Answer: C

A previously healthy 80-year-old woman is hospitalised and undergoes surgery to replace the broken hip that she sustained as a result of falling down stairs. Upon discharge to a nursing home 10 days later, she is unable to ambulate fully and, about a month later, she dies suddenly.
Which of the following is most likely to be the immediate cause of death found at post-mortem examination?

A. Tuberculosis (TB)
B. Pulmonary embolism
C. Pneumonia with pneumococcus
D. Congestive heart failure
E. Carcinoma of the uterus

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old man is admitted after being found lying on the street with a reduced conscious level.
On examination, he has pinpoint pupils and needle-track marks on his arms.
Which of the following patterns on the arterial blood gas would you most expect to find?

A. Hypercapnia and metabolic acidosis
B. Hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis
C. Hypercapnia and respiratory alkalosis
D. Hypocapnia and respiratory alkalosis
E. Hypocapnia and respiratory acidosis

Correct Answer: B

A 20-year-old footballer undergoes an anterior cruciate ligament repair following an injury. He is advised by his medical team that he will need an extended period of rest and physiotherapy before he resumes competitive football. Following the surgery, he says he feels better and discharges himself. He later goes drinking with his team and tells them that he will be back on the team next week.
What type of coping is this?

A. Projection
B. Avoidance
C. Appraisal
D. Problem focused
E. Emotional focused

Correct Answer: B

A care assistant from a local nursing home presents with sudden onset of an intensely itchy rash. This covers her whole body. She has no history of skin problems. On examination there is a combination of raised erythematous papules covering her arms and trunk and linear marks to her forearms. There is excoriated skin in the inter-digital spaces.
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Regular emollient plus a moderately potent topical steroid
B. Regular emollient plus a combination of moderately potent topical steroid and topical antifungal agent
C. Oral antihistamines
D. Malathion ointment
E. Permethrin cream

Correct Answer: E

A 61-year-old library assistant has increasing frequency of episodes of intermittent abdominal discomfort and bloating. She also complains of associated episodes of diarrhoea, with mucus in the stool, but no blood. The pain usually worsens after meals and improves after opening her bowels. She has not lost weight and continues to have a good appetite. She has had a knee replacement for osteoarthritis, but no other significant medical history of note.
Investigation of the patient’s symptoms reveals diverticular disease.
Which of the following complications is this patient most at risk of developing?

A. Colocutaneous fistulae
B. Colorectal carcinoma
C. Haemorrhoids
D. Anal fissure
E. Colovesical fistulae

Correct Answer: E

A 23-year-old woman presents with a hot and tender swelling in her breast. The area over the swelling is erythematous. She says she first noticed the erythema a week and a half ago. She thinks the swelling in her breast has been worsening. When taking the history, the woman becomes tearful. She tells you that her mum died of breast cancer 3 years ago. On examination, there is some cream discharge from the nipple. The woman tells you that she is still breast feeding her 8 month old son. Swelling is confined to one segment of the breast.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Galactocele
B. Fibroadenoma
C. Breast abscess
D. Inflammatory breast cancer
E. Ductal carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

Langerhans cells are irregularly shaped cells distributed in several layers of the epidermis. They have many dendritic processes, an indented nucleus, and characteristic tennis racquet-shaped intracellular Birbeck granules.
To which other cell in the human body are they most closely related?

A. Monocyte
B. Eosinophil
C. Basophil
D. Melanocyte
E. Merkel cell

Correct Answer: A

An 89-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with diffuse abdominal pain and one episode of dark rectal bleeding. He is noticed to be in fast atrial fibrillation. He is an ex-smoker and drinks three pints of beer per week. On examination, he is not peritonitic, but his pain is generalised and only temporarily alleviated by opioid analgesia. His bloods show: white blood count 14 (4.5 to 11.0 × 109/l), c-reactive protein 23 (normal: Less than 10 mg/L) and arterial lactate 4.8 (normal 1 ± 0.5 mmol/l4). Abdominal and chest X-rays are unremarkable.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bowel ischaemia
B. Ulcerative colitis
C. Bowel volvulus
D. Diverticulitis
E. Haemorrhoids

Correct Answer: A

You are reviewing an 18-hour-old neonate on the Postnatal Ward. During your examination, you notice a swelling over the occipital region of the skull. It is soft and does not appear tender. On further examination, you feel that the swelling is crossing the cranial sutures. Neurologically, the child appears normal. She was born by forceps due to failure to progress. There is no family history of note.
What is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Cerebral function monitoring
B. Cranial computed tomography (CT) scan
C. Cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
D. Cranial ultrasound scan
E. Liver function tests

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old ice hockey player was tackled by a member of the opposite team and fell on the ice, hitting the right side of his head. He was disoriented but was able to continue the game. The following evening, his roommate tried to wake him but found him unconscious in a pool of vomit.
Which of the following will most likely be present in a computed tomography (CT) scan of his head?

A. Unilateral crescent-shaped shadow along the lateral cortex
B. Unilateral biconvex-shaped shadow along the lateral cortex
C. Bilateral crescent-shaped shadow along the lateral cortex
D. Unilateral biconvex-shaped area along the anterior cortex
E. Shifting of the brain midline towards the side of the lesion

Correct Answer: B

An 8-year-old girl has been referred because of abdominal distension, nausea, bloating, and pelvic pressure. An ultrasound determines the presence of an 8 cm mass in the right lower quadrant, adjacent to the uterus. Pre-operative tests are taken and, at the time of surgery, an ovarian mass is removed. Upon microscopy the pathologist comments that the specimen contains structures whose histologic features resemble glomeruli.
Which one of the following tumour markers is likely to be elevated?

A. Alpha-fetoprotein
B. CA125
C. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
D. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
E. Inhibin

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old woman has been admitted to the Acute Medical Unit with shortness of breath, dizziness and feeling generally lethargic. Her full blood count reveals that her haemoglobin is 60 g/l. She reports that she suffers from menorrhagia. It is decided that she requires a blood transfusion. A few minutes after the transfusion begins, she develops a fever, lower back pain and starts vomiting.
Which of the following is used to diagnose an ABO incompatibility transfusion reaction?

A. Direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test)
B. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
C. Indirect antiglobulin test
D. Schirmer’s test
E. White cell count

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents with a gradual onset of weakness in the legs, arms, neck and face. However, he finds his muscle strength does increase after some exercise.
On examination, there is weakness in all limbs but more in the proximal arms and legs as well as ptosis in both eyelids. He is a chronic heavy smoker of 50 pack-years and was recently diagnosed with lung cancer.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Central Horner syndrome
B. Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome
C. Myasthenia gravis
D. Postganglionic Horner syndrome
E. Preganglionic Horner syndrome

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman presents with four episodes of oral ulceration in the course of 1 year. These have taken up to 3 weeks to heal properly. She has also suffered from painful vaginal ulceration. Additionally, there have been intermittent headaches, pain and swelling affecting both knees, and intermittent diarrhoea. On examination, there are several mouth ulcers of up to 1 cm in diameter. She also has erythema nodosum.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 129 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 190 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 45 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
C-reactive protein (CRP) 50 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Elevated level of immunoglobulin A (IgA)
ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) negative
Anti-phospholipid antibody negative
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
B. Behçet’s disease
C. Herpes simplex
D. Pemphigoid
E. Pemphigus

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department via ambulance with reduced level of consciousness, non-blanching rash, headache, neck stiffness and fever. Her mother accompanies her and states that this confusion started several hours previously. She also states that her daughter has not passed urine since the previous day, at least 16 hours ago. On clinical examination, she appears unwell and confused, and she has a purpuric rash over her lower limbs. Her observation results are as follows:
Temperature 39.5 °C
Blood pressure 82/50 mmHg
Heart rate 120 bpm
Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute
Which of the following are high-risk criteria when diagnosing and risk-stratifying suspected sepsis?

A. Normal mental state
B. Systolic blood pressure of 82 mmHg
C. Not passing urine for the previous 16 hours
D. Blanching rash of the skin
E. Respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute

Correct Answer: B

An elderly man with dementia is experiencing recurrent falls. He has a past medical history of ischaemic heart disease, angina, essential hypertension, Parkinson’s disease and gout. He is on regular diltiazem, ramipril, bendroflumethiazide, levodopa and allopurinol. When you review him, his heart rate is 45 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg.
Which of the patient’s regular medication is likely to be responsible for his recurrent falls?

A. Diltiazem
B. Ramipril
C. Levodopa
D. Bendroflumethiazide
E. Allopurinol

Correct Answer: A

The ward nurses contact you because they are worried about a 46-year-old man admitted yesterday with jaundice. They found him in the linen cupboard, apparently very disoriented. He explained he was looking for his luggage because he knew he needed to check-out before midday. When you arrive, he is wandering about very unsteadily, apparently still confused. On examination, you find he has a tachycardia of 120 bpm and nystagmus. He is co-operative with you and represents no immediate risk to himself or others.
Which of the following medications is appropriate for this patient?

A. N-acetylcysteine IV
B. Thiamine IV and chlordiazepoxide orally (PO)
C. Haloperidol intramuscularly (IM)
D. Propranolol PO
E. Thiamine IM and midazolam IM

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old first-year student presents to the Student Health Clinic because she feels depressed. She describes feeling homesick and is so sad that it is interfering with her ability to focus, work or make new friends. Her sleep, appetite and energy have been unaffected. She denies suicidal ideation or feelings of guilt. She thought it would have gotten better by now, but she said it has already been 2 months since she left home and she is still unhappy. She is worried that she is experiencing major depression.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A. Major depressive disorder
B. Dysthymia
C. Bipolar disorder
D. Adjustment disorder
E. Acute stress disorder

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man presents with epigastric pain which radiates to the back. He feels nauseous and has been vomiting since arriving at the Emergency Department (ED). On questioning, the man tells you that he takes no regular medication. He was last in hospital six months ago after a fell when drinking two litres ofalcohol. He was not admitted. He travelled to Nigeria to visit relatives two months ago.
On examination, the man’s abdomen is tender in the epigastrium. He is jaundiced. He is also tachycardic and pyrexial. Some of his investigation results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 300 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 60 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 43 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
What is the best initial treatment for this man?

A. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
B. Admission, iv fluids, analgesia, keep nil by mouth and place a nasogastric tube
C. iv fluids and antibiotics
D. iv fluids and chloroquinine
E. Send home with analgesia and anti-emetics

Correct Answer: B

A 12-year-old boy was admitted with high-grade fever for two weeks and bleeding gums. His peripheral blood picture revealed numerous blasts, some of which showed Auer rods.
Which one of the following congenital conditions is most closely associated with this condition?

A. Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome)
B. 47XX,Y (Klinefelter syndrome)
C. Gardner syndrome
D. Haemophilia
E. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)

Correct Answer: E

A 61-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with stiffness in his muscles, difficulty initiating movements such as getting up from a chair, slow movements and hand shaking, which started 5 weeks ago. He has a medical history of schizophrenia and has had good compliance with his medication for the past 3 months. He is taking haloperidol. On examination, his temperature is 37.5 °C, blood pressure 120/81 mmHg and pulse 98 bpm. On examination, there is decreased facial expression, pill-rolling tremor, cogwheel rigidity and festinating gait.
Which of the following terms best describes the presentation of this patient?

A. Akathisia
B. Tardive dyskinesia
C. Bradykinesia
D. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
E. Acute dystonia

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old businessman has called out the pest controller for the third time in the past month. He is concerned that the house is infested with rats and he continuously looks under the beds and around the property for evidence of the infestation. Apparently, he saw a psychologist in his teenage years for obsessive hand washing and had a short period of cognitive behavioural therapy.
Physical examination is entirely normal, he admits on further questioning that he feels compelled to check for rats and is constantly concerned about cleanliness.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anxiety
B. Bipolar disease
C. Depression
D. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
E. Schizophrenia

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old woman is suspected of having bone disease.
The following results are obtained:
Plasma
Investigation Result Normal range
Corrected Ca2+ 1.80 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Albumin 40 g/l 35–55 g/l
PO43− 0.6 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 170 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Which of the following diagnoses is consistent with these results?

A. Osteoporosis
B. Osteomalacia
C. Paget’s disease
D. Myeloma
E. Bone metastases

Correct Answer: B

You are seeing a 64-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with urge incontinence. She has trialled conservative measures, such as optimising fluid and caffeine intake and completing six weeks of bladder training, which have helped to some extent. Despite this, her main symptom of nocturia continues to affect her sleep and well-being.
She has no other medical history and currently takes no regular medication.
Which is the next most appropriate treatment?

A. Augmentation cystoplasty
B. Botulinum toxin
C. Desmopressin
D. Oxybutinin
E. Percutaneous sacral nerve stimulation

Correct Answer: D

Your consultant asks you to monitor an 83-year-old woman on a General Medical Ward admitted with a lower respiratory tract infection who the nurses say becomes really confused at night. She scores 28/30 on Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) on two occasions in the daytime. Between these two results, on a night when you are on call, you completed the examination and found she scored only 18/30. She also complained of animals running around the room.
What is the most likely reason for her cognitive impairment?

A. Mild dementia
B. Moderate dementia
C. Delirium
D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
E. Cerebral abscess

Correct Answer: C

A third year medical student on a ward round with your firm is asking about pacemakers.
Which of the following IS an indication for permanent pacemaker insertion?

A. Third degree AV block (complete heart block)
B. Type 1 second degree (Mobitz I) AV block
C. Ventricular tachycardia
D. Ventricular fibrillation
E. Non-symptomatic atrial fibrillation

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of fatigue, muscle and joint pain, abdominal bloating and a throbbing unilateral headache. She says that she cannot sleep well and has an intense desire to consume chocolate and sweet drinks. On examination, she is alert and orientated. There is bilateral breast tenderness and mild facial and hand puffiness. She seems easily distracted and recalls two of three words after a delay. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. She says she has had several similar episodes previously, each lasting about 1 week. During these episodes, she becomes irritable, frequently cries, tends to miss work and occasionally gets into conflict with her husband and colleagues.
To which of the following phases of the menstrual cycle is this condition most likely related?

A. Follicular phase
B. Peri-ovulatory phase
C. Luteal phase
D. Early menstrual phase
E. Late menstrual phase

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old woman is referred to the Diabetes Clinic with a new diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 34 kg/m2. Her finger-prick blood glucose test is 9 mmol/l. She has a past history of ischaemic heart disease and chronic kidney disease. Her medications include ramipril 10 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg, aspirin 75 mg and bisoprolol 5 mg. Her laboratory test results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal range
HbA1C 61 mmol/mol < 53 mmol/mol (<7.0%)
Creatinine 178 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 26 ml/min > 90 ml/min
Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate to manage this patient’s diabetes?

A. Glargine insulin
B. Rosiglitazone
C. Linagliptin
D. Metformin
E. Gliclazide

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old patient is admitted by ambulance to Accident and Emergency. He is unconscious, and therefore you are unable to take any sort of history. He is maintaining his own airway. However, he has a decreased respiratory rate (RR) of 8 breaths per minute and is saturating at 88% on air. His arterial blood gas (ABG) shows respiratory acidosis, and his pupils appear small.
Which of the following medications would be most appropriate during initial management?

A. Flumazenil
B. Naloxone
C. N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC)
D. Adrenaline
E. Atropine

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man with a history of allergic rhinitis and asthma, being treated with inhaled bronchodilators, cromolyn sodium and the anti-inflammatory agent montelukast, presents with mild fever, malaise, weight loss and night sweats. He has a stuffy nose, cough and exertional shortness of breath. He complains of multiple joint pain, tingling sensation in both hands and feet and occasional abdominal pain with diarrhoea. Full blood count with differential reveals peripheral blood eosinophilia of 24%. His serum perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody is positive. Blood urea nitrogen and creatinine are within normal range. Urinalysis is unrevealing.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Classic polyarteritis nodosa
B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
C. Microscopic polyangiitis
D. Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGP)
E. Asthma and systemic parasitic infection

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old woman involved in a motorbike accident is brought to the Emergency Department at 10 pm. Her airway is patent; the respiratory rate is 20/minute with normal pulse oximetry and a clear chest; she is slightly tachycardic but is well perfused with a normal blood pressure. She is found to have a tibial fracture on the right side. The broken bone is visible through a break in the skin.
Which of the following is most appropriate?

A. List the patient for theatre in the next few days to allow swelling to subside
B. Stabilise, give IV abx and take to theatre on the earliest scheduled trauma list
C. Give tetanus cover, oral antibiotics, apply plaster cast and discharge for fracture clinic review
D. Manage conservatively
E. Apply plaster casting and admit to infectious disease team due to risk of spreading infection

Correct Answer: B

An 81-year-old woman is seen by her general practitioner with increasing shortness of breath on exertion and swelling of her ankles and lower legs. On examination, she is fully alert and orientated and looks well but has significant erythema of her malar area.
CV – HR 92–104 irregular, low volume
BP – 145/90 mmHg lying = standing
JVP – raised, single wave form
Apex beat – undisplaced and ‘forceful’ in character
HS: 1 + 2 + soft mid-diastolic murmur
Chest – bibasal crackles
Pitting peripheral oedema to the mid-calf
Given this presentation and the clinical findings, what is the most likely cause of her collapse?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Aortic regurgitation
C. Mixed mitral and aortic valve disease
D. Mitral stenosis
E. Mitral regurgitation

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old Jewish woman was diagnosed with breast cancer. Genetic analysis revealed that she was BRCA1-positive.
What other kind of cancer is she at greatest risk for developing?

A. Gastric carcinoma
B. Endometrial cancer
C. Cervical cancer
D. Lung cancer
E. Ovarian cancer

Correct Answer: E

A 33-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset, severe chest pain, radiating to the intrascapular area, which he describes as a tearing-type pain.
The patient is usually well, with the only other medical history of note being a diagnosis of Ehlers–Danlos syndrome. He is a non-smoker and rarely drinks.
On examination, the patient appears to be in a significant amount of pain. He is apyrexial, with oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Of note, the patient has a blood pressure of 175/100 mmHg in the right arm and 150/80 mmHg in the left. An early diastolic murmur is also heard in the aortic area.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
B. Acute pancreatitis
C. Aortic dissection
D. Myocardial infarction
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: C

Which cell in the normal lymph node is a specialised, highly efficient antigen-presenting cell (APC) found mostly in areas of T-cell concentration?

A. Reticular cell
B. Dendritic cell
C. Macrophage
D. Follicular dendritic cell (FDC)
E. B cell

Correct Answer: B

A 74-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with stress incontinence. Her body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2 and her past medical history includes diabetes mellitus and sleep apnoea.
She comes to see you today as her symptoms have worsened despite reducing her daily caffeine intake and signing up with Weight Watchers, managing to lose 1 stone of weight in two months. She has a normal gynaecological examination.
She has completed three months of pelvic floor exercises, which have only mildly improved her symptoms. She wants to try something else, but she tells you she has previously had a severe reaction to general anaesthetic and would like to avoid surgery.
Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

A. Continue pelvic floor exercises for up to another three months and then reassess symptoms
B. Duloxetine
C. Intramural urethral-bulking agents
D. Ring pessary
E. Retropubic mid-urethral tape procedure

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old law graduate has a 2-month history of pains in the left wrist. The patient describes that the pain is worse in the evenings, usually increasing in severity as the day goes on. She is concerned, as her grandmother and an aunt have rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and wonders if she could have the condition too.
Which of the following options regarding rheumatoid arthritis is most accurate?

A. The distal interphalangeal joints are the most commonly affected
B. Rheumatoid nodules suggest negative rheumatoid factor
C. Those with extra-articular manifestations have a worse prognosis
D. Affected individuals often complain of joint stiffness, which is worse towards the end of the day
E. It is more common in males

Correct Answer: C

A 38-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe left loin pain radiating to his groin. Urinalysis illustrates haematuria. You suspect there may be a renal stone, and an ultrasound scan (USS) of the kidneys, ureters and bladder (KUB) shows a probable stone in the left ureter.
What is the most appropriate imaging modality to visualise a ureteric renal stone?

A. Non-contrast computed tomography (CT) KUB
B. Micturating cystourethrogram
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) KUB
D. Plain radiography KUB
E. Intravenous urography (IVU)

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old man attends the anticoagulation clinic for routine international normalised ratio (INR) measurement as he is on warfarin for chronic atrial fibrillation. While the test is carried out the patient mentions that he has been trying to change his diet to include more fruit and has started drinking cranberry juice.
The INR result is measured to be 6. He patient is well with no signs of active bleeding.
What is the next best step in his management?

A. Continue warfarin and recheck INR
B. Stop warfarin, commence vitamin K and recheck INR
C. Stop warfarin and recheck INR
D. Reduce warfarin and recheck INR
E. Stop warfarin, commence prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) and recheck INR

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man is having trouble with his short-term memory, which has occurred since an episode of near drowning. He also has lost the ability to learn new tasks. Due to the patient’s symptoms, ischaemic damage to specific areas within the medial temporal lobe is suspected.
To which area of the medial temporal lobe would bilateral damage result in loss of capacity to learn new things and affect short-term memory?

A. Hippocampus
B. Median raphe nucleus
C. Amygdala
D. Thalamus
E. Locus ceruleus

Correct Answer: A

A 16-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever, sore throat and pain on swallowing. There is no cough or breathing difficulty. She is able to swallow liquids, but her appetite is poor. She has a past medical history of recurrent tonsillitis.
On clinical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C, on throat examination there is tonsillar erythema and exudate and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. She does not appear dehydrated.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s sore throat?

A. Arrange hospital admission for intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Incision and drainage of tonsil
C. Oral antibiotics
D. Regular non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
E. Regular paracetamol

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old school teacher presented with abdominal fullness and weight loss over the last 5 months. On examination, he was found to be pale. His blood tests revealed:
Parameter Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 103 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 66.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophil count 38.4 × 109/l 2.2–8.6 × 109/l
Lymphocyte count 3.4 × 109/l 0.8–3.5 × 109/l
Platelets 510 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 54 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1sthour
His peripheral blood picture is shown here:
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
What is the next most definitive step in diagnosis?

A. Bone marrow study
B. Genotype study
C. Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score
D. Immunophenotyping
E. Iron kinetics study

Correct Answer: B

A 44-year-old, who has previously undergone a hysterectomy procedure for treatment of fibroids, presents to the Preoperative Gynaecology Clinic prior to sacrospinous fixation for treatment of a vault prolapse. The risks and complications of the surgery are outlined before consent is obtained.
Which of the following nerves is at risk of damage during sacrospinous fixation for treatment of a vault prolapse?

A. Common peroneal nerve
B. Femoral
C. Sciatic
D. Inguinal
E. Posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh

Correct Answer: C

While taking blood from a patient with suspected HIV, you sustain a needlestick injury.
What is the first most appropriate action to take?

A. Wash wound under running water, encouraging active bleeding
B. Contact occupational health immediately
C. Begin Truvada and Kaletra post exposure prophylaxis (PEP) treatment
D. Check HIV and bloodborne disease status of patient
E. Fill out a clinical incident form

Correct Answer: A

A fit and well 39-week pregnant patient is admitted for a planned Caesarean section. Blood tests show the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 102 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 89 fl 82–98 fl
Platelets 156 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 11 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
With which of the following are these findings consistent?

A. Pancytopenia
B. Folic acid deficiency
C. Iron deficiency anaemia
D. Dilutional anaemia of pregnancy
E. Myelodysplasia

Correct Answer: D

An 80-year-old man with atrial fibrillation presented 6 months after discharge from hospital, following a myocardial infarction. He had no further chest pain but had developed swelling of the breasts, which was uncomfortable on occasion. Examination revealed tender bilateral gynaecomastia.
Which of his current medications is most likely to be responsible?

A. Aspirin
B. Bisoprolol
C. Digoxin
D. Eplerenone
E. Simvastatin

Correct Answer: C

Vaginal discharge is a common complaint in gynaecology.
Which of the statements below is correct?

A. Oral metronidazole is not indicated in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis
B. PV metronidazole is a treatment option for bacterial vaginosis
C. Oral treatment has a higher cure rate than topical treatment for vaginal candidiasis (thrush)
D. PV metronidazole is commonly used to treat trichomoniasis
E. Recurrent candidiasis is common in women and does not warrant further work-up

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old woman presented to her General Practitioner complaining of six months of intermittent uncomfortable abdominal distension and bloating, which changed with her menstrual cycle. These symptoms were interspersed with bouts of loose motions. She worked as a trader in a busy office and found work very stressful; she had previously taken a course of fluoxetine for anxiety and depression. Examination, blood test results and sigmoidoscopy were all normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic pancreatitis
B. Diverticulitis
C. Irritable bowel syndrome
D. Peptic ulcer disease
E. Ulcerative colitis

Correct Answer: C

An elderly man comes into the surgery because he is unhappy with a new drug that he started in the last 2 months. He claims it gives him pain in the middle of his chest and he has felt more bloated recently.
Which one of the following is most likely to account for these symptoms?

A. Omeprazole
B. Alendronic acid
C. Bisoprolol
D. Digoxin
E. Gabapentin

Correct Answer: B

A 61-year-old man snores at night and his wife reports it is so loud that he often wakes her up. She notes that her husband sometimes appears to not take a breath for a long time and then gasps for air before continuing to snore. He suffers from daytime headaches and sleepiness. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 40 kg/m2.
What would the most likely arterial blood gas result be if it was measured in this patient?

A. Compensated respiratory acidosis
B. Compensated respiratory alkalosis
C. Compensated metabolic acidosis
D. Uncompensated respiratory acidosis
E. Uncompensated metabolic acidosis

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old man presents with central chest pain which is worse unless sitting forward. He says that the pain gets worse when he takes a deep breath in. There is no previous cardiac history and he is a non-smoker. Over the past few days, he has had a fever with cold and flu type symptoms.
On examination, his blood pressure is 135/80 mmHg, and he has an audible pericardial rub.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 41 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 345 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Creatine kinase (CK) 185 IU/l 23–175 IU/l
Total cholesterol 4.8 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
Electrocardiogram – saddle-shaped ST elevation across all leads.
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Cardiac tamponade
B. Acute pericarditis
C. Myocarditis
D. Acute myocardial infarction
E. Unstable angina

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man is due to have an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy in a week’s time under general anaesthesia, because of recurrent episodes of biliary colic. He has no known co-morbidities or allergies.
What is the correct advice to give him about eating and drinking before surgery?

A. No food or fluids from midnight before surgery
B. No food or fluids for 6 hours before surgery
C. No food for 6 hours before surgery, clear fluids until 4 hours before surgery
D. No food for 6 hours before surgery, clear fluids until 2 hours before surgery
E. No food for 6 hours before surgery, clear fluids for 1 hour before surgery

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old sheep farmer complains of vague abdominal pains predominantly affecting the right upper quadrant. He has no other significant past medical history.
On examination, there is vague abdominal tenderness, but no other specific findings.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 300 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 42 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Bilirubin 65 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 125 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 78 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Plain abdominal X-ray – Multiple calcified cysts within the liver
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Multiple hepatic adenomas
B. Cystic teratoma with metastases
C. Hydatid disease
D. Tuberculosis (TB)
E. Amoebic liver abscess

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man presents to the Accident and Emergency (A&E) department with breathlessness. The breathlessness started suddenly about 3 hours ago. He also has a sharp pain on the right side of his chest, which is worse if he takes a deep breath. He was recently on holiday in Australia, and returned this morning. He had a hernia repair 3 weeks ago, which was uneventful. While he was on holiday, he developed an ear infection, and was prescribed a 5-day course of amoxicillin. He uses a salbutamol inhaler occasionally for his asthma, but has no other regular medications. His observations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Respiratory rate (RR) 25 breaths per minute 12–20 breaths per minute
O2 saturation 95% on high-flow oxygen
via non-rebreather mask 94–99%
Pulse 110 beats per minute 60–100 beats per minute
Blood pressure (BP) 140/100 mmHg <120/<80 mmHg
What is the first test you would do?

A. Chest X-ray (CXR)
B. D-Dimer
C. Peak flow
D. Arterial blood gas (ABG)
E. Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old man presents with a 1-hour history of chest pain and is found to have an acute ST elevation inferior myocardial infarct. His blood pressure is 126/78 mmHg and has a pulse of 58 bpm. He is loaded with anti-platelets, and the cardiac monitor shows second-degree heart block (Wenckebach’s phenomenon).
What would you consider next for this patient?

A. Primary percutaneous intervention (PCI)
B. Temporary pacing and primary PCI
C. Beta blocker
D. Permanent pacemaker
E. Primary PCI and permanent pacemaker

Correct Answer: B

You go to see a 29-year-old woman in the Emergency Department (ED) who is experiencing an acute asthma attack. She has been assessed as having a severe attack. At present, she cannot complete sentences and has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths/minute, a pulse rate of >100 bpm and a peak expiratory flow (PEF) 39% of expected. Currently, she has had nebulised salbutamol and intravenous (IV) hydrocortisone, with minimal response. She is currently on high-flow oxygen, but saturations are still low (91%).
Which of the following options is most appropriate next step in the patient’s immediate management?

A. Stop salbutamol nebulisers
B. Add inhaled steroids
C. Reduce oxygen flow rate to help maintain hypoxic drive
D. IV morphine
E. Refer to the ITU

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old swimming instructor presents with an acute onset of widespread inflamed, erythematous, scaly skin changes which came on over a period of 48 hours. A diagnosis of erythroderma is suspected, and the patient is started on oral steroids as a part of management.
Which of the following dermatological conditions is most likely to cause erythroderma?

A. Lichen planus
B. Livedo reticularis
C. Norwegian scabies
D. Pityriasis rosea
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman with no significant medical history develops a paradoxical embolic stroke following a deep vein thrombosis.
What embryological problem is most likely to explain this?

A. Bicuspid aortic valve
B. Patent foramen ovale
C. Tetralogy of Fallot
D. Transposition of the great arteries
E. Triscuspid atresia

Correct Answer: B

A 67-year-old man is being seen by his General Practitioner for erectile dysfunction. He suffers from well-controlled hypertension and diabetes, for which he is on amlodipine and metformin, respectively. He reports good energy levels and high libido, having regular sexual intercourse 3–4 times per week, but struggles to maintain an erection. He still obtains morning erections. Examination and blood tests have come back normal.
What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

A. Alprostadil
B. Tadalafil (Cialis®)
C. Tamsulosin
D. Testosterone replacement
E. Vacuum erection devices

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old man presents with progressively worsening dysphagia, which is worse for food than liquid. He has lost several stones in weight and, on examination, he is cachetic. An oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD) confirms oesophageal cancer.
Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for oesophageal adenocarcinoma?

A. Barrett's oesophagus
B. Blood group A
C. Diet low in calcium
D. Ulcerative colitis
E. Alcohol

Correct Answer: A

A baby born to a 29-year-old woman has ambiguous genitalia on examination; the rest of the physical examination is normal. Genotype is determined to be XY. The testes are retained within the abdominal cavity, and the internal reproductive tracts exhibit the normal male phenotype.
Which of the following could account for this abnormal development?

A. 5α-reductase deficiency
B. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency
C. Complete androgen resistance
D. Sertoli-only syndrome
E. Testicular dysgenesis

Correct Answer: A

A patient was diagnosed with disease of a heart valve located between the left ventricle and the ascending aorta.
Which of the following is most likely to describe the cusps that comprise this heart valve?

A. Anterior, posterior and septal cusps
B. Right, left and posterior cusps
C. Anterior and posterior cusps
D. Right, left and anterior cusps
E. Anterior and septal cusps

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old woman presents to her Accident and Emergency with visual loss. She has known persistently uncontrolled hypertension, previously managed in the community. Blood tests are performed as follows:
Investigation Patient Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 148 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 2.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/
Chloride (Cl–) 100 mEq/l 96–106 mEq/l
What is the next most appropriate investigation?

A. Aldosterone levels
B. Aldosterone-to-renin ratio
C. Magnetic resonance (MR) angiogram of renal arteries
D. CT angiogram of renal arteries
E. 24 hour urine metanephrine levels

Correct Answer: B

A 12-year-old child developed headaches, vomiting and a staggering gait. A cerebellar neoplasm was diagnosed.
Which is the most common cerebellar neoplasm of childhood?

A. Ependymoma
B. Glioblastoma multiforme
C. Neuroblastoma
D. Astrocytoma
E. Oligodendroglioma

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old man was stabbed with a knife and brought to the Emergency Department, with the knife still in the left posterolateral side of his body. The knife entered the intercostal space between the left ninth and tenth ribs, 10 cm posterior to the mid-axillary line.
Which of the following structures was most likely the first to be damaged by the knife?

A. Pancreas
B. Left kidney
C. Stomach
D. Spleen
E. Gall bladder

Correct Answer: D

A 57-year-old woman is incidentally found to have an adenomatous polyp measuring 12 mm, following a colonoscopy for a 2-month history of change in bowel habit. No other bowel pathology is found. The polyp is removed completely during the procedure.
When will this patient be offered a further colonoscopy for surveillance of the bowel?

A. At one year
B. At two years
C. At three years
D. At five years
E. No surveillance required

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man comes for a review. He developed a red rash on his face a few months ago after several episodes of facial flushing. On examination, there are multiple erythaematous papules spread across his cheeks and his nose is red and bulbous.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
B. Acne vulgaris
C. Systemic lupus erythaematosus
D. Nodulocystic acne
E. Acne rosacea

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old businessman is seen in the Urology Clinic following a general practitioner (GP) referral for a single painful genital ulcer. The patient tells you that the skin lesion has changed over time, previously appearing pustular, shortly after he returned from South America. On examination, you notice the ulcer base to be filled with a malodorous yellow exudate, and on palpation there is unilateral tender lymphadenopathy.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Genital herpes
B. Chancroid
C. Syphilis
D. Donovanosis
E. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)

Correct Answer: B

A woman is having her preoperative assessment for a hernia repair. Her body mass index (BMI) is calculated at 38.
Which definition correctly describes her BMI value?

A. Normal BMI
B. Overweight
C. Obese class 1
D. Obese class 2
E. Morbid obesity/obese class 3

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner with anorexia, loss of appetite, hot flushes, especially at night and weight loss for the past six months. He has a cough with expectoration and intermittent fever for the past one month. Chest X-ray shows a large (4.5 cm), left upper-lobe cavity.
Which of the following investigations lead to a definitive diagnosis?

A. Blood cultures
B. Computed tomography (CT) scanning of the chest
C. Mantoux test
D. Serum inflammatory markers
E. Sputum sample

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old woman presents with a few months history of abdominal pain and diarrhoea. Further questioning reveals increasing episodes of facial flushing and occasional wheeze. Clinical examination reveals irregular, craggy hepatomegaly. Abdominal CT is performed which reveals non-specific thickening of a terminal small bowel loop, a large calcified lesion in the small bowel mesentery and innumerable lesions in the liver.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Carcinoid syndrome
B. Whipple’s disease
C. Yersinia ileitis
D. Tuberculosis
E. Normal menopause

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old man complained of recent difficulty in starting and stopping urination. He denied any previous history of urinary problems.
The doctor took a gloved index finger and palpated the patient’s prostate gland, most likely through the wall of which of the following structures?

A. Urinary bladder
B. Sigmoid colon
C. Anus
D. Caecum
E. Rectum

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old woman has had a burning sensation on passing urine with frequency for the past two days, and she also has some lower abdominal pain. She has no unusual vaginal discharge and denies any recent sexual contact. This is the first time she has experienced anything like this.
She is a non-smoker and a well-controlled asthmatic on regular inhalers (daily beclomethasone and salbutamol as needed) but has no other medical problems or medication apart from the oral combined contraceptive pill.
On examination her heart rate is 85 beats per minute, blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, and temperature 36.8°C.
Abdominal examination – soft abdomen, no guarding, mildly tender hypogastric region, active bowel sounds.
Urinalysis:
Leukocytes –
Nitrites ++
Blood +
Bilirubin –
Protein +
Glucose –
Ketones –
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Urinary tract infection (UTI)
B. Pelvic inflammatory disease
C. Bladder Cancer
D. Gonococcal infection
E. Nephrotic syndrome

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents to the clinic for the third time this year with fever, dysuria, dribbling of urine. Previous admissions were for urinary tract infections. He has a history of hypertension and previous myocardial infarction for which he takes ramipril and rosuvastatin. On examination, he is pyrexial (38.4 °C) and has a pulse of 110/min and his blood pressure (BP) is 140/82 mm Hg. His cardiovascular and respiratory examination is normal. There is suprapubic tenderness with dullness, on percussion, indicating a distended bladder. Per rectal examination reveals a smoothly enlarged prostate.
What is the best next investigation to determine the cause of this patient’s urinary retention?

A. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
B. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen
C. Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG)
D. Serum alpha-fetoprotein
E. Ultrasound pelvis with post-voidal bladder volume

Correct Answer: E

This 65-year-old man has had the rash shown on his hand for three months. It is also present and looks the same on the other hand. It is not particularly itchy. He has a rash on the sole of both feet that he treated with an anti-fungal cream, without effect. There is no nail involvement. There are no other skin lesions on the body and he cannot remember having had any significant skin problems in the past. He has recently started taking atenolol because of angina.
Which of the following features is most suggestive of a diagnosis of psoriasis, rather than a dermatophyte fungal infection?

A. Erythema
B. Involvement of the hands
C. Lack of itch
D. No nail involvement
E. Symmetrical rash

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old retired Professor presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with lesions on the back of his hand. The lesions have been there for months, and are slightly erythematous and scaly.
The man is otherwise well and enjoys golfing on weekends.
An image of his hand is shown below.
By James Heilman, MD [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], from Wikimedia Commons
What is the most appropriate treatment for this man’s lesions?

A. 5-fluorouracil cream
B. Betnovate ointment
C. Coal tar ointment
D. Hydromol ointment
E. Miconazole cream

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with massive haematemesis. An emergency endoscopy is performed which shows a bleeding gastric ulcer of the lesser curvature of the stomach.
Which of the following vessels is most likely to be involved?

A. The left gastroepiploic artery
B. The right gastroepiploic artery
C. The gastroduodenal artery
D. The left gastric artery
E. The short gastric arteries

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old G3P2 woman attends the Emergency Department, complaining of vaginal bleeding. She denies pain or fevers. Her last menstrual period was 9 weeks prior to attendance and she has not established care in this pregnancy. Her heart rate is 75 bpm, blood pressure 110/70 mmHg and temperature is 37.0 ºC. A serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin level is 9500 iu. Pelvic examination determines the cervical os to be closed. Bedside ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac with cardiac activity.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Ectopic pregnancy
B. Septic miscarriage
C. Missed miscarriage
D. Complete miscarriage
E. Threatened miscarriage

Correct Answer: E

A 17-year-old boy has been found to have proteinuria on urinalysis. He has a past medical history of type I diabetes which was diagnosed four years ago. He has managed his diabetes well and there have been no indications of any complications in this time. His urinary albumin : creatinine ratio is raised.
Which of the following features on a kidney biopsy of this patient is most likely to help confirm the diagnosis?

A. Diffuse mesangial immunoglobulin A (IgA) deposition
B. Focal segmental areas of mesangial sclerosis
C. Glomerular crescents
D. Interstitial eosinophilic infiltrate
E. Kimmelstein–Wilson nodules

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with fever, rigors, breathlessness and a cough. He is producing a frothy pink/green sputum spotted with blood. On examination, you find that he is very confused, with a respiratory rate (RR) of 33 breaths per minute and blood pressure (BP) of 100/70 mmHg. Bloods reveal his urea is 3.2 mmol/l. On auscultation of the chest, you hear a pleural rub. Chest X-ray reveals multilobar consolidation.
Which one of the following statements regarding his management is most appropriate?

A. This patient can be discharged with oral antibiotics
B. Oxygen saturations of <95% at presentation increase his risk of death
C. Analgesia is ineffective for pleuritic chest pain
D. He needs an ABC approach with fluid resuscitation
E. Antibiotics should be delayed until culture results are obtained

Correct Answer: D

A A. 28-year-old man with schizophrenia has been refusing to let the mental health team enter his house, convinced that they are MI5. His mother is concerned for his wellbeing and advises the team that he has not taken medication for two weeks.
Which is the most appropriate section of the mental health act that should be initiated prior to the further treatment of the patient?

A. 2
B. 3
C. 4
1B. 35
1B. 36

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man in referred to the Respiratory Outpatient clinic with a chronic non-productive cough. He is a non-smoker and has no other symptoms.
Initial investigations reveal normal full blood count and C-reactive protein, normal chest X-ray and normal spirometry.
What is the next most appropriate investigation?

A. Bronchial provocation testing
B. Computed tomography (CT) thorax
C. Bronchoscopy
D. Sputum culture
E. Maximal inspiratory and expiratory pressures

Correct Answer: A

You are reviewing an elderly but physically fit 74 year old gentleman in the urology outpatient clinic. He initially presented to his GP with an episode of frank haematuria. Urinalysis revealed ongoing microscopic haematuria. Following referral to the urologist, a contrast MRI scan reveals a solitary low risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment?

A. Radical cystectomy
B. Transurethral resection of bladder tumour (TURBT)
C. Radiotherapy alone
D. Palliative management
E. Intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG)

Correct Answer: B

A 83-year-old man with a history of dementia was admitted to your medical ward from a nursing home in Scotland a week ago. A swallow assessment was performed after the patient was noticed to have difficulty eating and drinking; which concluded that the patient was at high risk of aspiration. The care team therefore wish to make him nil by mouth and start intravenous (IV) fluids. You have explained the situation to him and asked for his consent, which he refused. You are not content that he has fully understood the gravity of the situation, as a result of his dementia. You note that the patient does not have a welfare attorney or guardian with power to consent.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate way to proceed in this scenario?

A. Start the IV nutrition under the principle of necessity
B. Contact the nursing home to see whether they are happy with the treatment
C. Find out if the patient has any relatives and ask them whether they will consent
D. Issue a certificate under section 47 of the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000 and begin the treatment
E. Apply to a court to make a decision

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old writer presents to his routine follow up at the Nephrology Clinic complaining of numbness and tingling sensation of his right fingers. This worsens when he types for more than an hour and slightly improves when he stops typing. He suffers from diabetes mellitus and end-stage kidney disease and has been on regular haemodialysis via brachiocephalic fistula on his right antecubital fossa. On examination, his right radial artery is palpable and he has reduced sensation in all his right fingers, predominantly affecting the finger tips. The numbness does not worsen with tapping over the wrist nor with forced flexion of his wrists. His capillary refill time over his right fingers is prolonged to three seconds.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Carpal tunnel syndrome
B. Diabetic neuropathy
C. Ulnar styloid fracture
D. Fistula steal syndrome
E. Radial nerve palsy

Correct Answer: D

A 7-year-old girl presents to her general practice clinic, accompanied by her mother. She has been feeling unwell over the last few days with nasal stuffiness, sneezing and a sore throat. On examination today, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute and temperature 36.9 °C. She has no relevant past medical history.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Common cold
B. Hay fever
C. Infectious mononucleosis
D. Influenza
E. Meningitis

Correct Answer: A

A 3-week-old infant, born at term, presents to the Emergency Department with persistent jaundice since birth, pale stools and dark urine. The infant is currently being breastfed.
What is the most likely cause of this child’s jaundice?

A. Biliary atresia
B. Cystic fibrosis
C. Cholelithiasis
D. Breastfeeding jaundice
E. Physiological jaundice

Correct Answer: A

A 29-year-old woman presents one week following delivery with some concerns about breastfeeding. She is exclusively breastfeeding at present, but the baby has lost weight (400 g) and she finds breastfeeding difficult and painful. The baby weighed 3300 grams at the time of birth. There is pain in both nipples, worse at the beginning of the feed, and clicking noises are heard when the baby is feeding. She sometimes has to stop feeding because of the discomfort.
On examination, the breasts are engorged and there is no area of erythema or tenderness. The nipples appear normal, and there is no discharge or erythema.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?

A. Advise on use of regular emollients
B. Flucloxacillin for 10–14 days
C. Refer to a breastfeeding specialist for assessment
D. Suggest trial of nipple shields
E. Topical miconazole after feeds

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner complaining of a backache that has persisted for the last two weeks. The doctor diagnoses her with a muscle strain and recommends rest with paracetamol for pain as needed. The patient requested narcotic pain medicine, but the doctor refused to prescribe the drug because she thought a medicine of that strength was unnecessary. The patient left the examination room angrily and yelled at the reception staff on her way out.
Which of the following defence mechanisms was the patient demonstrating?

A. Denial
B. Fixation
C. Projection
D. Displacement
E. Splitting

Correct Answer: D

A Foundation Year 1 doctor was going through some peripheral blood slides from patients, and she came across this large cell among some red blood cells (RBCs).
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
What is this cell called?

A. Neutrophil
B. Blast cell
C. Eosinophil
D. Nucleated RBC
E. Monocyte

Correct Answer: E

A 14-year-old girl presents to her General Practitioner with primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, the patient has normal secondary sexual development.
What is the most likely reason for her lack of periods?

A. Congenital deformity of the uterus
B. Imperforate hymen
C. Normal physiological delay
D. Hyperprolactinaemia
E. Hypothyroidism

Correct Answer: B

A 68-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner for an annual check-up, complaining of feeling tired and thirsty all the time. He has background history of obesity, hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His GP arranges screening for type II diabetes and the following are his results:
Investigation Result Normal range
HbA1C 48 mmol/mol < 53 mmol/mol (<7.0%)
Fasting plasma glucose 7.2 mmol/l < 7 mmol/l
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 90 ml/min > 90 ml/min
Which of the following is part of the diagnostic criteria for type II diabetes?

A. Fasting plasma glucose ≥7.0 mmol/l
B. 2-hour plasma glucose ≥12.1 mmol/l after oral 75 g glucose load
C. HbA1C ≥52 mmol/mol (7.0%)
D. Random plasma glucose ≥10 mmol/l in a patient with classic symptoms of diabetes or hyperglycaemic crisis
E. 1-hour plasma glucose ≥11.1 mmol/l after oral 75g glucose load

Correct Answer: A

A 74-year-old man presens to his General Practitioner with a history of 10-kg weight loss over the past six months and fevers. He has no history of cough or foreign travel. He takes no regular medication, except for emollients prescribed recently for itchy skin. He does not smoke and has stopped drinking, as this causes pain in his neck. On examination, he is noted to have normal cardiovascular and respiratory systems and no organomegaly on palpation of the abdomen. He is found to have two golf ball-sized cervical lymph nodes on the right.
Given the suspected diagnosis, which of the following is most likely to be used in the management of this patient?

A. Azacitidine
B. Radiotherapy
C. Rifampicin
D. Rituximab
E. Stem cell transplant

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man with a history of ulcerative colitis attends the Gastroenterology Clinic for review. Over the past few months, his bowel symptoms have been generally quiescent, but he has suffered from tiredness and itching.
On examination, you notice that he has jaundiced sclerae and there are some scratch marks on his abdomen consistent with the itching.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 5.6 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 90 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 110 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 290 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 45 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Autoantibody screen ANCA +, anti-cardiolipin +, ANA +
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 75 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 290 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Bilirubin 85 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cholelithiasis
B. Hepatocellular carcinoma
C. Primary biliary cholangitis
D. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
E. Ascending cholangitis

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of pains in her knees which are worse after prolonged exertion. She has been treated for osteoarthritis with physiotherapy and weight loss. Her symptoms have not improved and the GP is requesting an X-ray to confirm the diagnosis.
Which of the following findings on a knee X-ray suggests an alternative diagnosis to osteoarthritis?

A. Loss of joint space
B. Normal knee X-ray
C. Osteophyte formation
D. Reduction in bone marrow density
E. Subchondral sclerosis

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man with a family history of colorectal cancer presents for genetic screening. Genetic testing is performed and he is diagnosed with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer syndrome (HNPCC, or Lynch syndrome).
What is his lifetime risk for developing colorectal cancer?

A. 90–100%
B. 50–70%
C. 30–50%
D. 15–30%
E. <15%

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 10 weeks gestation visits her midwife for a routine booking appointment. She has sickle cell anaemia. Her partner’s sickle cell status is Hb AS. Her haemoglobin is 9.2 g / dl.
Which of the following best describes the chances of her baby having sickle cell disease?

A. 1 in 8
B. 1 in 4
C. 1 in 5
D. 1 in 2
E. 1 in 3

Correct Answer: D

During bronchoscopy, a surgeon observes a lesion of the carina at the bifurcation of the trachea.
At which vertebral level is this lesion located?

A. T2/3
B. T3/4
C. T4/5
D. T5/6
E. T6/7

Correct Answer: C

An elderly patient is admitted with severe epistaxis. The epistaxis continues despite multiple attempts at silver nitrate cautery. The bleeding is successfully slowed with nasal packing. Other history of note includes atrial fibrillation, for which he takes warfarin.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate first line pharmacological therapy for this gentleman’s epistaxis?

A. Vitamin K
B. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)
C. Prothrombin complex concentrate (such as Beriplex or Octoplex)
D. Factor VIII
E. Packed red blood cells

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old woman presents to herGeneral Practitioner with extreme pain on defecation and passage of fresh red blood when opening the bowels for the last 2 weeks. She is slightly constipated but otherwise well and has no significant past history of illness.
What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A. Refer to colorectal surgeons for further assessment
B. Order a colonoscopy
C. Prescribe GTN cream and laxatives
D. Prescribe co-codamol for analgesia
E. Give dietary advice and reassurance

Correct Answer: C

Disease X has an average annual incidence of 1.5 per 100 000 people. A city of population 2.5 million identifies a total of 292 patients diagnosed with disease X in a 7-day period.
This increase in point prevalence of disease X can be explained by which term?

A. Endemic disease
B. Epidemic disease
C. Hyperendemic disease
D. Pandemic disease
E. Sporadic disease

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old patient who has been diagnosed with severe sepsis is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). However, he is starting to deteriorate despite being on the sepsis six bundle.
On examination:
Investigation Result Normal value
Respiratory rate (RR) 30 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Heart rate (RR) 120 bpm 60–100 beats/min
Blood pressure (BP) 88/40 mmHg < 120/80 mmHg
You noted some bleeding along the cannulation site and on his gums, the coagulation profile showed prolonged prothrombin time, decrease in fibrinogen level and marked elevation of D-dimer.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the above condition?

A. Von Willebrand’s disease
B. Liver failure
C. Haemophilia
D. Administration of heparin
E. Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC)

Correct Answer: E

An elderly man attempts to lift a heavy shopping bag but feels sudden pain in his shoulder as he does so. Following this, he has soreness in the region of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. He finds when he tries to move his shoulder that he is unable to initiate abduction but can continue to abduct once the arm is lifted away from his side. Flexion and extension of the shoulder can be performed normally; medial and lateral rotation of the humerus is also unaffected.
Injury to the tendon of which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Supraspinatus
B. Infraspinatus
C. Deltoid
D. Subscapularis
E. Biceps brachii

Correct Answer: A

You are an FY2 in General Practice, and see a newly diagnosed pregnant woman. This is her first pregnancy, and the GP has just completed examining her. She is fit and well with no symptoms of anything currently. She is also going to have urine dipstick and blood tests including an infection screen, as all pregnant women do in the surgery.
Which of the following tests should be done as part of an antenatal infection screen?

A. Bacterial vaginosis
B. Chlamydia
C. Hepatitis B
D. Rubella
E. CMV

Correct Answer: C

You sustain a scald to your right hand whilst making a cup of tea.
What is the best initial first aid for minor scalds?

A. Apply an ice pack to the wound for 10-30 minutes followed by application of a moist dressing
B. Apply an emollient such as diprobase cream or butter to the burnt surface covered with a dry dressing
C. Immerse the burn in iced water for 10-15 minutes
D. Irrigate the burn with cool or tepid water for between 10-30 minutes, followed by application of a layer of cling film as a dressing
E. Wait for 20 minutes then run the injured area under cool water

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man attends cardiology outpatients, having been lost to follow-up for 2 years. He has an extensive cardiac history with two previous myocardial infarctions (MIs), peripheral vascular disease and three transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs). He is a non-insulin-dependent diabetic. Examination findings demonstrate a jugular venous pressure (JVP) raised by 2 cm, peripheral pitting oedema to the mid-calf bilaterally and bilateral basal fine inspiratory crepitations. His last echocardiogram (ECHO) 3 years ago demonstrated moderately impaired left ventricular (LV) function and mitral regurgitation. His current medications include: bisoprolol, aspirin, simvastatin, furosemide, ramipril and gliclazide.
Which one of the following medications would be of prognostic benefit if added?

A. Nifedipine
B. Sotalol
C. Digoxin
D. Naftidrofuryl
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: E

A couple attends for genetic counselling. They are considering having a child and wish to discuss pre-implantation genetic screening. The husband of the couple has attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (AFAP) and has undergone prophylactic colectomy as a teenager. The husband’s mother also had the condition. The wife of the couple has no family history of cancer or colon polyps.
What counselling should they be given around the risk of their future child inheriting AFAP?

A. 1 in 2
B. The risk is unknown until the wife of the couple undergoes genetic screening for the AFP gene
C. 1 in 4
D. The risk depends on whether their child is a boy or a girl
E. 3 in 4

Correct Answer: A

A builder makes an uneventful recovery post-appendicectomy, and three months later is back at work on a building site when he gets a sharp pain in the right inguinal region and notices a bulge just above his groin on the right. His GP diagnoses an inguinal hernia.
Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged at appendicectomy?

A. T10
B. Femoral
C. Genitofemoral
D. Obturator
E. Ilioinguinal

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old man presented to Emergency Department with central chest pain, radiating to his left arm. He looks very unwell and clammy. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST elevation in leads II,III and aVF.
Which coronary artery is most likely to be infarcted?

A. Right coronary artery (RCA)
B. Left circumflex artery
C. Left anterior descending artery (LAD)
D. Left circumflex & Right coronary artery
E. Left anterior descending & right coronary artery

Correct Answer: A

Mrs Simpson brings her 4-year-old son Oliver to the general practice surgery. Oliver has been suffering with atopic eczema and has been using aqueous cream regularly, with little effect. The general practitioner wants to try a topical steroid cream.
Which of the following topical steroids is the most appropriate next step?

A. Betnovate
B. Dermovate
C. Eumovate
D. Hydrocortisone 1%
E. Trimovate

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old woman presents to Haematology with fatigue, anaemia and splenomegaly. She is diagnosed with a hereditary condition characterised by abnormal blood cell shape due to a dysfunctional membrane protein. These cells are degraded by the spleen, resulting in splenomegaly and haemolytic anaemia.
What is the most likely abnormality found in a blood film of patients with this condition?

A. Acanthocytic cells
B. Microcytic red blood cells
C. Schistocytes
D. Sphere-shaped red blood cells
E. Teardrop-shaped red blood cells

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a sudden-onset unilateral ptosis on the right side.
On examination, there is anisocoria with miosis of the right pupil. There is also anhidrosis of his right face, arm and trunk. There is no pain in the right arm or scapular region. He is a chronic smoker of 50 pack-years.
A chest X-ray is normal and shows no cause of his symptoms.
What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A. Carotid artery dissection
B. Cavernous sinus thrombosis
C. Multiple sclerosis
D. Pancoast tumour
E. Stroke

Correct Answer: E

You are performing research into the hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis. Some of the hormone concentrations are noted to increase during pregnancy. Your team notices that one hormone in particular displays a greater increase than the others.
Which one of the following hormones is this likely to be?

A. Luteinising hormone (LH)
B. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
C. Oestrone
D. Oestradiol
E. Oestriol

Correct Answer: E

A 48-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a four-month history of nasal congestion, facial pain, a runny nose and a reduction in the sense of smell. He has a background history of exercise-induced asthma. Palpating the maxillofacial area elicits tenderness. There are no visible nasal polyps
Which of the following are major symptoms of chronic sinusitis?

A. Facial pain and/or pressure
B. Cough
C. Nasal polyps
D. Symptoms lasting greater than two weeks
E. Symptoms lasting less than 12 weeks

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old ex-footballer undergoes a right hip hemi-arthroplasty. He is an ex-smoker. He is admitted to the ward.
Which of the following statements is correct regarding his deep venous thrombosis (DVT) thromboprophylaxis?

A. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and compression stockings should be prescribed as standard
B. LMWH should be prescribed only if the patient is at risk of medium-term immobility
C. Heparin infusion should be prescribed as a first line therapy, followed by LMWH
D. Warfarin should be commenced post-operatively with LMWH cover until the international normalised ratio (INR) levels are therapeutic
E. 75 mg aspirin should be prescribed to avoid DVT formation and provide additional cardiac risk factor modification   

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a nodule on the side of his head. On examination, his GP is concerned that the nodule may be a basal cell carcinoma.
What feature is most consistent with this diagnosis?

A. Pigmentation
B. Telangiectasia
C. Size
D. Crusted edges
E. Bleeding

Correct Answer: B
