You are a junior doctor in paediatrics. You are called to attend an emergency Caesarean section for a baby at 38 weeks’ gestation due to failure to progress. The baby is delivered and does not cry immediately. The cord is cut, and the baby is dried and placed on the Resuscitaire®. There is no spontaneous respiratory effort from the baby who is pale and floppy, with a heart rate of 40 bpm.
When would it be appropriate to start chest compressions in a neonate?

A. After five inflation breaths if the baby is not spontaneously breathing
B. After a total of ten inflation breaths and 30 seconds of effective ventilation breaths if the baby’s heart rate is < 60 bpm
C. After ten inflation breaths if the baby’s heart rate is < 120 bpm
D. After ten inflation breaths and two minutes of effective ventilation breaths if the baby’s heart rate is < 60 bpm
E. Before any inflation breaths if the baby’s heart rate is < 60 bpm

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old woman has several large, ruptured, eroded plaques on her upper arm, scalp and groin as a result of the rupture of large, fluid-filled blisters (bullae). She also has an ulcerated blister on the mucosa of her lower lip. A diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris is made.
IgG autoantibodies to which protein is the pathogenesis of this disease due?

A. Collagen type XVIII
B. Desmoglein
C. Bullous pemphigoid antigen
D. Keratin
E. Desmoplakin

Correct Answer: B

A 9-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of right iliac fossa pain. A diagnosis of acute appendicitis is suspected and he is taken into the operating theatre. During surgery, a normal-looking appendix is found and excised. However, another bowel pathology is identified and excised (see picture).

What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Meckel’s diverticulum
B. Intussusception
C. Intestinal carcinoid
D. Intestinal polyp
E. Intestinal tumour

Correct Answer: A

A patient has a family history of blindness, phaeochromocytomas, renal cell carcinomas and haemangioblastomas.
Which gene is implicated?

A. NF1
B. RET
C. VHL
D. c-Myc
E. Menin

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man with no significant history presents complaining of pain in his left forearm and hand relieved by changing the position of his arm. On examination there is loss of sensation on the medial aspect of his hand. A cervical rib is suspected.
In which of the following motor tests would the detection of weakness confirm involvement of the C8 and T1 roots of the brachial plexus, rather than a palsy of the ulnar nerve?

A. Abduction of the fingers
B. Adduction of the fingers
C. Adduction of the thumb
D. Flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the index finger
E. Flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the little finger

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man returns from a hiking holiday and finds he has difficulty raising his right arm. He reports no history of shoulder problems in the past and no specific significant shoulder trauma while on holiday. On examination, there is no deformity of the shoulder joint on inspection. There is weakness of the first 30 degrees of shoulder abduction on the right side. The movement itself is not painful, and there is no loss of cutaneous sensation around the shoulder.
Which of the following structures is most likely to have been damaged?

A. Axillary nerve
B. Deltoid muscle
C. Long thoracic nerve
D. Suprascapular nerve
E. Supraspinatus muscle

Correct Answer: D

A 51-year-old man with a background of insulin-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension has been feeling increasingly lethargic and nauseated over the past four months. He has recently been feeling breathless, especially at night, and has noticed swelling of his ankles.
Blood tests:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 97 g/l 135–175 g/l
Creatinine 695 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Phosphate 2.0 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 50 ml/min/1.73 m2 90–120 ml/min/1.73 m2
Albumin : creatinine ratio 45 mg/mmol
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic kidney disease (CKD), stage G5A3
B. CKD, stage 4
C. Acute kidney injury (AKI)
D. Immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy
E. CKD, stage G3aA3

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old computer programmer presented with blood in the urine. It was painless and not associated with any obstructive feature. On examination, his blood pressure was found to be 166/90 mmHg, although his earlier medical check-up 1 year ago was normal. His only past history was nephrotic syndrome 6 years ago, which was diagnosed histologically as minimal change disease and treated successfully. Urine examination revealed blood only with a trace of protein. He is not currently taking any drugs.
What is the probable diagnosis?

A. Renal arteriovenous (AV) fistula
B. Renal vein thrombosis
C. Renal stones
D. Bladder carcinoma
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: A

A 91-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department from a nursing home with a 4-day history of fever and lethargy. He has a background history of chronic urinary catheterisation for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On clinical examination, he is noted to be acutely confused. His temperature is 38.5 °C, and he has a heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 133/70 mmHg and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute.
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count 13 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Blood glucose 6 mmol/l 4–10 mmol/l
Urinalysis
2+ blood
2+ leukocytes
1+ nitrites
NAD
Which of the following does he have?

A. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
B. Urinary tract infection
C. Sepsis
D. Septic shock
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman complains of irregular and unpredictable uterine bleeding during the last 6 months. Bleeding varies in amount, duration and timing. Review of systems reveals a recent weight gain despite low appetite and generalised weakness. Her work performance has significantly diminished due to fatigue and poor concentration. Her past medical history is unremarkable. She takes bulk-forming laxatives for constipation. She is married, lives with her husband and has one child. On pelvic examination, the vagina and cervix appear normal. There is no adnexal mass or tenderness.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
B. Cervical cancer
C. Submucosal leiomyoma
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Endometrial polyps

Correct Answer: D

A 2-year-old infant presents with a large bruise on the thigh after a fall. His mother comments that he has always been prone to bruising. Investigations show: haemoglobin (Hb) 112 g/l, platelets 186 × 109/l, prothrombin time (PT) 10 s, activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) 70 s and normal bleeding time.
Which of the following is most likely?

A. Haemophilia A
B. von Willebrand disease
C. Vitamin K deficiency
D. Childhood cirrhosis
E. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman, who is undergoing chemotherapy with doxorubicin for carcinoma of the breast, presents with severe nausea and vomiting as a side-effect of the treatment.
On examination, the patient is apyrexial. Her blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, and her pulse is 92 bpm and regular. The patient has a capillary refill time of 2 s and has dry mucous membranes.
Abdominal examination reveals a soft abdomen, with no tenderness or masses found on palpation. Bowel sounds were found to be normal.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate option for the management of this patient?

A. Aggressive oral rehydration and oral ondansetron
B. Intravenous (IV) rehydration and IV ondansetron
C. IV rehydration and intramuscular metoclopramide
D. IV rehydration and IV omeprazole
E. Advise that symptoms will settle, and discharge

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) with shortness of breath. He describes shortness of breath on exertion and feeling short of breath when he lies flat. He now uses five pillows when sleeping. His past medical history is remarkable for hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia and type II diabetes.
On examination, he has bilateral crepitation, a jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 5 cm and pitting oedema up to his shins. Despite these symptoms, his oxygen saturation is 99% and he is functioning normally at home. He says the symptoms started gradually about 6 months ago and have progressed slowly since.
Which of the following should the GP do first to confirm the provisional diagnosis?

A. Myocardial perfusion scan
B. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
C. Serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
D. Chest X-ray (CXR)
E. Serum troponin T

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old man is admitted to the Critical Care Unit with 40% full-thickness burns on his body following a boiler explosion. During the Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) approach, a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, which reveals absent P waves, a wide QRS complex and tall, peaked T waves.
What is the most likely underlying electrolyte abnormality which has resulted in the ECG changes?

A. Hypokalaemia
B. Hyponatraemia
C. Hyperkalaemia
D. Hypercalcaemia
E. Hypernatraemia

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old female patient presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a new rash. Bright red, hot and painful lumps have formed on her shins. She is also complaining of fever and generalised arthralgia. You are concerned that the rash is related to the medication she is taking.
What is the most likely culprit?

A. Ramipril
B. Cetirizine
C. Fluoxetine
D. Oral contraceptive pill (OCP)
E. Salbutamol

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, nausea and vomiting. She has a history of gallstones. She describes the pain as a severe stabbing pain that started this morning. On examination she has a heart rate of 112 beats/min (normal 60–100 beats/min), a temperature of 38.2°C (normal 36.1–37.2°C) and is Murphy’s sign positive. There is no evidence of jaundice and her bowels last opened this morning.
Based on the clinical history, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute cholecystitis
B. Pancreatitis
C. Ascending cholangitis
D. Gallstone ileus
E. Biliary colic

Correct Answer: A

A 60-year-old man presents with chronic pain in the knees. He enjoys running (about 20 miles per week), which he has been doing for the past 20 years. He has pain in both knees, which is relieved by analgesics [paracetamol and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)]. Recently, he has developed acute pain in the knee, with some swelling and limitation of movements which is very painful and has had some redness of the sclera. He also complains of joint stiffness.
On examination, his temperature is 36.9 °C. The knee joint appears swollen but is not hot or tender on palpation. There is mild to moderate limitation in knee flexion and extension movements bilaterally. Otherwise physical examination is unremarkable.
What differentiates rheumatoid arthritis (RA) from osteoarthritis (OA), given the signs and symptoms here?

A. Involvement of larger joints
B. Redness and swelling of joints
C. Involvement of areas beyond joints
D. Recurring episodes
E. Joint stiffness

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old man presents to the Student Health Service after a ‘flu like’ illness. He has noticed that his eyes have become yellow over the past two days and he has been off his food. On examination, there are no significant abnormal findings.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 140 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 230 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 80 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 25 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 67 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) 105 IU/l 100–190 IU/l
Urine bile salts +
Hepatic ultrasound scan – Normal
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hepatitis A
B. Infectious mononucleosis
C. Gilbert syndrome
D. Autoimmune haemolysis
E. Hepatitis B

Correct Answer: C

The neighbours of a 28-year-old woman are concerned that she is displaying erratic behaviour. She has a history of bipolar disorder and they are worried that her safety is currently compromised. They have tried to knock on her door at home to see if they can help, but they have had no response from her.
Which of the following Sections would be the most appropriate to issue under the Mental Health Act to ensure she can be assessed in a place of safety?

A. Section 2
B. Section 3
C. Section 5(2)
D. Section 135
E. Section 136

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old man is seen by his General Practitioner with a 1-month history of pain on passing urine. His urine dip is positive for blood, but negative for leukocytes and nitrites, and he is started on nitrofurantoin for suspected urinary tract infection. His urine culture is negative. Two weeks later, he continues to experience pain on passing urine. His urine dip results are unchanged and blood tests reveal a raised white cell count.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Further course of nitrofurantoin
B. Non-urgent Urology referral
C. Refer to Urology on the 2-week wait pathway
D. Same-day Urology referral
E. Trimethoprim

Correct Answer: C

An epileptic patient is seeking advice regarding her ability to drive following a seizure six months ago. On further enquiry, you discover that the seizure was in response to a medication change, which also took place six months ago and since being put back on her original medication, she has been seizure-free.
What advice is appropriate for this patient?

A. She will have to wait another six months before she will be eligible to drive, allowing for 12 months following the seizure
B. She will need to trial the new medication again to determine if she can drive
C. She can apply to the DVLA to reinstate her licence now
D. She will have to wait another 12 months due to her medication change resulting in the seizure
E. She will not be able to drive again

Correct Answer: C

A 66-year-old man is three days post-elective low anterior resection for colorectal cancer. He is being managed in the High Dependency Unit. He has developed a cough productive of green phlegm, increased wheeze and breathlessness on minor exertion. He has a background history of smoking. He also suffers from stage 3 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is a known carbon dioxide retainer. On examination, he is alert; his respiratory rate (RR) is 22 breaths/minute, blood pressure (BP) 126/78 mmHg, pulse 110 bpm, and oxygen saturations 87% on room air. He has mild wheeze and right basal crackles on chest auscultation.
Which of the following initial oxygen treatment routines is most appropriate for this patient?

A. 10 litres of oxygen delivered via simple face mask
B. 15 litres of oxygen delivered via non-rebreathing reservoir mask
C. Supplemental oxygen is not required
D. 2 litres of oxygen via simple face mask
E. Oxygen administration in conjunction with non-invasive ventilation

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman, who is exclusively breastfeeding, presents four months postpartum with burning pains and itching of the nipples. She has occasional sharp pains behind the areolae and reports that symptoms are worse after feeding.
On examination, both nipples appear erythematous and inflamed, with small fissures. On further questioning, she reports no history of atopy. She also tells you that last night, she noticed some white patches in her infant’s mouth that she tried to wipe off but were stuck on the mucosa.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Blocked duct
B. Nipple eczema
C. Nipple thrush
D. Paget’s disease of the nipple
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: C

A 43-year-old former teacher is being managed under the Palliative Care team for terminal metastatic breast cancer. Her symptoms of pain up until recently have been well controlled, but over the past few days, she has been experiencing some pain around an hour before her next dose of analgesia is due. This is making her feel increasingly anxious and she is worried that she will not be able to cope well if this continues.
Which of the following best describes the benefits of treating pain during palliative care?

A. Improved mobility
B. Increased appetite
C. Better sleep
D. General quality of life
E. All of the above

Correct Answer: E

A middle-aged lady presents with pain in the muscles around her shoulders. On examination, she is obese and has difficulty standing up from a chair without using her hands. There are discrete, erythematous, scaly papules over her knuckles bilaterally.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cushing’s syndrome
B. Dermatomyositis
C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
D. Polymyalgia rheumatic (PMR)
E. Psoriatic arthropathy

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old student comes to the General Practitioner, complaining of passing bright red blood when opening his bowels. The bowel movement is associated with severe pain, which occurs each time the bowels are opened. This has been happening for the past ten days. The patient is now very anxious and has been avoiding opening his bowels whenever possible. This, however, seems to make the pain symptoms even worse when he does eventually open his bowels.
Rectal examination is abandoned, as the patient is unable to tolerate the procedure due to pain.
Which of the following is used in the management of the most likely diagnosis?

A. Band ligation
B. Incision and drainage
C. Nitroglycerin ointment
D. Codeine phosphate
E. Oral antibiotics

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman is airlifted to your Emergency Department after being thrown from her horse during a show-jumping competition. She has been assessed at the scene and transported for further assessment and treatment of a serious head injury.
An arterial blood gas is taken on arrival: pH 7.2, PaCO2 8.0 kPa, PaO2 8.0 kPa , HCO3− 24 mmol/l, base excess −0.5 mmol/l.
What abnormality does this blood gas show?

A. Metabolic acidosis
B. Respiratory acidosis
C. Metabolic alkalosis
D. Respiratory alkalosis
E. Normal blood gas

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with essential hypertension and started on a medication to lower her blood pressure. She then stopped taking the medication as she reported ankle swelling. Her blood pressure readings usually run at 160/110 mmHg. She denies any headache, palpitation, chest pain, leg claudication or visual problems. She was diagnosed with osteoporosis with occasional back pain and has been admitted to the hospital for a hip fracture on two occasions over the last 3 years. There is no history of diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease or stroke. She has no known drug allergy. Her vital signs are within normal limits, other than high blood pressure. The S1 is loud. The S2 is normal. There is an S4 sound without a murmur, rub or gallop. The peripheral pulses are normal and symmetric. The serum electrolytes (sodium, potassium, calcium and chloride), creatinine and urea nitrogen are within normal range.
What is the most appropriate anti-hypertensive medication for this patient?

A. Enalapril
B. Indapamide
C. Propranolol
D. Prazosin
E. Amlodipine

Correct Answer: B

A Scottish resident presents with repeated acts of self-harm. He generally agrees to go to hospital (or presents himself) but sometimes refuses treatment. This evening, he took a large overdose of paracetamol and called a friend to tell her. An ambulance was called and he reluctantly agreed to come to hospital. Blood tests show his paracetamol levels are so high that he risks acute liver failure and death. Urgent treatment with the antidote Parvolex via an intravenous infusion is started. He tries several times to pull the cannula out, saying he wants to die. No legal provisions have been applied at this point.
Can he be physically restrained from removing the drip?

A. Yes – he clearly doesn’t really want to die otherwise he would not have rung his friend. The restraint must be proportionate and done in a way that is least restrictive and distressing, and must not be degrading
B. Yes – the principle of necessity allows for treatment in an emergency situation. The restraint must be proportionate and done in a way that is least restrictive and distressing, and must not be degrading
C. No – a friend or psychiatric nurse can stay with him and try to persuade him not to pull out the cannula, but they cannot physically touch him
D. No – he has not shown himself to lack capacity to consent, and so he must be able to refuse any and all treatment regardless of the consequences
E. No – he clearly wants to die, so there is no point wasting time and resources on him

Correct Answer: B

A prospective study is designed to compare the risks and benefits of combined oestrogen and progesterone replacement therapy versus oestrogen-only replacement therapy in patients aged < 60 years, who are within 10 years of their menopause. One group of women will receive systemic oestrogen and progesterone for 4 years (HRT group) and the second group will receive the same systemic dose of oestrogen (without progesterone) for the same period (ERT group). The levonorgestrel intrauterine system is placed in women of the second group to counterbalance the effect of systemic oestrogen on the endometrium. The study will only include women who have not undergone a hysterectomy.
Which one of the following outcomes is most likely to be observed at the end of this study?

A. The HRT group will most likely have a higher rate of breast cancer, compared to the general population
B. The HRT group will most likely have a lower rate of deep vein thrombosis, compared to similar women in the general population
C. The ERT group will most likely have a higher mortality rate, compared to similar women in the general population
D. The ERT group will most likely have a higher rate of cardiovascular diseases than the HRT group
E. The ERT group will most likely have a higher rate of osteoporotic fracture, compared to similar women in the general population

Correct Answer: A

A middle aged female patient presents with jaundice and epigastric abdominal pain, she describes an intermittent history of similar pain over the past 3 months, however, this time it is much worse. She has markedly raised bilirubin and mildly deranged LFTs, with a predominantly obstructive picture. Other pertinent history includes mild alcohol use.
What is the most likely cause for her symptoms?

A. Alcohol
B. Gallstones
C. Cholecystitis
D. Hepatitis C
E. Pancreatic carcinoma

Correct Answer: B

A patient presents with diarrhoea and vomiting; he is jaundiced. Hepatitis A infection is diagnosed.
Which one of the following modes of transmission is most likely?

A. Blood transfusion
B. Contaminated food
C. Mosquitoes
D. Sexually
E. Ticks

Correct Answer: B

A 59-year-old man came to the general practitioner, complaining of pain in the right big toe. He also said that he had developed severe pain that woke him up at night. He has a history of hypertension, for which he is taking thiazide diuretics. He drinks alcohol most nights of the week. Last week, he went to the doctor, complaining of painful urination and was prescribed antibiotics. On examination, there is tenderness, redness and warmth of the right first metatarsophalangeal joint. Aspiration of the affected joint is undertaken.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pseudogout
B. Gout
C. Psoriatic arthritis
D. Septic arthritis
E. Osteomyelitis

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old patient with alcohol dependence with a known history of gastric ulcers and Helicobacter pylori infection arrives at the Emergency Department with haematemesis. He is tachycardic, hypotensive and has ongoing upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. His haemoglobin is 89 g/l on arrival. He is resuscitated with a blood transfusion.
What is the best next step in management?

A. Computed tomography (CT) angiogram and percutaneous embolisation of bleeding vessel
B. Intravenous (IV) proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion
C. Partial gastrectomy
D. Terlipressin and octreotide therapy
E. Upper GI endoscopy

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with painless sudden loss of vision in his eyes.
On examination, he has a right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.
What is the location of the lesion causing this visual field defect?

A. Left occipital visual cortex
B. Left temporal lobe optic radiation
C. Optic chiasm
D. Right optic tract
E. Right parietal lobe optic radiation

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of increasing pain, blurry vision and lacrimation in the right eye. He also feels a foreign body sensation in the affected eye. He had been doing some DIY work at home without wearing any goggles for the past few days prior to the onset of pain.
On examination, his visual acuities are 6/18 in the right and 6/6 in the left. The conjunctiva in the right is red. The cornea is tested with fluorescein and it shows an uptake in the centre of the cornea which looks like a dendrite. On examination of his face, there are some small vesicles at the corner of his mouth as well.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Corneal abrasion
B. Corneal foreign body
C. Fungal keratitis
D. Microbial keratitis
E. Viral keratitis

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man presented after a road traffic accident with the X-ray shown. He cannot pass urine and is in pain. The patient is haemodynamically stable.
What is the most appropriate action prior to catheterisation?

A. Watch and wait
B. Suprapubic catheterisation
C. Urethral catheterisation
D. Retrograde urethrography
E. Computed tomography (CT) scan

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old junior doctor becomes acutely unwell in the doctors’ mess during his lunch break. He has a known severe peanut allergy. He is pale and distressed, has a respiratory rate of 50 breaths/minute, with audible wheeze, a pulse rate of 140 bpm and a blood pressure of 74/44 mmHg. Several of his colleagues are present. Anaphylaxis is suspected.
What is the first emergency treatment that should be administered by his colleagues?

A. 0.5 mg of 1 in 1000 adrenaline intramuscular (IM) injection
B. 1 mg of 1 in 10 000 adrenaline im injection
C. Hydrocortisone 200 mg intravenous (IV)
D. IV fluids through a wide-bore cannula
E. Promethazine 50 mg IV

Correct Answer: A

An 81-year-old man is brought to see his general practitioner by his wife, who gives a 3- to 4- month history of falls, intermittent confusion and worsening urinary incontinence. On examination, the man has an abbreviated mental test score (AMTS) of 4/10 but is otherwise well. There is no focal neurological deficit, but he is unable to walk without the assistance of his wife. Routine investigations, including FBC, U&Es, RBG, LFTs, TFTs, Ca2+ and ESR, are all within normal limits. The diagnosis is later confirmed by serial lumbar puncture studies.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
B. Wernicke's encephalopathy
C. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
D. Herpes encephalitis
E. A colloid cyst of the third ventricle

Correct Answer: C

A 49-year-old woman presents with a request for contraception advice. She has recently started a new relationship and has been using barrier methods of contraception, but would like to try an alternative method for convenience reasons.
She is still having periods, but they have become irregular in the last year. She is fit and well, with a history of mild hypertension, which is well controlled with ramipril. She does not drink but smokes around 20 cigarettes a day.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate method of contraception for this patient?

A. Natural family planning
B. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT)
C. No contraception needed due to patient age
D. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
E. Progesterone-only pill (POP)

Correct Answer: E

A 63-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of constipation. She says that it has been going on for a month and she now feels that she needs some medication to help. The woman says that she does feel more tired than usual and has noticed that she has gained some weight recently. On examination the GP notices that the patient has dry scaly skin. The patient’s record reveals that she was recently seen by an endocrinologist.
Which of the following would result in high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and a normal T4?

A. Thyrotoxicosis
B. Primary hypothyroidism
C. Secondary hypothyroidism
D. Sick euthyroid syndrome
E. Poor compliance with thyroxine

Correct Answer: E

A 38-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a three-month history of left-sided hearing loss and tinnitus, accompanied by dizziness which has now progressed to an unsteady gait when walking. Audiometry confirms unilateral left ear sensorineural hearing loss and a contrast magnetic resonance imaging scan suggests that the patient has a tumour with features consistent with an acoustic neuroma.
An acoustic neuroma is associated with an over-proliferation of which type of cell?

A. Astrocyte cell
B. Ependymal cell
C. Microglial cell
D. Satellite cell
E. Schwann cell

Correct Answer: E

A 41-year-old pub landlord is seen in the Gastroenterology Clinic due to abnormal liver function tests. He is normally fit and well, with no underlying medical problems, except for an admission six weeks ago following an upper gastrointestinal bleed. He reports drinking 48 units of alcohol per week and smokes ten cigarettes per day. On examination, he is noted to have an enlarged spleen, with the presence of ascites and enlarged distended veins around the umbilicus. He also describes some fresh blood on opening the bowels and is found to have haemorrhoids.
What is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?

A. Congestive cardiac failure
B. Haemochromatosis
C. Liver cirrhosis secondary to alcohol excess
D. Myelofibrosis
E. Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner for recent onset of acute back pain. For the last three months, she has been having a burning sensation and tingling of the hands and feet. Her past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, coronary artery disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She is on medication for her hypertension and diabetes which are well controlled. X-ray of thoracic vertebrae demonstrates punched-out lytic lesions.
Her laboratory investigation report shows the following abnormalities:
Investigations Results Normal values
Calcium 3.2 mmol/l 2.2–2.6 mmol/l
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 15 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Haemoglobin 98 g/dl 115–155 g/l
What is the most appropriate next investigation in this patient?

A. Autoimmune antibodies
B. Glycosylated haemoglobin
C. Serum vitamin B12 estimation
D. Thyroid function tests
E. Urine analysis

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old girl has had apparently normal appearance of secondary sexual characteristics, except that she has not menstruated. A pelvic examination reveals a mobile mass in her left labium major and a shallow, blind-ending vagina without a cervix, but otherwise normal female external genitalia. Ultrasound reveals no cervix, uterus or ovaries. Karyotype analysis reveals 46,XY.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Turner syndrome
B. Klinefelter’s syndrome
C. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS)
E. 5-α reductase deficiency

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old known intravenous (IV) drug user presents with an acute onset of jaundice; with associated nausea, vomiting, and lethargy. The patient also mentions that he has been passing very dark urine, but that his stools have been pale in colour.
On examination, the patient is mildly icteric; abdominal examination reveals some tenderness in the right upper quadrant and 2 cm hepatomegaly. The admitting physician runs numerous tests, of which the hepatitis B screen comes back positive.
Which antibody response is the initial response to the virus?

A. IgA
B. IgD
C. IgE
D. IgG
E. IgM

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a testicular lump which has been present for several weeks and is progressively enlarging. There is no history of trauma and he is otherwise asymptomatic. He has no past medical history of note or regular medications. Examination reveals a firm 3cm mass affecting the left testicle, and widespread lymphadenopathy. His blood results are listed below.
Alpha-fetoprotein (αFP): 0.1 ng/ml (0-10 ng/ml)
Beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin (βHCG): 4,500 IU/l
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 375 IU/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Testicular germ cell tumour: pure seminoma
B. Testicular germ cell tumour: non-seminomatous tumour
C. Testicular germ cell tumour: teratoma
D. Leydig cell tumour
E. Sertoli cell tumour

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department, having fallen from his bike onto his face. He initially experienced a small amount of epistaxis which resolved spontaneously. However, his mum is concerned as his breathing now seems noisy and congested and his nose is becoming increasingly swollen. On examination, the right-sided nasal septum appears widened and erythematous, with a fluctuant swelling on palpation.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Conservative management with analgesia
B. Nasal packing to reduce swelling
C. Oral antibiotics
D. Refer to Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) for urgent drainage
E. Routine ENT referral

Correct Answer: D

While performing a cholecystectomy, the consultant ligates the cystic artery.
The cystic artery supplying the gall bladder is usually a branch of the:

A. Gastroduodenal artery
B. Right gastric artery
C. Hepatic proper artery
D. Right hepatic artery
E. Left hepatic artery

Correct Answer: D

Whilst working in the Gynaecology outpatient department, you review a 59 year old patient who has been referred due to abnormal vaginal bleeding. She reports that she went through the menopause aged 54.
What is the most common cause of post menopausal bleeding (PMB)?

A. Endometrial cancer
B. Cervical cancer
C. Endometrial hyperplasia
D. Vaginal atrophy
E. Use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old man was brought to the Emergency Department after being shot in the arm. The victim had significant damage to his biceps brachii muscle.
Which cell in this large skeletal muscle is most significantly involved in regeneration and repair of the damaged muscle fibres?

A. Satellite cells
B. Endomysial fibroblasts
C. Striated muscle fibres
D. Capillary endothelial cells
E. Schwann cells

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old man is seen in an Orthopaedic Outpatient Clinic. He suffered a knee injury while playing football and was referred by his general practitioner. He cannot recall the exact mechanism of the injury. On examination, you record a positive McMurray’s test and pain on palpation of the lateral aspect of the joint line.
Which imaging modality would be most useful to perform for this patient?

A. X-ray of the knee
B. Ultrasound scan (USS) knee with joint aspiration
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the knee
D. MRI scan of the knee
E. CT scan of the knee with contrast

Correct Answer: D

Which structure of the spermatozoon remains in the cytoplasm of the oocyte after fertilisation occurs?

A. Mitochondria from the midpiece
B. Kinocilium
C. Nucleus
D. Acrosome
E. Plasma membrane covering the tail

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department from a nursing home with confusion, fever and flank pain. Her temperature is 38.5 °C, blood pressure 82/48 mmHg, pulse rate 123 bpm and respiration rate 27 breaths per minute. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and flank tenderness. Urinalysis shows 50–100 leukocytes and many bacteria per high-powered field.
Which of the following is most likely to improve survival for this patient?

A. Albumin infusion
B. Aggressive fluid resuscitation
C. Haemodynamic monitoring with a pulmonary artery catheter
D. Maintaining haemoglobin level above 120 g/l
E. Maintaining Pa(CO2) below 50 mmHg

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a road traffic collision. After appropriate resuscitation, a full neurological examination is carried out. It is observed that he has normal sensation and power in the upper limbs, but no sensation below the level of the umbilicus, and 0/5 power in all muscle groups in his thighs and legs. A cranial nerve examination is normal. A per rectum examination is performed, in the presence of a chaperone, which reveals loss of anal tone. The trauma team conjecture that this clinical picture is likely reflective of a complete transection of the spinal cord.
At which spinal level has this transection most likely occurred?

A. C7
B. T4
C. L2
D. C2
E. T10

Correct Answer: E

A female patient has the BRCA2 mutation.
Which of the following cancers are she and her fellow affected family members considered to be at increased risk of contracting?

A. Breast, prostate, thyroid, ovarian, bladder
B. Breast, prostate, pancreatic, ovarian, melanoma
C. Breast, prostate, pancreatic, ovarian, bladder
D. Breast, leukaemia, pancreatic, endometrial, melanoma
E. Breast, leukaemia, thyroid, endometrial, melanoma

Correct Answer: B

A 3-month-old female infant has oral candidiasis, severe nappy rash and failure to thrive. She has also had pneumonia and varicella infections. Her thymus has been noted to appear small on chest X-rays obtained during her previous episodes of pneumonia, but her parathyroid function is normal. Biochemical tests reveal a deficiency in the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. di George syndrome
B. Hyper-IgM syndrome
C. Isolated IgA deficiency
D. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
E. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

Correct Answer: E

An 85-year-old woman fell down stairs and presented to the Emergency Department with a painful left hip and an inability to ambulate. Radiographs showed not only a fracture of the left femoral head, but also a compression fracture of the T10 vertebra. She was previously fit with an unremarkable past medical history.
Which of the following conditions is she most likely to have?

A. Acute osteomyelitis
B. Osteogenesis imperfecta
C. Osteoporosis
D. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
E. Metastatic breast carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of deteriorating physical performance at work, associated with dysarthria and clumsiness. On examination he looks anaemic and has hepatomegaly and golden–brown-coloured rings in the cornea. He has a palpable liver edge. He denies any excess alcohol and has no history of foreign travel, intravenous drug use or unprotected sexual intercourse, and his weekly alcohol intake is 0–2 units. He reports that his father died from a ‘psychiatric illness’ in his early forties.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alcohol abuse
B. Hepatitis C infection
C. Herpes encephalitis
D. Motor neurone disease
E. Wilson’s disease

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old married woman has experienced a long history of infertility. Ultrasound reveals that her ovaries are enlarged. Her menses have been scant or absent, but her external genitalia is normal. She has also experienced unexplained weight gain and hirsutism. Hormonal studies reveal decreased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and increased luteinising hormone (LH), increased androgens and undetectable beta human chorionic gonadotropin.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

A. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
B. Gonadal dysgenesis, monosomy X variant
C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
D. Chronic adrenal insufficiency
E. Early pregnancy

Correct Answer: C

A study was designed to look at a group of junior doctors ability to correctly identify streptococcal throat infections. Their clinical impressions were compared to throat cultures. Of the 48 patients who had positive throat swabs, the doctors correctly diagnosed 40. In the 128 patients who had a negative culture, the doctors diagnosed 17 with strep throat.
Calculate the specificity of the junior doctors clinical assessment:

A. 111/128
B. 17/128
C. 40/48
D. 8/111
E. 40/57

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old diabetic presents to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain. The pain came on suddenly with bloody diarrhoea over the past six hours. His examination does not show findings in proportion to the patient’s pain. He has a significant past medical history with previous myocardial infarction which required implantation of a pacemaker.
Which investigation is most likely to confirm a diagnosis of mesenteric ischaemia?

A. Abdominal computed tomography (CT)
B. Abdominal ultrasound
C. Abdominal X-ray
D. Colonoscopy
E. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman, with a history of hearing voices, was brought to the Emergency Department by her family. She described the voices as telling her to kill her father as ‘he has the devil in him’. She also reported noting her intelligence being tapped through the Internet by a higher power. This has been going on for the past 6 months. Her family denies either depression or manic episodes. The patient was admitted to an inpatient Psychiatry Unit and started on haloperidol for her symptoms, after an evaluation and diagnosis of schizophrenia. Twelve hours after initiation of therapy, the patient started to have stiffness in the neck muscles and spine. Physical examination revealed muscular spasms in the neck and spine, a temperature of 37.2 °C, blood pressure 125/70 mmHg and a pulse of 80 bpm.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
B. Serotonin syndrome
C. Acute dystonia
D. Meningitis
E. Malignant hyperthermia

Correct Answer: C

A 78-year-old man presents with painless, symmetrical swellings in his neck. He has no other symptoms of note. Blood tests reveal a haemoglobin of 100 g/l, and a white cell count of 23 × 109/l. Blood film shows smear cells, with over 60% of the cells being small mature lymphocytes.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
B. Multiple myeloma
C. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
D. Chronic myeloid leukaemia
E. Hodgkin’s lymphoma

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old man presents to his local Sexual Health Clinic complaining of itching in the region of his pubic hair. He has had a number of sexual partners over the past three months.
On examination, you see a number of blue-grey macules within the margin and just beyond the border of his pubic hair. Upon investigation, fine combing of the pubic hair reveals a number of crab-like creatures and white specks.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pediculosis capitis
B. Scabies
C. Pediculosis pubis
D. Pediculosis corporis
E. Piedra

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old man is referred by his general practitioner (GP) for counselling. He describes being incredibly happy with his long-time girlfriend, describing how they have been together for 12 years. They go out shopping together, own a successful business together, frequently host parties and are very outgoing and popular. But when his partner brings up marriage, he convulses with fear. ‘I know it’s ridiculous, but I really think if we get married, everything will suddenly be terrible.’
Which of the following best describes this patient?

A. Algophobia
B. Acrophobia
C. Agoraphobia
D. Gamophobia
E. Generalised anxiety disorder

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old man, known to have human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), attends his regular clinic appointment. He has missed an earlier appointment and is poorly compliant with his antiretroviral therapy, which he puts down to his travelling lifestyle. He has recently noticed blotches on his nose. His partner reports that the patient also has similar lesions on his back.
On examination, you note several red-purple papules across the patient’s back and face.
Which of the following viruses may have caused these lesions?

A. Human herpesvirus 8
B. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
C. Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
D. Cryptococcus neoformans
E. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old woman presents with unilateral facial drop and on examination, she is unable to close her left eye fully. She is normally fit and well but does describe a recent viral upper respiratory tract infection. Her husband is present during the consultation and is concerned that she has suffered from a stroke. However, on examination, no other focal neurology is identified other than an isolated left-sided facial nerve palsy.
Which feature on examination would you expect to find?

A. Loss of sensation of the left side of the face
B. Mydriasis
C. Loss of lacrimation
D. Left-sided facial weakness with forehead sparing
E. Ptosis

Correct Answer: C

A combination of reduced infant mortality, improved public health, modern medical advances and the introduction of the welfare state has increased life expectancy in the United Kingdom (UK) dramatically over the past 100 years.
What was the life expectancy for a man in the UK during the second decade of the twenty-first century?

A. 65–69 years
B. 70–74 years
C. 77–82 years
D. 83–88 years
E. 89–92 years

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old primip presents at 28 weeks’ gestation, extremely worried as she attended her 3-year old nephew’s birthday party three days ago and stayed over at her sister’s house.
Today, her sister called to say that her nephew has developed a vesicular rash all over his body, and the general practitioner (GP) diagnosed him with chickenpox.
The patient denies any viral symptoms at present, but is unsure whether she has had chickenpox herself.
Which of the following should be performed?

A. Admission for further management and isolation
B. Blood test for varicella-zoster antigen
C. Blood test for varicella-zoster immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies
D. No further investigation is required as it was not a significant contact
E. Varicella-zoster immunoglobulin administration

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman in the fourteenth week of pregnancy presents to the Emergency Department with vaginal bleeding and vomiting. On examination, the uterus is noted to be large for her stage of pregnancy. Ultrasound scan reveals a snowstorm appearance with multiple highly reflective echoes and areas of vacuolation within the uterine cavity.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Threatened miscarriage
B. Trophoblastic disease
C. Ectopic pregnancy
D. Confirmed miscarriage
E. Septic abortion

Correct Answer: B

Early transplantation experiments were conducted, in which skin from a monkey was transplanted onto a pig. Researchers quickly learned that this kind of transplantation did not work because the recipient mounted an acute immune response to the graft tissue, which was ultimately destroyed.
Which one of the following best describes this kind of transplantation?

A. Allograft
B. Autograft
C. Homograft
D. Isograft
E. Xenograft

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old accountant presents to the Emergency Department with nausea and vomiting, with associated lethargy. He has mild asthma which is well controlled with a steroid inhaler but has no other medical history of note. He does not smoke but drinks up to 30 units of alcohol a week, mostly on the weekends. Observations are as follows:
Temperature is 37.2 oC, blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg, heart rate is 92 bpm and regular.
On examination, the patient appears to be clinically dehydrated, but there are no other abnormalities noted.
Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal Values
Haemoglobin (Hb) 145 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Urea 9.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 178 µmol/l
(bloods carried out one year
previously showed a creatinine
of 76) 50–120 µmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Sodium (Na+) 131 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Which of the following is most suggestive of acute kidney injury rather than chronic renal failure?

A. Raised parathyroid hormone levels
B. Oliguria
C. Peripheral neuropathy
D. Nocturia
E. Small kidneys

Correct Answer: B

A survey is conducted to determine the number of people in a former mining town suffering from coal worker’s pneumoconiosis. The town’s population is 25 000 people. The total number of people found to have a confirmed diagnosis of pneumoconiosis is 125.
According to the result of this survey, what is the prevalence of pneumoconiosis in this population?

A. 5%
B. 10%
0.2A. 5%
0.A. 5%
0.0A. 5%

Correct Answer: D

A 12-year-old boy presents with a midline cyst that moves superiorly with protrusion of the tongue. You suspect a thyroglossal cyst.
From which of the following locations does the thyroid gland develop?

A. Hyoid bone
B. Third branchial pouch
C. Foramen caecum
D. Skull base
E. Fourth branchial pouch

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old girl presents to her GP with discharge. On examination a thick cottage cheese-like discharged is visualised. She insists there are no other symptoms.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gonorrhoea
B. Chlamydia
C. Candida albicans
D. Bacterial vaginosis
E. Trichomonas vaginalis

Correct Answer: C

A 37-year-old woman, with a history of severe depression, is admitted unconscious to the hospital, following a suicide attempt where she stabbed herself with a knife, with significant intent of causing death. Her past psychiatric history suggests that this is her fourth suicide attempt, with the three previous attempts involving taking an overdose of her antidepressants and paracetamol. During this admission, she needed surgery for bowel repair. She is now two days post-operation on the Surgical Ward and is having one-to-one nursing due to recurrent suicidal thoughts after her surgery. The consulting surgeon thinks she is not fit enough to be discharged, and a referral is made to liaison psychiatry. After assessing the patient, the psychiatrist reports that the patient’s current severe depression is affecting her capacity and that the patient’s mental health puts herself at risk of harm. The psychiatrist decides to detain her on the ward for at least two days. The patient insists on leaving and maintains that she has no interest to be alive.
Which is the most appropriate section for the doctor to use to keep this patient in hospital?

A. Section 2
B. Section 5(2)
C. Section 4
D. Section 5(4)
E. Section 3

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with right-sided chest pain. She describes shortness of breath and fever that began 1 week prior to her presentation. Examination demonstrated decreased breath sounds on the right, and a chest X-ray demonstrated a right pleural effusion without loculation. The patient agrees to undergo a thoracentesis to sample the pleural fluid.
Where is the best needle insertion site?

A. Above the second rib in the mid-clavicular line anteriorly
B. Above the third rib in the mid-axillary line
C. Below the seventh rib
D. Above the fifth rib in the mid-axillary line
E. Below the second rib in the mid-clavicular line

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presented a diary with evidence of cyclical symptoms present in the second half of her menstrual cycle, consisting of abdominal bloating, mood swings and aggression ongoing for five months. During these episodes, she becomes withdrawn, requires time off work and does not attend social engagements. She is worried because her relationship is suffering as a result of this.
Examination and basic blood profile are unremarkable. She is diagnosed with severe pre-menstrual syndrome.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A. Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
B. Fluoxetine
C. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
D. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
E. Referral to a specialist clinic

Correct Answer: B

A 15-year-old girl presents to her GP requesting contraception.
In which of the following scenarios could contraception be legally withheld?

A. She demands it because she is frightened to say “No” to her boyfriend
B. She refuses to discuss matters with her parents reminding you that she has refused to do so before
C. She requests a contraceptive implant
D. She does not have an understanding of the implications of contraception
E. Her parents are abroad

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman with ischaemic heart disease presents with sudden onset palpitations. She has no other complaints. On examination, a regular tachycardia is present. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Chest is clear. ECG reveals a regular tachycardia with a QRS width of 80 ms and a rate of 149 beats per min in a sawtooth pattern.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Fast atrial fibrillation
B. Atrial flutter
C. Ventricular tachycardia
D. Mobitz type II
E. Brugada syndrome

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old traveller returns from a protracted period of travelling in Indonesia. He complains of persistent fever and night sweats, has lost weight and now feels a dull right upper quadrant pain. On further questioning, he admits to having lived very cheaply during his trip and to eating meat from street vendors that may have been undercooked. On examination, he is mildly jaundiced.
Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Bilirubin 98 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 57 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 186 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Haemoglobin 112 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 12.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 165 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 55 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
An abdominal ultrasound scan shows a cystic mass within the right lobe of the liver.
Which of the following represents the most effective treatment for this man?

A. Metronidazole orally (po)
B. Cefuroxime intravenously (iv)
C. Albendazole po
D. Drainage and albendazole po
E. Ultrasound-guided drainage and metronidazole po

Correct Answer: D

A 16-year-old boy is accompanied by his mother to his GP and complains of bilateral leg weakness and dragging his feet while walking. This has progressively worsened over several years. The mother says that the patient’s father, who died four years ago from a heart attack, had similar problems with his legs. Examination revealed pes cavus, bilateral foot drop and a stamping gait. He had bilateral areflexia and flexor plantar responses. There was glove-and-stocking sensory loss to the ankle.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Charcot–Marie–Tooth
B. Chronic idiopathic demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)
C. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
D. Old polio
E. Peripheral vascular disease

Correct Answer: A

A 51-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of chest pain and pain in his left shoulder. He had spent the previous 2 h digging in his allotment, but had to stop because of the pain. He admits to several prior episodes of chest pain under similar circumstances. No ST segment changes are seen on the electrocardiogram (ECG). The patient is given sublingual nitroglycerin, which relieves his pain, and is admitted for an overnight stay. The following morning, serum cardiac enzymes are within normal limits and no ECG changes are seen.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Prinzmetal variant angina
B. Stable (typical) angina
C. Subendocardial infarction
D. Transmural infarction
E. Unstable (crescendo) angina

Correct Answer: B

A 66-year-old patient presents to the Emergency Department with loose stools. His medical history is notable for metastatic bowel cancer, with which he has been relatively asymptomatic. He is on the second cycle of chemotherapy, but he cannot remember the name. He reports eight episodes of watery diarrhoea over the past 24 h. On examination, he is haemodynamically stable but appears dehydrated.
What is the most likely cause?

A. Capecitabine
B. Cisplatin
C. Bleomycin
D. Imatinib
E. Vincristine

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old man spends the evening on the town with his friends, consuming 8 pints of beer and a number of whiskey chasers. He falls asleep in the kitchen of a friend’s house with his arm draped over the back of a chair. When he awakens next morning, he has soreness in the right axillary region, and he is unable to extend his wrist.
Which other symptom is he most likely to have with this injury?

A. Numbness over the little finger of the right hand
B. Numbness over the palm of the right hand
C. Numbness over the dorsal aspect of the right hand between the thumb and index finger
D. Weakness of the adductor pollicis
E. Weakness of the lumbrical muscles

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman presents with pain of the hand, wrist, ankle and knee which is asymmetrical and has been going on for the past few months. She has developed a rash on her face and has developed a dry cough and pain on inspiration. She has a child but has had two previous miscarriages (Gravida 3, Para 1). She has no other concurrent medical problems or medications.
Testing for which one of the following autoantibodies is most likely to reveal the diagnosis in this patient?

A. Anti-dsDNA
B. Anti-Ro
C. Anti-Jo
D. Anti-centromere
E. Anti-Rh

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department by ambulance after a high-speed motorcycle collision. He is in full spinal immobilisation and complaining of severe pain in his abdomen. His observations are as follows:
Blood pressure 90/40, heart rate 110, sats 99% on high-flow oxygen, respiratory rate 20.
On primary survey, you find bruising to his lower abdomen and severe tenderness when you palpate around both his hips.
What is the best next step in management of this patient?

A. Perform rapid sequence intubation (RSI)
B. Insert a chest drain
C. Apply an Asherman seal
D. Insert a urinary catheter
E. Apply a pelvic splint

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman has seen her general practitioner (GP) with some symptoms of pre-syncope. She has an ejection systolic murmur loudest at the left sternal edge, so she is sent for a transthoracic echocardiogram. It shows her to have aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.7 cm. She is referred to the cardiac surgeons who have placed her on the list for an aortic valve replacement.
Which of the following is included in the required work-up for her procedure?

A. Coronary angiogram
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan chest
C. Ultrasound (US) Doppler of femoral vessels
D. Exercise/dobutamine testing
E. Transoesophageal echo

Correct Answer: A

This 52-year-old man has a history of dry cough, fever, and dyspnoea and weight loss over the preceding 3 months. He thinks the change in appearance of his nose has been present for this length of time. A skin biopsy has shown non-caseating epithelioid granulomas.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What disease are these symptoms and signs most likely indicative of?

A. Leprosy
B. Lung cancer
C. Lymphoma
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: D

A 59-year-old woman presents with severe pain in her right loin and shivering episodes. Her heart rate is 130 bpm, blood pressure 70/30 mmHg and her temperature 38.7 °C. Urine dipstick reveals leukocytes, nitrites and traces of blood.
A computerised tomography of the kidneys, ureter and bladder (CT KUB) confirms the presence of a large right ureteric calculus, which is obstructing the right ureter, as well as mild right-sided hydronephrosis is noted associated with perinephric stranding. The patient is resuscitated with fluids and intravenous antibiotics.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Diagnostic cystoscopy
B. Percutaneous nephrostomy
C. Renal dialysis
D. Shockwave lithotripsy
E. Foley catheterisation

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old male patient is admitted to hospital with an acute arterial thrombosis in his left leg. He requires an intravenous infusion of an anticoagulant whilst waiting for surgery. This drug requires monitoring and dose adjustment.
How is this done?

A. Directly measuring the drug in the patient’s serum
B. Examine the patient for side-effects and reduce dose subsequently
C. Measure directly the levels of clotting factors
D. Measure drug metabolites in the patient’s serum
E. Monitor the ability of the patient’s blood to clot in vitro

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old stockbroker has developed difficulty in swallowing solids over the last few months, with no problem swallowing liquids. He is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol use. There is nothing significant in his past medical history, except that he has been using antacids and H2-receptor blockers for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease for the last 5 years, with limited symptomatic relief. His clinical examination is normal.
What is the most likely cause for this man’s dysphagia?

A. Diffuse oesophageal spasm
B. Lower oesophageal web
C. Oesophageal squamous carcinoma
D. Scleroderma
E. Benign oesophageal stricture

Correct Answer: E

A 37-year-old homeless man with known human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection comes to the Emergency Department complaining of 4 weeks of headache, neck stiffness and photophobia. He does not know if he has had fevers but has felt chilled at times. His other medical problems include hepatitis C and a history of intravenous drug abuse. He is afebrile and his vital signs are stable. On physical exam, he is in obvious discomfort and hides under the blankets when you turn on the light. A lumbar puncture is performed, and several round, thickly encapsulated organisms are highlighted with India ink.
What is the most likely pattern of findings in his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?

A. Opening pressure: normal; cells: normal; protein: normal; glucose: normal
B. Opening pressure: increased; lymphocyte-predominant; protein: increased; glucose: normal/decreased
C. Opening pressure: normal; lymphocyte-predominant; protein: normal; glucose: normal
D. Opening pressure: increased; neutrophil-predominant; protein: increased; glucose: decreased
E. Opening pressure: normal; neutrophil-predominant; protein: decreased; glucose: increased

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old man presents with a 6-hour history of a painful swelling in the region of his glans penis. On examination, the glans penis is very tender, oedematous and red. The foreskin is retracted. There is no scrotal or penile redness or necrosis.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Refer to Urology for emergency circumcision
B. Soak the foreskin and glans penis in a hypertonic solution and attempt to manually replace the foreskin by using gentle, but sustained, distal traction
C. Prescribe a 7-day course of hydrocortisone and clotrimazole cream, and review after 1 week
D. Prescribe a 7-day course of flucloxacillin
E. Swab the area for microscopy and culture, and await the result before deciding on treatment

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year old girl is admitted to a hospital in Scotland with a two day history of abdominal pain. She tells you the pain is worsening and that she has been vomiting. The patient has a history of Down syndrome and after discussing the possibility of a diagnosis of appendicitis with the patient and her parents, you feel that she does not have the capacity to give consent for surgery.
In Scotland, what are the provisions for treatment of 17-year olds who lack capacity to consent to treatment and investigation?

A. A court order is needed to decide on investigations and treatments that are in the patient’s best interests
B. Such patients are to be treated the same way as adults who lack capacity
C. Such patients are to be treated the same way as children, so clinicians can proceed with what they believe is in the patient’s best interest
D. Such patients are to be treated the same way as children and discussion with parents is necessary
E. The parents can consent to investigations and treatments that are in the patient’s best interests

Correct Answer: B

You are working in a GP surgery and discussing the importance of primary prevention medication for a patient who has attended for a cardiovascular health check up, including blood tests. Unfortunately, the patient returns 4 weeks later complaining of muscle soreness.
Which of the following medications is the likely cause for the symptom of myalgia?

A. Aspirin
B. Clopidogrel
C. Bisoprolol
D. Simvastatin
E. Candesartan

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic for assessment. She has suffered from an erythematous rash on her face for a period of 6–12 months and now has arthralgia affecting a number of joints. There is also a history of episodes of pleuritic chest pain. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated at 155/92 mmHg. She has a butterfly rash affecting her face.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 192 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 160 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 66 mm/hr 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) +ve
Urine Blood +, protein+
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
B. Rheumatoid arthritis
C. Systemic sclerosis
D. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
E. Mixed connective tissue disease

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old investment banker is referred to Dermatology after developing some patches of hypopigmentation. The patient describes a 2-month history of patchy areas of discolouration over her chest and back. She finds the condition extremely distressing and is very self-conscious about these areas. The patient has now stopped going swimming due to the lesions, which she previously did frequently.
On examination, the patient has multiple patches of flaky, discoloured hypopigmented lesions distributed over the chest and back.
Which of the following is most likely to be the cause of hypopigmented skin?

A. High oestriol
B. Neurofibromatosis
C. Pityriasis versicolor
D. Urticaria pigmentosa
E. Whipple’s disease

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old patient presents to her GP for an old-age check-up. Her blood pressure measured in both arms, and the results are as follows:
Right arm 149/98
Left arm 135/90
What is the most appropriate action to take for this patient?

A. Confirm a diagnosis of hypertension and start the patient on verapamil
B. Take the lower of the two readings as accurate and confirm the patient does not have hypertension
C. Ask the patient to come back in one week to re-record blood pressure
D. Confirm a diagnosis of hypertension and start the patient on ramipril
E. Ask the patient to start ambulatory blood pressure monitoring

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old girl presents with increased urinary frequency and thirst.
Her initial observations and clinical examination reveal no abnormalities. On initial blood tests, the only abnormalities found are a urea of 10.5 mmol/l (normal range 2.5–6.5 mmol/l) and a borderline serum osmolality of 270 mOsmol/kg (normal range 270–295 mOsmol/kg).
She subsequently had water deprivation testing.
Time Investigation Result Normal range
0 hours Serum osmolality 270 mOsmol/kg 270–295 mOsmol/kg
4 hours – testing stopped Serum osmolality
Urine osmolality 300 mOsmol/kg
285 mOsmol/kg 270–295 mOsmol/kg
350–1000 mOsmol/kg
After administration of desmopressin Urine osmolality 287 mOsmol/kg 350–1000 mOsmol/kg
Based on the investigative results, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal results
B. Primary polydipsia
C. Cranial diabetes insipidus
D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
E. Further testing required to make diagnosis

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to attend the death of a patient who has died suddenly at home. The patient is aged 88 years and, when you take the phone call from a distressed neighbour who found the patient dead, it appears he has been well recently. On reviewing the notes, you find he was last seen by a colleague 5 weeks previously for a routine review of medication, but not since. You note that he was known to have a 7.8-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and hypertension, which was treated with ramipril. There is no other past medical history of note. You attend to verify death and find the patient is still warm and slumped over his kitchen table. You suspect he died from a ruptured AAA. It is 1800 h and the Coroner’s Office is closed.
In addition to telephoning the patient’s family to advise what has happened, what should you do next?

A. Examine the patient to verify death and issue a death certificate to the patient’s family with ‘ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm’ recorded as the cause
B. Examine the patient to verify death and ask the patient’s family to enlist the services of a local undertaker in removing the patient’s body, but discuss the case with the Coroner the following day before issuing a death certificate with ‘ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm’ recorded as the cause
C. Examine the patient to verify death and make arrangements for the patient’s body to be transferred to the local hospital mortuary to await a post-mortem examination and advise the family that the death certificate will be issued only after this examination is complete
D. Examine the patient to verify death and call the police to report a sudden death, so that they can investigate the cause and notify the Coroner’s Office to arrange further examination of the body, including a post-mortem examination, if appropriate
E. Contact the police to report an unexpected and sudden death. Do not examine the body any further, and remove yourself and anyone else from the vicinity of the body in case the police wish to designate the area as a crime scene

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old woman presents at 35 weeks’ gestation in clinic. She had a primary infection with genital herpes at 24 weeks’ gestation, which was treated with aciclovir. She has attended clinic to discuss birth and management options.
Which of the following best describes the management plan for this patient?

A. Aciclovir daily for seven days and expectant delivery
B. Aciclovir daily from today and elective Caesarean section
C. Aciclovir daily from 36 weeks and expectant delivery
D. Expectant delivery, with no further treatment required
E. Vaginal delivery with intravenous administration of aciclovir

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department the morning after a fall on the dry ski slope. She fell with her thumb outstretched and caught it in the matting on the slope surface.
On examination, the thumb is bruised and swollen and she finds it very difficult to make a pinching movement between her index finger and thumb. There is a palpable mass on the ulnar aspect of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. A plain X-ray reveals no fracture or dislocation.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Scaphoid fracture
B. Simple thumb dislocation
C. Undisplaced proximal phalanx fracture
D. Ruptured ulnar collateral ligament (UCL)
E. Ruptured radial collateral ligament (RCL)

Correct Answer: D

A 76-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation was admitted to hospital with a fractured neck of femur. She was maintained on digoxin 187.5 μg daily. On examination, her pulse was 72 bpm and her blood pressure was 122/74 mmHg. She was fully conscious.
Investigation: plasma digoxin (taken at least 6 hours post-dose) 2.5 nmol/l (1.0–2.0)
What is the most appropriate action regarding her digoxin dosage?

A. Give a loading dose of digoxin 500 μg and continue regular therapy
B. Give digoxin Fab fragments and stop digoxin
C. Increase digoxin to 250 μg daily
D. Perform immediate haemodialysis and replace digoxin with atenolol
E. Reduce digoxin to 125 μg and retest the serum level in a few days

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department via a trauma call after being rescued from a burning block of flats. He is covered in extensive burns, and your consultant asks you to quantify the percentage of his body that is covered in third-degree burns.
Which of the following best describes a third-degree burn?

A. This involves the whole of the epidermis and dermis, as well as varying layers of the subcutaneous tissue
B. This involves the whole of the epidermis and the papillary layer of the dermis
C. The epidermis is involved
D. A burn involving the whole of the epidermis and usually involving varying depths of the dermis, including the papillary and reticular layers
E. A mixture of epidermal involvement, with some areas of epidermal and superficial dermal involvement

Correct Answer: A

A 42-year-old woman presents for assessment of troublesome headaches. These occur about once a week and can be very disabling. She feels throbbing pain around the left eye and left temporal region, spreading to involve the whole head after about 30 minutes. She feels that her vision is blurred during attacks and, at the beginning of attacks, can have an impression of shimmering in her peripheral visual field. She is often nauseated and once or twice has vomited during episodes. Once she noticed tingling in the right hand and arm at the beginning of an attack. She tends to lie down in a darkened room and feels unable to perform her usual activities for at least several hours. The headaches are sometimes more pronounced just before her period is due. She takes paracetamol and ibuprofen for these attacks, with limited effect. She is on thyroxine for hypothyroidism, but no other regular medications and describes her general health as good. Her mother also suffers from headaches. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan is shown below:
Image courtesy of UCLA Interactive Neuroscience, The Regents of the University of California
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Idiopathic intra-cranial hypertension
B. Tension headache
C. Familial hemiplegic migraine
D. Classic migraine with aura
E. Cluster headache

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man complains of pain in the buttocks and calves during walking, running and climbing stairs. The pain is not relieved by standing still. Only sitting relieves the pain. Walking uphill is less painful than walking downhill. Power in both legs is 4/5.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Vascular claudication
B. Deep vein thrombosis
C. Lumbar spinal stenosis
D. Osteoarthritis of the hip
E. Spondylolisthesis

Correct Answer: C

A 47-year-old primary teacher is started on tamoxifen for the treatment of oestrogen receptor (ER)-positive breast cancer.
Which of the following is a commonly occurring side-effect of tamoxifen?

A. Hirsutism
B. Hot flushes
C. Weight loss
D. Increased risk of bleeding and bruising
E. Haematuria

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old man noticed a non-painful swelling of his left testicle whilst he was taking a shower. He is sexually active, although he denies any recent sexual activity.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate serological assay to aid in the evaluation of his disease?

A. Parathyroid-related peptide (PTHrP)
B. Calcitonin
C. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
D. CA-125
E. Alpha-fetoprotein (aFP)

Correct Answer: E

A woman aged 58 presents with a unilateral ovarian cyst accompanied by a large omental metastasis.
Which one of the following is the surgical treatment of choice?

A. Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
B. Total abdominal hysterectomy and unilateral oophorectomy
C. Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
D. Omentectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
E. Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with crushing substernal pain and left shoulder pain of 2 hours’ duration. The pain is not relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin, and the electrocardiogram shows ST elevation in several leads. Primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) is contraindicated due to coexisting renal impairment, and therefore medical management is initiated in the Coronary Care Unit. The next morning, serum cardiac enzymes are elevated to four times the upper limit of normal, and the electrocardiographic changes are still present.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Prinzmetal angina
B. Stable angina
C. Subendocardial infarction
D. Transmural infarction
E. Unstable angina

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man presents with rapid onset abdominal pain, which is worse on lying. He feels nauseous and is vomiting. The nurses report that he is tachycardic and pyrexial at 38.1°C. His abdomen is tender with marked guarding. There is bruising around his umbilicus. The patient reports drinking six cans of strong lager per day. He also smokes two packets of cigarettes a day. He says he was last in hospital 2 years ago, when he was vomiting blood. He cannot remember what treatment he was given. He has no other medical history of note. He does not take any medications regularly.
What is the most likely cause for the man’s presentation and signs?

A. Ruptured duodenal ulcer
B. Bleeding oesophageal varices
C. Pancreatic abscess
D. Pancreatitis with retroperitoneal haemorrhage
E. Hepatic cirrhosis and consequent coagulopathy

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old woman presents with a sudden-onset, severe, sharp, colicky pain in the right iliac fossa, radiating to the right loin and her right labia. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago.
Which of the following would be most useful as an initial investigation?

A. Blood sugar levels
B. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)
C. Rectal examination
D. Urine dipstick
E. Vaginal examination

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with bloody bowel motions and abdominal cramping for the last eight hours. He is also complaining of fatigue.
He has a past medical history significant for Crohn’s disease, but is non-compliant with azathioprine as it gives him severe nausea. He takes no other regular medications. He has no drug allergies and does not smoke or drink alcohol.
Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal pain, with no abdominal rigidity.
His observations are as follows:
Temperature 37.5 °C
Blood pressure 105/88 mmHg
Heart rate 105 bpm
Respiratory rate 20 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation (SpO2) 99% (room air)
His blood tests results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 14.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 51.2 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 135–175 g/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Azathioprine
B. Immediate surgery
C. Infliximab
D. Intravenous (IV) steroids
E. Oral steroids

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman presents to her GP with a 4-month history of urinary urgency. On several occasions she has not made it to the toilet in time and had urinary incontinence. She also reports needing to go to the toilet more often, and having to get up once in the night – which is unusual for her. There are no other symptoms of note. You perform a urine dip which is negative.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Oxybutynin (antimuscarinic)
B. Retropubic mid-urethral tape (surgery)
C. Injection of the bladder wall with botulinum
D. Bladder training
E. Trimethoprim (antibiotic)

Correct Answer: D
