A 6-year-old girl is referred to the Paediatric Neurology Service after her teacher raised concerns that the child sometimes appears to ‘stare into space’. The parents brought her to the General Practitioner reporting that they have also noticed that she would look blank for a minute and then looks confused. After these episodes, the girl becomes her normal self and does not remember what happened. The girl says that she sometimes has headaches, which usually occur at home and for which she takes paracetamol. There is no significant past medical or family history.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Absence seizure
B. Generalised tonic–clonic seizure
C. Atonic seizure
D. Migraine
E. Focal seizure

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 4-month history of night sweats and weight loss. He has no history of cough, shortness of breath or foreign travel. He denies any back or joint pain. He is normally fit and well, except for high blood pressure for which he takes enalapril. He continues to drink ten units of alcohol per week.
On examination. he is noted to have cervical and groin lymphadenopathy, with an enlarged spleen. The remainder of the examination and observations are normal.
Which of the following is most likely to be used in the management of this patient?

A. Infliximab
B. Lenalidomide
C. Radiotherapy
D. Rifampicin
E. Rituximab

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old woman presents to her GP with a 1-week history of in increasingly sore throat, coryzal symptoms, cough, feeling feverish and general malaise. She is eating and drinking well. On examination her temperature is 37.1°C, her chest is clear. She has inflamed tonsils, but no exudate. She is normally fit and well, and his only past medical history is carpal tunnel syndrome.
Given her Fever PAIN score, what would be the most appropriate management plan?

A. Immediate antibiotics
B. Delayed antibiotics
C. Admit to hospital
D. Safety net and review in 1 week if no improvement
E. Reassure and send home

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old man with colon cancer has a resection showing pathological stage III (6/13 lymph nodes positive) disease. He is initiated on adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil (5FU) and oxaliplatin. During his third month of treatment, he attends the Emergency Department, complaining of central chest pain which is exacerbated by exertion and shortness of breath. He is approximately halfway through a 48-h dose of 5FU.
What is the most likely mechanism of his symptoms?

A. Coronary artery thromboembolism
B. Coronary vasospasm
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Left ventricular akinesis
E. Central catheter displacement

Correct Answer: B

A 6-week-old baby boy is seen in the Emergency Department with a two-week history of vomiting after every feed and then appearing very hungry afterwards. His weight has remained at 4 kg for the past two weeks, and for the past two days, the vomiting has become projectile. His birthweight was 3.6 kg. He is exclusively breastfed. A small mass can be palpated in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cow’s milk protein allergy
B. Gastroenteritis
C. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)
D. Pyloric stenosis
E. Volvulus

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man develops a tender nodule in the palm near the middle finger, which gradually becomes painless, followed by the formation of a superficial cord and contraction of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the finger. Fibrous nodules are formed on the penis as well.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the inheritance pattern of this condition?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Autosomal recessive
C. X-linked recessive
D. X-linked dominant
E. Polygenic

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man with a long history of back pain complains of excruciating pain in the thoracic spine. When the patient was 38-years-old, he underwent spinal fusion surgery whereby the T3 and T4 vertebrae were fused together with metal rods. His consultant decides to order a diagnostic imaging study of the thoracic spine.
Which of the following imaging modalities would be the MOST appropriate to order, based on the patient’s past surgical history?

A. Conventional radiography
B. Computed tomography
C. Ultrasonography
D. Magnetic resonance imaging
E. Fluoroscopy

Correct Answer: B

A radiologist examines the ankle and foot X-rays of a young man with a suspected ankle fracture. A fracture of the talus is noted, with the fracture line interrupting the subtalar joint.
With which of the following bones does the talus articulate at the subtalar joint?

A. Tibia
B. Fibula
C. Calcaneus
D. Navicular
E. Lateral cuneiform

Correct Answer: C

A rugby player suffers from a spiral fracture of the lower fibula following an awkward tackle. The orthopaedic doctor dealing with him is young and enthusiastic and assures him he will be on his feet in no time. He puts on a circumferential cast, pending review in the Fracture clinic. The patient notes some discomfort in the upper calf shortly thereafter and has itching and numbness on the anterolateral aspect of the leg and over much of the dorsum of his foot. When the cast is removed, he is unable to dorsiflex or evert his foot. He also has numbness over the entire lateral aspect of the affected leg from the knee down. Sensation over the sole of the foot is intact.
Which structure is most likely to have been injured?

A. The tibial nerve
B. The superficial peroneal nerve
C. The deep peroneal nerve
D. The common peroneal nerve
E. The femoral nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 39-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of increasing lethargy and weight gain over the past year. The GP finds nil of note on examination, but decides to carry out some blood tests, the results of which are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 145 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 263 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 102 fl 76–98 fl
Urea and electrolytes normal, liver function tests (LFTs) normal; thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 10.9 miu/l, free T4 5 pmol/l.
Which of the following statements is correct?

A. Macrocytosis usually indicates coexistent vitamin B12 deficiency
B. The treatment of choice is carbimazole
C. Menorrhagia may be a feature
D. Thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies commonly occur
E. Thyroid eye disease commonly occurs

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old man describes feeling fatigued and feels this is worse towards the end of the day. Recently, he has had difficulty swallowing and now finds movement difficult, particularly on repetition.
What is the likely mechanism causing these symptoms?

A. Antibodies against acetylcholine receptors
B. Acetylcholinesterase inhibition
C. Reduced acetylcholine
D. Presynaptic calcium channel antibodies
E. Destruction of myelin

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year old woman became pregnant unexpectedly. She had given birth to five healthy children in her 20s and 30s with her now 50-year-old husband. Chorionic villus biopsy and karyotype analysis revealed that she was carrying a fetus with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
What is the most likely cause of the condition?

A. The mother is a translocation carrier
B. The husband is a translocation carrier
C. The mother’s age
D. The husband’s age
E. Spontaneous appearance of an autosomal dominant mutation in her fetus

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old man presents to the general practitioner (GP) with visual complaints in the right eye. He intermittently loses vision in the right eye, which he states feel like a curtain vertically across his visual field. Each episode lasts about two or three minutes. He denies eye pain, eye discharge or headaches.
His past medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia.
On examination, his pupils are of normal size and reactive to light. There is no scalp tenderness. Blood test results are pending, and his electrocardiogram (ECG) shows normal sinus rhythm, with no ischaemic changes.
A provisional diagnosis of amaurosis fugax (AG) is being considered.
Given this diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment at this time?

A. Aspirin
B. Warfarin
C. High-flow oxygen
D. Prednisolone
E. Propranolol

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with abdominal distension, diffuse mild tenderness and hyperactive bowel sounds in the mid-abdomen. He had undergone a right hemicolectomy for a 2-cm malignant polyp in the ascending colon 6 weeks ago. An erect abdominal radiograph shows multiple air fluid levels in the small intestine.
What is the next most appropriate step in management?

A. Abdominal computerised tomography (CT)
B. Barium enema
C. Small bowel series
D. Placement of a nasogastric tube
E. Surgical exploration

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man is referred to Gastroenterology after being admitted with haematemesis. He is found to have oesophageal varices on endoscopy. He mentions that he has never consumed alcohol. His blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg and heart rate is 90 beats per minute. On examination it is noted he has a small liver with some splenomegaly.
Investigations Results Normal Values
Albumin 27 g/l 35–55 g/l
Bilirubin 35 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 120 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate transaminase (AST) 200 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 150 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 13 mm 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Ferritin 900 20–230 µg/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Primary biliary cholangitis
B. Haemochromatosis
C. Wilson’s disease
D. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
E. Viral hepatitis

Correct Answer: B

A mother brings her 14-year-old boy into the Emergency Department. She is concerned as he has started to limp over the last few days and is in pain. There is no history of trauma; he has no temperature and is otherwise well. You notice he is overweight for his age.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Slipped femoral epiphysis
B. Perthes’ disease
C. Septic arthritis
D. Musculoskeletal back pain
E. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old woman is a candidate for artificial insemination.
Which blood hormone can be used as a reliable marker of imminent ovulation?

A. Luteinising hormone (LH)
B. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
C. Oestrogen
D. Progesterone
E. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old patient attends A+E complaining of feeling unwell and pain in a wound on his left leg. He describes sustaining the injury 8 days ago when he slipped and burned his leg on his gas fire. As the wound did not seem very severe at the time he did not seek medical advice. He describes feeling ‘out of sorts’ for the last two days with episodes of feeling hot and cold, and the pain in his leg has been getting worse. He denies cough, dysuria, or pain anywhere else. On examination you find a healing deep partial thickness burn to his left leg with surrounding erythema and ascending lymphangitis tracking up past his left knee.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 14 × 109/l 3.6–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 56 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
What would the most appropriate management be?

A. Oral antibiotics, discharge with GP review in 5 days
B. IV antibiotics, keep NBM and discuss with regional burns referral centre
C. Admit for IV antibiotics and review in 24 hours
D. No treatment needed - discharge
E. Admit for oral antibiotics and review in 24 hours

Correct Answer: B

A 62-year-old woman has been scheduled for a left total knee replacement in one month’s time. She has a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis (RA), for which she takes methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine.
Which of the following investigations would be most important before the patient’s operation?

A. Cervical spine X-rays
B. Eye exam
C. Rheumatoid factor levels
D. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
E. Anti-citrullinated protein antibody levels

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old man returns to his General Practitioner for the results of a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test; the result is positive.
Which of the following investigations will be most useful in estimating his risk of developing an opportunistic infection (OI)?

A. Blood cultures
B. CD4 count
C. Chest X-ray
D. Full blood count (FBC) with differential and blood film
E. Tuberculin skin test (TST)

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with thick, demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scaling over the extensor surface of the elbows and knees. He has had these skin lesions on and off for the last 2 years. The lesions become less severe during summer, worsen at times of stress and recur at the site of trauma, particularly at sites of scratching. Histopathological examination of a skin biopsy specimen shows epidermal hyperplasia and parakeratosis, with neutrophils inside the epidermis.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lichen planus
B. Plaque psoriasis
C. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
D. Atopic dermatitis
E. Tinea corporis

Correct Answer: B

A 36-year-old woman who was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis (UC) seven years ago comes to see you for information regarding frequency of colonoscopy in UC.
Her UC is currently well controlled, and she has no family history of malignancy. She had a routine colonoscopy just over one year ago.
What would be the most appropriate date for her next colonoscopy appointment?

A. As soon as possible – they should be done annually
B. In one year’s time
C. In two years' time
D. In four years' time
E. Colonoscopy is only indicated if the patient’s symptoms deteriorate

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man with fatigue, weakness, tachycardia and generalised pallor, has an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds. During the past year, he has been frequently constipated and at times has noted streaks of red blood on the surface of his stools. Family history is remarkable for a colorectal cancer. On examination, a mass is palpated on the left lower abdominal quadrant. The barium enema reveals an apple-core lesion of the descending colon. There are enlarged lymph nodes and foci of liver metastasis on the abdominal CT scan. The serum carcinoembryonic antigen is significantly elevated. On molecular genetic studies, a mutation was found in a gene located on the short arm of chromosome 12.
Which of the following genes is most likely affected by this mutation?

A. P53
B. APC
C. KRAS
D. DCC
E. Rb

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old cricketer presents with right shoulder pain. This came on suddenly while he was throwing a ball during the previous Saturday’s league game. He mentions that he has had shoulder pain intermittently throughout the season, but it is now much worse and is keeping him awake at night. He has no past medical history, takes no regular medications and has no known drug allergies. On examination, he is holding his neck in lateral flexion to the right, but neck movements are preserved, with no bony tenderness. There is good external rotation of the right shoulder, but abduction and internal rotation are very limited.
What is the best initial approach for diagnosis and treatment?

A. Prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, refer urgently for physiotherapy and arrange to review in 4 weeks
B. Prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, arrange an urgent magnetic resonance (MR) scan of the shoulder and review with the result
C. Prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, arrange an urgent ultrasound of the shoulder and review with the result
D. Prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, arrange an X-ray of the shoulder and review with the result
E. Prescribe a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug and refer urgently to orthopaedics

Correct Answer: C

A 13-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with excruciating scrotal pain for the last 3 hours. On examination, he is crying in pain and his scrotum is red and tender. He shouts in pain when you attempt to palpate his left testicle or raise it with your hand. His right testicle seems unremarkable.
Which investigation should you undertake next?

A. X-ray
B. Ultrasound
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) testes
D. C-reactive protein (CRP) and white cell count (WCC) as inflammatory markers
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year-old woman presents with unintentional weight loss and bloodstained diarrhoea. The blood is fresh, and mucous is often present in the stool. On examination, she has oral ulcers, erythema nodosum and conjunctivitis. The mucosa looks abnormal and multiple biopsies are taken. Ulcerative colitis is suspected.
Which of the following findings would support a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis over Crohn’s disease?

A. Crypt abscesses
B. Terminal ileum involvement
C. Aphthous stomatitis
D. Non-caseating granulomata
E. Stricturing of bowel wall

Correct Answer: A

A 66-year-old smoker with a 20 pack-year history presents with a 4-week history of non-productive cough. He has been feeling more tired for the last three months but has a good appetite and has not lost weight. He has however reported some streaks of blood in his sputum a few times. He has a history of gastro-oesophageal reflux, for which he takes occasional over-the-counter treatment. Physical examination was unremarkable. No other reasons could be found for his cough. He returns to discuss the results of some basic investigations with you:
Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic ratio, no abnormality in the unobscured lung fields, mediastinum normal
Full blood count (FBC): Hb 148 g/l; WCC 10.2 × 109/l; PLT 782 × 109/l
What is the next most appropriate course of action?

A. Reassure the patient that his chest X-ray is normal and repeat his FBC in 8-12 weeks to ensure his platelet count has returned to normal
B. Reassure the patient that his chest X-ray is normal and repeat his FBC in 8–12 weeks to ensure his platelet count has returned to normal, after treating with a week’s course of amoxicillin to clear up any infection
C. Reassure the patient that his chest X-ray is normal and repeat his FBC in 8–12 weeks to ensure his platelet count has returned to normal; also commence a 3-month trial of a high-dose proton pump inhibitor as a trial of treatment for reflux-associated cough
D. Refer the patient urgently to a chest physician with suspected lung cancer
E. Refer the patient routinely to a chest physician for further advice on the diagnosis

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset chest pain. The pain is described as a tearing pain that radiates through to his back and is associated with left-sided weakness. He is a little short of breath and he is very hypertensive, with a blood pressure reading of 200/110 mmHg. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows anterior ST elevation.
Which of the options below is the best course of action?

A. Take to the cardiac catheter lab for a primary angioplasty
B. Thrombolysis
C. Echocardiography
D. CT aortogram
E. CT pulmonary angiogram

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old man presents with an acutely painful, swollen and red left big toe. He reports this started yesterday and it is now so painful he cannot wear shoes.
He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes and a stomach ulcer diagnosed last year. The diagnosis of a first episode of acute gout is made.
What would be the most appropriate first-line management?

A. Allopurinol
B. Colchicine
C. Naproxen
D. Paracetamol
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: B

A 78-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with worsening epigastric pain for the past two weeks. The patient describes a deep pain in the central part of the abdomen that tends to become better at the time of eating and worsens approximately two hours after the meal. The pain does not radiate.
She has a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes methotrexate and anti-inflammatory medications. The patient is also a heavy smoker. Her observations are normal. Examination of the abdomen reveals epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rigidity. Bowel sounds are present.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Appendicitis
B. Chronic mesenteric ischaemia
C. Diverticulitis
D. Pancreatitis
E. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD)

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department, complaining of minimal vaginal bleeding. She reports her last menstrual period as having been 5 weeks ago. She denies pain but reports severe nausea and vomiting. She also denies any significant past medical history and states that her last check-up 3 months ago did not identify any abnormalities. Examination shows a blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg and the uterus measures 10 weeks’ size. A serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin (β-HCG) is drawn and found to be in excess of 200 000 iu. An ultrasound does not identify foetal parts.
Which one of the following is this patient at risk of developing?

A. Rupture of the fallopian tube
B. Septic miscarriage
C. Pulmonary metastasis and thyroid dysfunction
D. Twin or triplet pregnancy
E. Occlusion of the coronary vessels

Correct Answer: C

During the examination of a 48-year-old man with chest pain, a cardiologist uses his stethoscope to auscultate the heart.
Which area on the surface of the chest most likely corresponds to the location of the apex of the heart?

A. Right fourth intercostal space
B. Left second intercostal space
C. Left fourth intercostal space
D. Right fifth intercostal space
E. Left fifth intercostal space

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year-old university student complains of a short history of headache of gradual onset associated with malaise. On examination: temperature 37.8 °C, no focal neurology. Computed tomography (CT) brain: normal. Lumbar puncture was performed: clear, opening pressure 15 cmH2O, no organisms seen, total protein 0.91 g/l, RCC 1/mm3, WCC 154/mm3 (>95% lymphocytes).
What diagnosis does this most likely indicate?

A. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
B. Viral meningitis
C. Tuberculous meningitis
D. Cerebral abscess
E. Bacterial meningitis

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old swimwear model presents with concerns about her recently prescribed medication. She had read the patient information leaflet before starting the medication and was very concerned to see that staining of the teeth was listed as a potential side-effect. She is very worried about the chance that this could happen as it could potentially affect her work; she has therefore held off starting the tablets.
Which one of the following antibiotics can cause staining of the teeth?

A. Phenytoin
B. Carbimazole
C. Azithromycin
D. Gentamicin
E. Tetracycline

Correct Answer: E

An 87-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath, tiredness, intermittent chest pain and leg swelling for the last 6 months. His past medical history includes hypertension, gout and a previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago. His current medications are as follows:
diltiazem 60 mg orally (po) twice daily (bd)
spironolactone 100 mg po once daily (od)
allopurinol 100 mg po od
paracetamol 1 g po four times daily (qds) as required (prn)
lisinopril 20 mg po od.
Given this man’s likely diagnosis, which of the above medications should be stopped?

A. Allopurinol
B. Diltiazem
C. Spironolactone
D. Paracetamol
E. Lisinopril

Correct Answer: B

A 75-year-old woman presents for her regular follow-up psychiatric out-patient appointment. She had suffered from difficult-to-control schizophrenia for many years however had been stable for the last 5 years on a number of antipsychotic drugs. She also suffers from type II diabetes mellitus. She is stable from a psychiatric point of view however complains of repetitive, involuntary lip and tongue movements, particularly lip smacking and grimacing.
What drug is most likely to have caused this?

A. Olanzapine
B. Quetiapine
C. Metformin
D. Risperidone
E. Haloperidol

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman is admitted with an overdose. She is currently taking antidepressants prescribed by her general practitioner and painkillers for a chronic back complaint. Other past medical history of note includes hypertension. On examination, she has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 7. Her pulse is 105 bpm and regular, and her blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Her pupils are sluggish and dilated.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sdoium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 182 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
pH 7.15 7.35–7.45
pO2 8.1 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 5.9 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate 14 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Opiate overdose
B. Diazepam overdose
C. Tricyclic anti-depressant overdose
D. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) overdose
E. Nor-adrenalin reuptake inhibitor overdose

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her daughter who noticed that she had slurred speech which she described as sudden in onset. There are no other symptoms. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus, essential hypertension and a 25-pack-year smoking history.
On neurological examination, the patient is alert. There is a right-sided facial droop but no limb weakness and the patient could wrinkle her forehead. Eye examination does not reveal any abnormality and the patient has normal range of eye movements with no visual field defects.
Which of the following cranial nerve (CN) abnormalities does this patient most likely have?

A. CN III palsy
B. Unilateral masseter weakness is seen in a lower motor neurone CN VII palsy
C. Upper motor neurone CN VII lesion
D. CN XI palsy
E. CN XII palsy

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman presents to the Labour Ward at 38 weeks’ gestation for an elective Caesarean section. She has human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), had been taking combined highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) during pregnancy, and her viral load today is 60 copies/ml. She is asking about breastfeeding and also wants to know what will happen to the baby once it is born.
Which of the following statements best answers this patient’s questions?

A. Breastfeeding should be avoided and the baby will have a single dose of antiretroviral therapy immediately after birth
B. Breastfeeding should be avoided and the baby will have a single blood test two days after birth to confirm if they have HIV
C. Breastfeeding should be avoided and the baby should have antiretroviral therapy for 4–6 weeks
D. It is safe to breastfeed if the viral load is < 50 copies/ml and the baby should have blood tests up to the age of 18 months
E. It is safe to breastfeed if the viral load is < 50 copies/ml and the baby should have hepatitis B vaccination at birth

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old woman has had bowel surgery two days ago. She is currently on post-operative day one, and you are called to see her as she has developed sudden-onset shortness of breath. She denies any coughing but complains of chest discomfort. The surgical scar appears clean. Upon examination, the patient is afebrile; vital signs are stable other than rapid and irregular heart beat and upon auscultation, the chest sounds are clear. The patient does not have any other significant past medical history, aside from her breast cancer for which she had a mastectomy five years ago. She has no family history of any heart disease.
What is the patient’s most likely diagnosis?

A. Pneumonia
B. Lung fibrosis
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Cellulitis
E. Anaphylaxis

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman, a smoker, was referred to the Antenatal Unit with a small amount of dark brown vaginal bleeding at 39+2 weeks’ gestation. On admission, a speculum examination showed some old blood in the vagina, but no evidence of active bleeding. The cervix was long, and the os closed. Patient observations were stable, and an ultrasound scan was unremarkable. Two hours later, the emergency alarm is heard. The patient is in distress with extreme abdominal pain and fresh vaginal bleeding. The CTG records a prolonged deceleration of four minutes.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of the patient?

A. Vaginal examination to assess the bleeding
B. Blood transfusion of two units of O-negative blood and crossmatch
C. Emergency Caesarean section
D. Intravenous fluids and analgesia
E. Urgent instrumental delivery

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old man comes to the general practitioner, complaining chiefly of pain in his left arm, from which he has suffered for many years. Recently he got a job in a library that requires him to carry heavy parcels, which has made his pain worse. Occasionally he has tingling and numbness in the little finger and ring finger of his left hand. He also has pain on the medial side of his forearm. On examination, opposition and adduction of his left thumb are weak and he has muscle wasting of the thenar and hypothenar eminences. The patient failed to hold a piece of paper between his index and middle fingers.
Damage to which one of the following is responsible for the patient’s condition?

A. Axillary nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Musculocutaneous nerve
D. Lower trunk of the brachial plexus
E. Long thoracic nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old woman with a history of manic-depressive psychosis, diagnosed at the age of 22, presents to her General Practitioner with polydipsia and polyuria. Current medication includes lithium and a steroid inhaler for bronchial asthma. Examination reveals a blood pressure (BP) of 105/70 mmHg, with a pulse of 82 bpm and regular. There are normal fasting sugar levels and there is no postural drop on standing.
What are the investigation findings most likely to help diagnose this condition?

A. Elevated serum calcium levels
B. High blood sugars
C. High urine osmolality and low serum osmolality
D. Low urine osmolality and high serum osmolality
E. Low urine osmolality and low serum osmolality

Correct Answer: D

A 29-year-old woman comes to the Emergency Department (ED) with shortness of breath and chest pain, which is worse on inspiration. She had a Caesarean section 10 days ago. She is otherwise well and has no past medical history. An urgent chest X-ray is performed, and it is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pneumothorax
B. Amniotic fluid embolus
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Lobar pneumonia
E. Musculoskeletal chest pain

Correct Answer: C

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the general practitioner (GP) by his parents. He has been experiencing a dry cough with coryzal symptoms. On examination, there is evidence of conjunctivitis and an erythematous rash on his forehead and neck which is confluent. Oral examination reveals red spots with a white centre on the buccal mucosa, adjacent to the lower second molar tooth. He is currently apyrexial, though his parents state he has been feverish over the past two days. His heart rate is 80 bpm. No one else in his family is unwell, though his brother did have chickenpox earlier in the month.
What is the most likely cause for this presentation?

A. Kawasaki disease
B. Measles
C. Mumps
D. Parvovirus B19
E. Rubella

Correct Answer: B

A 53-year-old man presents to his GP with tingling in both hands which started about a month ago and has gradually got worse. There is no past medical history of note. On examination you notice the man has large hands, widely spaced teeth and a prominent brow. You suspect a diagnosis of acromegaly.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first line investigation for acromegaly?

A. Computed tomography (CT) Head
B. Random serum glucose
C. Serum growth hormone
D. Serum IGF1 levels
E. Visual field testing and acuity

Correct Answer: D

You are advising a patient with regards to malaria chemoprophylaxis for their upcoming holiday to the coast of Kenya. It is a known area with widespread cholorquine resistance; the species of malaria found in the area include; P. flaciparum, P. Vivax and P. Ovale. The patient is fair skinned and has a known psychiatric history.
Based on this information only, which anti-malarial would you recommend?

A. No chemoprophylaxis required
B. Chloroquine
C. Mefloquine
D. Atovaquone/Proguanil
E. Doxycycline

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old man with diagnosed primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) had been taking colestyramine and vitamin supplementation for the last 3 years. He had ulcerative colitis which was in remission, and colonoscopic surveillance had not shown any dysplastic changes. His only significant history was three episodes of cholangitis for which he had to be hospitalised in the past year. On examination, he was mildly icteric with a body weight of 50 kg. At present, he had no complaints, except fatigue.
What is the next best treatment option?

A. Continue current management
B. Steroids
C. Antibiotic prophylaxis
D. Liver transplantation
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: D

A 76-year-old man reports recent passage of blood with stool and weight loss. Rectal examination demonstrates a suspicious lesion inferior to the pectinate line, concerning for malignancy. Next you palpate for lymphadenopathy.
Where would you expect to find enlarged lymph nodes?

A. Internal iliac
B. External iliac
C. Superficial inguinal
D. Superior mesenteric
E. Inferior mesenteric

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a fall from a horse. She complains of pain in the left lower limb.
Examination of the patient reveals dry mucous membranes and tachycardia. Her left thigh is swollen and tender, and an X-ray confirms fracture of the left femur.
Which of the following statements regarding a fracture of the femur is CORRECT?

A. Fracture of the femoral neck just distal to the head (subcapital fracture) is not associated with avascular necrosis of the head of the femur.
B. Pertrochanteric fracture of the femur (linear fracture through the greater and lesser trochanters) is associated with avascular necrosis of the head of the femur.
C. Unimpacted fractures of the femoral shaft are typically associated with shortening of the limb.
D. Closed fractures of the femoral shaft are typically associated with minimal blood loss.
E. Application of a traction splint is recommended with distal supracondylar fractures of the femur.

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department review clinic the morning after a fall onto his outstretched hand.
On examination, he has pain and tenderness on the radial aspect of his wrist with particular pain over the area of the anatomical snuffbox (ASB). A wrist X-ray with scaphoid views reveals no fracture.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Give advice about mobilisation and discharge
B. Arrange for a tubigrip to be fitted
C. Apply a Colles’ plaster
D. Apply a scaphoid plaster and review in 6 weeks
E. Apply a scaphoid plaster and review after a week in the fracture clinic with repeat X-rays

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman presents with a neck swelling. She is very concerned as her mother recently passed away from an extremely aggressive form of thyroid cancer that is common in the elderly and difficult to treat.
What is she referring to?

A. Anaplastic carcinoma
B. Papillary carcinoma
C. Follicular carcinoma
D. Medullary carcinoma
E. Thyroid lymphoma

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old man with a long history of ulcerative colitis (UC) comes to the clinic for review. His inflammatory bowel disease is quiescent at the moment, but he has increasing symptoms of lethargy and itching. On examination, his blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, with a pulse of 70 bpm. He has mildly jaundiced sclerae and signs of scratch marks on examination of his skin.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 109 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 191 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 390 u/l 30–130 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 210 u/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 83 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Ultrasound Evidence of bile duct dilatation
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alcoholic-related cirrhosis
B. Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)
C. Ascending cholangitis
D. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
E. Autoimmune hepatitis

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old patient with a history of phaeochromocytoma develops a neck mass. Resection of the neck mass demonstrates a multifocal tumour with haemorrhage, necrosis and spread outside the thyroid capsule. The tumour is composed of polygonal cells in nests. Amyloid deposits are seen in the intervening fibrovascular stroma.
Which one of the following would the polygonal cells most likely secrete?

A. Calcitonin
B. Parathyroid hormone
C. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
D. Thyroxine (T4)
E. Triiodothyronine (T3)

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old girl presents with her parents to the Emergency Department (ED) with a painful knee. The knee is red, hot, swollen and tender. Movement of the joint is extremely painful, and when you try and passively flex the knee, the patient does not want you to touch or move the joint at all. You notice a cut on the affected knee, which the parents inform you is from a fall she had in the school playground recently. She has mild pyrexia but is otherwise well, with no other sites of pain and no further joint involvement.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Non-accidental injury (NAI)
B. Slipped upper femoral epiphysis (SUFE)
C. Osgood–Schlatter’s disease
D. Patellofemoral pain syndrome
E. Septic arthritis

Correct Answer: E

You meet a 23-year-old patient who has just discovered that she is pregnant. Her medical history is notable for hypothyroidism diagnosed eight years previously. She has been stable on her current dose of levothyroxine for years.
Which of the following is the correct management of her medication?

A. She should be taking iodine supplements in addition to levothyroxine
B. She should stop taking her levothyroxine
C. Thyroid function tests (TFTs) should not be taken, as these are unreliable in pregnancy
D. TFTs should be taken and dose unchanged until specialist review
E. The dose of levothyroxine should be increased when pregnancy is diagnosed

Correct Answer: E

A 21-year-old man was stabbed in the left upper quadrant and brought to the Emergency Department with the knife still in his abdomen. A CT scan demonstrated that the tip of the knife had pierced the superior border of the greater omentum at the junction of the body and pyloric antrum of the stomach.
The artery that has been severed by the knife is most likely to be a direct branch of which of the following vessels?

A. Coeliac trunk
B. Hepatic artery proper
C. Gastroduodenal artery
D. Splenic artery
E. Short gastric artery

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man complains of an aching sensation in the pelvis and right femur. The pain developed insidiously over the span of weeks and is associated with stiffness. He also complains of frequent headaches and hearing loss. On examination, it is noticed that the affected limb is warm and deformed (bowed). There is frontal bossing of the skull. Dilated scalp veins are present. Fundoscopy shows angioid streaks. Investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels, with normal gamma glutamyl transpeptidase levels. X-ray of the affected limb shows increased bone sclerosis, abnormal architecture, bowing and bone enlargement.
Which one of the following is a commonly occurring complication of this condition?

A. Aortic regurgitation
B. Bone marrow aplasia
C. Cataracts
D. Malignant transformation
E. Rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: D

A large area of grey–blue pigment is noted over the left buttock of a newborn baby by the midwife following a normal vaginal delivery. There are no other signs of bleeding or bruising visible on the baby. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother has no health conditions.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Haemophilia
B. Haemorrhagic disease of the newborn
C. Dermal melanocytosis
D. Non-accidental injury
E. Osteogenesis imperfecta

Correct Answer: C

A 54-year-old man has been diagnosed with type II diabetes and started on metformin in addition to appropriate dietary and lifestyle advice. He asks you about the possible adverse effects of metformin treatment.
Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to be attributable to metformin treatment?

A. Anaphylaxis
B. Cardiotoxicity
C. Lactic acidosis
D. Pulmonary fibrosis
E. Rhabdomyolysis

Correct Answer: C

A 42-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner with new lower back pain. The pain started yesterday when she was lifting a heavy item at her workplace. She is otherwise fit and well, and not on any regular medications.
Which of the following features would suggest an urgent hospital admission should be arranged?

A. Shooting pain radiating from the lumbar spine down the back of the left leg
B. Back pain worsened by coughing or sneezing
C. Loss of perineal sensation
D. Down-going plantar reflexes
E. Pain remaining after 1 week

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman attends your General Practice Clinic accompanied by her partner. She is currently eight weeks’ pregnant and has been experiencing heavy bleeding for the past 36 hours since falling down the stairs. She is very tearful and withdrawn and her boyfriend does most of the talking. She tells you she has been very clumsy recently and fell down the stairs, as she was rushing and missed her step.
Her medical records indicate she miscarried three months previously. You refer her to the Early Pregnancy Unit for further assessment, as you expect she may be having a miscarriage.
What would be the most likely cause to consider at this initial assessment?

A. Alcohol abuse
B. Antiphospholipid syndrome
C. Domestic violence
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old mechanic is made nil by mouth following admission with suspected appendicitis, and is written up for intravenous (IV) fluids to be administered pre- and post-procedure to maintain hydration.
Which of the following constitutes a bag of normal saline 0.9% (in mmol/l)?

A. Sodium 131, chloride 111, potassium 5, bicarbonate 29, calcium 2
B. Sodium 154, chloride 154, potassium 0, bicarbonate 0
C. Sodium 30, chloride 30, potassium 0, bicarbonate dextrose 50 g
D. Sodium 30, chloride 30, potassium 0, bicarbonate dextrose 100 g
E. Sodium 154, chloride 125, potassium 0

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department complaining of right upper quadrant and epigastric pain and associated vomiting. This is his third attack in the past 9 months. He has a past history of obesity, hypertension and hypertriglyceridaemia. Medications include ramipril, amlodipine, fenofibrate, aspirin and indapamide. On examination, he is obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 31; his blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, and he has jaundiced sclerae. There is right upper quadrant tenderness.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 140 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 10.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 239 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Alanine aminotransferase 75 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 99 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 285 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Ultrasound of abdomen: gallstones clearly visualised within a thick-walled gall bladder, dilated duct consistent with further stones.
Which of his medications is most likely to be responsible for his condition?

A. Indapamide
B. Ramipril
C. Amlodipine
D. Aspirin
E. Fenofibrate

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old male patient arrives in hospital with a hip fracture. His wife mentions that he drinks around two bottles of wine per day. He is prescribed chlordiazepoxide, a benzodiazepine, for alcohol withdrawal.
What is the rationale for using this medication in this instance?

A. Alcohol withdrawal leads to gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) deficiency; benzodiazepines facilitate GABA-A binding to its receptor
B. Benzodiazepines block acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, causing unpleasant symptoms when alcohol is consumed
C. Benzodiazepines cause sedation so that the patient is not awake during the withdrawal symptoms
D. Benzodiazepines inhibit autonomic hyperactivity caused by alcohol withdrawal by acting as a noradrenaline antagonist
E. Chronic alcohol use leads to down-regulation of dopamine pathways; benzodiazepines act as a dopamine agonist

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents with increased satiety, dull abdominal pain and weight loss over the past 6 months. He smokes 20 cigarettes per day and has suffered from indigestion symptoms for some years. On examination, his body mass index is 18 and he looks thin. He has epigastric tenderness and a suspicion of a mass on examination of the abdomen.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 101 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Faecal occult blood (FOB) Positive
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy Yellowish coloured, ulcerating
sub-mucosal mass within the
stomach
Histology Extensive lymphocytes within the biopsy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Helicobacter pylori gastritis
B. Gastric ulcer
C. Gastric carcinoma
D. Alcoholic gastritis
E. Gastric lymphoma

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man presents with the following lesion on his right arm. It has been there for about two years, and its appearance has not significantly changed over the past six months. He describes an occasional itch over the past two years but reports it does not particularly bother him.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Actinic keratosis
B. Basal cell carcinoma
C. Keratoacanthoma
D. Malignant melanoma
E. Pyogenic granuloma

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old divorced man gives a history of moderately heavy drinking for 10 years. In the 2 years since his divorce, he has experienced disrupted sleep, fatigue, irritability and cynicism. He typically drinks excessively. For example, he consumes a case of beer in a weekend and now drinks before work.
Which is the most appropriate initial form of psychotherapy?

A. Interpersonal psychotherapy and antidepressants
B. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
C. Structural family therapy
D. Self-help group
E. Psychoanalytic psychotherapy

Correct Answer: D

A dishevelled-looking 80-year-old woman is admitted from a nursing home following a fall. Her son indicates that she has become increasingly forgetful over the last 2 months. She has had diarrhoea for the last 3 weeks, thought to be related to an outbreak of norovirus at her nursing home, and has been vomiting occasionally. On examination you notice a scaly red rash on her neck and hands.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Scurvy
B. Post-infective lactose intolerance
C. Pellagra
D. Depression
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man is being assessed for hoarseness of 6 weeks’ duration. He has a cigarette habit of 30 per day and has had a chronic cough for 3 months. He gives no history of haemoptysis. As an initial investigation, the otolaryngologist (ear, nose and throat specialist) performs an indirect laryngoscopy and notes that the left vocal fold does not move during phonation.
Which of the following is the most likely causative factor?

A. Left superior laryngeal nerve palsy
B. Left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
C. Left glossopharyngeal nerve palsy
D. Cerebrovascular accident involving the left middle cerebral artery
E. Cerebrovascular accident involving the left anterior cerebral artery

Correct Answer: B

A medical student is assisting in orthopaedic surgery. A patient is having a lag screw fixation of a medial malleolar fracture. The student attempts to remember the structures in the vicinity of the medial malleolus.
Which of the following is correct?

A. The great saphenous vein lies posterior to the medial malleolus
B. The tendon of the tibialis posterior is the most anterior structure passing behind the malleolus
C. The tendon of the flexor digitorum longus lies anterior to that of the tibialis posterior behind the malleolus
D. The tendon of the tibialis posterior lies posterior to the posterior tibial vascular bundle
E. The posterior tibial vascular bundle lies immediately posterior to the tibial nerve in this region

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old motorcyclist suffers a low-impact motor vehicle collision and injures his left shoulder. On physical examination, he has a positive belly press and lift-off test, and has weakness of internal rotation and increased passive external rotation of the left arm.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Superior labral anterior–posterior tear (SLAP)
B. Supraspinatus tear
C. Infraspinatus tear
D. Teres minor tear
E. Subscapularis tear

Correct Answer: E

A 49-year-old man is admitted with an ischaemic left leg which is unviable and requires amputation. He becomes increasingly unwell while awaiting surgery, including experiencing episodes of difficulty breathing. An arterial blood gas (ABG) was taken.
pH 7.23, pO2 12.4, PCO2 ?, HCO3− ?, lactate 10.3 mmol/l.
What are the most likely PCO2 and HCO3−?

A. PCO2 5.4 + HCO3− 17.4
B. PCO2 4.1 + HCO3− 34.4
C. PCO2 2.5 + HCO3− 34.5
D. PCO2 3.8 + HCO3− 22.3
E. PCO2 2.5 + HCO3− 17.5

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man visits the Genitourinary Medicine (GUM) Clinic, as he has developed a painless lesion on his penis after unprotected sex with a new female partner approximately two weeks ago. This is his first time at the GUM Clinic. His last sexual encounter was six weeks previously with his ex-girlfriend. He reports that he always used a condom with his ex-girlfriend. He does not complain of any additional symptoms. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any regular medication. He denies any recent foreign travel.
On examination, the lesion is a solitary indurated ulcer located below the glans, which is discrete from the skin. It is not associated with any satellite lesions or surrounding skin changes. A lymph node examination reveals two enlarged rubbery nodes in the inguinal region.
What is the most likely causative organism?

A. Chlamydia trachomatis
B. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
C. Herpes simplex virus
D. Trichomonas vaginalis
E. Treponema pallidum

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old truck driver is admitted with a left-sided facial droop, dysphasia and dysarthria. His symptoms slowly improve and he is very keen to get back to work as he is self-employed. After 3 weeks, he has made a full clinical recovery and neurological examination is normal.
According to the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) guidelines, when can he resume driving his truck?

A. 18 months after initial onset of symptoms
B. 6 months after onset of symptoms
C. 4 weeks after onset of symptoms
D. 2 weeks after onset of symptoms
E. 12 months after onset of symptoms

Correct Answer: E

A group of medical students attend a pharmacology lecture regarding the mechanisms of actions of certain medications.
Which one of the following drugs is correctly paired with the enzyme that it inhibits?

A. Neostigmine and cholinesterase
B. Enalapril and angiotensin I
C. Aspirin and thromboxane A2
D. Penicillin and penicillinase
E. Losartan and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old obese woman presents with a gradual onset of hirsutism and abnormal menses. Her menses are irregular and vary in duration, timing and amount of bleeding. She had an impaired glucose tolerance diagnosis 2 years ago, using an oral glucose tolerance test. Luteinising hormone concentration is elevated. Serum androstenedione and testosterone concentrations are mildly elevated. Serum sex hormone-binding globulin is decreased. The concentration of 17-hydroxyprogesterone is normal. Ultrasound shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ovarian stromal hyperthecosis
B. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
C. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
D. Luteoma of pregnancy
E. Adrenal tumour

Correct Answer: B

A patient with a history of penicillin allergy presents with erythematous painful swelling of their right leg. They are pyrexic and feeling generally unwell. On examination, the leg looks like this:
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Oral flucloxacillin, paracetamol and advise hydration
B. Admit to hospital, intravenous (IV) flucloxacillin, IV fluids, paracetamol
C. Admit to hospital, IV clarithromycin, IV fluids, paracetamol
D. Topical steroids, topical emollients
E. Rehydration, analgesia and reassurance

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and dizziness. On examination, he has an irregularly irregular pulse.
Which of the following conditions in his past medical history might be the cause of his presentation?

A. Cushing syndrome
B. Hyperparathyroidism
C. Hyperthyroidism
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Type I diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with acute pancreatitis secondary to alcohol excess. His abdominal sepsis is complicated by multi-organ failure. He is being managed in ICU with mechanical ventilation, inotropic support and continuous haemodialysis.
Which strategies proven in studies are shown to reduce mortality in sepsis?

A. Administration of high-dose steroids
B. Administration of low-dose steroids
C. Blood transfusion to maintain a haemoglobin level above 100 g/l
D. Maintenance of the patient’s blood sugar level between 4.4 and 6 mmol/l
E. Managing the patient in the supine position

Correct Answer: D

A 67-year-old post-menopausal woman with three previous vaginal deliveries presents to her general practitioner (GP) with a 2-week history of urinary incontinence. She was recently diagnosed with hypertension and was commenced doxazosin therapy one month ago. She reports that these episodes occur during the day when she is walking to work and while she is working. She is a volunteer at the hospital shop and frequently lifts boxes as part of this role. She denies any preceding symptoms.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Functional incontinence
B. Overflow incontinence
C. Stress incontinence
D. True incontinence
E. Urge incontinence

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with pain in her left eye. There is no photophobia and no blurring of vision. She denies any previous trauma or eye disease. She has a history of diabetes which has been controlled by diet alone for the past three years. On examination the eye is red and hard to touch.
What is the best next step?

A. Refer back to diabetic clinic
B. Urgent and immediate referral to ophthalmic surgeon
C. Chloramphenicol drops
D. Oral flucoxacillin, swab eye
E. Reassure, give eye lubrication and discharge her with a referral to an ophthalmic surgeon in 2 weeks

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old woman presents to you after being seen two days ago following a fall. She has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, bilateral knee replacements, chronic hypotension and heart failure, which means she rarely gets out the house. She weighs 120 kg. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) at the time showed that she had atrial fibrillation (AF) and her heart rate was 180 bpm. She was started on bisoprolol and it was decided that she should have a 48-hour ECG tape to monitor her heart rate. Having returned following the 48-hour tape, you find that she has non-paroxysmal AF.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Increase the dose of bisoprolol
B. Start her on amlodipine
C. Give her amiodarone
D. Start her on digoxin
E. Send her for urgent electrical cardioversion

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old woman presents following a fall. During an assessment of her fall, she complained of balance problems, nausea and dizziness whenever she moves her head or looks up, eg to hang laundry on her washing line outside. She denies loss of consciousness and did not injure herself during the fall. Her past medical history consists of osteoarthritis of the knees and lower back.
On examination, her gait and balance and neurological examination are normal and there are no injuries. The Hallpike test is positive.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s vertigo?

A. Admit for brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
B. Regular stemetil®
C. Regular betahistine
D. Vestibular retraining exercises
E. Epley manoeuvre

Correct Answer: E

A 3-year-old child is bought into the emergency department by ambulance after falling from a climbing frame in the local park. He landed awkwardly and his mother saw that he hit his head. The child was initially crying but fell unconscious within a few minutes of the fall. On assessing the child's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, it is noted that he only opens his eyes to pain, has abnormal flexion to pain and is moaning.
What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score for this patient?

A. GCS 5
B. GCS 6
C. GCS 7
D. GCS 8
E. GCS 9

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old man presents with acute onset of dizziness and right ear hearing loss three hours previously. He has fallen twice since then and has been helped to the Emergency Department by his son. He feels that the room is spinning around him. He has nausea but has not vomited.
A stroke involving the territory of which of the following arteries is most likely to be associated with these findings?

A. Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
B. Right anterior inferior cerebellar artery
C. Right superior cerebellar artery
D. Right middle cerebral artery
E. Right posterior cerebral artery

Correct Answer: B

A randomised, placebo-controlled trial of a new anti-platelet agent is completed in patients who have atrial fibrillation. A total of 1000 patients were randomised to receive the new agent, and 1000 patients were randomised to receive a placebo. In the group receiving the new agent, A. 50 people suffered a stroke, compared with 100 people in the placebo group.
What is the number needed to treat (NNT) for the new anti-platelet agent to prevent one stroke?

A. 50
B. 0.05
C. 20
C. D. 200
E. 0.02

Correct Answer: C

A 74-year-old retired farmer has changed his General Practitioner (GP) and presents for a check-up. During the appointment, he requests review of multiple lesions on his forehead.
On examination, he is bald and has multiple scaly, crusted lesions on his mid-frontal scalp, in addition to a keratinous horn with a smooth base on the helix of his right ear. He states that he previously had similar lesions on his scalp. These were treated with a cream which made the lesions worse for four weeks before completely resolving when the treatment was completed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Actinic keratosis
B. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC)
C. Chondrodermatitis nodularis helicis
D. Lentigo maligna
E. Seborrhoeic keratosis

Correct Answer: A

A 78-year-old man with extensive peripheral vascular disease has sudden-onset severe abdominal pain with cramping and bloody stools. An arterial blood gas shows a pH of 6.9.
Which one of the following would you most likely find in this patient?

A. pCO2: increased; HCO3−: increased; urine pH: decreased
B. pCO2: increased; HCO3−: increased; urine pH: increased
C. pCO2: decreased; HCO3−: decreased; urine pH: decreased
D. pCO2: decreased; HCO3−: decreased; urine pH: increased
E. pCO2: decreased; HCO3−: increased; urine pH: decreased

Correct Answer: C

A man was brought to the Emergency Department after being stabbed in the abdomen, one inch (2.54 cm) superior to the umbilicus in the midline.
Assuming the knife entered the peritoneal cavity, which one of the following abdominal wall structures would the knife penetrate first?

A. Rectus muscle
B. Aponeurosis of the external oblique and internal oblique muscles
C. Aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle
D. Transversalis fascia
E. Aponeurosis of the internal oblique and transversus muscles

Correct Answer: B

A 44-year-old man is admitted to Emergency Department (ED) with haematemesis of bright red blood. He is an alcoholic. He has cool extremities, guarding over the epigastric region, he is ascitic, and has eight spider naevi on his neck and chest. An ABCD management is begun along with fluid resuscitation.
Given the likely diagnosis, what medication is it most important to start?

A. Clopidogrel
B. Antibiotics iv
C. Omeprazole iv
D. Terlipressin
E. Tranexamic acid

Correct Answer: D

A general practice is auditing the prescribing of antibiotics in patients diagnosed with acute otitis media.
Regarding use of patients’ records in clinical audit in general practice, which one of the following statements is true?

A. Patient information must be anonymised for clinical audit within the general practice
B. Patient information does not need to be anonymised if the audit is being undertaken by a healthcare trust
C. Patient information does not need to be anonymised for research being undertaken by a medical school
D. Patients do not need to be notified that their records will be used if the audit is being undertaken within the general practice
E. A generic flyer posted to all the patients under the general practice is sufficient notification that their records may be used in a clinical audit

Correct Answer: E

Requesting any investigation involves weighing up the potential benefits to the patient against the potential harms.
Which of the following radiographic investigations are associated with the greatest radiation exposure?

A. Chest X-ray
B. Abdominal X-ray
C. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
D. Ankle X-ray
E. Knee X-ray

Correct Answer: B

This is the blood slide from a girl with a medical problem.
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
Which one of the following is most likely to be a complication of this disease or its treatment?

A. Secondary iron overload
B. Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord
C. Bleeding gums
D. Sepsis with capsulated bacteria
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: A

An 8-week-old baby is admitted to the Paediatric Ward by her General Practitioner (GP). She was born at term via normal vaginal delivery after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Her birthweight was 2800 g. Her 20-week anomaly scan was unremarkable. Her parents inform you that a heart murmur was noted at her 6-week check, for which she is awaiting routine outpatient assessment. Her parents report that, over the last week, she has had episodes of going blue during feeds and friends have remarked that she looks ‘off colour’. She had a similar episode while with her GP, and oxygen saturation was recorded at 88% peripherally. As a result, the GP called 999 and transferred her to hospital. She is growing along the 25th centile. On examination, she is alert with normal vital signs. Heart sounds reveal a loud systolic murmur at the lower left sternal edge; she had palpable femoral pulses bilaterally and very slight cyanosis. Her chest is clear, with no recession or signs of distress. Her liver is not enlarged.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Tetralogy of Fallot
B. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
C. Total pulmonary atresia
D. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
E. Patent ductus arteriosus

Correct Answer: A

A 3-week-old boy who initially was feeding normally has now developed forceful, non-bilious vomiting after feeds. The following blood and blood gas results are obtained:
Investigation Result Normal Range
Haemoglobin 180 g/l 130–200 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 10 × 103/mm3 6–18 × 103/mm3
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3 mmol/l 3.5–6 mmol/l
Chloride (Cl-) 75 mmol/l 95–105 mmol/l
Bilirubin 14 mmol/l 3–17 mmol/l
Urea 10 mmol/l 1–5 mmol/l
Creatinine 60 μmol/l 20–65 μmol/l
pH 7.5 7.35–7.45
pO2 30.5 kPa 11–14 kPa
pCO2 3 kPa 4.5–6 kPa
HCO3- 30 mmol/l 18–25 mmol/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Intussusception
C. Biliary Atresia
D. Hirschprung’s disease
E. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old man develops sustained, severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. He takes several antacid tablets without significant relief.
Finally, he came to the Emergency Department and he is diagnosed with a myocardial infarction and is admitted and stabilised, then discharged five days later.
Three weeks after the myocardial infarction, the man develops steady, burning chest pain. He returns to the hospital where a friction rub is heard on auscultation. Heart sounds are also muffled.
Which of the following is the most probable underlying cause of this complication?

A. Autoimmune phenomenon
B. Bacterial infection
C. Chlamydial infection
D. Fungal infection
E. Viral infection

Correct Answer: A

A 58-year-old woman is seen in the ear, nose and throat clinic, complaining of a dry mouth. She occasionally gets dry, gritty eyes, but this problem is not present at the time of the consultation. She does not report a sore throat, ear pain or any persistent change in her voice. She smokes four cigarettes each day and drinks a bottle of wine most weekends. She suffers from sciatica, for which she takes amitriptyline at night. She does not take any other medication. She works as a head teacher at a school in a deprived area, which she describes as a very stressful job, and the dryness has been affecting her speech when talking to classes. Examination of the oral cavity and neck is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Increase the amitriptyline to help tackle her anxiety and ask her general practitioner to follow up this problem
B. Perform an autoimmune screen
C. Add Glandosane® to the patient’s ongoing treatment
D. Stop amitriptyline and swap for another analgesic
E. Perform a laryngoscopy

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of acute-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a history of factor V Leiden mutation and 18 pack-year of smoking. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.0 °C, blood pressure of 134/82 mmHg, heart rate of 101 bpm, respiratory rate of 28 breaths/minute and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac examination demonstrates a loud P2 and a new systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The patient is also seen to have an erythematous, swollen right lower extremity. An electrocardiogram (ECG) taken in the Emergency Department was normal, and troponins were in the normal range.
Which of the following findings on chest X-ray is consistent with this patient’s most likely underlying pathology?

A. Wedge-shaped opacity in the right middle lobe
B. Diffuse bilateral patchy, cloudy opacities
C. Rib-notching
D. Cardiomegaly
E. Lower lobe opacities with blunting of the costophrenic angle on posterior–anterior (PA) chest film and opacities along the left lateral thorax on left lateral decubitus film

Correct Answer: A

After a tennis match, a thin 20-year-old woman complains of left-sided chest pain that radiates into her abdomen. The physical examination reveals reduced air entry at the left base of the lung with hyper-resonant percussion sounds at the left side of the chest. The abdominal examination shows generalised tenderness. A few minutes later she develops cyanosis.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Acute pancreatitis
B. Ectopic pregnancy
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Tension pneumothorax

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man is being reviewed in the Cardiac Unit. He has developed a ventricular tachycardia of 160 bpm, looks unwell and has a blood pressure of 70/52 mmHg.
Which one of the following would be the most immediate treatment of choice?

A. Carotid sinus massage
B. DC cardioversion
C. Immediate heparinisation
D. Intravenous adenosine
E. Intravenous lidocaine

Correct Answer: B

A 69-year-old man is referred to the Urology Clinic with a 3-month history of poor flow when passing urine and difficulty initiating micturition. He reports that he gets up 3–4 times a night to pass urine. His bowel habit is unchanged. He does not report any overt haematuria and is well in himself. There is no family history of prostate cancer.
Digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a slightly enlarged and smooth prostate. Dipstick urinalysis finds protein + but is negative for blood, ketones, glucose, nitrites and leukocytes. Full blood count, urea and electrolytes and liver function tests are all normal. His prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is 1.2 ng/ml.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Arrange an urgent transrectal prostate biopsy
B. Commence an anticholinergic agent
C. Commence a 5a-reductase inhibitor and review in clinic in 3 months
D. Commence an a-1-antagonist
E. Commence trimethoprim 200 mg twice daily (bd) for 1 week and review symptoms in 1 month

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old patient arrives by ambulance after developing breathing difficulties. She is otherwise fit and well but had recently been prescribed amoxicillin by her general practitioner for a lower respiratory tract infection.
On examination, she is unable to talk and has harsh upper airways sounds on inspiration. She has a florid rash. Her pulse is 160 bpm and her blood pressure is 80/40. Her oxygen saturation is 90% on high-flow oxygen.
What is the most appropriate first step in the management of this patient?

A. Give a 500-ml bolus of 0.9% sodium chloride intravenously (iv)
B. Administer 10 mg of chlorphenamine iv
C. Administer 1 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline solution iv
D. Administer 0.5 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline solution intramuscularly (im)
E. Administer 200 mg of hydrocortisone iv

Correct Answer: D

You are working as a Foundation Year 2 in a GP surgery. A mother brings her 3-year-old boy to see you with a cough. You notice an alert on his notes that states he is on a child protection plan.
Which of the following is true regarding a child protection plan?

A. The intervention is voluntary for parents or carers
B. They are devised by social services without consultation with parents or any other agencies
C. They are devised for children at risk of significant harm
D. They are devised for children in need of extra support for health, safety ± developmental issues
E. They are indefinite and will not be routinely reviewed unless there are significant changes reported

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old man has a telephone appointment with his General Practitioner (GP) as he has had symptoms consistent with chickenpox over the last three days. He works as a car mechanic and has subsequently had to take time off work. He would like a ‘sick note’ to provide to his employer.
For how long can this man self-certify off work before he is required to obtain a note from his GP?

A. Three days
B. Seven days
C. 14 days
D. One month
E. Three months

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with perineal pain. He has found it very difficult to pass his stool every morning due to excruciating pain. This has been going on for two weeks. He had earlier been referred to a surgeon who diagnosed an anal fissure; treatment failed to relieve his symptoms. Recently he found streaks of blood in his stool. He has recently returned from a trip to Bangkok. He looked very distressed and said that, for the last five days, his undergarments were becoming soiled by continuous anal discharge.
What is the treatment for this condition?

A. Steroid enema
B. Oral ciprofloxacin
C. Probiotics
D. Single dose ceftriaxone
E. Surgical intervention

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old woman presents to you with bilateral palpable flank masses and headaches. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg and creatinine is 176.8 μmol/l. She has no past medical history of this, but her family history is significant for renal disease requiring transplant in her mother, brother and maternal grandmother.
On which chromosome would genetic analysis most likely find an abnormality?

A. Chromosome 3
B. Chromosome 9
C. Chromosome 13
D. Chromosome 16
E. Chromosome 22q11

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old man undergoes a right hemicolectomy procedure which lasts 2 h. In the 24 h prior to this operation, he has had two sachets of bowel prep solution. His operation is straightforward and there are no intra- or perioperative complications. He has been given 3 l of intravenous fluids prior to his waking up in recovery. His vitals are noted as follows:
Heart rate 105 bpm
Blood pressure 87/51 mmHg
Temperature 35.9 °C
Respiratory rate 13/min
Oxygen saturation 99% on 2 l
His urine output over the last 2 h has been averaged to around 28 ml/h (assume he weighs 75 kg).
His nasogastric tube has been removed and his abdominal drains have rose-coloured fluid of about 130 ml in two drains.
Which of the following situations would best account for the findings above?

A. Primary haemorrhage
B. Reactionary haemorrhage
C. Secondary haemorrhage
D. Fluid volume depletion
E. Anaesthetic reaction

Correct Answer: D

An 85-year-old nursing home resident with end-stage dementia has an acute bowel obstruction; she is not a suitable candidate for surgical intervention.
Which of the following medications may be most effective in reducing her discomfort?

A. Dexamethasone
B. Loperamide hydrochloride
C. Ondansetron
D. Lorazepam
E. Paracetamol

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old housewife is admitted to the Emergency Department with facial bruising following a fall. She initially informs the doctor that she fell down the stairs, but then later admits that her partner hit her, and that he has been violent to her in the past on many occasions.
She is very anxious about the situation and asks the doctor to not inform anyone of this information.
Doctors may breach patient confidentiality in which one of the following situations?

A. When asked to do so by a police officer
B. When asked to do so via a court order
C. To a police officer when a patient tells you he has committed a minor non-violent crime
D. When referring a patient on to another service
E. To a parent of a minor refusing non-urgent and non-life threatening treatment

Correct Answer: B

A 36-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner, complaining of crusting of both eyelids which is worse in the morning and associated with an itching sensation. She reports no visual changes. On examination of the eyelids, there is crusting at the eyelid margins which are red and inflamed. The conjunctivae appear normal and the pupils are equal and reactive to light.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Blepharitis
B. Chalazion
C. Conjunctivitis
D. Entropion
E. Hordeolum

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents with fatigue, and generalised pain in his joints. He also describes increasing difficulty getting out of his chair at home.
On examination you notice a blue-ish rash around his eyelid with associated orbital swelling, and some papules on the backs of his hands. He has symmetrical muscle wasting of his quadriceps and shoulders.
What is the most likely positive antibody test that matches his diagnosis?

A. Anti-centromere
B. Anti-Scl70
C. ANA
D. Anti-Ro
E. Anti-CCP

Correct Answer: C

A 42-year-old man presents to his GP practice with itchy, polygonal, violaceous papules on his inner aspect of his forearm. Some of these papules have coalesced to form plaques.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Scabies
B. Lichen sclerosus
C. Eczema
D. Psoriasis
E. Lichen planus

Correct Answer: E

A 74-year-old man presented to his general practitioner with forgetfulness. His wife noticed that this has been getting particularly bad over the past few months. On a couple of occasions, he has had to rush to the toilet to pass urine and has not quite made it. There has also been a little unsteadiness, but they had put this down to a couple of glasses of wine in the evening. On examination, he has a bradykinetic shuffling gait. There is clear poor short-term memory recall.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 13.1 g/dl 13.5–17.5 g/dl
Platelets 165 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 145 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urea 7.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan – ventricular enlargement, periventricular increased signal intensity
Lumbar puncture (LP) – opening pressure 18 cm of water
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Parkinson’s disease
B. Multi-infarct dementia
C. Alzheimer’s disease
D. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
E. Chronic alcohol abuse

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with progressive dysarthria, swallowing trouble and labile emotions, often inappropriately bursting into laughter/tears. On examination, he is found to have a spastic tongue, an exaggerated jaw jerk, normal gag reflex and bilateral upper motor neurone signs.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bulbar palsy
B. Cerebellar infarct
C. Frontal lobe tumour
D. Huntington’s disease
E. Pseudobulbar palsy

Correct Answer: E

A 41-year-old mother attends her first antenatal appointment at eight weeks’ gestation. This is her first pregnancy. She has no past medical history and is taking regular folic acid. She is offered antenatal screening for chromosomal abnormalities, including Down syndrome.
Which of the following tests is used in antenatal screening for Down syndrome?

A. Nuchal thickness
B. Utero-placental Doppler
C. Biparietal diameter (BPD)
D. Ultrasound assessment for herniation of dural sac
E. Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate

Correct Answer: A

An 86-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) arrives in the Emergency Department. She cannot provide a history as she is too drowsy. Her family tells you that she is usually housebound with a baseline exercise tolerance of 10 metres, but that she is now very short of breath at rest, having become rapidly unwell over the previous 48 hours despite using a rescue pack. She has not had a cough or fever. Her past medical history includes two admissions for an infective exacerbation of her COPD in the past five years for which there was a ward-based ceiling of care.
On examination, she has a silent chest and is taking rapid, shallow breaths. An arterial blood gas sample provides the following results:
Investigation Result Normal value
FiO2 0.21
pH 7.19 7.35–7.45
pO2 6.4 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 11.8 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate 31 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
What is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?

A. 28% Venturi mask
B. Bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP)
C. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
D. Invasive ventilation
E. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old student presents to his GP a few days after returning from a regeneration project working with a fishing community in South America. His main complaint is of an itchy, erythematous rash predominantly affecting both feet. He has no past medical history of note.
