On examination he has erythematous, edematous papules and vesicles affecting both feet. There are serpiginous erythematous trails which track 2-3 cm from each lesion. Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 138 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.0 × 109/l
(slight peripheral blood eosinophilia) 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 245 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 79 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Chest X-ray Normal lung fields
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical scenario?

A. Impetigo
B. Tinea pedis
C. Photoallergic dermatitis
D. Cutaneous larva migrans
E. Larva currens

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man was treated with antibiotics for a urinary tract infection (UTI) by the General Practitioner (GP) a few days ago. He has a past medical history of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD). He presented to GP surgery again a few days later, generally unwell, looking pale and jaundiced.
Which of the following antibiotics have been prescribed and could cause this presentation?

A. Erythromycin
B. Cefalexin
C. Chloramphenicol
D. Ciprofloxacin
E. Co-amoxiclav

Correct Answer: D

Some cancers are particularly associated with ‘driver’ genetic mutations.
In which gene is a 34-year-old woman with a left-sided renal cell carcinoma, a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour and retinal haemangioblastomas most likely to be carrying a germline mutation?

A. APC
B. BRCA
C. EGFR
D. MEN1
E. VHL

Correct Answer: E

A 17-year-old girl presents to Accident and Emergency with sudden onset abdominal pain. The pain is severe, and has now localised to the right iliac fossa. She has a temperature of 37.6°C (normal 36.1–37.2°C). Other observations are normal. The surgical registrar comes to review this patient. During her examination she flexes and internally rotates her right hip, which causes her pain. She states that this girl’s appendix lies close to the obturator internus muscle.
What is the name of the clinical sign the registrar elicited?

A. Cope’s sign
B. Murphy’s sign
C. Pemberton’s sign
D. Psoas sign
E. Rovsing’s sign

Correct Answer: A

A 10-year-old boy presents to his General Practitioner with erythema around his right eye and pain on eye movements since waking this morning. He has been suffering from coryzal symptoms for several days. On examination of his right eye, he has erythema surrounding the eye, proptosis, painful and restricted eye movements and reduced visual acuity. Examination of his left eye is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chalazion
B. Optic neuritis
C. Orbital cellulitis
D. Preseptal cellulitis
E. Sinusitis

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old medical student is booked in for colonoscopy, following a 2-month history of abdominal pain and diarrhoea. She is otherwise well and has no family history of any bowel conditions. She has not had any recent foreign travel and has no unwell contacts.
Colonoscopy reveals no abnormality of the colorectal mucosa, apart from seven polyps measuring <5 mm in diameter, proximal to the sigmoid colon, which are removed and sent for further analysis.
Which of the following conditions associated with polyps of the bowel is classed as a non-hereditary condition?

A. Lynch syndrome
B. Serrated polyposis syndrome
C. Peutz–Jeghers syndrome
D. Gardner syndrome
E. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

Correct Answer: B

During a teaching session arranged by the radiology registrar, medical students are asked to comment on various images. A chest X-ray of a woman admitted to the Emergency Department is presented to the students. You are told that the patient is 43 years old, but no other clinical details are given.
What is the radiological diagnosis?

A. Pneumonia
B. Pleural effusion
C. Pneumothorax
D. Pulmonary oedema
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: C

An 8-year-old boy visits his General Practitioner with his mother, complaining of rhinitis, sneezing and itchy and watery eyes in summer. The doctor notes that he has presented with similar episodes in the past years during summer. He is otherwise well but has a history of mild eczema, which is managed with emollients and occasional topical steroids. The mother has suffered from hay fever since her teens and feels her son may have the condition also.
What antibody is most likely to be responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

A. IgE
B. IgA
C. IgM
D. IgG
E. IgD

Correct Answer: A

A 73-year-old man who is in hospital for pneumonia begins to deteriorate on his third day of intravenous antibiotics. He develops purple bruises on his skin and on the inside of his mouth, and tells you that he feels short of breath and fatigued. His platelet count has dropped from 165 × 109/l to 43 × 109/l over the last two days. He also complains of blurred vision in the last few hours.
Which of the following will form part of his initial management?

A. Aspirin
B. Cryoprecipitate
C. Factor VIII infusion
D. Plasma exchange
E. Platelet transfusions

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old footballer presents to the Emergency Department after a bad tackle where his foot was trodden on, causing him to twist at the knee as he fell. He reported immediate severe pain and was unable to continue playing. On examination, he has an effusion and is unable to fully extend the knee. There is tenderness along the medial joint line, with a positive McMurray’s test.
What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

A. Arthrography
B. Diagnostic arthroscopy
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
D. Ultrasound
E. X-ray

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old girl presents to her General Practitioner with four weeks of bilateral knee pain. She explains that she competes for her school running team, however, denies any falls or trauma. On examination, her tibial tuberosities are tender bilaterally. Her anterior and posterior cruciate ligament stress tests are normal, as are the results of the Apley’s and McMurray tests.
What is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Request a routine X-ray and review her afterwards
B. Request an urgent X-ray and review her afterwards
C. Request a routine magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
D. Do no further investigations - advise analgesia, reduce physical exertion and consider physiotherapy
E. Refer the girl to paediatric orthopaedics to rule out juvenile idiopathic arthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman is being seen in the Psychiatry Clinic after being referred by her General Practitioner. The patient complains that her mood has been persistently low for the past two months and there are times that she does not want to get out of bed to go to work. She used to play tennis, which she really enjoyed, but recently she does not find any pleasure doing any sports. In addition, she does not enjoy food as she used to and does not have the motivation to go out to meet her friends anymore. The patient also reports that she has been waking up early in the morning and finding it difficult to go back to sleep. She lives alone and has been divorced for one year. She is a smoker and drinks moderate amount of alcohol.
The patient’s blood tests are normal, including normal thyroid function tests, and she does not currently take any regular medication.
Which one of the following is most affected in this patient’s lack of pleasure?

A. Acetylcholine
B. Serotonin
C. Noradrenaline
D. Dopamine
E. Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)

Correct Answer: D

A young woman has forgotten to take her combined contraception pill (standard strength) in the middle of her pill pack and it is nearly 48 h since her last pill. She is regularly having intercourse.
Which is the best advice to give her?

A. The missed pill must be taken as soon as it is remembered and the remaining pills should be taken at the correct time
B. Do not take the missed pill but continue the pack as normal otherwise
C. The missed pill must be taken as soon as it is remembered and she must take emergency contraception
D. Emergency contraception is needed and she must wait until she has a period before restarting the pill
E. She must continue the pill pack as usual but start the next pack without the week break

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old farmer presented with progressive dyspnoea. He had a dry cough and exercise intolerance. On examination, few crackles were found in the upper zones of both lungs. Surgical lung biopsy was done which was reported as:
Interstitial inflammation, chronic bronchiolitis, and two foci of non-necrotizing granuloma.
What is the most likely clinical diagnosis?

A. Aspergillosis
B. Sarcoidosis
C. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
D. Histiocytosis X
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man is referred to the Dermatology Outpatient Department with mildly itchy, erythematous plaques with oily, yellow scales on the scalp, forehead and behind his ears. The plaques have been present for two weeks. He has no significant medical history and is otherwise well.
What is the definitive management for this patient?

A. Antihistamines
B. Ketoconazole shampoo and topical corticosteroid therapy
C. Oral corticosteroids
D. Retinoids
E. Vitamin C

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old man suffered a road traffic accident in a motorbike race, when a rod pierced his abdomen. Emergency surgery saved his life.
One year later, he presents with abdominal pain and frequent stools. He is found to have anaemia. Blood tests reveal a vitamin B12 level of 41 (160–900 pmol/l), and serum folate of 35 ug/l (4.20 - 18.70 ug/l). He denies any dietary intolerance or any bleeding per rectum.
Which of the following tests is the gold standard for diagnosis of this condition?

A. Hydrogen breath test
B. Blood IgA–tTG level
C. Intestinal biopsy
D. Culture of small intestinal fluid
E. Serum folate levels

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old man has had surgery to remove his left lung after being diagnosed with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.
Which of the following complications of this management is most likely to have the highest mortality?

A. Anastomotic dehiscence
B. Arrhythmias
C. Pneumonia
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Pulmonary oedema

Correct Answer: E

A 37-year-old man is being investigated for a seminoma (a malignant tumour of the testis), and possible spread of the tumour is being considered.
To which group of lymph nodes do the testes drain?

A. Deep inguinal nodes
B. External iliac nodes
C. Internal iliac nodes
D. Para-aortic nodes
E. Superficial inguinal nodes

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent, crampy abdominal pain over the past three months. She has noted frequent loose stools containing blood and mucus. She has also had a recent unintentional weight loss of 15 pounds. Past medical history of note includes treatment for a perianal fistula and anal fissures. The patient is investigated with imaging studies and endoscopy; histological examination of the intestinal biopsy specimens confirms a diagnosis of Crohn’s disease.
Antibodies to which of the following organisms is most likely to be found in this patient’s serum?

A. Yersinia enterocolitica
B. Entamoeba histolytica
C. Saccharomyces cerevisiae
D. Giardia lamblia
E. Cryptosporidium parvum

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department. An X-ray is taken and is shown below.
Which of these statements is TRUE?

A. The humerus is most likely to lie posterior to the scapula.
B. The regimental badge area over the left upper arm may be numb
C. The injury is likely to require operative intervention
D. A post-reduction X-ray is not usually performed
E. Associated rotator cuff injuries are rare

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man is on the surgical ward after admission for neurological observations following a head injury. He had fallen on the pavement and banged his head with a moderate laceration. He suffered from no loss of consciousness but now complains of nausea and double vision. You notice that:
his eyes open to speech
he is able to obey commands
he can talk properly but appears disorientated in time and place.
What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. 11
B. 12
C. 13
D. 14
E. 15

Correct Answer: C

A 3-day-old male infant is noted to have increasing abdominal swelling. He was noted to not have passed stool since birth. Insertion of a gloved finger into the rectum leads to the passing of explosive stool. Blood tests and abdominal examination add no further information to the clinical picture.
What is the definitive step in diagnosis?

A. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
B. Ultrasound of the hernial orifices
C. Upper GI fluoroscopic study
D. Sigmoidoscopy with rectal mucosal biopsies
E. Suction-assisted full-thickness rectal biopsies

Correct Answer: E

A 47-year-old man started a new relationship a year ago. He had problems with his libido and started taking testosterone on the advice of an Internet ‘expert’. He ordered a supply of testosterone patches from a website. After 10 months, his libido had improved, but his partner had still not conceived. The couple badly want a child and are considering in vitro fertilisation (IVF). They come to your clinic for counselling.
What is your immediate advice to them or next action to take?

A. Check his sperm count
B. Change his testosterone from patch to oral tablet
C. Stop testosterone
D. Measure his follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinising hormone (LH) levels
E. Check her oestrogen levels

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old man presents with syncope, which was preceded by palpitations. He has no past medical history and is generally fit and well. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a positive delta wave in V1.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atrioventricularseptal defect
B. Brugada syndrome
C. Maladie de Roger
D. Tetralogy of Fallot
E. Wolff–Parkinson–White (WPW) syndrome

Correct Answer: E

This man is 26 years old. The abnormalities shown first appeared in childhood. They worsened during the teenage years. On the skin, there are also several large brown macules and freckles in the axilla and groin. He has learning difficulties and, at school, was thought to have attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). There is a family history of other affected individuals.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the usual mode of inheritance of this condition?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Autosomal recessive
C. Complex inheritance
D. X-linked dominant
E. X-linked recessive

Correct Answer: A

A patient presents with jaundice. The following results are available:
HBsAg +ve, HBeAg +ve, HBeAb −ve, HBc IgM +ve
Which one of the following interpretations is correct?

A. Susceptible to hepatitis B
B. Chronic hepatitis B with low infectivity
C. Chronic hepatitis B with high infectivity
D. Previous immunisation against hepatitis B
E. Natural immunity against hepatitis B

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old cricket player presents to the Emergency Department after being hit in the hand by a ball. He is unable to extend the tip of his middle finger at the level of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. An X-ray reveals a small, non-displaced avulsion fragment at the insertion of the extensor tendon of the distal phalanx at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.
What is the most appropriate way to manage the injury?

A. Conservatively with analgesia and rest
B. Intramedullary nail
C. Open reduction and internal fixation with Kirschner wire
D. Plaster of Paris to keep the DIP joint in extension
E. Splinting to keep the DIP joint in extension

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old man presents to his family doctor with hoarseness of 3 weeks’ duration. Inspection of his vocal cords using indirect laryngoscopy reveals paralysis of the left vocal cord.
Which of the following nerves supplies the majority of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx?

A. Superior laryngeal nerve
B. Glossopharyngeal nerve
C. External laryngeal nerve
D. Internal laryngeal nerve
E. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old woman experiences gradual masculinisation, characterised by increased body hair, deepening of her voice, and clitoral enlargement. Ultrasonography revealed a tumour in the left ovarian hilus. She also had elevated 17-ketosteroid excretion. A diagnosis of hilus cell tumour is made based on histopathology, revealing large, lipid-laden tumour cells.
To which cells in the male reproductive system are the affected cells homologous?

A. Epithelial cells in epididymis
B. Leydig cells
C. Sertoli cells
D. Spermatocytes
E. Spermatogonia

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman is seen by her General Practitioner (GP) for her 6-week postnatal examination. She reports feeling mildly low in mood at times but denies any problems with her appetite or sleep. She is coping well with caring for the baby and has a lot of support from her friends and family. She is breastfeeding.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Advise her about local social support: local children’s centres, mother and baby groups and the health visitor
B. Advise her to buy an over-the-counter preparation containing St John’s wort
C. Arrange admission to a Mother and Baby Psychiatric Unit urgently
D. Refer her routinely to Psychiatry
E. Start a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)

Correct Answer: A

A mother brings her 6-year-old son to see the general practitioner (GP) as she is very concerned about his school performance. His teacher has reported that he is being highly disruptive in the classroom.
Which of the following sets of behaviours fit best with a diagnosis of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?

A. Aggression towards classmates, destruction of school property, easily distracted
B. Difficulties in forming friendships, unable to empathise with peers, excessive hyperactivity
C. Easily distracted, hyperactivity, interrupts classmates
D. Lack of imaginative play, inflexible, interrupts classmates
E. Unable to take orders from teachers, narrow set of interests, fails to finish tasks

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old white woman, who is known to have had rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for the past 10 years, is scheduled for knee replacement surgery. Spinal anaesthesia is unsuccessful, so emergency general anaesthesia is given using thiopentone as inducing agent, succinyl choline and halothane. Minutes after intubation, the patient goes into cardiac arrest and dies.
Which one of the following is the most likely cause of death?

A. Malignant hyperthermia
B. Adrenal insufficiency
C. Atlanto-axial subluxation
D. Acute intermittent porphyria
E. Asystole due to hyperkalemia

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner complaining of generalised muscle weakness and twitching. On systems review, she also mentions occasional palpitations, which she had put down to anxiety and poor appetite. She has a past medical history of Crohn’s disease and chronic diarrhoea.
What is the most likely abnormality to be found on her blood results?

A. Low haemoglobin
B. Low magnesium
C. Low vitamin D
D. Raised bilirubin
E. Raised creatinine

Correct Answer: B

An obese 57-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with ongoing vague abdominal pain and fatigue for the last three months. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
Physical examination suggests hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal a negative hepatitis panel and normal iron studies. Antibodies for autoimmune liver disease are also normal.
A diagnosis of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is likely.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Liver transplant
B. Oral steroids
C. Penicillamine
D. Ursodeoxycholic acid
E. Weight loss

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old man presents with sudden-onset severe occipital headache and neck stiffness. His wife helped him into bed but had to call an ambulance after he became increasingly confused and drowsy. He is currently under investigation for chronic renal failure. On examination, his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) is 6 and his blood pressure is elevated at 192/100 mmHg. There are bilateral ballotable renal masses on abdominal palpation.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 189 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 195 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Embolic stroke
B. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
C. Extra-dural haemorrhage
D. Subdural haemorrhage
E. Pituitary apoplexy

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old woman recently diagnosed with osteoporosis is prescribed oral bisphosphonates. She is worried about the side-effects associated with it.
Which of the following is the most common side-effect she might experience?

A. Oesophagitis
B. Atrial fibrillation
C. Hypercalcaemia
D. Femoral shaft fractures
E. Osteonecrosis of the jaw

Correct Answer: A

A patient presents to the Emergency Department with a fast, irregular pulse, chest pain, weakness and palpitations. Upon arrival, investigations were carried out, including the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
PaO2 90 mmHg 75–100 mmHg
pH 7.35 7.35–7.45
PaCO2 27 mmHg 35–45 mmHg
Sodium (Na+) 125 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
HCO3− 15 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Chloride (Cl−) 107 mmol/l 98–106 mmol/l
Normal anion gap 10–18 mmol/l
With which of the following are the results consistent?

A. Excessive thiazide treatment
B. Diabetic ketoacidosis
C. Addisonian crisis
D. Burns
E. Diarrhoea

Correct Answer: C

A patient in a small hospital in the Highlands of Scotland has been detained under an emergency detention order. A psychiatrist attends the patient after 36 hours and conducts an examination of the patient’s mental state. She finds that the patient has paranoid ideation, believing that hospital staff are trying to kill him, is experiencing auditory hallucinations and is talking of causing harm to his wife, who ‘got’ him ‘into all this.’
What is the psychiatrist’s most likely course of action?

A. Prescribe a course of major tranquilizers (eg chlorpromazine) and leave the patient in the current hospital
B. Contact the Mental Health Tribunal to request a Compulsory Treatment Order be granted
C. Make an appointment for the patient to attend his outpatient clinic when he is discharged from the current hospital
D. Arrange for a mental health officer to attend with a view to issuing a short-term detention certificate
E. Arrange to visit the patient in another two days to see if there is any difference in his condition

Correct Answer: D

A 6-week-old baby girl is taken to see the general practioner (GP). She has been struggling to feed for a few days, seems to be working harder with her breathing and has not gained weight in two weeks. On examination, there is a parasternal heave and a loud systolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border.
Which statement is true regarding this condition?

A. Cardiac catheterisation is frequently used to confirm the diagnosis
B. Following closure of this defect, the patient is no longer considered at high risk of developing infective endocarditis
C. Prophylactic antibiotics before dental procedures are indicated in patients with this condition who do not have surgical repair of the defect
D. Spontaneous closure rarely occurs in this condition
E. Surgical repair is indicated for all patients with this condition

Correct Answer: B

A mother with a 3-week-old baby is concerned about the side-effects of vaccines, and would like some advice before her baby has his first set of vaccinations (scheduled in five weeks’ time). She is particularly worried, as her friend has told her that some vaccines contain ‘live’ organisms, and wonders if her child could catch a disease from one of these vaccines.
Which of the following is a live attenuated vaccine?

A. Intramuscular influenza vaccine
B. Intramuscular typhoid vaccine
C. Rabies
D. Diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus
E. Bacille Calmette–Guérin (BCG)

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old ice skater is seen in the Emergency Department, having fallen and landed on her outstretched hand. She is reporting pain in the wrist and is noted to be tender in the anatomical snuffbox. There is no bony tenderness.
What is the most appropriate investigation of her pain?

A. No further investigations needed
B. To place in a cast and have an X-ray performed in two weeks in the Fracture Clinic
C. X-ray of the wrist in postero-anterior (PA) and lateral views
D. X-ray of the wrist in PA, lateral, PA with ulnar deviation and oblique views
E. X-ray of the base of the thumb

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old primigravida presents at eight weeks’ gestation for her booking midwifery appointment. She was born in Romania and is unsure of whether she has had measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccination.
Which of the following results corresponds to immunity to rubella due to vaccination?

A. None of the options below
B. Rubella immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody negative, immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody negative
C. Rubella IgM antibody negative, IgG antibody positive
D. Rubella IgM antibody positive, IgG antibody negative
E. Rubella IgM antibody positive, IgG antibody positive

Correct Answer: C

Diagnostic imaging of a 30-year-old woman who was constipated revealed a volvulus of the part of the colon located between the descending colon and rectum.
This part of the colon is supplied by vessels originating directly from which of the following arteries?

A. Ileocolic artery
B. Inferior mesenteric artery
C. Left common iliac artery
D. Superior mesenteric artery
E. Abdominal aorta

Correct Answer: B

A 74-year-old woman is admitted to hospital with increasing shortness of breath and a productive cough. She is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and is commenced on cefuroxime and clarithromycin. She has a past medical history significant for atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), haemorrhoids and hypertension. Her medications include warfarin, metformin, gliclazide and ramipril.
Four days into her admission, she suffers an episode of epistaxis, which resolves with simple first aid measures. An international normalised ratio (INR) is measured and is found to be 8.2. She is haemodynamically stable and a full ABCDE assessment reveals a small amount of per rectum (PR) bleeding. She weighs 70 kg.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action to take?

A. Continue warfarin at the current dose and re-check INR in 24 hours
B. Reduce dose of warfarin and re-check INR in 24 hours
C. E. Stop warfarin immediately and administer 0.5 mg phytomenadione intravenously (IV) and 105 ml of fresh frozen plasma (FFP)
D. E. Stop warfarin immediately and administer 5 mg phytomenadione by slow IV injection
E. Stop warfarin immediately

Correct Answer: D

A patient is brought to see you by his wife. She is very concerned about him, saying that over the last few weeks, he has been hiding himself in their bedroom, heard to be talking to himself and accusing her of stealing his secret work and selling it to the government.
You conduct a mental state examination and elicit the following symptoms.
Which of these symptoms is a negative symptom?

A. Auditory hallucinations
B. Blunted affect
C. Delusions of grandeur
D. Delusions of passivity
E. Thought echo

Correct Answer: B

A patient is reviewed in the Psychiatric Clinic. He is a 26-year-old diagnosed with schizophrenia. He has been taking olanzapine for two months now. He reports all the changes in his life – he has now given up smoking, cut down on drinking alcohol and is drinking lots of fruit juice. He is taking St John’s Wort on the recommendation of a friend and has stopped taking regular ibuprofen, as his back pain has improved. You are concerned that his dose of olanzapine may need to be reduced.
Which of the following options is most likely to justify why the olanzapine dose may need reducing?

A. Alcohol induces metabolism of olanzapine
B. Certain fruit juices induce metabolism of olanzapine
C. Ibuprofen induces metabolism of olanzapine
D. Smoking induces metabolism of olanzapine
E. St John’s Wort inhibits metabolism of olanzapine

Correct Answer: D

A 70kg man with a functional residual capacity (FRC) of 2.5 l is pre-oxygenated adequately for 3 minutes. Oxygen extraction per minute is 250 ml.
IHow long will the patient have in theory before they begin to desaturate?

A. 1 minute
B. 2.C. 5 minutes
C. 5 minutes
D. 10 minutes
2C. 5 minutes

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department in a distressed state. He says he hears voices telling him that he is worthless and that the people talking to him know what he is doing as they are listening to his thoughts via the television and radio. His friends who attend with him tell you that he has become withdrawn over the past few months and has been missing lectures. There is a history of cannabis use but nil else of note. When he talks to you, he appears to have constructed a number of new words to describe the machines used to listen to him.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 294 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.3 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 34 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 16 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Delerium tremens
B. Manic-depressive psychosis
C. Amphetamine abuse
D. Schizophrenia
E. Sub-dural haematoma

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old woman presents with an irregular mole on her back to her General Practitioner (GP). The mole is 2 cm in length and oval in shape, but with an irregular border throughout. The colour is uniform, and there has been no change in sensation. The GP wants to assess the lesion according to the weighted 7-point checklist for assessment of pigmented lesions to help determine whether the lesion needs to be referred to Dermatology.
Which one of these is a major feature, scoring 2 on the checklist?

A. Change in sensation (including itch)
B. Inflammation
C. Irregular shape or border
D. Oozing or crusting of a lesion
E. Largest diameter of 5 mm or more

Correct Answer: C

You are bleeped by a nurse to see a 75-year-old woman on the Surgical Ward, as she is complaining of becoming very breathless. She is day 9 post-operative, following a total hip replacement. When you see the patient, she describes a sharp, stabbing pleuritic pain on the right side of her chest that has come on acutely.
Given the likely diagnosis, what imaging modality is the gold standard first-line investigation to perform?

A. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)
B. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chest
C. X-ray chest
D. Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) chest
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) chest

Correct Answer: A

A 12-month-old boy is due to receive his vaccinations today.
Which of the following vaccines are most likley to be given to a child at 1-year old?

A. Rotavirus, measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR), six-in-one, meningitis B
B. MMR, rotavirus and pneumococcal
C. MMR, Hib/meningitis C, meningitis B and pneumococcal
D. Pneumococcal, rotavirus, Meningitis B and MMR
E. Six-in-one vaccine

Correct Answer: C

A 39-year-old man, who had recently undergone treatment for an inflamed appendix, presented with fever, abdominal pain and diarrhoea. He is diagnosed with Clostridium difficile infection and started on oral vancomycin. However, after 3 days, his diarrhoea continues and his total white cell count (WCC) is 22.7 (4–11 × 109/l). He remembers having a similar illness 2 years ago, after gall bladder surgery which seemed to come back subsequently.
Which of the following treatment options may be tried in his case?

A. Faecal transplant
B. Intravenous ciprofloxacin
C. Oral metronidazole
D. Total colectomy
E. IV clindamycin

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old healthy man undergoes physical examination prior to joining the army. On physical examination, both his testes are palpable in the scrotum, and the testes and scrotum are normal in size, with no masses palpable. However, the spermatic cord on the left has the feel of a ‘bag of worms’. Laboratory studies show oligospermia.
Which of the following conditions is this man most likely to have?

A. Testicular torsion
B. Hydrocele
C. Spermatocele
D. Seminoma
E. Varicocele

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old obese man presents to Accident and Emergency with a 2-day history of nausea, frank haematuria and sharp, persistent left-sided flank pain, radiating from the loin to the groin. On examination, he has left renal angle tenderness.
Urine dip shows:
frank haematuria
blood 2+
protein 2+.
He has a history of hypertension, appendicitis 12 years ago and gout. You order a non-contrast computerised tomography (CT) for the kidney–ureter–bladder (KUB), which shows a 2.2 cm calculus in the proximal left (LT) ureter.
Which of the following is the definitive treatment for this patient’s stone?

A. Send home with paracetamol, advise to drink at least 3 litres of water per day and reassurance that the stone will likely pass spontaneously within 1–3 weeks
B. Admission and treatment with diclofenac, antiemetic, and rehydration therapy
C. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL)
D. Admit for medical expulsive therapy
E. Percutaneous ureterolithotomy

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old woman is one day post-anterior resection for rectal cancer. During the morning ward round, she complains of severe abdominal pain, refractory to intravenous (IV) paracetamol, which the patient is currently prescribed. The patient is examined by the consultant, who feels that the pain is secondary to the procedure and that there are no signs of any acute complications. The patient reports that she is allergic to morphine.
Which is the single most appropriate subsequent management for her pain?

A. Codeine phosphate
B. Gabapentin
C. Ibuprofen
D. Oxycodone
E. Tramadol

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old woman complains that her right ring finger regularly becomes locked after it has been flexed. It is difficult to straighten out without pulling on it with the other hand, and sometimes a click is heard when it straightens.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cramp
B. Dupuytren’s contracture
C. Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joint
D. Tetany
E. Trigger finger

Correct Answer: E

An 82-year-old man is admitted to hospital with palpitations and is subsequently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. His cardiologist commences him on apixaban. He has no other long-term medical problems and his renal function is within a normal range.
Which of the following parameters is used in the regular monitoring of patients on apixaban?

A. Anti-factor Xa
B. Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)
C. International normalised ratio (INR)
D. No specific parameter is monitored
E. Prothrombin time (PT)

Correct Answer: D

A 6-year-old boy was bought to the Emergency Department by his parents. His lips were swollen; he had stridor and was short of breath, and he was sweaty and clammy. He has a known allergy to nuts and had eaten some homemade cake at his friend’s house.
Which is the correct management plan?

A. 0.5 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline intramuscularly (im)
B. 500 mcg of 1 : 1000 adrenaline im
C. 150 mcg of 1 : 1000 adrenaline im
D. 300 mcg of 1 : 1000 adrenaline im
E. 0.3 ml of 1 : 1000 adrenaline intravenously (iv)

Correct Answer: D

This is a peripheral blood slide from a person presenting with weakness and fatigue.
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
Which one of the following red cell indices may be found in this patient?

A. Low mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
B. Low red cell distribution width (RDW)
C. High RDW
D. High mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
E. High MCV

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman known to be 10 weeks pregnant is admitted to the Surgical Assessment Unit with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Examination reveals a large uterus and a dilated internal os. An inevitable miscarriage is diagnosed and the patient is taken to theatre for surgical evacuation. This is the patient’s second miscarriage in 2 years.
What is the percentage chance that she will have a successful pregnancy on her third attempt?

A. 15%
B. 90%
C. 65%
D. 40%
E. 75%

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old baker presents to the general practitioner (GP) as he is concerned that his sclera have become yellow over the past week. He is normally fit and well with no other medical history to note. He did have a viral infection around two weeks ago but has now recovered. He drinks socially, approximately 20 units a week, and has been in a relationship with his girlfriend for four years.
He is especially concerned as his aunt passed away from complications of Wilson’s disease and he remembers that her eyes also looked yellow before she became severely unwell.
Which of the following results is most commonly associated with Wilson’s disease?

A. Positive antimitochondrial antibody (AMA)
B. Low urinary copper
C. Low ceruloplasmin
D. High transferrin saturation
E. Positive antinuclear antibody

Correct Answer: C

A 47-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP), complaining of bleeding gums every time she brushes her teeth. She reports that this is very concerning to her and has gotten to the point where she has stopped brushing her teeth.
Her past medical history is significant for epilepsy, for which she takes phenytoin. She takes no anticoagulants or antiplatelet medication.
Her observations are as follows:
Temperature 37.3°C
Blood pressure 125/88 mmHg
Heart rate 71 bpm
Respiratory rate 14 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation (SpO2) 99% (room air)
Examination of the oral cavity reveals red, swollen gingiva, with bleeding easily provoked with a periodontal probe.
Which of the following is the next best step?

A. Advise the patient to avoid brushing her teeth
B. Epstein–Barr virus testing
C. Pregnancy test
D. Referral to a neurologist
E. Vitamin K

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman from Vietnam presents with abdominal swelling. She denies any history of blood transfusion or jaundice in the past. She is in a stable relationship, with two children. After admission, she was found to be icteric. As she was being investigated, she had a bout of haematemesis and was admitted to the High Dependency Unit.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of her symptoms?

A. Hepatitis B infection
B. Mushroom poisoning
C. Paracetamol toxicity
D. Hepatitis C infection
E. Haemochromatosis

Correct Answer: A

During a race, a 24-year-old professional off-road (dirt) motorcyclist was involved in a severe crash involving multiple motorcycles. His right foot was crushed, and X-rays taken at the Emergency Department revealed a complete fracture of the sustentaculum tali.
This bony feature was displaced inferiorly and most likely entrapped the tendon of which of the following muscles?

A. Flexor hallucis longus
B. Extensor digitorum longus
C. Flexor hallucis brevis
D. Extensor hallucis longus
E. Flexor digitorum longus

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of constant abdominal pain. She tells you she has a history of peptic ulcers. The pain is worse with inspiration and movement.
On examination, there is rebound tenderness and guarding. There are absent bowel sounds. A chest X-ray shows free air under the diaphragm.
What clinical sign tells you that the peritonitis involves the whole abdomen and is not localised?

A. Pain worse on inspiration
B. Rebound tenderness
C. Guarding
D. Absent bowel sounds
E. Constant abdominal pain

Correct Answer: D

A jaundiced patient has predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia.
Which of the following condition is most likely to be associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia?

A. Haemolysis caused by hereditary spherocytosis
B. Haemolysis resulting from rhesus incompatibility
C. Acute haemolytic crisis in sickle-cell disease
D. Obstructive jaundice caused by carcinoma of the head of pancreas
E. Gilbert syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with facial erythema. She also has papules and pustules forming, which have noticeable telangiectasia.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acne vulgaris
B. Discoid lupus erythematosus
C. Acne Rosacea
D. Pityriasis rosea
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: C

The patient in the picture below presents with gradual onset and progressive blurring of vision in the left eye. He has a history of diabetes and long-term steroid use for polymyalgia rheumatica. Recently he has also started to get double vision.
Which of the following is the next best step in his treatment?

A. Stop steroid usage and consider alternative therapies
B. Tighter diabetic control and stop steroids
C. Undergo phacoemulsification
D. Undergo corneal transplantation
E. Refractive laser eye surgery

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with chest and abdominal pain, following three days of severe vomiting secondary to gastroenteritis. She reports pain being worse on swallowing and feels short of breath. On examination, she looks unwell and has a heart rate of 105 bpm, a blood pressure of 110/90 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute and a temperature of 38 °C. Boerhaave syndrome is suspected.
What is the most appropriate initial investigation, given the suspected diagnosis?

A. Abdominal X-ray
B. Barium swallow
C. Blood cultures
D. Chest X-ray
E. Endoscopy

Correct Answer: D

A 2-year-old boy is seen by the General Practitioner (GP). He has been unwell with coryzal symptoms for two days and has fever. He has been eating a little less than usual but drinking plenty of fluids and having his normal number of wet nappies. His mother reports that he had an episode of being unresponsive with jerking limbs while in the waiting room, which lasted about 30 seconds. On examination, following the episode, he is alert, with no signs of focal neurology. His temperature is 38.9 °C, his heart rate is 120 bpm and his capillary refill time is < 2 seconds. He has moist mucous membranes. There is no sign of increased work of breathing. His chest is clear. He has cervical lymphadenopathy; his throat is red, but no exudate is present on his tonsils. He has clear, thick nasal discharge, and both his tympanic membranes are inflamed, but not bulging.
Which of the following is most likely to indicate that the child can be managed safely at home?

A. Child currently taking antibiotics, with a clear bacterial focus of infection
B. Examination reveals signs of pneumonia
C. First febrile convulsion for this child
D. Focal features during the seizure
E. Seizure/convulsion lasted for < 5 minutes

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with symptoms, including chorea, inco-ordination, personality changes and psychiatric symptoms such as depression. His father died at the age of 50. You suspect this may be a case of Huntington’s disease.
Which of the following investigations would be the most useful to confirm this diagnosis?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan
B. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
C. Genetic testing
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
E. Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old man presents with complaints of recurrent headaches. He also admits to impotence and loss of libido that has gradually worsened during the past year. Visual field examination reveals a bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory examination reveals an increase in serum prolactin, while serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and testosterone are decreased.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Craniopharyngioma
B. Idiopathic panhypopituitarism
C. Isolated LH deficiency
D. Pituitary infarction
E. Prolactinoma

Correct Answer: E

A 69-year-old woman is diagnosed with a 6.9-cm infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). She is a heavy smoker, suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She also suffers from diabetes and has angina. She can walk 40 m before becoming short of breath. She is short of breath on climbing one flight of stairs. However, she is socially active and enjoys participating in the local community. She has four grandchildren and looks forward to seeing them go through university.
What is the best management of this woman’s aneurysm?

A. EVAR
B. Femoral-femoral bypass
C. Open AAA repair with Dacron graft
TA. EVAR
E. ‘Watch and wait’ policy with best medical therapy and 6-monthly ultrasound scans

Correct Answer: A

A 60-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath after being sat at home.
An arterial blood gas (ABG) is performed and shows the following results:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.48 7.35–7.45
pO2 7.3 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 3.9 kPa 4.6–6 kPa
HCO3 24 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Which one of the following conditions is most likely to account for these investigation results?

A. Hypothyroidism
B. Guillain–Barré syndrome
C. Myasthenia gravis
D. Opiate overdose
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: E

A 5-year-old girl presents to the General Practitioner with skin lesions. After taking a history and a full examination of the patient, the doctor informs the child’s mother that the skin lesions that are present are caused by a viral infection.
Which one of the following is the most likely condition to be caused by a virus?

A. Cellulitis
B. Folliculitis
C. Impetigo
D. Molluscum contagiosum
E. Necrotizing fasciitis

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old woman falls and lands awkwardly on her outstretched left hand. In the Emergency Department, the patient tells the doctor that she is experiencing tingling in her left hand. On examination, a bulge is noted on the anterior aspect of her wrist. The anatomy of the anatomical snuffbox is intact. The patient has anteroposterior and lateral radiographs taken of her left hand. The lateral view shows the profile of a displaced carpal bone that has a concave surface.
Which carpal bone is most likely to have been dislocated?

A. Hamate
B. Lunate
C. Scaphoid
D. Trapezium
E. Triquetrum/triquetral

Correct Answer: B

An FY1 doctor on the surgical assessment unit reviews the result of a blood test of one of the admitted patients. It appears that the patient has had an acute rise in his plasma urea levels.
In which of the following conditions would you expect a raised plasma urea level?

A. Colon cancer
B. Diverticular disease
C. Gastric ulcer
D. Intracranial haemorrhage
E. Ulcerative colitis

Correct Answer: C

A study is carried out investigating the relationship between smoking status and development of heart failure. Smoking status was characterised as ‘smoker’ or ‘non-smoker’. The outcome measure was development of heart failure. 1000 individuals were included in the study, of which 150 have heart failure. A total of 30 with heart failure have a past history of smoking; 20 without heart failure have a past history of smoking.
What is the odds ratio of getting heart failure in those who smoke versus those who do not smoke?

A. 0.12
B. 0.2
C. 0.6
D. 4.8
E. 10.4

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer presents with bony leg pain, constipation for 4 days, abdominal pain, thirst and disorientation. On examination, he is cachectic and dehydrated. He is apyrexial and haemodynamically stable. He has a past medical history of hypertension and is an ex-smoker. He has no known drug allergies. His calcium is 3.1 mmol/l and he has normal renal function.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Dexamethasone
B. Intravenous (iv) 0.9% normal saline
C. Furosemide
D. IV pamidronate
E. Urgent chemotherapy

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man who has been diagnosed with severe Gram-positive sepsis is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). However, he is starting to deteriorate despite being on the Sepsis Six Bundle. He is pyrexial and appears very unwell. On examination:
Investigation Results Normal value
Respiratory rate (RR) 30 breaths/minute 12–18 breaths/minute
Heart rate (HR) 120 bpm 60–100 bpm
Blood pressure (BP) 88/40 mmHg < 120/80 mmHg
You noted some bleeding along the cannulation site and on his gums. The coagulation profile showed prolonged prothrombin time, a decrease in fibrinogen level and marked elevation of D-dimer. He has some purpuric rash on his extremities.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the above condition?

A. von Willebrand’s disease
B. Liver failure
C. Haemophilia
D. Administration of heparin
E. Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC)

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old farmer was brought to the Emergency Department by his family. For the last six to seven months, he has become progressively withdrawn and has lost a significant amount of weight. He preferred lying in his room and had begun to fail to keep up with work.
On examination, occasional chewing movements of his jaws were evident. His right knee joint was swollen.
Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 91 g/l 135–175 g/l
Ferritin 3.6 μg/l 20–250 μg/l
Albumin 30 g/l 35–55 g/l
Rheumatoid factor Negative
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 102 mm in 1st hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
What is the best treatment for this condition?

A. Co-trimoxazole
B. Gluten-free diet
C. Ciprofloxacin
D. Iron therapy
E. D-penicillamine

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old man comes to the doctor’s office complaining of double vision, drooping eyelids and difficulty with speaking, chewing and swallowing. He has noticed that, in the morning, he feels well and there is no weakness, but that, as the day goes on, he begins to feel weak and tired. He has also noticed muscle weakness after exercise, which is relieved by resting. On examination, there is no muscle fasciculation, muscle atrophy or muscle spasticity. His sensation is normal, as are all his reflexes. On eye examination, his pupils are equal and reactive to light.
To which of the following are autoantibodies causing this patient’s condition directed?

A. Double-stranded (ds) DNA
B. Acetylcholine receptors
C. Dystrophin
D. Myelin
E. Presynaptic calcium receptor

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old man with a past medical history of severe mental illness presents to the Emergency Department with emesis, abdominal pain and stupor. The paramedic states the patient was found unconscious with a container of windshield washer fluid in his hands.
On examination, there is a strong smell of alcohol on the breath of the patient. You decide to perform an arterial blood gas (ABG) as part of your initial assessment.
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.25 7.35–7.45
pCO2 4.6 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
pO2 13.2 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
HCO3- 14 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Chloride (Cl-) 102 mmol/l 98–106 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic option?

A. Ethanol
B. Ethylene glycol
C. Fomepizole
D. Gastric lavage
E. Thiamine and vitamin B

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old girl presents to the Emergency Department accompanied by her mother. She complains of a 3-day history of right iliac fossa and suprapubic pain. She does not complain of vomiting, although she does mention that she has lost her appetite. Her bowel habit is regular and she describes no urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago and she should be starting her period soon. On asking, she states that she has never been sexually active.
Examination reveals suprapubic tenderness and some right iliac fossa tenderness, inferior to McBurney’s point. Her vitals are normal otherwise. Her blood test results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 123 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 290 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.3 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 4.5 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 35 mmol/l 50–120 mmol/l
Amylase 35 U/l < 200 U/l
LFTs Normal
Her urine dipstick shows 1+ of leukocytes, 1+ of proteins and a trace of blood, but is otherwise normal.
Which of the following tests is the next step in investigating this girl?

A. Beta human choriogonadotropin (β-hCG) test
B. Abdominal/pelvic ultrasound
C. Admit for observation and review in 12 hours
D. Computerised tomography (CT) of the abdomen
E. Erect chest X-ray

Correct Answer: A

A 43-year-old man who works for a pest control company attends the Emergency Department complaining of profuse diarrhoea, vomiting and hypersalivation. When you examine him, you notice bilateral constriction of the pupils, excess lacrimation, salivation and muscle fasciculations. He is bradycardic at 32 bpm and his blood pressure is recorded as 84/50 mmHg. He is immediately transferred to intensive care for management of suspected acute organophosphate poisoning.
Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management option in this patient?

A. Atropine
B. Benzodiazepine
C. Intravenous (IV) 0.9% saline
D. Pralidoxime chloride
E. Tropicamide

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman is in the second stage of labour. The fetal head is not descending, and the obstetrician decides to perform a ventouse extraction. He injects local anaesthetic into a nerve that crosses the ischial spine. This nerve then passes along the lateral wall of the ischiorectal fossa embedded in the obturator internus fascia in Alcock’s canal.
Which of the following is this nerve?

A. Pudendal nerve
B. Sciatic nerve
C. Perineal branch of S4
D. Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
E. Obturator nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 79-year-old man is admitted to hospital with increasing pains in his left hip, lumbar spine and ribs, more recently associated with confusion, weakness and falls.
Routine investigations reveal:
Investigation
Result
Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 83 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume 106 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count 2.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 48 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 149 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 11.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 176 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Random blood glucose 5.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 3.67 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
PO42- 0.76 mmol/l 0.70 – 1.40 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 165 IU/l 30 – 130 IU/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 132 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Given this presentation and his blood results, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Small cell carcinoma of the lung
B. Multiple myeloma
C. CML
D. Hyperparathyroidism
E. Myelofibrosis

Correct Answer: B

A 51-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain, fever and weight loss. Abdominal imaging revealed multiple retroperitoneal lymph nodes. She was diagnosed with intestinal tuberculosis and received a full drug regimen for six months. However, after completion of treatment, her symptoms remain. She presents to us with a body weight of 38 kg. There is angular stomatitis and diffuse loss of hair. She looks tanned. Repeat abdominal imaging reveals persistence of the lymph nodes. Her son, who accompanied her, complains that his mother is becoming listless and she has even given up her favourite hobby of Sudoku. She also has a few involuntary movements of her face, such as chewing.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Prion disease
B. Huntington’s chorea
C. Whipple’s disease
D. Coeliac disease
E. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) dementia

Correct Answer: C

A 69-year-old patient is found to have an HbA1c of 43 mmol/mol at a recent chronic disease health check after being assessed as being at high risk of diabetes mellitus.
The patient is being called in to discuss the result with her registered general practitioner.
How should the patient’s diagnosis be coded in her notes?

A. Diabetes mellitus type 2
B. Normoglycaemic
C. Pre-diabetes
D. Impaired fasting glucose
E. Impaired glucose tolerance

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department (ED) in extreme pain. He reports one day of pain in his right loin spreading round into the groin. The pain comes in waves and he says it is the worst pain he has ever experienced. The ED doctor suspects a diagnosis of renal colic.
What investigation finding would be the most consistent with this diagnosis?

A. Microscopic haematuria
B. Positive leukocytes on urine dipstick
C. Positive nitrites on urine dipstick
D. Raised serum creatinine
E. Raised serum white cell count

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman presents at 18 weeks’ gestation in a very worried state. She spent one day last week looking after her poorly niece who had cold symptoms, and a few days later, her niece developed a facial rash like a ‘slapped cheek’. The patient tells you that she herself had some myalgia and fever for two days, and today she developed a rash on her trunk and back.
On examination, her temperature is 37.7 °C and there is a maculopapular rash on her trunk and back with a lace-like appearance.
Blood tests are as follows:
rubella: immunoglobulin M (IgM) negative, immunoglobulin G (IgG) positive
parvovirus B19: IgM positive, IgG negative.
Which of the following should be the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Advise the woman to avoid going to work and contact with other pregnant women for at least five days
B. Arrange fetal blood sampling and transfusion
C. Give one dose of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) immunoglobulin and review in five days
D. Arrange urgent referral to a specialist Fetal Medicine Unit (to be seen within 4 weeks) and do serial ultrasound scans
E. Suggest paracetamol as required and plenty of fluids at present

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department after a fall. The patient is alert and oriented. She reports that she tripped over a rug and was able to brace herself with her right hand. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications or supplements. She usually drinks one glass of wine per night and does not smoke. Family history is non-contributory. Examination demonstrates tenderness in the right wrist, and computerised tomography (CT) confirms the diagnosis.
Which of the following bones is most likely fractured?

A. Hook of hamate
B. Pisiform
C. Scaphoid
D. Triquetrum
E. Capitate

Correct Answer: C

A 16-year-old boy presents with central abdominal pain and haematuria for 1 week. He also complains of pain in both knees. Examination reveals a non-blanching purpuric rash on his legs and buttocks. Urine dipstick shows: blood ++, protein +. Renal function is abnormal (urea 26.3 mmol/l, creatinine 289 μmol/l).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Nephrotic syndrome
B. Henoch–Schönlein purpura
C. Urinary tract infection
D. Goodpasture's syndrome
E. Appendicitis

Correct Answer: B

You visit a 55-year-old woman with motor neurone disease at home in England. She has become unwell over the last 48 h and, after assessing her, you conclude that she has aspiration pneumonia. Without admission to hospital for intravenous antibiotics, there is a high probability that she will die. At the time you assess her, she is exhibiting signs of delirium and is unable to retain or weigh the information needed to make decisions about her medical care. Her family indicates that she has repeatedly said that she does not want admission to hospital for treatment under any circumstances and would like to die at home. There is also a record of these wishes, as stated to her general practitioner, in her primary care records.
Select the most appropriate course of action:

A. As she lacks mental capacity, she should be admitted to hospital and treated for aspiration pneumonia as this is in her medical best interests
B. You should respect her previous wishes and make arrangements for her to be cared for at home
C. Arrange formal assessment of mental capacity by a consultant psychiatrist before deciding how to proceed
D. She should be admitted to hospital and treated until such time as she has the mental capacity to make her own decisions about her care
E. As the patient lacks mental capacity, you should ask the family to make decisions about the patient’s medical care on her behalf until such time as she regains the mental capacity to make her own decisions

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old science teacher is diagnosed with tenosynovitis of the fingers of the left hand, although she is not suffering with tenderness or swelling of the affected fingers.
In which one of the following conditions can tendinitis/tenosynovitis present without being swollen and tender?

A. Systemic sclerosis
B. Gout
C. Rheumatoid arthritis
D. Disseminated gonococcal infection
E. Reactive arthritis

Correct Answer: A

A 69-year-old man with oesophageal cancer has received two cycles of neo-adjuvant cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil (5FU) and is due for his third cycle of chemotherapy in a week. He presents with a pyrexia of 38.8 °C and pain, discharge and redness around the site of his jejunostomy. On examination, he was haemodynamically stable with a clear chest and soft abdomen, but with evidence of infection around the jejunostomy. His renal function is normal and he has no known drug allergies. A full blood count taken yesterday has a neutrophil count of 0.4 × 109/l.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Discharge home
B. Obtain intravenous (iv) access, take full blood count and blood cultures and await blood culture results prior to starting antibiotics
C. Obtain iv access, take full blood count and blood cultures and commence iv piperacillin–tazobactam (as per local policy) as soon as possible
D. Start the third cycle of chemotherapy early
E. Take full blood count and blood cultures and start oral Augmentin® and ciprofloxacin

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a fall off a ladder. She has a head injury and has vomited three times within the ambulance. Her eyes are open to voice; she is able to squeeze your hand with both hands, when asked, and wiggle her toes. She is confused about what has happened and does not remember falling. She cannot remember her age and tells you that she does not know where she is currently. Other injuries include an open tibial fracture (splinted). Her sats are A. 100% on 15 l high-flow oxygen, with a heart rate of 90 bpm and a blood pressure of 1A. 10/78 mmHg.
What is her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. 10
B. 11
C. 12
D. 13
E. 14

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old man complains of epigastric pain and heartburn that has begun to interfere with his daily activities. Endoscopy shows a single shallow ulcer on the posterior aspect of the first part of the duodenum.
Which one of the following arteries is the ulcer most likely to erode?

A. Splenic artery
B. Short gastric artery
C. Left gastric artery
D. Left gastroepiploic artery
E. Gastroduodenal artery

Correct Answer: E

A 26-year-old man, diagnosed with ulcerative colitis (UC) 18 months ago, presents with 2-day history of progressively worsening abdominal pain and bloody diarrhoea. He is currently passing motion 11 times per day.
On examination, there is generalised abdominal tenderness and distension. He is pyrexial, with a temperature of 39 °C; his pulse is 124 bpm.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 90 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 15 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Erect chest X-ray Normal
Plain abdominal X-ray 12-cm dilatation of the transverse colon
He also has a raised C-reactive protein (CRP).
What would be the most appropriate initial management of this patient?

A. Intravenous (IV) hydrocortisone, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), IV fluids, reassess response after 72 hours
B. Oral mesalazine
C. Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy
D. IV hydrocortisone, LMWH, IV fluids, IV infliximab
E. IV vedolizumab infusion

Correct Answer: A

A 42-year-old computer programmer had been experiencing increasing right-hand pain during the last 3 months, accompanied by loss of strength in his thumb. He was referred to a neurologist who ordered radiographic studies.
Which condition does this man most likely have?

A. Dupuytren’s contracture
B. Erb’s palsy
C. Carpal tunnel syndrome
D. Pronator syndrome
E. Wrist drop

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 6-week history of sweating, tremors and palpitations. The patient is 8 months pregnant. She has no significant past medical history. On clinical examination, she is noted to have prominent eyes, a heart rate of 110 bpm and a small, diffuse goitre. Her laboratory investigations are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Free T4 44 pmol/l 11–22 pmol/l
Free T3 15 pmol/l 3.5–5 pmol/l
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) <0.01 µU/l 0.17–3.2 µU/l
TSH receptor antibody (TRAb) 20 U/l < 0.9 U/l
Which of the following treatments should be prescribed?

A. Carbimazole
B. Thyroxine
C. Ibuprofen
D. Tri-iodothyronine
E. Propylthiouracil as part of a blocking-replacement regime

Correct Answer: A

A 13-year-old girl with known sickle-cell disease presents to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain.
On examination, she is found to have a tachycardia of 130 bpm, with generalised abdominal tenderness and 3 cm splenomegaly. Blood tests reveal marked anaemia, and a diagnosis of splenic sequestration crises is considered.
Which blood vessel in the spleen is most responsible for monitoring the quality of red blood cells and removing aged ones from circulation?

A. Trabecular veins
B. Trabecular artery
C. Central artery
D. Sheathed capillary
E. Splenic sinusoid

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man attends to the outpatient urology clinic. Two weeks ago, he saw his General Practitioner with a lump in the left testicle. He denies any other symptoms. On examination, the lump is approximately 5 mm in diameter, firm and painless on palpation. Ultrasound of the testicle and tumour markers suggests a diagnosis of testicular cancer.
Which of the following tumour marker combinations were likely requested for this man?

A. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
B. AFP and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
C. CEA and hCG
D. CEA and prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
E. PSA and CA-125

Correct Answer: A

A patient visits her General Practitioner (GP) with some questions about the Breast Cancer Screening Programme, regarding which she has recently received a letter.
Which of the following most accurately describes the components of breast cancer screening?

A. Mammogram every three years
B. Ultrasound scan every three years
C. Triple assessment every three years
D. Breast examination by a doctor every three years
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the chest every three years

Correct Answer: A

A 74-year-old retired boiler maker presents to his General Practitioner with increasing shortness of breath and non-specific dull right-sided chest ache. He has a 30-pack-year history and has recently lost a little weight. On examination, there is evidence of a large right-sided pleural effusion.
Investigations:
Investigation
Result
Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 130 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 111 g/l 135–175 g/l
Platelets 165 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Chest X-ray: large right-sided pleural effusion.
Pleural tap: pleural effusion contains occasional red blood cells, white blood cells and abnormal-looking cells which look of a sarcomatous type.
Which of the following statements fits best with the underlying condition?

A. The vast majority of cases are associated with a history of asbestos exposure
B. Curative resection is possible in most patients
C. Smoking is likely to have played a significant role in the development of the effusion
D. Median survival is around three years
E. Radiation therapy is curative in around 40% of cases

Correct Answer: A

A 5-year-old Chinese girl is brought to the Emergency Department by her parents because her skin and face turned blue after playing with her friends. The girl was born in China, and soon after her birth she and her parents moved to the United Kingdom. An ultrasound examination revealed a large gap in the upper portion of the ventricular septum and a slightly enlarged right ventricle. The doctor explained to the parents the severity of the disease and the importance of a surgical intervention.
If the parents decide not to go ahead with surgery to correct this condition, which of the following is most likely to happen to their child in the future?

A. Development of a persistent foramen ovale
B. Atrial fibrillation
C. Progressive lengthening of the PR interval
D. Pulmonary vascular hypertrophy with shunt reversal leading to congestive heart failure
E. Dilated cardiomyopathy

Correct Answer: D

A medical student is reading up on hypersensitivity reactions, and finds that systemic lupus erythematosus is classed as a type of hypersensitivity reaction which involves damage to tissue mediated by the deposition of antigen–antibody complexes, resulting in the activation of complement
Which of the following hypersensitivity reaction types does this describe?

A. Type I
A. B. Type II
A. B. C. Type III
A. D. Type IV
E. Type V

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of increasingly painful periods over the last few months. The pain is unrelieved by ibuprofen and is worsened during sexual intercourse. On clinical examination, there is adnexal tenderness. You suspect a diagnosis of endometriosis may be the underlying cause of her dysmenorrhoea.
What is the most appropriate first-line investigation in cases of suspected endometriosis?

A. Diagnostic laparoscopy
B. Laparotomy with biopsy
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) pelvis
D. Transabdominal ultrasound
E. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS)

Correct Answer: E

A 20-year-old woman presents with a chronic history of diarrhoea, weight loss and fatigue. Based upon the clinical history and examination findings, you suspect she has coeliac disease.
What is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Immunoglobulin A (IgA) endomysial antibody testing
B. IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTGA) antibody
C. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing
D. Small bowel biopsy
E. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old man presents with right-sided pleuritic chest pain. He says he felt a ‘pop’ and soon after, the pain and shortness of breath began.
On examination, he looks short of breath and has a respiratory rate of 35 breaths per minute. There are diminished breath sounds on the right-hand side of the chest on auscultation.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
PaO2 7.9 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
PaCO2 3.1 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Chest X-ray: 50% right-sided pneumothorax
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A. 32F chest drain insertion with a cut-down
B. 28F chest drain insertion using a trochar
C. 24F Portex chest drain insertion
D. Repeated air aspiration
E. 14F chest drain insertion over a Seldinger wire

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old retired ship dockland worker presents to the Medical Outpatient Department with a history of difficulty breathing, hoarse voice, weight loss and occasional night sweats. He also complains of difficulty in swallowing, although this happens very infrequently. He has also noticed that, in the past month, he has become easily tired when performing his daily activities.
On examination, there is unilateral dullness to percussion at the right lung base, decreased breath sounds on the right side, asymmetrical chest wall expansion and scoliosis are observed. A chest X-ray demonstrates diffuse pleural thickening on the right side and decreased right lung volume. A positron emission tomography (PET) scan and video-assisted thoracoscopy (VAT) are performed to obtain the pleural biopsy, and a histopathological diagnosis is made.
Which of the treatments could achieve the best possible outcome in this patient?

A. Cisplatin plus pemetrexed
B. Combination therapy
C. Immunotherapy
D. Macroscopic complete resection (MCR)
E. Radiotherapy

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old man complained of unilateral headache and cheek pain (pain rated 9/10) after he ate certain foods. During examination, the doctor reproduced the patient’s pain by squirting lemon juice into the patient’s mouth.
Which of the following structures is most likely to be directly involved in this patient’s diagnosis?

A. Molar teeth
B. Submandibular duct
C. Parotid duct
D. Buccinator muscle
E. Facial nerve

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old man has presented to the Emergency Department, following a 3-day history of progressive shortness of breath, productive cough and fever. His past medical history is significant for type II diabetes, currently controlled with metformin. He is a non-smoker, denies recent travel and has no regular contact with animals.
An examination is performed, which reveals a heart rate of 91 bpm, a blood pressure of 98/59 mmHg, a temperature of 38.2 °C and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute. Coarse crackles are heard on auscultation of the right lower lobe. A chest X-ray is performed, which confirms the presence of a right lower lobe pneumonia. The patient is admitted to the Respiratory Ward for intravenous (IV) empirical antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. A sputum culture result has been received two days later:
Investigation Result
Sputum
Rust-coloured sputum
After two days of growth, a Gram-positive spherical bacterium which tends to grow in chains is observed
Partial haemolysis is observed on blood agar plate
Which of the following organisms is the most likely responsible for the patient’s pneumonia?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Streptococcus pneumoniae
C. Klebsiella pneumoniae
D. Haemophilus influenzae
E. Streptococcus pyogenes

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man is being discharged from the Surgical Ward following a midline laparotomy for a perforated duodenal ulcer. He has several surgical staples in situ.
How many days post-surgery should the staples be removed?

A. 1–2 days
B. 5–7 days
C. 10–14 days
D. 14–21 days
E. 21–28 days

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge. She describes it as a thin, greyish, watery discharge. It is painless and has a fishy odour.
Which is the appropriate treatment?

A. Azithromycin 1 g stat
B. Metronidazole 400 mg twice a day for a week
C. Aciclovir 800 mg five times a day for 5 days
D. Fluconazole 1 g stat
E. Pivmecillinam 200 mg three times a day

Correct Answer: B

An 85-year-old is brought to the Emergency Department after being found at home on the floor by her daughter. Her daughter tried to rouse her but had no response. She has a laceration to her head and her daughter believes she may have had a fall. You notice she has a sudden decrease in consciousness in the department. You are unable to get the patient to make any vocalisation. When you apply supraorbital pressure, she briefly opens her eyes and withdraws from the pain.
Which one of the following is the best immediate management option for this patient?

A. Referral to the neurosurgical registrar
B. Start a neurological observation chart
C. Insert Guedel airway
D. Urgent CT brain scan
E. Medication review

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old man presents to an Ophthalmology Clinic complaining that straight lines appear “bendy and distorted”. He has also noticed dark, blurry areas in the centre of his vision in both of his eyes. This has been getting progressively worse over the last 18 months. He has no pain in either eye and there is no redness in either of his eyes. Fundoscopy examination of his eye is performed.
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on fundoscopy?

A. Detached retina
B. Disc cupping
C. Drusen
D. Macular neovascularisation
E. Retinal haemorrhages

Correct Answer: C

A 73-year-old woman presented with weakness and low-grade irregular fever for 3 months. On examination, firm non-tender lymph nodes were found in the left axilla and left side of the neck. Abdominal examination revealed splenomegaly of 3 cm. Blood tests showed the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 21 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Lymphocyte percentage 62% 25%–33%
Platelets 164 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
A peripheral blood smear of the patient is shown here:
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
What is the next appropriate treatment?

A. Observation
B. Oral antibiotics
C. Bone marrow transplantation
D. Fludarabine
E. Rituximab

Correct Answer: A

A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) with 71% of bone marrow blasts. She declined bone marrow transplant and was started on appropriate chemotherapy. After 2 months, a repeat bone marrow revealed 8% of blasts. Peripheral blood was blast-free and blood tests revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 106 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 5.2 × 109/l 2.5–7.58 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.8 × 109/l 1.5–3.5 × 109/l
Platelets 131 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
What is her clinical status?

A. Complete remission
B. Partial remission
A. C. Complete remission with incomplete recovery
D. Resistant disease
E. Morphologic leukaemia-free state

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man with a family history of autosomal-dominant polycystic kidneys has been diagnosed with polycystic kidneys using ultrasound. He is currently asymptomatic and has no other past medical history.
Which of the following factors is most important to control, to improve his long-term prognosis?

A. Control blood pressure < 130/90
B. Decrease caffeine intake
C. Decrease protein intake
D. Increase exercise to 150 min/week (NHS guidelines)
E. Stop drinking alcohol

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old man who used to work as a stonemason comes to the clinic, complaining of shortness of breath on minimal exercise and a dry cough. His shortness of breath has increased progressively over the course of the past year. He also smokes 20–30 cigarettes per day and has occasional wheeze. A chest X-ray reveals some upper lobe nodular opacities. On examination, he is clubbed and you can hear bilateral late-inspiratory crackles at both lung bases.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 125 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 189 × 109/l 150–410 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 135 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
FVC 2.1 litres >4.05 litres
FEV1 1.82 litres >3.15 litres
Chest X-ray Nodular lung opacities
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
B. Occupational asthma
C. Occupational interstitial lung disease
D. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
E. Non-occupational asthma

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing a curtain coming from the right inferonasal side towards the centre, but it does not affect her central vision. She also describes seeing flashes of lights at the right inferonasal side and an increase in the number of floaters in her right eye.
On examination, her vision is 6/6 in the right eye, 6/6 in the left eye.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Inferior macula-off retinal detachment
B. Inferonasal macula-off retinal detachment
