C. Inferotemporal macula-off retinal detachment
D. Superonasal macula-on retinal detachment
E. Superotemporal macula-on retinal detachment

Correct Answer: E

A 69-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) with complaints of difficulty swallowing. He mentions that solid food like meat often gets stuck in his throat. He is also beginning to lose weight and have difficulty swallowing thick liquids like soups. There is some pain on swallowing. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and depression. His current medications include amlodipine and sertraline. He has no drug allergies. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and drinks approximately 3–4 pints of beer per day. He is unsure of his family medical history, as he was adopted.
Physical examination is normal, and his observations are shown below:
Temperature 37.1°C
Blood pressure 145/81 mmHg
Heart rate 71 bpm
Respiratory rate 14 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation (SpO2) 97% (room air)
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?

A. Abdominal plain film
B. Abdominal ultrasound
C. Chest plain film
D. Oesophageal manometry
E. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man complains of scratchy sensation in the eyes as the day progresses. He complains that his eyes feel tired. He only has these symptoms during weekdays when he works as a computer programmer in a local company. On examination, aside from mild conjunctival hyperaemia, the rest of the ocular examination is normal.
Stimulation of which of the following nerves is associated with tear formation?

A. Oculomotor nerve
B. Intermediate nerve
C. Glossopharyngeal nerve
D. Vagus nerve
E. Chorda tympani

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old woman is recovering in hospital following a stroke.
On examination, it is discovered that she has a right homonymous superior quadrantanopia.
Where is the lesion causing this visual field defect?

A. Left occipital visual cortex
B. Left temporal (lower) optic radiation
C. Left parietal (upper) optic radiation
D. Right parietal (upper) optic radiation
E. Right temporal (lower) optic radiation

Correct Answer: B

A radiologist read a coronary angiogram of a 70-year-old man with long-standing heart disease and observed stenosis of the right coronary artery causing decreased perfusion of the right atrial myocardium.
A decreased blood flow to which of the following structures related to the right atrium is most likely to have been affected?

A. Sinoatrial node
B. Atrioventricular node
C. Atrioventricular bundle
D. Left bundle branch
E. Right bundle branch

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old carpet layer presents to the clinic for review. He has been complaining of severe anterior knee pain for a few days. On examination, you notice that the left knee is warm and there is swelling on the patella. There is local pain on patellar pressure and pain with knee flexion.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 185 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 12 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Knee aspirate: Gram stain negative for bacteria; fluid contains occasional white cells; culture is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Localised cellulitis
B. Osteoarthritis of the knee
C. Rheumatoid arthritis
D. Gout
E. Pre–patellar bursitis

Correct Answer: E

Acute limb compartment syndrome is characterised by increased pressure within an unyielding osseo-fascial compartment, resulting in local tissue hypoxia.
Of the following symptoms, which one is a late sign of compartment syndrome indicating a poor prognosis?

A. Anaesthesia
B. Paraesthesia within distribution sensory nerves
C. Pulses present
D. Severe pain on passive muscle stretch
E. Swollen leg

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old woman is in the Intensive Care Unit. She has an arterial blood gas that demonstrates pH 7.48, PaCO2 6.8 kPa, PaO2 9.6 kPa and HCO3− 38 mmol/l.
Which of the following is most likely to adjust the patient’s blood pH to normal range?

A. Increase the tidal volume
B. Decrease the tidal volume
C. Increase the respiratory rate
D. Administer intravenous bicarbonate
E. Increase the patient’s minute ventilation

Correct Answer: B

A 3-day-old baby boy is admitted to hospital. He was diagnosed with Down syndrome soon after birth. He has not opened his bowels since birth and no meconium has been passed. His abdomen is distended, and he has had several episode of bile-stained vomit. The mother denies any complication during pregnancy. An abdominal X-ray does not show any double bubble sign but a rather shows a picture of bowel obstruction.
Which of the following investigations would provide a definitive diagnosis?

A. Abdominal ultrasound
B. Upper GI endoscopy
C. Erect chest X-ray
D. Colonoscopy
E. Rectal biopsy

Correct Answer: E

A 7-year-old child is admitted to the Emergency Department with a displaced supracondylar fracture. It requires manipulation using procedural sedation.
Which of the following would be the best?

A. Morphine
B. Ketamine
C. Midazolam
D. Propofol
E. Lorazepam

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man wishes to discuss ‘the prostate cancer’ blood test. He has no lower urinary tract symptoms, and digital rectal examination reveals a normal prostate.
In discussing the advantages and disadvantages of the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test, which statement best reflects the advice you should give about the accuracy of the test?

A. The test is now not recommended as it provides misleading results
B. Around two-thirds of men with a positive PSA will not have prostate cancer and if you take men with prostate cancer, around 15% of them will have a normal PSA level
C. Around one-third of men with a positive PSA will not have prostate cancer and if you take men with prostate cancer, around 85% of them will have a normal PSA level
D. Around two-thirds of men with a positive PSA will not have prostate cancer and if you take men with prostate cancer, around 85% of them will have a normal PSA level
E. Around one-third of men with a positive PSA will not have prostate cancer and if you take men with prostate cancer, around 15% of them will have a normal PSA level

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with excruciating chest pain. He has had severe vomiting and retching over the last 24 hours after he ate some off-food at a restaurant. The last four episodes of vomiting have been bloody and he states that he has vomited too many times to count. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 38.9 °C
Blood pressure 95/59 mmHg
Heart rate 115 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 95% (room air)
Physical examination of the chest reveals subcutaneous emphysema over the chest wall. His electrocardiogram (ECG) is significant for sinus tachycardia with no ischaemic changes and his blood tests results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count 21.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein 105.5 mgl 0–10 mg/l
Haemoglobin 103 g/l 135–175 g/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute coronary syndrome
B. Aortic dissection
C. Boerhaave syndrome
D. Mallory–Weiss tear
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: C

A 6-year-old boy with no past medical history is brought to the General Practitioner (GP) by his mother with 24 hours of headache and fever. He has also had two episodes of non-bloody vomiting this morning and states that ‘both legs are sore all over’. He is up to date with all of his vaccinations and has never been hospitalised in the past. No one in the child’s social circle has been unwell recently and he has no travel history. He has no drug allergies.
On examination, discrete lesions of approximately 1–2 mm are visible, present on the trunk and legs. This rash is non-blanching. The mucous membranes are moist with no lesions present. His hands are cool to touch with a capillary refill time of three seconds. He is unable to fully flex his neck. His observations are shown below:
Temperature 38.2 °C
Blood pressure 100/59 mmHg
Heart rate 107 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Discharge with advice for supportive care
B. Intramuscular benzylpenicillin
C. Oral ciprofloxacin
D. Oral prednisolone
E. Oral rifampicin

Correct Answer: B

A 14-year-old girl has been admitted to the acute medical unit for a mild exacerbation of her asthma. She has recovered well, and her peak flow measurements have almost returned to normal. After being seen on the ward round, she asks an FY1 for contraceptive advice. She mentions that she is sexually active with one partner, her 17-year old boyfriend.
What is the first most appropriate action?

A. Tell her it’s illegal to have sex at her age and decline providing contraceptive advice
B. Determine if the Fraser guideline criteria are met and ask questions about her relationship to ascertain if there are any safeguarding concerns
C. Inform her parents and escalate the case to the child protection lead
D. Explain that there are several contraceptive options and arrange an appointment with her GP to discuss these with her
E. Determine if the Fraser guideline criteria have been met and, if so, prescribe an appropriate contraceptive

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old, 80 kg woman presents to the Emergency Department with chest pain that started 6 hours previously. She was previously well, has no known allergies and is on no regular medications. Her electrocardiogram displays a sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion in lateral leads but no ST changes. Her serum troponin is raised significantly.
Which one of the following combination of drugs should be given immediately?

A. Aspirin 75 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, fondaparinux 2.5 mg
B. Aspirin 300 mg, fondaparinux 2.5 mg
C. Clopidogrel 300 mg, fondaparinux 2.5 mg
D. Aspirin 300 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, fondaparinux 2.5 mg
E. Aspirin 300 mg, prasugrel 60 mg, fondaparinux 2.5 mg

Correct Answer: E

An 85-year-old woman is admitted to hospital after suddenly losing all sensation to her right leg and right arm. She has no loss of consciousness, no visual disturbances, no slurring of speech and no motor symptoms. A stroke is suspected.
Based on the findings, what type of stroke is most likely?

A. Lacunar stroke
B. Locked in syndrome
C. Millard–Gubler syndrome
D. Partial anterior circulation stroke
E. Total anterior circulation stroke

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department in December because, for the past three days, she has had a high fever (up to 40 °C), vomiting and night sweats. For the last four weeks, she has been lethargic and has sweated through her pyjamas almost every night. She has had several nosebleeds in this time period, which her parents attributed to dry air from the heater. She has also been complaining that her back hurts.
On examination, her temperature is 39.5 °C, her heart rate 140 bpm, her blood pressure 80/60 mmHg and her respiratory rate 20 breaths/minute. She appears acutely ill and you notice small petechiae on her abdomen.
Which one of the following would examination of peripheral lymphocytes most likely show?

A. A clonal population of mature B cells
B. A clonal population of immature cells expressing terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT)
C. A clonal population of immature cells with intracytoplasmic dark pink rods
D. Lymphocytes with thin projections of the cytoplasm
E. A chromosomal translocation that leads to a constitutively active tyrosine kinase

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old male patient presents with sudden-onset severe headache and vomiting. He has a family history of subarachnoid haemorrhage.
Which of the following statements is true?

A. Rupture of posterior circulation aneurysm is most likely
B. Computed tomography (CT) will be diagnostic in 75% of cases
C. Lumbar puncture with microscopy is the gold standard investigation
D. Bradycardia with high blood pressure suggests increased intracranial pressure
E. Lumbar puncture to test for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) xanthochromia should be performed immediately to make a diagnosis

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old plasterer presents to the general practitioner (GP) with an acutely swollen and painful left thumb. The pain came on rapidly over the course of 24 hours, with no history of trauma or injury. The patient describes the thumb as being extremely painful and particularly tender to touch. The patient is a type 2 diabetic, which is well controlled with metformin. He does not smoke, but drinks around ten pints of beer at weekends.
Examination reveals a swelling, erythema and tenderness over the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The clinician suspects a possible crystal arthropathy.
With regard to gout, which of the following statements is true?

A. Gout may be seen in patients with chronic haemolytic anaemia
B. Gout only affects the first metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint
C. Allopurinol is effective in the treatment of acute gout
D. A diagnosis of gout is made if there are positively birefringent crystals in the joint aspirate
E. All cases of acute gout have an elevated serum urate

Correct Answer: A

Which of the following substances are secreted by virally infected cells, as part of a signalling mechanism?

A. Secretory immunoglobulin A
B. Membrane attack complex
C. Interferon α
D. Tumour necrosis factor α
E. Histamine

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old solicitor complains of right upper quadrant pain and has deranged liver function tests (LFTs). Ultrasonography of the abdomen demonstrated a dilated common bile duct. He proceeds to endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Whilst observing the procedure, the consultant asks you the location of the ampulla of Vater, which is cannulated during the procedure.
Where does the ampulla of Vater enter the bowel?

A. Jejunum
B. Ascending (fourth part) duodenum
C. Descending (second part) duodenum
D. Inferior (third part) duodenum
E. Superior (first part) duodenum

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old hypertensive man has been prescribed six medications but still has uncontrolled hypertension. You suspect that he is not adherent to his medications.
Which screening tool is the best to use to determine his adherence to his medications?

A. The patient health questionnaire (PHQ-9)
B. Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA)
C. Moriskey scale
D. CAGE questionnaire
E. Wells score

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old retired general practitioner (GP) has been experiencing increasing swelling and tenderness of the right knee. Symptoms have been progressively worsening over four days. There is no history of trauma, and he has had no similar symptoms previously. The patient thinks that he may have pseudogout of the knee.
Which one of the following tissues is the most common site of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition in patients with pseudogout?

A. Synovium
B. Ligaments
C. Cartilage
D. Tendons
E. Bursae

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. After workup, including blood tests, an electrocardiogram (ECG) and a chest X-ray, a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE) is suspected.
In which situation might a ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan be preferred to a computerised tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) to confirm a diagnosis of PE?

A. Wells PE score of 3
B. Weekend admission
C. Abnormal chest X-ray
D. Renal impairment
E. History of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man with long-standing diabetes mellitus comes to the Renal Clinic for review. His creatinine has worsened over the past year from 152 μmol/l to 199 μmol/l. He is currently managed with ramipril, amlodipine and indapamide. His blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg. His diabetes is controlled with twice-daily (bd) mixed insulin.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 109 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 193 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 199 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
HbA1c 7.3%
Ultrasound scan of the renal tract Bilateral normal-sized kidneys,
no ureteric obstruction
Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

A. Stop his ramipril
B. Reduce the dose of his ramipril
C. Add an α-blocker to his regime
D. Add furosemide to his regime
E. Stop his indapamide

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with lower back pain, fever, bilateral leg weakness with numbness and urinary incontinence. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan shows normal bone anatomy, with inflammation at around L4–5 segment of the spinal cord.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate initial treatment option?

A. Intravenous dexamethasone
B. Intravenous immunoglobulin
C. Oral prednisolone
D. Plasma exchange
E. Surgery

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old woman with a history of metastatic lung cancer presents with increasingly severe left-sided facial pain and paraesthesia. On examination, she is noted to have reduced sensation in the distribution of the maxillary branch of the left trigeminal nerve (V2). CT scan of brain reveals a destructive lesion of the left side of the skull base consistent with a bony metastasis.
Which of the following skull base structures is most likely to be involved?

A. Jugular foramen
B. Foramen lacerum
C. Foramen ovale
D. Hypoglossal canal
E. Foramen rotundum

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old farmer presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a one week history of severe pain over the left parotid area. The pain is usually bought on when the patient is eating or about to eat. The GP considers a diagnosis of a parotid duct stone.
With regard to the parotid gland, which one of the following statements is correct?

A. It contains within it branches of the facial nerve deep to the retromandibular vein
B. It consists of superficial, middle and deep lobes
C. It has secretomotor action via the glossopharyngeal and auriculotemporal nerves
D. It has a duct that pierces the masseter muscle to enter the mouth opposite the upper second molar tooth
E. It produces mainly a mucus secretion

Correct Answer: C

Which of the following diseases is correctly paired with its associated autoantibody?

A. Pernicious anaemia and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies
B. Myasthenia gravis and voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies
C. Primary biliary cholangitis and anti-Jo-1 antibodies
D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) and anti-myeloperoxidase (p-ANCA) antibody
E. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and thyroid-stimulating antibodies

Correct Answer: A

A 53-year-old male patient is called to attend the Emergency Department, following the results of a routine blood test at his general practice surgery. Unfortunately, no documentation has arrived with him, but he informs you that he has a history of abdominal swelling due to alcoholic liver disease. His blood results in the department reveal the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 91 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 132 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 85 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
He reports that he has recently started a medication to treat his abdominal swelling. You are concerned that this drug is the cause of his biochemical abnormality. What is the likely causative agent?

A. Amlodipine
B. Bumetanide
C. Furosemide
D. Ramipril
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man is brought by ambulance, having fallen off his motorbike. He was wearing a helmet at the time of the crash; the helmet cracked on impact. At presentation, he is haemodynamically stable and examination is unremarkable, aside from superficial abrasions on the arms and legs. Specifically, he is neurologically intact. He is nevertheless offered admission for head injury charting and observation. Two hours after admission, nurses find him unresponsive, with a unilateral fixed, dilated pupil. An emergency computed tomography (CT) scan is performed.
What is the likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Extradural haemorrhage
B. Subdural haemorrhage
C. Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH)
D. Intra-parenchymal haemorrhage
E. Scalp haematoma

Correct Answer: A

A 75-year-old lady with metastatic breast cancer is admitted to the hospice for ongoing care. She complains that, at night, strange men enter her room and move her belongings and that staff talk about her during the day. In addition, she sometimes sees a vision of her deceased sister in her room and this has caused her anxiety and distress.
Which of the following medications would be most appropriate to treat her symptoms?

A. Lorazepam
B. Diazepam
C. Midazolam
D. Haloperidol
E. Hyoscine bromide

Correct Answer: D

You are the surgical foundation year 1 doctor and have been bleeped by the nurse on the surgical ward regarding a 68-year-old patient who had a laparotomy for large bowel obstruction 2 days ago. On attending the ward the nurse reports that she thinks the patient is becoming unconscious with a drop in respiratory rate to eight breaths per minute. You have tried to secure the patient’s airway and noted on the drug chart that patient has been using the patient controlled analgesia with morphine regularly.
Which of the following is the next appropriate treatment?

A. 400 µg bolus of naloxone
B. 400 mg bolus of naloxone
C. 300 µg of flumazenil
D. 40 µg increments of naloxone titrated to effect
E. Intubation and ventilation

Correct Answer: A

A 5-month-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department by her worried parents. They have noticed that she has been distressed over the last few days with what appears to be painful finger and toe swelling. They have noticed she has been excessively tired and that her eyes and skin look yellow in colour. Her family have recently moved from Nigeria but were unable to access antenatal or postnatal screening tests. Her parents were hoping to travel by air for a pre-booked holiday in two days.
Given the likely diagnosis for this child, after how many days is it safe for them to travel?

A. Three days
B. Ten days
C. Indefinitely
D. Four weeks
E. Six months

Correct Answer: B

A 3-year-old boy is seen by a Paediatrician as he has learning and behavioural difficulties. On examination, he has symmetrical muscle weakness and has only just learned how to walk. He needs to use his hands to help him get up into a standing position. The doctor suspects that he may have Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and requests further tests.
Which protein is absent in DMD?

A. Collagen
B. Dystrophin
C. Creatine kinase
D. Fibrillin
E. Sarcoglycan

Correct Answer: B

An 84-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with increasing ‘weakness’ all over, following a prolonged stay in hospital with a severe chest infection and heart failure. Of note, she is on bendroflumethiazide, furosemide, aspirin and atorvastatin. Examination is relatively unremarkable, and the GP thinks it may be due to her prolonged illness but sends some routine bloods.
FBC: A. Hb 93 g/l, MCV 84 fl, WCC 5.9 × 109/l, platelets 108 × 109/l
U&Es: C. Na+ 129 mmol/l, D. K+ 2.1 mmol/l, urea 12.2 mmol/l, creatinine 146 μmol/l
BG 9.6 mmol/l
CK 112 iu/l
Which of the blood results is the probable cause of her weakness?

A. Hb 93 g/l, MCV 84 fl
B. Platelets 108 × 109/l
C. Na+ 129 mmol/l
D. K+ 2.1 mmol/l
E. Urea 12.2 mmol/l, creatinine 146 μmol/l

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old intravenous drug user (ivDU) is admitted with fever, cough and shortness of breath (SOB). An echocardiogram shows evidence of severe tricuspid regurgitation and there are two vegetations on the valve.
Which of the following organisms is most likely to be grown in blood culture?

A. Mycoplasma pneumoniae
B. Pneumocystis carinii
C. Staphylococcus aureus
D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
E. Legionella pneumophila

Correct Answer: C

During your psychiatry rotation, you are looking at non-pharmacological treatments available to treat and manage various mental health conditions.
Which of the following mental health conditions can electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) be used for?

A. Catatonia
B. Moderate depression
C. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
D. Anxiety
E. Severe dementia

Correct Answer: A

A 16-year-old girl with a family history of short-sightedness presents to her General Practice Clinic, complaining of difficulty seeing objects that are far away. She is a keen scientist and wants to understand what the underlying pathophysiology is for the condition she is experiencing.
Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of her myopia?

A. Increased axial length of the eye, meaning the focal point is anterior to the retina
B. Increased axial length of the eye, meaning the focal point is posterior to the retina
C. Reduced axial length of the eye, meaning the focal point is anterior to the retina
D. Reduced axial length of the eye, meaning the focal point is posterior to the retina
E. Refractive error which hinders refraction

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man received a two unit blood transfusion 1 hour ago. He reports noticing a funny feeling in his chest, like his heart keeps missing a beat. You perform an ECG which shows tall tented T waves in multiple leads.
An arterial blood gas (ABG) test shows:
Na+: 136 mmol/l (normal 135–145 mmol/l)
K+: 7.1 mmol/l (normal 3.5–5.0 mmol/l)
Cl–: 96 mmol/l (normal 95–105 mmol/l).
Given the findings, what treatment should be given immediately?

A. Calcium resonium
B. Calcium gluconate
C. Insulin and dextrose
D. Normal saline bolus
E. Dexamethasone

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman who is at 10 weeks’ gestation in her second pregnancy sees her midwife to receive her Booking Clinic blood results. She feels a bit tired at present and appears pale. She denies any infective symptoms, and observations and examination are unremarkable.
Her full blood count is as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 101 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 73 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 323 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Which of the following statements best describes the management of anaemia in pregnancy?

A. Anaemia is defined as a haemoglobin level of < 100 g/l in the first trimester and < 110 g/l in the second trimester
B. All pregnant women in the United Kingdom (UK) should be offered iron supplementation
C. A trial of iron supplementation, followed by a re-check of the full blood count at two weeks, is the standard method for treating anaemia in pregnancy
D. The full blood count should be assessed a minimum of three times in a normal, uncomplicated pregnancy
E. Women with a haemoglobin level of < 110 g/l at delivery should be treated with iron supplementation for at least three months after delivery

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old farmer presents to the clinic with muscle pain in his lower back, calves and neck. He takes regular paracetamol but this has not helped his symptoms. For the past three weeks, he has become increasingly agitated and reports that he can no longer sleep for more than a few hours because the pain wakes him up. He feels increasingly lethargic and helpless. He also reports that as a result of his pain, he feels that his memory has worsened and he reports a low mood. A Kessler Psychological Distress Scale screening questionnaire is performed and he has a score of 29. His laboratory blood tests are unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Codeine
B. Duloxetine
C. Paracetamol
D. Psychotherapy
E. Venlafaxine

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man is admitted to the Medical Assessment Unit with increased confusion. He has a past medical history of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The patient has no allergies.
On examination, his heart sounds are normal; he has a few crackles bibasally, and there is suprapubic dullness on abdominal percussion. The patient is catheterised by the medical house officer and a urine dipstick is taken. On the Elderly Care Ward, while helping the patient to wash, the ward staff notice the head of his penis is red and swollen. Otherwise, he has normal anatomy.
Which is the most likely cause?

A. Phimosis
B. Paraphimosis
C. Penile cancer
D. Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)
E. Peyronie’s disease

Correct Answer: B

A 4-year-old boy presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with his mother, with a 3-day history of a sore and itchy patch around the upper lip. The mother first noted a few little blisters on the lip, which then seemed to pop, leaving areas of patches covered with brown and/or honey-coloured crusts. The patch has slowly been getting bigger.
Following examination, the GP makes a diagnosis of impetigo.
Which of the following is most likely to be the cause of impetigo?

A. Staphylococcus epidermidis
B. Staphylococcus saprophyticus
C. Streptococcus viridans
D. Staphylococcus aureus
E. Staphylococcus albicans

Correct Answer: D

A 14-year-old girl presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of amenorrhoea. She is accompanied by her parents who mention that the girl has learning difficulties at school and is requiring additional support. Upon examination, the doctor notes include sparse breast development, broad shoulders, increased blood pressure and a wide neck.
What is the most likely chromosomal abnormality that this patient has?

A. 45 XO
B. 47 XXX
C. 47 XXY
D. 46 XY
E. 46 XX

Correct Answer: A

A 79-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath. His observations include a pulse rate of 105 bpm, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute and SpO2 saturations on pulse oximetry of 80%. He has a 10-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). On auscultation, there is bilateral reduced air entry, as well as coarse crackles.
Which of the following investigations would be the most important to perform next?

A. Arterial blood gas (ABG)
B. Chest X-ray
C. D-dimer
D. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
E. Pulmonary function tests

Correct Answer: A

Which of the following conditions is correctly paired with an eye sign that is seen in that condition?

A. Down syndrome and Bitot’s spots
B. Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and blue sclerae
C. Haemochromatosis and Kayser–Fleischer rings
D. Hypocalcaemia and band keratopathy
E. Tuberous sclerosis and Lisch nodules

Correct Answer: B

You are asked to assess a patient in A+E with a burn. He is a 42 year old man who sustained a contact burn to the palm of his left hand and index, middle and ring fingers from a heated metal object an hour ago.
He is haemodynamically stable, and not in significant pain. He a right handed metalworker and is otherwise fit and well with no drug allergies. On examination you find the burnt skin on the palmar aspect is white and leathery in appearance. It does not blanch to pressure and the patient can not feel you touching the skin in that area.
This assessment would be compatible with what depth of burn?

A. Superficial
B. Deep dermal (partial thickness)
C. Full thickness
A. D. Superficial dermal (partial thickness)
E. More information needed

Correct Answer: C

An overweight 56-year-old Caucasian male patient attends for the results of a health check arranged by your surgery. He smokes 12 cigarettes a day and is trying to cut down. Alcohol intake is 8 units per week. He tells you that his father underwent a ‘triple bypass’ aged 58 years. His results are as follows:
Total cholesterol : HDL ratio 6
HbA1c: 39 mmol/mol
Urea and electrolytes: normal
Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR): 97 ml/min/1.73m2
Liver function tests: normal
Blood pressure (daytime average on 24-h ambulatory monitor): 140/87
Body mass index (BMI): 25
His QRISK2 10-year cardiovascular risk is calculated at 22.7%.
In addition to assisting with smoking cessation and providing lifestyle advice, what is the most appropriate means of managing his risk?

A. Commence atorvastatin 40 mg once a night and start blood pressure treatment if this rises above 150/90
B. Commence atorvastatin 20 mg once a night and recheck cholesterol in 3 months, aiming to titrate the therapy to maintain a total cholesterol of <5; start an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor
C. Commence atorvastatin 40 mg once a night and start an ACE inhibitor
D. Commence atorvastatin 20 mg once a night and start a calcium channel blocker, review after three months
E. Commence atorvastatin 20 mg once a night and recheck cholesterol in 6 months, aiming to titrate the therapy to maintain a total cholesterol of <5; start a calcium channel blocker

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman with bipolar disorder has been taking her medication throughout pregnancy. On her latest scan, her baby is noted to have features associated with spina bifida.
What medication has she been taking that is most likely to cause this?

A. Sodium valproate
B. Lithium
C. Olanzapine
D. Bupropion
E. Carbamazepine

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance after collapsing at his workplace. Co-workers report that he is the head chef at a busy restaurant and that the kitchen is very hot, sometimes approaching 46 °C. The patient admits that he had not been drinking water, despite the heat, and that he was taking 1800 mg ibuprofen everyday for aches and pains from work. Further questioning reveals that he has hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus, but he does not recall the names of the medications he is taking. The patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown.
What electrolyte imbalance is most likely to cause these findings?

A. Hypercalcaemia
B. Hyperkalaemia
C. Hypernatraemia
D. Hyperuricaemia
E. Hyperchloraemia

Correct Answer: B

A 3-year-old patient is referred to the Paediatric Unit after having presented to her General Practitioner (GP) twice over the course of the week with fever and a red tongue and throat. A course of penicillin V has so far been ineffective. She is fully immunised and has not been in contact with any other children with notifiable infectious diseases. Her parents report that she has not been well for around 7 days with a high fever, which they have been unable to bring down with paracetamol and ibuprofen. She has had a cough with coryzal symptoms and has now developed conjunctivitis.
On examination, she looks unwell. Temperature is 38 °C, heart rate 124 bpm and respiratory rate 28. Capillary refill time is 2 s centrally. She has bilateral conjunctivitis. She has a red oropharynx and a red tongue. There is cervical lymphadenopathy and a widespread maculopapular rash. Her hands and feet are red and there is some peeling of the skin around the toes.
Which of the following diagnoses should be made?

A. Coxsackie infection
B. Measles
C. Kawasaki disease
D. Viral upper respiratory tract infection with exanthema
E. Scarlet fever

Correct Answer: C

The family of a 67-year-old retired teacher with end-stage heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy wishes to discuss the possibility of the patient being listed for a heart transplant. The patient is a type 2 diabetic, controlled with diet alone, and has a previous history of basal cell carcinoma, which was successfully removed 12 years ago, with no recurrence or complications. The patient’s current body mass index (BMI) is 18. The patient is currently being treated for a cellulitis infection at a previous cannula site.
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to heart transplantation?

A. Age over 65
B. Previous history of malignancy
C. Diabetes
D. Active infection
E. BMI of <18.5 kg/m2

Correct Answer: D

A 79-year-old retired architect is under assessment for progressive memory dysfunction. Due to the history given by the patient’s wife, the clinician suspects that the patient may be suffering from vascular dementia.
Which of the following is characteristic of vascular dementia?

A. Slow, insidious progression
B. Wasting and weakness of the tongue and palate
C. Unsteadiness and falls
D. Agnosia
E. Visual hallucinations

Correct Answer: C

You arrive with the ambulance crew to the scene of a high-energy road traffic accident involving a 35-year-old man. He has an open fracture of his right femur and is unconscious. He appears to be struggling to breathe. On initial observation, you see a large pool of blood gathered around his abdomen coming from a wide wound.
Which of the following is the first step in his immediate management?

A. Apply pressure to the abdominal wound to minimise bleeding
B. Secure the airway and stabilise the C spine
C. Undress the patient to assess the wounds and then cover with blankets to prevent hypothermia
D. Start intravenous (IV) fluids via two large-bore cannulae
E. Give morphine

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old woman is on her second day postpartum, following a Caesarean section. She is taking regular paracetamol for pain around the wound site, which has not alleviated her symptoms.
She is breastfeeding and is asking whether there are any other safe analgesics to help with her pain.
Which of the following medication is the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Aspirin
B. Codeine
C. Ibuprofen
D. Indometacin
E. Tramadol

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year old woman has been called into her General Practice (GP) surgery as the results of her recent blood tests reveal that she has a raised anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody level.
Which of the following diseases is associated with anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody?

A. Coeliac disease
B. Graves’ disease
C. Pemphigus vulgaris
D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
E. Type 1 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: A

A 27-year-old Caucasian woman presents with complaints of fatigue, malaise, anorexia, fever, headache and weight loss. She has pain and swelling of the knees, ankles, elbows and metacarpophalangeal joints. She tells you that she is sensitive to sunlight and avoids going out in the day. On examination, you notice a butterfly-shaped erythematous rash on her face. She has pallor, splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed:
Investigation
Result
Normal value
Haemoglobin 80 g/l 115–155 g/l
Red blood cells 2.8 × 1012 3.8–5 × 1012
White cell count 4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelet count: 90 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
CUE (creatinine, urea, electrolytes) reveals 1+ proteinuria and cellular casts; an X-ray of affected joints reveals non-deforming arthritis.
Which one of the following tests correlates best with this disease activity?

A. Anti- chromatin antibodies
B. Heterophile antibody
C. Anti-double-stranded DNA
D. Rheumatoid factor
E. Anti-ribonucleoprotein antibody

Correct Answer: C

A 67-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) with a painful lesion on the plantar aspect of her foot.
On examination, there is a 30 mm × 15 mm firm, hyperkeratotic lesion, with central pinpoint petechiae. She has no past medical history and is otherwise well. The lesion is particularly bothering her due to its cosmetic appearance.
On examination, the lesion appears as below.
By Marionette [CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0)]
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

A. Cryotherapy
B. Do nothing
C. Topical retinoid
D. Topical salicylic acid
E. Topical silver nitrate

Correct Answer: D

Following newborn screening, an 11-day-old term baby boy tests positive for raised levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. Further samples are taken for DNA analysis, and a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF) is confirmed.
Which of the following statements is true about CF?

A. Diabetes occurs as a result of insulin resistance
B. Cystic fibrosis is diagnosed by confirming low levels of sodium chloride in sweat
C. Most men with CF are infertile
D. Autosomal dominant inheritance is typical
E. Dextrocardia is a feature

Correct Answer: C

A 70-year-old woman is referred to a respiratory out-patient clinic with a 6-month history of shortness of breath and dry cough. She is a non-smoker however her husband is a pigeon breeder. On examination, she has an Sp0­2 of 95% on room air. She is clubbed. Chest examination reveals bilateral and symmetrical reduced chest expansion together with fine end-inspiratory crepitations. Chest radiograph shows bilateral lower zone increased interstitial markings. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) confirms these findings and also shows bibasal honeycombing. There is no lymphadenopathy on CT.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bronchiectasis
B. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (usual interstitial pneumonia)
C. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (extrinsic allergic alveolitis)
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: B

A 20-year-old woman, presenting with a 4-month history of severe mood swings, breast tenderness and reduced cognitive ability to perform functions at work, comes for a review with her diary of symptoms corresponding to a period of three cycles. She attends work regularly during these episodes and goes out with friends, but does not enjoy it as much and is less productive.
Going through the diary, symptoms occur during the luteal phase and resolve 2–3 days into menstruation.
Blood tests, including thyroid function tests, are normal. She has tried the progesterone implant, which made her symptoms worse; therefore, she is not currently using any contraception.
A diagnosis of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) is made.
Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
B. Fluoxetine
C. Regular exercise
D. Referral to a specialist clinic
E. St John’s wort

Correct Answer: A

An 82-year-old man with rising levels of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is having a transperineal biopsy to determine whether he has carcinoma of the prostate. The needle passes through a number of structures en route to the prostate.
Which of these structures will be the first encountered after the needle passes through the skin?

A. Peritoneum
B. Colles’ fascia
C. Inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm
D. Superior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm
E. Camper's fascia

Correct Answer: E

An 8-year-old boy attends the Emergency Department with his mother and has been complaining of a 2-day history of right iliac fossa pain. He has previously been fit and well, with no other medical problems, apart from a cough and sore throat over the last week. He has had a high fever over the last 2 days and has been off his food but denies any other symptoms. Examination reveals a temperature of 38.9 °C and a heart rate of 130 bpm. Bilateral enlarged submandibular and cervical lymph nodes are palpable and slightly tender. Chest examination is clear, with transmitted sounds from the upper airways. Abdominal examination reveals marked tenderness in the right iliac fossa with no guarding.
Urine dipstick reveals 2+ of ketones and 1+ of protein.
Blood test results for his full blood count (FBC) are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 145 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 14.3 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 425 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?

A. Appendicitis
B. Mesenteric adenitis
C. Urinary tract infection (UTI)
D. Meckel’s diverticulitis
E. Retroperitoneal appendix abscess

Correct Answer: B

This type of psychotherapy examines the patient’s early past experiences, especially within the family. These experiences theoretically determine perceptions of others, including the therapist. The therapist identifies these patterns of thinking and relating to others with the intent of allowing the patient gain insight into unconscious motivations. The aim of the therapy is to improve effectiveness in the adult world and improve interpersonal relationships.
Which type of therapy is most likely, given the above explanation?

A. Cognitive therapy
B. Behaviour therapy
C. Psychoanalysis
D. Brief interpersonal therapy
E. Structural family therapy

Correct Answer: C

A 44-year-old man has a high thoracic spine injury at T2 sustained from a motorbike accident. He is now 10 days post injury and has had a spinal fixation. He is paraplegic with a sensory level at T2. He has had a normal blood pressure today requiring no haemodynamic support. You are called to see him on the trauma ward as he has a tachycardia at about 150/beat per minute and very high blood pressure, up to 230/110 mmHg. The nurses have just changed his catheter. He says he feels slightly strange, sweaty and flushed in his face.
What would explain this?

A. Pulmonary embolus
B. Neurogenic shock
C. Autonomic dysreflexia
D. Stress cardiomyopathy
E. Anxiety and depression

Correct Answer: C

A young man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a lump on his eyelid. He has had this for two days. The GP diagnoses this as a chalazion.
Which is the best management option?

A. Topical antibiotics, eg chloramphenicol ointment
B. Refer to ophthalmology urgently
C. Apply heat and massage daily
D. Surgical incision
E. Watch and wait

Correct Answer: C

A homeless alcoholic who frequently attends the Emergency Department is brought by ambulance, having been found unconscious on the street. He had been examined the previous day with head and facial injuries following a fist fight. Examination on admission reveals an unconscious patient smelling strongly of alcohol. He is rousable with painful stimuli, but confused and unco-operative. His pupils are unequal, with the left pupil measuring approximately 8 mm and the right 4 mm. The left pupil is unreactive to both direct and consensual light stimulus, whereas the right pupil constricts normally to direct and consensual light stimulus.
Which cranial nerve(s) is this lesion affecting?

A. The left optic nerve
B. The right optic nerve
C. The left oculomotor nerve
D. The right oculomotor nerve
E. A combined lesion of the left oculomotor and optic nerves

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year old man attends his general practice as he has recently been feeling increasingly tired. He currently drinks 4–6 units of alcohol a day. He has been taking medication for a chronic medical condition for the past year. On examination he appears healthy and well nourished. Blood tests are ordered which show an elevated gamma glutamyl transpeptidase and a decreased alkaline phosphatase (ALP).
What of the following drugs is most likely to cause these blood results?

A. Carbamazepine
B. Amlodipine
C. Gentamicin
D. Insulin
E. Bisoprolol

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old woman is reviewed in the Gastroenterology Clinic following hospitalisation for a Crohn’s flare. She is taking steroids and the physician wishes to commence her on medication to maintain remission and is considering azathioprine.
What may be measured to evaluate if azathioprine is appropriate for this patient?

A. Alpha-1-antitrypsin
B. CYP2D6 activity
C. Faecal calprotectin levels
D. Lactate dehydrogenase
E. Thiopurine methyl transferase activity

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman presents at 12 weeks’ gestation for her dating scan. The radiographer calls you in to speak to the patient, as the gestational sac is small for dates and she is unable to demonstrate a fetal heart rate. On further questioning, the patient reports an episode of bleeding while abroad at nine weeks’ gestation, which settled spontaneously.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Complete miscarriage
B. Incomplete miscarriage
C. Inevitable miscarriage
D. Missed miscarriage
E. Threatened miscarriage

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old sportsman who is very tall attends the Emergency Department with acute-onset shortness of breath, accompanied by right-sided pleuritic chest discomfort. His only past medical history is of a previous hospital admission for gastroenteritis when he was 12 years old. He is a non-smoker. On examination: respiratory rate 22 breaths/min, SpO2 95%. Chest X-ray (CXR): right-sided pneumothorax, 3 cm from the rim.
What is the most suitable course of action in the short term?

A. Immediate chest drain insertion
B. Send home
C. Needle aspiration
D. Observation and daily CXR
E. Refer to thoracic surgeons for pleurodesis

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old woman (an immigrant from India) presented with pain in her lower back and pelvis. She also has weakness when climbing stairs. Her doctor suspects vitamin D deficiency.
Which of the following blood reports is most compatible with this diagnosis?

A. Alkaline phosphatase 35 u/l (20–70 u/l)
B. Serum calcium 7.9 mg/dl (8.4–10.2 mg/dl)
C. Serum phosphate 5.2 mg/dl (3.0–4.5 mg/dl)
D. Normal 25-(OH) D3 level
E. High magnesium level

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath on exertion, and reports that she sleeps on three pillows at night to avoid shortness of breath. Past medical history of note includes two recent transient ischaemic attacks which have resulted in transient speech disturbance and minor right arm weakness. Other non-specific symptoms include fever and gradual weight loss over the past few months. On auscultation of the heart you notice a loud first heart sound, and a plopping sound in early diastole. General examination also reveals that she is clubbed.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 6.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 101 g/dl
(normochromic normocytic) 115–155 g/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 85 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Chest X-ray Unusual intra-cardiac calcification
within the left atrium

Which of the following fits best with the likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Rheumatic heart disease
B. Left atrial myxoma
C. Mitral stenosis
D. Mitral regurgitation
E. Infective endocarditis

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old man attends the Emergency Department with severe central chest pain. The pain is worse on lying down, relieved by sitting forward, and radiates to the left shoulder. He has recently had two cycles of radiotherapy for prostate cancer. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg (normal <120/80 mmHg), a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) and a pulse of 100 bpm that appears to fade on inspiration. Quiet heart sounds are heard. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows low-voltage QRS complexes.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this condition?

A. DC cardioversion
B. Fluid challenge with 1litre sodium chloride STAT
C. GTN spray
D. Low-molecular-weight heparin
E. Urgent pericardiocentesis

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic cardiac failure with reduced ventricular systolic function presents with recent onset of increasing breathlessness, and worsening peripheral oedema and lethargy. He is currently taking ramipril and bisoprolol alongside occasional paracetamol.
What is the most appropriate long-term management?

A. Addition of ivabradine
B. Addition of furosemide
C. Addition of spironolactone
D. Insertion of an implantable cardiac defibrillator device
E. Encourage regular exercise and a healthy diet

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old accountant presents with an acute history of chest pain, with associated shortness of breath. He has recently returned from a holiday in Singapore. He does not smoke, drinks occasionally and likes to keep fit in his spare time. The only other medical history to note is a previous deep vein thrombosis aged 30.
The admitting doctor is concerned that the patient may have a pulmonary embolism.
Which of the following symptoms described would most support this diagnosis?

A. Chest pain which is central, radiating to the left arm
B. Chest pain associated with waterbrash and bloating
C. Chest pain that is worse when lying flat and relieved by leaning forwards
D. Chest pain that is worse on deep inspiration
E. Chest pain that is relieved by rest

Correct Answer: D

A 29-year-old man who has recently been under a lot of stress at work presents with an itchy, erythematous rash, superolateral to the right corner of the mouth. The rash started 3 months previously, remitted and then relapsed shortly after. He has applied topical corticosteroid to relieve the symptoms, but because of a flare-up of his facial acne, he had to stop using it. He admits to consuming excessive amounts of alcohol lately. On physical examination, there is an ill-defined erythematous rash on the right side of his face, involving the nasolabial fold. Fine, greasy scales are also noted.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
B. Lichen planus
C. Atopic dermatitis
D. Psoriasis
E. Dermatitis herpetiformis

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department with hypotension despite 6 units of blood and maelena. He has a history of arthritis for which he takes methotrexate and ibuprofen.
What is the next most appropriate management step from the following list?

A. Continued transfusion
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan
C. Endoscopy
D. Laparotomy
E. Diagnostic laparoscopy

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old baker presents to his General Practitioner with rhinitis, breathlessness and wheeze. He reports his symptoms have acutely worsened since he returned from a 2-week holiday in Spain. He has been experiencing these symptoms on and off for the past year. He has a ten-pack-year smoking history.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Occupational asthma
B. Legionnaires’ disease
C. Hay fever
D. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
E. Pulmonary embolus

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old man is brought by ambulance to Accident and Emergency. He presents with central crushing chest pain and has ST-segment elevation present on an electrocardiogram (ECG). You are at a District General Hospital without access to percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and you will not be able to transfer the patient across for PCI in time.
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to thrombolysis?

A. Blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg
B. Active peptic ulceration
C. Advanced liver disease
D. Pregnancy
E. Brain neoplasm

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old man is referred to an otolaryngologist with vertigo and hearing loss. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the cranial region reveals a tumour at the cerebellopontine angle. A working diagnosis of acoustic neuroma is made. In light of the progressive symptoms, the surgeon plans to remove the tumour.
With regard to the vestibulocochlear nerve, which of the following is correct?

A. Vestibular fibres pass to the vestibular nuclear complex, located in the floor of the fourth ventricle
B. The vestibulocochlear nerve provides the efferent nerve supply to the tensor tympani
C. The vestibulocochlear nerve enters the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction, medial to the facial nerve
D. The vestibulocochlear nerve exits the cranium through the jugular foramen
E. Cochlear fibres pass to the cochlear nucleus, located in the midbrain

Correct Answer: A

A 57-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) as he has been feeling generally tired all the time and has experienced frontal hair loss.
He has a background of high blood pressure and asthma, and his medication includes salbutamol, amlodipine and simvastatin. He is otherwise well.
Neurological exam is grossly normal.
Investigation Result Normal value
Auto-antibody screen Negative
Creatine kinase (CK) 1 000 U/l 22–198 U/l
Which of the following is most likely to have caused this man’s presentation?

A. Extensive exercise
B. Dermatomyositis
C. Polymyositis
D. Rhabdomyolysis
E. Statin therapy

Correct Answer: E

A mother brings her newborn baby to the Paediatric Ward for a baby check. The baby’s mother is concerned about a birthmark on her torso, the appearance of which is shown below. In total, there are two of these marks.
What is the most appropriate investigation?

A. Biopsy of lesion
B. Genetic testing
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain
D. No further testing required
E. Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Correct Answer: D

A 42-year-old man presents with a one-month history of feeling a lump in his throat. The feeling comes and goes and has not progressed. He has no difficulty swallowing food or liquids; in fact, eating and drinking help to relieve the symptoms. He has not lost weight. He is a non-smoker. He was recently diagnosed with gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) and is taking a proton pump inhibitor. He also has chronic sinusitis, for which he takes a steroid nasal spray.
Examination is normal, with no cervical lymphadenopathy.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Achalasia
B. Eosinophilic oesophagitis
C. Globus pharyngeus
D. Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
E. Oesophageal ring

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old lady is brought to the Emergency Department complaining of right-sided chest pain. She was discharged from hospital 2 days ago after an elective total knee replacement. She has no other past medical history of note and is a lifetime non-smoker. On examination, she appears relatively well but remains in slight discomfort.
Observations are as follows: blood pressure 140/80, heart rate 110 bpm, afebrile, sats 91% on air, respiratory rate 20.
Positive examination findings include a rapid, regular radial pulse and a diffusely swollen, but not erythematous, left leg with a clean-looking surgical scar over the anterior aspect of the knee.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pulmonary embolism (PE)
B. Lower respiratory tract infection
C. Acute coronary syndrome
D. Heart failure
E. Costochondritis

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after an episode of near-drowning. He fell from a boat into a lake and was unable to swim. He was underwater for < 2 minutes before he was rescued. He did not lose consciousness. He reports swallowing lots of water and vomited twice in the ambulance. He is awake and alert; his observations are as follows: blood pressure 126/76 mmHg, pulse 94 bpm, oxygen saturations 94% on room air, and temperature 36 °C. He is coughing occasionally, and his lungs are clear to auscultation. One hour after the episode, he feels well and wishes to go home.
What is the best management plan for this patient?

A. Admit to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
B. Administer intravenous (IV) antibiotics and IV fluids
C. Administer IV fluids
D. Admit overnight for observation
E. Discharge home

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department as a trauma alert, with knife stab wounds in the right arm and thorax. On arrival, he has a heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure (BP) of 100/70 mmHg, a weak pulse and raised jugular vein pressure (JVP) (+5 cm), respiratory rate (RR) of 20 breaths/min, with widespread wheeze bilaterally, and oxygen saturations of 100% on 5 litres of oxygen. He is complaining of chest pain despite just having had 1 g of paracetamol.
Investigation Result Normal value
Heart rate 120 bpm 60–100 bpm
BP 100/70 mmHg < 120/< 80 mmHg
RR 20 breaths/minute 12–20 breaths/minute
O2 saturation 100% on 5 litres O2 94–99%
What complication is he likely to have suffered as a consequence of his injuries?

A. Fractured ribs
B. Tension pneumothorax
C. Cardiac tamponade
D. Hypovolaemia from haemorrhage
E. Traumatic aortic dissection

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old man attends Accident and Emergency with severe central chest pain. The pain is worse on lying down, relieved by sitting forward and radiates to the left shoulder. He has recently had two cycles of radiotherapy for prostate cancer. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg (normal <120/80 mmHg), a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) and a pulse of 100 bpm that appears to fade on inspiration. Quiet heart sounds are heard. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows low-voltage QRS complexes.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this condition?

A. Ibuprofen
B. Fluid challenge with 1 litre of sodium chloride STAT
C. Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray, morphine, clopidogrel, aspirin
D. Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)
E. Urgent pericardiocentesis

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old man with a long history of diabetes and peripheral vascular disease presents with an ulcer under the ball of his foot. His wife noticed the ulcer.
Which is the most likely underlying cause?

A. Diabetes
B. Venous disease
C. Ischaemia
D. Cancer
E. Infection

Correct Answer: A

Warfarin is known to have a volume of distribution of 8 litres, whereas for chloroquine, this is 15 000 litres.
Which of the following is true?

A. Chloroquine is not lipophilic
B. Chloroquine is highly protein bound
C. Warfarin is dosed according to international normalised ratio (INR)
D. Warfarin is metabolised and excreted by the liver, whereas chloroquine is excreted by the kidney
E. Warfarin is subject to first-pass metabolism

Correct Answer: C

A 79-year-old former solicitor is brought to your clinic by his wife who says he keeps losing his way walking home from town. He appears otherwise fit and well, but his General Practitioner (GP) writes that, in response to previous concerns about him repeatedly forgetting his hotel room while on holiday 2 months ago, he scored his patient 24/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination. You repeat the same examination and score him 23/30, losing most marks for attention and orientation.
What is his most likely diagnosis?

A. Mild dementia
B. Moderate dementia
C. Severe dementia
D. Delirium
E. Normal mental state

Correct Answer: A

A 14-year-old girl visits her GP with her best friend. She discloses that her relative has been sexually abusing her for the past several months.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Advise her that nothing can be done without her parent’s consent
B. Advise her to self-present at the police station
C. Discuss the case with the safeguarding lead after the child has left
D. Perform a pelvic examination and swabs
E. Refer urgently for a forensic examination

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old woman is on day one postpartum, following a normal vaginal delivery. She has called the midwife, as she is struggling to establish breastfeeding and correct positioning of the baby to the breast. She reports pain when the baby is breastfeeding.
Which of the following is a feature of a poor latch?

A. Clicking noises are heard
B. The baby’s arms and hands are relaxed
C. The baby’s chin touches the breast
D. The baby’s lips are rolled out
E. There is less areola visible below the chin than above the nipple

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old girl presents to your surgery with sore throat and high-grade fever. She has little difficulty in swallowing and denies any difficulty breathing. She has never suffered from these symptoms before.
Upon examining her throat, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Quinsy
B. Tonsillitis
C. Infectious mononucleosis
D. Tonsillar lymphoma
E. Pharyngitis

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old woman who is 26 weeks’ pregnant sees you in the Emergency Department (ED) as she has some swelling of her ankles. She is otherwise well and has had no other pregnancy problems. This is her first child. Her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg and she has 2+ protein in her urine. You repeat this after 4 hours and her blood pressure has decreased to 130/95 mmHg. You do not have access to her booking bloods or previous bloods. Her results are below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Blood pressure 130/95 mmHg < 120/< 80 mmHg
Haemoglobin (Hb) 85 g/l 115–155 g/l
Platelets (Plts) < 210 × 109/l 150-400 × 109/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 250 U/litre 25–250 U/litre (in pregnancy)
Which one of these statements is the most likely to be true?

A. She does not have pre-eclampsia as her repeat bloods pressure has a systolic of <140 mmHg. She can be discharged home and followed up at a later stage. The above shows normal changes for pregnancy
B. By definition she has pre-eclampsia and should be admitted for investigations and blood pressure (BP) control
C. She has HELLP (haemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)
D. Most likely hypertension of pregnancy. No great concern
E. She should have an ultrasound scan (USS) of her biliary tree as her high ALP signifies biliary obstruction

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old man is referred by his general practitioner (GP). He was brought in by his parents after he had attempted to set fire to his room. His parents reported that, over the past two months, they have noticed that the patient appears withdrawn and has been spending a lot of time in his room. He will not let anyone in his room and has also blocked the view from his windows using aluminium foil.
At the clinic, he accused the GP of being one of the police agents sent to spy on him. He has also lost significant weight, and his parents report that his mood seems to be quite low on some days. The patient has no insight into his current condition and says that his room needs to be burnt down to destroy the surveillance devices installed by the police. The patient denies drug use, but his father confirms that he has once seen his son smoking what he suspected was an illicit drug in the back yard.
The GP refers the patient to a psychiatric hospital, and the doctors there explain to the parents that it is in the patient’s best interests to be kept in hospital for assessment for a maximum of 28 days.
Which of the following is the most appropriate Section to be used for this patient?

A. Section 5(2)
B. Section 4
C. Section 3
D. Section 5(4)
E. Section 2

Correct Answer: E

A 48-year-old man, with known polycystic kidney disease (PKD), presents with acute-onset fever, left mid-back pain and occasional chills. He has no dysuria or haematuria. The left renal angle is tender. The white cell count is 27.8 × 109/l, with 92% of neutrophils (54–62%).
What is the best diagnostic modality to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

A. Urine culture
B. Blood culture
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen
D. Ultrasonography of the kidneys
E. Scintiscan of the kidneys

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old HIV-positive man, evaluated for weight loss and weakness, has been found to have disseminated tuberculosis.
On examination, he is hypotensive and has hyperpigmentation of the mucosa, elbows and skin creases. Further investigations confirm a diagnosis of Addison’s disease.
Which of the following biochemical abnormalities would most typically be found in this condition?

A. Increased bicarbonate
B. Increased glucose
C. Increased potassium
D. Increased sodium
E. Reduced urea

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with an asthma attack. On examination, he is alert, with difficulty completing sentences in one breath, and has a peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) of 40%, a respiratory rate of 25 breaths/minute and a silent chest.
Which one of the following features best indicates a life-threatening asthma attack?

A. PEFR 40% of predicted or best
B. Silent chest
C. Difficulty completing sentences in one breath
D. Alert
E. Respiratory rate >25 breaths/minute

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man presents with a lesion on his upper arm. The lesion first appeared 2 months ago as a red papule, however it has since progressed and is centrally filled with yellow/brown material, and is hard to the touch. The lesion measures 6 mm in diameter. He is seen 3 months later and the papule has reduced and is resolving by itself.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Basal-cell carcinoma
B. Malignant melanoma
C. Keratoacanthoma
D. Solar keratosis
E. Squamous-cell carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old man was involved in a car crash and was brought by ambulance to the Emergency Department with abdominal pain. He had some bruising on the abdominal wall. His blood pressure was 100/40 mmHg, with a pulse rate of 130 bpm. Emergency computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen was performed, which is shown here.
Picture courtesy: Dept. of Radiology, MCH, Kolkata
Which of the following will be the most likely outcome for this patient?

A. Gut segment devitalisation
B. Nephrectomy
C. Paraplegia
D. Splenectomy
E. Trauma-induced pancreatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 27 year old patient is admitted by ambulance to the emergency department. He is known to be an intravenous drug user and currently has a reduced level of consciousness, mild respiratory depression and pin point pupils.
Which of the following medications would be most appropriate during initial management?

A. Flumazenil
B. Naloxone
C. N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC)
D. Adrenaline
E. Atropine

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old woman was referred to colposcopy, following the detection of high-grade (moderate) abnormalities on her recent cervical smear cytology – high-risk (HR) human papillomavirus (HPV) positive. She had a loop excision of the cervix, and the histology report said it contained cervical intra-epithelial neoplasia 1 + 2.
What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A. HPV test of cure in three months, if negative recall in five years
B. HPV test of cure in six months, if negative recall in three years
C. HPV test of cure in six months, if negative recall in five years
D. Refer back to routine screening, repeat in three years
E. Refer back to routine screening, repeat in five years

Correct Answer: B

An investigator intended to test the antiglycaemic action of a new drug, which acts by increasing the peripheral uptake of glucose and reduces postprandial glucose level. He noted that in the control group, subjects receiving an oral glucose load have higher postprandial insulin concentrations and more rapid glucose clearance, compared to subjects receiving isoglycaemic intravenous glucose infusion.
Which of the following is the most likely mediator of this effect?

A. Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1)
B. Secretin
C. Cholecystokinin
D. Gastrin
E. Somatostatin

Correct Answer: A

You are assessing a 90-year-old woman with advanced dementia who is bed-bound and has a grade two pressure ulcer. Her carer thinks she feels pain when being moved in bed. The patient takes no pain medication at present. The patient is having severe nausea, vomiting and has severely impaired mental status.
Which of the following is the most appropriate prescription?

A. Paracetamol 1 g intravenous
B. Paracetamol 1 g per rectum
C. Lidocaine patch 5% topical
D. Morphine sulfate 5 mg oral
E. Fentanyl patch transdermal

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman is admitted with a 48-hour history of headache and malaise which has worsened in the last 6 hours. She has vomited twice. She has recently had a sore throat. Her general practitioner has been treating her with a topical anti-fungal cream for vaginal thrush. On examination, she is photophobic and has moderate neck stiffness. The Glasgow Coma Score is 15/15, and she has no focal neurological signs. Her temperature is 38.5 °C.
A computed tomography (CT) brain scan is reported as ‘Normal intracranial appearances’.
CT brain scan is reported as ’Normal intracranial appearances’.
A lumbar puncture is performed and CSF results are as follows:
Investigation Result
CSF protein 0.6 g/l (<0.45)
Cell count 98 white cells/mm3, mainly lymphocytes (<5)
CSF glucose 2.8 mmol/l (2.5 – 4.4 mmol/l)
Blood glucose 4.3 mmol/l (3-6 mmol/l)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Guillain-Barré syndrome
B. Acute bacterial meningitis
C. Acute viral meningitis
D. Tuberculous meningitis
E. Fungal meningitis

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old man experiences sudden right-sided chest pain while exercising. The pain persists in Accident and Emergency and he is experiencing worsening shortness of breath. On examination, you find distended neck veins, tracheal deviation to the patient’s left-hand side and reduced breath sounds on the right side of the chest. He is tachycardic and has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths/minute, with oxygen saturations of 93%.
Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Send for an urgent chest X-ray to confirm a pneumothorax
B. Start on high-flow 100% oxygen
C. Insert a chest drain STAT
D. Prescribe analgesia and admit for monitoring
E. Insert a wide-bore cannula into the second intercostal space

Correct Answer: E

A 22-year-old woman attends her general practice to discuss referral for tonsillectomy. She has had four episodes of acute tonsillitis per year over the last three years. Some of these have required antibiotics and some have been managed conservatively. She is a medical student and each of these episodes has been disabling and she has had to miss several days of university.
Which of the following is an indication for referral for tonsillectomy for tonsillitis?

A. Episodes of tonsillitis are disabling and prevent normal functioning
B. Five or more well-documented, clinically significant, adequately treated tonsillitis in the preceding year
C. Three or more well-documented, clinically significant, adequately treated tonsillitis in each of the preceding two years
D. Two or more well-documented, clinically significant, adequately treated tonsillitis in each of the preceding three years
E. One severe episode of tonsillitis requiring admission

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old female medical student experiences severe epigastric pain, following an evening indulging in large amounts of fatty foods. She went to visit her general practitioner (GP) who, upon further investigation, organised an analysis of her lipoprotein profile.
Analysis showed a deficiency of apolipoprotein (apo) C-II; all other lipoproteins were normal.
Which of the following profiles is plasma electrophoresis most likely to show?

A. Elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and no other changes
B. Elevated levels of chylomicrons and low levels of very low-density lipoproteins (VLDLs)
C. Elevated levels of both chylomicrons and VLDLs
D. Low VLDL levels and no other changes
E. Low levels of both chylomicrons and VLDLs

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman is referred to the Emergency Department by her General Practitioner (GP) with a 4-day history of right flank pain, dysuria and fever. Urosepsis is suspected, and the Sepsis Six Pathway is implemented in the Emergency Department.
Which of the following is part of the ‘Sepsis Six’, the six key components to managing sepsis?

A. Anti pyretics
B. Intravenous (IV) fluids
C. Corticosteroids
D. Maintain blood glucose 8–12 mmol/l
E. Avoid oxygen therapy unless severe hypoxia

Correct Answer: B

A 71-year-old man is undergoing open surgery to repair a direct inguinal hernia. In theatre, the hernial sac is noted to lie medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
To weakness of which of the following structures can the hernia best be attributed?

A. Aponeurosis of external oblique
B. Conjoint tendon
C. Muscular fibres of internal oblique
D. Muscular fibres of transversus abdominis
E. Superficial inguinal ring

Correct Answer: B

You are working on a General Medical Ward and have been asked to report all cases of notifiable disease to the local authority proper officers (under Health Protection Legislation 2010). There are eight patients whom you feel may have a notifiable disease:
Patient 1 27-year-old man with acute meningitis (no causative agent identified yet)
Patient 2 43-year-old woman with severe acute respiratory syndrome
Patient 3 19-year-old woman with diarrhoea (no causative agent identified)
Patient 4 42-year-old woman with hepatitis B (high HBeAg titre)
Patient 5 73-year-old man with flu (influenza virus)
Patient 6 88-year-old woman with a community-acquired pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae) identified
Patient 7 74-year-old woman with diarrhoea (Clostridium difficile isolated)
Patient 8 28-year-old man with glandular fever (Epstein-Barr virus)
Which five patients require notification via the proper officer?

A. 1, 2, 4, 5, 6
B. 1, 4, 6, 7, 8
C. 2, 3, 5, 6, 8
D. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7
E. 2, 4, 5, 6, 8

Correct Answer: A

A 27-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with fever, fatigue and weight loss of 1-week duration. He complains of pain and swelling of the right knee and left ankle over the same period, along with lower back pain. On further questioning, he also gives a history of multiple vesicles on the palms and soles, which healed by forming crusts. He also describes inflammation and discharge from his eyes.
He thinks it might be linked to his holiday to Thailand one month ago, when he developed a purulent discharge from the glans penis and dysuria. On examination, there are multiple ulcers in the oral mucosa and glans penis. Hyperkeratotic crusts are present on his palms and soles.
This disease is a response, in certain individuals, following infection with which one of the following organisms?

A. Neisseria gonorrhoeae
B. Treponema pallidum
C. Chlamydia trachomatis
D. Streptococcus pyogenes
E. Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with recurrent chest infections over the last year. She has suffered from rheumatoid arthritis for a long time and is on methotrexate and sulfasalazine. On examination, there are some crepitations at the right lung base and splenomegaly.
Full blood counts showed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 96 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 0.8 × 109/l 1.7–7.5 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.5 × 109/l 1.0–4.5 × 109/l
Eosinophils 0.6 × 109/l 0.0–0.4 × 109/l
What is the mostly likely diagnosis?

A. Felty’s syndrome
B. Side-effects from methotrexate
C. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
D. Non-E. Hodgkin’s disease
E. Hodgkin’s disease

Correct Answer: A

A young man in his twenties sustains a punch to the left side of his face and develops a black eye. He complains of numbness of his left cheek and upper teeth on that side.
Which nerve has been damaged?

A. Mental nerve
B. Infraorbital nerve
C. Supratrochlear nerve
D. Zygomatic branch of the facial nerve
E. Chorda tympani

Correct Answer: B

An 87-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe pain in his right leg. The pain came on suddenly an hour ago, after walking to his kitchen, and is worst below the knee. He denies any falls or trauma to his leg. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, for which he takes rivaroxaban. On examination, his right leg below the knee is pale in colour. It is cold to touch, with a lack of sensation and absent dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. Sensation is normal, and pulses are present on the left leg.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Intermittent claudication
B. Peripheral neuropathy
C. Acute limb ischaemia
D. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
E. Compartment syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man with a past medical history of hypercholesterolaemia and psoriasis is admitted to the hospital following an episode of central crushing chest pain. This was subsequently diagnosed as a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and appropriately treated. During admission, he experienced a flare-up of his psoriasis.
Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause the flare-up of his psoriasis?

A. Beta blockers
B. Clopidogrel
C. Glyceryl trinitrate spray
D. Low-molecular-weight heparin
E. Statins

Correct Answer: A
