A 23-year-old woman presents complaining of severe itching, which is mainly affecting her groin. The problem has been worsening over the past two to three weeks and is now unbearable. She admits to having slept with a new partner a few weeks before she noticed the problem.
You notice an erythematous, papular rash affecting the web spaces on the hands. She also has erythematous papules and scratch marks around the groin in particular.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 320 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 80 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
You draw on the web spaces between her fingers with a felt-tip. Rubbing off the excess reveals a number of burrows.
Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atopic dermatitis
B. Sarcoptes scabiei hominis infection
C. Folliculitis
D. Erythema infectiosum infection
E. Keratosis pilaris infection

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old man, complaining of altered mood and behaviour that had been progressing for the past 7 years, is brought to the clinic by his daughter. The daughter also mentions that her grandfather passed away from Alzheimer’s disease at the age of 51. History reveals recent aphasia, disorientation and memory loss. The patient dies a few weeks later. A biopsy of his brain revealed cortical atrophy with widening of the cerebral sulci.
Which of the following mechanisms most likely contributed to the onset of the patient’s condition?

A. SORL1 protein deficiency
B. α-secretase deficiency
C. Mutations in amyloid precursor protein
D. Hyper-phosphorylation of tau protein
E. Increased accumulation of amyloid light protein

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old woman, who was recently diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), has had significant problems with persistent hirsutism and acne since being a teenager. She reports this is now affecting her self-esteem and she has not seen improvement with over-the-counter acne regimes.
When questioned about her menstrual cycles, she reports these are still irregular. She does not wish to conceive at present.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?

A. Clomifene citrate
B. Co-cyprindiol
C. Desogestrel
D. Isotretinoin
E. Topical retinoid

Correct Answer: B

A healthy baby is born at term but, at 1 minute, demonstrates no respiratory effort. The baby’s heart rate is over 100 bpm, but the skin colour is blue and the baby is not moving.
After drying and covering the baby, what is the most appropriate action to take?

A. Suction to airways
B. Cardiac massage
C. Wrap the baby tightly in a towel
D. Give five breaths of air via a face mask
E. Intubate the baby

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old man comes in after being found unconscious. He smells strongly of alcohol.
When considering withdrawal from this substance, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Flumazenil is routinely used as part of the detoxification process
B. Seizures are rare
C. Visual hallucinations suggest a coexisting psychiatric disorder
D. Hypophosphataemia is commonly seen
E. All patients who have a seizure should be started on an antiepileptic

Correct Answer: D

A 16-year-old girl (who has been recently diagnosed with anorexia nervosa) exercises regularly. During one period of exercise, she becomes very light-headed. Several minutes later, she breaks into a sweat and develops palpitations. A friend takes her to an Emergency Department where a serum glucose of 2.2 mmol/l is demonstrated. The patient is given a soft drink to sip and feels better half an hour later.
Which of the following hormones most likely triggered the sweating and palpitations the patient experienced?

A. Calcitonin
B. Insulin
C. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
D. Epinephrine
E. Thyroxine

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old woman has been referred by her general practitioner (GP), as she is passing an unusually large volume of urine. She complains that she is continuously thirsty.
The investigations included the following results:
Random plasma:
Investigation Result
Sodium (Na+) 155 mmol/l
Osmolality 300mOsmol/kg
Glucose 4.5 mmol/l
Urine:
Investigation Result
Osmolality 90mOsmol/kg
Glucose 0.1 mmol/l
In healthy patients, the urine : plasma osmolality ratio is > 2.
Water deprivation test:

After 6.5 h of fluid deprivation, the patient’s weight had dropped by >3% and the serum osmolality was 310 mOsmol/kg. Urine osmolality at this stage was 210 mOsmol/kg. The patient was then given desmopressin intramuscularly (im) and allowed to drink. The urine osmolality increased to 700 mOsmol/kg and her plasma osmolality was 292 mOsmol/kg.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Diabetes mellitus
B. A pituitary tumour
C. Chronic renal disease
D. Lithium therapy
E. Primary polydipsia

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old man has had a mitral valve repair and is having a protracted post-operative course on the cardiac intensive care unit. To help manage his case, a pulmonary artery catheter is inserted.
Which of the following is a derived measurement provided by the pulmonary artery catheter?

A. Pulmonary artery wedge pressure
B. Central venous saturations
C. Cardiac output
D. Left atrial pressure
E. Right ventricular pressure

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old female medical student consults her general practitioner as she is gaining weight and suffering from excessive hair on the face and over the upper chest. She only tends to have a period once every 2 or 3 months. On examination, she has excessive facial and body hair and acne and is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 28. Testosterone level is elevated at 3.5 nmol/l, and the luteinising hormone (LH) : follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio is also elevated.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Androgen-secreting tumour
B. Simple obesity
C. Cushing syndrome
D. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
E. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 23-old-nursery nurse who works at a holiday resort in Tunisia has flown back to visit her doctor because she feels unwell. She has had increasing nausea and lethargy and noticed that her urine had darkened a few days ago, and now her stools are pale. Other history of note is that she is suffering from severe itching. On examination she is pyrexial with a temperature of 38.1°C, jaundiced and there are scratch marks on her skin.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 170 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Prothrombin Test (PT) 17.1 s 10.6–14.9 s
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 48 mm/hr 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 795 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 100 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 90 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Anti hepatitis A IgM markedly elevated
Which of the following most accurately reflects the prognosis for this woman?

A. She has a chance of progression to cirrhosis of approximately 70%
B. She has a chance of progression to cirrhosis of approximately 0%
C. She has a chance of progression to cirrhosis of approximately 50%
D. She has a chance of progression to cirrhosis of approximately 90%
E. She has a chance of progression to cirrhosis of approximately 10%

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman is investigated by her general practitioner for potential problems in her hypothalamic–pituitary–thyroid axis. The following results were obtained:
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) <0.1 mu/l (0.4–4.0 mu/l)
fT4 32 pmol/l (9.0–26.0 pmol/l)
fT3 12 pmol/l (3.0–9.0 pmol/l)
These results are consistent with the diagnosis of which of the following?

A. Graves’ disease
B. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
C. Post-thyroidectomy
D. Sick euthyroidism
E. Early treatment of hyperthyroidism

Correct Answer: A

A student is enquiring about the power of a statistical test.
Which statement best describes the power of a statistical test?

A. The probability of a type 1 error
B. The probability of a type 2 error
C. The probability of not committing a type 2 error
D. The probability of not committing a type 1 error
E. The p-value

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old man with a long history of sarcoidosis presents for review. He has been intermittently treated with varying doses of oral prednisolone and chloroquine. On this occasion, he complains of drooping and weakness affecting the left-hand side of his face, blurred vision, thirst and polyuria. On examination, he has a left facial nerve palsy.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 149 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 15.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 195 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Ca2+ corrected 2.21 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Random glucose 5.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 36 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Which of the following diagnoses fit best with this clinical picture?

A. Bacterial meningitis
B. Bell’s palsy
C. Viral meningitis
D. Neurosarcoidosis
E. Intracerebral abscess

Correct Answer: D

A 44-year-old man is rescued from the water onto the beach by lifeguards after he was witnessed to have been struggling while swimming in heavy currents. He was submerged for five minutes before being rescued. You happen to be a bystander on the beach and assist in the resuscitation effort, while awaiting the ambulance. He is unresponsive and not breathing. You open his airway.
What is the most appropriate next step in the resuscitation of this man?

A. Begin continuous chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute
B. Give five rescue breaths before commencing chest compressions
C. Give 30 chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute and two rescue breaths
D. Give two rescue breaths, followed by 30 chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute
E. Give continuous rescue breaths until the ambulance arrives

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old woman is suffering from nausea associated with her chemotherapy treatment. She received an intravenous injection of an antiemetic 4 h ago and now is experiencing difficulty speaking and controlling her facial muscles. When you review her, her eyes are deviated up and outwards and she is unable to look directly at you and makes strange faces.
Which of the following antiemetic medications is likely to have caused this reaction?

A. Ondansetron
B. Dexamethasone
C. Megestrol
D. Metoclopramide
E. Trazodone

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old student presents to the Emergency Department with confusion and recurring fevers. He describes a flu-like illness in recent days, with myalgia and rigors every two days. He has previously been well, other than an episode of suspected malaria on a gap year in Brazil two years ago, which was felt to be successfully treated. He has not been abroad since. On examination, he has splenomegaly, scleral icterus and a temperature of 39.1°C. Initial investigations are detailed below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 95 g/l 135–175 g/l
White Cell Count (WCC) 14 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 100 × 109 150–450 × 109/l
Blood film Awaited
Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A. Dengue virus
B. Plasmodium falciparum
C. Plasmodium malariae
D. Plasmodium vivax
E. Yellow fever virus

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old man in hospital with terminal cancer has suddenly deteriorated over the last week. He can no longer communicate his decisions with regard to his health care. He had previously made an advanced decision that stated he did not want to be put on a ventilator.
In which one of the following scenarios would the advanced decision be considered valid?

A. He was 17 when he made the advanced decision
B. His lasting power of attorney (LPA) (created after his advanced decision) consents to artificial ventilation on his behalf
C. It was signed by him, but not witnessed
D. The decision was communicated verbally only
E. The decision may stand valid even if not made via a solicitor

Correct Answer: E

A General Practitioner (GP) sees a 26-month-old girl who is failing to thrive. The GP carries out some tests and discovers antibody to tissue transglutaminase in the girl’s plasma.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Coeliac disease
B. Cystic fibrosis
C. Ulcerative colitis
D. Crohn’s
E. Phenylketonuria

Correct Answer: A

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a multisystem autoimmune disease. It is associated with many defects in the immune system, which are genetically determined and triggered by environmental factors.
Which one of the following chromosomal anomalies has the highest incidence of SLE?

A. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)
B. Fragile X syndrome
C. 47,XXY (Klinefelter’s syndrome)
D. Bloom syndrome
E. Trisomy 18 (Edwards’ syndrome)

Correct Answer: C

A newborn baby is found to have absent femoral pulses and a systolic ejection murmur over the left side of his chest and back upon his routine newborn examination. His brachial pulses are strong. He appears pale and is tachypnoeic. He has not managed to take much milk from his mother’s breast, as he becomes distressed.
Which of the following statements about his condition is true?

A. Always presents in first few days of life if not diagnosed antenatally
B. Following repair of the defect, there are rarely any long-term complications
C. If diagnosed antenatally, the baby should be given a prostaglandin inhibitor after birth to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus
D. May be treated by balloon angioplasty with or without stenting
E. Must be treated by reconstructive surgery

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old man presents to the Renal Clinic with haematuria, frequency and urgency. The patient also has a history of intermittent haemoptysis and chest pain of moderate intensity. A previous chest X-ray had demonstrated multiple opacities. In addition, the patient has chronic cold-like nasal symptoms and recurrent epistaxis. Physical examination shows a saddle-shaped nose due to perforation of the nasal septum. He also complains of difficulty in hearing. Renal biopsy demonstrates a focal necrotising glomerulonephritis with crescent formation.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
B. Aspergillosis
C. Renal carcinoma with lung metastasis
D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman, who is normally fit and well, presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of a red, watery eye that is only mildly tender on palpation over the redness. She had initially gone to her General Practitioner (GP) and has been given chloramphenicol ointment to apply to her eyes four times daily. However, she found no improvement to her red eye.
On examination, her visual acuities are 6/6 in both eyes. Her affected eye shows a red patch on the lateral side of the eyeball. By administering phenylephrine 10% eye drops, the redness seemed to have improved.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Conjunctivitis
B. Episcleritis
C. Iritis
D. Keratitis
E. Scleritis

Correct Answer: B

A 73-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with vague, crampy central abdominal ‘discomfort’ for the last three days. He was recently prescribed codeine phosphate for knee pain, which is secondary to osteoarthritis. He has never had this type of abdominal discomfort before. He last moved his bowels three days ago but denies nausea and vomiting. His past medical history is significant for hypertension. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and denies any history of alcohol use. He has had no previous surgery.
His physical examination is normal. His observations and blood test results are shown below.
Temperature 36.3°C
Blood pressure 145/88 mmHg
Respiratory rate 15 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation (SpO2) 99% (room air)
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 5.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 1.5 mg/dl 0–10 mg/l
Total bilirubin 5.0 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
The Emergency doctor performs an abdominal ultrasound to examine for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. During this process, he also performs an ultrasound scan of the right upper quadrant, which shows several gallstones in a thin-walled gall bladder. The abdominal aorta is visualised and has a diameter of 2.3 cm. The patient’s abdominal pain is thought to be due to constipation.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s gallstones?

A. Elective cholecystectomy
B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C. Immediate cholecystectomy
D. No intervention required
E. Percutaneous cholecystectomy

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old business man recently returned from a work conference in Turkey, where he spent a lot of his time in air-conditioned conference rooms. He has a dry cough and a respiratory rate of 24. He also reports multiple episodes of vomiting and loose stools.
What is the most likely causative organism of this patient symptom?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Pneumocystis jiroveci
C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
D. Mycoplasma
E. Legionella

Correct Answer: E

Mrs Smith is an 89-year-old lady who has been admitted with a urinary tract infection. She has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), for which she takes inhalers. Her abbreviated mental test score (AMTS) was 8/10 on admission. A midstream urine sample was sent for microbiology and the report indicates a pure growth of Escherichia coli sensitive to trimethoprim and co-amoxiclav. After receiving 48 hours of intravenous co-amoxiclav, she is now on appropriate oral antibiotic therapy.
You are called to the ward at 0100 h as Mrs Smith is increasingly agitated and confused. She now has an AMTS of 2/10 and is refusing to stay in bed. Her vital signs are normal, and respiratory, cardiovascular, abdominal and neurological examinations reveal some fine crepitations at both lung bases, but no other abnormality. Her Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) is 14.
What is the most appropriate next management option?

A. Arrange an urgent computed tomography (CT) head
B. Prescribe haloperidol 1 mg intramuscular (im) to help Mrs Smith to settle
C. Advise nursing in a well-lit environment with frequent reassurance and reorientation
D. Prescribe lorazepam 0.5 mg orally (po) to help Mrs Smith settle
E. Arrange a full septic screen, including chest X-ray, repeat urinalysis, inflammatory markers and blood cultures

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man presents to the General Practice (GP) Surgery with complaints of an inability to maintain an erection during sexual intercourse. He is not known to have any medical co-morbidities and says he does not have any stress or difficulties in his relationship.
On examination, he has loss of proprioception in his bilateral toes. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are unremarkable.
Physical examination, including genital examination is unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate first-line investigation for this patient?

A. Fasting blood sugar
B. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
C. Semen analysis
D. Serum oestrogen and progesterone levels
E. Ultrasound of testes

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old man goes to see his general practitioner (GP) with a 2-day history of rectal bleeding, which is worse after passing stools. He has recently increased his fibre intake, but it is still very difficult to pass stools, as defecation causes severe pain, lasting for hours. You attempt a digital rectal examination (DRE) but it could not be performed due to severe pain.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Fistula in ano
B. Anal carcinoma
C. Rectal prolapse
D. Haemorrhoids
E. Anal fissure

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP), accompanied by her husband, as she is becoming more forgetful. She used to manage her own financial matters but now forgets to pay her utility bills on time. There have been several occasions where she has left the taps running, resulting in flooding of her kitchen. She becomes agitated when confronted about these issues.
Her laboratory studies are normal for vitamin B12, folate, thyroid levels and electrolytes. Her depression screen is negative. Her Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is 21/30, and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is significant for generalised brain atrophy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Donepezil
B. Memantine
C. Risperidone
D. Tacrine
E. Trazadone

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with blood in his urine and loin pain. He has also been feeling fatigued in recent weeks and has lost approximately 5 kg of weight unintentionally in the past three weeks. He has a history of hypertension and his body mass index (BMI) is 35 kg/m2. You suspect the underlying cause of his symptoms could be renal cancer.
What type of kidney tumour is this most likely to be?

A. Angiomyolipoma
B. Clear cell carcinoma
C. Sarcoma
D. Transitional cell carcinoma
E. Wilms’ tumour

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old actress presents to the Emergency Department with her third episode of epistaxis in a 24-h period. On each occasion, the nosebleeds stopped with pressure applied just below the nasal bridge, but the most recent bleed went on for an hour. She has asthma, for which she takes salbutamol on an ‘as-required’ basis. She also admits to drinking 20–30 units of alcohol each week and describes herself as a ‘social smoker’. There is no history of trauma. She is desperate for the problem to be treated, as she is appearing in a theatrical production the following evening.
On examination, she looks well and is not pale, and her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits. She is peripherally well perfused. On inspection of the nasal vestibule, there are prominent blood vessels visible on the left side of the nasal septum, with a small amount of clotted blood also present.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Check full blood count and liver function tests, and send a clotting screen
B. Insert a nasal tampon and refer to the ear, nose and throat (ENT) acute clinic
C. Give advice on first aid measures and reassure her that the problem is normally self limiting
D. Cauterise the bleeding point using silver nitrate
E. Obtain intravenous access; check blood count and liver function tests, and send a clotting screen; arrange a group and save, and admit under the ENT team

Correct Answer: D

A 999 call is received regarding a 16-year-old boy with a history of eczema and asthma who experienced sudden breathlessness, nausea and swelling of the face after eating a chicken skewer at a party. Friends report his skin is covered in raised red bumps and his lips are turning blue.
Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management of this patient?

A. Intramuscular (IM) adrenaline 0.5 mg (1 : 1000)
B. Salbutamol
C. Intravenous (IV) chlorphenamine in 0.9% saline (500 ml)
D. IV adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1 : 10 000
E. Reassurance and breathing exercises

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man is an in-patient on a medical ward. The medical team worry that he has mental health problems in addition to the serious medical problems that require imminent treatment. The patient is refusing treatment and wants to go home. They suspect he is mentally impaired and unable to make a decision.
In England and Wales, under which Act of the Mental Health Act (MHA) can they detain this gentleman?

A. Section 2
B. Section 3
C. Section 5 (2)
D. Section 135
E. Section 136

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman is being investigated by her general practitioner for potential problems in her hypothalamic–pituitary–thyroid axis. The following results were obtained:
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 5.2 mu/l (0.4–4.0 mu/l)
fT4 8.0 pmol/l (9.0–26.0 pmol/l)
fT3 3.5 pmol/l (3.0–9.0 pmol/l)
These results are consistent with the diagnosis of which of the following?

A. Hyperthyroidism
B. Hypothyroidism
C. Pituitary TSH-secreting tumour
D. Subclinical hypothyroidism
E. Thyroid hormone resistance

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old woman who has had severe itching for three weeks presents to your clinic. She has been taking over-the-counter anti-itching preparations, with little benefit. She has malaise, fatigue and occasional nausea, but denies abdominal pain, change in bowel habit or weight loss. She had been diagnosed with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and hypothyroidism two years earlier and was receiving levothyroxine. Since then, her follow-up thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) measurements were within normal limit. She also had mild microcytic anaemia with high red blood cell distribution width. Family history is remarkable for type II diabetes in her mother and one of her siblings. On examination, vital signs are normal. There is a mild scleral icterus. Abdomen is soft and non-tender without shifting dullness. Investigations revealed the following results:
Investigation Result Normal Range
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 125 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 156 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 879 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Total bilirubin 20.5 μmol/l 2–17 μmol/l
Direct bilirubin 10.3 μmol/l 2–17 μmol/l
Cholesterol 7.3 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
Triglyceride 3.6 mmol/l 0–1.5 mmol/l
Albumin 42 g/l 35–55 g/l
Prothrombin Test (PT) 13 s 11–15 s
Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 30 s 30–45 s
International normalised ratio (INR) 1.08 0.9-1.1
ANA + (weakly positive); anti-TPO antibody 305 iu/ml (highly raised); anti-mitochondrial antibody positive; anti-smooth muscle antibody negative; anti-LKM-1 antibody negative; anti-HBs antibody 70 iu/l; HBs antigen negative; anti-HBC antibody negative.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Primary sclerosing cholangitis
B. Addison’s disease
C. Autoimmune hepatitis
D. Chronic viral hepatitis
E. Primary biliary cholangitis

Correct Answer: E

A 38-year-old man with a known history of severe depression has been in hospital for the past year. He was diagnosed with depression at the age of 25 and has been on antidepressants since. He has had multiple self-harm and suicide attempts in the past. For the past year, he has been receiving treatment in hospital and has been making some progress with regard to his mental health. He is not happy to be in hospital, but the doctors thought that it was in his best interests to keep him in hospital for treatment. He has been under a Section which allowed him to be kept in hospital for six months. At the end of the first six months, the doctors applied for a second time for him to be kept for another six months, as they feel he is not yet fit for discharge.
For how long can the relevant Section be renewed for this patient for the third time?

A. Six months
B. 28 days
C. Three months
D. One year
E. Two years

Correct Answer: D

A 12-year-old girl became acutely ill last week with vomiting, high fevers (maximum temperature of 39.5 °C) and weakness. Her mother took the girl to the general practitioner (GP) on day two of the illness, and he suggested she had gastroenteritis and that it should resolve itself in a week. However, the girl continues to be very ill and has now developed a non-blanching petechial rash on her abdomen.
Blood tests show many blasts in the periphery, low platelets and severe anaemia.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute myeloblastic leukemia
B. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia
E. Hairy cell leukemia

Correct Answer: B

Mr Williams, an 86-year-old retired dock worker, with a history of hypertension and mitral valve replacement, presented to his general practitioner with symptoms of fever, night sweats and fatigue. Examination of his hands showed loss of angle between the nail fold and nail plate, a bulbous fingertip and painful, erythematous nodules present on both hands.
What is the most likely cause of these nail changes?

A. Inflammatory bowel disease
B. Infective endocarditis
C. Pulmonary fibrosis
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: B

Which of the following is associated with abnormal production of antibodies that activate complement?

A. X-linked agammaglobulinaemia
B. Common variable hypogammaglobulinaemia
C. Selective IgA deficiency
D. Goodpasture syndrome
E. Type 1 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old woman had a mammogram that revealed a 2-cm lump in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast.
If the primary tumour had metastasised to a regional lymph node, which one of the following would be the most likely location of the metastatic cells?

A. Cervical
B. Axillary
C. Hilar
D. Mediastinal
E. Coeliac

Correct Answer: B

You are fast-bleeped to the ward where you find a 56-year-old woman in ventricular tachycardia. She had a witnessed syncopal episode while walking to the toilet with nursing staff and currently has a blood pressure of 85/56 mmHg. She is orientated to time, place and person but is complaining of feeling light-headed.
How would you manage this patient’s ventricular tachycardia?

A. Amiodarone 300 mg loading dose intravenously (iv), followed by 900 mg over 24 hours
B. Synchronised direct current (DC) cardioversion
C. Unsynchronised DC cardioversion
D. Digoxin 500 micrograms iv loading dose
E. Metoprolol 5 mg iv

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old woman is two days post-operative, following a Hartmann’s procedure for bowel cancer. Her haemoglobin levels had dropped to 70 g/l, and as a result, she was started on a blood transfusion 12 hours ago. You are asked to review the patient, as she has suddenly become very agitated, pyrexial and hypotensive, with chest pain.
Which of the following transfusion reactions is most likely to be occurring in this patient?

A. Iron overload
B. Hepatitis B infection
C. Acute haemolytic reaction
D. Graft-versus-host disease (GvHD)
E. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old boy presents with fevers and headache. His father has been admitted to hospital several times in the past with infections. He has a family history of systemic lupus erythematosus in a paternal uncle.
Which one of the following recurrent infections is a feature of complement deficiency?

A. Herpes simplex virus
B. Mycoplasma pneumoniae
C. Neisseria meningitides
D. Giardia lamblia
E. Pneumocystis jiroveci

Correct Answer: C

While working in the haematology outpatient clinic, you are discussing sickle cell disease with your consultant having just seen a patient with known sickle cell anaemia.
Which of the following is the inheritance pattern for sickle cell disease?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Mitochondrial inheritance
C. Autosomal recessive
D. No inheritance pattern is known
E. X-linked recessive

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old girl with a 9-year history of type I diabetes self presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with a 24-hour history of vomiting. She tested her glucose and ketones at home and they were both high, glucose 32mmol/L, ketones 4 mmol/L, so she attended the ED. She admits to omitting her insulin frequently. She appears dehydrated, has ketotic fetor, BP 110/74 mmHg, pulse 110 beats per minute, temp 36.9 degrees, oxygen saturations 99% on room air. Clinical examination is otherwise normal. The following are her laboratory investigations:
Test Result Normal range
pH 7.2 7.35–7.45
Ketones 4 mmol/l < 0.6 mmol/l
Glucose 29 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Bicarbonate 12 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Base excess -4 mEq/l −2 to +2 mEq/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 2 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Which of the following are required to make a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis?

A. pH<7.35
B. pH > 7.35
C. Glucose < 11 mmol/l
D. Bicarbonate level > 20 mmol/l
E. Anion gap < 16

Correct Answer: A

A 31-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department at midnight with severe, sudden-onset lower abdominal pain. The pain is sharp and unrelenting, with an intensity of 10/10, and is radiating to her lower back. She cannot lie down quietly because of pain. She has nausea but has not vomited. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago and was normal. Her menses are always regular.
On examination: blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, pulse 110 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, temperature 37.3 °C. There is a periumbilical and right lower quadrant tenderness on palpation. On abdominal ultrasound, a fair amount of free pelvic fluid is noted.
What is the most likely injured organ/structure in this patient?

A. Appendix
B. Ureter
C. Fallopian tube
D. Ovary
E. Rectum

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old man suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with severe dyspnoea, having been getting these attacks more frequently recently. However, he can tolerate 3 hours of physical therapy on the ward. On testing, we find a forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV1) of <25% post-bronchodilator therapy. The man is keen to get the best possible treatment and wants to discuss choices for a lung transplant. Investigations reveal:
Investigation Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 60 g/l 135–175 g/l
WCC 3.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelet count 80 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Calcium 2.50 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Hepatitis B and C markers Negative
Which of the following conditions preclude his chances of getting a lung transplant in future?

A. His age
B. His FEV1
C. The haematology picture
D. Both his age and the haematology picture
E. COPD is not an indication for lung transplant

Correct Answer: D

An 80-year-old man has been admitted to the Elderly Care Ward following a fall. He is clinically euvolaemic and does not take diuretics. He is hyponatraemic with the following paired investigation results
Serum Electrolytes
Investigation Result Normal value
Creatinine 97 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urea 3.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Sodium 124 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Osmolality 200 mmol/l 275-295 mmol/l
Urine Biochemistry
Sodium 32 mmol/l < 20 mmol/l
Osmolality 420 mOsm/l < 100 mOsm/l
Select the most likely diagnosis from the list below:

A. Addison's disease
B. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic secretion (SIADH)
C. Viral gastroenteritis
D. Psychogenic polydipsia
E. Diabetes insipidus

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man with a background of diabetes is five days post-open umbilical hernia repair. He is complaining of mild central abdominal pain and feeling generally unwell. On examination of the wound, the area surrounding it appears erythematous with localised tenderness. Although there is purulent discharge from the wound, no dehiscence is noted.
Observations:
Blood pressure 130/70 mmHg
Heart rate 110 bpm
Respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute
Oxygen saturations 98% on room air
Temperature 38.2 °C
Based on the likely diagnosis, which is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

A. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
B. Intravenous (iv) fluids and analgesia
C. Resuturing of the wound
D. Taking a wound swab and re-dressing the wound
E. Wound debridement

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old woman is seen in the Orthopaedic Clinic with progressive neck pain that intermittently radiates down the left arm into the hand. She describes the pain as a sharp stabbing pain, which is associated with pins and needles in the hand. She has a past medical history of hypertension and peptic ulceration. On examination, she has poor neck mobility, with some crepitus. There is normal power and sensation, with normal reflexes. She is diagnosed with cervical spondylosis.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Foraminectomy
B. Laminectomy
C. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories
D. Physiotherapy
E. Rigid neck collar

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman visits her general practitioner (GP) because of blurry vision and because her eyelids ‘feel heavy’. She is an office assistant at a large medical practice and says that it has become increasingly difficult for her to read documents, especially towards the end of the day.
What is the most likely underlying pathogenesis of this patient’s symptoms?

A. Type I hypersensitivity
B. Type II non-cytotoxic hypersensitivity
C. Type II cytotoxic hypersensitivity
D. Type III hypersensitivity
E. Type IV hypersensitivity

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old woman, a known type 1 diabetic, attended the GP Surgery complaining of reduction in her vision. Her vision is 6/18 in the right, 6/6 in the left.
You were asked by your GP placement supervisor to perform a dilated direct fundoscopy on her eyes. You found some exudates forming a ring around a dot haemorrhage near the fovea.
What is the first-line management for this eye condition?

A. Focal laser photocoagulation
B. Community diabetic eye screening
C. Anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) intravitreal injection
D. Increase daily insulin dose
E. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

Correct Answer: C

An 83-year-old woman is admitted after a fall. On clinical examination, she is unkempt and disorientated. She has had recurrent admissions after falls and recurring infections. She has a background history of severe dementia and lives alone. This patient has previously refused assistance at home and has refused to move to a care home. Her son is very concerned about her welfare and feels she can no longer live safely at home.
Which legal Act will be considered by the decision about whether this patient will move to a care home?

A. Equality Act
B. Health and Social Care Act
C. Mental Health Act
D. Mental Capacity Act
E. Social Value Act

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man, following a successful renal transplant, performed two months ago, presents to the Emergency Department with clinical symptoms of fever and flank pain. Tests show elevations in serum creatinine and donor-specific human leukocyte antigen (HLA) alloantibodies. A renal biopsy was performed. Histology showed microvascular endothelial cell injury and positive C4d staining.
What is the appropriate next line of management?

A. Belatacept
B. Mycophenolate
C. Plasmapheresis and rabbit anti-thymocyte globulin (rATG)-thymoglobulin
D. Prednisone
E. Tacrolimus

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman is brought to the hospital by her parents after she used her father’s credit card excessively, claiming that she is here to save poor people in her community. She claims she is the only one who can save them and will do absolutely anything for them. She is very agitated, and the doctor cannot engage with her to obtain a history. Her mother confirms that she has a known diagnosis of bipolar disorder and is currently on lithium. For the past few days, the patient has not had much sleep and has been awake all night with her plans to save the poor people. There is no evidence that she has taken any overdose, but her mother says that she was out camping with her friends last week and may not have taken her medication. The doctor on call writes a report to the hospital manager and decides to keep the patient in hospital under a Section until tomorrow morning when an approved mental health professional can assess the patient.
For how long can the patient be kept under the Section used?

A. Six months
B. 28 days
C. 72 hours
D. Six hours
E. One year

Correct Answer: C

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his mother following a 2-day history of a non-productive cough. His mother denies any recent viral illness.
On examination, the patient has no accessory muscle usage and is afebrile. On auscultation, he is noted to have a right-sided wheeze with no crepitations. The patient has been developing normally and has never had any respiratory problems before. He has no significant past medical or family history. His immunisation records are up to date.
What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A. Bronchiolitis
B. Pneumonia
C. Inhaled foreign body
D. Asthma
E. Croup

Correct Answer: C

A 67-year-old woman takes medication for hypertension and raised cholesterol. At her annual check-up, she reports that she is feeling well. Among the results of her blood tests are the following: serum calcium 2.90 mmol/l (2.1–2.8 mmol/l), serum phosphate 0.80 mmol/l (1.0–1.5 mmol/l) and alkaline phosphatase 215 iu/l (53–128 iu/l).
Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these results in this woman?

A. Occult malignancy
B. Paget's disease of bone
C. Primary hyperparathyroidism
D. Thyrotoxicosis
E. Phaeochromocytoma

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old head trauma patient who is in Critical Care is not managing to eat enough calories, as he has bilateral limb fractures that are non-weight-bearing and previous blunt trauma to the chest causing multiple rib fractures. The decision to give supplemental feeding through a nasogastric (NG) tube is made. The senior house officer inserts the NG tube correctly but asks their senior how they should best check that the NG tube is in place.
How should the correct placement of the NG tube be confirmed?

A. Commence NG feed and monitor oxygen saturations
B. Aspirate and if the aspirate looks like stomach contents, then it is confirmed
C. Aspirate and test pH. If pH is above 2, then it is inserted correctly
D. Perform a chest X-ray (CXR) and if not in the lung field, then correct placement
E. Perform a CXR and look for midline descent to below the diaphragm before crossing to the patient’s left-hand side in the stomach.

Correct Answer: E

This 40-year-old woman has the skin changes visible in this picture. She also has skin changes in her hands.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which of the following conditions is also likely to be present in this patient?

A. Oesophageal carcinoma
B. Hepatomegaly
C. Pregnancy
D. Raynaud’s phenomenon
E. Recurrent epistaxis

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man was rushed to the Emergency Department after a road traffic collision. On examination in the Emergency Department, he has no signs of external bleeding, but his blood pressure is 90/40 mmHg and his heart rate is 120 bpm. He has distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds.
Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on an echocardiogram?

A. Pneumothorax
B. Haemothorax
C. Mitral regurgitation
D. Pericardial effusion
E. Pleural effusion

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old male is referred to the medical assessment unit with a 6-week history of increasing frequency of diarrhoea and abdominal pain. The patient is now opening his bowels up to eight times a day, and he is also needing to get up during the night to pass motions. He describes the stool as watery, with some mucus and blood. He is also suffering with intermittent cramping abdominal pain. He has had no recent foreign travel, and no other contacts have been unwell with similar symptoms. He has lost almost 6 kg in weight. He has no other past medical history of note.
Inflammatory bowel disease is high on the list of differentials.
Which one of the following is most commonly associated with Ulcerative colitis (UC)?

A. Anal fistulae
B. Rectal involvement
C. Transmural inflammation
D. Duodenal involvement
E. Anal abscess formation

Correct Answer: B

A 20-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after complaining of feeling short of breath. On examination, he is tachypnoeic. Auscultation of the chest reveals clear lungs bilaterally. An arterial blood gas demonstrates a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 8.7 kPa.
The patient has an alveolar PaO2 of 13.3 kPa, and supplemental oxygen does not improve the PaO2 in his blood,
Which of the following processes is likely causing his hypoxaemia?

A. Hypoventilation
B. Ventilation-perfusion mismatch
C. Low-inspired oxygen
D. Complete right-to-left shunt
E. Partial diffusion abnormality

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to place a catheter in a patient for urinary retention. You select a 24-Fr catheter.
Which of the following is the most accurate description of the size of this catheter?

A. The external circumference of the catheter is approximately 24mm
B. The outer diameter of the catheter is approximately 24mm
C. The length of the catheter is approximately 24 mm
D. The size of the internal drainage canal of the catheter is approximately 24mm
E. The length of the catheter is 24cm

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of an increasingly painful and swollen right eye. He complains of blurring of vision and pain, especially with eye movements.
On examination, visual acuity is 6/18 in the right and 6/6 in the left. The periorbital area of the right eye is very swollen and erythematous. The eye itself is red and proptosed. The conjunctiva is chemosed. Eye movements in the right eye are quite restricted in all directions. There is relative afferent pupillary defect on the right. Fundoscopy shows a swollen optic disc in the right eye. Computed tomography (CT) scan shows some opacities in the ethmoid sinuses.
Vital observations are as follows:
Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg
Heart rate 75 bpm
Respiratory rate 18 per minute
Oxygen saturation 98% on air
Temperature 37.9 °C
What is the definitive treatment for this eye problem?

A. Cefuroxime intravenously (IV)
B. Cefuroxime and metronidazole IV
C. Co-amoxiclav IV
D. Drainage of the ethmoid sinuses
E. Tazocin® IV

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman who has had fever, anorexia and right upper quadrant pain for 3 days is brought to the Emergency Department. She is lethargic and disoriented with regard to time and place. On examination, there is marked abdominal tenderness, especially on palpation of the right upper quadrant.
What is the most likely bacterial cause of her infection?

A. Escherichia
B. Bacteroides
C. Enterococcus
D. Pseudomonas
E. Proteus

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) with complaints of not having moved her bowels for the last three days. The patient typically moves her bowels every morning. She denies vomiting or nausea and has been passing flatus. The patient was prescribed a variety of painkillers by a home doctor service for right knee pain, from which she has been suffering for the last two weeks. The patient has known severe degeneration of her right knee and is awaiting an elective right-sided total knee replacement. She has a past medical history of hypertension, which she controls with lifestyle measures. A rectal examination reveals no faecal impaction.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s constipation?

A. Ispaghula husk
B. Loperamide
C. Metoclopramide
D. Phosphate enema
E. Senna

Correct Answer: E

A 23-year-old with cystic fibrosis was examined for cor pulmonale for suitability for a cadaveric double-lung transplant.
What is the surface anatomical landmark for detecting right ventricular hypertrophy?

A. Second intercostal space, left parasternal area
B. Second intercostal space, right parasternal area
C. Fourth intercostal space, left parasternal area
D. Fourth intercostal space, right parasternal area
E. Fifth intercostal space, mid-clavicular line

Correct Answer: C

After a game of squash, a 32-year-old woman complains of pain at the lateral aspect of her right elbow which radiates down the back of the forearm. She is diagnosed as having tennis elbow, epicondylitis of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
Which one of the following muscles has an attachment at this site?

A. Coracobrachialis
B. Extensor digitorum
C. Flexor carpi radialis
D. Pronator teres
E. Triceps

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old woman presents to the clinic with left upper-lobe cavitating consolidation and sputum samples confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is fully sensitive. There is no previous history of treatment for tuberculosis (TB).
Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic regimen?

A. Rifampicin and clarithromycin for six months
B. Rifampicin and ethambutol for six months
C. Rifampicin/isoniazid/pyrazinamide/ethambutol for two months, then rifampicin/isoniazid for four months
D. Rifampicin/isoniazid/pyrazinamide for four months
E. Rifampicin for 12 months

Correct Answer: C

A 31-year-old woman who is 17 weeks pregnant presents to the Emergency Department with intermittent right upper quadrant pain (RUQ) and nausea. She says there have been two episodes in the past fortnight, when she has eaten a takeaway for dinner. This is her first pregnancy. On examination, she is tender to palpation in the RUQ. She has a temperature of 37.6 °C. The body mass index (BMI) before pregnancy was estimated at 29.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.3 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 85 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Bilirubin 19 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 54 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 295 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Ultrasound scan – Multiple stones seen within the gall bladder, but normal-sized common bile duct (CBD)
Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this case?

A. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
B. Open cholecystectomy
C. ERCP
D. Conservative management with hydration and antibiotics
E. Discharge with advice

Correct Answer: D

A 39-year-old woman, G1P0, presents with constant pelvic pain at 33 weeks’ gestation. The pain started in early morning and has an intensity of 9/10. There is frequent, intermittent uterine contraction, but no vaginal bleeding. Vital signs are blood pressure of 110/70 and heart rate of 90 bpm. Respiratory rate and body temperature are within normal limits. Investigations revealed a diminished platelet count. D-dimer is elevated. Prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) are increased. Schistocytes are noted in the peripheral blood smear.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lower limb deep venous thrombosis
B. Pelvic thrombophlebitis
C. Placental abruption
D. Urinary tract infection and sepsis
E. Isoimmunisation

Correct Answer: C

A 58-year-old man presents to the Accident & Emergency Department following an overdose of one of his medications. On initial triage, his blood pressure is found to be 72/48 mmHg, heart rate 34 bpm and his serum blood glucose is recorded as 1.4 mmol/l. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus bradycardia. He has a past medical history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes and hypercholesterolaemia.
Which of the following medications is most likely to be responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

A. Amlodipine
B. Bisoprolol
C. Digoxin
D. Insulin
E. Metformin

Correct Answer: B

A 90-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner. He is worried that he will be unable to make financial decisions for himself in the future and would like his son to make these decisions on his behalf. He is aware that he will have to submit a form to ensure his son is granted these powers.
With which organisation will these forms need to be registered?

A. National Information Board
B. Office of the Public Guardian
C. Official Solicitor and Public Trustee
D. Public Health England
E. The Pensions Regulator

Correct Answer: B

A 79-year-old man is admitted to the hospital feeling generally unwell. He has also developed a fever and diffuse erythematous rash over the last few days. Urinalysis is positive for blood and protein, and blood tests show raised eosinophils and creatinine. His General Practitioner started him on a new medication two weeks ago, but he cannot remember the name or what it was for.
Which of the following drugs would be safe to continue at present, given the suspected diagnosis?

A. Allopurinol
B. Amoxicillin
C. Diclofenac
D. Omeprazole
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: E

A 19-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department, following a road traffic collision. He is breathing erratically, with a respiratory rate of four breaths/minute, and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of three. A decision is made by the trauma team to intubate in the department. However, due to oropharyngeal swelling secondary to trauma, they fail to intubate. He quickly deteriorates and is now hypoxic, with an oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 72%, despite mechanical ventilation with a bag–valve–mask and basic airway manoeuvres.
Which of the following interventions would be the most suitable for restoring oxygenation?

A. Oropharyngeal airway insertion
B. Tracheostomy
C. Emergency cricothyroidotomy
D. Nasopharyngeal airway insertion
E. Laryngectomy

Correct Answer: C

A 69-year-old woman attends clinic for an annual review. She is concerned about osteoporosis and has specific questions regarding bone formation and calcium homeostasis. As part of the discussion, you elaborate on the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in calcium regulation.
Which of the following statements regarding PTH is correct?

A. It increases the release of osteoprotegerin
B. It causes a decrease in serum calcium
C. It enhances bone deposition in the colloid matrix
D. It causes indirect osteoclastic activation via RANK-L
E. Renal phosphate reabsorption is enhanced

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old woman is admitted in a drowsy and septic state to the Emergency Department. Although she was brought in by ambulance, a friend who attended with her states that she has no past medical history of note. She has apparently felt unwell for the past few days as it is the time of her monthly period. On examination, she is pyrexial with a temperature of 39.1 °C, with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. Respiratory examination is normal. She groans when the lower abdomen is palpated.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 109 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 16.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 85 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 175 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Lumbar puncture No white cells or organisms seen
MSU White cells +, red cells +
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bacterial meningitis
B. Gram negative urinary tract infection
C. Appendicitis
D. Toxic shock syndrome
E. Viral meningitis

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner. He has been smoking 20 cigarettes a day for the last five years but would now like some help quitting. He has a past medical history of epilepsy.
Which of the following smoking cessation aids is the most likely to cause adverse effects in this man?

A. Behavioural therapy
B. Bupropion
C. E-cigarettes
D. Nicotine replacement therapy
E. Varenicline

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman presents to her Occupational Health Service. She works in the sterile supplies group at her local hospital. Over the past few months, she has noticed increasing shortness of breath with cough and wheeze during the course of a working week, but improves when she takes a week off on holiday. On examination at the general practitioner’s surgery, after a few weeks off, her chest is clear.
Peak flow diary:
Monday p.m 460 l/min (85% predicted)
Tuesday p.m 440 l/min
Wednesday p.m 400 l/min
Thursday p.m 370 l/min
Friday p.m 350 l/min
Saturday a.m 420 l/min
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment choice?

A. Salbutamol inhaler as required (prn)
B. Beclomethasone 100 micrograms inhaler twice daily (bd)
C. Fluticasone 100 micrograms/salmeterol 50 inhaler bd
D. Redeployment to another role if possible
E. 7-day course of oral prednisolone

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old patient is being consented for an exploratory laparoscopy for suspected endometriosis. The patient is especially anxious about the risk of dying from the procedure and wishes to talk through the causes of death in laparoscopic surgery in detail.
Which is the most reported cause of death in laparoscopic surgery after anaesthesia?

A. Electrocautery
B. Initial incision
C. Insertion of clips
D. Insufflation of carbon dioxide into the abdominal cavity
E. Trocar insertion

Correct Answer: E

An elderly man presents to his general practitioner with isolated left facial weakness. He complains that he is unable to clear food from his mouth when eating a meal.
Which of the following muscles is likely affected?

A. Temporalis
B. Medial pterygoid
C. Lateral pterygoid
D. Buccinator
E. Masseter

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old man (weighing 100 kg) was pulled from a house fire. He was intubated by the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service (HEMS) team at the scene for airway compromise (nasal soot, singed facial hair and change in voice). He has sustained 40% full-thickness burns to his face, chest and legs. The specialty registrar (SpR) has asked you to calculate this mans resuscitation fluid requirements for the first 24 hours.
Which of the following is the correct resuscitation volume?

A. 4 litres
B. 8 litres
C. 12 litres
D. 16 litres
2A. 4 litres

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old female patient presents with an overdose of an unknown quantity of an unknown drug, which she took 4 hours earlier. During your assessment, she complains of severe ‘ringing’ in her ears. She has a resting respiratory rate of 24/min. Chest examination is clear.
Which one of the following drugs is she most likely to have taken?

A. Paracetamol
B. Amitriptyline
C. Lithium
D. Codeine phosphate
E. Aspirin

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old woman with a 4-week-old baby visits the General Practitioner (GP) with ongoing breast pain despite taking three days of antibiotics for mastitis.
On examination, the patient’s temperature is 38 °C; her pulse is 90 bpm, and blood pressure 108/78 mmHg.
Examination of the breast now reveals a painful, swollen lump in the affected breast, with redness, heat and swelling of the overlying skin.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Continue the oral antibiotics and offer reassurance to the patient
B. Prescribe another antibiotic and ask to return if symptoms do not settle
C. Refer as an urgent basis to a general surgeon
D. Discontinue antibiotics and manage conservatively with analgesia and heat compresses
E. Refer to the Breast Clinic for triple assessment of the breast lump

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old girl, with a background of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), presents to the Paediatric Ward, having had a fever of 38.7 °C at home. Her last treatment was 1 week ago. Mum reports that she has been well, with no cough/cold, no rash and no diarrhoea or vomiting.
Observations show a temperature of 38.2 °C, but otherwise they are within normal range. Examination is unremarkable. Bloods and blood culture are sent from the portacath and show: haemoglobin (Hb) 11.2, white cell count (WCC) 1.2, neutrophils 0.1, C-reactive protein (CRP) 81.
What is the most important next step in management?

A. Start intravenous (iv) Tazocin®
B. Start iv fluids
C. Arrange a chest X-ray
D. Send urine and stool samples for microbial culture and sensitivity (MC&S)
E. Start oral Augmentin®

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old metal worker slips onto a furnace wall. He presents with a leathery lesion on his chest. It is dry and insensate with a waxy appearance. It does not blanch.
How would you describe this burn?

A. Superficial burn (first-degree burn)   
B. Partial-thickness burn (second-degree burn)
C. Full-thickness burn (third-degree burn)
D. Fourth-degree burn
E. Fifth-degree burn

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old with schizophrenia comes to see you complaining of a milk-like nipple discharge. After further questioning and examination, you believe this to be a side-effect of her anti-psychotic medications.
Which of the following pathways affected by anti-psychotics is most likely to be the culprit?

A. Alpha adrenergic receptor blockage
B. Anticholinergic receptor blockage
C. Histaminergic receptor blockage
D. Nigrostriatal pathway blockage
E. Tuberoinfundibular pathway blockage

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man presents with a mole on his back. He has just returned from holiday in Spain and is worried it may be cancerous. As it is on his back, he is unsure about its size and whether it has changed in appearance recently, as he cannot see it well.
Which of the following features is most concerning for a possible diagnosis of a malignant melanoma?

A. A uniformly brown lesion
B. A pale halo around the mole
C. Easy-contact bleeding
D. Diameter <0.5 cm
E. Regular edges

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old woman complains of a 1-week history of seeing an 'arc of white light and some cobwebs' in her vision. This is painless and there is no recent trauma. She is myopic in both eyes.
On examination, her vision is 6/9 in both eyes. Both anterior segments were unremarkable. On dilated fundoscopy, no horseshoe tear has been identified on either side.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cataract
B. Exudative retinal detachment
C. Posterior vitreous detachment
D. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
E. Tractional retinal detachment

Correct Answer: C

A 54-year-old woman presents with a 30-year history of psoriasis, which has not responded to ciclosporin. She has multiple patches on her arms, legs and scalp, and she reports that this affects her ability to sleep and go to work. The Dermatologist decides to start her on biological therapy in the form of a tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha inhibitor. The patient has a history of tuberculosis, which, at present, is inactive.
Which of the following biologicals used in the treatment of severe psoriasis is the drug described in the scenario?

A. Brodalumab
B. Infliximab
C. Adalimumab
D. Guselkumab
E. Secukinumab

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department. She has had food poisoning for the past few days with severe nausea and vomiting and took an anti-sickness tablet of her mother’s a few minutes earlier. She is concerned that she may be having a stroke as she is unable to focus, cannot stop her tongue protruding and has spasm of her jaw, uncontrolled facial grimacing and torticollis.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 129 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 183 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this condition?

A. Potassium supplementation
B. Diazepam
C. Midazolam
D. Benztropine
E. Atropine

Correct Answer: D

You are asked by a nurse to review a 43-year-old woman who is day one post-operative following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She is pyrexial with a temperature of 38.3 °C. When you see her, she complains of shortness of breath and a non-productive cough.
What is the most likely post-operative complication seen in this patient?

A. Pulmonary embolus (PE)
B. Wound infection
C. Anastomotic leak
D. Atelectasis
E. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)

Correct Answer: D

A newly registered couple comes to see you as they have been trying to have a baby for 6 months. She is 34 years old and was previously taking the oral contraceptive pill for 10 years. Her body mass index (BMI) is 28 and she is a non-smoker. She reports regular periods. He is 38 years old with no medical history. His BMI 26 and he smokes ten cigarettes per day.
What would you suggest next?

A. Referral to infertility services
B. Sperm analysis
C. Blood tests
D. Advice about weight loss and lifestyle measures
E. Female pelvic ultrasound

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old man, who is a known intravenous drug user, presented with progressive dyspnoea. On examination, his respiratory rate was 31 breaths per minute and his chest X-ray showed diffuse infiltrates in a bat-wing pattern. However, chest auscultation was normal. While staying in hospital, he developed sudden severe dyspnoea, and an emergency chest X-ray showed right-sided pneumothorax.
What is the underlying disease of this patient?

A. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
B. Cystic fibrosis
C. Pneumoconiosis
D. Pneumocystis jirovecii infection
E. Pulmonary histoplasmosis

Correct Answer: D

A 66-year-old woman presented with abdominal bloating and diarrhoea for one week. She was particularly distressed by frequent passage of flatus. She had recently returned from India where she went on a missionary activity. There was no blood in her stool. She also complained of mild nausea. She was not taking any drugs and had had no abdominal surgery.
What is the ideal treatment?

A. Tinidazole, 2 g orally for three days
B. Metronidazole, 400 mg three times daily (tid) for 5 days
C. Albendazole, 400 mg stat
D. Oral rehydration therapy only
E. None needed

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old man presents with an acutely swollen and painful left testicle. He states he is sexually active. His investigation results are as follows:
Urine blood, protein, ketone and nitrite – negative.
Bloods: haemoglobin (Hb) 130 g/l; white cell count (WCC) 10 × 103/mm3, urea 4 mmol/l, creatinine 50 μmol/l, C-reactive protein (CRP) 7.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Epididymo-orchitis
B. Testicular torsion
C. Teratoma
D. Urinary tract infection
E. Infected hydrocoele

Correct Answer: B

John is an 18-year-old star rugby player who is tackled sideways while his feet were firmly planted. He heard a popping sound, following which he found his knee to be very painful, swollen and feeling very unstable with any weight on it. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed a complete tear in the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
What would be the best treatment option for him?

A. Physical therapy and avoidance of future contact sports
B. Rest, ice, compression and elevation of the limb
C. Knee bracing with an immobiliser, analgesia and physiotherapy
D. Operative repair with ligament repair
E. Operative repair with anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction

Correct Answer: E

A 21-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-week history of redness, watering and burning in both eyes.
On examination, vision is 6/6 in both eyes. The conjunctivae are diffusely injected. Tender preauricular lymphadenopathy is evident on palpation of the face and neck.
On further history taking, she has a sore throat and blocked nose as well.
What is the first-line treatment for this patient’s eye problem?

A. Eye shield
B. Supportive measures with cool compresses and artificial tears
C. Topical chloramphenicol eye drops
D. Topical prednisolone eye drops
E. Topical dexamethasone eye drops

Correct Answer: B

A 47-year-old woman has been investigated by her General Practitioner (GP) as to the cause of her lethargy, weight gain and low mood. On biochemical testing, she was found to have high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 and T4. She was subsequently diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism and commenced on levothyroxine.
When should this patient’s thyroid function tests (TFTs) be re-checked?

A. One week
B. Three monthly
C. Six months
D. 12 months
E. No follow up is required

Correct Answer: B

A newborn infant who was born at term and did not pass meconium within the first 48 hours is being cared for in the Neonatal Unit. He initially presented with pallor, abdominal distension and bilious vomiting before undergoing emergency surgery. He is diagnosed with Hirschsprung’s disease.
What is the underlying cause of Hirschsprung’s disease?

A. Bacterial infection
B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency
C. Parasympathetic nerve dysfunction
D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency
E. Sympathetic nerve dysfunction

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old athlete attends a routine check-up. Her past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes since the age of 8. Her glucose is well controlled with self-administration of insulin. She reports that she is training for the upcoming Olympic Games. She has specific questions regarding the effects and actions of insulin.
Which of the following is correct regarding the action of insulin?

A. Insulin increases protein synthesis in muscle
B. Insulin increases serum potassium levels
C. Insulin promotes sodium secretion in the renal tubules
D. Insulin decreases triglyceride synthesis and storage
E. Insulin decreases glycogen storage in cells

Correct Answer: A

A 79-year-old woman, who lives alone at home, has sustained a head injury following a dizzy spell. She arrives in the Emergency Department and is drowsy with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 7. You perform a computerised tomography (CT) of the head, which is shown below.
This clinical picture is most likely due to which one of the following?

A. Middle meningeal artery tear
B. Basal skull fracture
C. Torn bridging veins
D. Rupture of berry aneurysm
E. Temporal bone fracture

Correct Answer: C

An infant with macrosomia has had a difficult delivery, owing to shoulder dystocia. The obstetrician pulled the baby’s head downwards towards the floor to disengage the anterior shoulder from below the pubic bones. When the baby is having a check-up prior to discharge, the paediatrician notes that the left upper limb is adducted and medially rotated, with extension at the elbow joint. When questioned, the mother admits that the baby has not been moving it.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Isolated radial nerve injury in the axilla
B. Erb–Duchenne palsy due to trauma to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus
C. Klumpke’s palsy due to trauma to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus
D. Isolated axillary nerve injury
E. Isolated musculocutaneous nerve injury

Correct Answer: B

A 43-year-old woman is admitted with central chest pain of 18 hours’ duration and shortness of breath. Her troponin is elevated, and her electrocardiogram (ECG) shows changes in leads V2–V6. While undergoing initial management in preparation for primary percutaneous coronary intervention (primary PCI), she deteriorates suddenly and goes into cardiac arrest. Efforts to resuscitate her are unsuccessful. At post-mortem, rupture of the left ventricular cardiac wall is evident at the apex.
Which is the most likely blood vessel to have been involved in the infarct?

A. The posterior interventricular artery
B. The anterior interventricular (left anterior descending) artery
C. The right (acute) marginal artery
D. The circumflex artery
E. The conus branch of the right coronary artery

Correct Answer: B

At a routine occupational health check, a 25-year-old man is found to have mild hypercalcaemia. He is anxious because the problem failed to resolve in his father, despite neck surgery. 24-hour urinary calcium excretion levels are low.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Sarcoidosis
B. Primary hyperparathyroidism
C. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
D. Hypercalcaemia of malignancy
E. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia (FHH)

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman is found to be hypertensive at 12 weeks’ gestation. She has never been hypertensive previously. She has headache and right lower quadrant pain and tenderness. A pelvic ultrasound shows multiple bilateral ovarian cysts. There is no evidence of hirsutism or virilism.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
B. Luteoma of pregnancy
C. Adrenal tumour
D. Molar pregnancy
E. Polycystic ovary syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old patient, who is 23 weeks pregnant, has been suffering from severe allergic rhinitis. She reports rhinorrhoea, bilateral eye puffiness and itching, as well as chronic nasal congestion. She is really struggling with the symptoms and requires your advice on medical management. She has previously used nasal sprays which did not work. However, she has avoided any medication, as she is pregnant, but her symptoms are now interfering with her work and sleep.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line medication to try in this patient?

A. Intranasal sodium cromoglicate spray
B. Oral chlorphenamine
C. Oral loratadine
D. Oral montelukast
E. Pseudoephedrine hydrochloride

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old girl with learning difficulties was brought in by ambulance with her carer, she was found lying on the floor at home. She was suspected of having took some pills at home as the carer found an empty bottle next to her. On arrival, she is very agitated with her jaw clenched, there is also involuntary upward deviation of her eyes.
Which of the following drugs is most likely the causative agent?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Phenytoin
C. Carbamazepine
D. Metoclopramide
E. Aspirin

Correct Answer: D

A fourth-year medical student is on placement at a GP practice is taking part in the Vaccination Clinic. The practice nurse informs the student that all the patients who are attending to clinic today are listed for the shingles vaccine.
At what age are people eligible for the shingles vaccination?

A. 4-5 years old
B. 50-60 years old
C. 70-79 years old
D. 80 or 86-years old
E. 5-6 years old

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman attends for a mole check after reading a newspaper article about skin cancer. She is worried about the lesion shown in the picture because it has been growing bigger over the last 3 months. She is uncertain how long it has been present. It does not bleed or itch.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Actinic keratosis
B. Basal cell carcinoma
C. Compound naevus
D. Junctional naevus
E. Malignant melanoma

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) for a review of her blood pressure, which is proving difficult to control despite lifestyle measures and the combination of ramipril and felodipine. There are no clinical features to guide diagnosis on examination. The GP performs a urinalysis, which is normal, and requests some blood tests which show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 175 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 4.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
eGFR >60 ml/min/1.73m2 >60 ml/min/1.73m2
Which secondary cause of hypertension would be most likely, given this presentation?

A. Glomerulonephritis
B. Phaeochromocytoma
C. Diabetic nephropathy
D. Cushing syndrome
E. Primary hyperaldosteronism

Correct Answer: E

A new father is curious as to when his baby will be receiving her vaccines. He is particularly interested in the six-in-one vaccine which he has heard about from some friends at work.
When is the six-in-one vaccine given?

A. One year
B. 12, 24 and 36 weeks
C. 8, 12, and 16 weeks
D. 8, 12 and 16 months
E. 24 months

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old university student exhibits involuntary head twitching and flicking of his hands. He also says that he suffers from embarrassing grunting which can affect him at almost any time. When he is in lectures at the university he manages to control it, but often when he comes home and relaxes the movements and noises get the better of him. His girlfriend who attends the consultation with him tells you that he seems very easily distracted and often is really very annoying, repeating things which she says to him and mimicking her. On further questioning, it transpires that this has actually been a problem since childhood. On examination his BP is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 74 beats/min and regular. His heart sounds are normal, respiratory, abdominal and neurological examinations are entirely normal.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 129 g/l 135–175 g/l
White Cell Count (WCC) 8.0 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 193 × 109 /l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 95 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT) 23 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Congenital cerebellar ataxia
B. Gilles de la Tourette syndrome
C. Haemochromatosis
D. Huntington's disease
E. Wilson's disease

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old driver is admitted with a left-sided facial droop, dysphasia and dysarthria. His symptoms slowly improve and he is very keen to get back to work as he is self-employed.
Following a stroke, what is the minimum time that patients are advised not to drive a car for?

A. 18 months
B. 6 months
C. 4 weeks
D. 2 weeks
E. 12 months

Correct Answer: C

This 30-year-old woman has an area of recent hair loss as shown. She has another smaller similar area of hair loss in the left parietal region. Near the periphery of the picture, but not visible, are several small hairs that are tapered near their proximal end. She has a history of atopic dermatitis. Upon examination the scalp looks normal.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Trichotillomania
B. Telogen effluvium
C. Tinea capitis
D. Discoid lupus
E. Alopecia areata

Correct Answer: E

A 3-week-old baby boy is brought in by his worried parents. Since a week of age, he has had a slowly expanding lump to the left side of his head. He is otherwise well. He is gaining weight and doing well with breastfeeding. He wakes to demand food and is starting to demonstrate a smile. He was delivered by unassisted normal vaginal delivery at 39 weeks’ gestation after an uneventful pregnancy. Birthweight was 3.65 kg. Other than a slightly prolonged second stage of labour, there is no significant perinatal history. He has no siblings and there is no family history of note.
Examination reveals an alert, vigorous baby. Vital signs are normal. There is a 2 × 3 cm smooth lump arising in the left parieto-occipital region. The lump is compressible and non-pulsatile and does not cross the suture lines. Head to toe examination of the baby reveals no other lumps, skin lesions, rashes or marks. The anterior fontanelle is normal. The baby has good tone and a normal Moro reflex. There is no jaundice or pallor.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Non-accidental injury
B. Caput succedaneum
C. Cephalohaematoma
D. Cephalocele
E. Subgaleal haemorrhage

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old otherwise healthy woman falls onto a bonfire and sustains burns on 30% of her total body surface area. Routine blood tests in the Emergency Department show a potassium of 3 mmol/l.
Which of the following hormonal alterations would she most likely have?

A. Increased oestrogen
B. Decreased aldosterone
C. Increased aldosterone
D. Decreased cortisol
E. Increased free T3/T4

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman complains of feeling tired. She also notices she has dysphagia, a dry mouth, a gritty sensation in her eyes and increased photosensitivity.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Haemochromatosis
B. Hepatitis C virus infection
C. Oesophageal carcinoma
D. Polymyositis
E. Sjögren syndrome

Correct Answer: E

A 22-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner (GP) to discuss symptoms that she thinks are attributed to a diagnosis of obsessive–compulsive disorder (OCD). She has been troubled by the symptoms for several years, but they have become worse over the past few months, since she started a new job as a cleaner. She experiences unwelcome, persistent and intrusive thoughts about germs, which result in her repeatedly washing her hands, washing her clothes and cleaning her house. Her partner is very concerned about her, and they end up arguing if he tries to encourage her to resist the urge to clean, as this heightens her anxiety symptoms.
Which one of the following medications is licensed for use in OCD?

A. Citalopram
B. Diazepam
C. Imipramine
D. Sertraline
E. Venlafaxine

Correct Answer: D
