A 20-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department, having taken an overdose of paracetamol 12 h earlier. She claims that she took 30 500-mg tablets. She took the tablets along with half a litre of vodka and states that she does not normally drink alcohol. She appears to have mild alcohol intoxication.
What is the most appropriate action to take in this case?

A. Take bloods for paracetamol level, urea and electrolytes, liver function tests and a coagulation screen and assess the need for treatment with acetylcysteine once the results are available using the risk line on the paracetamol treatment chart
B. Take bloods for paracetamol level and a coagulation screen and assess the need for treatment with acetylcysteine once the results are available using the risk line on the paracetamol treatment chart
C. Administer activated charcoal via a nasogastric tube
D. Commence treatment with acetylcysteine immediately, and take bloods for paracetamol level, urea and electrolytes, liver function tests and a coagulation screen
E. Observe the patient until there is no evidence of alcohol intoxication and then reassess the situation

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old man and his 25-year-old wife go to see their General Practitioner (GP) for a follow-up appointment regarding their inability to conceive.
The couple have been trying to conceive over the past year but have failed so far. The wife has a regular menstrual cycle and has never had any gynaecological problems previously. An ovulation test involving measuring her progesterone level revealed that ovulation occurs normally. The GP explains to the couple that the husband will also need to undergo some tests to find out if there is any cause on his side contributing to the infertility. Both the man and the woman have no history of sexually transmitted infections. The man has smoked one to two cigarettes a day since the age of 16.
Which of the following is the best next investigation for the patient?

A. Follicle-stimulating hormone level
B. Genetic testing
C. Testosterone level
D. Testicular biopsy
E. Semen analysis

Correct Answer: E

You are an orthopaedic senior house officer and are seeing a patient referred by her general practitioner. He has stated in his letter that the patient has vertebral tenderness at the level of the spine of her scapula, which you confirm by examination.
What level is this vertebrae?

A. C7
B. C8
C. T1
D. T2
E. T3

Correct Answer: E

A mother brings her 6-month-old son to the general practitioner. She is concerned, as he has had an unusually high-pitched cry and has been drawing his legs up and vomiting. His last nappy revealed some bloody, slimy stools. She has recently started to wean him.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Colic
B. Food intolerance
C. Pyloric stenosis
D. Intussusception
E. Cystic fibrosis

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old woman with a history of smoking and high blood pressure presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset abdominal pain. She says that the pain is severe and she can also feel the pain in her back. On examination, there is a pulsatile mass in her abdomen. She is currently haemodynamically stable and conversing comfortably. There are concerns about an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
Which of the layers of the abdominal aortic wall are likely to be dilated in this patient?

A. Adventitia and media
B. Adventitia only
C. Intima and media
D. Intima, media and adventitia
E. Intima only

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old man visits his general practitioner (GP), as he is concerned that he may have inherited a heart condition. He is fit and well and has no history of any medical conditions. However, his 24-year-old brother has recently been diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) after collapsing when he was playing football. The patient’s father died suddenly when he was 39, which the family now thinks might have been due to the same condition.
Which of the following signs is most likely to be found in a patient with this condition?

A. Early diastolic murmur at the end of expiration
B. Pansystolic murmur increased by squatting
C. Pansystolic murmur unaffected by position
D. Ejection systolic murmur increased by squatting
E. Ejection systolic murmur decreased by squatting

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman, a smoker, presents to the Emergency Department at 30 weeks’ gestation with a swollen left lower leg. She said she had some pain and swelling in both her legs in the last week or so but woke up this morning with the left leg being tender and erythematous.
Past medical history is unremarkable. She feels short of breath, and her observations are stable.
Examination reveals bilateral lower limb swelling, significantly more so on the left side when compared to the right, erythema and pain on palpation. The skin is hot to touch. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal.
Given the likely diagnosis, what should be the first step in the patient’s management?

A. Commence low-molecular-weight heparin treatment
B. Commence warfarin treatment
C. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)
D. Chest X-ray
E. Ultrasound Doppler of left lower leg

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old woman complains of scant abnormal vaginal bleeding for 5 days before menses during each cycle over the past 6 months. She is married but has been unable to conceive within the last year. Her menses are associated with lower abdominal cramp for which she takes naproxen. She also complains of pelvic pain during intercourse and defecation. On examination, there is mild right adnexal tenderness.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Ovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding
B. Cervical cancer
C. Submucosal leiomyoma
D. Endometrial polyps
E. Endometriosis

Correct Answer: E

This 55-year-old woman complains of being tired with some loss of appetite and weight. She thinks the symptoms have appeared over the previous six months. The patient has several lesions like those shown in the picture. They are mainly distributed on the upper trunk and face. They also are of recent onset.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
With which of the following conditions are these lesions associated with?

A. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
B. Cirrhosis of the liver
C. Hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia
D. Leukaemia
E. Type II diabetes

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe and unremitting occipital headache. On examination, she is drowsy and confused, with a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg. You suspect that she may have had a subarachnoid haemorrhage and arrange a computed tomography (CT) scan. This is normal. She undergoes a lumbar puncture and the results are shown below:
Pot 1: red cells 490 × 109/l, white cells 10 × 109/l, no organisms seen
Pot 2: red cells 154 × 109/l, white cells 8 × 109/l, no organisms seen
Pot 3: red cells 51 × 109/l, white cells <5 × 109/l, no organisms seen
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these results?

A. Confirmed recent subarachnoid haemorrhage
B. Bacterial meningitis
C. Viral meningitis
D. Traumatic tap
E. Subarachnoid haemorrhage >1 week ago

Correct Answer: D

A 9-month-old baby boy is admitted to the Emergency Department with a swelling located in the right groin area, extending to the scrotum. The mother explains that the child has been very unsettled.
What is the best course of action in this patient?

A. Conservative treatment – intravenous (iv) fluids and analgesia
B. Sedation and attempt reduction
C. Start iv fluids and analgesia, and book in for elective surgery
D. Emergency surgery
E. Discharge with analgesia; advise to return if there are signs of strangulation

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old girl is brought from a school party following an episode of loss of consciousness. She was noted to have jerking of the limbs, frothing at the mouth and was incontinent of urine in the episode. Examination is non-contributory. Blood investigations and CT scan of the brain are normal. She mentions a similar case when on holiday about a year before this episode for which she did not receive treatment.
Which of these is an appropriate step in this patient’s management?

A. Involve an epilepsy nurse specialist
B. Refer for electroencephalography (EEG) if there are any further episodes
C. Advise to continue driving lessons until a diagnosis is confirmed
D. Sodium valproate at an initial dose of 300 mg twice daily
E. Refer for MRI of the brain if EEG shows abnormality

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of feeling like there is a lump in her throat. She is not in pain, but she describes feeling an itching sensation. The symptoms come and go, they are not related to swallowing solids or liquids and there is no persistent hoarseness. She does report that she is feeling anxious and tired as a result. She has an unremarkable family history. She reports being a heavy smoker when she was 20–30 years old but now, she does not drink or smoke. Her selected blood results of the patient’s blood profile and thyroid function are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 101 g/l 115 – 165 g/l
Mean corpuscular value 73 fl 80 – 100 fl
Thyroid stimulating hormone 2.0 mU/L 0.45 – 4.1 mU/L
What is the most appropriate initial investigation for this patient?

A. Barium swallow
B. Computed tomography neck
C. Naso-endoscopy
D. No further investigation warranted
E. Ultrasound neck

Correct Answer: C

A 67 year old woman has been admitted to the cardiology ward with worsening symptoms of congestive cardiac failure. She is breathless at rest and has pitting oedema bilaterally to the level of the shins. The cardiology consultant asks you to prescribe a furosemide infusion.
Which of the following mechanisms best describes the way that furosemide acts as a diuretic?

A. Na+/ K+/2Cl– co-transporter inhibition
B. NaCl transport inhibitors
C. Aldosterone antagonist
D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
E. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor

Correct Answer: A

A 22-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department very unwell. She tells you she has been ill with flu for the last few days and is ‘struggling to keep anything down’. She feels weak, drowsy and confused. She feels dizzy on standing. You notice, on observation, that she is tachycardic and hypotensive and has a fever. She tells you the only medication she takes is hydrocortisone 20 mg orally (PO) once daily for Addison’s disease.
Which of the following is the single most important management?

A. Give 40 mg hydrocortisone PO
B. Give 100 mg hydrocortisone IM STAT
C. Give glucose gel sublingually for hypoglycaemia
D. Check bloods for serum cortisol, and treat with IM hydrocortisone once confirmed low

A 79-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with loin pain, haematuria and a palpable abdominal mass. He is diagnosed with renal clear cell carcinoma. On staging, the tumour is found to have metastasised to the adrenal gland.
Which of the following management options would be first-line for this patient?

A. Cryotherapy
B. Immunomodulatory drugs
C. Partial nephrectomy
D. Radiofrequency ablation
E. Radical nephrectomy

Correct Answer: B

A 58-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department after sudden onset of palpitations and shortness of breath. On initial assessment, she is talking to you in broken sentences but appears sweaty and distressed. Observations are as follows:
Blood pressure 70/30, heart rate 180 bpm, respiratory rate 28, sats 98% on air.
On auscultation, there are crepitations at both lung bases. The patient begins to complain of crushing chest pain during your assessment. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a regular broad complex tachycardia.
What is the best next step in management of this patient?

A. Immediate crystalloid fluid challenge
B. Loading dose of intravenous (iv) amiodarone 300 mg
C. Sedation and synchronised direct current (DC) shock
D. Administer iv metoprolol 5 mg
E. Immediate precordial thump

Correct Answer: C

A 4-year-old boy has been brought in by his concerned mother. She describes him as a normal boy; however, he has had trouble walking and falls frequently. He began walking at 14 months old, and she has noticed that he needs help standing from a sitting position. He is otherwise similar to his peers in school and has developed normally. On examination, he shows proximal weakness, but preserved distal muscle strength.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
B. Progressive muscular atrophy
C. Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS)
D. Global developmental delay
E. Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA)

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman with asthma presented with rapidly developing asthma and wheezing. She was admitted, and during her treatment, she coughed out tubular gelatinous materials. A chest X-ray showed collapse of the lingular lobe.
What is this clinical spectrum better known as?

A. Plastic bronchitis
B. Loeffler syndrome
C. Lofgren syndrome
D. Cardiac asthma
E. Croup

Correct Answer: A

A 74-year-old man is found to have bilateral pleural effusion. A sample is aspirated and is found to contain 15 g/l of protein.
Based on this finding, what is the possible cause of the pleural effusion?

A. Inflammation from SLE
B. Pancreatitis
C. Renal failure
D. Right-sided mesothelioma
E. Right-sided pneumonia

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old woman has a long history of vulval lichen sclerosis et atrophicus. She presents with increasing itching and easy-contact bleeding of the vulva. On examination, there is a 2.2 cm unilateral aggressive looking ulcer. Biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Clinically, there is no evidence of lymph node metastasis. She is otherwise healthy.
What is the recommended management?

A. C. Simple vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy
B. Radiation therapy
C. Simple vulvectomy
D. Chemotherapy
E. Wide local excision

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner after suffering from several miscarriages and is afraid her husband will leave her. The patient gave the history of bruising even with minor injuries and several spontaneous miscarriages. On examination, the patient is noted to have a rash in a butterfly distribution on the nose and cheeks. Tests reveal 1+ proteinuria only.
What is the most likely cause of her main concern?

A. Nephritic syndrome
B. Antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS)
C. Poorly controlled diabetes
D. Dermatomyositis
E. Bicornuate uterus

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old man presents with a hot and swollen knee which he has had for the last 2 days and which has been getting progressively more painful. He has seen his GP who treated him for gout and gave him analgesia, with little effect. He reports that he has a strong family history of rheumatoid arthritis. Knee X-rays are unremarkable. On examination, his knee is tender, warm and swollen, and especially painful on movement.
Which of the following represents the best course of action?

A. Start the patient on allopurinol, colchicine and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for gout
B. Recommend rest, ice, compression and elevation for his knee pain, and suggest a knee guard
C. Perform blood tests and a joint fluid aspirate
D. Book the patient for an elective magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in a week to ensure no ligamentous injury
E. Start the patient on steroids and NSAIDs for likely rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: C

A 9-month-old female infant was brought to the paediatrician for evaluation of repeated pneumonia, otitis media and skin infections. Laboratory analysis of her blood revealed severe lymphopenia, and her lymphocytes did not respond to mitogens. Her levels of serum antibodies were abnormally diminished, as were B-cell and T-cell functions.
What was the most likely diagnosis?

A. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
B. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
C. di George syndrome
D. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: A

A 53-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe abdominal pain. She is currently undergoing peritoneal dialysis, and the treating physician is concerned that the patient may have peritonitis.
Which of the following signs and symptoms is most consistent with a diagnosis of peritonitis?

A. Hyperactive tinkling bowel sounds
B. Reduced abdominal wall rigidity
C. Hypothermia
D. Pain improving on movement
E. Tachycardia

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman is prescribed antibiotics for treatment of mastitis by her General Practitioner (GP).
Which of the following descriptions is most consistent with this diagnosis?

A. A firm, round, non-tender lump in the breast
B. Painless swelling of the breast tissue
C. Absence of erythema
D. Peau d’orange
E. A wedge-shaped distribution of erythema

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of a hoarse voice and recent unexplained weight loss. Laryngoscopy demonstrated paralysis of the right vocal fold (cord). Based on these findings, a chest radiograph was ordered.
Which of the following radiographic views would best demonstrate this patient’s lesion?

A. Aortic arch
B. Basal region of the lung
C. Hilar region of the lung of the right lung
D. Lung apex
E. Retrocardiac

Correct Answer: D

An 86-year-old woman with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction and diabetes mellitus presents to the Acute Medical Admissions Unit with a right hemiplegia and associated sensory loss. On examination, she has a fixed flexion deformity of her right arm, increased tone and 0/5 power in both her right arm and leg. There is reduced sensation down the right-hand side of her body. Her pulse is 85 bpm and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure (BP) 160/124 mmHg. A provisional diagnosis of a partial anterior circulatory stroke is made.
What percentage of strokes are ischaemic in nature as opposed to haemorrhagic?

A. 80-85%
B. 60-65%
C. 50-55%
D. 10-20%
E. 45-55%

Correct Answer: A

A couple have been trying to conceive for the last 18 months, but have been unsuccessful. The wife recently attended a fertility clinic and all the results came back normal. The husband is now attending and a blood test has shown that he has low levels of testosterone, but high levels of LH and FSH.
What is likely to be causing this man’s subfertility?

A. Absence of vas deferens
B. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
C. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
D. Poor sperm morphology
E. Poor sperm motility

Correct Answer: B

It is Friday and you have had a long week. You have made plans with friends and are very keen to leave work on time. You go home and get ready, and then realise you forgot to hand something important over to the on-call team.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Go back to the hospital immediately and hand over the message in person
B. Forget about it, the patient will be fine
C. Phone the hospital’s switchboard and asked to be transferred to the on-call junior doctor
D. Text the on-call doctor as the doctor is your friend
E. Send the on-call doctor a Facebook message and hope they check their messages

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of involuntary muscle movements of the tongue, fingers and trunk for the past 2 months. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia 20 years ago and has been taking haloperidol, with good compliance. On examination, his temperature is 37.7 °C, blood pressure 110/80 mmHg and pulse 90 bpm. His respiratory rate is 13 cycles/min. There is pronounced choreoathetoid movement of his hands and fingers. His haloperidol was stopped and clozapine was prescribed.
What is the next line of investigation for this patient?

A. PT and PTT
B. Full blood count
C. Haloperidol levels
D. Clozapine levels
E. Blood electrolytes

Correct Answer: B

A 5B. 1-year-old male taxi driver presented with altered consciousness. He was found on the roadside in this state and brought to the Emergency Department. He smelt of alcohol and was also found to be icteric. Clinically there was ascites and gynaecomastia. On examination the next morning, he was found lying still in bed, with no interest in his surroundings. He could report his own name and occupation promptly but continued to insist that it was midnight. He was co-operative to physical examination, but once, when the attending doctor pressed his abdomen, he swore loudly, although he was generally known as a gentle person.
What is the grading of hepatic encephalopathy for this patient?

A. 0
B. 1
C. 2
D. 3
E. 4

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old child is brought to their General Practitioner (GP) with failure to thrive. His parents complain that he drinks a lot of water and urinates frequently and is not growing very well. The GP does blood and urine tests and diagnoses Fanconi syndrome.
Which of the following features would you most likely see in Fanconi syndrome?

A. Oliguria
B. Hyperphosphatemia
C. Alkalosis
D. Hypokalaemia
E. Hyperkalaemia

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and is noted to have an irregular pulse. He reports intermittent palpitations over the past two months, which come on around four to five times weekly and are troublesome. He has diet-controlled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rate of 82 bpm. He has no chest pain and is not in overt cardiac failure. He is otherwise well and enjoys hill walking.
What is the appropriate new pharmacological therapy for the patient’s condition?

A. Bisoprolol and apixaban
B. Bisoprolol and aspirin
C. Digoxin and warfarin
D. Digoxin and aspirin
E. Warfarin alone

Correct Answer: A

A term baby is born with ambiguous genitalia, following an uneventful pregnancy and labour. Further investigation reveals that that child has congenital adrenal hyperplasia secondary to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
Which of the following is a feature of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency?

A. Hypogonadism
B. Type II diabetes mellitus
C. Diabetes insipidus
D. Acromegaly
E. Adrenocortical insufficiency

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) for a follow-up after complaining of hair loss for the past three months. She denies any other symptoms on systems enquiry and reports no itching of her scalp. She had some blood tests after her initial consultation with another GP, which showed a normal full blood count (FBC), normal haematinics, normal renal function, normal bone profile and unremarkable liver function. Her thyroid function is also normal. She has no regular medications prescribed and denies taking anything over-the-counter. She does report being low in mood after her boyfriend passed away three months ago. On examination, there is diffuse loss of hair on the scalp.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anagen effluvium
B. Telogen effluvium
C. Tinea capitis
D. Trichotillomania
E. Traction alopecia

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman at 36 weeks’ gestation develops severe abdominal pain. She also says she had a small amount of vaginal bleeding. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated and previous scans have been normal. On examination, she has tenderness over the uterine fundus, plus:
Investigation Result Normal value
Blood pressure (BP) 90/60 mmHg < 120/< 80 mmHg
Heart rate 110 beats per minute 60–100 beats per minute
Respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths per minute 12–20 breaths per minute
O2saturation 98% 95–100%
What is the diagnosis?

A. Early labour
B. Uterine rupture
C. Placental abruption
D. Placenta previa
E. Placenta accreta

Correct Answer: C

A 61-year-old man of Afro-Caribbean descent presented with bipedal oedema. He was a businessman with frequent international travel. On examination, his body weight was 38 kg with some oral ulcers.
Tests revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 110 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 1.0 × 109/l 2.5–7.58 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.2 × 109/l 1.5–3.5 × 109/l
Eosinophils 1.0 × 109/l 0.1–0.4 × 109/l
Urine Protein 3+
Cholesterol 4.3 <5.2 mmol/l
Which of the following tests is next indicated for this patient?

A. CD4 count
B. Renal biopsy
C. Serum immunoglobulin A (IgA) levels
D. Serum complement levels
E. Anti-nuclear factor

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old patient, with learning difficulties and poorly controlled epilepsy, is admitted following a tonic−clonic seizure which resolved after the administration of lorazepam by a Casualty officer. Twenty minutes later, a further seizure occurred that again ceased with lorazepam. A further 10 minutes later, another seizure takes place.
What commonly would be the next step in the management of this patient?

A. Rectal diazepam
B. Admission to the intensive care unit (ICU)
C. Paraldehyde
D. Topiramate
E. Phenytoin

Correct Answer: E

A 22-year-old woman with a history of two episodes of pneumothorax over the last 12 months was found to have ectopia lentis, during a recent examination by an ophthalmologist. It is noted that she has pectus excavatum, pes planus, a high arched palate and a positive wrist and thumb sign.
What is the likely finding from her echocardiogram?

A. Aortic valve stenosis
B. Coarctation of the aorta
C. Dilated aortic root
D. Ventricular septal defect
E. Ebstein’s anomaly

Correct Answer: C

A General Practice is carrying out an audit on numbers of patients with gastrointestinal symptoms who were referred for endoscopy without a clear clinical indication.
Which of the following intestinal diseases requires blood tests and small intestinal biopsy for accurate diagnosis?

A. Coeliac disease
B. Abetalipoproteinemia
C. Mycobacterium avium infection
D. Whipple’s disease
E. Intestinal lymphangiectasia

Correct Answer: A

A 12-year-old boy was admitted with high-grade fever for 2 weeks and bleeding gums. His peripheral blood picture revealed numerous blasts, some of which showed Auer rods.
Which one of the following congenital conditions is most closely associated with this condition?

A. Trisomy 18 (Edwards’ syndrome)
B. 47,XXY (Klinefelter’s syndrome)
C. Gardner syndrome
D. Haemophilia
E. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)

Correct Answer: E

A 10-year-old boy is brought into the Emergency Department by his mother. He is known to have haemophilia B and has fallen while playing football. His knee is very swollen and bruised.
Which of the following would be the best treatment option for this patient?

A. Recombinant factor VIII
B. Recombinant factor XI
C. Cryoprecipitate
D. Recombinant factor IX
E. Vitamin K

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with two days of fever, headache and feeling generally unwell. She has no rash, neck stiffness, photophobia or vomiting. Observations are normal. She is suspected of having viral encephalitis and undergoes a computed tomography head scan and lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis.
Initial CSF results confirm the suspected diagnosis with a normal opening pressure and CSF glucose level, with a mildly raised white cell count, predominantly lymphocytes, and protein level of 0.6 g/l (Normal value < 0.45 g/l).
While awaiting CSF culture, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Aciclovir
B. Benzylpenicillin
C. Ceftriaxone
D. Dexamethasone
E. Supportive management only

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl is evaluated for primary amenorrhoea. The girl has never menstruated. Physical examination demonstrates downy hair at the armpits and on the genital area. No breast development is seen. Pelvic examination demonstrates a vagina, but no uterus is palpable. Genetic studies demonstrate a 46,XY karyotype. The rest of the physical examination is normal, and her blood tests are within normal range.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. True intersex
B. Female intersex
C. Male intersex
D. Fragile X syndrome
E. Turner syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old man who suffers from inflammatory bowel disease has developed pain and stiffness in his lower back with buttock pain over the past six months. His pain tends to get better after he plays squash on Saturdays. He tests positive for HLA-B27. His blood tests, including C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are normal, apart from a mild hypochromic microcytic anaemia.
What is the most probable diagnosis?

A. Ankylosing spondylitis
B. Osteoarthritis
C. Prolapsed invertebral disc
D. Reactive arthritis
E. Rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old man is seen in the Cardiology Clinic for worsening central crushing chest pain. It occurs only on exertion and never at rest. The pain does not radiate. His current medications are: bisoprolol 20 mg per day, ramipril, omeprazole, glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) and atorvastatin.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Arrange an outpatient angiogram
B. Commence isosorbide mononitrate and arrange an outpatient angiogram
C. Immediate angiogram
D. Increase the dose of ramipril
E. Increase the dose of statin

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old man with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with haemoptysis. While in the ED, he has a further episode of frank haemoptysis measuring 180 ml.
An urgent computed tomography (CT) aortogram is performed, which shows tortuous and dilated bronchial arteries.
Which of the following could be detrimental in this patient’s management?

A. Tranexamic acid
B. Vitamin K
C. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
D. Bronchial artery embolisation
E. Non-invasive ventilation

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman was diagnosed with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome, for which she often took over-the-counter laxatives. For a recent episode of blood in the stool, she underwent colonoscopy where the colon was reported as abnormal. Biopsy was taken from the colon.
Which of the following is the most likely histological finding in this case?

A. Macrophages containing melanin in the mucosa
B. Non-caseating granuloma in the mucosa
C. Macrophages containing lipofuscin in the mucosa
D. Non-specific colitis
E. Crypt abscesses

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old woman is referred to the Cardiology clinic with a heart murmur. On examination, the patient has a collapsing pulse. Auscultation reveals a 2/5 early diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal edge, which is louder in expiration.
Which of the following clinical signs is most likely to be present?

A. Tapping apex
B. Malar flush
C. Pulsatile hepatomegaly
D. Corrigan’s sign
E. Clubbing

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman with known depression is brought in to the Emergency Department with tachycardia, hypotension and decreased salivation. Her current prescribed medications include tricyclic antidepressants. Her partner thinks she may have taken a large amount of her tablets earlier on in the day following an argument.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
B. Sepsis screen
C. Echocardiogram
D. International normalised ratio (INR)
E. Chest X-ray

Correct Answer: A

A 66-year-old woman was admitted 3 days ago with small bowel obstruction. A nasogastric (NG) tube was inserted, and she began 2 litres of intravenous (IV) fluids daily. She reports feeling short of breath and, on examination has widespread fine crackles on auscultation of her chest and pitting sacral oedema. Her notes show that she weighs 48 kg. You re-calculate her daily fluid intake.
What is her required daily fluid intake?

A. 1000–1500 ml
B. 1500–2000 ml
C. 2000–2500 ml
D. 2500–3000 ml
E. 3000–3500 ml

Correct Answer: A

A 43-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer, requiring a lumpectomy two years ago, is currently on tamoxifen therapy and presents to her follow-up clinic with her partner.
She is tearful, has a low mood and reports sleep disturbance secondary to hot flushes. She would like some help on improving her mood.
Which of the following options is the best management option for this patient?

A. A 2-week trial of fluoxetine
B. Commence combined cyclic hormonal replacement therapy (HRT)
C. Recommend black cohosh that can be bought over the counter
D. Lifestyle changes
E. Referral for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman with shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, non-productive cough and two documented episodes of pulmonary thromboemboli over the last year receives a heart–lung transplant. Her native heart shows massive right ventricular hypertrophy. The lungs show numerous thromboemboli, and the vasculature shows marked medial smooth muscle hypertrophy and atherosclerotic plaques on the main pulmonary arteries.
With which of the following diagnoses are these findings most consistent?

A. Pneumonia
B. Atopic asthma
C. Pulmonary hypertension
D. Adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
E. Goodpasture’s syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A gram-staining of a bacterial culture taken from an ITU patient is shown below in the picture.
You note the presence of two clusters of bacteria which have stained a purple colour.
Which of the following groups of bacteria does the culture specimen represent?

A. Gram-positive bacilli
B. Gram-positive cocci
C. Gram-negative bacilli
D. Gram-negative cocci
E. Acid-fast bacilli

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old student is hit by a bus while cycling to university at moderate speed. He falls and lands on the curb, hitting his left ribs. There is no loss of consciousness. He is brought into the Emergency Department, complaining of left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain. On examination, his heart rate is 120 bpm after morphine analgesia; his blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg and he is peripherally cold; the respiratory rate is 25 and saturations are 99% on room air. Chest X-ray reveals displaced left lower rib fractures, with no other thoracic pathology.
What diagnosis would you be most concerned about?

A. Aspiration pneumonia
B. Cardiac tamponade
C. Early chest infection
D. Occult pneumothorax
E. Splenic rupture

Correct Answer: E

A newborn is found to be cyanotic at birth. A chest X-ray demonstrates a ‘boot-shaped’ heart, and a holosystolic murmur is audible at the left lower sternal border.
Which of the following findings is also likely in this patient?

A. Atrial septal defect (ASD)
B. Fixed, widely split S2
C. Decrescendo, diastolic murmur audible at the right upper sternal border
D. Harsh crescendo–decrescendo systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border
E. Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction

Correct Answer: E

A 19-year old patient is brought to the Emergency Department by paramedics following an assault. On examination, there are two puncture wounds on the posterior chest wall. The ambulance crew believe the patient was attacked with a screwdriver. He is currently extremely short of breath, haemodynamically unstable, and his oxygen saturations are falling despite high-flow oxygen. There are reduced breath sounds in the right hemithorax.
What is the most appropriate first step in managing this patient?

A. Urgent chest radiograph
B. Placement of chest drain
C. Contact on-call anaesthetist
D. Use of non-invasive ventilation
E. Needle decompression of right hemithorax

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old woman presents complaining of fever, malaise and pain in the neck, especially when swallowing. History reveals that she was treated for a viral respiratory infection 1 week ago. Examination showed an enlarged thyroid, heart palpitations and excessive sweating. Additional tests indicated elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), leukocytosis, thyroid antibodies and low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. Also, a radionuclide thyroid uptake test showed a decreased uptake of iodide.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Graves' disease
B. de Quervain's thyroiditis
C. Hashimoto's thyroiditis
D. Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis
E. Riedel's thyroiditis

Correct Answer: B

You are called to confirm the death of an 84-year-old man who is registered with your practice. The person used to live alone. You complete the necessary checks to verify this man’s death.
In which one of the following scenarios would it be most acceptable to issue a death certificate immediately?

A. History of asbestos-related disease
B. History of chronic alcohol-related liver disease
C. Lack of adequate nourishment
D. Suspicion of suicide
E. Suspicion of violence

Correct Answer: B

Both primary and secondary prevention measures are used to try and prevent disease.
Which of the following is a secondary prevention measure?

A. Annual influenza vaccination
B. Giving away free condoms in General Practice
C. Introducing healthy school meals
D. Offering smoking cessation services
E. Screening for breast cancer

Correct Answer: E

A man is referred by his general practitioner (GP) after noticing blood in his urine. He has no significant past medical history and is on no medications. Extensive tests confirm the presence of haematuria but do not suggest a specific cause of the problem. A renal ultrasound reveals that the left renal vein is dilated.
Which of the following conditions could explain his renal vein condition?

A. Left renal artery thrombosis
B. Left testicular vein thrombosis
C. Left ureteral stone
D. Superior mesenteric artery dilation
E. Acute tubular necrosis

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus attended the Emergency Department with severe, crushing central chest pain, breathlessness and diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST elevation in leads II, III and aVF.
What is the likely location of the responsible arterial stenosis?

A. Aorta
B. Circumflex artery
C. Left anterior descending artery
D. Right coronary artery
E. Left main stem

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department following a knife fight in a bar. He has a deep laceration extending across the left cheek laterally from just below the medial orbit extending toward the angle of the mandible. The wound is bleeding heavily. The doctor dealing with him is concerned that the parotid gland and duct may be involved in the laceration. He considers the structures that may be damaged.
Which of the following is correct?

A. Within the parotid gland, the facial nerve is least likely to be damaged, as it lies deep to the external carotid artery and retromandibular vein
B. The facial nerve provides innervation to the parotid gland
C. The parotid duct is landmarked one-third of the way down a line from the tragus of the ear to the philtrum of the lip
D. The parotid duct pierces the masseter
E. The parotid duct opens into the mouth on the mucous membrane of the cheek opposite the third upper premolar tooth

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man undergoes abdominoperineal resection for an advanced colorectal carcinoma. His baseline blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg. Intraoperatively there was faecal contamination of the peritoneal cavity. Postoperatively on return to intensive care, the patient is mechanically ventilated and his blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. His urinary output is 20 ml in the first hour.
Which of the following is the best strategy to improve his urine output?

A. Start an infusion of inotrope
B. Fluid challenge followed by a vasopressor
C. Give intravenous corticosteroids
D. Insert a Swan-Ganz catheter
E. Use a stroke volume monitor

Correct Answer: B

Mr Chen is a 50-year-old male involved in a high speed motor vehicle accident. After controlling his cervical spine with tapes, blocks and a collar, you note that his breathing is laboured and there is significant stridor. He has multiple bruises over his face, bilateral periorbital ecchymosis and Battle's sign. He also has significant nose, mouth and jaw injuries and bleeding and when you attempt to intubate, you are unable to get a clear view of the cords due to the distorted anatomy.
Which of the following is the next best step to ventilate the patient?

A. Use a nasopharyngeal airway as an adjunct
B. Proceed to fibre-optic guided intubation
C. Attempt a percutaneous tracheostomy
D. Attempt a blind insertion of the endotracheal tube with a bougie
E. Perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy

Correct Answer: E

A 41-year-old school teacher comes to see you for a follow-up review 2 weeks after presenting with symptoms suggesting low mood. She had felt ‘down’ for several weeks, no longer enjoyed work or seeing friends and was sleeping more than usual. Despite this, she had a normal appetite, a strong sense of self-worth, denied any thoughts of self-harm or suicide and came across as reasonably active and lively. She says that she feels very anxious on Sunday evenings before going to work on a Monday and is getting increasingly ‘short and snappy’ with her pupils. However, she says that work is otherwise going well and she is managing to get through the day. She does not feel any better at today’s consultation and is requesting advice about treatment options. She says she is ‘not a tablet person’.
What should you advise?

A. A 6-month course of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant
B. A trial of computer-based cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) or peer support
C. A combination of referral for group CBT and treatment with an SSRI antidepressant for 6 months
D. Trial of computer-based CBT or peer support, combined with an SSRI antidepressant for 6 months
E. A short course of benzodiazepines for anxiety with reassessment in 2 weeks

Correct Answer: B

A 79-year-old woman with a history of recurrent falls attends the Elderly Care Clinic with her son. She also has a history of mild dementia, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She takes furosemide, lisinopril, amitriptyline, aspirin, metoprolol, olanzapine and simvastatin. She lives by herself in a house in which she has lived for 25 years and has help with all activities of daily living. On examination, she appears frail, has mild bruising over both knees from recent falls and has reduced proximal lower-extremity muscle strength.
Which of the following interventions will decrease her risk of falling in the future?

A. Continuing furosemide
B. Balance and gait training physical exercises
C. Commencing donepezil
D. Continuing amitriptyline
E. Continuing olanzapine

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old woman presents to the Eye Casualty with a painful reduction in vision in her left eye over the last five hours. She has no complaints of any other symptoms.
On examination, her visual acuity is 6/6 in the right eye and 6/36 in the left. Colour vision is reduced in the left eye. Eye movements show no diplopia, but the pain gets worse. Performance of the swinging torch test and finds that the left pupil dilates when the torch light is swung from the right eye to the left. Dilated fundoscopy shows a swollen optic disc and exudates lining up like a star at the macula in the left eye.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Neuroretinitis
B. Papillitis
C. Papilloedema
D. Post-viral demyelination
E. Retrobulbar neuritis

Correct Answer: A

A 22-year-old woman comes to see you at the General Practice for advice about contraception. She has been taking Microgynon® but finds it difficult to remember to take the pills and would like to try an implant, as her friend got this a few months ago and seems much happier with it. You discuss the advantages and disadvantages and confirm that there are no contraindications. Her last period was eight days ago.
How soon can the implant be fitted?

A. Today, and there is no need for further precautions
B. Today, but there is a need to use condoms for 7 days
C. In 7 days, provided a pregnancy test is negative
D. On the first day of her next period
E. On day 21 of her cycle

Correct Answer: B

After a weekend of hiking, a 55-year-old man finds that he is having difficulty raising his right arm. The weakness is found to be of abduction of the right shoulder with particular difficulty initiating the movement. The movement at the shoulder that can be elicited is not particularly painful and there is no loss of cutaneous sensation.
Which one of the following structures is most likely to have been damaged?

A. Axillary nerve
B. Deltoid muscle
C. Subacromial bursa
D. Suprascapular nerve
E. Infraspinatus muscle

Correct Answer: D

A 67-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of spots, mainly on the fingers and toes and lower legs. She has no significant past medical history. However, she mentions that she been feeling more tired recently and has been experience pain in hand joints. She has not been taking over-the-counter drugs. The lesions do not blanch on pressure. Some are just palpable on touch. Her blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Dipstick urine test result is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Erythema multiforme
B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura
C. Spider naevi
D. Splinter haemorrhages
E. Vasculitis

Correct Answer: E

An 8-year-old child is brought to the general practitioner by his mother. He complains of loss of sensation over the dorsal aspect of his right forearm and hand for the last few days. His mother also states that he cannot extend his fingers and wrist after she pulled her son’s right hand gently while crossing a street 4 days ago. He had pain in his right elbow at that time but did not see a doctor immediately. On examination, there is loss of sensation and muscle weakness over the extensor surface of his right forearm and hand.
Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured in this patient?

A. Musculocutaneous nerve
B. Axillary nerve
C. Long thoracic nerve
D. Radial nerve
E. Middle subscapular nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old Romanian smoker presents with a 3-month history of cough productive of blood-tinged sputum, fever, night sweats and weight loss. At presentation he is haemodynamically stable, has a fever of 37.7°C and appears cachectic. On examination, there are coarse crepitations in the right upper zone of lung. Chest radiograph reveals patchy, non-specific increased upper zone interstitial markings bilaterally together with a well-defined round opacity with a central lucency in the right upper zone and bilateral enlarged hila.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Staphylococcal pneumonia
B. Klebsiella pneumonia
C. Squamous cell bronchial carcinoma
D. Primary pulmonary lymphoma
E. Tuberculosis

Correct Answer: E

A 23-year-old woman has been referred to the Haematology Clinic by her General Practitioner (GP). For the last few weeks, she has been experiencing pallor and fatigue, with a full blood count showing anaemia (haemoglobin of 86 g/l). She is also suffering from painful cyanosis of her fingers and toes, which was the reason she initially saw her GP. The GP ordered a peripheral blood smear, the results of which have come back when the patient is seen in the Haematology Clinic. Her direct antiglobin test (DAT) is positive, with both immunoglobulin G (IgG) and C3 present.
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on a peripheral blood smear?

A. Bite cells
B. Howell-Jolly bodies
C. Rouleaux cells
D. Siderocyte
E. Spherocytes

Correct Answer: E

A man has been diagnosed with a sexually transmitted infection. The underlying organism is an obligate intracellular bacteria. The patient has agreed to treatment of the infection and has no known allergies. However, he is a homeless man with no fixed abode, and you are concerned with his potential treatment compliance.
Which of the following would be most appropriate?

A. Doxycycline
B. Azithromycin
C. Erythromycin
D. Ceftriaxone intramuscularly (IM)
E. Penicillin G IM

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with a 1-day history of complete unilateral right-sided facial weakness. There are no other neurological findings on examination. No loss of hearing was reported. Apart from drooling of saliva, the patient is otherwise fit and well. An ear examination is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acoustic neuroma
B. Stroke
C. Bell's Palsy
D. Ramsey-Hunt Syndrome
E. Neurosarcoidosis

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old painter and decorator presents to his general practitioner (GP) with a swelling of the lower neck area, which had been present for at least two months. Although the lump is not painful, the patient mentions that his left arm does tend to ache much more than the right when he is working with his arms held high (such as when he is wallpapering). The patient is fit and well and has no medical history of note.
On examination, the GP notes that the patient has a significant swelling with an expansible pulsation above the left clavicle.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancoast’s tumour
B. An aneurysm of the subclavian artery
C. A dilated subclavian vein
D. Virchow’s node
E. A branchial cyst

Correct Answer: B

A 78-year-old man who has recently seen his GP for a change in bowel habit towards constipation arrives in the Emergency Department with a tender, distended abdomen. He has also been suffering with a chest infection recently and has known chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 4. Bowel sounds are absent. The rectum is empty on examination. Abdominal X-ray reveals distended loops of large bowel, consistent with large bowel obstruction.
Which one of these investigations should be performed next?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan with Gastrogaffin®
B. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage
C. Gastroscopy
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen
E. Ultrasound of the abdomen

Correct Answer: A

A young man is bought into the Emergency Department following a road traffic collision (RTC). On examination, he is tachycardic at 120 bpm, sweating and pale. He has decreased breath sounds on his right side and has decreased chest movement. His trachea is deviated to the left. You are asked to insert a large-bore cannula.
Where will you place it in this patient?

A. In the fifth intercostal space, mid-axillary line of the chest, on the side of the decreased breath sounds
B. In the second intercostal space, mid-axillary line of the chest, on the side with the normal breath signs
C. In the third intercostal space, mid-clavicular line, on the side of the decreased breath sounds
D. In the second intercostal space, mid-clavicular line, on the side of the decreased breath sounds
E. In the sixth intercostal space, mid-clavicular line, on the side of the chest with decreased breath sounds

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man presents to his GP with a 6-week history of bothersome tinnitus. He describes hearing a ringing noise in his right ear only and hearing loss on the right side. The noise is intrusive and is keeping him awake at night. He denies any vertigo, headache or any other neurological symptoms. He has a past medical history of hypertension, for which he takes atenolol.
Ear examination is normal.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Perform Epley manoeuvre
B. Refer urgently to ENT
C. Refer routinely to ENT
D. Regular stemetil for five days
E. Vestibular retraining

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old man presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness and chest pain which he describes as tearing in nature on direct questioning. He is a little short of breath and he is very hypertensive 200/110 mmHg. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows anterior ST elevation.
Which of the options below is the best course of action:

A. Take to cardiac catheter lab for a primary angioplasty
B. Thrombolysis
C. Echocardiography
D. Computed tomography (CT) aortogram
E. Computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man complains of progressive shortness of breath for 3 months. Initially, it occurred with intense exercise, but now even mild exertion brings it on. He also has a non-productive cough and chest pain localised to the left lower rib cage.
The chest pain is aggravated by deep breaths and turning to the left side in bed. He denies fever, haemoptysis or wheezing. He has had a low appetite lately and an unintentional weight loss of about 7 kg over 2 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago. He is currently taking atenolol and aspirin. He had an appendicectomy at the age of 35. He is a retired shipyard worker, has never smoked, drinks occasionally and lives with his wife. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chest expansion is restricted to the left side. Tactile fremitus and breath sounds are reduced over the left lower lung zone. There is no ascites or leg oedema. Chest X-ray shows mild to moderate left-sided pleural effusion. A left pleural-based mass with adjacent pleural fibrosis and plaque formation is noted on the helical chest computed tomography (CT) scan. An open thoracoscopy and biopsy is performed.
What is the most likely histopathological finding in this patient?

A. Caseating granuloma with giant cells
B. Pleomorphic cells in a cluster with keratin pearls and intercellular bridges
C. Large, undifferentiated (anaplastic) cells
D. Atypical epithelial tubules in a sarcomatous background
E. Neoplastic cells forming mucinous glands

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old G1P0 woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her husband at 10 weeks’ gestation because she has been experiencing extreme morning sickness, palpitations and heat intolerance. Ultrasound of her uterus reveals a ‘snow storm’ appearance and complete lack of fetal tissue.
Which one of the following is most appropriate to monitor for successful treatment of this patient’s condition?

A. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)
B. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin (β-HCG)
C. CA-125
D. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
E. Oestriol

Correct Answer: B

A school caretaker receives a letter inviting him to attend for an ultrasound scan, as part of the NHS Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) Screening Programme. He has never attended AAA screening before.
How old is the patient most likely to be?

A. 50
B. 55
C. 60
D. 65
E. 70

Correct Answer: D

A 17-year-old youth receives a downward blow to his left shoulder during football practice. There is soreness in his shoulder between the lateral clavicle and the acromion, and pain when the injured shoulder is abducted above the shoulder.
X-rays show that the coracoclavicular (CC) and acromioclavicular (AC) spaces are about 70% wider than normal.
Which injury is most likely in this case?

A. Sternoclavicular joint dislocation
B. Shoulder joint dislocation
C. AC joint sprain
D. AC joint subluxation
E. AC joint dislocation

Correct Answer: E

A 26-year-old woman is seen in Accident and Emergency with abdominal pain for the last few hours associated with nausea. She has irregular periods and cannot remember when her last one was. She looks unwell and distressed, with examination revealing tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Speculum examination is normal. Vaginal examination shows cervical excitation and right adnexal tenderness. Observations show temperature is 37.8 °C, blood pressure 90/60, heart rate 110 bpm, and respiratory rate 22 with oxygen saturations 100% in air. Urine beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-HCG) is positive. Urine dipstick shows leukocytes 1+ and blood 1+.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute appendicitis
B. Pelvic inflammatory disease
C. Ectopic pregnancy
D. Miscarriage
E. Urinary tract infection

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old woman is admitted to the Surgical Assessment Unit with acute abdominal pain. She is also complaining of pain in her right shoulder and pain on defecation. The first day of her last period was approximately 8 weeks ago. A pregnancy test is performed and comes back positive. An urgent ultrasound scan is requested and results confirm an ectopic pregnancy within the Fallopian tube.
Which of the following is the most common site of implantation for an ectopic pregnancy?

A. Cervix
B. Ovary
C. Peritoneum
D. Broad ligament
E. The ampullary region of the Fallopian tube

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man with history of hyperlipidaemia and hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with cough and shortness of breath that has been worsening over the past 24 h. On examination, he is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 110 bpm and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. On chest auscultation, the patient has fine crackles in bilateral lung bases. He also has a new audible systolic murmur at the apex.
Which of the following conditions is most likely causing the patient’s pulmonary symptoms?

A. Pleural effusion
B. Lobar pneumonia
C. Pericardial effusion
D. Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
E. Pulmonary oedema

Correct Answer: E

When designing a vaccination, adjuvants can be added to strengthen and lengthen the immune response of the vaccine, improving immunity.
Which of the following is an adjuvant that can be used in vaccinations?

A. Thiomersal
B. Aluminium salts
C. Gelatine
D. Sorbitol
E. Ovalbumin (egg protein)

Correct Answer: B

A patient with Graves’ disease is commenced on carbimazole.
What important side-effect must be highlighted to the patient?

A. Alopecia
B. Easy bruising
C. Diarrhoea
D. Agranulocytosis
E. Skin rash

Correct Answer: D

A 59-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with worsening exertional dyspnoea associated with bilateral peripheral oedema. He also notes he has been feeling very lethargic recently. On examination, his lungs are clear and he has ascites. On auscultation of his heart sounds, you hear a high-pitched holosystolic murmur at the left sternal edge, radiating to the right sternal edge.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

A. Aortic regurgitation
B. Aortic stenosis
C. Mitral regurgitation
D. Pulmonary stenosis
E. Tricuspid regurgitation

Correct Answer: E

A 67-year-old woman is admitted with an unstable open tib-fib fracture after a road traffic collision. There is neurovascular compromise; however, there is no overt bleeding, and the decision is made to bleep the on-call consultants in vascular and trauma and orthopaedics to take the patient to theatre. She is on warfarin for atrial fibrillation (AF), and her international normalised ratio (INR) is currently 3.2 (normal value <1.1).
What is the most appropriate intervention before surgery, with regard to her INR?

A. Oral vitamin K 5 mg
B. No intervention required as benefits of operation outweigh risks
C. Administer Prothrombinex™ 35–50 iu/kg
D. 3 mg vitamin K IV
E. Fresh frozen plasma 15 ml/kg

Correct Answer: C

A 53-year-old woman presents with acute abdominal pain and a temperature of 38.5 °C, pulse 130 bpm and blood pressure 100/70 mmHg. She does not allow any attending doctor to touch her abdomen, as she is in severe pain.
Past records reveal that she was suffering from ulcerative colitis, for which she was on oral mesalazine and azathioprine. She has recently had diarrhoea for which she has taken loperamide.
What is the next appropriate diagnostic test?

A. Serum electrolytes
B. Blood for C-reactive protein (CRP)
C. Erect X-ray of the abdomen
D. Blood for ANCA
E. Blood azathioprine levels

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a hand injury. He was involved in a pub fight and has glass embedded into a wound. Upon examination, he cannot make a fist, and there is no palmar sensation over his thumb, index and middle fingers. He has no other neurological deficits in his arms or other limbs.
Which nerve is most likely to be involved in this patient?

A. Ulnar nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Musculocutaneous nerve
D. Median nerve
E. Axillary nerve

Correct Answer: D

Which of the following cells is most likely to be derived from the bone marrow and contains granules that release mediators, such as histamine and cytokines, during allergic responses?

A. B cell
B. T cell
C. Macrophage
D. Mast cell
E. Natural killer (NK) cell

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man presented with a recurrent cough that has persisted for 2 years. He had been diagnosed with pleural effusion twice during this time. On examination, the nails of his hand were thickened, curved and yellowish-brown in colour, and there was mild bipedal non-pitting oedema. Examination of his respiratory system revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lower zone, along with some scattered crepitations in both lung fields.
Which of the following conditions may be associated with the underlying disease?

A. Protein-losing enteropathy
B. Membranous nephropathy
C. Apical lung fibrosis
D. T cell deficiency
E. Parathyroid adenoma

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old man presents with symptoms of early satiety, nausea and abdominal fullness. He has lost 6 kg in weight over the past 3 months. There is no other past medical history of note. On examination, he looks very thin and there is a palpable epigastric mass.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 101 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 140 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.3 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 170 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 35 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 68 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a smooth mass in the body of the stomach with normal-looking mucosa overlying it. Multiple biopsies: spindle cell tissue, cells undergoing multiple mitoses.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gastric carcinoma
B. Helicobacter pylori gastritis
C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)
D. Gastric leiomyosarcoma
E. Gastric lipoma

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old man presents with severe breathlessness which started this morning and has become gradually worse. The patient denies coughing up any phlegm. He has a history of essential hypertension. On examination, the patient has a blood pressure of 114/75 mmHg and a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. His temperature is 37.1°C. His jugular venous pressure (JVP) is 8 cm above the sternal angle. On auscultation there are fine bi-basal crackles and a third heart sound is audible. The patient is an ex-smoker and used to smoke 5–10 cigarettes a day for about 10 years.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pneumonia
B. Pulmonary embolus
C. Pericardial effusion
D. Pulmonary oedema
E. Tricuspid regurgitation

Correct Answer: D

A man provides his general practitioner with a semen specimen, as part of an investigation for failure to conceive over a 2-year period.
In semen analysis, which of the following is incompatible with normal fertility?

A. Semen volume of 3 ml per ejaculation
B. Ejaculate pH of 7.2
C. Sperm count of 5 million per ml of ejaculate
D. 75% sperm viability by World Health Organisation (WHO) criteria
E. 55% sperm motility 4 hours after ejaculation

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old professional footballer presents to Dermatology Clinic with a lesion on his leg. It began as a small cut which he suffered during a match; however, this has progressed over the past few weeks, developing into a large, painful ulcer.
On examination, the lesion is 50 mm × 75 mm and ulcerated with a necrotic centre. He has no past medical history; however, he has recently been investigated by his general practitioner (GP) for change in bowel habit, including bloody stools, and fatigue.
Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody Positive
Wound swab No organisms grown
He is treated with systemic steroids and there is rapid improvement.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Erythema nodosum
B. Livedo reticularis
C. Lupus pernio
D. Pyoderma gangrenosum
E. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old postal worker with asthma attends his General Practitioner (GP) surgery for an annual asthma review. He states he has been breathlessness during his morning postal round for the past few months.
The GP had not found any abnormalities on examination and asked him to undertake a period of peak flow monitoring.
The results of his monitoring show a best peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) of 650 L/min and average of 439 L/min. His predicted PEFR is 660 L/min.
What do these PEFR results most likely indicate?

A. Occupational asthma
B. Sub-optimal therapy
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Interstitial lung disease
E. Acute exacerbation of asthma

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old patient presents with lethargy and reduced exercise tolerance. They also complain of tingling in the fingers and feet, and examination reveals reduced sensation in a glove-and-stocking distribution.
Bloods show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 62 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 102 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 114 fl 76-98 fl
Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A. Hypothyroidism
B. Lead poisoning
C. Iron deficiency
D. Folate deficiency
E. Vitamin B12 deficiency

Correct Answer: E

A laboratory technician conducted an indirect enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to test whether a patient was human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive (in this scenario, assume that the patient was truly HIV-positive). The steps below were used to conduct the assay:
The patient’s serum was added to the microwell and anti-HIV antibodies bound to HIV.
The substrate was added to the microwell and resulted in a visible colour change in that well.
The microwell used was pre-coated with HIV.
Anti-anti-HIV antibody conjugated to an enzyme was added to the microwell.
Which one of the following most likely represents the correct sequence of steps for this assay?

A. 3-4-1-2
B. 4-3-2-1
C. 3-1-4-2
D. 4-2-3-1
E. 1-2-3-4

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year man sees a psychiatrist as he has had recent mood swings and has become increasingly short-tempered with his wife. He also gives a history of diarrhoea, marked increase in appetite, weight gain and increasing difficulty standing up from a sitting position. He is noted to have an irregularly irregular heartbeat on examination.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cushing’s syndrome
B. Cushing’s disease
C. Phaeochromocytoma
D. Schizoaffective disorder
E. Hyperthyroidism

Correct Answer: E

A 33-year-old woman is found to have a blood pressure of 180/130 mmHg incidentally on three separate occasions. Her General Practitioner completes the rest of her cardiovascular examination which was unremarkable. Causes of secondary hypertension are investigated for, and an abdominal computed tomography (CT) angiogram is performed. This shows a significantly smaller left kidney, when compared to the right, with the left renal artery displaying a ‘string of beads’ appearance.
What would be the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A. Balloon angioplasty
B. Kidney transplantation
C. Nephrectomy
D. Statins
E. Surgical revascularisation

Correct Answer: A

An 18-year-old woman is admitted to hospital with anorexia nervosa. She has a BMI of 14 kg/m². She is placed on a feeding regime via nasogastric tube and her bloods are closely monitored due to the risk of refeeding syndrome.
Which of the following biochemical derangements is seen in refeeding syndrome?

A. Hyperkalaemia
B. Hypermagnesaemia
C. Hypophosphataemia
D. Thiamine overload
E. Uraemia

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old man with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease and depression underwent bypass surgery last night. His depression has responded well to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and there is no past history of psychosis. His blood pressure is also well controlled with medications. The following morning, he develops confusion, agitation and irritability, tries to remove his intravenous (iv) lines and wants to run away from hospital. His level of consciousness fluctuates, and at times he forgets who he is. He is given a neuroleptic drug and appears much improved.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adjustment disorder
B. Delirium
C. Dementia
D. Exacerbation of depression with suicidal ideation and psychotic features
E. Schizophrenia

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old woman presents to Accident and Emergency with recurrent chest infections over the last year. She has suffered from rheumatoid arthritis for a long time and is on methotrexate and sulfasalazine. On examination, there are some crepitations at the right lung base and splenomegaly. She has some abnormal discolouration on her legs.
Full blood counts showed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 96 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 0.8 × 109/l 1.7–7.5 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.5 × 109/l 1.0–4.5 × 109/l
Eosinophils 0.6 × 109/l 0.0–0.4 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Felty syndrome
B. Side-effects from methotrexate
C. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
D. Non-E. Hodgkin’s disease
E. Hodgkin’s disease

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old woman presents with blisters on the skin. She says that a couple of the blisters have healed and left scars but others continue to grow and new ones are forming. They have failed to respond to antibiotics prescribed by her GP. On examination, she has multiple superficial skin lesions on her skin and also inside the oral cavity that slough off easily. Immunofluorescent examination of a skin punch biopsy reveals circular intra-epidermal deposits.
What else is likely to be present in this patient?

A. Antibodies against hemidesmosomes
B. Psoriatic plaques behind the elbows and knees
C. Antibodies against desmosomes
D. Positive HIV serology
E. Alopecia

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old man complains of left scrotal discomfort and ‘tightening’. Physical examination of his genitals reveals mild swelling of the left scrotum with varices reminiscent of a bag of worms in the overlying skin that has a dark red appearance. Scrotal ultrasound confirms a varicocele on the left.
Which one of the following structures is most likely dilated in this patient?

A. Pampiniform plexus
B. Ductus deferens
C. Processus vaginalis
D. Testicular artery
E. Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old man with known dementia is admitted to hospital for treatment of a community acquired pneumonia. Unfortunately, he was not accompanied by a family member and the history provided by the patient seems confused. Upon arrival of the daughter, she confirms that her father has been confusing real events with those from his imagination. Through this process he appears to be able to maintain a superficial conversation despite significant cognitive impairment.
Which of the following describes this phenomenon?

A. Delusions
B. Flight of ideas
C. Confabulation
D. Hallucinations
E. Pressure of speech

Correct Answer: C

This 20-year-old man has developed the lesions shown in the picture over three weeks. These consist of itchy, erythematous, scaly plaques that have enlarged in diameter over this time. He is otherwise well. He is a student of English literature and plays rugby regularly.

Wikimedia Commons
Which of the following topical preparations would be the most suitable to treat this condition?

A. Betamethasone valerate
B. Calcipotriol
C. Fusidic acid
D. Hydrocortisone
E. Clotrimazole

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man presents with acute onset of upper abdominal pain associated with vomiting. His observations from triage are within normal limits.
On examination, he is in obvious severe discomfort and has a rigid abdomen on palpation.
Which investigation would be first line to confirm a perforation?

A. Abdominal X-ray
B. Bedside ultrasound
C. Urine dipstick
D. Erect chest X-ray
E. Liver function tests

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old professional tennis player grabs his shoulder immediately after serving the ball to his opponent during a tennis match. He is assessed on the sideline by the tournament doctor. The player complains of shoulder pain and, on examination, is unable to abduct the arm voluntarily. If the doctor passively abducts the patient’s arm a few degrees, the patient is then able to actively continue abduction through the full range of motion.
What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?

A. Supraspinatus tear
B. Teres minor damage
C. Infraspinatus damage
D. Subscapularis tear
E. Deltoid dysfunction

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old man falls from the roof of a garden shed, and lands heavily on his right leg. He is admitted to the Emergency Department with severe pain to upper leg, and an X-ray is requested.
After carefully analysing the X-ray, which one of the following statements are TRUE?

A. This fracture is not angulated
B. This fracture is displaced
C. This fracture is rotated
D. This fracture is not comminuted
E. This fracture is open

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man presents to his GP with a 3-day history of ear pain, itch and pus-like discharge. He is otherwise well and has not had a fever. There is no loss of hearing. He has a background history of psoriasis.
On clinical examination, there is a raised red lesion on the external ear with thick, silvery-white adherent scales. There is no visible mucus and the tympanic membrane is intact. There is mild erythema and swelling of the external auditory canal. There is no palpable lymphadenopathy.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this man’s acute ear condition?

A. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Oral antibiotics
C. Topical antibiotics
D. Topical antifungal agent
E. Topical steroids

Correct Answer: C

A couple have diarrhoea and vomiting over night. They had eaten a chicken curry earlier that evening, with fresh ingredients, apart from rice that had been reheated.
Which organism is most likely to be responsible for the gastrointestinal (GI) infection?

A. Bacillus cereus
B. Campylobacter jejuni
C. Clostridium perfringens
D. E. coli EHEC
E. Salmonella enteritidis

Correct Answer: A

Following a routine screening appointment for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), a 65-year-old postal worker is found to have an AAA measuring 4.2 cm at its widest diameter.
Which of the following would be the correct management for this patient?

A. Discharge with reassurance
B. Annual monitoring with ultrasound scanning
C. Three-monthly monitoring with ultrasound scanning
D. Referral to a specialist surgeon within two weeks for further assessment
E. Immediate admission under a surgical team for surgical repair

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by paramedics after being knocked off his bike by a car. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 7 (E1V1M5), but he is maintaining his airway, with good saturations via an oxygen mask, and with no added airway sounds. His pupils are equal and reactive to light, but he is being kept in a collar and blocks for C-spine immobilisation, and he has been log-rolled to protect his spine. Primary survey is complete, and there is no obvious explanation for his decreased consciousness.
What is the next best course of action?

A. Computed tomography (CT) traumagram (full-body CT)
B. Intubate the patient
C. Perform C-spine and chest and pelvis X-rays before proceeding to CT head
D. Proceed to theatre for a decompressive craniectomy
E. Commence secondary survey to detect further injuries

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department following a fall in the local supermarket. He is in an acute confusional state and unaccompanied, so a history is not available. Upon examination, the doctor noted digital clubbing and signs of a right-sided pleural effusion. The patient was euvolaemic.
Investigations:
Serum:
Na+ 114 mmol/l (135–145 mmol/l)
K+ 3.6 mmol/l (3.5–5 mmol/l)
Urea 2.35 mmol/l (2.5–6.7 mmol/l)
Osmolality 255 mOsmol/kg (282–295 mOsm/kg)
Urine:
Osmolality 510 mOsmol/kg (raised)
Na+ 50 mmol/l (25–250 mmol/l, depending on hydration state)
Which of the following could be the diagnosis?

A. Nephrotic syndrome
B. Small cell lung cancer
C. Addison’s disease
D. Cystic fibrosis
E. Diuretic therapy

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman presents with two episodes of post-coital bleeding. She reports that she noticed some red spotting immediately after intercourse, which settled shortly afterwards. She is on the combined oral contraceptive pill, with a regular partner, and does not use barrier contraception.
Examination reveals a malodorous, green, frothy discharge and an erythematous cervix with small areas of exudation. High vaginal and endocervical swabs were performed.
Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Azithromycin 1 g as a single dose
B. Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly, followed by 1 g of azithromycin
C. Metronidazole 400–500 mg twice daily for 5–7 days
D. Reassure the patient as no treatment is required
E. Refer for colposcopy

Correct Answer: C

A 70-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with painless sudden loss of vision in his eyes.
On examination, he has a right homonymous superior quadrantanopia.
What is the location of the lesion causing this visual field defect?

A. Left occipital visual cortex
B. Left temporal lobe optic radiation
C. Optic chiasm
D. Right optic tract
E. Right parietal lobe optic radiation

Correct Answer: B

100 000 people attend the Genitourinary Medicine Clinic over a 5-year period. A total of 56% of these patients were female. Following assessment, 87 men and 37 women were diagnosed with gonorrhoea.
What is the relative risk of gonorrhoea in males (compared with females) during the 5-year period?

A. 0.3
B. 0.7
C. 1.7
D. 2.4
E. 3.0

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old accountant presents to the general practitioner (GP) complaining of lethargy and muscle aches. The symptoms have come on gradually over the past few months, and now she feels that she is so tired after coming home from work that she cannot go to the gym like she used to. She is usually fit and well, with only a history of hay fever, for which she takes antihistamines during the summer. The patient does not smoke, drinks rarely, and follows a vegan diet.
There are no abnormalities to find on examination, and the GP orders a set of blood tests for further investigation. The results of these show a serum vitamin D (25OHD) of 22 nmol/l (normal value recommended > 50 nmol/l)
Which of the following compounds involved in the vitamin D synthesis pathway binds to the vitamin D receptor to exert its role in calcium homeostasis?

A. Calcidiol
B. Colecalciferol
C. Calcitriol
D. Previtamin D3
E. 24, 25-dihydroxycolecalciferol

Correct Answer: C

A 38-year-old woman comes to her general practitioner (GP) for routine blood tests at her new General Practice after recently moving locations. She informs you that her previous GP said that she had a ‘problem with her thyroid’, for which she was given medication. However, she is unable to tell you any more information. Her bloods return as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 18 mu/l 0.5–5.5 mu/l
Free thyroxine (T4) 9.2 pmol/l 9–18 pmol/l
Which of the following situations would result in the above biochemical results?

A. Thyrotoxicosis
B. Primary hypothyroidism
C. Secondary hypothyroidism
D. Sick euthyroid syndrome
E. Poor compliance with thyroxine

Correct Answer: E

Life expectancy of people in all countries throughout the world has continued to increase over the last 150 years.
What is the maximum lifespan for a human being estimated to be?

A. 111-120 years
B. 121-130 years
C. 131-140 years
D. 141-150 years
E. 151-160 years

Correct Answer: C
