A 22-year-old man with no previous history of skin problems presents with severe pruritus that is worse at night. The rash consists of tiny, red, intensely itchy papules on the limbs and trunk. His girlfriend is also reported to be itching. You examine his skin more closely.
Which one of the following would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this case?

A. Burrows
B. Crusts
C. Erythema
D. Excoriations
E. Nodules

Correct Answer: A

A 78-year-old man is admitted to hospital with worsening control of his chronic back pain. He admits he is struggling to continue with his oral morphine as it is making him feel nauseated. He enquires about whether he can have injections or an analgesia patch. He currently takes paracetamol 1000 mg orally (PO) four times daily (QDS), codeine 60 mg PO QDS, ibuprofen 400 mg PO three times daily (TDS) and morphine sulphate 30 mg PO QDS.
Which of the following fentanyl patches would be appropriate for this patient?

A. Fentanyl 12 µg/hour patch every 72 hours
B. Fentanyl 25 µg/hour patch every 72 hours
C. Fentanyl 50 µg/hour patch every 72 hours
D. Fentanyl 100 µg/hour patch every 72 hours
E. Fentanyl 120 µg/hour patch every 72 hours

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old woman presents at 18 weeks’ gestation, seeking advice. She was collecting her son from school the other day when the teacher alerted the parents that a few children had developed ‘slapped cheek syndrome’. One of those children was at her house with his parents for dinner over the weekend.
She is concerned she may have been infected and is worried about her baby. She had all her paediatric vaccinations, as per the National Health Service (NHS) schedule.
Which of the following should be the next step in the investigation of this patient?

A. No further investigation is required as she immune to the virus
B. No further investigation is required as there was no significant contact
C. Parvovirus B19 immunoglobulin G (IgG) and immunoglobulin M (IgM) serology
D. Rubella IgG serology and IgM serology
E. Varicella IgG serology

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman was on a skiing holiday when she slipped and twisted her knee while in the lift queue. She felt a sharp pain at the time and found it difficult to ski afterwards, feeling that her knee was unstable and would give way a bit. It was not particularly swollen afterwards and has never been very swollen since. On examination, she has a very mild effusion and a positive patellar tap. There is no joint line tenderness or pain on valgus or varus strain. McMurray’s test is negative, but painful. The main finding is of pain on the anterior drawer test, which seems intact.
Which of the following is the most likely abnormality?

A. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury
B. Medial collateral ligament injury
C. Complete patellar tendon rupture
D. Posterior cruciate ligament injury
E. Isolated meniscal tear

Correct Answer: A

A 43-year-old woman and her 16-year-old daughter are apprehended after being caught trying to destroy a statue in the town square. When asked why, they both explain how the statue comes to life and terrorises them at night, breaking things in their house, whispering violent thoughts in their minds and urging them to kill themselves. The police officer brings them to the Emergency Department where you evaluate them. The mother is a well-known psychiatric patient, but the daughter has never been seen before.
Which of the following is most likely to acutely reverse the psychosis in at least one of the patients?

A. Benzodiazepines
B. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
C. Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA)
D. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
E. Separate the patients

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man has erythema, vesicles and crusted ulcerations on the right scalp, forehead and periorbital region. The area is oedematous and painful. There are also some vesicles at the tip of the nose. The rash started 2 days ago, but several days prior to that, he noticed a headache in that area.
Which organism is most likely to be responsible for this rash?

A. Herpes simplex virus infection
B. Varicella-zoster virus
C. Malassezia furfur
D. Trichophyton verrucosum
E. Staphylococcus aureus

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old primiparous woman presented to Labour Ward triage at 34+1/40 with upper back/chest pain and a headache. The pregnancy had been straightforward to this point, with just some lower back pain over the preceding 2 weeks.
Obs: blood pressure 151/102, respiratory rate 18, sats 100% room air, heart rate 60 bpm, afebrile. On examination, she was well – PERL. Heart sounds normal, chest clear, no shortness of breath (SOB), abdo + uterus soft, non-tender (SNT), calves SNT. Normal reflexes. Urine dip showed nitrate +, leukocytes +, protein 1+. Electrocardiography (ECG) and cardiotocography (CTG) were both normal. Bloods were taken, with results pending.
In view of the likely diagnosis, what management step would you do first?

A. Admit for monitoring
B. Start po labetalol and admit for monitoring
C. Start IV magnesium sulphate
D. Arrange induction of labour
E. Give analgesia and discharge home

Correct Answer: B

An 81-year-old man has presented with a productive cough, green sputum, a temperature of 39.5°C, heart rate 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg. He has been given oxygen and started on intravenous antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia but despite full care he has not been responding to treatment. He is currently unresponsive.
The patient has a background of lung adenocarcinoma and is receiving chemotherapy. His wife says that he has had enough of his treatment, particularly as it has not been effective, and on his last admission he said he did not wish to have cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and this was recorded in the notes.
What is the best option regarding a do not resuscitate order for this patient?

A. Ask consultant oncologist
B. Ask admissions team
C. Ask his wife
D. Review in 24 hours and see if the patient gets better
E. Institute DNR

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman attends for a mammogram as part of the Breast Cancer Screening Programme.
At which age is the NHS Breast Cancer Screening Programme routinely recommended for women?

A. Between 50 and 83
B. Between 50 and 70
C. Between 30 and 50
D. Between 30 and 80
E. From 50 years old and is lifelong

Correct Answer: B

An 80-year-old man develops a bundle branch block during an acute myocardial infarction.
Which of the following arteries is most likely to be involved?

A. Left anterior descending artery
B. Circumflex branch of the left coronary artery
C. Acute marginal branch of the right coronary artery
D. Obtuse marginal branch of the circumflex artery
E. Atrioventricular nodal branch of the right coronary artery

Correct Answer: A

A 63-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department from a nursing home. The carer at the nursing home mentioned that the man complained of severe back pain and soon after became very dizzy and fell onto his side. When you perform a primary survey of the patient, you notice that his vitals are as follows: heart rate 123 bpm, blood pressure 95/60 mmHg, oxygen saturation 95% and temperature 37.2 °C.
On examination, he has exquisite abdominal and back pain and there is a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. He has been unconscious for the past three hours and is currently receiving intravenous fluids. He was diagnosed with aortic abdominal aneurysm six months ago.
Which of the following is the most important next step?

A. Computed tomography (CT) angiography
B. Immediate transfer to theatre
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen
D. Ultrasound
E. Vascular surgery review

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old woman who recently gave birth presents to the general practitioner with symptoms of rectal bleeding for the past two weeks. She has noticed fresh red blood on the toilet paper after passing a bowel motion, associated with some discomfort and itching around the anus. She has noticed bulging around the anus also. She is otherwise well, with no changes in bowel habit or recent weight loss. She is very worried that she may have bowel cancer, as her grandfather was diagnosed with colorectal cancer after episodes of rectal bleeding when he was 81.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Anal fissure
B. Haemorrhoids
C. Colorectal carcinoma
D. Fistula-in-ano
E. Sentinel pile

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man presents to his general practice surgery with a complaint of headaches. On physical examination, there are no abnormalities, but it is noticed that he has a blood pressure of 178/90 mmHg. The General Practitioner is concerned about a renal cause for the hypertension.
What is the best initial screening investigation for renovascular causes of hypertension?

A. Abdominal duplex ultrasound
B. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of abdomen
C. Glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c)
D. Magnetic resonance angiography of abdomen
E. Urine albumin : creatinine ratio

Correct Answer: A

A 47-year-old woman presents with haematemesis. She has vomited twice, producing large amounts of bright red blood, although the exact volume was not measured. On examination, you discover that there is a palpable spleen tip, and spider naevi over the chest, neck and arms.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Bleeding oesophageal varices
B. Mallory–Weiss tear
C. Peptic ulcer
D. Gastric ulcer
E. Oesophagitis

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old professional athlete is investigated in the Endocrinology Clinic for symptoms of low mood, reduced energy, and difficulty in maintain muscle mass. The patient also complains that his skin has felt dry and he notes that he has been experiencing some hair loss. As a part of his workup, the physician orders a glucagon stimulation test.
Which of the following is increased after the glucagon stimulation test?

A. C-peptide
B. Cortisol
C. Growth hormone
A. D. C-peptide, cortisol and growth hormone
E. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old woman is rushed into the Emergency Department (ED) by the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service (HEMS) in profound hypovolaemic shock. She was the driver in a multivehicle accident and has top-to-toe injuries including head, chest, abdomen, and long bones. She is intubated with C-spine control and a large bore subclavian line is inserted for resuscitation. She has had 2 units of packed red cells (PRC) and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) in the ambulance, and she still has a very faint thready pulse.
Her initial blood gas shows a pH of 6.9 Resuscitation is continued and she receives another 3 units of PRC and 3 units of FFP on the way to theatre. Platelets and cryoprecipitate are requested. Her pulse is still very thready and the anaesthetist is very distracted trying to place an arterial line for blood pressure monitoring and continued blood sampling. You notice a change in her electrocardiogram (ECG): it was narrow and tachycardic, but is now broad and becoming slower.
What is most likely to explain this?

A. Hypocalcaemia
B. Hypokalaemia
C. Hyperkalaemia
D. Clot in coronary artery
E. Transfusion reaction

Correct Answer: C

A known HIV patient presents to A&E due to increased confusion and drowsiness.
A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows:

What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Metastatic disease
B. Toxoplasmosis
C. Cerebral abscess
D. Tuberculosis
E. Multiple glioma

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old man is investigated by his general practitioner for potential problems in his hypothalamic–pituitary–thyroid axis. The following results were obtained:
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 5.0 mu/l (0.4–4.0 mu/l)
fT3 4.0 pmol/l (3.0–9.0 pmol/l)
These results are consistent with a diagnosis of which of the following?

A. A TSH-secreting tumour
B. Primary hypothyroidism
C. Secondary hypothyroidism
D. Hyperthyroidism
E. Need more information

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman with rheumatic fever has persistent breathlessness after her infectious illness resolves. You suspect she has mitral stenosis.
What is the best surface anatomical landmark at which to hear this murmur?

A. Second intercostal space, left of the sternum
B. Fourth intercostal space, left of the sternum
C. Fifth intercostal space, mid-axillary line
D. At the apex beat
E. At the xiphisternum

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with haematemesis. His friends say that he consumed a large quantity of alcohol earlier and experienced prolonged vomiting as he is not accustomed to drinking so much. On examination, his vital signs are: pulse 110 bpm, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg. Systemic examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following conditions is most probably responsible for the haematemesis?

A. Peptic ulcer disease
B. Mallory-Weiss tear
C. Oesophageal varices
D. Barrett’s oesophagus
E. Gastritis

Correct Answer: B

A 67-year-old woman is admitted to Accident and Emergency having suffered a massive upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage. She is known to have atrial fibrillation, which is treated with warfarin. She has had several episodes of copious haematemesis since admission, her blood pressure is 80/54 mmHg (normal <120/80 mmHg) and her heart rate is 136 beats/min (normal 60–100 beats/min). You have begun resuscitation with normal saline and have sent a group and save and a crossmatch. Her INR is currently 8.4 (0.9–1.3).
What is the most appropriate management of this patient’s INR?

A. Withhold warfarin
B. Withhold warfarin, give iv vitamin K
C. Withhold warfarin, give iv vitamin K and fresh-frozen plasma
D. Withhold warfarin, give iv vitamin K and prothrombin complex concentrate
E. Withhold warfarin, give iv vitamin K, prothrombin complex concentrate and fresh-frozen plasma

Correct Answer: D

A 67-year-old type 2 diabetic is due to have a vaginal hysterectomy in the morning. She normally takes Metformin in the morning and Gliclazide at breakfast and dinner time.
How should she manage her medications in preparation for surgery?

A. Take Metformin as normal. Omit Gliclazide.
B. Omit Metformin the day before and on the day. Omit Gliclazide on the day of surgery.
C. Omit Metformin the day before and on the day. Take Gliclazide as normal.
D. Omit Metformin on the day of surgery. Halve the Gliclazide doses at lunchtime and dinner.
E. Omit Metformin on the day of surgery. Omit the morning Gliclazide, and take the dinner time Gliclazide if she is able to eat.

Correct Answer: E

You are called to see a 26-year-old primiparous woman who has just delivered via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She had an active third stage of labour with 10 mg of Syntocinon® administered intramuscularly. The placenta was delivered ten minutes ago and appears complete. The midwife has called you, as there is a continuous small stream of fresh red blood loss. It is estimated that the patient has lost 1050 ml of blood so far. You palpate the abdomen, and you cannot feel any uterine contractions.
Observations:
Heart rate (HR) 107 bpm
Blood pressure (BP) 158/105 mmHg
Temperature 37.1 °C
Respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths per minute
Oxygen saturations 98% on air
Which of the following is the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Ergometrine infusion
B. Hysterectomy
C. Intrauterine balloon tamponade
D. Transfuse two units of O-negative blood
E. Uterine massage and oxytocin infusion

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old woman attends her general practice (GP). She has an established diagnosis of heart failure. She tells her GP she has recently read that certain drugs used in the management of heart failure can decrease mortality and wants to know more about this.
Which one of the following drugs has been shown to reduce mortality in heart failure?

A. Atenolol
B. Furosemide
C. Simvastatin
D. Spironolactone
E. Digoxin

Correct Answer: D

A nurse in the Emergency Department presents an electrocardiogram (ECG) to you. The patient is feeling breathless and has long-standing limited mobility. The ECG shows a sinus tachycardia with an S-wave in lead I, Q-wave in lead III and T-wave inversion in lead III.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
B. Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)
C. Pulmonary embolus
D. Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
E. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department following an upper gastrointestinal bleed. He requires a blood transfusion, but he is very wary of this and tells you that his wife had a life-threatening reaction following a transfusion after being given the wrong blood group. This patient’s blood group is Rhesus O–.
Which of the following donor blood types can be given to this patient?

A. A. A+, A−, B+, B−, O+, E. O−
B. A+, B+
C. A−, B−
D. O+ or E. O−
E. O−

Correct Answer: E

A 13-year-old boy cuts his leg while playing football in the park. His father takes him to see the emergency doctor in his GP surgery later that day as the bleeding has not stopped. The cut is not large, and is over the boy’s shin. They immediately applied pressure to the wound and then a plaster, however on examination the wound is still bleeding a small amount of blood. The boy’s father is aware that there is a bleeding disorder on his wife’s side of the family.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Continue to apply pressure as the bleeding will stop soon
B. Give fresh-frozen plasma, platelets and heparin
C. Give von Willebrand factor
D. Give desmopressin and tranexamic acid
E. Give recombinant factor 8

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old postal worker complains of a two-day history of worsening right-sided flank pain, radiating to the groin. The patient also reports an episode of frank haematuria. The patient has had a similar episode in the past, and at the time he was diagnosed with a kidney stone.
An ultrasound scan is carried out, which confirms the presence of a right-sided renal calculi.
Which of the following is most likely to be the underlying cause?

A. Bisoprolol use
B. Vitamin D deficiency
C. Low sodium diet
D. Hyperparathyroidism
E. Osteoarthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 69-year-old man presents to his neurologist with increasing spasticity of his right hand over the last one month. He has a diagnosis of motor neurone disease (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) and takes riluzole daily. Although the patient attends regular physiotherapy sessions and is compliant with his exercise regimen, the spasticity of his right hand is progressing rapidly. He asks his neurologist whether another form of treatment could be trialled to alleviate his spastic muscles.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s spasticity?

A. Baclofen
B. Diazepam
C. Edaravone
D. Memantine
E. Phenol injection

Correct Answer: A

A 29-year-old pregnant woman is recovering from cavernous venous sinus thrombosis. All nerves passing through the wall of the sinus have been affected.
Which of the following clinical signs most reflects cranial nerve damage due to this pathological lesion?

A. Ipsilateral corneal reflex absent
B. The patient is unable to resist forced lateral mandibular excursion with the mouth partially open
C. The patient is unable to blow out the cheeks
D. Loss of sensation over the lower lip
E. Loss of somatic sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Correct Answer: A

An 80-year-old hypertensive, diabetic smoker presents with sudden onset unilateral facial weakness, hemiparesis of the upper and lower limbs and sensory disturbance. All symptoms are on the same side. Global aphasia is also noted on examination. CT brain is normal. An ischaemic cerebrovascular accident (CVA) is diagnosed.
What is the most likely vascular territory involved?

A. Right middle cerebral artery
B. Basilar artery
C. Left middle cerebral artery
D. Right internal carotid artery
E. Left vertebral artery

Correct Answer: C

A 57-year-old publican presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset abdominal pain. She is vomiting profusely and complains of severe pain in the epigastric region that radiates through to her back. On questioning, she admits to having a few too many drinks at a hen party the previous night. Serum amylase is 1190 u/l.
Which of the following options is the most appropriate next step in the initial management?

A. Urgent computerised tomography (CT) of the abdomen
B. Abdominal ultrasound
C. Fluids by mouth
D. Fluid resuscitation
E. Intravenous antibiotics

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old man with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis visits his general practitioner with a 6-month history of cough and increasing shortness of breath. The GP is concerned that the patient’s symptoms may be linked to his arthritis
Which ONE of the following pulmonary conditions is most commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis?

A. Shrinking lung syndrome
B. Pulmonary hypertension
C. Apical fibrosis
D. Bronchiectasis
E. Yellow nail syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old woman has been referred by her optician to the eye clinic. She was involved in a road traffic accident and is worried that there may be trouble with her vision. On examination, her external eye, including the pupil, looks normal.
Investigations:
Slit-lamp: Quiet anterior chamber
Intra-ocular pressure: 35 mmHg
Fundoscopy: Optic disc appears slightly cupped
Visual field testing: Arcuate scotoma
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Acute angle closure glaucoma
B. Primary open angle glaucoma
C. Central retinal vein occlusion
D. Retinal detachment
E. Anterior uveitis

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman attends for her routine antenatal appointment at 16 weeks. This is her first pregnancy and she is well, but is concerned because her mother has just been diagnosed with diabetes. She is feeling well and has no other concerns. Her uterus is in keeping with dates. BP is normal. Urinalysis shows nit negative, leuc negative, protein negative.
What would you do next?

A. Arrange oral glucose tolerance test for the 24-28 weeks stage
B. Check HbA1c
C. Fasting plasma glucose
D. Dietary advice
E. Random blood glucose

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old woman was taking treatment for a relapse of her pulmonary tuberculosis. She adhered to the regimen rigidly and had completed 7 months of therapy. However, she now presents with low back pain and weakness. A repeat chest X-ray reveals clearing of the tubercular lesions and she is also gaining weight. Palpation of the pelvic bones reveals tenderness. Her blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 126 g/l 115–155 g/l
Calcium 1.8 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphorus 0.38 mmol/l 0.70–1.4 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 657 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Albumin 42 g/l 35–55 g/l
What is the reason for her abnormal blood tests?

A. Relapse of tuberculosis
B. Malnutrition
C. Anti-tuberculous drugs
D. Malignancy
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old man came to the Emergency Department with severe pain in his right knee and a high fever. On specific questioning he reports he has had urinary symptoms and a penile discharge for the past few weeks. On examination there is redness, swelling, and tenderness of the right knee joint and exquisite pain on movement.
Which of the following is the pathogenesis of the patient’s disease?

A. Infectious
B. Degenerative
C. Crystal deposition
D. Joint erosion
E. Bone remodeling

Correct Answer: A

A 37-year-old woman with Crohn’s disease presents with severe abdominal pain. Investigations reveal small intestinal obstruction, and a large stricture is found in the terminal part of ileum, intraoperatively. About 100 cm of the terminal ileum had to be resected.
Which of the following complications is the most common in this case?

A. Uric acid kidney stones
B. Iron deficiency
C. Vitamin B12 deficiency
D. Vitamin K deficiency
E. Vitamin D deficiency

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old woman with uncontrolled psoriasis is re-presenting with worsening symptoms. Potent topical treatments have failed to control her psoriasis.
What is the most appropriate progression in her management?

A. Changing the topical steroids
B. Add in narrow-band ultraviolet B (UVB) phototherapy
C. Commence biologics
D. Add in psoralen with local ultraviolet A (UVA) irradiation
E. Stop steroids and start narrow-band UVB phototherapy

Correct Answer: B

A 67-year-old retired gardener has presented with increasing confusion. He was found wandering around the town centre at night and brought in by a neighbour, as he suspected he was intoxicated; however, his daughter has attended and insists that the patient is teetotal. The family has been extremely concerned that he has had worsening memory over the past four months. GP notes from earlier in the year report no cognitive impairment. A mini-mental state examination (MMSE) is 13/30. On examination, there is an ataxic gait and myoclonus. You suspect Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD).
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to support this diagnosis?

A. Brain biopsy
B. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture and microscopy
C. Computed tomography (CT) head
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) head
E. Nerve biopsy

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to review a 48-year-old woman on the surgical ward. She complains of feeling ‘strange’, with numbness around her mouth and tingling in her hands and feet. The nurses tell you that she underwent parathyroid surgery earlier in the day.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 219 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Ca corrected 2.05 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Which of the following is the optimal management for this patient?

A. Give 10 ml of intravenous (iv) calcium gluconate
B. Give oral calcium supplements
C. Observe
D. Start an infusion of calcium-containing fluids at a rate of 0.05 mmol/kg/h
E. Commence her on vitamin D supplementation

Correct Answer: C

A diner in a restaurant grasps her neck and appears to be choking in the middle of a steak dinner. A nearby doctor attempts the Heimlich manoeuver several times, but to no avail. The woman eventually becomes unconscious and deeply cyanosed. The doctor decides to insert an emergency surgical airway using a sharp steak knife and a pen from which the inside has been removed.
Which of the following is the most optimal site for insertion of an emergency surgical airway?

A. Above the hyoid bone
B. Thyrohyoid membrane
C. Cricothyroid membrane
D. Anterior midline between the second and third tracheal cartilages
E. Anterior midline between the seventh and eighth tracheal cartilages

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman presents with epigastric pain radiating to the right upper quadrant, associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had two similar episodes 1 year ago which were short-lived. She has no other past medical history. She drinks one glass of wine per day.
On examination, she is tender in the epigastrium and has point tenderness in the right upper quadrant. She is tachycardic at 110 bpm. She is not clinically jaundiced. Liver function tests are normal. White cell count is 17.3; C-reactive protein (CRP) is 120; amylase is 32. An erect chest X-ray is unremarkable. She is apyrexial.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute cholecystitis
B. Acute pancreatitis
C. Biliary colic
D. Perforated gastric ulcer
E. Perforated duodenal ulcer

Correct Answer: A

A 73-year-old woman has mild chronic heart failure and a baseline estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 56 ml/min (> 90 ml/min) and otherwise normal electrolytes. She complains to her doctor of breathlessness and increasing pedal oedema and is started on a diuretic. Her serum biochemistry is rechecked two weeks later, and she is found to be hypokalaemic, hyponatraemic and hypocalcaemic.
Which diuretic is she most likely to have been prescribed?

A. Amiloride
B. Bendroflumethiazide
C. Furosemide
D. Indapamide
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: C

A 52-year old postman is found to have a raised fasting glucose and abnormal cholesterol results following routine blood testing as a part of his NHS health check. He is noted to have a BMI of 34. He is also hypertensive. The reviewing physician suspects that the patient has metabolic syndrome.
Which of the following statements is true about the metabolic syndrome?

A. High serum high-density lipoprotein (HDL) is typical
B. Patients usually have high circulating insulin levels
C. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is rare
D. Hypouricaemia is a feature
E. It is most common in individuals in their fifth decade of life

Correct Answer: B

A concerned mother visits her GP to discuss her 6-week-old baby. She is concerned as he is not feeding well, his urine has a musty smell and he has very dry skin all over his trunk, which is not responding to regular emollients. On examination, the baby’s weight has dropped from the 25th to the 9th centile, he has a mild tremor and his trunk is covered in an eczema-like rash. Her older son has an inborn error of metabolism and she is concerned this baby may also be affected.
Which of the following is a disorder of amino acid metabolism?

A. G6PD deficiency (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency)
B. Lesch–Nyhan syndrome
C. Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD)
D. Phenylketonuria (PKU)
E. Porphyria

Correct Answer: D

A 48-year-old medical registrar presents to the Emergency Department with severe back pain, inability to walk and urinary retention for four hours. On further questioning, he admitted to having dull nagging back ache for the past six months but did not seek any medical attention for it. He denies any recent fall or illness. He also denies any weight loss, loss of appetite or night sweats.
Examination revealed loss of sensation over medial aspect of his right leg, and weakness of right knee extension with areflexia of right patellar reflex. He also had saddle anaesthesia. His upper limbs and left lower limb had no neurological deficit.
Urgent magnetic resonance image (MRI) of lumbosacral spine is ordered.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cauda equina syndrome
B. Conus medullaris syndrome
C. Vitamin B12 deficiency
D. Cerebrovascular accident
E. Guillain–Barré syndrome

Correct Answer: A

Which one of the following cells is most likely to bind to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecule carrying a viral antigen that is expressed on the surface of a virally infected cell?

A. B cell
B. CD4 T cell
C. CD8 T cell
D. Natural killer cell
E. Macrophage

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman receives a letter inviting her to attend for a mammogram as a part of the NHS Breast Cancer Screening Programme.
If no abnormalities are found at screening, when will this patient be called for her next screening appointment?

A. Annually
B. At two years
C. At three years
D. At five years
E. No further screening required

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old boy is admitted by blue light ambulance to the Emergency Department (ED). He suffered from a blow to the side of his head during a rugby match, which was followed by a brief period of unconsciousness. On arrival to hospital, he could relate moments of the match prior to the blow. Around 40–50 minutes later, while waiting for his parents to arrive to hospital, he collapsed in the ED.
On examination, he has a blood pressure of 185/95 mmHg and pupils are sluggish and poorly reactive; GCS is 7.
Computed tomography (CT) head: mass adjacent to the area of head injury between the brain and the skull, leading to significant compression and mass effect; suspected temporal bone fracture.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next management step in this case?

A. Referral for neurosurgery
B. IV mannitol
C. Consideration of Burr-Hole
D. Call for help from a senior and an anaesthetist
E. Flexible fiberoptic bronchoscopy (FFB)

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old patient attends his general practitioner (GP) with a 3-month history of a dry cough. He has smoked 20 cigarettes per day for the past 10 years but has no other past medical history.
On examination, no abnormalities are detected. Observations including pulse rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, temperature and oxygen saturations are also normal. Spirometry is performed and shows forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) 3.5 litres (predicted = 3.45 litres) and forced vital capacity 4.7 litres (predicted 4.64 litres).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Community-acquired pneumonia
B. Angina
C. Asthma
D. Bronchiectasis
E. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Correct Answer: C

A 3-month-old infant has difficulty with feeding, failure to thrive and episodes of bluish pale skin during crying or feeding. Examination reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur that is heard over the pulmonic area and left sternal border. A chest radiograph during birth was normal. A second radiograph at presentation shows a boot-shaped heart.
Which of the following events will most likely explain the embryologic mechanism responsible for the development of this condition?

A. Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum
B. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral
C. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to divide
D. Underdevelopment of the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle
E. Incomplete absorption of the sinus venosus into the right atrium

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old woman has been treated for urinary tract infection three times during the last four months. A recent investigation reveals that the patient’s HbA1c is 113 mmol/mol (<42 mmol/mol), and she was diagnosed at this time with type II diabetes mellitus on the basis of elevated HbA1c; symptoms suggestive of diabetes mellitus include polyuria and polydipsia, with unexplained weight loss and general malaise. She again presents with dysuria and flank pain associated with fever and chills.
A derangement in which of the following aspects of the immune system may have contributed to recurrent infection?

A. Reduced IgA production
B. Reduced IgG production
C. Impaired cytotoxic T-cell function
D. Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis and phagocytosis
E. Increased microbial attachment to tissue surfaces due to changes in carbohydrate composition

Correct Answer: D

An 87-year-old patient presents to the Cardiology clinic. She has been seen previously for worsening congestive heart failure symptoms, but today she reports that her mobility and breathlessness have greatly improved, thanks to a new medication she has been prescribed. Routine blood tests report the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 122 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 187 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 2.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 115 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
What is the cause of her biochemical abnormality?

A. Antagonism of aldosterone
B. Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase
C. Inhibition of the epithelial sodium channel in the late distal convoluted tubules, connecting tubules and collecting ducts
D. Inhibition of the Na+K+2Cl− symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
E. Inhibition of the production of angiotensin II

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old woman who is a law student has severe anxiety about public speaking and in informal social settings. She avoids situations where she might have to enter into conversations with strangers. She reports that she thinks others are frustrated by her inability in casual social interactions and that she ‘feels stupid and awkward’. Her social problems are also affecting her academic performance. She is considering leaving university for a less stressful environment.
Which is the most appropriate form of psychotherapy for this woman?

A. Cognitive behavioural therapy
B. Psychoanalytic psychotherapy
C. Network therapy
D. Self-help group
E. Vocational counseling

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl is suspected of suffering from insulin-dependent diabetes. She undergoes a glucose tolerance test following an overnight fast.
Which of the following results would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

A. A plasma glucose level of 4 mmol/l at zero time
B. A peak of plasma glucose occurring between 1 and 2 h that stays high
C. An ‘overshoot’ in the decline of plasma glucose at 3.5 h
D. A glucose concentration of 5.2 mmol/l at 4 h
E. A low HbA1c

Correct Answer: B

A 90-year-old patient presents with dysphagia and upper back pain radiating between the scapulae. During gastrointestinal workup, he is noted to have a calcified aneurysm in the descending thoracic aorta.
The descending thoracic aorta lies in which of the following compartments of the mediastinum?

A. Superior only
B. Posterior only
C. Middle only
D. Middle and superior
E. Superior and posterior
F. Anterior and middle

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old man is admitted with a 30-min history of severe central ‘crushing’ chest pain radiating down the left arm. He is profusely sweating and looks ‘grey’. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia and 3-mm ST elevation in V3–V6.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Give the patient aspirin, ticagrelor and low molecular weight heparin
B. Give the patient aspirin, ticagrelor and low-molecular-weight heparin, and perform thrombolysis therapy
C. Give the patient aspirin, ticagrelor and low-molecular-weight heparin, followed by a primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
D. Give the patient nitrates, aspirin and ticagrelor, and await cardiac enzymes
E. Treat the pain with sublingual glyceryl trinitrate (GTN), aspirin and oxygen, and review the patient in 15 min

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman presents to the general practitioner (GP) at 26 weeks’ gestation with a vesicular, itchy rash that has developed this morning over her arms, legs and trunk. She shows you some vesicles on her palms as well. She reports feeling generally unwell for the last two days with a headache.
She was visiting her niece in hospital last week, and a child on the ward was treated for a similar rash. Observations are stable.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Immediate admission to hospital
B. Immediate fetal growth scan to assess the baby’s wellbeing
C. Varicella immunoglobuln G (IgG) vaccination
D. Oral aciclovir and symptomatic relief
E. Termination of pregnancy

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman who has recently sustained a right neck of femur (NOF) fracture is referred for a DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) scan to assess her bone density. Her results are shown below:
Region T score (standard deviations below mean)
Left NOF -3.1
Right NOF -2.9
Spine (L1–L4) -2.2

What do her results show?

A. Osteoporosis left NOF, osteopenia right NOF and osteopenia of spine
B. Osteoporosis left NOF, osteopenia right NOF, normal bone density of spine
C. Osteopenia left NOF, right NOF and spine
D. Osteoporosis right NOF, left NOF and spine
E. Osteoporosis right NOF, osteoporosis left NOF, osteopenia of spine

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-hour history of searing, interscapular back pain of sudden onset. His past medical history includes hypertension, for which he takes ramipril and amlodipine.
His vital signs are as follows: heart rate 110 beats per minute, blood pressure (BP) 140/91 mmHg, respiratory rate 22 per minute, oxygen saturation 95% on room air, temperature 37.1°C. On examination of the chest, there are no additional positive findings. The lungs expand symmetrically and have normal breath sounds. Heart sounds I and II are present with no additional sounds.
His initial electrocardiogram (ECG) was normal and a portable chest X-ray displayed a widened mediastinum as the only abnormality.
Which of the following investigations is most useful for diagnosing the patient’s likely underlying condition?

A. 24 hour ECG
B. Troponin
C. Coronary angiogram
D. CT thorax with intravenous (IV) contrast
E. Echocardiogram

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old woman attends her general practice surgery post discharge from hospital. She was admitted three weeks ago with chest pain and diagnosed with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. While admitted, she was started on a number of new medications to prevent further cardiac events and would now like some more advice.
What is the most appropriate advice to give on her dose of statin?

A. Simvastatin 40 mg od
B. Simvastatin 80 mg od
C. Atorvastatin 20 mg od
D. Atorvastatin 40 mg od
E. Atorvastatin 80 mg od

Correct Answer: E

A 38-year-old patient came to the general practitioner complaining of a pale, velvety, hypopigmented patch over his chest and shoulder, which he has had for the last few months. He has no pain, itching or scaling over the lesion. He has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, for which he is taking methotrexate. On examination, there is scaling on scraping.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A. Toxic epidermal necrolysis
B. Tinea versicolor
C. Tinea corporis
D. Vitiligo
E. Fixed drug reaction

Correct Answer: B

A 73-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Department after being found in an acute confusional state. He was drowsy and aggressive and tried to hit out at the home help when she visited his home that morning. He is known to have a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and continues to smoke 20 cigarettes per day, and is currently undergoing investigations for prostatism. On examination, he is pyrexial at 38.2 °C and has coarse crackles and wheeze in both lungs on auscultation.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 14.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 231 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 128 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 120 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urine Blood +
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Worsening dementia
B. Diabetes insipidus
C. Lower respiratory tract infection
D. Urinary tract infection
E. Viral encephalitis

Correct Answer: C

An ECG shows small T-waves, ST depression, and prominent U-waves.
What is the likely cause of these abnormalities?

A. Hypocalcaemia
B. Hypokalaemia
C. Hyponatraemia
D. Hyperkalaemia
E. Hypercalcaemia

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man with advanced cancer of the stomach complains of hoarseness. On clinical examination, he has enlarged deep cervical lymph nodes.
The hoarse voice is a result of enlarged nodes pressing on which of the following?

A. Recurrent laryngeal branch of the vagus
B. External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
C. Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
D. Nerve to the cricothyroid muscle
E. Pharyngeal branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 34-year-old woman comes to her General Practitioner four weeks after a positive home pregnancy test. Her medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, generalised tonic–clonic seizures and hyperlipidaemia. Her obstetric history is remarkable for an elective termination of pregnancy at 19 weeks for trisomy 18. Her current medications include hydroxychloroquine, phenytoin, atorvastatin and a herbal supplement. She drinks socially and averages one drink per week and does not smoke. Her physical examination is unremarkable.
Given her medical history, which one of the following fetal complications is most likely to occur?

A. Meningomyelocele
B. Omphalocele
C. Hypoplastic fingernail defects
D. Pulmonary hypertension
E. Seizures

Correct Answer: C

An 80-year-old left-handed man with permanent atrial fibrillation presents with difficulty finding words and weakness affecting his right arm and leg. The onset of these symptoms was sudden and they have been present for 36 hours. His vision is not affected.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Transient ischaemic attack
B. Total anterior circulation syndrome stroke (TACS)
C. Posterior circulation syndrome stroke (POCS)
D. Lacunar syndrome stroke (LACS)
E. Partial anterior circulation syndrome stroke (PACS)

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old man was involved in a motor vehicle crash and was rushed to the Emergency Department where a chest tube was placed to drain fluid. The following anatomic structures are related to the thoracic wall:
internal intercostal muscle
skin
innermost intercostal muscle
parietal pleura
external intercostal muscle
visceral pleura
Which of the following best represents the order of structures traversed by the tube during the procedure?

A. 4-5-1-3-2
B. 2-5-1-3-6-4
C. 2-3-1-5-4
D. 2-1-3-5-4
E. 2-5-1-3-4

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old patient presents for an annual review. He has no significant past medical history. He is a smoker and has a family history of ischaemic heart disease: body mass index (BMI) 27.4, blood pressure (BP) 178/62 mmHg, fasting serum cholesterol 7.9 mmol/l (normal value < 5.17 mmol/l), triglycerides 2.2 mmol/l (normal value < 1.7 mmol/l), fasting glucose 5.8 mmol/l (normal value 3.9–5.6 mmol/l).
Which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment for his cholesterol?

A. Reassure and repeat in one year
B. Dietary advice and repeat in six months
C. Start atorvastatin
D. Start bezafibrate
E. Start ezetimibe

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) after having been found to have a low haemoglobin level when he went to give blood a few days ago. He reports having noticed some fatigue and breathlessness on mild exertion over the past few weeks. He has given blood on two occasions previously, although the last occasion was a year ago. He has been on 30 mg lansoprazole daily for several years for acid reflux, and he reports his reflux is well controlled. He is also on cetirizine for hay fever. He has no nausea or vomiting; there have been no changes in his bowels, and he has not noticed any blood in his stools or his urine. His diet is varied, and he is not a vegetarian or a vegan. Chest and abdominal examinations are normal. Urinalysis is NAD. Blood test results are given below:
Investigation Patient Normal
Haemoglobin 100 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 72.0 fl 82–100 fl
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 355 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Ferritin 6.0 µg/l 20–250 µg/l
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) tissue transglutaminase antibody (tTGA) is negative and IgA level is normal.
What is the most appropriate initial management step?

A. Trial of oral iron (eg ferrous sulphate), with repeat full blood count in 3 weeks
B. Faecal occult blood test
C. Referral to gastroenterology
D. Referral to haematology
E. Dietary advice

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department with breathlessness and an episode of haemoptysis which came on suddenly over the last two hours. He had recently returned home from a holiday in Singapore and had been complaining to his wife about a painful left leg. Upon arrival at the hospital, he is found to have an oxygen saturation of 89% on room air, a blood pressure of 90/80 mmHg and a heart rate of 130 bpm. His only medical history to note is hypertension, which is managed with lifestyle measures only. He does not smoke and, until recently, worked as a gardener.
While initial management is commenced, the patient suddenly becomes unresponsive, stops breathing and is found to have no pulse. Despite prolonged attempts at resuscitation, the patient is pronounced dead after 45 minutes.
Which of the following vessels is most likely to be affected, leading to this patient’s death?

A. Pulmonary artery
B. Pulmonary vein
C. Azygous vein
D. Brachiocephalic
E. Coronary artery

Correct Answer: A

An 18-year-old man has numerous inflamed, open comedones on his face, chest and neck, due to acne vulgaris.
Which micro-organism produces inflammatory fatty acids by degrading sebum in cases of acne vulgaris?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Propionibacterium acnes
C. Poxvirus
D. Papillomavirus
E. Malassezia furfur

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a headache for 48 hours.
He has photophobia and neck stiffness. He is pyrexial at 39 °C and Brudzinski sign is positive.
His past medical history includes human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and intravenous drug use (IVDU). He admits to non-compliance of his highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) medication.
A lumbar puncture is taken, and an analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows budding yeast cells which stain strongly to India Ink.
Which antimicrobial medication would you recommend?

A. Amphotericin B
B. Azithromycin
C. Ceftriaxone
D. Co-amoxiclav
E. Clotrimazole

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old primip is brought in by ambulance at 37+3 weeks’ gestation. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy so far, and she is a smoker. This morning, she had sudden-onset abdominal pain, which has become very severe. The uterus is hard and contracted. There is no vaginal bleeding, and the os is closed, with a long cervix. She looks clammy and pale.
Her observations are as follows: heart rate (HR) 130 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 98/56 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturations 96% on air, and temperature 37.1 °C. The cardiotocogram shows fetal distress, and fetal movements cannot be palpated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Admit for monitoring and analgesia
B. Emergency Caesarean section
C. Induction of labour
D. Intravenous (iv) fluids, iv paracetamol and reassess
E. Ultrasound scan to assess fetal wellbeing

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old patient came to the general practitioner, complaining of bloody diarrhoea. He has had these symptoms for the last 6 months. He also has fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and a painful, erythematous rash over the anterior surface of the leg. A faecal occult blood test was positive. Colonoscopy showed crypt abscesses.
Which of the following skin lesions is commonly present in this patient?

A. Morbilliform rash
B. Erythema multiforme
C. Tinea corporis
D. Urticaria
E. Erythema nodosum

Correct Answer: E

A 22-year-old man presents with an acute onset of shortness of breath with associated stabbing chest pain which is worse on inspiration. He is normally fit and well and active. He is a smoker and drinks occasionally. The patient is diagnosed with a pneumothorax due to spontaneous rupture of an apical bulla.
Which of the following options is the best description of the lung volume and chest wall position in this patient?

A. The lung expands outward and the chest wall collapses inward
B. The lung expands outward and the chest wall springs outward
C. The lung collapses inward and the chest wall collapses inward
D. The lung collapses inward and the chest wall expands outward
E. The lung volume is unaffected and the chest wall springs outward

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman with an intensely itchy bullous rash presents to the general practitioner. She tells you that the spots begin as intensely itchy papules or vesicles and then she cannot resist scratching them. There is also a history of intermittent diarrhoea and abdominal bloating, but this has been previously put down to irritable bowel syndrome. Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 111 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 191 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 92 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Anti-endomysial antibody Positive
Histology Granular IgA deposits in the
dermal papillae of peri-lesional skin.
Neutrophil infiltration and fibrin
deposition seen on light microscopy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pemphigus
B. Bullous pemphigoid
C. Acute intermittent porphyria
D. Dermatitis herpetiformis
E. Epidermolysis bullosa

Correct Answer: D

A patient with known human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents at her booking visit at eight weeks’ gestation. Her booking blood tests include a CD4 count of 480 and a viral load of 40 copies/ml. She is not currently on any antiretrovirals. She wishes to have a vaginal delivery if possible.
Which of the following best describes this patient’s HIV management during her pregnancy?

A. Combined antiretroviral therapy starting by 24 weeks and continuing lifelong
B. Combined antiretroviral therapy starting by 24 weeks until delivery
C. No antiretroviral therapy required as the viral load is low
D. Zidovudine monotherapy starting by 24 weeks until delivery
E. Zidovudine monotherapy starting now until delivery

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man with hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia suffered severe central chest pain lasting one hour. His electrocardiogram (ECG) in the ambulance shows anterolateral ST segment elevation. His symptoms stabilised with medical treatment in the ambulance, but suddenly he dies while on the way to hospital.
What is the most likely cause of his deterioration and death?

A. Mural thrombosis
B. Myocardial wall rupture
C. Papillary muscle rupture
D. Pulmonary oedema
E. Ventricular arrhythmia

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old pregnant woman attends her midwife-led booking visit. She informs the midwife that she has diabetes and has undergone foot checks in the past. She smokes two cigarettes and drinks two glasses of wine each day. She has just had her cervical screening test, which was normal.
The midwife goes through each of these things with her, recommending she stops drinking alcohol and smoking. She then goes through the booking visit and offers the patient a routine human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test.
Which one of the following is an example of tertiary prevention?

A. Alcohol intervention
B. Foot check in diabetic patients
C. Smoking cessation advice in early pregnancy
D. Cervical screening
E. HIV screening

Correct Answer: B

Mr Currie, a long-term psoriasis sufferer, comes to see you with new-onset joint pain, stiffness and swelling. You suspect arthritis.
Which of the following is a subtype of psoriatic arthropathy?

A. Gout-like
B. Osteoarthritis-like
C. Pseudogout-like
D. Reactive arthritis-like
E. Rheumatoid arthritis-like

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old nulliparous woman has presented to her General Practitioner (GP), requesting an appointment to discuss contraceptive options. She has previously relied on condoms for contraception but would now prefer alternative means of contraception. Her last menstrual period was one week ago. Her previous cervical smears were normal, and she denies any symptoms consistent with a diagnosis of a sexually transmitted infection. She has a past medical history of epilepsy, for which she takes regular carbamazepine, and menorrhagia secondary to several large uterine fibroids, for which she takes tranexamic acid. She does not wish to have children in the near future. She does not smoke. The GP decides to take a blood pressure reading and calculates the patient’s body mass index (BMI):
Investigation Result
Blood pressure 132/71 mmHg
BMI 28 kg/m2
Which of the following would be the contraceptive most suited to the patient?

A. Progestogen-only injectable
B. Copper intrauterine device
C. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system
D. Progestogen-only implant
E. Combined oral contraceptive pill

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old woman, a mother of three, comes to see you on day 20 postpartum and asks for contraception. She is currently alternating between breastfeeding and bottle-feeding her newborn, struggling with sleepless nights, and wants a referral for Fallopian tube ligation as she explains that, at present, she does not want any other children. She is a smoker.
Which of the following is the best method of contraception in this patient?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
B. Intrauterine system
C. No contraception is required as she is breastfeeding
D. Progesterone-only pill
E. Tubal ligation (sterilisation)

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old man presents for a general check-up. He is well in himself and reports no symptoms.
On examination, he has a body mass index (BMI) of 35 kg/m2 and there are some thickened folds of skin in his axilla and the nape of his neck. His blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg. He is a non-smoker and does not drink.
A set of blood work is ordered. He demonstrated impaired fasting glucose in addition to the results below.
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 135 g/l 135–175 g/l
Cholesterol 6.2 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
Triglyceride 4.1 mmol/l 0–1.5 mmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 65 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 25 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) 35 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
What is the next best investigation?

A. Screen for hereditary haemochromatosis
B. Haematinics
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan abdomen
D. Ultrasound liver
E. Serum ceruloplasmin

Correct Answer: D

An 18-month-old child is brought to see you with concerns about his development.
Which of the following sets of findings on history and examination reflects age-appropriate development for this child?

A. Able to stand independently and walk with a wide-based gait, uses three words other than ‘mama’ and ‘dada’, demonstrates a neat pincer grip, indicates wants, drinks from a cup and plays ball with the examiner
B. Runs, walks up and down steps holding on, copies a vertical line, builds a tower of six blocks, points to several body parts, combines two different words, says 30 clear words, helps with simple tasks, uses a spoon and helps with dressing and undressing
C. Sits without support, attempts to crawl, points with index finger, holds objects between thumb and fingers, constantly babbles, imitates speech sounds, feeds self with easy-to-grasp food, plays peek-a-boo, attempts to get toys out of reach
D. Stands and walks confidently, bends or crouches to pick up an object, makes a tower of 2–3 blocks, scribbles, tries to sing, says six clear words, points to named pictures, plays games, enjoys sitting and looking at books, points to body parts, clothing and objects and helps with dressing
E. Walks heel to toe, able to stand on one leg for 1 second, copies a circle and a cross, builds a tower of 6–8 blocks, uses a fork and spoon, able to undo a button, names objects and body parts, gives first name, follows three-step instructions, identifies two colours, plays interactive games, dresses without supervision

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old diabetic lady is admitted with malaise by her general practitioner (GP). Liver function tests (LFTs) were taken by her GP: bilirubin 41 μmol/l, AST 46 iu/l, ALT 56 iu/l, GGT 241 iu/l, ALP 198 iu/l. On examination: abdomen is soft and non-tender, and there are no palpable masses or organomegaly.
Which one of the following is the next best investigation?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan abdomen
B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C. Autoantibody screen
D. Ultrasound scan of the abdomen
E. PABA test

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman is scheduled for an elective cholecystectomy tomorrow. She is a type 1 diabetic, and takes long-acting insulin (Lantus) in the morning and evening, as well as boluses of rapid-acting insulin with her meals.
Which perioperative insulin regime is most appropriate?

A. Continue long-acting insulin, stop rapid-acting insulin, and put on fixed-scale insulin infusion
B. Continue long-acting insulin, stop rapid-acting insulin, and put on variable-rate insulin infusion
C. Continue normal insulin regime
D. Stop long-acting and rapid-acting insulin and put on fixed-scale insulin infusion
E. Stop long-acting and rapid-acting insulin and put on variable-rate insulin infusion

Correct Answer: B

A 12-year-old boy presents to his General Practitioner. He has been feeling unwell for the last two days with a sore throat, general malaise and nasal congestion. He has not had a cough or fever. On examination, his pulse rate is 70 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute and temperature 37.3 °C. You also assess that he has tender, swollen anterior cervical lymph nodes.
Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate to consider requesting?

A. Chest X-ray
B. Full blood count
C. Sputum culture
D. Throat swab
E. Viral testing

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman is referred to your Surgical Clinic via her General Practitioner (GP), complaining of recent heartburn and indigestion which is worse at night. She denies any other symptoms from the gastrointestinal (GI) point of view. She smokes 20 a day and has a normal diet. On examination, you note that she is a rather large lady with a body mass index (BMI) of 37. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. You organise an endoscopy for this lady and the report is shown below:
Endoscopy – oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD)
The OGD was carried out with xylocaine throat spray and intubation was straightforward. Normal oesophagus. A 5-cm hiatus hernia is seen and confirmed on J-manoeuvre. The stomach and duodenum up to D2 appear to be normal. CLO test was negative. Z-line at 45 cm.
What would be your next best step in managing this patient?

A. Refer for fundoplication
B. Refer for oesophageal manometry studies
C. Refer for 24-hour pH studies
D. Conservative therapy with weight loss, smoking cessation and dietary advice, and proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy
E. Triple therapy for Helicobacter pylori

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes is diagnosed with otitis externa. He is treated with topical antibiotics by his GP for 2 weeks without resolution of signs or symptoms. He presents to the Emergency Department with increasing otalgia and marked swelling of the external auditory canal. On examination, the external auditory canal is oedematous and slight facial asymmetry is noted. Malignant (necrotising) otitis externa is diagnosed.
What is the likely underlying aetiology?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal
C. Basal cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal
D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
E. Fungal infection

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old man was admitted via ambulance as a trauma call, after being involved in a road traffic collision. He has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10 on admission, and a primary survey is performed that reveals asymmetric pupils, but with no obvious external head injury, an obvious open right forearm fracture without neurovascular compromise, absent breath sounds on the right side, extensive right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain with a painful abdomen and a systolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg.
When approaching intervention and stabilisation of the patient, which injury should take priority?

A. RUQ pain and potential abdominal bleeding
B. Open forearm fracture
C. Asymmetric pupils and potential head injury
D. Absent breath sounds on the right side
E. Hypotension

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old man has recently been diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. Investigation has revealed that he has distal disease only. He has a moderate exacerbation of his disease with an average of 4–5 episodes of bloody diarrhoea per day. There is no anaemia. His pulse rate is 80 bpm. He has no fever. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are normal.
Which is the most appropriate medication to use in the first instance in this exacerbation?

A. Codeine phosphate
B. Cyclosporine
C. Infliximab
D. Mesalazine
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman presents to labour ward in active labour. She is having regular contractions, is sweating profusely, and in a lot of pain.
Which of the following hormones is causing her contractions?

A. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
B. Prolactin
C. Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)
D. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)
E. Oxytocin

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department after a fall. She was standing on a chair, decorating, when she fell, and she immediately had severe pain in her hip.
X-rays reveal a fracture of the left neck of the femur. Her medical history included a seizure disorder, for which she was taking topiramate. Her menstruation cycle is normal. She is a non-vegetarian and a non-smoker and works as a landscaper.
What is the most likely reason for her fracture?

A. Vitamin D deficiency
B. Multiple myeloma
C. Chronic acidosis
D. Only the trauma
E. Osteoporosis

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old man has an 8-week history of auditory hallucinations and delusions, on a background of a one-year history of personality change, low mood and disorganisation. He attends his GP with his mother but then refuses emergency psychiatric admission. His GP is concerned that he is at risk to himself and others in the community and does not have the capacity to make decisions about his medical care. Assessment with regard to need for involuntary admission is arranged to his local psychiatric unit.
Which section of the Mental Health Act would apply to his admission for treatment following assessment by a mental health specialist?

A. Community treatment order under section 17 of the Mental Health Act
B. Detainment under section 2 of the Mental Health Act
C. Emergency detainment under section 4 of the Mental Health Act
D. Holding under section 5 of the Mental Health Act
E. Treatment order under section 3 of the Mental Health Act

Correct Answer: B

A 17-year-old female patient presents to the Emergency Department following an overdose of some medication she found in the house. She has currently a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15/15 but is unwilling to reveal what she took. Her father thinks that it was acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. As part of her work-up, a venous blood gas is taken.
What biochemical abnormality would you expect if her father were correct?

A. Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap
B. Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap
C. Metabolic alkalosis
D. Respiratory acidosis
E. Respiratory alkalosis

Correct Answer: B

You are called to see an obstetric patient with an epidural in situ. She is complaining of pain, is feeling light-headed and has tingling to her arms, lips and face. As you arrive, she collapses and has no palpable pulse. You notice that her drip epidural catheter is not attached and, looking at her intravenous (iv) fluid, you realise that 0.125% bupivacaine has been running through her iv drip. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is in progress and help is on its way.
What is your first priority?

A. Fill in an incident form as soon as possible
B. Continue CPR, secure a definitive airway and remove the epidural
C. Continue CPR, secure a definitive airway and recommence the epidural
D. Continue CPR, secure a definitive airway, give Intralipid and perform an emergency Caesarean section within 5 minutes
E. Continue CPR, secure a definitive airway, give Intralipid and perform an emergency Caesarean section within 10 minutes

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old, fit and well woman develops severe headache, confusion and nausea on day 5 of climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in her gap year.
A doctor travelling with the group examines her and finds her to be tachycardic with a raised temperature. They diagnose high-altitude cerebral oedema.
What is the most important step in the management of this patient?

A. Acetazolamide
B. Descent
C. Dexamethasone
D. Oxygen
E. Rest

Correct Answer: B

A 37-year-old woman presents with four miscarriages. She has an uneventful pregnancy until the second trimester where she miscarries. The patient has no significant past medical history and has never had any surgery to the abdomen or female reproductive tract. She has a younger brother with learning difficulties and microcephaly. Her husband is fit and healthy as well, and he has no significant family history.
What is the most likely reason for the miscarriages?

A. Reciprocal translocation of chromosomes
B. Down syndrome (Trisomy 21)
C. Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18)
D. Fragile X
E. Mutation of the cystic fibrosis gene

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman presents with a feeling of having a lump in her throat and feeling choked up. This has been present for six months. The feeling is intermittent and has not progressed. She has no difficulty swallowing food or liquids, in fact eating and drinking help to relieve the symptoms. She has not lost weight. She is a non-smoker. She has a past medical history of generalised anxiety disorder managed by cognitive behavioural therapy.
Examination is normal, with no cervical lymphadenopathy.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Barrett’s oesophagus
B. Globus pharyngeus
C. Laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma
D. Reflux oesophagitis
E. Zenker’s diverticulum

Correct Answer: B

An 18-month-old presents with a 4-day history of high fever and coryza. His parents bring him to clinic with a rash that started today on his chest and has now spread to his arms. He has been off his food for the last 48 hours, but his fever has settled. On examination, he is apyrexial. Other vital signs are normal. He is alert and responsive. He has cervical lymphadenopathy, with enlarged red tonsils but no pus. Both tympanic membranes are slightly pink. His chest is clear. He has a pink blanching maculopapular rash to his torso and arms.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Parvovirus infection
B. Scarlet fever
C. Meningococcal septicaemia
D. Roseola infantum
E. Glandular fever

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old student presents to her general practitioner because of a tremor she has noticed in her left hand over the past few months. On examination, she has subtle dysarthria and a wide-based gait. When the doctor passively moves her left elbow, he notices hypertonia which is independent of whether he moves her elbows slowly or briskly. She has a history of bipolar disorder and was started on olanzapine by her psychiatrist 2 weeks ago.
Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Dat scan
B. 24-h urine collection
C. Urine toxicology
D. Computed tomography (CT) brain
E. Electroencephalography (EEG)

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old woman is admitted to the Acute Admissions Ward, having taken an overdose. She is drowsy and poorly responsive. On examination, her blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg, and her pulse is 42 bpm and regular; there are bibasal crackles on auscultation of her chest. While in the unit, she suffers from a tonic–clonic seizure.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 141 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 200 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 74 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glucose 2.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Electrocardiography Severe bradycardia,
no signs of acute ischaemia
Which of the following medications has she most likely taken an overdose of?

A. Digoxin
B. Theophylline
C. Diltiazem
D. Amitriptyline
E. Propranolol

Correct Answer: E

A 12-year-old boy is brought into the Emergency Department by his mother. He is known to have severe haemophilia A and has been having a nosebleed for over 30 minutes. He is on a regular injection to manage his condition but is aware of the need for potential further treatment if he has a significant bleed.
Which of the following is the best option for the management of this patient?

A. Desmopressin
B. Recombinant factor VIII
C. Recombinant factor IX
D. Recombinant factor X
E. Local measures

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old woman with sickle-cell disease is seen in Haematology Outpatients. She has had a number of recent admissions with sickle-cell crisis and abdominal pain and is suspected of having had multiple splenic infarcts.
Which of the following blood film abnormalities would be suggestive of hyposplenism?

A. Howell–Jolly bodies
B. Rouleaux formation
C. Schistocytes
D. Tear drop cells
E. Toxic granulation

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old woman with a history of asthma and eczema presents to her General Practitioner and wants to know why she continues to wheeze hours after exposure to pollen. She is known to have an allergy to tree pollen.
Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for this?

A. Exposure to another allergen
B. Inflammation followed by mucosal oedema
C. Persistent bronchospasm causing smooth muscle hypertrophy
D. Pollen stuck on cilia
E. Systemic absorption of pollen antigen through lungs

Correct Answer: B

A 4-week-old baby boy begins to exhibit forceful vomiting after each meal. Before this, he had been gaining weight normally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Congenital duodenal atresia
B. Hirschsprung’s disease
C. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TOF)
D. Pyloric stenosis
E. Necrotising enterocolitis (NEC)

Correct Answer: D

In Scotland, the rules on treatment and investigation of 16-year olds who lack capacity to consent are set by:

A. Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000
B. Children (Scotland) Act 1995
C. Mental Health (Scotland) Act 2000
D. The Scotland’s Commissioner for Children and Young People guidance
E. The decision regarding young person’s competence in R v Gillick

Correct Answer: A

A 57-year-old Afro-Caribbean man presents to you with increasing difficulty in breathing and shortness of breath. A chest examination reveals decreased expansion on the right side of the chest, along with decreased breath sounds and stony dullness to percussion. A chest X-ray reveals a pleural effusion which you proceed to tap for diagnostic serum biochemistry, cytology and culture. The cytology and culture results are still awaited, although the serum biochemistry returns back showing the following:
Pleural fluid protein 55 g/dl
Pleural fluid cholesterol 4.5 g/dl
Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) : serum ratio 0.7
Which of the following might be considered as a diagnosis in this patient?

A. Myxoedema
B. Meigs syndrome
C. Sarcoidosis
D. Cardiac failure
E. Nephrotic syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old child was admitted due to high fever, cervical lymph node enlargement, conjunctival congestion, redness of lips and palms and desquamation of fingertips. On examination, there is erythema of the oral cavity. Investigations revealed Hb 110 g/l and platelet count 450 000. Symptoms resolved after 2 weeks. During the third week, the child dies unexpectedly. Autopsy findings revealed vasculitis of coronary arteries and aneurysm formation.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Scarlet fever
B. Rheumatic fever
C. Diphtheria
D. Marfan syndrome
E. Kawasaki’s disease

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department as a pre-alert with chest pain. He has a history of angina, hypertension and high cholesterol and is a current smoker. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed shortly after arrival. It shows ST elevation in leads II, III and aVF.
Which coronary artery is most likely to be the culprit?

A. Left anterior descending
B. Left circumflex
C. Left coronary artery
D. Right coronary artery
E. Right marginal artery

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old woman is referred to Ophthalmology with bilateral cataracts. She reports gradual worsening of her vision over many years and struggles with night-time driving due to glare. She is put on the waiting list for surgical repair.
What structure in the eye is affected by cataract formation?

A. Cornea
B. Iris
C. Lens
D. Retina
E. Sclera

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance from a music festival. It is a hot day and she had been standing in the crowd when she suddenly collapsed and lost consciousness. She is now fully alert and gives a history of feeling dizzy and nauseated before the collapse. She tells you that she is healthy, plays tennis for her local club and is a keen runner. She has had no previous episodes of losing consciousness. Her father has recently had a heart attack aged 60 years. Her resting electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a corrected QT interval of 400 ms and a slightly prolonged PR interval but is otherwise normal.
Select the most likely diagnosis from the list below:

A. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
B. Substance misuse
C. Vasovagal syncope
D. Long QT syndrome
E. Complete heart block

Correct Answer: C

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Outpatient Department by his mother who informs the Consultant of his repeated nosebleeds. He is an avid football player, and his mother has noticed multiple bruises after matches. The Consultant goes through the list of recent laboratory investigations ordered by the boy’s Paediatrician. Full blood count (FBC), haemoglobin, platelet count, white blood cell count and clotting times [prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT)] were all found to be within normal values. Additional haematological test results were also normal, including activity assays for factor VIII and XIII, platelet aggregation assay and von Willebrand factor (vWF) antigen.
Which of the following physical findings would give the most effective information regarding his diagnosis?

A. Bruises in the shins
B. Hypermobility of fingers and toes
C. Petechial rashes on pressure sites
D. Subconjunctival haemorrhages
E. Visual acuity defects and albinism

Correct Answer: B

You are reviewing a patient who attends the clinic with a respiratory disorder.
Which of the following conditions would be suitable for long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT)?

A. Type 2 respiratory failure secondary to opiate toxicity
B. Asthma
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Croup
E. Myasthenia gravis

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old man is seen in the Ophthalmology Clinic with a painful red right eye and reduced visual acuity. On examination, he is found to have watery eyes and is photophobic. Slit-lamp examination shows the presence of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber. He is usually fit and well, except for some back pain for which he has been seeing the Physiotherapy Team.
Given the likely diagnosis, which investigation is most helpful to determine the underlying cause?

A. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
B. Intraocular pressure
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain
D. MRI pelvis
E. Rheumatoid factor

Correct Answer: D

A 72-year-old man has pain in his left hip which has progressively worsened over the past six months, such that his movement is now severely limited.
Examination reveals severe limitation of flexion and external rotation of the left hip. A hip X-ray shows gross deformity of the joint with loss of joint space and extensive new bone formation. You suspect Paget’s disease.
Which of the following is most likely to be elevated?

A. Alkaline phosphatase
B. Calcium
C. Magnesium
D. Phosphate
E. Vitamin D

Correct Answer: A

A 75-year-old known cardiopath is brought to hospital by ambulance, complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. He looks pale and is very sweaty. Examination reveals a blood pressure of 80/55 mmHg, pulse of 135 bpm, SpO2 of 93% and bibasal wet crackles in the chest, as well as peripheral oedema. Peripheral pulses are palpable. A previous median sternotomy is noted. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals regular tachycardia, with QRS complexes of uniform amplitude, a QRS width of 164 ms and a rate of 135 bpm.
What is the most important step in management?

A. Intravenous (IV) magnesium
B. Aspirin 300 mg and clopidogrel 300 mg
