C. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
D. DC cardioversion
E. IV furosemide and oxygen

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old man is assessed by the team physiotherapist following the collapse of a rugby scrum. He is conscious and breathing spontaneously.
He has tenderness and swelling over the cervical spine and has evidence of a haematoma behind the pharyngeal mucosa. He is rushed to the nearest Emergency Department where lateral X-ray of the cervical spine confirms a fracture dislocation in the region of the seventh cervical vertebra.
Which of the following features would be consistent with a spinal injury?

A. Only Lower motor neurone lesion in the upper limbs
B. High mean arterial pressure
C. Bradycardia
D. Period of flaccid paralysis followed by upper motor neurone lesion in the lower limbs
E. Positive Babinski reflex

Correct Answer: D

A 67-year-old man presented with fever, body ache and pedal oedema for three months. He was taking oral diclofenac frequently for the aches. He had no other drug history and had not travelled recently.
On examination, there was sternal tenderness. His blood report revealed:
Investigation Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 76 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 134 mm/hr 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Platelets 280 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Urea 13 mmol/l 2.5–6.0 mmol/l
Calcium 2.8 mmol/l 2.2–2.6 mmol/l
What is the most likely cause of renal failure in this case?

A. Use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
B. Light chain deposition
C. Hypercalcaemia
D. Hyperuricaemia
E. Infiltration of the kidney

Correct Answer: B

An 86-year-old man presents to Accident and Emergency confused, dehydrated and constipated. He is complaining of significant pain down his left flank. He was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 6 months ago and is currently undergoing treatment. He is treated with aggressive fluid resuscitation and recovers promptly.
Elevated levels of which biochemical parameter would has caused this presentation?

A. Phosphate
B. Calcium
C. Vitamin D
D. Sodium
E. Potassium

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old multiparous woman attends a specialist clinic for menorrhagia. She has multiple fibroids, distorting the uterine cavity, and has completed a 3-month trial of tranexamic acid, which has failed to improve her symptoms.
She appears pale and on examination you palpate a uterus equivalent to 16 weeks of pregnancy. The patient tells you she is fed up and wants a definitive treatment this time.
A urinary pregnancy test is negative.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient’s menorrhagia?

A. Hysterectomy
B. Mefenamic acid
C. Myomectomy
D. Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena®)
E. Uterine artery embolisation

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhoea. She is of normal height and build and has normal intellect. Her breast development is normal, and pubic hair is of Tanner stage II. Past history revealed an inguinal mass on the right side, which was excised 3 years ago. Ultrasonography of the lower abdomen reveals no uterus.
Which of the following tests will help in diagnosis of the condition?

A. Karyotype
B. Serum oestradiol level
C. Pituitary magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
D. Transvaginal ultrasound
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her flatmates who claim that she has vomited up blood. Apparently she had consumed far too much alcohol over the course of the night, had vomited on multiple occasions, and then began to dry-retch. After a period of retching, she vomited a minimal amount of bright red blood. On examination, she is intoxicated and has marked epigastric tenderness; her blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg, with a heart rate of 70 bpm, regular.
Investigations:
Investigation
Result
Normal value
Haemoglobin 145 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 301 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for her?

A. Discharge in the morning if stable
B. Repeat Hb in the morning and arrange upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
C. Give intravenous (iv) pantoprazole
D. Discharge with 4 weeks of oral omeprazole
E. Arrange urgent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy tonight

Correct Answer: A

You are a medical senior house officer seeing a patient called Edith with your consultant. Edith is a very frail 92-year-old lady with urinary sepsis and a history of metastatic bladder carcinoma. Your consultant completes her ward round and is of the opinion that cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) would be unsuccessful if Edith were to have a cardiac arrest. After the round, a nurse asks you to complete a Do Not Attempt Resuscitation order (DNAR), which will mean that Edith would not undergo CPR in the event of a cardiac arrest. Edith does not currently have mental capacity to make decisions about her care. You have not discussed resuscitation with Edith or her family and do not have any more information available to you at this time. Her son has been appointed Power of Attorney, which includes provision for him to make decisions about Edith’s welfare and medical care.
Select the most appropriate action to take in this case:

A. Attempt to contact Edith’s son to discuss the DNACPR order first and then complete the DNAR form
B. Complete the DNAR form, but only when Edith has regained the mental capacity to consent to a DNAR being completed
C. Wait for your consultant to complete a DNAR form on the following morning’s ward round
D. Complete the DNAR form straightaway
E. Complete the DNAR form only if you obtain consent from Edith’s Power of Attorney

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year old housewife is extremely worried that a mole on her hand might be cancerous. She has been seen by a dermatologist regarding the mole who has reassured her that it is a harmless pigmented naevus, however the patient is still convinced that she is going to get skin cancer.
In the absence of another major psychiatric syndrome, what is neurotic anxiety about serious medical illness that cannot be relieved by physician reassurance called?

A. Malingering
B. Somatisation disorder
C. Hypochondriasis
D. Pain disorder
E. Munchausen syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man came for a medication review at the GP surgery as he was recently started on Ramipril a few weeks ago because of hypertension. There is a past medical history of chronic pain and peripheral arterial disease. He is currently taking aspirin, simvastatin and co-codamol. His blood pressure is poorly controlled and upon checking blood results, the creatinine has raised from 114 µmol/l to 205 µmol/l in the last two weeks
Which of the following is most likely to explain the increase in creatinine level?

A. Underlying renal artery stenosis
B. Nephropathy caused by Ramipril
C. Normal for patients who just started Ramipril
D. Dehydration
E. Obstructive nephropathy

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man received a blood transfusion of 2 units of crossmatched blood 1 hour ago, following acute blood loss. He reports noticing a funny feeling in his chest, like his heart keeps missing a beat. You perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) which shows tall, tented T-waves and flattened P-waves in multiple leads.
An arterial blood gas (ABG) test shows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 7.1 mmol/l 5–5.0 mmol/l
Chloride (Cl–) 96 mmol/l 95–105 mmol/l
Given the findings, what treatment should be given immediately?

A. Calcium resonium
B. Calcium gluconate
C. Insulin and dextrose
D. Nebulised salbutamol
E. Dexamethasone

Correct Answer: B

A 22-year-old woman cuts her arm on a branch while running outside. Over the next few days a small pustule develops at the wound site, which then develops into an ulcer. The ulcer has an irregular purple border, and deepens and widens rapidly. The ulcer is very painful.
What medical condition is the patient likely to have?

A. Coeliac disease
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Grave’s disease
D. SLE
E. T1 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: B

An elderly woman presents to her doctor complaining of painful sensation over the outer aspect of her thigh. A diagnosis of meralgia paraesthetica is made.
Which nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the thigh?

A. Pudendal nerve
B. Branch of the lumbar plexus
C. Obturator nerve
D. Sciatic nerve
E. Femoral nerve

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man with a chronic bowel condition presents with severe pain on defecation, which has lasted over two months despite increasing fluid intake and stool softeners. He has had anal fissures in the past, as well as a previous perianal abscess. On examination, the anal area is inflamed, with evidence of a deep anal fissure with an associated large sentinel tag.
The doctor explains that this is a symptom of active perianal disease secondary to this patient’s chronic bowel condition.
With which of the following conditions is perianal disease most commonly associated?

A. Diverticular disease
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Ulcerative colitis
D. Irritable bowel disease
E. Coeliac disease

Correct Answer: B

While on call overnight on orthogeriatrics, you are bleeped to see a patient you do not know. They are 2 days post-op from a left total hip replacement. They appear drowsy and confused, and have a very fast heart rate. electrocardiogram (ECG) shows peaked T-waves, PR interval of 230 ms and a wide QRS. Potassium on ABG is 6.4 mmol.
What is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Bleep the on-call registrar
B. Give calcium gluconate 10% 10 ml by slow iv injection
C. Give 10 U Actrapid in 50 ml of 50% glucose over 10–15 ml iv
D. Give calcium gluconate 15% 50 ml by slow iv injection
E. Give calcium resonium 15 mg po

Correct Answer: B

A 16-year-old youth reports recurrent reactions to his nose ring. He recalls a recent similar reaction on his wrist when wearing a nickel bracelet.
Which of the following investigations is used to confirm a nickel allergy?

A. Patch test
B. Flow cytometry
C. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) typing
D. Skin prick testing
E. Polymerase chain reaction

Correct Answer: A

The microscopic examination of a lymph node biopsy revealed complete effacement of the lymph node morphology by scattered malignant cells. These cells were large and binucleated, and the pathologist identified them as Reed-Sternberg cells.
Based on these findings, what was the most likely pathologic diagnosis?

A. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
B. Waldenström macroglobulinemia
C. Hodgkin lymphoma
D. Follicular lymphoma
E. Burkitt lymphoma

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old woman with metastatic oesophageal cancer is being seen on a home visit by her GP. She is felt to be approaching the end of life. She is unable to swallow and is bed bound. Her current medication regime is morphine sulphate modified release tablets (MST) 40 mg twice daily; she rarely needs to take oramorph for breakthrough pain.
What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A. Buprenorphine 5 μg patch
B. Diamorphine 80 mg/24 hours via syringe driver
C. Fentanyl 100 μg patch
D. Morphine 40 mg/24 hours via syringe driver
E. Morphine 80 mg/24 hours via syringe driver

Correct Answer: D

A 16-year-old boy was diagnosed with Reifenstein syndrome. He had hypospadias, micropenis and small testes in the scrotum.
Which of the following is the next treatment option?

A. Oestrogen replacement
B. Testosterone replacement
C. Surgical management
D. Psychological counselling
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: B

Some students currently studying public health have collected data on the population of Cambodians with malaria. They sampled 500 people. The data collected are shown in the table.
True positive (has the disease) True negative (does not have the disease)
Screen positive 200 50
Screen negative 20 230
Which of the following is the best description for the calculation of positive predictive value?

A. The proportion of people who test positive for the disease in the group who have the disease
B. The proportion of people who have the disease in the group will test positive for the disease
C. The proportion of people disease free in the group who test positive for the disease
D. The proportion of people disease free in the group who test negative for the disease
E. The proportion of people who have the disease in the group who test negative for the disease

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old man is seen at outpatient clinic with the complaint of altered bowel habit. He reveals a 3-month history of increased frequency of motions of up to eight times a day with per rectum (pr) blood on occasion. On examination, he was tender on the left iliac fossa. He was unable to tolerate a pr examination. Liver function tests at his general practice surgery revealed a raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP).
Which one of the following findings on the autoantibody screen is most likely?

A. Raised anti-mitochondrial antibody (AMA)
B. Raised anti-smooth muscle antibody (ASMA)
C. Raised anti-endomysial
D. Negative result
E. Raised anti-Jo

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old man who is a known alcoholic is brought to the Emergency Department after being found unconscious. Over several hours, he regains consciousness. His blood alcohol level is high and a head computerised tomography (CT) scan is negative, so you diagnose acute intoxication. A routine chest X-ray demonstrated an enlarged globular heart. An echocardiogram revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 45%.
What is the most likely cause of his cardiac pathology, and what might gross examination of his heart reveal?

A. Alcohol and dilation of all four chambers of the heart
B. Alcohol and dilation of the left ventricle with normal atria and right ventricle
C. Alcohol and concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle
D. Alcohol and asymmetric hypertrophy of the interventricular septum
E. Trypanosomes and dilation of all four chambers of the heart

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old woman with a body mass index of 33 kg/m2 is found to have a fasting blood sugar of 10 mmol/l and 11.7 mmol/l on two separate occasions. The family history is positive for diabetes mellitus in her father and maternal uncle. She attempts to lose weight with diet and exercise, but so far she has been unable to achieve a balanced diet. She is willing to take orlistat or an anorexigenic agent. An additional investigation shows that the blood insulin level tends to be relatively high.
Which of the following hormonal changes is most likely to be observed in this patient?

A. Reduced leptin
B. Increased epinephrine
C. Increased growth hormone
D. Increased cortisol
E. Reduced adiponectin

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance after he developed acute headache and nausea at home. He describes one episode of non-bloody vomiting, vertigo, dysphagia and hoarseness that began in association with a headache 1 h prior to evaluation in the Emergency Department. On physical examination, the man is afebrile with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg, heart rate 90 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. He has decreased pain and temperature sensations over the right side of his face, dysphagia and hoarseness. Right-sided ptosis is also noticed.
Which of the following arteries is most likely occluded in this patient?

A. Anterior spinal artery
B. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
C. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
D. Posterior cerebral artery
E. Anterior communicating artery

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman presents for her first trimester scan at 12 weeks’ gestation. She is well and denies any bleeding per vagina. The ultrasound scan reveals an intrauterine gestational sac with a fetal pole corresponding to nine weeks’ gestation. No fetal heart rate is demonstrated. The patient had a stillbirth at 27 weeks in her previous pregnancy, and she required a prolonged psychotherapy treatment course to overcome the effects of this event.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line management for this patient?

A. Admit for surgical evacuation of products of conception
B. Allow expectant management and review 14 days later
C. Allow expectant management and review 21 days later
D. Offer mifepristone treatment
E. Offer vaginal misoprostol

Correct Answer: E

A 63-year-old male inpatient with an infective exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has suddenly become very unwell in the space of 10–15 minutes and is struggling to breathe. The nurse tells you he is on intravenous (IV) antibiotics for this exacerbation and has been on the ward for a few days.
Which one of the following would be the most worrying finding after seeing this patient?

A. He is also on non-invasive ventilation (NIV)
B. Heart rate 82 bpm and respiratory rate 19 breaths/minute
C. Left-sided pleuritic chest pain
D. Increased antero-posterior (AP) diameter on X-ray
E. Temperature 37.9 °C

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old pregnant woman complains of feeling short of breath for a month, which is aggravated by physical activity. She is 12 weeks pregnant, and all her prenatal tests were normal. At this current visit, her vitals are within normal limits. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally; there is no cardiac murmur. There is mild lower limb dependent oedema.
What is the most likely cause of her dyspnoea?

A. Increased respiratory rate
B. Reduced tidal volume
C. Increased residual volume
D. Reduced functional residual capacity
E. Increased minute ventilation

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old woman complained of fever and joint pain. When she was describing her symptoms to her doctor, the doctor noticed that she had a rash on both cheeks. A kidney biopsy sample demonstrated deposits of immunoglobulin, C3 and fibrinogen in the basement membrane. Laboratory analysis of her serum revealed high levels of anti-dsDNA antibody.
What was the most likely diagnosis?

A. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
B. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)
C. di George syndrome
D. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman attends her midwife for a routine pregnancy check. Her clinical course is unremarkable. She submits routine bloods and urine for examination.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 300 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urine Escherichia coli grown after 48 h,
sensitive to amoxicillin and ciprofloxacin
Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this case?

A. Take no action and review in 4 weeks
B. Prescribe a 4-week course of amoxicillin
C. Prescribe a 10-day course of ciprofloxacin
D. Prescribe a 10-day course of amoxicillin
E. Prescribe 2-week intermittent courses of amoxicillin for the remainder of her pregnancy

Correct Answer: D

You are conducting an annual review of a patient with known asthma. They currently take an inhaled corticosteroid (fluticasone) twice daily. Despite this they are having to use their salbutamol inhaler around 5 times per week for the past 3 months.
According to British Thoracic Society guidelines, what would be the next most appropriate step in the management of their asthma?

A. Regular salbutamol twice daily
B. Short course of oral steroids
C. Switch to high dose inhaled steroid
D. Add on long-acting beta-2-agonist (LABA)
E. Refer to specialist care

Correct Answer: D

Perforation of a duodenal ulcer that lies posteriorly can cause haemorrhage. Which artery is most likely to be the cause of this bleeding?

A. Right gastric artery
B. Gastroduodenal artery
C. Right gastroepiploic artery
D. Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery
E. Cystic artery

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man is complaining of right shoulder pain after falling down on an outstretched hand three hours ago. He cannot move the arm because of pain, and passive motion is also significantly restricted. He is holding his arm slightly abducted and external rotated. The skin over the upper lateral aspect of the right arm is numb. The acromion is prominent with a visible gap immediately below it. There is no localised tenderness over the acromion.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anterior shoulder dislocation
B. Posterior shoulder dislocation
C. Rotator cuff tear
D. Acromial fracture
E. Humeral neck fracture

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old obese woman is admitted with episodic retrosternal chest pain not relieved by rest, for the past 3 weeks. The pain is described as squeezing in nature, and is not affected by meals or breathing. The episodic pain is of fixed pattern and is of same intensity. She has a background of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidaemia and hypertension. Her family history is remarkable for a paternal myocardial infarction at the age of 63. She is currently haemodynamically stable.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Acute coronary syndrome
B. Stable angina pectoris
C. Aortic dissection
D. Myocarditis
E. Aortic stenosis

Correct Answer: A

You are called to see a 72-year-old man who has suddenly deteriorated after pacemaker insertion. He has sudden-onset shortness of breath and is cold and clammy. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, pulse 100 bpm and regular. His jugular venous pressure (JVP) is markedly elevated and his heart sounds are muffled. You give him oxygen and plasma volume expanders intravenously (iv).
Which of the following is the next most appropriate intervention?

A. Arrange an urgent echocardiogram
B. Arrange an urgent chest X-ray
C. Prepare for pericardiocentesis
D. Consider Swann−Ganz catheter insertion to check his pressures
E. Give him high-dose inotropic support

Correct Answer: C

A 41-year-old known intravenous (iv) drug user visits her general practitioner, complaining of fever, morning stiffness and joint pain. The joint pain is 3/10 in intensity, dull and constant, predominantly in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints bilaterally. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, but her family history is significant for ‘a skin condition’ and rheumatoid arthritis. The patient drinks 15 alcoholic units per week and smokes two packs of cigarettes per day. The patient is febrile to 38.1 °C. Physical exam demonstrates warmth and swelling in the DIP joints and symmetric nail pitting.
Which of the following is most consistent with this patient’s current presentation?

A. Appearance of a silver, scaly rash
B. Gram positive cocci on synovial fluid analysis
C. Subchondral cyst formation
D. Joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation
E. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) positivity

Correct Answer: A

You are discussing bipolar disorder with your consultant in a foundation trainees teaching session as part of your psychiatry attachment.
Which of the following is the most common medical treatment in the long-term management of bipolar disorder?

A. Lithium
B. Carbamazepine
C. Sertraline
D. Diazepam
E. Clozapine

Correct Answer: A

A 6-week-old baby has been brought in by his mother after she is concerned about his movement. He is diagnosed as having developmental dysplasia of the hip on ultrasound.
Which statement is correct regarding the management of developmental dysplasia of the hip?

A. Avascular necrosis and temporary femoral nerve palsy are potential complications of splinting
B. A Pavlik harness can be applied at any age
C. Prognosis is not affected by the age at diagnosis
D. Recovery following closed reduction is usually complete after four weeks
E. Surgical reduction is always indicated

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department as she has been lethargic, with high fever and headache. On examination, she has neck stiffness and a rash.
When is the best time to inform the communicable disease consultant (CDC)?

A. Upon microbiological diagnosis
B. Clinical diagnosis
C. Upon culture and isolation
D. Upon treatment
E. After discharge

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old man has been admitted to hospital for pain management. The patient has metastatic lung cancer and is undergoing palliative radiotherapy. He received his last dose of analgesia 3 hours ago. On inspection, the patient is obtunded and has constricted pupils and a respiratory rate of 6 breaths per minute.
Which analgesia is the patient most likely to have received to cause this adverse reaction?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Phenobarbital
C. Diazepam
D. Haloperidol
E. Oxycodone

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old patient presents with a 2-day history of vaginal discharge, without itching or bleeding. She is normally fit and well, with no past medical history. There is no history of sexually transmitted infections. She is sexually active and has a progesterone implant for contraception.
Examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen. On pelvic examination, you notice the vagina has a white-grey coating on the walls and a fishy odour. A small amount of grey vaginal discharge is also seen. The cervix looks normal, and there is no cervical excitation. Observations are stable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bacterial vaginosis
B. Candidiasis
C. Gonorrhoea
D. Pelvic inflammatory disease
E. Trichomonas vaginalis

Correct Answer: A

An 8-year-old girl with Down syndrome presents to her General Practitioner, accompanied by her mother. She has been suffering with blurred vision over the past few months, and this is now accompanied by headaches and eye fatigue. The blurred vision is usually worse when looking at distant objects but can also be an issue when looking at nearer objects.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line investigation?

A. Anterior segment optical coherence tomography
B. Corneal topography
C. Keratometry
D. Retinoscopy
E. Wavefront analysis technology

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old man visits his general practitioner due to an enlarging neck mass. His family history is significant for a right adrenal phaeochromocytoma in his mother, which was surgically removed without complications. The patient is 1.9m (6 ft 3 inches) tall and weighs 74 kg. On examination, the patient has numerous yellowish white masses on the lips and tongue. Then, 3 months later, the patient undergoes total thyroidectomy.
The nerve that is most at risk during this procedure is part of the vagus nerve which also innervates which one of the following structures?

A. Anterior two-thirds of the tongue
B. Aortic arch
C. Platysma
D. Carotid sinus
E. Sternocleidomastoid

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man arrives in the resuscitation area of the Emergency Department with significant facial, torso and hand burns sustained from throwing petrol on to a bonfire. He is calculated to have 31.5% burns based on the rule of nines. He weighs 95 kg.
Based on the Parkland formula, what would the correct amount of fluid resuscitation be approximately?

A. 12L, with 6L given in the first 8 h followed by 6L over the next 16 h
B. 18L, with 6L given in the first 6 h followed by 12L over the next 12 h
C. 18L, with 9L given in the first 8 h followed by 9L over the next 16 h
D. 12L, with 4L given in the first 6 h followed by 8L over the next 12 h
E. 15L, with 10L given in the first 6 h followed by 5L over the next 12 h

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old smoker presents to his GP with a 6-month history of cough, shortness of breath, weight loss (4 kg) and night sweats. An urgent chest X-ray (CXR) is performed, which shows several well defined central opacities. A blood test reveals the following:
calcium: 3.8 mmol/l (2.1–2.6 mmol/l).
Based on these findings, what type of lung cancer would be most likely?

A. Small cell
B. Squamous cell
C. Large cell
D. Adenocarcinoma
E. Bronchoalveolar

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department acutely short of breath with right-sided pleuritic chest discomfort and dizziness.
On examination: no chest wall tenderness, nil adventitious sounds on auscultation. Calves unremarkable. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia, 128 bpm. D-dimer 0.79 mg/l (raised). A chest X-ray is unremarkable. Oxygen saturation 91% on room air. Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan was reported as low probability for a pulmonary embolus.
What is the most appropriate next step?

A. Investigations complete; the patient may be discharged
B. Undertake bronchoscopy
C. Repeat VQ scan the following day
D. Treat as for a lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI)
E. Request a computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old woman known to have a tumour in the superior (first) part of the duodenum presents with jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. A CT scan of the abdomen shows the tumour is pressing against, and causing obstruction of, the biliary tree.
Which part of the biliary tree is most likely to be affected?

A. Common bile duct
B. Common hepatic duct
C. Left hepatic duct
D. Cystic duct
E. Right hepatic duct

Correct Answer: A

A colleague of yours admits to being romantically involved with a patient who was discharged 2 days ago. She claims they hit it off when he was an in-patient and have now started dating.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Congratulate your colleague, as she has been single for a while
B. Threaten to expose her relationship if she doesn’t end it
C. Spread rumours about your colleague and the patient
D. Do nothing
E. Express your concerns about her dating a recent patient and ask her to consider the implications of it

Correct Answer: E

A 53-year-old man is suspected of having a renal calculus. He has some investigations carried out by the general practitioner to monitor the effects of his medication. The following results are obtained:
Plasma
Na+ 138 mmol/l (135–145 mmol/l)
K+ 3.1 mmol/l (3.5–5 mmol/l)
24-hour urine sample:
Ca2+ 40 mg/day (100–300 mg/day)
Given the results above, which one of the following is the patient most likely taking?

A. A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
B. Furosemide
C. Bendroflumethiazide
D. Spironolactone
E. Mannitol

Correct Answer: C

You are the out-of-hours General Practitioner (GP) on call. You receive a call from the relative of a 90-year-old man with palliative prostate cancer and a complete Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR) order. The relative believes he has passed away and is not sure what to do. You offer your condolences and arrange a home visit to confirm death.
Which of the following should be confirmed in order to diagnose death?

A. No response to verbal/painful stimuli, absence of carotid pulse, absence of breath sounds for more than three minutes, absence of heart sounds for more than two minutes, pupils fixed and dilated
B. No response to verbal/painful stimuli, absence of carotid pulse, absence of breath sounds for more than two minutes, absence of heart sounds for more than three minutes, pupils fixed and dilated, lack of gag reflex
C. No response to verbal/painful stimuli, absence of carotid pulse, absence of breath sounds for more than one minute, absence of heart sounds for more than one minute, pupils fixed and dilated
D. No response to verbal/painful stimuli, absence of radial pulse, absence of breath sounds for more than one minute, absence of heart sounds for more than one minute, pupils fixed and dilated
E. No response to verbal/painful stimuli, absence of radial pulse, absence of breath sounds for more than two minutes, absence of heart sounds for more than three minutes, pupils fixed and dilated

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old woman attends with a history of oligomenorrhoea and menstrual irregularity (menses every 32–38 days). She has a body mass index (BMI) of 28 kg/m2 and is hirsute. She has short hair distributed in a male pattern of baldness.
Examination reveals brown, hyperpigmented areas in the creases of the axillae and around the neck. A glucose tolerance test is performed and shows the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Fasting plasma glucose 4.3 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) plasma glucose 9.2 mmol/l
Which of the following best describes monitoring required for this patient?

A. Annual fasting glucose testing is appropriate
B. Annual glucose tolerance testing as her BMI is 28 kg/m2
C. Annual glucose tolerance testing as there is evidence of impaired glucose tolerance
D. No further monitoring is required
E. The above results indicate diabetes and treatment should be initiated

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old white man is found to have a 4.2 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm following routine screening He is asymptomatic, though he is found to be hypertensive on review by his general practitioner. He has no other medical history of note.
What would be the most appropriate management plan?

A. Control his hypertension initially with amlodipine and re-scan in a year
B. Control his hypertension initially with amlodipine and re-scan in three months
C. Control his hypertension initially with amlodipine and re-scan in two years
D. Control his hypertension initially with ramipril and re-scan in one year
E. Control his hypertension initially with furosemide and offer endovascular surgical repair

Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-week history of pain, redness, tearing of the right eye. She also reports photophobia. The pain is constant and boring in nature and it can be so severe that it wakes her up at night. The pain sometimes radiates to her jaw, neck, and head. She also has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis.
On examination, her visual acuity is 6/9 in the right, 6/6 in the left. The eye appears diffusely injected.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute angle-closure glaucoma
B. Central retinal artery occlusion
C. Conjunctivitis
D. Episcleritis
E. Scleritis

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old woman presents with generalised malaise and tiredness. There are no other symptoms of note. Examination reveals conjunctival pallor and a red sore tongue. Basic blood tests reveal a macrocytic anaemia. Further investigation reveals antiparietal cell antibodies are positive.
Which of these results would you most likely find on further investigation?

A. Deranged liver enzymes, particularly gamma GT
B. Low vitamin B12
C. Distal duodenal biopsies showing villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia
D. Large bowel biopsies showing transmural inflammation with granuloma formation
E. Bone marrow examination showing plasma cells infiltrating >20% of marrow

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with fever, chill, loin pain and decreased urine output following a left renal transplant which was performed six months ago. He is treated symptomatically, but his renal output and serum creatinine do not improve. Following a renal biopsy, he has been diagnosed to have developed T-cell-mediated rejection (TCMR), with histological Banff Ia grade.
Which of the following is the first-line of treatment in a case of TCMR?

A. Alemtuzumab
B. Belatacept
C. Pulse methylprednisolone
D. Rabbit anti-thymocyte globulin (rATG)-thymoglobulin®
E. Tacrolimus

Correct Answer: C

A 70-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with painless sudden loss of vision in his eyes.
On examination, he has a left homonymous hemianopia.
What is the location of the lesion causing this visual field defect?

A. Left occipital visual cortex
B. Left temporal lobe optic radiation
C. Optic chiasm
D. Right optic tract
E. Right parietal lobe optic radiation

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man complains of a left swollen testicle. He states that he began to notice this 3 weeks ago. He also complains of a dull, achy sensation in his lower abdomen. He denies any trauma or any systemic signs of infection and he is not sexually active. On examination, a mass is palpated in the left testicle. This mass cannot be separated from the testicle. A well-defined hypoechoic lesion in the left testicle without cystic areas is seen on ultrasound, which confirms your suspected diagnosis.
Which of the following most likely represents the route by which this disease process spreads from the left testicle to the rest of the body?

A. Left testicular vein; inferior vena cava; left renal vein
B. Right testicular vein; left testicular vein; inferior vena cava
C. Left testicular vein; left common iliac vein; inferior vena cava
D. Left testicular vein; median sacral vein; inferior vena cava
E. Left testicular vein; left renal vein; inferior vena cava

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with progressive weakness and fatigue. He said that he had been having ‘abdominal complaints’ for the last 5 years; all treatments have failed to bring relief. Examination reveals severe pallor and glossitis. He passes stools five to six times per day. His only significant history is that, at 5 years of age, he swallowed a toy and it had to be removed by operation.
Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 98 g/l 135–175 g/l
Vitamin B12 60 pmol/l 160–900 pmol/l
Folate 51 μg/l 2.0–11.0 μg/l
Cholesterol 2.7 mmol/l <5.2 mmol/l
What is the appropriate definitive treatment for this condition?

A. Gluten free diet
B. Antibiotics
C. Steroids
D. Vitamin B12 replacement
E. Anti-tubercular drug

Correct Answer: B

You are the on-call general practitioner and are called urgently to the nurses’ room where a 4-year-old boy receiving his preschool vaccinations has developed breathing difficulties. The child has swollen lips and is covered in a blotchy rash; respiratory rate is 40, heart rate is 140 and there is a wheeze audible without using a stethoscope.
After lying the patient flat and raising his legs, what immediate action is required?

A. Administer 150 micrograms of adrenaline intravenously (iv)
B. Administer 150 micrograms of adrenaline intramuscularly (im)
C. Administer 300 micrograms of adrenaline iv
D. Administer 300 micrograms of adrenaline im
E. Administer 1 mg of adrenaline im

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man receives a letter inviting him to attend screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is concerned about the process and visits his general practitioner (GP) to find out some more information.
Which of the following methods is routinely used to diagnose AAA by the NHS screening programme?

A. Abdominal examination
B. Abdominal X-ray
C. Abdominal ultrasound
D. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen

Correct Answer: C

A 5-day-old baby who is 40+1 weeks’ gestation on the Neonatal Unit develops jaundice with a conjugated fraction of 38% (reference < 20%). The baby has feeding difficulty and so is being fed through a nasogastric tube. Investigations are being completed into a diagnosis of conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia. The baby is currently under single phototherapy for his jaundice.
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Caffeine
B. Double phototherapy
C. Milk fortifier
D. Omeprazole
E. Ursodeoxycholic acid

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) after noticing sudden-onset hair growth, particularly in the facial region. She is becoming increasingly embarrassed by this. She is keen to have the problem sorted. Blood tests were performed, with the only abnormality being a testosterone level of 10.4 nmol/l l (reference range 0.8–3.1 nmol/l).
What is the next step in her management?

A. Prescribe topical Eflornithine
B. Reassure and advise her that no additional investigations are required
C. Refer for an ultrasound scan of her pelvis to look for polycystic ovary disease
D. Refer to Endocrinology routinely for management of her hirsutism
E. Refer to Endocrinology as a suspected cancer referral

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a one-year history of erectile dysfunction. He had never suffered from this problem before, and it is causing him much distress. He has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, ischaemic heart disease and poor urinary flow. He also underwent a thyroidectomy several years ago, the reason for which is unclear. He is currently taking insulin, gliclazide, amlodipine and aspirin. His latest HbA1c was 12.1% or 108 mmol/mol.
What is the most likely cause of his erectile dysfunction?

A. Diabetes
B. Ischaemic heart disease
C. Thyroidectomy
D. Prostatic hyperplasia
E. Hypertension

Correct Answer: A

A 3-year-old child, who was born in Germany, is brought to the General Practitioner (GP) by his mother because of recurrent sinus infections and failure to thrive. She is also concerned that the child has had diarrhoea for a few months, which is not resolving.
On examination, you observe several shiny, pink masses occupying the nasal canals.
What is the most appropriate first step in managing this patient?

A. Testing in which pilocarpine is administered
B. Genetic testing
C. Treatment with loratadine
D. Biopsy the mass for pathology
E. Bacterial culture

Correct Answer: A

A 27-year-old G3P0 (pregnancies/gestation 3, deliveries/childbirth 0) attends the practice for review, following a miscarriage at 16 weeks’ gestation. She reports that in her other two pregnancies, she miscarried at 15 weeks’ and 18 weeks’ gestation, respectively. In all three pregnancies, she had ultrasound scans that were consistent with her dates.
Which one of the following is a possible contributing factor?

A. Paternal Robertsonian translocation
B. Incomplete fusion of paramesonephric ducts
C. Maternal 45,XO chromosome complement
D. Low maternal serum progesterone
E. Failure of migration of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)-secreting neurones from the olfactory placode

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old bird keeper in a zoo presented with fever and dyspnoea. He had recently been handling a new group of birds imported from Brazil to his zoo.
Which of the following organisms is probably responsible for his disease?

A. Legionella pneumophila
B. Chlamydia psittaci
C. Coxiella burnetti
D. Rhodococcus
E. Klebsiella pneumonia

Correct Answer: B

John Parker, a 28-year-old IT consultant, has just been diagnosed with plaque psoriasis confined to his elbows.
Which of the following treatments would be the most appropriate at this stage?

A. Dovobet®
B. Infliximab
C. Methotrexate
D. Photochemotherapy (PUVA)
E. Retinoids

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old woman is referred to hospital by her midwife 5 days after giving birth to a healthy baby girl by vaginal delivery. She has reported increasing lochia and has had an increase in lower abdominal cramping over the last few days. On examination, she is hot and sweaty with temperature 38 °C, heart rate 120 bpm and capillary refill time (CRT) 3 s, and her abdomen is firm and tender, with the uterus still palpable just below the umbilicus. There is mild perineal swelling but no tears, and lochia is offensive. The rest of the examination is normal. She is keen to get home to her baby as she is breastfeeding.
What would you do next?

A. Allow home on oral antibiotics
B. Admit, send vaginal swabs and blood cultures, start intravenous (iv) antibiotics and arrange a pelvic ultrasound scan
C. Admit, send blood cultures, arrange a pelvic ultrasound scan
D. Admit, send vaginal swabs, start iv antibiotics and arrange a pelvic ultrasound scan
E. Ambulate on iv antibiotics

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department complaining of epigastric pain. The patient reports that he developed acute abdominal pain 2 hours prior to presentation after eating a cheeseburger. The patient otherwise has no significant past medical history. He does not take any medications and denies smoking, alcohol consumption and drug use. He has been recently been released from prison and has not got stable living and has had to sleep outside since his release.
On examination, the patient has normal vital signs. His abdominal examination demonstrates normoactive bowel sounds, no tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium and no guarding or rebound tenderness. Rectal exam for stool occult blood is negative and a chest X-ray does not reveal free air under the diaphragm. A right upper quadrant ultrasound does not demonstrate stones. The doctor recommends antacids. When the doctor tells the patient that he is safe for discharge, the patient insists that he must be admitted to hospital for further tests.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Factitious disorder
B. Malingering
C. Factitious or induced illness
D. Conversion disorder
E. Hypochondriasis

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old man with lung cancer takes ibuprofen as part of his analgesia regimen. He presents to the Emergency Department with melaena and a haemoglobin level of 8.0.
Which of the following medications was he most likely to have been taking?

A. Buprenorphine
B. Fentanyl
C. Oxycontin
D. Prednisolone
E. Tramadol

Correct Answer: D

Which one of the following statements is true about coronary artery grafting for ischaemic heart disease?

A. It always requires cardiopulmonary bypass
B. It is usually performed using intercostal arteries as grafts
C. It is unlikely to be successful if >2 major coronary arteries are narrowed
D. It requires a preceding coronary angiography
E. It has not been shown to prolong life

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with gastroenteritis. He has vomited five times in the past 24 hours and reports severe cramps in his left calf. He has blood tests, which demonstrate hypokalaemia, and an electrocardiogram (ECG).
Which one of the following ECG changes is most associated with hypokalaemia?

A. Peaked T waves
B. Broadening of QRS complex
C. Decreased amplitude of P wave
D. Reduced PR interval
E. Prominent U waves

Correct Answer: E

An 82-year-old woman is having part of her sigmoid colon resected for diverticular disease. Local arteries will require to be ligated.
From which artery do the sigmoid arterial branches arise?

A. Ileocolic artery
B. Inferior mesenteric artery
C. Middle colic artery
D. Superior mesenteric artery
E. Superior rectal artery

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old woman patient presents with a subacute history of lethargy and low-grade fever. Among other findings, full clinical examination reveals retinal haemorrhages with pale centres, painful red raised lesions on the hands and feet and subcentimetre, non-tender, raised papules on the palms and soles of the feet.
What is the underlying condition?

A. Endocarditis
B. Systemic lupus erythaematosus
C. Tuberculosis
D. Subacute meningococcal septicaemia
E. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

Correct Answer: A

A 22-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after being involved in a fight. He had been in the shower after a gym session, when someone made a derogatory comment about his body, and that started the fight. A history reveals that he has had three girlfriends in the last 3 months, but none of the relationships have lasted. He admits that he struggles to achieve an erection. On examination, the patient is of normal height with normal pubic hair. His penis is small and his breasts are enlarged. He said that he had started growing breasts from the age of 11. This often caused him embarrassment. His blood pressure is 119/73 mmHg.
Which of the following syndromes must be ruled out?

A. Kallmann syndrome
B. Klinefelter syndrome
C. Reifenstein syndrome
D. 17-α hydroxylase deficiency
E. Turner syndrome

Correct Answer: C

You are evaluating a new drug X, which follows a linear pharmacokinetic pattern. Peak plasma concentration is measured at 0.4 mg/ml. Eight hours later, the plasma concentration is 0.1 mg/ml.
Which of the following best reflects the half-life of drug X?

A. 4 hours
B. 8 hours
C. 2 hours
D. 1 hour
E. 30 minutes

Correct Answer: A

A 22-year-old woman suffered a severe crushing injury to her left upper leg in a motor vehicle accident. She sustained a severe contusion around the neck and head of the fibula.
Which nerve is susceptible to compression at the lateral head and neck of the fibula?

A. Deep peroneal nerve
B. Common peroneal nerve
C. Superficial peroneal nerve
D. Saphenous nerve
E. Tibial nerve

Correct Answer: B

A biochemist isolated a receptor from a cell and found that it was a two-chained structure composed of α and β polypeptide chains linked by disulfide bonds. Further analysis revealed that the receptor consisted of transmembrane glycoproteins with short cytoplasmic tails and had a single antigen-binding site.
Which of the following cells most likely contained this receptor?

A. T cell
B. B cell
C. Mast cell
D. Dendritic cell
E. Kupffer cell

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man is referred to gastro-enterology out-patients with increasing epigastric pain. He claims that despite his GP prescribing omeprazole, he has had several episodes of blood-stained vomitus in recent weeks. Urgent oesophago-gastroduodenoscopy (OGD) is performed with demonstrates multiple peptic ulcers. Biopsies are negative for H. pylori. Further work-up reveals elevated serum gastrin levels. Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is suspected.
What is the most common site for gastrin-secreting tumours that cause Zollinger–Ellison syndrome?

A. First/second parts of duodenum
B. Body of pancreas
C. Tail of pancreas
D. Fundus of stomach
E. Pylorus of stomach

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old man presents with bilateral tremor of his hands and abdominal pain. He is a student of architecture at the local university, and has been having increasing difficulty drawing. The abdominal pain has been constant over the last 3 weeks. Over the last 8 months his family have noticed a significant change in his behaviour, with several episodes of depression interspersed with episodes of excessive drinking – both of which are very unusual for him. On examination he has resting tremor bilateral, is slightly hypertonic and has bradykinesia. The examining physician has noted brownish iris of both eyes. The patient has not noticed any change in his colouring. His liver function tests are as follows:
serum bilirubin: 18.9 µmol/l (normal 3–17 µmol/l)
serum ALT: 176 IU/l (normal 3–40 IU/l)
serum AST: 254 IU/l (normal 3–30 IU/l)
serum ALP: 259 µmol/l (normal 30–100 µmol/l)
γ-glutamyl transferase (GT): 49 IU/l (normal 8–60 IU/l).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hereditary haemochromatosis
B. Early onset Parkinson’s’ disease
C. Alpha-1 anti-trypsin deficiency
D. Atypical depression
E. Wilson’s disease

Correct Answer: E

A 64-year-old man, who presented to the Emergency Department a day before for uncontrollable epistaxis, has been admitted following Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) referral. Bleeding was located and managed by posterior nasal packing. He had no complications following the procedure. However, on the next day, he developed fever, myalgia, hypotension, rashes in the oral mucocutaneous junctions, generalized oedema and several episodes of watery diarrhoea, with nausea and vomiting.
Which of the following investigations/findings would help you make a diagnosis?

A. Blood culture
B. Culture and sensitivity of posterior nasal swab
C. Eosinophilia
D. Increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)
E. Non-blanching purpuric rash

Correct Answer: B

An 89-year-old, unkempt man presents to the Emergency Department after being sat by his fire for over 24 h with no clothing. His legs have reticulated, erythaematous patches and hyperpigmentation.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Eczema
B. Psoriasis
C. Result of being unkempt
D. Erythaema ab igne
E. Pityriasis versicolour

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman who has been treated with a full course of heparin and warfarin for a recent pulmonary thromboembolism is discharged after 5 days in hospital. She is to continue on oral warfarin for 6 months, to prevent a recurrence of thrombosis. The day after discharge, she suddenly develops shortness of breath and respiratory symptoms, the same as she had 1 week ago. Examination reveals tachycardia, tachypnoea and mild left leg swelling and pain. A new chest X-ray is unremarkable. An arterial blood gas shows a mild acute respiratory alkalosis.
What is the most likely finding on blood tests?

A. Schistocytes in a peripheral blood smear
B. Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase
C. Low platelet count
D. Highly elevated serum troponin
E. Elevated white blood cell count with left shift

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation is brought to his local Emergency Department after suddenly losing vision in the lower left quadrant of his visual field in both eyes. A computed tomography (CT) scan of his head shows an area of infarction in his brain and he is diagnosed with an acute ischaemic stroke.
Which of the following blood vessels was most likely occluded?

A. Left anterior cerebral artery
B. Right middle cerebral artery
C. Left posterior cerebral artery
D. Right vertebral artery
E. Left ophthalmic artery

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old patient came to the Emergency Department after a fall on an outstretched right arm. He is holding his right arm with his left hand. On examination, he has flattening of the deltoid muscle, with weakness and loss of sensation of the lateral aspect of his right arm. An X-ray shows a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. You believe the fracture may have caused a nerve injury.
Which of the following describes the nerve roots of the affected nerve?

A. C5 and 6
B. C5, 6, 7, 8 and T1
C. C8 and T1
D. C5, 6 and 7
E. C5, 6, 7 and 8

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old man presents with right shoulder pain and stiffness. On examination, he is unable to internally and externally rotate or abduct the shoulder. He is diabetic.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adhesive capsulitis
B. Rotator cuff tendonitis
C. Subacromial impingement
D. Medial epicondylitis
E. Shoulder dislocation

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old woman is brought to her General Practitioner for follow-up 1 week after being attacked and raped by an acquaintance on her university campus. Immediately after the episode, she was seen in the Emergency Department for her injuries and evidence gathering, interviewed by the police and discharged home. Today she reports difficulty sleeping and flashbacks about the event. She has had difficulty concentrating at university and feels anxious that ‘something bad’ might happen to her again.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adjustment disorder
B. Generalized anxiety disorder
C. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
D. Acute stress disorder
E. Panic disorder

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old African-Caribbean woman with sickle-cell anaemia presents with acute kidney injury. Her only medication is hydroxycarbamide (hydroxyurea).
What is the most likely cause?

A. Renal papillary necrosis
B. Drug-induced interstitial nephritis
C. Hypoperfusion of renal tubules from hypotension
D. Pyelonephritis from Salmonella species
E. Diffuse cortical necrosis

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner complaining of ‘bulging blue veins’ on her legs. While examining the patient’s legs, you note the presence of tortuous, dilated veins, accompanied by brown patches of pigmentation and dry, scaly plaques of skin. A diagnosis of varicose veins is made.
Which vein is most likely to be affected?

A. Cephalic vein
B. Femoral vein
C. Long saphenous vein
D. Popliteal vein
E. Short saphenous vein

Correct Answer: C

A 79-year-old man is seen in the Emergency Department, brought in by his niece. He has been found collapsed at home by his home help and appears confused. He is complaining of headache. His niece says that he has a history of an irregular heart beat for which he takes digoxin and warfarin. On examination there is no evidence of skull trauma or of other injury. He is confused (Mini Mental score 24/30) and slightly drowsy, although readily roused. He has mild weakness of the left arm and leg and the left plantar response is extensor.
Urgent blood results:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 111 g/l 135-175 g/l
International normalised ratio (INR) 5.7 usual range for this patient 2-3
Urea 9.6 mmol/l 2.5-6.5 mmol/l
Other blood tests are within the normal range.
An urgent computed tomography (CT) scan is requested. What is this most likely to show?

A. Intraparenchymal haematoma in the right temporal lobe with mass effect
B. Right sided extradural haematoma
C. Right sided chronic subdural haematoma
D. Right sided acute subdural haematoma
E. Right sided subarachnoid haemorrhage

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) continues to be breathless at rest despite maximal inhaler therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation and home oxygen therapy. He has been reviewed for lung volume reduction surgery but was deemed unsuitable. He is referred for consideration of lung transplantation.
His FEV1 is 30% predicted, he has not smoked for 12 years, and his past medical history includes bowel cancer, for which he underwent partial colectomy and adjunctive chemotherapy six years previously with no evidence of recurrence on surveillance, and pulmonary tuberculosis age 37, which was fully sensitive and treated with six months of anti-tuberculous therapy. The patient’s body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2.
Which feature in this patient’s history makes him ineligible for listing for lung transplantation at this time?

A. FEV1 30% predicted
B. Previous history of pulmonary tuberculosis
C. BMI 29 kg/m2
D. Age 60 years old
E. Previous malignancy

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of increasingly painful periods over the last year. This pain has been accompanied by heavier menstrual bleeding. On bimanual pelvic examination, there is an enlarged, non-tender, palpable uterus. A transvaginal ultrasound scan shows a fibroid measuring 2 cm. She is nulliparous and wishes to become pregnant in the future but does not wish to conceive any time in the next two years.
What would be the most suitable initial management for this patient?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill
B. Expectant management
C. Hysterectomy
D. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
E. Progesterone-releasing intrauterine system

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old woman develops dyspnoea on exertion and palpitations. Her pulse is irregularly irregular and tachycardic. On auscultation, a systolic murmur is noted. An ECG is performed, which shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. An echocardiogram shows an atrial septal defect.
Which of the following is true of the formation of the atrial septum?

A. The septum primum is thick and muscular
B. The septum secundum grows down to the right of the septum primum
C. The foramen ovale is a physiological defect in the septum primum in the fetus
D. Babies with atrial septal defects are typically cyanosed at birth
E. The septum secundum normally fuses with the endocardial cushions

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhoea and weight loss. She also has iron deficiency anaemia and oral ulcers. A malabsorption syndrome is suspected and endoscopy is done. The report shows: stomach normal; duodenum shows absence of folds and scalloping in some places.
Which of the following diseases is the most likely to be associated with duodenal scalloping on endoscopy?

A. Bulimia
B. Granulomatous disease
C. Villous hypertrophy
D. Whipple disease
E. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection

Correct Answer: E

A 63 year-old man, who had recently received a full bone marrow transplantation for acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), presented with progressive dyspnoea over the past 2 weeks. There was an associated dry cough, but no fever. Examination revealed scattered wheezes and some expiratory high-pitched sounds. C-reactive protein (CRP) level was normal. Mantoux test was negative. Spirometry revealed the following report:
FEV1 51%
FVC 88%
FEV1/FVC 58%
What is the most probable diagnosis?

A. Pneumocystis pneumonia
B. Infective exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
C. Idiopathic pulmonary hypertension
D. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
E. Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO)

Correct Answer: E

A 43-year-old man is found to have a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg on multiple readings. He undergoes investigation for secondary hypertension. Computed tomography (CT) imaging shows a 4.3-cm right-sided adrenal lesion. Below are his blood results. He is listed for elective adrenalectomy.
Result Normal reference range
Plasma free metanephrines 3000 pmol/l 80-510 pmol/l
Which of the following treatments should be started to commence preparation of this patient for surgery for removal of adrenal phaeochromocytoma?

A. Alpha-adrenergic receptor blockers
B. Beta-adrenergic receptor blockers
C. Calcium channel blockers
D. IV fluids
E. Low-salt diet and low fluid intake

Correct Answer: A

A 3-year-old boy undergoes surgery for a sebaceous cyst on his neck. On examination, a 2-cm diameter superficial sebaceous cystic swelling in the left anterior neck triangle close to the midline, with an overlying punctum, is found. An elliptical skin incision is made around the cyst and the overlying skin with the central punctum is excised. The cyst is followed to 1 cm depth and removed. You have been asked to close the skin wound.
Which is the most appropriate choice?

A. Nylon
B. Steristrips
C. Staples
D. Silk
E. Monocryl

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner complaining of difficulty maintaining an erection. This has been going on for some time and is causing strain in his relationship. He is normally fit and well, except for high blood pressure treated with amlodipine. He reports still getting morning erections and has no changes in his libido. On examination, blood pressure is 145/78 mmHg and body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2. He has a normal abdominal, genital and prostate examination.
What is the most important investigation to rule out organic causes for his difficulty maintaining an erection?

A. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
B. HbA1c
C. No investigations required
D. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
E. Testosterone levels

Correct Answer: B

You induce a 40-year-old woman undergoing an open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) of the radius, following a fracture 2 days ago. She has no past medical history and is adequately starved. You insert a size 4 laryngeal mask airway (LMA).
Following insertion, your ODP asks you how much air she should put into the cuff?

A. Up to 7 ml
B. Up to 10 ml
C. Up to 20 ml
D. Up to 30 ml
E. Up to 40 ml

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man with known essential hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with facial swelling, difficulty breathing and stridor. He says it all started this morning and he does not remember eating anything unusual and does not have any food allergies as far as he can remember. He denies any history of asthma and does not smoke. None of his medications have been changed recently. He takes antihypertensive medications and statins.
Which medication is the most likely to have caused these side effects?

A. Ramipril
B. Amlodipine
C. Thiazide
D. Atenalol
E. Doxazosin

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman of African origin presented to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset dyspnoea. She was a known case of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), previously treated for nephropathy and presently on mycophenolate mofetil and hydroxychloroquine sulfate. She had no fever. On examination, her respiratory rate was 45 breaths per minute, with coarse crepitations in the right lung base. After admission, blood test results revealed:
Investigation Value Normal range
Haemoglobin 100g/l 115–155 g/l
Sodium (Na+) 136mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.7mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
PaO2on room air 85mmHg 95–100 mmHg
C-reactive protein (CRP) 6.6mg/l 0-10 mg/l
C3 level 41mg/dl 83–180 mg/dl
Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient as the cause for her dyspnoea?

A. High diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO)
B. High erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
C. Sputum for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) positive
D. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) positive for CD4 cells
E. Lung scan with isotopes showing defects in perfusion

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old woman (who has gone through the menopause) comes to the surgery to discuss concerns about possible osteoporosis. She says that her mother suffered from a Colles’ fracture, and then a fractured neck of femur, at an early age. She takes no medication and clinical examination is unremarkable. Her body mass index (BMI) is 28; her blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 210 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 2.31 mmol/l 2.2-2.6 mmol/l
Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan: T score −3.1 (score > −1 = normal range; score between −1 and −2.5 = osteopenic range; score < −2.5 = osteoporotic range).
Which of the following is the best way to manage her?

A. Reassure
B. Give her calcium and vitamin D tablets
C. Give her a weekly bisphosphonate
D. Give her strontium
E. Give her a monthly bisphosphonate

Correct Answer: C

A 43-year-old woman develops sudden-onset high fever, lethargy and dyspnoea. She has a harsh, pan-systolic murmur at the apex. A clinical diagnosis of viral myocarditis is made.
What is the most likely causative pathogen?

A. Coronavirus
B. Coxsackie B virus
C. Echovirus
D. Influenza virus
E. Parainfluenza virus

Correct Answer: B

A 69-year-old patient who lives in a residential home is admitted with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain associated with bloody diarrhoea. She has a history of angina, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and atrial fibrillation. Her drugs include a statin, β-blocker and digoxin. An erect chest X-ray is performed which shows no free air.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely?

A. Pseudomembranous colitis
B. Infective diarrhoea
C. Colorectal carcinoma
D. Ischaemic colitis
E. Angiodysplasia

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. An ultrasound scan (USS) is suggestive of gallstones and the common bile duct has a dilatation of 7 mm (abnormal). The patient takes morphine. After four hours the pain subsides, and she remains pain-free from discharge. She visits again two weeks later symptom free.
What is the next best definitive management step?

A. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
B. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
C. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
D. Repeat USS
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: C

A 16-year-old boy presents to his General Practitioner (GP) reporting several episodes of visible haematuria, alongside with some episodes of passing tea coloured urine, over the past day. He has no difficulty passing urine has no abdominal or flank pain. He mentions that he also has a sore throat and coryzal symptoms, which have been ongoing for around five days.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Renal cell carcinoma
B. Nephritic syndrome
C. IgA nephropathy
D. Bladder cancer
E. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman is amenorrhoeic; the general practitioner refers her for further investigation.
Serum
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) (follicular phase): 3 u/l (women: 2–8 u/l)
Luteinising hormone (LH) (follicular phase): 14 u/l (women: 2–10 u/l)
Testosterone: 3.7 mmol/l (adult women 0.5–2.5 mmol/l)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Turner syndrome
B. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
C. Anorexia nervosa
D. Hyperprolactinaemia
E. Pregnancy

Correct Answer: B

A 9-year-old boy is brought into the Emergency Department by his worried parents, who have noticed he is covered in a rash and has developed numerous bruises on his legs. This has come on suddenly and he has been well, apart from a ‘cold’ that he got over around 2 weeks previously. He has no past medical history of note, apart from undergoing an uncomplicated tonsillectomy aged 7 years following recurrent tonsillitis. There is no family history of any bleeding disorders. There is no history of fever within the last 24 hours.
On examination, vital signs are normal. There is a purpuric rash to all four limbs and his trunk. A few red spots are noted on the oral mucosa. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable, with no lymphadenopathy and no hepatosplenomegaly. Fundi are normal.
A full blood count and urine dipstick are performed and yield the following results:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 134 g/l 115–140 g/l
White cell count 4.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 23 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Blood film thrombocytopenia
Urine dipstick no abnormality detected
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)
B. Non-accidental injury (NAI)
C. Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
D. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: D

You are fast bleeped to the Surgical Ward to see a 40-year-old man who has just returned from Theatre following a stoma reversal. The nurses noted he was appearing drowsy, and observations revealed a blood pressure of 70/42 mmHg, a heart rate of 120 bpm, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute, oxygen saturation of 98% and a temperature of 36.7 °C. On examination, he is difficult to rouse and has a thready pulse. Chest sounds are clear, with normal heart sounds and soft calves. He groans when you examine his abdomen.
What is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Bloods, including full blood count and crossmatch
B. Chest X-ray
C. Computerised tomography (CT) of abdomen
D. D-dimer
E. Return to Theatre for diagnostic laparotomy

Correct Answer: A

A patient is referred to the ENT clinic with facial pain. The patient is aged 47 and reports periods where he experiences a large number of attacks of pain around the left eye and left cheek. He can have 15–20 such attacks in a day and they tend to be very short (maybe 3–4 min but can last up to a quarter of an hour). They can sometimes be triggered by stretching or turning the neck. When they occur, he finds his eye tends to water. The headaches always resolve and are not associated with any vomiting, aversion to light or sound or limb weakness. Ear, nose and throat and neurological examination are both normal. He is normotensive.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Migraine
B. Trigeminal neuralgia
C. Cluster headache
D. Frontal lobe glioblastoma
E. Paroxysmal hemicrania

Correct Answer: E

A 67-year-old lady presents following a fall on her outstretched hand (FOOSH). She has marked pain around the wrist joint with bony tenderness on palpation. A wrist X-ray demonstrates a fracture of the distal radius with anterior (palmar) displacement of the distal fragment. There is no neurovascular compromise.
Select the most appropriate initial management option:

A. Reduction under local anaesthesia
B. Referral to orthopaedics for reduction under anaesthetic
C. Application of a scaphoid cast and referral to Fracture clinic
D. Application of a backslab plaster of Paris cast and referral to Fracture clinic the next day
E. Application of a backslab plaster of Paris cast and referral to Fracture clinic in 2–6 weeks

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-week history of productive cough and fever. She has had no sick contacts or foreign travel. She has a background history of mild intermittent asthma and is a non-smoker. She has been taking paracetamol and salbutamol. On clinical examination, her respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, oxygen saturations 96% (on room air), blood pressure 136/82 mmHg and temperature 38.2 °C. On chest auscultation, there is mild expiratory wheeze and coarse crackles in the right lung base.
What is the most appropriate management of this woman?

A. Arrange admission for intravenous (IV) antibiotics and steroids
B. Arrange a chest X-ray
C. Advise to continue symptomatic management and to return in three days if there is no improvement
D. Prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for five days
E. Prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily and clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily for seven days

Correct Answer: D

You receive a telephone referral for a 41-year-old woman with 5% burns to her right hand and arm.
Based on epidemiological data, what is the commonest cause of burns in adults in England and Wales?

A. Flame and flash burns
B. Sunburn
C. Hot water spills and scalds
D. Electrical
E. Contact burns

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department with a history of acute agitation, fever, nausea and vomiting.
On clinical examination, she is agitated and disorientated; her temperature is 40 °C and heart rate 130 bpm, with an irregular pulse, and she has congestive cardiac failure. She has a background history of hyperthyroidism secondary to Graves’ disease , neutropenia and agranulocytosis and cognitive impairment. She lives alone. The following are her laboratory investigations:
Test Result Normal reference range
Free T4 > 100 pmol/l 11–22 pmol/l
Free T3 > 30 pmol/l 3.5–5 pmol/l
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) < 0.01 µU/l 0.17–3.2 µU/l
TSH receptor antibody > 30 U/l < 0.9 U/l
Which of the following should all be included in the management plan of this patient?

A. Carbimazole, iodine, tri-iodothyronine
B. Esmolol, thyroxine, dexamethasone
C. Lugol’s iodine, frusemide, thyroxine
D. Prednisolone, paracetamol, tri-iodothyronine
E. Propylthiouracil, iodine, propranolol, hydrocortisone

Correct Answer: E

A 77-year-old woman presented to the Emergency Department with severe left flank pain. Emergency computed tomography (CT) of her abdomen revealed a stone in the left ureter, and she underwent a successful endoscopic removal of the stone. Five days later, she presented to the clinic with weakness. Her blood pressure was 120/77 mmHg; oedema: absent. Initial investigations revealed Na+ 129 (135–145 mmol/l) and K+ 4.2 (3.5–5.0 mmol/l). Further reports revealed a spot urinary sodium of 66 (≤20 mmol/l). Urine output was normal. She was not receiving any drugs.
What is the cause of her hyponatraemia?

A. Dehydration
B. Renal failure
C. Salt-losing nephropathy
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Pseudohyponatraemia

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old woman sustains an injury to her left hand and visits the Emergency Department. On examination, she is tender in the left anatomical snuffbox. Dedicated scaphoid views (X-rays) are performed. No abnormality is seen. Clinical concern of a fracture remains.
What is the next most appropriate course of action?

A. No treatment is required
B. Request a lateral view of the wrist
C. Repeat scaphoid views in 10-14 days
D. Bone scan
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) wrist after 3 days

Correct Answer: C

A 78-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of weight loss and lethargy. He said he suffers from upper abdominal discomfort, that worsens on eating and on lying down. His stool has become pale in colour. His son also noted he was looking very yellow. He has high blood glucose levels on two different instances.
Which of the following tumour markers would you perform next?

A. CEA
B. CA 19–9
C. Prostate specific antigen (PSA)
D. CA 125
E. Alpha-feto protein (AFP)

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man, with a long history of alcohol abuse, staggers into the Emergency Department and complains of severe abdominal pain. Examination of his abdomen reveals caput medusae.
The blood vessel that is obstructed in this patient is formed by the union of which of the following vessels?

A. Right and left common iliac arteries
B. Superior mesenteric and left gastric veins
C. Inferior mesenteric and left gastric veins
D. Inferior mesenteric and paraumbilical veins
E. Superior mesenteric and splenic veins

Correct Answer: E

A 57-year-old smoker is referred by his General Practitioner (GP) for diagnostic spirometry after presenting with worsening respiratory symptoms suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
With regard to spirometry, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Residual volume can be measured
B. Vital capacity increases with age
C. Peak flow is helpful in the diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Peak flow is a measure of the calibre of the small airways
E. FEV1 is a good marker of disease severity in COPD

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old lady receives an invitation to attend for breast screening at her local hospital.
Which one of the following statements with regard to breast screening is most accurate?

A. Screening is offered to 50–75 year olds
B. Triple assessment is performed
C. Recall is on a yearly basis
D. Two mammogram views are routinely taken
E. Can only be performed on post-menopausal women

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with jaundice and darker urine for the last two weeks. He presented four days ago for the same reasons and the GP ordered some blood tests. He has now returned for the results. The patient has been well otherwise. He has no past medical history and takes no regular medications. He works as a nurse at the local hospital and has no recent travel history. His older brother has recently been diagnosed with colorectal cancer and is currently undergoing treatment.
Physical examination is significant for an obese abdomen and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Murphy’s sign is negative. There is no lymph node enlargement.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.9 °C
Blood pressure 121/59 mmHg
Heart rate 67 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
His blood test results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count 15.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein 49 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Aspartate transaminase (AST) 62 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 69 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 472 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Total bilirubin 71 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alpha fetoprotein 8 IU/l 8–10 IU/l
Anti-hepatitis C virus antibody Negative
Hepatitis A IgG Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen, surface antibody and core antibody Negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibody Negative
Anti-mitochondrial antibody Negative
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cholangiocarcinoma
B. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
E. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)

Correct Answer: A

A 69-year-old retired dinner lady with advanced ovarian cancer is reviewed at home by her General Practitioner (GP). Her husband requested a home visit due to significant deterioration in her health over the past few days, and he is concerned that he can no longer meet her healthcare needs at home without assistance.
During the consultation, the GP discusses considering hospice care for the patient.
To be appropriate for hospice care management, a patient must:

A. Have a diagnosis of terminal cancer
B. Be bed-bound
