C. Have a ‘do not resuscitate’ (DNACPR) decision
D. Have uncontrolled pain
E. No longer be seeking curative treatment

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old schoolteacher presents with abdominal pain and bloating. He complains of recurrent belching after meals and, although he once enjoyed Chinese food, he has now lost all taste for it. This has been going on for the last 12 years.
Ten years ago, he had an upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy, which was reported as normal. After that, he tried many over-the-counter remedies with little effect and a trial of medication from the GP.
What is the next appropriate step for him?

A. Proton pump inhibitors orally
B. Upper GI endoscopy
C. Anti-Helicobacter pylori treatment
D. Acupuncture
E. Gastric motility study

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old woman’s blood tests show a high CA-125. She has had a 6-month history of feeling bloated and has also lost some weight.
Which cancer is an elevated CA125 most likely to suggest?

A. Breast cancer
B. Pancreatic cancer
C. Colorectal cancer
D. Ovarian cancer
E. Rectal cancer

Correct Answer: D

A 48-year-old woman is diagnosed with hypertension following ambulatory monitoring, which showed her average blood pressure to be 158/98 mmHg. She is commenced on 2.5 mg ramipril therapy. Her General Practitioner (GP) performs an assessment of her renal function:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 5.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 89 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
One month later, the patient’s blood pressure was recorded as 114/74 mmHg and they have repeat renal function tests performed:
Investigation Result
Na+ 137 mmol/l
K+ 5.2 mmol/l
Urea 5.9 mmol/l
Creatinine 112 µmol/l
Which of the following actions should the GP perform in light of these results?

A. Continue ramipril and re-check urea and electrolytes (U&Es) in 1-months’ time
B. Reduce dose of ramipril from 2.5 mg to 1.25 mg
C. Stop ramipril and switch to an aldosterone receptor blocker (ARB)
D. Stop ramipril and switch to a calcium-channel blocker
E. Temporarily withhold ramipril for two weeks and then re-check blood pressure and U&Es

Correct Answer: A

This 55-year-old woman has the large lesion, just above the natal cleft, shown in the picture. She has similar lesions on the elbows, knees and scalp, and scattered smaller lesions on the rest of the trunk. The lesions itch slightly. They have troubled her for most of her adult life. Topical treatments provide some improvement, but the rash inevitably returns.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What terminology can be used best to describe the lesion shown in the picture?

A. Patch
B. Papule
C. Plaque
D. Macule
E. Nodule

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old patient presents with a history of well demarcated, erythematous lesions with silvery-white scaling plaques on the extensor surfaces of the elbows. There is evidence of nail pitting.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Topical 1% hydrocortisone
B. Topical betnovate + vitamin D
C. Topical dermovate + vitamin D
D. Phototherapy
E. Biologic treatment

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old patient is referred for investigation of hypertension. On examination, she has a beaked nose and telangiectasia on the face. There is evidence of tight, waxy skin of the fingers, with calcification on one finger. She has had Raynaud’s disease for many years.
Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be positive?

A. Anti-centromere antibody
B. Anti-Scl-70
C. Anti-RNP antibody
D. Anti-Ro antibody
E. Anti-Jo-1 antibody

Correct Answer: A

A 3-year-old boy has a biopsy performed on a large, painless testicular tumour. On microscopy, tissue is noted that appears to resemble glomeruli.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Embryonal carcinoma
B. Leydig cell tumour
C. Yolk cell tumour
D. Seminoma
E. Choriocarcinoma

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman has been referred to the Ear, Nose and Throat clinic complaining of a sensation of feeling pressure and tightness in her throat. This feeling lessens when she eats and drinks. She notices that the sensation has been getting worse over the last few weeks as she has transitioned into a more stressful job role. She has previously been tested for acid reflux, which was negative, and a trial of omeprazole led to no significant improvement in her symptoms. Her General Practitioner suggested that it might be post-nasal drip, but a nasal spray similarly led to no significant change in symptoms. She has no history of smoking and is a social drinker. She recently had a laryngoscopy, which identified no pathology.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Pantoprazole
B. Restart omeprazole
C. Stress reduction techniques
D. Throat clearing
E. Water restriction

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old woman attends for her 20-week anomaly scan. This is her first pregnancy, and she is a late booker, as she only found out she was pregnant at 16 weeks’ gestation. The sonographer calls the consultant in the room, as she has identified spina bifida. The patient tells you her sister’s baby had the same diagnosis a few years ago.
Given the above, what would be the recommended folic acid dosing for this patient in future pregnancies?

A. Commence folic acid 400 μg daily as soon as pregnancy is discovered and continue throughout the pregnancy
B. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily as soon as pregnancy is discovered and continue throughout the pregnancy
C. Commence folic acid 400 μg daily in the pre-conception period and continue until week 12 of gestation
D. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily in the pre-conception period and continue until week 12 of gestation
E. Commence folic acid 5 mg daily in the pre-conception period and discontinue once pregnancy is discovered

Correct Answer: D

A surgeon performs an open repair of a large popliteal aneurysm, which extends proximally to involve the femoral artery. He opens the adductor canal and identifies its contents.
Which of the following structures is located in the adductor canal?

A. Nerve to the vastus lateralis
B. Profunda femoris artery
C. Saphenous nerve
D. Great saphenous vein
E. Sciatic nerve

Correct Answer: C

During the palliative care attachment for a group of final-year medical students, the palliative care consultant is discussing the possible alternatives to conventional pharmacological management for pain symptoms.
Which of the following herbal therapies have been clinically shown to have an analgesic benefit in palliative care?

A. Arnica
B. Capsaicin
C. Cod liver oil
D. Clove oil
E. Echinacea

Correct Answer: B

You are the Foundation Year doctor on the Gastroenterology ward round. The consultant is reviewing a new patient to the ward. This is a 36-year-old man with active Crohn’s disease. From the medical notes, you are aware that the patient has had a number of previous admissions to the Unit and poor response to conventional therapy. The consultant mentions the possibility of using a drug called infliximab, and the patient asks whether this is an antibiotic.
What is the mode of action of infliximab?

A. Antibody against tumour necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α)
B. Antibody against CD20
C. Interleukin (IL)-1 blocker
D. α-4 integrin antagonist
E. IL-2 blocker

Correct Answer: A

A 49-year-old long-distance lorry driver presents with difficulty in maintaining a strong grip with his right hand. When you ask the patient to hold out the affected hand, the attempt is shown in the picture below.
Further examination reveals loss of sensation in areas of the forearm and wrist. A peripheral nerve injury is suspected.
Which of the following nerves has been injured?

A. Radial
B. Median
C. Ulnar
D. Musculocutaneous
E. Dorsal interosseous

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl with known sickle cell disease presents with increasing pain of the right thigh and fever. An X-ray of the femur reveals bone changes suggestive of osteomyelitis.
What is the most likely causative organism?

A. Group B streptococci
B. Proteus mirabilis
C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
D. Salmonella enteritides
E. Escherichia coli

Correct Answer: D

A patient twists his left knee on the football pitch. The knee swelled up a few minutes after the injury. He has difficulty walking down stairs and feels as if his knee wants to give way. On examination, there is instability of the knee joint and giving when the tibia is pushed posteriorly.
What is the most likely structure to have been injured?

A. Anterior cruciate ligament
B. Posterior cruciate ligament
C. Medial meniscus
D. Lateral meniscus
E. Popliteus tendon

Correct Answer: B

A 66-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast undergoes surgery to remove the lump. Histological examination shows that the mass contains a large number of blood vessels.
An increase in which of the following is the most likely stimulus for the proliferation of these vessels?

A. Tissue oxygen partial pressure
B. Growth hormone
C. Angiostatin
D. Vascular endothelial growth factor
E. Thrombospondin

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner, complaining of double vision. He notes that he has developed a squint and his left eye appears to be looking inwards towards his nose. On examination, an inability to move the left eye to the left is noted and he is diagnosed with a lateral rectus palsy.
A lesion of which cranial nerve is most likely responsible for his symptoms?

A. Abducens nerve
B. Oculomotor nerve
C. Optic nerve
D. Trigeminal nerve
E. Trochlear nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman presents with marked bleeding through the vagina (PV) and a hydatidiform mole is diagnosed and treated by evacuation of the uterus. Despite this, she remains unwell and β-human chorionic gonadotrophin (β-HCG) continues to rise over the following weeks.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adrenal adenoma
B. Pituitary adenoma
C. Ectopic pregnancy
D. Choriocarcinoma
E. Second, untreated, non-invasive hydatidiform mole

Correct Answer: D

A 69-year-old smoker complains of a persistent cough, haemoptysis, wheeze and hoarseness of voice. He is diagnosed with small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC). He has gained weight, and he says that his face has recently ‘ballooned’.
Which of the following additional symptoms is this patient most likely to be experiencing?

A. Insatiable thirst and polyuria
B. Cold intolerance and hair loss
C. Galactorrhoea
D. Restlessness and tremor
E. Poor wound healing and hirsutism

Correct Answer: E

As part of the investigation of breathlessness, a 72-year-old patient has spirometry performed. You learn that he spent all his working life in a factory. The following results are available:
Measured Expected
FEV1 (L) 2.59 3.46
FVC (L) 3.16 4.21
Ratio (%) 82 81
Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A. Asthma
B. Emphysema
C. Bronchiectasis
D. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)
E. Asbestosis

Correct Answer: E

A 77-year-old man presents to the clinic with increasing shortness of breath and dry cough over the past three months. He is breathless after walking a few hundred metres. He is a non-smoker and takes medication for type II diabetes mellitus. On examination, his pulse is 80/minute and regular, blood pressure (BP) 130/70 mmHg, bilateral clubbing of digits, oxygen saturation (SpO2) in room air is 90%. Auscultation reveals bilateral, fine, late inspiratory crackles, more marked in the mid-zones and at the lung bases. Chest X-ray reveals patchy shadowing at the lung bases.
What is the definitive investigation in guiding his management?

A. Antinuclear antibody (ANA), anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP)
B. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis
C. Bronchoalveolar lavage
D. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chest
E. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs)

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old primigravida presents for her booking visit at eight weeks’ gestation. She is eager to find out exactly what her due date is and the gender of the baby. She asks you whether you can refer her for a scan as soon as possible. You explain that there is a national screening programme in pregnancy, and antenatal scans are offered at specific stages during the course of the pregnancy.
Which of the following statements best describes antenatal screening with ultrasound scans?

A. All pregnant women in the United Kingdom (UK) are offered a minimum of three scans in pregnancy
B. The anomaly scan is performed any time between 17+0 and 20+6 weeks’ gestation
C. The first antenatal ultrasound scan can be offered as early as nine weeks’ gestation
D. Women presenting with severe symptomatic hyperemesis gravidarum before the first scan is performed should be offered an early pregnancy ultrasound scan
E. Women with pre-existing diabetes have fetal growth scans every two weeks from 28 to 36 weeks’ gestation

Correct Answer: D

A mother brings her 7-month-old son Henry to the Emergency Department (ED) at 0700 h. She is very concerned. She reports that he has been crying all night. She has two older children: a 4-year-old daughter Allison and a 2-year-old son James, who are both well. Henry was born at 40+1 weeks by normal vaginal delivery. She developed gestational diabetes, but there were no other complications during the pregnancy or birth. Henry has had all his vaccinations. He was breast-fed until 6 months old, then bottle-fed. Mother reports that he has been crying non-stop since 0400 h this morning. She tried to feed him, but he vomited twice, minutes after the feed. The first vomit contained food only, the second time it was greenish. Mom has not noticed a change in faeces or urine, except that she has not had to change his nappies since last night. On examination: crying, warm and well perfused, heart rate 150 beats per minute (bpm), abdomen appears distended with tinkling bowel sounds. When you look in his nappies, you notice his stools look like redcurrant jelly.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
B. Meconium obstruction
C. Intussusception
D. Ileus
E. Duodenal atresia

Correct Answer: C

With regard to haemolysis, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Hereditary spherocytosis is predominately inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern
B. Chronic haemolysis predisposes to gallstones
C. Low reticulocyte count is typically seen
D. Elevated serum haptoglobins are seen
E. Elevated conjugated bilirubin is typical

Correct Answer: B

A mother of three brings her youngest daughter, aged 16, to the general practitioner (GP) as she is yet to start menstruating, whereas both her sisters had menarche at the age of 12.
The patient has developed secondary female sexual characteristics and has a normal height. She reports struggling with headaches and one episode of galactorrhoea.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals an intracranial tumour measuring 11 mm in maximal diameter.
Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the first-line management option?

A. Medical treatment with cabergoline
B. Medical treatment with metoclopramide
C. Medical treatment with thyroxine
D. Surgery to remove the tumour
E. Radiotherapy

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old gentleman presents with a recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He has been on warfarin for the last 2 months since his first DVT.
What is the appropriate management plan from now on?

A. International normalised ratio (INR) target at 2.5 and complete 3 months of treatment
B. Increase the target INR to 3.5 and finish treatment at 6 months
C. Lifelong warfarin at target INR of 2
C. D. Lifelong warfarin at target INR of 2.5
E. Lifelong warfarin at target INR of 3.5

Correct Answer: E

A 37-week-old neonate has been born with an abdominal defect described as 6 cm of herniated bowel through the abdominal wall. The bowel is exposed without a covering. The patient is hypotensive (50/30), tachycardic (220 bpm) and hypothermic (35.2 °C). Bloods were taken, which showed the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 200 g/l Female: 115–155 g/l
Male: 135–175 g/l
White cell count 27 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 20 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Incubate, fluid-resuscitate, pass nasogastric (NG) tube, surgery within a few hours
B. Incubate, fluid-resuscitate, pass NG tube, surgery immediately
C. Incubate, fluid-restrict, surgery on an elective basis
D. Incubate, abdominal X-ray, surgical review
E. Incubate, fluid-resuscitate, surgery electively

Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old factory worker is prescribed low molecular weight heparin following a left hemicolectomy for colorectal cancer, as he is likely to be immobile post-surgery.
Which one of the following is most accurate regarding heparin?

A. Is given intravenously in prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
B. May cause osteomalacia
C. Is reversible with protamine
D. Has a half-life of 12 hours
E. Action is monitored by the international normalised ratio (INR)

Correct Answer: C

You are a General Practitioner in Scotland who has been called to a man who has become very confused over a period of a few days. He has a previous history of depressive illness. On examination, which he was reluctant to consent to, it is clear that he has a severe chest infection. He has hallucinations, a high fever and refuses all treatment. It is clear that the chest infection is the cause of an acute delirium.
Can you use provisions in the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 to admit him to hospital?

A. Yes – administration of treatment under the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 may be appropriate where the physical disorder is a direct cause or consequence of the mental disorder
B. Yes – administration of treatment under the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 may be appropriate where a person with a history of mental disorder refuses treatment for a physical disorder
C. No – but you could use the Age of Legal Capacity Act to treat his physical disorder
D. No – his refusal of treatment is separate from the hallucinations
E. It depends – has the patient expressed suicidal ideas in the past?


Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old man visits his General Practitioner (GP) with his wife. Since retiring from the army, he has been struggling with anger issues. This is affecting his marriage, and he has been drinking more heavily to help him to relax. He also reports feeling low in mood and having frequent nightmares, including flashbacks from his past experiences while fighting in Iraq.
Which one of the following psychological therapies would be most appropriate to manage this condition?

A. Anger management
B. Eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing (EMDR)
C. Psychoanalytical therapy
D. Psychologically focused debriefing
E. Trauma-focused cognitive behavioural therapy

Correct Answer: E

You review a patient on the ward on day two of admission. He is a 17-year-old with no medical history; however, his family history reveals that his mother has type II diabetes. The 17-year-old originally presented with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3/15. The paramedics recorded that the glucose monitor at the scene read ‘LO’ and he was given intravenous dextrose and intramuscular glucagon. On arrival to the Emergency Department, blood glucose was 2.1 and his treatment was continued. He is now euglycaemic off treatment. Blood tests were taken at the time and they have just returned. These tests reveal that:
Serum insulin – raised
C-peptide – raised
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

A. Gliclazide overdose
B. Insulin overdose
C. Metformin overdose
D. Starvation
E. Type 1 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: A

A 23 year old patient presents to the accident and emergency department having been involved in a fight 1 hour ago. He cannot give you much history as he is still inebriated.
On examination, he has bruising around his left eye and significant facial swelling on the left lower aspect. He is not tender to palpation either side of his nose. When you ask him to bite down he complains of his mouth feeling strange and you notice his left sided teeth come together before the right side. He is also missing two teeth on the left side.
What would the most appropriate next investigation be?

A. CT facial skeleton
B. Chest radiograph
C. MRI facial skeleton
D. Mandible radiographs with (orthopantogram)
E. Lateral facial radiographs

Correct Answer: D

An elderly man presents with a severe headache, nausea, vomiting and a painful, red right eye. He has reduced visual acuity in the right eye and normal visual acuity in the left eye. On examination, he had a stony hard eye with marked pericorneal reddening and a hazy corneal reflex. Tonometry revealed a raised intraocular pressure. The patient mentions that he has recently been started on some new medication by his general practitioner.
Which medication might account for this acute presentation?

A. Acetazolamide
B. Bisoprolol
C. Ipratropium nebuliser
D. Montelukast
E. Topical pilocarpine

Correct Answer: C

You are evaluating a 62-year-old man who has presented with a change in his hearing. On tuning fork testing, you find that the Weber’s test localises to the right, Rinne’s test on the right demonstrates that bone conduction is greater than air. Rinne’s test on the left demonstrates that air conduction is greater than bone conduction.
What do these results indicate?

A. Left conductive hearing deficit
B. Right sensorineural hearing deficit
C. Left sensorineural hearing deficit
D. Mixed sensorineural and conductive deafness
E. Right conductive hearing deficit

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old patient presents to her General Practitioner (GP), complaining of chest pain and difficulty breathing when climbing up stairs. She is otherwise well. On examination, she has a slow-rising pulse; her blood pressure is 130/100 mmHg, and the GP hears a murmur on auscultation.
Which one of the following best describes the likely murmur heard in this patient?

A. Ejection systolic murmur (ESM)
B. Pansystolic murmur
C. Mid-diastolic murmur
D. Early diastolic murmur (EDM)
E. Continuous murmur

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old man sustains a myocardial infarction (MI) that causes necrosis of the anterior papillary muscle of the right ventricle. As a result of the MI, the man now has valve prolapse.
Which of the following structures is most likely to be responsible for the prolapse?

A. Anterior and posterior cusps of the mitral valve
B. Posterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve
C. Anterior and posterior cusps of the tricuspid valve
D. Anterior and septal cusps of the tricuspid valve
E. Anterior and septal cusps of the mitral valve

Correct Answer: C

You are asked to review a patient who has developed an acutely painful spreading rash that is associated with a fever. On examination, you identify a spreading erythema of the lower limb that is hot to touch. You diagnose cellulitis and prescribe appropriate antibiotics.
What is the most likely causative organism?

A. Group A beta-haemolytic streptococcus
B. Staphylococcus aureus
C. Methicillin resistant staph. Aureus
D. Haemophilus influenza
E. Clostridium perfringens

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with acute-onset, worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain. He has a significantly reduced appetite and has vomited several times over the past couple of days. On examination, there is marked tenderness on palpation in the right iliac fossa. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen confirms acute appendicitis. Following surgical review, a decision to perform an emergency open appendicectomy is made.
Which is the single most appropriate preoperative management for this patient?

A. A single dose of intravenous (iv) Tazocin® 30 minutes before the procedure
B. Continue oral hydration as tolerated
C. Insertion of nasogastric tube
D. iv flucloxacillin
E. Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old man who lives in a local hostel for the homeless is added onto the medical take following a seizure. He last consumed alcohol 32 h previously and, when assessed, he is tremulous and anxious, wishing to self-discharge. His nutritional status and personal hygiene are poor.
Which one of the following is the most essential to be carefully monitored while an inpatient?

A. Gamma glutamyl transferase (GGT)
B. Serum alcohol level
C. Sodium
D. Phosphate
E. Haemoglobin

Correct Answer: D

A mother presents with her 7-year-old son who was recently diagnosed with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
She is attending surgery, as she is still struggling to manage her son’s disruptive and challenging behaviour, despite group-based support and environmental modifications.
Which of the following treatment options is first line in the management of ADHD?

A. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
B. Dexamphetamine
C. Diazepam
D. Melatonin
E. Methylphenidate

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old man presents to the Cancer Outpatient Department with extensive back pain. He says that the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and opioids which have been prescribed are not working. He has been diagnosed with rapidly progressing castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). He has undergone a full course of chemotherapy (taxane) and investigations have identified vertebral and visceral metastases.
What is the next best step of management in this patient?

A. Bisphosphonates
B. Enzalutamide
C. External beam radiation therapy (EBRT)
D. Radium-223
E. Stereotactic body radiotherapy (STBRT)

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old woman has recently noticed that all of her relationships end in a dramatic fashion. She tells you that she has poor taste in friends and boyfriends and that everyone ends up turning out to be a terrible person.
Which one of the following defence mechanisms is most likely in this patient?

A. Identification
B. Dissociation
C. Sublimation
D. Reaction formation
E. Splitting

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old intravenous (IV) drug user presents with pyrexia (39.8 °C) and general malaise. On examination, you identify a pan-systolic murmur at the lower left sternal edge. You also notice that he has vertical red lines running along his nails and he tells you that he has been experiencing night sweats.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Mitral stenosis
C. Infective endocarditis
D. IV drug user (IVDU)-associated hepatitis C
E. Tricuspid regurgitation

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man comes to the general practitioner complaining of a pruritic rash on both of his elbows. He has a history of hypothyroidism and malabsorption. He has been advised to avoid wheat, rye and oats, and he is also taking iron tablets to treat iron deficiency. An image of the rash is shown below.
Which of the following is the underlying skin lesion?

A. Dermatitis herpetiformis
B. Erythema multiforme
C. Erythema nodosum
D. Folliculitis
E. Cellulitis

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man was admitted with pain in the left groin. He had fallen from his chair, after which the pain started. He was unable to walk and his left leg was externally rotated. X-rays revealed a neck of femur fracture. He lives alone in a flat and is a vegetarian. His past medical history includes shortness of breath, body itching and occasional swelling of legs. His blood tests revealed:
Investigation Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 135–175 g/l
Calcium 3.5 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate 1.52 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 184 mm/h 0–15 mm/h
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Vitamin D deficiency
B. Osteoporosis
C. Multiple myeloma
D. Acute leukaemia
E. Malignancy with metastasis

Correct Answer: C

A 12-year-old boy trips, while playing football, and falls to the ground. He lands on his right arm and is brought to the Emergency Department for evaluation. An X-ray of the right arm demonstrates a mid-humeral shaft fracture. There is no evidence of growing haematoma, and the patient has a strong radial pulse with good perfusion. Doppler studies of the arm do not show bleeding.
Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely to suffer?

A. Atrophy of the deltoid muscle
B. Inability to flex the wrist
C. Loss of sensation to the right fifth finger
D. Compartment syndrome
E. Loss of sensation to the dorsum of the right hand

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old nulliparous woman is being investigated by the Infertility Clinic.
Initial investigations, including thyroid function tests and mid-luteal phase progesterone and prolactin levels, are normal. Semen analysis is also normal. No sexually transmitted infections were detected.
Her periods are regular and heavy, with dysmenorrhoea starting 1–2 days before the bleeding. She reports deep dyspareunia. A transvaginal ultrasound was normal.
Which of the following investigations is most likely to offer a definite diagnosis?

A. Explorative laparoscopy
B. Hysterosalpingography
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen pelvis
D. CA-125
E. Transabdominal ultrasound

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old man was admitted to hospital for a cellulitis that had not improved with empirical antibiotic treatment. He is currently taking warfarin for atrial fibrillation and is allergic to penicillin. During the course of his stay he developed a severe diarrhoea, and was put into a side-room after a stool sample returned positive for Clostridium difficile.
Which antibiotic most likely contributed to his developing C. difficile?

A. Clarithromycin
B. Clindamycin
C. Amoxicillin
D. Ceftaroline
E. Metronidazole

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old pregnant woman presents to the genetic counselling clinic along with her husband. They are anxious to find out the chance of their baby inheriting an autosomal-recessive genetic condition for which the woman is a known carrier. The carrier status of the husband is unknown.
Both the woman and her husband are unaffected by the condition; the condition in question has a carrier rate of C. 1 in 1E. 0E. 0 in the general population.
What is the chance of the baby being affected by the condition?

A. 1 in 4
A. B. 1 in 4E. 0E. 0
C. 1 in 1E. 0E. 0
D. 1 in 2E. 0E. 0
E. 0

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man falls while skiing. He sees you in clinic. He has weakness of pincer grip and pain and laxity on valgus stress of his thumb.
What is the most likely injury?

A. Scaphoid fracture
B. Extensor pollicis longus strain
C. Ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb injury
D. De Quervain’s tenosynovitis
E. Bennett’s fracture

Correct Answer: C

This 80-year-old man has the skin lesion on the dorsal aspect of his right forearm shown in the picture. He first noticed it when it was a few millimetres in diameter about 12 months ago and he thinks it has increased a little in size. It is sometimes hard to see but is easier to feel because of its rough texture.
Which of the following is the most likely causative factor?

A. Arsenic
B. Genetic
C. Human papilloma virus
D. Sunlight
E. Vitamin A deficiency

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents at 16 weeks’ gestation, requesting an abortion. Her relationship has fallen apart; she has moved back in with her parents, and her depression has flared up. She feels hopeless and states that, at this stage, she cannot cope with a baby. She has undergone a thorough consultation, and her decision remains unchanged.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A. No management required at present; reassess the patient in two weeks to allow her time to change her mind
B. Oral mifepristone
B. C. Oral mifepristone followed by vaginal misoprostol as an outpatient
D. Vaginal misoprostol
E. Surgical evacuation of products of conception

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman who was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease 5 years ago presented with severe right flank pain. She said that she had had similar episodes in the past, but repeated ultrasonography and CT scans of her abdomen had not shown any pathology. Gastroenterology consultation was done and a barium meal study showed extensive strictures in the jejunum and ileum. The most recent ultrasonography reveals two small stones in the right renal pelvis.
What is the likely composition of these renal stones?

A. Calcium phosphate
B. Cystine
C. Calcium oxalate
D. Struvite
E. Uric acid

Correct Answer: C

Examine the following arterial blood gas results:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.6 7.35–7.45
pO2 13.3 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 5.6 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
HCO3 32 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
SaO2 97% on room air
Which of the following clinical scenarios best fits the arterial blood gas results shown above?

A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Septic shock
C. Pneumothorax
D. Hyperventilation
E. Bowel ischaemia

Correct Answer: A

A 75-year-old African-American has marked left-sided weakness and an expressive aphasia. He is diagnosed with a stroke. Blood results show the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 90 g/l 135–175 g/l
Platelets 80 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
calcium 3.80 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
creatinine 128 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which investigation is likely to reveal the cause of this man’s stroke?

A. Computed tomography (CT) head
B. Urinary Bence Jones proteins
C. MRI head
D. Liver function tests
E. X-ray spine

Correct Answer: B

A 34-year-old woman presents on day 28 postpartum with burning pain in the nipples bilaterally and itching. She reports symptoms are worse after feeds.
On examination, you notice that the nipples are erythematous, swollen and fissured. The breasts are unremarkable. Her observations are stable, and she is apyrexial. She tells you she wants you to review her baby and that she noticed small white patches in his mouth.
Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Arrange an urgent referral under a 2-week wait to the Breast team
B. Oral flucloxacillin three times a day
C. Regular emollients and corticosteroid cream
D. Topical antibacterial cream
E. Topical antifungal cream

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department in Nepal. She had flown from the United Kingdom the previous day for a skiing trip with her friends. She mentions that she felt light-headed and dizzy in the hotel lobby in the morning. After taking a short rest, she continued feeling unwell and complained of nausea and generalised dull headache. She is obese and does not have a previous history of migraine. She is well orientated but feels that her nausea and headache are worsening.
What is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

A. Administer oxygen and acetazolamide
B. Antiemetics and a dose of prophylactic antibiotics
C. Nifedipine
D. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and bed rest
E. Transfer the patient immediately to a location at lower altitude

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old man presents to his GP with his wife. His wife describes how he has become more forgetful, often missing plans with friends and occasionally forgetting to turn the cooker off. He has also recently had several episodes of urinary incontinence. The patient’s cranial and peripheral nerve examination is normal, apart from the patient having a slow gait, with decreased step height and decreased foot-clearance.
Given the history and examination finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Parkinson’s disease
B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
C. Multiple sclerosis
D. Guillain–Barré syndrome
E. Cauda equina

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old doctor is referred to the Breast Clinic after finding a painless pea-sized lump in her right breast. Her mother died aged 43 after suffering from breast cancer, and the patient is very concerned that she may have the condition also.
With regard to breast cancer, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A. All patients with BRCA1 will develop breast cancer
B. Breast cancer is more common in women from low socioeconomic groups
C. Malignant lumps are usually painful
D. Most breast cancers are lobular carcinomas
E. Women with a history of ovarian cancer are at increased risk of breast cancer

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two hour history of central crushing chest pain. She has a background of ischaemic heart disease and poorly controlled diabetes. The electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST-elevation in V1, V2 and V3, whilst serum troponin levels are outstanding.
Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive management strategy?

A. Therapeutic alteplase
B. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
C. Treatment dose aspirin and clopidogrel
D. High-flow oxygen and intravenous morphine
E. Await troponin result before further management

Correct Answer: B

This 38-year-old woman has been epileptic since infancy. She also has intellectual disability. On her face, she has multiple small reddish nodules that coalesce to form larger plaques. There are multiple areas of depigmentation on the trunk. There is an area of thick, pigmented, leathery skin that is dimpled like orange peel on the lower lumbar area. Her nails are shown in the picture.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the abnormality shown?

A. Kaposi’s sarcoma
B. Keloid scars
C. Periungual fibromas
D. Periungual warts
E. Pyogenic granulomas

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old waitress is admitted with increasing confusion over the past 48 hours. She is normally well, with no medical history of note. She takes the oral contraceptive pill, but is on no other medication. She does not drink or smoke and denies taking recreational drugs. Blood and urine tests are concerning, for a possible diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH).
With regard to SIADH secretion, which of the following statements is true?

A. Hypernatraemia is typical
B. It may occur in subarachnoid haemorrhage
C. Intravenous saline is the treatment of choice
D. It may be induced by demeclocycline
E. Occurs frequently in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Correct Answer: B

A 4-year-old child of African descent presents with a 2-day history of increasing abdominal pain. It is not associated with nausea or vomiting, and the bowels are opening regularly. The child’s mother tells you that he has had a few episodes of similar symptoms in the past, but none as severe.
On examination, the child has generalised abdominal tenderness, and splenomegaly is noted. After further investigation, the child is diagnosed with sickle-cell anaemia.
Which organ is most responsible for the removal of sickled red blood cells from the circulatory system?

A. Axillary lymph nodes
B. Thymus
C. Bone marrow
D. Liver
E. Spleen

Correct Answer: E

An 11-year-old boy is seen in the Paediatric Clinic due to progressive bilateral upper leg weakness. He struggles to walk up the stairs and is no longer able to take part in school sports due to severe muscle cramps on exertion. There is a family history of muscle problems on his mothers’ side of the family and the paediatrician suspects a genetic muscular dystrophy.
What is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Creatine kinase
B. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
C. Genetic testing
D. Muscle biopsy
E. Serum magnesium

Correct Answer: A

A newborn baby boy develops bluish skin and mucous membrane discoloration immediately after full-term vaginal delivery. The pregnancy and labour were uneventful. The arterial oxygen saturation is 70%. The arterial partial pressure of oxygen is 35 mmHg (normal range is 75-100 mmHg) after administration of 100% oxygen. There is no evidence of pulmonary oedema or respiratory distress on examination.
What is the most likely cause of the newborn’s discoloration?

A. Tetralogy of Fallot with severe pulmonary stenosis
B. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
C. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
D. Severe ventricular septal defect
E. Tricuspid atresia with atrial and ventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: B

Ben Masters, a 17-year-old college student, attends the Dermatology Clinic, very concerned about his appearance. He has suffered from severe acne for several years now and has tried multiple over-the-counter preparations and topical and oral antibiotics, without effect. He has been reading about Roaccutane® (an isotretinoin) and is keen to try this.
What is the most common side-effect Ben may experience when taking Roaccutane®?

A. Dry skin and lips
B. Night sweats
C. Peptic ulceration
D. Photosensitivity
E. Weight gain

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old woman, a known type 1 diabetic, was asked to attend the General Practice (GP) Surgery for her results in the diabetic retinopathy screening.
You asked your GP supervisor if you can examine her eyes so that you can get signed off for using a direct ophthalmoscope. You found out that she had some dot-and-blot haemorrhages in her right eye with some venous looping and beading in the peripheral retina.
What is the next step in management for this patient's eye condition?

A. Annual screening
B. Fast-track referral to ophthalmology
C. Pan-retinal laser photocoagulation
D. Routine referral to ophthalmology
E. Routine referral to an optometrist for a regular eye test

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department after a low-speed road traffic collision. He removed himself from the vehicle and was standing in the layby upon arrival of the ambulance. Since he was complaining of neck pain, he was immobilised at the scene as a precaution. All observation en route and on arrival to the Emergency Department are within the normal range, but he is complaining of ongoing pain in the ‘middle’ of his neck. There are no neurological symptoms of note. When you examine him, there are no other injuries apparent, but he is complaining of pain when you press over his upper cervical spine.
What is the next step in the investigation and management of this patient?

A. Remove the cervical collar and allow the patient to mobilise
B. Give analgesia and re-examine the patient in 20 minutes
C. Request an urgent computed tomography (CT) scan of the cervical spine
D. Urgent orthopaedic consultation regarding further management
E. Keep the patient immobilised and request plain films of the cervical spine

Correct Answer: E

A marine biologist was snorkelling among giant stingrays when the tail (barb) of one of the stingrays suddenly pierced his chest. The tip of the barb pierced the right ventricle and the man instinctively removed it in the water. When he was brought onto the boat, there was absence of heart sounds, reduced cardiac output and engorged jugular veins.
Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?

A. Stroke
B. Deep vein thrombosis
C. Cardiac tamponade
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Haemothorax

Correct Answer: C

You are asked to see a patient on the Obstetric Ward who is suffering from severe eclampsia. Two hours previously, she began to bleed profusely from her cannula site. After checking her coagulation screen, you are suspicious she has developed disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
Which one of the following test result would you expect in a diagnosis of DIC?

A. High platelets
B. Normal fibrinogen
C. Elevated prothrombin time (PT)
D. Elevated antithrombin III
E. Normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner after he has been complaining of back pain. The pain started gradually and has been getting worse over the past few months. The man works as a software engineer and does not remember lifting any heavy items or trauma to his back.
An MRI of the back is requested which shows a mass compressing the lumbar vertebrae and the radiology report advises that this could be a metastatic mass. The patient is referred to the oncology service for further evaluation and was diagnosed with testicular seminoma.
Which lymph nodes does this type of tumour usually metastasise to?

A. Inguinal
B. Internal iliac
C. External iliac
D. Lateral aortic
E. Inferior mesenteric

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old diabetic woman presents with general malaise and epigastric pain of 2 hours’ duration. She is hypotensive (blood pressure 90/55) and has jugular venous distension. Cardiac workup reveals ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V5 and V6. A diagnosis of high lateral myocardial infarction is made, and the patient is prepared for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
Blockage of which of the following arteries is most likely to lead to this type of infarction?

A. Anterior interventricular (left anterior descending) artery
B. Posterior interventricular artery
C. Left (obtuse) marginal artery
D. Right (acute) marginal artery
E. Right mainstem coronary artery

Correct Answer: C

A 66-year-old lady presents to the general practitioner with gradual onset of bradykinesia, rigidity and tremor.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cerebral tumour
B. Lewy body dementia
C. Parkinson’s disease
D. Benign essential tremor
E. Alzheimer’s disease

Correct Answer: C

A man seeks counselling because of marital discord. He and his wife have been having problems because he is uninterested in doing anything but watching football. He has neglected his responsibilities at home and his work performance is beginning to suffer as well.
Which one of the following best describes his behaviour?

A. Fixation
B. Dissociation
C. Sublimation
D. Reaction formation
E. Splitting

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old previously healthy man is involved in an accident at work. He is brought to Accident and Emergency where he is found to have superficial abrasions to the left side of his chest and upper abdomen, together with an obvious deformity of the left humerus. Radiograph of the left arm shows a displaced mid-shaft humerus fracture. Neurovascular examination reveals radial nerve palsy, together with absent peripheral pulses and a cool, clammy distal arm. He was given oral paracetamol at work, while waiting for the ambulance to arrive. Pain score remains 9/10. Parameters are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Temperature 36.8 °C 36.1–37.2 °C
Pulse 115 bpm 60–100 bpm
Blood pressure 145/93 mmHg < 120/80 mmHg
Oxygen saturations 99% on room air 94–98%
Respiratory rate 24 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Which of the following is the most appropriate form of pain relief?

A. Intravenous (IV) paracetamol
B. Oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
C. Oral morphine (Oramorph®)
D. IV morphine
E. Oxycodone prolonged release orally

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old man complains of sudden onset severe pain in his right loin. The pain started 4 hours ago just below the right side of his rib cage, and has gradually moved down to his right groin, radiating into his right testis. He has not noticed any visible haematuria. He is unable to tolerate physical examination, and is writhing around on his bed.
What the most appropriate initial management?

A. Paracetamol po
B. Diclofenac im
C. Morphine po
D. Morphine iv
E. Diazepam pr

Correct Answer: B

A 63-year-old man from Nigeria developed large, destructive, multifocal lesions in his vertebral column, ribs and skull. A bone marrow aspirate from this patient is shown below.
A diagnosis of multiple myeloma was made following electrophoretic analysis of serum revealing increased levels of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and Bence Jones proteins.
This disease is due to abnormal accumulation of which immune cell type?

A. Plasma cells
B. Monocytes
C. Osteoclasts
D. T cells
E. Macrophages

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 3-week history of tiredness, epigastric discomfort and an episode of passing black stools. His past medical history includes a 4-year history of rheumatoid arthritis for which he takes regular methotrexate, folic acid and naproxen. He recently received a course of oral corticosteroids for a flare of his rheumatoid arthritis. He denies alcohol consumption and is a non-smoker. On systemic enquiry he reports a good appetite and denies any weight loss. The examination reveals conjunctival pallor and a soft abdomen with tenderness in the epigastrium. His temperature is 36.7°C, blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 81 beats per minute and oxygen saturations are 96% on room air. A full blood count is taken which reveals the following:
Investigation Result Normal Value
Haemoglobin 76 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 68 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 5.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 380 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atrophic gastritis
B. Barrett's oesophagus
C. Gastric cancer
D. Oesophageal varices
E. Peptic ulcer

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old man is referred to the Acute Medicine Unit by his GP with hyponatraemia. He feels generally unwell and apathetic but is orientated and has no seizure activity. He has noted 6 kg weight loss over the last three months. He is not taking any medications and has a history of heavy smoking. Clinically he is euvolaemic. Chest X-ray shows a right hilar mass. His blood results are listed below:
Investigation Result Normal range
Serum sodium 123 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Serum osmolality 267 mosmol/kg 275–295 mosmol/kg
Urine sodium 55 mmol/l <20 mmol/l
Urine osmolality 110 mosmol/l <100 mosmol/kg
Morning cortisol 450 nmol/l 119–618 mmol/l
What is the most appropriate initial management of his hyponatraemia?

A. Intravenous 0.9% saline infusion over 12 hours
B. Fluid restriction 800 ml/24 hours
C. Intranasal desmopressin 10 μg
D. Intravenous hydrocortisone 100 mg
E. Perform water-deprivation test

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old man with end-stage liver disease is admitted with a painful, distended abdomen. Examination findings: generalised abdominal tenderness and ascites. Temperature 37.5 °C.
Which intervention should be undertaken first?

A. Therapeutic paracentesis
B. Commence benzylpenicillin
C. Commence furosemide
D. Diagnostic ascitic tap
E. Commence spironolactone

Correct Answer: D

An 84-year-old man attends his General Practitioner (GP) with his daughter to discuss advance care planning. He has a background history of metastatic lung cancer, mild dementia and a previous stroke with residual mild dysphasia. He wishes to make an advance care directive to state that if he becomes acutely unwell with a life-threatening illness, he wishes to be managed in a palliative manner.
Which of the following would make the writing of an advance directive invalid?

A. If a copy of the advance directive is not put in the patient’s medical records
B. If the patient has dysphasia
C. Lack of capacity to weigh up the information given to make an informed decision
D. Mild dementia
E. Signing of directive not witnessed by a solicitor

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old man attends Elderly Care Clinic accompanied by his wife. He has a history of Parkinson’s disease, which has been managed relatively effectively with a number of medications. Unfortunately, his wife is very distressed as he has been behaving unusually recently, including spending a significant sum of the couple’s savings on a boat, in addition to making sudden, inappropriate sexual advances to his elderly neighbour.
Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this man’s behavioural change?

A. Amantadine
B. Levodopa
C. Procyclidine
D. Ropinirole
E. Selegiline

Correct Answer: D

A 17-year-old girl attends the Minor Injuries Unit, having ‘twisted’ her left ankle during a hockey match. She played on after the injury and has come to see you after the game ended, as her ankle has become increasingly swollen and painful.
She has walked into the Emergency Department unaided. There is marked swelling around the left ankle. There is some tenderness anterior to the lateral malleolus. Otherwise, there is no bony tenderness on examination of the ankle, foot and knee.
Select the most appropriate management option:

A. Arrange an X-ray of the ankle
B. Refer the patient to orthopaedics for further assessment
C. Advise analgesia, rest, ice and elevation, then discharge the patient
D. Place the ankle in traction and send for an X-ray
E. Arrange an X-ray of the foot

Correct Answer: C

A 37-year-old Irish man is seen in Dermatology clinic for a 3-cm pigmented lesion on his right shin. He has a Fitzpatrick skin type 1. On inspection, it is macular, and contains three different shades of pigment.
What is the most important next step?

A. Clinical photographs and follow-up in 3 months
B. Scrapings for mycology
C. Biopsy
D. Measure angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level
E. Clinical photographs and follow-up in 2 weeks

Correct Answer: C

According to the Mental Health Act (1983), which section should be used to detain a patient, already in a psychiatric hospital, who is suffering from acute psychosis and is trying to actively leave the hospital?

A. Section 2
B. Section 3
C. Section 5.2
D. Section 135
E. Section 136

Correct Answer: C

A patient presents to the Emergency Department after being assaulted. He tells you that this occurred a few hours ago and he has taken several blows to the head. On examination, there is bruising around the eyes. Clear fluid can be seen discharging from his nose.
Where is the patient’s pathology likely to be?

A. Middle cranial fossa
B. Cribriform plate
C. Occiput bone
D. Frontal bone
E. Zygoma

Correct Answer: B

A 5-week-old baby boy presents to the Emergency Department with cyanotic episodes during feeding. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery, following an uneventful pregnancy. Apart from some difficulty in feeding and slow weight gain, the baby had been well until the recent onset of bluish skin during feeds.
Following investigation, a diagnosis of Fallot’s tetralogy is made.
Which one of the following is associated with a patient diagnosed with Fallot’s tetralogy?

A. Pulmonary regurgitation
B. A continuous murmur throughout systole and diastole
C. Atrial septal defect (ASD)
D. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
E. Hypoplastic right ventricle

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old woman presents in May with new-onset sneezing, clear rhinorrhoea, and bilateral nasal congestion. She has no other symptoms.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Infective rhinitis
B. Non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES)
C. Allergic rhinitis
D. Rhinosinusitis
E. Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD)

Correct Answer: C

You are asked to see a 42-year-old man with difficult-to-treat psoriasis. He has extensive plaque psoriasis and has tried a number of therapies, including retinoids, topical corticosteroids and photochemotherapy (PUVA).
What would be the next best step in management?

A. Add a vitamin D analogue
B. Add coal tar products
C. Start methotrexate
D. Start oral steroids
E. Trial etanercept

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old woman presents with increasing abdominal distension and feeling bloated, which has been getting worse over the last six months. She has no other medical history of note. She has regular periods with a 30-day cycle with no heavy or intermenstrual bleeding.
On examination, there is an abdominal mass in the region of the left iliac fossa which is tender to palpation. The doctor orders blood tests and arranges an urgent ultrasound scan of the abdomen to assess the mass further.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Fibroids
B. Cystocele
C. Rectocele
D. Ovarian serous cystadenomas
E. Polycystic ovarian syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 13-month-old baby is brought in by his mother who is concerned that he has ongoing eczematous rashes, pruritus, loose stools and symptoms of colic for several weeks. She is unsure of the pattern of occurrence but says it is happening daily. There has been no improvement following treatment with emollients.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated cows’ milk protein allergy
B. Lactose intolerance
C. Non-IgE-mediated cows’ milk protein allergy
D. Peanut allergy
E. Eczema

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old man with inflammatory bowel disease undergoes emergency surgery, involving resection of a portion of his bowel. At the clinicopathological conference, the histological findings of the operative sample are discussed.
Which of the following features is most suggestive of Crohn’s disease?

A. Crypt abscesses
B. Mucosal inflammation
C. Disease limited to the large bowel
D. Transmural inflammation
E. Continuous portions of disease

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old Afro-Carribbean woman presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe chest pain and a cough. You are unable to take a history because the patient does not speak fluent English, and there are no translators available. You are able to ascertain that the patient has a persistent central sharp chest pain, and you administer appropriate analgesics for this, while also carrying out a 3-lead ECG, ordering a chest X-ray, obtaining IV access and taking multiple blood samples.
Examination of the patient reveals a tender swelling of her hands and feet, as well as scleral icterus. You are able to ascertain that her chest pain is worse on inspiration.
Observations are taken, and reveal the following:
Temperature 38.8 °C
Blood pressure (BP) 122/86 mmHg
Heart rate 120 bpm
Respiratory rate 24 breaths/min
Pa(O2) 88%
You administer 15 litres of oxygen through a non-rebreather mask, and in light of the above results you also take a sample for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. See results below:
Investigation Result Normal range
pH 7.40 7.35–7.45
p(O2) 70 mmHg 80–100 mmHg
p(CO2) 40 mmHg 35–45 mmHg
Afterwards, you notice that the blood results have come back:
Investigation Result Normal range
White cell count (WCC) 13.0 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Red cell count (RCC) 3.0 × 1012/l Male 4.6–6.2 × 1012/l
Female 4.2–5.4 × 1012/l
Platelets 310 150–400 × 109/l
Troponin I 0.02 ng/ml <0.07 ng/ml
D-dimer 0.03 μg/ml <0.05 μg/ml
The chest X-ray results have also come back, and they show right lower lobe consolidation with a basal pleural effusion.
The ECG you requested shows sinus tachycardia, with T-wave inversion in aVR. You have no previous ECGs to compare this with.
The results of an urgent blood film you requested are also brought to you, which shows abnormally shaped erythrocytes, Howell–Jolly bodies and nucleated red blood cells.
What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) blast crisis
B. Right lower lobe pneumonia with parapneumonic effusion
C. Sickle cell disease acute chest syndrome
D. Myelodysplastic syndrome
E. Unstable angina

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man undergoes a right middle lobectomy of his lung for lung cancer. A chest drain is inserted at the time of surgery to allow full lung reinflation. Three days after the operation, you notice that air bubbles escape through the chest drain into the water seal whenever the patient coughs.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Air leak from the area of resected lung
B. Blocked chest drain
C. Contralateral pneumothorax
D. Empyema with gas-forming organisms
E. Recurrent lung cancer

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the general practitioner by her mother who is concerned about her. She has experienced irregular and unpredictable uterine bleeding during the last 2 years. Her menses started at age 13 and have always varied in amount, duration and timing. The mother states that her older daughter who is 22 years old now had normal menses at teenage years. There is no adnexal mass or tenderness.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding
B. Ovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding
C. Cervical cancer
D. Submucosal leiomyoma
E. Prolactinoma

Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old carpet fitter complains of pain and swelling over the right kneecap. The patient finds it especially difficult to bend his knee, and the symptoms are becoming severe enough to interfere with his job.
In view of the history and examination findings, a diagnosis of ‘housemaid’s knee’ is suspected.
‘Housemaid’s knee’ is inflammation of the:

A. Suprapatellar bursa
B. Prepatellar bursa
C. Infrapatellar bursa
D. Semimembranous bursa
E. Popliteus bursa

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman with a history of back pain uses paracetamol and ibuprofen regularly for analgesia. She and her partner are trying to conceive, and would like to know about safe analgesia in pregnancy.
Which of the following statements best describes the safety of analgesics in pregnancy?

A. Codeine phosphate can be used at low doses if needed
B. Ibuprofen is safe to use throughout pregnancy
C. Naproxen can be used safely in pregnancy
D. Paracetamol can be used as it does not cross the placenta
E. Tramadol is safe to use in pregnancy

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old woman has been suffering from a dragging sensation, which is better lying down. Her cervix is found to prolapse 0.8 cm below the level of the hymen during straining.
What is the diagnosis based on the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POPQ)?

A. Stage 1 prolapse
B. Procidentia
C. Stage 4 prolapse
D. Stage 2 prolapse
E. Enterocoele

Correct Answer: D

A 67-year-old man with a 12-year history of diabetes awakes with weakness of the right leg. On examination, there is weakness of ankle eversion and inversion and loss of big toe dorsiflexion. Knee reflexes are normal, and ankle jerks present with reinforcement. He has loss of sensation over the first toe.
Where is the lesion?

A. Right common peroneal nerve
B. Right femoral nerve
C. Right L5 root
D. Right sciatic nerve
E. Right lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old man is jaundiced and has noticed progressive weight loss over the previous 4 months. He has no history of abdominal pain or fever. His stool is pale-coloured and his urine is dark.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute cholecystitis
B. Chronic pancreatitis
C. Gallstone obstruction
D. Hepatitis A
E. Pancreatic carcinoma

Correct Answer: E

A new asthma medication is being developed that is described as having a higher potency than current drugs of that class.
What is meant by potency?

A. The maximal response that a drug can produce when all receptors are occupied
B. The rate at which a drug enters blood circulation
C. The rate at which a drug is converted to its metabolites
D. The amount required to produce an effect of given intensity
E. The dose range at which the drug is within a safety range

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old primigravida is brought to the Emergency Department by her husband at 33 weeks of gestation after experiencing a generalised tonic–clonic seizure.
Examination reveals blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, temperature of 37 °C and 2+ pitting oedema in the lower extremities. She appears lethargic but responds to simple commands.
What is the definitive treatment of this patient’s condition?

A. Immediate delivery
B. Hydralazine
C. Salt and water restriction
D. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor
E. Diazepam

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old girl takes 45 of her stepfather’s aspirin tablets, following an argument with her boyfriend. 12 hours into her admission, the following arterial blood gas (ABG) and biochemistry tests were performed.
pH 7.27, PCO2 3.0 kPa, PO2 14.3 kPa, HCO3− 16.2 mmol/l, base excess −7.4 mmol/l
Na+ 143 mmol/l, K+ 4.5 mmol/l, Cl− 107 mmol/l, urea 12.4 mmol/l, creatinine 87 μmol/l
What is the patient’s anion gap?

A. 24.3 mmol/l
B. 21.3 mmol/l
C. 20.1 mmol/l
D. 47.7 mmol/l
E. 2.13 mmol/l

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old patient presented with progressive dyspnoea. On computerised tomography (CT) scan of the chest, a lesion was found in the middle lobe of the right lung. The radiologist reported the findings as ‘a region of ground-glass opacity surrounded by denser lung tissue’.
What is this sign better known as?

A. Atoll sign
B. Halo sign
C. Kerley B lines
D. Signet ring sign
E. Tree-in-bud sign

Correct Answer: A

Tom Beckmann, a 30-year-old accountant, has just noticed a dark lesion on his right lower leg. Concerned about the possibility of skin cancer, he has been doing research on the Internet into how to recognise malignant melanoma.
Using the ABCDE criteria, what features should Tom be looking out for?

A. Ache, border irregularity, crusting, diameter >6mm, evolving
B. Asymmetry, bleeding, crusting, diameter >6mm, elevated lesion
C. Asymmetry, border irregularity, colour variation, depth >5mm, evolving
D. Asymmetry, border irregularity, colour variation, diameter >6mm, evolving
E. Asymmetry, border irregularity, crusting, diameter >6mm, elevated lesion

Correct Answer: D

A 15-year-old girl is brought into paediatric casualty with decreased level of consciousness. She has no past medical history. Her 6-year-old sister was recently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus. Family history is also otherwise unremarkable. Urgent arterial blood gas analysis reveals a surprising finding of blood glucose level of 2.1 mmol/l. This is confirmed on urgent formal blood glucose testing. She is transferred to the hospital’s high dependency unit (HDU) for monitoring and treatment. Blood tests taken shortly after admission reveal elevated insulin and low C-peptide levels.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Type 1 diabetes mellitus
B. Familial insulinoma syndrome
C. Maturity onset diabetes of the young
D. Insulinoma
E. Factitious hypoglycaemia

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man visits his doctor complaining of excessive dandruff. He also mentions some scaling lesion on his face.
On examination, there is also waxing scale with underlying erythema occurring on his eyebrows, scalp and nasolabial fold. He has a history of HIV for the last 2 years and is taking retroviral drugs.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Contact dermatitis
B. Atopic dermatitis
C. Acne
D. Alopecia areata
E. Seborrhoeic dermatitis

Correct Answer: E

A 7-year-old boy presents with easy bleeding and bruising, even in response to what seem like relatively minor bangs and scrapes. His mother and father are well, although the boy’s mother tells you that her brother is affected by a similar bleeding tendency and she believes that others among her male relatives also suffer from the problem.
Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following represents the most likely mode of inheritance for this disorder?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Autosomal recessive
C. Y-linked
D. X-linked dominant
E. X-linked recessive

Correct Answer: E

You are a Foundation Year 2 (FY2) doctor in the Emergency Department seeing a patient with severe abdominal pain. The pain is diffuse and difficult to localise, and the patient says that he feels very faint. On examination, he has a pulsatile expansile mass above his umbilicus with generalised abdominal tenderness. His blood pressure is 95/51 mmHg and his pulse is 114 bpm. The patient is receiving fluid resuscitation for his low blood pressure while awaiting a surgical review.
Which of the following would provide the best information with regards to planning the management of this patient?

A. X-ray
B. Ultrasound
C. Computerised tomography (CT) scan
D. Intravenous (iv) arteriogram
E. No imaging required – this is a clinical diagnosis

Correct Answer: C

A first-year medical student approaches you and asks you to explain the difference between primary and secondary prevention strategies to reduce disease burden. As part of your explanation, you decide to use an example of a secondary prevention measure to illustrate your description.
Which of the following is an example of a secondary prevention measure?

A. Annual influenza vaccination
B. Providing free condoms in general practice
C. Introducing alcohol drinking guideline limits
D. Offering smoking cessation services
E. Screening for breast cancer

Correct Answer: E

You review a patient with chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) and are considering starting them on imatinib. Imatinib is a kinase inhibitor.
Which of the following best describes the mode of action of a kinase inhibitor?

A. Inhibits sulfonation
B. Inhibits hydroxylation
C. Inhibits phosphorylation
D. Inhibits dephosphorylation
E. Inhibits dihydroxylation

Correct Answer: C

The photomicrograph shows a peripheral blood cell marked with an asterisk. This cell is involved in allergic reactions and helminthic infestations.
Identify this cell:

A. Neutrophil
B. Eosinophil
C. Basophil
D. Mast cell
E. Monocyte

Correct Answer: B

A patient presents to the Emergency Department, complaining of a gradually worsening cough. She admits to a choking incident while eating peanuts two days prior to presentation.
At which of the following sites has the peanut most likely impacted?

A. The right superior lobar bronchus
B. The right middle lobar bronchus
C. The right inferior lobar bronchus
D. The left superior lobar bronchus
E. The left inferior lobar bronchus

Correct Answer: C

A 13-year-old girl is admitted to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath and a severe wheeze. On arrival, she has stridor and marked swelling of the tongue, lips and palate. She had been at a friend’s party that evening.
Which one of the following statements concerning this type of reaction is true?

A. These types of reaction occur several hours after exposure to antigen
B. These reactions follow the synthesis and release of inflammatory mediators by mast cell granules
C. This is a type I hypersensitivity reaction
D. Eosinophils are recruited almost immediately
E. T-helper cells promote further production of IgG during the late-phase reaction

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year old male patient on the gastrointestinal ward has a condition that has been graded using the Los Angeles (LA) classification.
Which of the following can be graded by the Los Angeles (LA) classification?

A. Bleeding peptic ulcer
B. Oesophagitis
C. Colon malignancy
D. Cirrhosis of the liver
E. Duodenal ulcer

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman presents with a solitary thyroid nodule, and histology confirms a medullary thyroid tumour.
From which of the following cells is the biochemical tumour marker used to assess for recurrence secreted?

A. Endothelial cells
B. Follicular cells (aka epithelial cells)
C. Parafollicular cells (aka C cells)
D. Pericytes
E. Colloid cells

Correct Answer: C

A 63-year-old man (with known metastatic pancreatic cancer) presented with severe obstructive jaundice and signs of hepatic encephalopathy. He was treated with a biliary stent (percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)) and discharged when his jaundice, confusion and pruritus had started to improve. He re-presented shortly after discharge with rigors, pyrexia and feeling generally unwell. His blood cultures showed Gram-negative rods.
What is the most likely cause of his current presentation?

A. Ascending cholangitis
B. Hepatitis
C. Lower respiratory tract infection
D. Metastatic pancreatic cancer
E. Pyelonephritis

Correct Answer: A

An 87-year-old presents to the Emergency Department with epigastric pain and shortness of breath. There is reduced air entry at the left base. A chest X-ray reveals an air–fluid level behind the mediastinum.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aspiration pneumonia of the left lower lobe of the lung
B. Diaphragmatic hiatal hernia
C. Early cholangitis
D. Ruptured left ventricle
E. Ruptured right ventricle

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man presents with blood in his ejaculate. He has no lower urinary tract symptoms and no abdominal pain and is otherwise well. He is in a long-term monogamous relationship. There is no history of trauma. Scrotal and penile examination is normal. Digital rectal examination reveals a normal and non-tender prostate. Urinalysis is normal. There is no family history of malignancy.
In addition to sending a sample of urine for microscopy, culture and sensitivities, what is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Reassure him that this symptom is not a sign of anything serious but ask him to return if he has >3 episodes or the problem persists for over a month
B. Reassure him that this symptom is not a sign of anything serious and advise him that no follow-up is required
C. Arrange a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test
D. Refer urgently to Urology
E. Prescribe a 2 week course of Ciprofloxacin and advise him to return if the symptoms do not settle

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of insomnia. She describes feeling constantly anxious and unable to stop worrying about everything. The GP thinks she may be suffering from an anxiety disorder.
Which of the following tools is most useful in reaching a diagnosis?

A. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT)
B. Generalised Anxiety DisorderQuestionnaire (GAD-7)
C. Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
D. Modified Single-Answer ScreeningQuestion (M SASQ)
E. Patient HealthQuestionnaire (PHQ-9)

Correct Answer: B

You are working in the paediatric acute admissions unit during winter when you are asked to see a 14-month-old child with a runny nose, dry cough, increased work of breathing and a raised respiratory rate. There is a mild generalised wheeze on examination, as well as fever and difficulty feeding.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bronchiolitis
B. Pneumonia
C. Asthma
D. Viral upper respiratory tract infection (URTI)
E. Croup

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old obese women presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with shortness of breath and right-sided chest pain increasing over the last few days. She looks unwell. She has a temperature of 38.9°C. Her oxygen saturations are 85% on room air and her blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg with a heart rate of 130 beats per minute sinus rhythm. Her chest X-ray (CXR) shows right lower lobe consolidation. Her blood tests show bilirubin 120 µmol/litre and ALP 300 IU/litre. She has right upper quadrant tenderness
Result Normal
Temperature 38.9°C 36.5–37.5°C
Oxygen saturation 85% 95–100%
Blood pressure 70/40 mmHg <120/<80 mmHg
Heart rate sinus rhythm 130 beats per minute 50–100 beats per minute
Bilirubin 120 µmol/litre 2–17 µmol/litre
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 300 IU/litre 30–130 IU/litre
What other investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Computed tomography (CT) chest to define the extent of the consolidation
B. Ultrasound scan abdomen
C. Blood cultures
D. Sputum sample
E. Serum haptoglobin to confirm haemolysis caused by mycoplasma pneumonia

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man has experienced pain with urination for the past week. His temperature is 37.5 °C. On digital rectal examination, his prostate is slightly enlarged and mildly tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show his white blood cell count to be 13 000 mL. Urine culture grows > 100 000 Escherichia coli organisms. His serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is 6 ng/ml (normal < 5ng/ml). He receives antibiotic therapy and his clinical condition initially improves. However, his symptoms recur six times over the next 12 months.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Nodular prostatic hyperplasia
B. Prostatic adenocarcinoma
C. Chronic bacterial prostatitis
D. Prostodynia
E. Urothelial carcinoma of the urethra

Correct Answer: C

One of the following is true regarding human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
Which is the correct answer?

A. HIV is a single stranded DNA virus
B. Acute infection is often asymptomatic
C. Kaposi’s sarcoma is not considered an AIDS-defining illness
D. HIV treatment and increased CD4 counts are most often associated with an improvement of pre-existing infection
E. There is no increased risk of malignancy in HIV

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man presents to the general practitioner with double vision. On examination, his eye is turned down and out; he has ptosis and limited adduction, elevation and depression of the eye. His pupil is fixed and dilated.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Third nerve palsy
B. Fourth nerve palsy
C. Sixth nerve palsy
D. Horner’s syndrome
E. Fifth nerve palsy

Correct Answer: A

A patient with chronic sinusitis is booked for endoscopic surgical management, with a view to removing any obstruction to the drainage channels and for balloon catheter dilatation of the paranasal sinus ostia. The surgeon visualises the middle meatus of the nasal cavity with a view to cannulating the ostia.
Which of the following paranasal sinuses drains into the sphenoethmoid recess?

A. Maxillary sinus
B. Anterior ethmoidal sinus
C. Frontal sinus
D. Sphenoidal sinus
E. Middle ethmoidal sinus

Correct Answer: D

A 47-year-old woman is admitted to the Emergency Department with palpitations. The patient has a history of hypertension for which she is taking lisinopril but is otherwise well. Apart from the fluttering sensation in her chest, she feels well and has no shortness of breath.
On examination, the patient’s pulse is 160 bpm and regular. She is haemodynamically stable, with a blood pressure of 134/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturations are 99% in room air. On examination, her chest is clear and there is no pedal oedema.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) taken shows a sinus tachycardia with narrow complexes. Vagal manoeuvres are tried with no effect.
Which of the following would be the next most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Adenosine
B. Verapamil and atenolol
C. Lidocaine
D. Synchronised DC shock
E. Magnesium

Correct Answer: A

A 2-year-old girl is brought to see the GP by her mother. She was born at 32/40 weeks gestation. Her mother is concerned about cerebral palsy, as she has read a lot about problems associated with preterm delivery. So far, the child has met all her developmental milestones. On examination, she has normal power, tone and reflexes in all four limbs.
Which one of the following developmental issues would suggest a diagnosis of cerebral palsy?

A. Hand preference at 18 months old
B. Loss of attained developmental milestones
C. Not able to balance on one leg by the age of two years
D. Not sitting up by six months old (corrected for prematurity)
E. Not walking by 18 months old (corrected for prematurity)

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old man from a nursing home was brought in by ambulance to the Emergency Department feeling generally unwell. He was recently treated with amoxicillin for community acquired pneumonia by his GP. The nursing staff said yesterday he was complaining of some muscle pain and weakness and tiredness. He has been vomiting over the last few days. He has a past medical history of asthma, type II diabetes, gout, hypercholesterolaemia and osteoarthritis. Medication includes simvastatin, co-codamol, allopurinol, metformin and a salbutamol inhaler. On examination:
Investigation Result Normal
Respiratory rate (RR) 23 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Sats 96% on air 94–98%
Blood pressure (BP) 126/68 mmHg <120/80 mmHg
Heart rate (HR) 98 beats/min 60–100 beats/min
Temperature 36.8ºC 36.1–37.2°C
He is drowsy but nothing remarkable otherwise. An arterial blood gas (ABG) on air showed:
Investigation Result Normal
pH 7.28 7.35–7.45
pO2 12.0 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 5.5 kPa 4.7–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate 18 mmol/l 22–26 mmol/l
BE 1.0 –2 +2
What is the most likely cause of the above presentation and investigation results?

A. Simvastatin
B. Unresolved pneumonia
C. Metformin
D. Allopurinol
E. Co-codamol

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old Afro-Caribbean woman presents to the Emergency Department complaining of shortness of breath, fever and a productive cough. She has suffered multiple severe infections over the past five years; however, she has no other past medical history.
