On examination, you note intercostal recessions and the use of accessory muscles of respiration. She has significant coarse crepitations in her right lower lobe.
You take some basic observations, which are as follows:
Temperature: 39.8 °C
Heart rate: 120 bpm
Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min
Blood pressure: 150/94 mmHg (lying) 146/90 mmHg (standing)
Oxygen saturation: 86% on room air
Her initial investigation findings are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count (WCC) 14.4 × 109/l 4–11. × 109/l
Neutrophils 12800 × 106/l 3000–5800 × 106/l
Lymphocytes 1400 × 106/l 1500–3000 × 106/l
Haemoglobin (Hb) 110 g/dl 115–155 g/dl
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 94 fl 76–98 fl
Platelets 360 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Her chest X-ray shows significant consolidation in the right lower lobe.
A blood film comes back and shows the following: sickled erythrocytes and Howell–Jolly bodies.
A sputum culture is grown and shows Streptococcus pneumoniae, and the patient’s pneumonia is managed successfully with antibiotics and IV fluid therapy.
What condition is predisposing this patient to severe infections?

A. Acute chest pain crisis
B. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
C. Advanced human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
D. Aplastic crisis
E. Splenic dysfunction

Correct Answer: E

A 17-year-old boy, originally from India, has recently been having behavioural issues at school. A few months later he began having involuntary movements of his limbs and is now having tonic-clonic seizures. An EEG confirms a diagnosis of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is likely to show antibodies to which infectious agent?

A. Malaria
B. Measles
C. Mumps
D. Rubella
E. Varicella zoster

Correct Answer: B

An 80 kg 35-year-old man who is normally fit and well is scheduled for an appendectomy today. He has been made nil by mouth, and surgeons expect him to continue to be nil by mouth for approximately 24 hours. The man has a past medical history of childhood asthma. He has been taking paracetamol for pain but takes no other regular medication. On examination, the man’s blood pressure (BP) is 105/75 mmHg and heart rate 60 bpm. His lungs are clear. Jugular venous pressure (JVP) is not raised, and he has no peripheral oedema. Skin turgor is normal.
What is the appropriate fluid prescription for this man for the 24 hours while he is nil by mouth?

A. 1 litre 0.9% sodium chloride with 20 mmol potassium over 12 hours; 1 litre 5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 12 hours
B. 1 litre 5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours; 1 litre 0.9% sodium chloride with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours; 640 ml 0.9% sodium chloride with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours
C. 1 litre 0.9% sodium chloride with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours, 1 litre 5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours; 500 ml 5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours
D. 1 litre 10% dextrose over 6 hours; 1 litre 5% dextrose over 6 hours; 1 litre 0.9% sodium chloride over 6 hours; 1 litre 0.9% sodium chloride with 20 mmol potassium over 6 hours
E. 1 litre human albumin solution (HAS) over 8 hours; 1 litre 0.5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours; 640 ml 0.5% dextrose with 20 mmol potassium over 8 hours

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old woman is on the General Surgical Ward following a Hartmann’s procedure to remove a bowel cancer. A nurse on the ward has asked you to review the patient as she is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 102/73 mmHg. She weighs 67 kg and has no significant past medical history. When you review her, her urine output is 60 ml over the last two hours; she is tachycardic, with a capillary refill time of four seconds. There is no raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) and no signs of ankle or sacral oedema, and her chest is clear to auscultation.
What is the best initial management of this patient?

A. Fluid restriction
B. Intravenous (IV) furosemide
C. 500 ml of 10% dextrose IV
D. 500 ml of 0.9% saline IV
E. 500 ml of human albumin solution (HAS) IV

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old student midwife presents with increasing pain and swelling of the ring finger of her left hand. The pain and swelling started two days ago and is now extremely uncomfortable to the point the patient has been avoiding using the left hand altogether. She cannot remember injuring the affected area, and is usually fit and well, with no medical conditions to note except an allergy to peanuts.
On examination, the affected finger is markedly swollen and erythematous, with tenderness to touch – especially along the flexor aspect of the finger. The patient is holding the finger in slight flexion; attempts at straightening the finger passively causes the patient extreme pain. The patient is diagnosed with tenosynovitis.
About which one of the following conditions should the presence of acute migratory tenosynovitis in young adults, particularly women, alert the doctor?

A. Scleroderma
B. Fluoroquinolone toxicity
C. Disseminated gonococcal infection
D. Rheumatoid arthritis
E. Reactive arthritis

Correct Answer: C

A patient who is having an excision of a large squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on his back has had C. 20 ml of lidocaine 0.5%, but is still able to feel pain. You know that the maximum safe dose of lidocaine is 3 mg/kg and he weighs 90 kg.
How much more lidocaine can you give?

A. 10 ml
B. 30 ml
C. 20 ml
D. 40 ml
E. Cannot give any more lidocaine

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old primigravida woman presents at 38+5 weeks’ gestation to the Labour Ward with regular contractions that have started about three hours ago.
On examination, she has a short, soft cervix which is 2 cm dilated. Contractions are roughly every 4–5 minutes and are palpable, demonstrated on cardiotocography, but are not very strong or painful at present.
Which of the following statements applies to the first stage of labour?

A. During this stage, the fetal heart rate should be monitored on cardiotocography at least every five minutes and after each contraction
B. It occurs at a rate of about 0.5-1 cm per hour in a nulliparous woman
C. It involves cervical shortening and dilatation in the absence of uterine contractions
D. It is described as the period from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the fetus
E. It is described as the period from 4 cm of cervical dilatation to full cervical dilatation at a rate of about 0.5cm per hour

Correct Answer: B

A 62-year-old woman is admitted for a radical nephrectomy for renal cell carcinoma. She has an uncomplicated postoperative course and after one week is ready for discharge home. You are the house officer on the urology team and have attended her daily. You are writing her discharge summary when she approaches you and hands you an envelope. Inside you find a thank you card with a voucher for a department store for £500.
What should you do with regard to the gift you have been given?

A. Keep it and share it with your team
B. Give it to a charity
C. Return it to the patient and explain you cannot accept such a gift
D. Thank the patient and keep it
E. Thank the patient and then use the money to buy something nice for the ward

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old woman presents with intense itching in the perineal area, associated with pain on micturition and dyspareunia.
On examination, you notice white, polygonal papules on the labia majora, coalescing into a patch affecting the labia minora. There is one fissuring area, which bleeds on contact. The skin is white, thin and shiny. Mild scarring is noted. There is no vaginal discharge. There are no other skin lesions on the body.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Candidiasis
B. Contact dermatitis
C. Lichen planus
D. Lichen sclerosus
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: D

A 59-year-old man attends the Respiratory Clinic. He has had two episodes of right-sided bronchial pneumonia over the past 2 months and his symptoms have failed to completely resolve. He is known to smoke 30 cigarettes per day and has done so since the age of 16. On examination, he has a body mass index (BMI) of 18 and signs consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and right-sided consolidation on respiratory examination.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 114 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 232 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 119 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 2.82 mmol/l 2.2–2.6 mmol/l
Chest X-ray Right hilar mass – 4 x 2 cm in size
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bronchial carcinoid
B. Large cell bronchial carcinoma
C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the bronchus
D. Small cell bronchial carcinoma
E. Adenocarcinoma of the bronchus

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) with a recent history of dyspareunia, occasional post-coital spotting and lower abdominal pain since having sexual intercourse with a new partner without using barrier methods. Her menstrual cycle is regular, and a pregnancy test is negative.
A pelvic examination reveals a bloodstained purulent discharge, and cervical excitation is elicited on bimanual examination. Her blood pressure is 108/65 mmHg, heart rate 88 bpm and temperature 37.2 °C. Cervical and high-vaginal swabs are sent for analysis.
The patient reports she had two previous episodes of gonorrhoeal infection.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Admit to hospital for intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Await results of swabs and, if positive, prescribe oral antibiotics
C. Prescribe 400 mg ofloxacin twice daily and 400 mg metronidazole twice daily for 14 days
D. 500 mg ceftriaxone intramuscularly (IM) as a single dose
E. 1 g ceftriaxone IM (single dose), followed by metronidazole 400 mg orally twice daily and doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days

Correct Answer: E

You are asked to see a 41-year-old man with a stoma in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. It is spouted and produces a liquid, light brown fluid.
What form of stoma is this likely to be?

A. Colostomy
B. Entero-cutaneous fistula
C. Mucous fistula
D. Ileostomy
E. Urostomy

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old woman presents to her GP with unsteadiness on her feet and frequent falls of 2 days' duration. On examination, she is noted to have loss of sensation and weakness of the muscles of the right lower limb. Her upper limbs and face have no weakness or sensory deficit. Her GP refers her to the nearest stroke unit for assessment and management. Computed tomography (CT) scan confirms a thromboembolic cerebrovascular accident.
Which vessel is most likely to have been involved?

A. The right anterior cerebral artery distal to the anterior communicating branch
B. The left anterior cerebral artery distal to the anterior communicating branch
C. Main stem occlusion in the left middle cerebral artery
D. The right posterior cerebral artery proximal occlusion
E. The left posterior cerebral artery proximal occlusion

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man presents to the Outpatient Department with severe right ear pain. His symptoms started four days ago. He does not report any fever, chills or rigors or any other respiratory symptoms of cough or cold. On examination, he has mild fever (38.2 °C) and a swollen external ear canal on the right side, with no discharge, but that is extremely tender to touch.
Which of the following options is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Characteristic history and clinical examination
B. Computerised tomography (CT) scan of temporal bone
C. Culture and sensitivity of external ear canal swabs
D. Otomicroscopy
E. Patch testing

Correct Answer: A

A 46-year-old man felt dizzy at work and later had a rhythm strip (lead II) performed in the Emergency Department. It reveals one P wave for every QRS complex and a PR interval of 240 ms.
What does this rhythm strip reveal?

A. First-degree heart block
B. Second-degree heart block, Mobitz type 1
C. Second-degree heart block, Mobitz type 2
D. Third-degree heart block
E. Normal sinus rhythm

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman is seen in the Outpatient Department with a few months’ history of increasing malaise, nausea and decreased appetite. She is a known intravenous drug user. On examination, she appears cachectic and unwell. Mild hepatomegaly and icterus of the sclerae are also noted. Blood results reveal normal bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GT) levels and markedly deranged aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) levels. She cannot remember her hepatitis B immunisation status. Viral serology is performed:
Test Patient
HBsAg +ve
Anti-HBsAg -ve
HBcAg +ve
IgM anti-HBcAg -ve
IgG anti-HBcAg +ve
HBeAg +ve
Anti-HBeAg -ve
Which of the following is correct in relation to this woman’s hepatitis B status?

A. Incubation period of infection
B. Recovery from infection
C. Acute infection
D. Chronic infection
E. Recent vaccination

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old man attends his general practitioner with a penile complaint. He reports that during erection, a significant curvature occurs and that this has worsened over recent years. He reports feeling very embarrassed and is concerned about malignancy.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bowenoid papulosis
B. Bowen’s disease
C. Peyronie’s disease
D. Penile lymphoma
E. Erythroplasia of Queyrat

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old insurance broker with mitral stenosis is reviewed in the Cardiology Clinic. During the consultation, he describes that he has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath on exertion over the past six months, as well as generalised fatigue. He also mentions that he has noticed his feet and ankles are often quite swollen by the end of the day.
Which of the following interventions would be considered first line for symptomatic mitral stenosis with a mobile undistorted mitral valve, in the absence of a left atrial thrombus with no mitral regurgitation?

A. Aortic valve replacement
B. Balloon valvuloplasty
C. Blalock–Taussig shunt
D. Mitral valve repair
E. Mitral valve replacement

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man is sent to your office for evaluation by his family. The patient recently went to university and has had trouble adapting and fitting in. His parents note that he has always been a loner, preferring to stay in his room, play video games and make models of his favourite characters. They hoped university would bring him out of his shell. He has not made any new friends, but only his parents are bothered by this. Instead of socialising, he seems to have continued to play video games alone in his room.
On interview, he is withdrawn and quiet. His range of affect is restricted, and he displays no clear happiness or joy when discussing activities that he reports enjoying. He denies any auditory or visual hallucinations and has no suicidal or homicidal intent. He reports that he has no change in his sleep, appetite, energy or concentration.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Avoidant personality disorder
B. Schizoaffective disorder
C. Schizoid personality disorder
D. Schizotypal personality disorder
E. Schizophrenia

Correct Answer: C

A 58-year-old man presents with jaundice, which has been getting worse over the last two months. He denies abdominal pain. He reports that his stools look paler than normal, and that his urine has been an odd, dark colour. The man currently takes sulfasalazine for ulcerative colitis. He has recently been on holiday to Tanzania. On examination, the man has hepatomegaly. He is apyrexic and haemodynamically stable.
What is the most likely cause of the man’s presentation?

A. Haemolytic anaemia
B. Malaria
C. Acute cholecystitis
D. Pancreatitis
E. Cholangiocarcinoma

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department, looking unwell at 2200 after ingesting ‘a few handfuls’ of paracetamol tablets. On further questioning, you find out this was around 1300 and the weight of the patient is 80 kgs.
Which of the following options should be done first?

A. Give naloxone
B. Administer activated charcoal
C. Monitor observations and treat if deterioration occurs
D. Intravenous (IV) N-acetylcysteine (NAC) STAT
E. Take a plasma paracetamol measurement to direct treatment

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old motorcyclist is brought to the Emergency Department (ED) 45 minutes after a collision with a heavy-goods vehicle. Immediately after the collision she was unconscious for three minutes. Since regaining consciousness, she appears dazed and complains of a headache, nausea and ringing in her ears, and she is aversive to light and sound. Prior to examination she had an episode of vomiting.
An ABCDE assessment is performed and the results are below:

Airway Patent, able to speak
Breathing Respiratory rate (RR) 18 per min, SaO2 97% on room air, normal and symmetrical chest expansion, normal percussion note bilaterally, normal vesicular breath sounds throughout
Circulation Heart rate (HR) 97/min, blood pressure (BP) 139/87 mmHg, capillary refill time (CRT) <2 s, ECG with sinus tachycardia, normal heart sounds with no added sounds or murmurs
Disability AVPU, pupils equal and reactive to light, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) = 13 (E4, V4, M5), no signs suggestive of basal skull fracture
Exposure Temperature 36.8 °C, multiple bruises but no sites of external bleeding, abdomen is soft and non-tender
Which of the following would be appropriate in the further management of this patient?

A. Intubation and ventilation
B. Immediate referral to neurosurgery
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan within eight hours
D. Discharge from hospital
E. Fluid resuscitation with saline and albumin

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old child with a suspected squint is referred to an ophthalmologist by her General Practitioner. The ophthalmologist makes a diagnosis of amblyopia (lazy eye) and suggests occlusion therapy.
Which of the following best describes occlusion therapy?

A. Atropine drops in the normal eye
B. Covering the abnormal eye with a patch
C. Covering the normal eye with a patch
D. Corrective glasses
E. Surgical management

Correct Answer: C

A 5-year-old boy presents with a 5-day history of an itchy rash, initially on his abdomen and now spreading across the rest of his torso and limbs. He is usually fit and well and on no other medications, and the rest of his family is well. On examination, he looks unwell, with a temperature of 38.5 °C. There is a widespread vesicular rash with some papules and crusting, as well as newer papules. The skin is generally erythematous and there is some discharge from the vesicles. Physical examination reveals tender and swollen lymph nodes. He screams in pain when you try to touch the vesicles as they are very tender to the touch.
What is the next best step in management?

A. Zoster immunoglobulin
B. Calamine lotion
C. Chlorphenamine
D. Oral aciclovir
E. Intravenous flucloxacillin and aciclovir

Correct Answer: E

A mother presents with her 2-week-old baby boy to ask advice about his failed newborn hearing screening. Further tests were normal; however, she has been advised to seek medical advice if she has any concerns about his hearing in the future.
Which one of the following would warrant referral for a further hearing test?

A. More than 200 spoken words by the age of two years
B. Not babbling or imitating sounds by the age of nine months old
C. Putting two words together by the age of 18 months old
D. Not responding to his own name by the age of six months old
E. Speaking 6–20 words by the age of one year

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old patient has been complaining of a 1-month history of generalised headache, malaise and fever. He has also noticed scalp sensitivity while brushing his hair.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Giant-cell arteritis
B. Intracranial tumour
C. Meningitis
D. Migraine
E. Transient ischaemic attacks (TIA)

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old man has presented to the Emergency Department with fever, jaundice and malaise for the past three days.
Initial laboratory studies show raised liver enzymes and a low platelet count. He has no recent travel history.
A diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis is being considered.
Which of the following antibodies are most specific for this condition?

A. Anti-smooth muscle antibodies
B. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies
C. Hepatitis A Immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies
D. Anti-nuclear antibody
E. Anti-Smith antibodies

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old man, with no known comorbidities, presents with chronic neck pain that he has had for the past six months. He has been having the pain on and off, but it is often worse at the end of the day. He denies any stiffness or radiating pain from the neck. He can continue his daily activities but is worried the pain might be due to cancer.
Physical examination revealed localised tenderness over the neck, with full range of movement for cervical spine. He had no sensory deficit or muscle weakness over his upper limbs.
Cervical X-ray shows osteophyte formation over C4/C5 vertebral levels.
What is the most important intervention?

A. Counselling
B. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief and physiotherapy
C. Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion
D. Posterior cervical laminoforaminotomy
E. Local corticosteroid injection

Correct Answer: B

An 89-year-old man is admitted with severe community-acquired pneumonia, CURB-65 score is 4. He has been an inpatient on the ward where you are working as an FY1 for two weeks. His condition has progressively worsened, and the decision is made to switch to a palliative approach of management. He passes away the following morning, with his wife by his side. You confirm his death on the ward. He has a past medical history of ischaemic heart disease, mesothelioma, hypertension, type 2 diabetes and benign prostate hypertrophy (BPH).
Which of the following should you do when completing his death certificate?

A. Complete part 1 stating community-acquired pneumonia, leave part 2 blank
B. Complete part 1 stating community-acquired pneumonia, complete part 2 stating ischaemic heart disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes and benign prostate hypertrophy
C. Complete part 1 stating community-acquired pneumonia, complete part 2 stating ischaemic heart disease type 2 diabetes and mesothelioma.
D. Complete part 1 stating community-acquired pneumonia and ischaemic heart disease, complete part 2 stating ischaemic heart disease, mesothelioma and type 2 diabetes
E. The form should be completed by the registrar or consultant

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old former miner is referred to the psycho-geriatrician by his general practitioner. His daughter is concerned over his increasingly poor memory and difficulty looking after himself particularly in the last month. Two years previously, he was well and an active member of the local Rotary Club. His past medical history includes a myocardial infarction aged 68 years, osteoarthritis of the knees and peripheral vascular disease.
On examination: bibasal fine inspiratory crepitations; right inguinal hernia; left renal bruit.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

A. Frontotemporal dementia (Pick’s disease)
B. Alzheimer’s disease
C. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
D. Sporadic Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD)
E. Multi-infarct dementia

Correct Answer: E

An elderly male attends the Gastrointestinal Clinic following a referral from their general practitioner due to problems with swallowing. Following assessment by the consultant, the patient undergoes a barium swallow. A radiograph from the procedure is shown below.
Which of the following pathologies does this demonstrate?

A. Achalasia
B. Gastro-oesophageal reflux
C. Oesophageal rupture
D. Pharyngeal pouch
E. Oesophageal stricture

Correct Answer: D

A 79-year-old man attends his General Practice Surgery with several episodes of noticing visible blood in his urine over the last week. On further questioning, he has no abdominal pain and no dysuria, frequency, urgency, incontinence or any other lower urinary tract symptoms. He used to work in a dye factory and has smoked 20 cigarettes a day since he was a teenager. Urinalysis is strongly positive for blood and is negative for all other markers.
What is the next most appropriate investigation to request for a diagnosis?

A. Computed tomography (CT) pelvis
B. Send a urine sample for microscopy, culture and sensitivities
C. CT kidneys, ureters and bladder (KUB)
D. Ultrasound scan (USS) KUB
E. Cystoscopy

Correct Answer: E

You are consulted by the parents of a 7-year-old boy. He has a lifelong history of bed wetting, and they are becoming increasingly concerned that the problem is not getting any better. He never has accidents in the day and opens his bowels at least once a day. He has been potty-trained since the age of 3. Apart from hay fever, there is no relevant family history. Physical examination is normal. Urinalysis reveals no abnormality. Things have come to a head as he is going away on a camping trip with his friend’s parents in 2 weeks’ time, and they do not want him to wet the bed.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Give general advice on enuresis, reassure the parents that he is almost certain to grow out of the problem and advise to restrict fluid intake from 0400 h to prevent bedwetting during the camping trip
B. Give general advice on enuresis, reassure the parents that he is almost certain to grow out of the problem and commence treatment with an enuresis alarm to prepare him for his camping trip and advise to restrict fluid from 1600 h to prevent bedwetting during the camping trip
C. Give general advice on enuresis, reassure the parents that he is almost certain to grow out of the problem and prescribe desmopressin to be taken during the camping trip to prevent bedwetting
D. Refer to a paediatric urologist for investigation
E. Give general advice on enuresis and reassure the parents that he is almost certain to grow out of the problem, but indicate there is little you can do to cure the problem prior to his camping trip

Correct Answer: C

A 21-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 1-day history of itching and watery discharge from both eyes.
On examination, the vision is 6/9 in both eyes. Both pupils are equally reactive to light. The conjunctivae are both chemosed with mild diffuse injection. The eyelids are slightly oedematous.
Her past medical history includes eczema. Her vital observations are as follows:
Blood pressure 110/70 mmHg
Heart rate 65 bpm
Respiratory rate 12
Temperature 36.7 °C
Oxygen saturation 99% on air
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Allergic conjunctivitis
B. Bacterial conjunctivitis
C. Orbital cellulitis
D. Preseptal cellulitis
E. Viral conjunctivitis

Correct Answer: A

You are performing a pre-assessment for a 26-year-old man who is due to have a colectomy for treatment resistant ulcerative colitis. He has never had an operation before. Your plan is to use propofol and sevofluorine as induction agents and suxamethonium as a muscle relaxant.
Which of these features of the patient’s clinical condition and history might prompt you to alter your anaesthetic plan?

A. The patient’s blood pressure is 110/75
B. The patient’s diabetic grandfather died of peri-operative cardiac arrest aged 65
C. The patient has asthma
D. The patient’s mother was ‘unable to move’ for 5 h after having an abdominal hysterectomy
E. The patient has a severe penicillin allergy

Correct Answer: D

A 25-year-old man presents with urinary symptoms of incomplete emptying and hesitancy. He has primary progressive multiple sclerosis but lives independently. He has recently recovered from a urinary tract infection (UTI) and, upon investigation, shows heavy colonisation of Proteus. An ultrasound bladder scan shows 400 ml of residual volume.
What is the most appropriate long-term management?

A. Continuous low-dose trimethoprim
B. Intermittent self-catheterisation
C. Suprapubic catheterisation
D. Long-term urethral catheterisation
E. Muscle relaxant baclofen

Correct Answer: B

A young woman has come to the general practitioner (GP) with bowel symptoms, in particular wind and bloating. The GP has carried out various tests and diagnosed irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
Which statement below is accurate dietary advice to give this young woman?

A. Increase fresh fruit to five portions a day
B. Increase bran intake and reduce oat intake
C. Eat less frequently
D. Increase sorbitol content
E. Restrict caffeinated and fizzy drinks

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old man is referred with a 2-year history of gradual-onset lower back pain. The pain is usually worse at night, but he finds his back is particularly stiff in the morning. Examination reveals loss of spinal flexion and tender lower lumbar and bilateral sacroiliac joints. As part of the workup, a chest X-ray is performed, which demonstrates bilateral apical lung fibrosis. Blood tests reveal a normocytic anaemia, raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP).
What other blood test is likely to be positive?

A. Anti-neutrophil antibody (ANA)
B. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B27
C. Rheumatoid factor (RF)
D. Anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies
E. Anti-Jo antibodies

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old girl is referred to cardiology out-patients with intermittent palpitations. She describes occasional spontaneous episodes of being abnormally aware of her heart. She says her heart rate is markedly increased during episodes. She has no significant medical or family history. She is on the oral contraceptive pill. ECG is performed. She is in sinus rhythm at 80 beats per min. PR interval is 108 ms. A slurring slow rise of the initial portion of the QRS complex is noted; QRS duration is 125 ms.
What is the correct diagnosis?

A. Pulmonary embolism
B. Hyperthyroidism
C. First-degree heart block
D. Wenckebach syndrome
E. Wolf–Parkinson–White syndrome

Correct Answer: E

A mother brings her 7-month-old baby to clinic for a check-up. His prior medical history has been unremarkable and his immunisations are up-to-date. The mother is concerned about his growth. After you determine that the baby has grown appropriately since the last visit and is unchanged from the 50th centile, you provide the mother with advice regarding growth.
What signalling pathway does growth hormone (GH) use?

A. A tyrosine kinase receptor that uses the JAK/STAT pathway
B. Inositol trisphosphate (IP3)
C. Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (GMP) as a second messenger
D. By binding to the same class of receptor as aldosterone
E. Utilisation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) as an intracellular signalling molecule

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a fall over the curb. She tells you that she is a refugee from Afghanistan. Imaging reveals a fracture of the pubic rami.
What is the most likely cause of this?

A. Tuberculosis
B. Osteomalacia
C. Osteoporosis
D. Osteogenesis Imperfecta
E. Osteosarcoma

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old woman has made repeated attendances to her doctor over the last year, distressed by frequent episodes of diarrhoea and abdominal cramps. There is no associated rectal bleeding. She is anxious about the possibility of bowel cancer, as her father died of this at the age of 86. There is no other relevant family history. She also mentions in passing that she needs a repeat prescription for the salbutamol inhaler she takes for her recently diagnosed asthma and is worried she might be having an early menopause as she has noticed ‘hot flushes’ occurring with increasing regularity. She has lost some weight which she attributes to her healthy diet.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Irritable bowel syndrome
B. Colorectal adenocarcinoma
C. Gastric adenocarcinoma
D. Gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumour (NET)
E. Hypochondriasis

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to Accident and Emergency with difficulty breathing. On arrival, his saturations were 78% on air, pulse 120 bpm and blood pressure 110/70 mmHg. He was given nebulised bronchodilators and started on 5 litres of oxygen, which improved his saturations up to 97%. He is more comfortable now, but a bit confused.
Which of the following is the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Arterial blood gas
B. Pulmonary function testing
C. Intravenous (IV) aminophylline
D. Call the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and intubate the patient
E. Antibiotics

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old woman has presented to her General Practitioner with a 1-week history of a fishy-smelling, thin, grey vaginal discharge. On examination the vagina is coated with a thin grey coloured discharge.
What is the most likely cause?

A. Candidiasis
B. Bacterial vaginosis
C. Trichomonas vaginalis
D. Gonorrhoea
E. Chlamydia

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old man with a history of hearing voices is brought to the Emergency Department by his family. He describes these voices as telling him to kill himself, ‘as he has a demon in him’. He also reports noting his intelligence being tapped through the television by a higher power. This has been going on for the past 3 months. His family denies either depression or manic episodes. The patient was admitted to the inpatient Psychiatry Unit and, after an evaluation, a diagnosis of schizophreniform disorder was made. He was started on Haldol (haloperidol) for his symptoms. Two days after initiation of therapy, the patient’s temperature rose to 41 °C, blood pressure 150/85 mmHg and pulse 110 bpm. Physical examination revealed muscular rigidity and delirium.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Serotonin syndrome
B. Malignant hyperthermia
C. Meningitis
D. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
E. Acute dystonia

Correct Answer: D

A man with known peptic ulcer disease presents to the Emergency Department in the middle of the night. He has been throwing up fresh blood for the last two hours and now feels very faint and dizzy. He has an extremely tender abdomen. He has no other history of note, only takes omeprazole for his peptic ulcer disease and ibuprofen for back pain. On examination, he is shocked, hypotensive, tachycardic, with cool and clammy peripheries. The jugular venous pressure (JVP) is not visible. You suspect an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed secondary to peptic ulcer disease.
Which one of the following options will contribute to the patient’s Rockall Score?

A. Patient’s sex
B. Consciousness level
C. Shock (systolic blood pressure and pulse)
D. Co-existing migraines
E. Anticoagulant use

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman presents with acute-onset abdominal pain and swelling. She is a computer engineer and is in a steady relationship with her boyfriend. On examination, her abdomen is tender, especially in the right upper quadrant, and there is mild icterus. She takes the combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP), but otherwise no regular medication or past medical history of note. Three days after admission, her abdomen became swollen and fluid thrill was elicited. Blood tests reveal:
Parameter Result
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 150 g/l 115–155 g/l
Bilirubin 51 μmol/ 2–17 μmol/
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 1050 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 998 IU/l 5−30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 210 IU/l 36–76 IU/l
Gamma-Glutamyl transferase (γGT) 108 IU/l 8–35 IU/l
Albumin 30 g/l 35–55 g/l
Ultrasonography revealed a slightly enlarged liver with a prominent caudate lobe.
Which of the following is the ideal definitive management?

A. Oral lactulose
B. Liver transplantation
C. Anticoagulation
D. Therapeutic drainage of ascitic fluid
E. Intravenous (iv) furosemide

Correct Answer: B

A 55-year-old woman came to her general practitioner, complaining of knee pain. She has been suffering from knee pain for the last couple of years, but it has become worse in the last few months. She is obese and remains at home most of the time, as movement increases the pain. On examination, she has crepitation on joint movement and no warmth of the joint. Blood tests did not reveal any abnormalities. Aspiration of the joint is done.
Which of the following will be found on X-ray of the joint?

A. Sacroiliitis
B. Periarticular osteopenia
C. Non-erosive arthritis
D. Osteophytes
E. Radio dense deposit in cartilage

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old student presented with red rashes on her feet.
On examination, she was found to be pale, with purpuric spots on her lower legs. Her temperature was 38.3 °C and she also complained of nausea.
After admission, on the second day, her fever increased and she became disoriented. New bleeding spots started appearing on her face. There was no other significant history and no drug history.
Blood reports revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 88 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 90 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Creatinine 229 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Peripheral blood smear Helmet cells and anisocytosis
Cerebrospinal (CSF) study Normal
Which of the following tests is indicated next in this patient?

A. Blood culture
B. Antiplatelet antibody
C. Urinary β-human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG)
D. Bone marrow study
E. Blood drug levels

Correct Answer: C

A 18-year old man with suspected schizophrenia is reviewed in clinic. During the consultation the patient informs you that there is a plot to destroy the world and that he has been chosen as a saviour.
Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this patient's belief?

A. Perseveration
B. Hallucination
C. Illusion
D. Mood incongruent delusion
E. Delusion

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old primip presents very tearful on day 12 postpartum. She is struggling with breastfeeding; her breasts are engorged, and breastfeeding is painful. She also feels her daughter is not feeding enough, as she is irritable and crying for most of the day. Breast examination reveals bilateral breast engorgement, but no evidence of infection. The patient tells you she felt shy to ask the health visitor for advice when she had her first postnatal visit, as she did not want her to think she was a failure as a mother.
Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

A. Arrange a one-to-one appointment with a health visitor
B. Prescribe formula milk
C. Provide the patient with information leaflets on effective breastfeeding
D. Provide the patient with national breastfeeding support organisation websites
E. Reassure the patient that it can take a few weeks to establish a good breastfeeding technique, and ask her to come back if there is no improvement in one week

Correct Answer: A

A 13-year-old boy presents with his mother, complaining of increasing growth of the breast tissue bilaterally. This is causing him extreme embarrassment, and the mother is concerned that there may be an underlying medical reason.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this child’s gynaecomastia?

A. Hypothyroidism
B. Turner syndrome
C. Increased androgen action
D. Inhaled salbutamol use
E. Puberty

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old man is brought to the edge of a roof by a trained practitioner and then left there for as long as possible until he overcomes his phobia of heights.
What sort of behavioural therapy is this?

A. Flooding
B. Graded exposure
C. Relaxation training
D. Aversion therapy
E. Exposure response therapy

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents saying that he has recently noticed small amounts of fresh red blood passed with his stool. On further questioning, he says there has also been a small amount of mucous discharge with his stool. He denies any pain, but says that his anus has been feeling pruritic and sore for the past couple of days. The patient also reports having been more constipated than usual over the past couple of months. He denies any recent weight loss, and you estimate his body mass index (BMI) as around 35. The patient has hypercholesterolaemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has had a recent lower respiratory tract infection, and finished a 7-day course of amoxicillin 5 days ago.
What is the most likely cause of his rectal bleeding?

A. Diverticulitis
B. Haemorrhoids
C. Anal fissure
D. Ulcerative colitis
E. Colonic cancer

Correct Answer: B

A 71-year-old woman with ovarian cancer is currently taking morphine sulphate modified release (MST) tablets orally 30 mg twice a day. She is admitted under palliative care and her pain is not controlling well. Your consultant asked you to prescribe oral morphine for breakthrough pain.
What dose of Oramorph and frequency should you prescribed?

A. 10 mg 2–4 hourly
B. 5 mg 1–2 hourly
C. 10 mg 6 hourly
D. 15 mg 2–4 hourly
E. 30 mg 2–4 hourly

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old primiparous woman attends her booking visit where she is given an appointment for her first scan at 12+4 weeks’ gestation. She wants to know what the appointment will involve.
Regarding the 11–13 week appointment, which of the following is correct?

A. All pregnant women need to have a Down Syndrome screening appointment
B. If the patient has booked late, then screening can be performed at 15 weeks
C. It can be diagnostic of Down syndrome
D. It can also include the ‘combined test’
E. It is also described as the ‘quadruple test’

Correct Answer: D

A 47-year-old architect presents with a lump in his neck. He first noticed the swelling in the lower right neck two months ago, and initially thought it would go away by itself; however, if anything, it seems to have got bigger. The patient has also noticed that he tends to be very tired at the end of the day. He mentions that he has also been experiencing night sweats.
On examination, the patient is found to have numerous enlarged cervical lymph nodes, as well as lymphadenopathy in the axilla. The patient is further investigated after which he is diagnosed with lymphoma.
From which cells do B and T lymphocytes originate?

A. Basophils
B. Myeloid stem cell
C. CD40
D. Plasma cells
E. Lymphoid stem cells

Correct Answer: E

A middle-aged Caucasian man presents with complaints of fever, anorexia, malaise, weight loss, weakness and myalgia and testicular pain over the past month. He is a known case of hepatitis B, diagnosed 6 months ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. Investigations revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 80 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 20 × 109/l 80% neutrophils 4–11 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 90 mm/h 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Serum creatinine 450 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 44.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
A renal arteriogram was performed which showed aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries. A testicular biopsy was done which showed necrotising vasculitis of medium and small arteries. A diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) was made.
Which one of the following arteries is most likely to be involved in PAN?

A. Pulmonary
B. Aorta
C. Common iliac artery
D. Renal artery
E. Brachiocephalic artery

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with worsening constipation over the past six months. He also mentioned some instances of rectal bleeding, which the patient attributed to haemorrhoids. When questioned, the patient reports a 6-month history of weight loss.
The patient is referred for a colonoscopy, during which a suspicious mass is found in the lumen of the descending colon. A biopsy of the lesion confirms the diagnosis of colorectal cancer.
Which of the following blood test results is most likely to be seen in this patient?

A. Reduced levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
B. Reduced levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
C. Increased levels of CEA
D. Elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
E. Elevated levels of Ca-125

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with pain and swelling of the right elbow. He reports feeling generally unwell for the past few days and recalls knocking his elbow while out cycling the week before. On examination, he has a temperature of 37.7 °C, a heart rate of 78 bpm and a blood pressure of 124/78 mmHg. There is a swelling over the posterior aspect of his right elbow, which is erythematous and warm to touch.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Arrange for corticosteroid injection
B. Oral flucloxacillin only
C. Oral flucloxacillin and refer for urgent aspiration
D. Oral amoxicillin and refer for urgent aspiration
E. Refer for urgent aspiration

Correct Answer: C

A 39-year-old man is referred by his general practitioner because of epigastric pain. The pain appears about 3 hours after taking a meal. He has used both histamine 2 receptor blockers and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) with moderate benefit and tests negative on a urease breath test. He undergoes endoscopy, which shows multiple duodenal ulcers. The patient’s gastrin level is tested and is found be above normal. A computed tomography (CT) scan is ordered, and the patient is diagnosed with Zollinger–Ellison syndrome.
Which of the following hormones normally inhibits gastrin secretion?

A. Aldosterone
B. Glycogen synthase
C. Hexokinase
D. Progesterone
E. Somatostatin

Correct Answer: E

The mother of a newborn wants to begin nursing him. However, each attempt fails because although the child suckles avidly, he immediately vomits uncurdled milk. The mother had polyhydramnios during her pregnancy.
Which is the most likely developmental defect in this child?

A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Annular pancreas
C. Omphalocele
D. Tracheoesophageal fistula
E. Ileal diverticulum

Correct Answer: D

A 66-year-old woman presents with epigastric pain, vomiting and weight loss. She is sent to endoscopy, as the surgeon suspects gastric cancer.
Where is the cancer most likely to be?

A. Cardia
B. Fundus
C. Body of the stomach
D. Antrum
E. Pylorus

Correct Answer: A

A 91-year-old man was admitted to your medical ward in Scotland a week ago, having developed pneumonia. He has a history of dementia, has had two previous small strokes and lives in a residential home. His dementia has been worsening for 5 years. He has difficulty remembering who the nursing home staff are. The staff report that his appetite is poor and that he has gradually lost weight over the last few months.
He is treated with antibiotics with good effect. A week later, a swallowing assessment is performed by the speech and language therapist, which suggests a high risk of aspiration. As a result of this assessment, the care team wish to stop him taking food and drink by mouth and start intravenous (IV) fluids.
How should you proceed next?

A. Start the IV without consulting anyone else – the team agree that this is the best way to proceed
B. Contact the nursing home to see whether they are happy with the decision
C. Find out if the patient has any relatives and ask them whether they have any objection
D. Talk to the patient, explaining what you want to do and why, and listen to his answers
E. Apply to a court to make a decision

Correct Answer: D

A 44-year-old woman, who has completed her family, presents to the Gynaecology Clinic after abnormal cervical cytology is detected on a cervical smear screen. Clinical examination is carried out under anaesthesia and a biopsy is taken from a lesion found on the ectocervix. Histology and further investigations confirm stage 1b cervical cancer.

What would be the most appropriate treatment option for this patient, considering the stage of the cancer?

A. Radical trachelectomy
B. Close cytological follow-up
C. Radical hysterectomy
D. Platinum-based chemotherapy
E. Simple hysterectomy

Correct Answer: C

An 86-year-old retired teacher with Alzheimer’s disease is reviewed in the Memory Clinic with her daughter. The daughter feels that her mother’s Alzheimer’s dementia has progressed significantly over the past few months. She notes that her mother is becoming increasingly forgetful and is having problems with dressing and eating regular meals. The consultant assesses the patient and decides to start her on memantine.
Which of the following is a common side-effect of memantine?

A. Hypotension
B. Headaches
C. Parkinsonism
D. Mobitz type II block
E. Diarrhoea

Correct Answer: B

This 40-year-old man first noticed the lesions on his lips when he was about 16-years-old. Since then he has developed similar lesions on the face, nares, tongue, ears, hands, chest and feet. The lesions blanch with pressure. His father was similarly affected.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most common initial mode of presentation of patients with this condition?

A. Anaemia
B. Cyanosis
C. Melaena
D. Recurrent epistaxis
E. Stroke

Correct Answer: D

A young woman presents with complaints of claudication of the right arm, blurring of vision, dizziness and episodes of syncope. For 2 months, she has had malaise, fever, night sweats, arthralgia, anorexia and weight loss. On clinical examination, blood pressure is non-recordable in the right arm, and in the left arm it is 160/100 mmHg. Pulses are not felt in the right arm. Investigations revealed: Hb 80 g/l (115–155 g/l); erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 70 mm/h (0–10 mm).
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Giant cell arteritis
B. Takayasu’s arteritis
C. Kawasaki’s disease
D. Subacute bacterial endocarditis
E. Occult malignancy

Correct Answer: B

An 8-year-old boy with known coeliac disease breaks out in a symmetrical prurigo with many vesicles distributed over his shoulders, back and buttocks. He also has several mouth ulcers at present.
What is the most likely diagnosis for his skin rash?

A. Dermatitis herpetiformis
B. Atopic dermatitis
C. Seborrheic dermatitis
D. Guttate psoriasis
E. Eczema pompholyx

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the Accident and Emergency department. He is visibly distressed but gives a history of sudden onset central compressive chest pain radiating to his left upper limb. He is also nauseous and very sweaty. He has had previous myocardial infarctions (MI) in the past and claims the pain is identical to those episodes. ECG reveals an anterior ST elevation MI.
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to thrombolysis?

A. Blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg
B. Peptic ulcer
C. Prolonged CPR
D. Pregnancy
E. Brain neoplasm

Correct Answer: E

A 73-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with worsening pain from his metastatic prostate cancer. He is taking morphine sulphate modified release tablets orally A. 60 mg twice a day, however your registrar decided to convert this to subcutaneously as he is unable to tolerate oral tablets with vomiting.
What is the dose of morphine that you will prescribe over 24 h using a continuous subcutaneous infusion?

A. 60 mg
B. 1D. 20 mg
C. 40 mg
D. 20 mg
E. 30 mg

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old Caucasian woman presents with a severe acute attack of bronchial asthma. For 1 week, she has had fever, malaise, anorexia and weight loss. She has tingling and numbness in her feet and hands. On examination, palpable purpura is present and nodular lesions are present on the skin. Investigations revealed eosinophilia, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, and α-2-globulin, positive p-ANCA, and a chest X-ray reveals pulmonary infiltrates.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
C. Hypereosinophilic syndrome
D. Allergic granulomatosis (Churg-Strauss syndrome)
E. Microscopic polyangitis

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to review a 28-year-old woman, who is breastfeeding on day two post-emergency Caesarean section, because her wound is tender. On examination, you notice that the skin surrounding the wound is erythematous, with a small amount of yellow discharge. There is no wound dehiscence. The area is tender on examination. Observations are stable, and the patient is apyrexial. You send a swab from the wound for culture. She has an allergy to penicillin.
Which of the following is the best next step in this patient’s management?

A. Analgesia and topical fusidic acid
B. Await blood cultures before starting antibiotics
C. Oral erythromycin
D. Oral flucloxacillin
E. Intravenous antibiotics

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman is going through a complicated marriage separation. She presents with a 2-week history of increasing generalised headache. The headache is worsened on straining. She is also complaining of increasing nausea. She is neurologically intact although slight papilloedema is noted on funduscopy. Examination is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for a calf deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her 20s for which she received 6 months of treatment. She has no significant recent drug history. Non-contrast CT scan of the brain is performed and is normal.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Venous sinus thrombosis
B. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
C. Bacterial meningitis
D. Tension headache
E. Encephalitis

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with dyspareunia, increased urinary frequency and vaginal dryness. She denies any vaginal bleeding, discharge or haematuria. There is no evidence of vasomotor or psychological menopausal symptoms.
Regarding treatment of vaginal atrophy in post-menopausal women, which of the following statements is correct?

A. All effective topical treatment options are hormonal
B. Following cessation of treatment, symptoms recur
C. Systemic hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) is the first-line treatment in women presenting with vaginal symptoms only
D. Vaginal bleeding is a common side-effect of hormonal treatment and does not require further investigation
E. Vaginal oestrogens improve vaginal, but not urinary, symptoms associated with vaginal atrophy

Correct Answer: B

An 80-year-old lady fell down some stairs and fractured the neck of her right femur.
Fracture of the femoral neck may lead to avascular necrosis of the femoral head as a result of the interruption of which artery?

A. First perforating branch of the deep femoral
B. Inferior epigastric
C. Internal pudendal
D. Medial circumflex femoral
E. Lateral circumflex femoral

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner with worsening anxiety. She describes one of her symptoms as feeling severely nauseous and even vomiting every time she hears a particular song on the radio.
What theory of learning explains this?

A. Classical conditioning
B. Habituation
C. Latent inhibition
D. Operant conditioning
E. Tolerance

Correct Answer: A

A 79-year-old man with metastatic cancer of the prostate is suffering with breakthrough pain in between his doses of oral morphine. The Palliative Care team is contacted to assess the patient and change or add to his medications to help optimise pain control.
Which of the following has the longest duration of analgesic effect?

A. Oramorph® SR oral
B. Oxycodone oral
C. Hydromorphone oral
D. Methadone oral
E. Fentanyl transdermal

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man with coeliac disease presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden-onset pain in the left leg following a trivial trauma. He is unable to walk. An X-ray of the pelvis shows fracture of the left-side neck of the femur. Routine blood investigations were carried out.
What does the blood panel likely show?

A. Decreased parathyroid hormone (PTH) with hypocalcaemia and hyperphosphataemia
B. Elevated PTH with hypercalcaemia and hypophosphataemia
C. Elevated PTH with hypocalcaemia and hypophosphataemia
D. Metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia and hypocalcaemia
E. Normal serum calcium and phosphate with elevated alkaline phosphatase

Correct Answer: C

You are a Foundation Year 2 (FY2) doctor in the Emergency Department. You are asked to see a 6-year-old boy. He has been brought in by his mother with a wrist injury following a fall from a trampoline while staying with his father. His mother reports that this is the fourth time in the past six months that he has been injured while staying with his father. On examination, he has several bruises on his arms and legs. You are concerned about the welfare of the child.
What is the most appropriate immediate action for you to take?

A. Contact his father
B. Contact the police
C. Discharge the child once he has been treated for the wrist injury and advise his mother to see the GP the following week
D. Discuss the case with the safeguarding lead in the department
E. Refer urgently to social services without consent from the patient or his mother

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner. In recent weeks, she has been awakening with painful tingling over the lateral side of her right hand. She is also complaining of clumsiness in her hand. She is found to have reduced sensation on the palmar aspects of her right thumb, index, and middle and ring fingers, and a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is suspected.
Which one of the following clinical examinations would best confirm the diagnosis?

A. Abduction of the index finger and palpation of the soft tissue between the first and second metacarpal bones
B. Abduction of the thumb with palpation of the thenar eminence
C. Abduction of the thumb and opposition of the thumb against resistance
D. Extension of the thumb with palpation of the anatomical snuffbox
E. Opposition of the thumb with palpation of the thenar eminence

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old is brought unconscious to the Emergency Department. An alert ambulance attendant notes that the patient's breath smells like fruit punch. The patient was found holding a glass containing clear liquid and the ambulance attendant had noted a syringe on the patient's coffee table and a pool of vomit near the patient.
With which of the following would this presentation be most consistent?

A. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
B. Diabetic hyperosmolar coma
C. Profound hypoglycaemia
D. Heroin overdose
E. Alcohol intoxication

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man visits his General Practitioner (GP), complaining of wrist pain and weakness of the thumb and index finger of the right hand for the last 2 weeks. He also mentioned that 4 weeks ago he had fallen on his outstretched hand but did not seek medical treatment. On examination, he has weakness in his ability to oppose the right thumb, with loss of sensation over the palmar aspect of the lateral fingers of his right hand.
Which of the following bones is most likely to be dislocated in this patient?

A. Scaphoid
B. Hamate
C. Capitate
D. Pisiform
E. Lunate

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department after noticing a markedly visible bulge in his groin while lifting heavy weights. Examination reveals a soft palpable mass in the scrotum that is reducible with gentle massage.
Which of the following most likely ascends along the deep inguinal ring through which this palpable mass has passed in this patient?

A. Rectus abdominis muscle
B. Inguinal ligament
C. Femoral artery and vein
D. Inferior epigastric artery and vein
E. Superficial inguinal ring

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department after falling down the stairs at home. She attends complaining of ‘rib pain’ and is moved to the resus room from triage, as she was unable to complete full sentences due to shortness of breath. Sats on room air were 91%. You are asked to see her urgently as the nursing staff are concerned about her deterioration.
On examination, she appears distressed; blood pressure is 80/40, heart rate 120 bpm, respiratory rate 40 and sats 85% on air. Her left chest does not appear to be moving very well, and there are no audible breath sounds on the left on auscultation.
What is the most appropriate next step in immediate management of this patient?

A. Portable chest X-ray
B. Left-sided chest drain
C. Nebulised salbutamol/ipratropium
D. Needle thoracocentesis of left chest
E. Urgent respiratory consultation

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old man presents with intermittent claudication. He has a body mass index of 32 kg/m2 and smokes 40 cigarettes a day. He admits that he has an extremely unhealthy diet. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease but his father died of complications of diabetes. His blood pressure is 160/110 mmHg.
What is the most likely cause of the claudication?

A. Atherosclerosis
B. Diabetes
C. Buerger’s disease
D. Coarctation of the aorta
E. Takayasu’s disease

Correct Answer: A

A 74-year-old man presents with gradually worsening vision. He reports struggling with night-time driving due to glare from oncoming traffic. He denies any pain in the eye. His doctor is suspicious that he may have developed cataracts.
What findings on examination are most classical of complete cataract formation?

A. Absent red reflex
B. Cotton wool spots
C. Increased ocular pressure
D. Positive Schirmer’s test
E. Reduced visual acuity

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man is being treated in hospital for pneumonia with ciprofloxacin. Two days later the patient develops generalised abdominal pain, a fever and bloody diarrhoea. A stool sample confirms the diagnosis of Clostridium difficile.
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Continue ciprofloxacin and add clindamycin
B. Continue ciprofloxacin and add metronidazole
C. Stop all antibiotic treatment until the GI symptoms have resolved
D. Stop ciprofloxacin and switch to clindamycin
E. Stop ciprofloxacin and switch to vancomycin

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old is admitted to A&E with seizures. He is told not to drive. You bump into him in the car park in your local supermarket, he has just parked the car he was driving. He is due to be seen in clinic in a week’s time.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Stop him in the car park and remind him that he shouldn't be driving
B. Call the police
C. Call the DVLA and report the patient
D. Phone the patient when you are next at work
E. Ignore what you have just seen, you are post-night shifts and could be wrong.

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old woman in her second pregnancy has been diagnosed with pre-eclampsia and is on labetalol twice daily. She attends the Antenatal Assessment Unit with abdominal pain that started earlier this morning, followed by a brown discharge. The pain is constant and radiates to the back. On examination, the uterus is hard and tender; there is a small amount of dark red blood on the pad she shows you.
Which of the following investigations is more likely to be diagnostic of the cause of this patient’s antepartum bleeding?

A. Bimanual examination
B. Full blood count
C. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
D. Transabdominal ultrasound scan
E. Urinalysis

Correct Answer: D

A final-year medical student takes a history from a 43-year-old man who suffers from narcolepsy. Following this the student presents the case to her consultant, who quizzes the student about normal sleep regulation.
Which neurotransmitter is chiefly involved in rapid eye movement (REM) sleep regulation?

A. Adrenaline (epinephrine)
B. Noradrenaline (norepinephrine)
C. Acetylcholine
D. Serotonin
E. Dopamine

Correct Answer: B

Following a coughing fit, a 72-year-old woman complains of severe lumbar back pain radiating around to the waist. She takes no medications. Clinical observations are within the normal range.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Mechanical back pain
B. Herniated lumbar disc prolapse
C. Osteoarthritis
D. Osteoporotic wedge fracture
E. Osteomyelitis

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman who is known to have advanced chronic kidney disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy presents with vomiting, chest pain and generalised lethargy. She was advised for creation of arteriovenous fistula for commencement of renal replacement therapy three months ago. However, she defaulted the appointment to seek traditional medical treatment.
On arrival to the Emergency Department, she is seen by the physician and urgent blood investigations were ordered.
Her blood results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal range
Potassium (K+) 7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 44 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 618 mmol/l 50-120 mmol/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Bicarbonate ion 12 mEq/l 22–28 mEq/l
After reviewing the blood investigations, femoral venous catheter is inserted for urgent haemodialysis.
Which of the following is the most suitable constituent of the dialysing fluid?

A. Na+ 142, K+ 7, creatinine 650, urea 45, and HCO3– 12
B. Na+ 142, K+ 9.0, creatinine 0, urea 0, and HCO3– 0
C. Na+ 71, K+ 3.5, creatinine 325, urea 22, and HCO3– 6
D. Na+ 133, K+ 1.0, creatinine 0, urea 0, and HCO3– 35
E. Na+ 156, K+ 14, creatinine 1000, urea 90, and HCO3– 24

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old man presents with a 72-hour history of gradual onset of pain in the left testicle. He walks into the Emergency Department without being in obvious discomfort. However, when examined, his left testicle is tender to firm palpation. Vital signs are normal. There is no redness or swelling. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. He reports dysuria and has recently entered a new sexual relationship.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Immediate involvement of the on-call urologist to arrange exploration of the scrotum to exclude torsion
B. Treat with ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (im) plus doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 10–14 days
C. Treat with ciprofloxacin orally for 10 days
D. Admit to hospital for intravenous (iv) teicoplanin for 3 days
E. Offer pain relief only

Correct Answer: B

A woman aged 76 presents with a 2-cm unilateral, invasive vulvar carcinoma, with no evidence of lymph node involvement.
What is the recommended management?

A. C. Simple vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy
B. Radiation therapy
C. Simple vulvectomy
D. Chemotherapy
E. Wide local excision

Correct Answer: A

A 57-year-old man has been under regular haemodialysis for the last 5 years. He had earlier had an arteriovenous (AV) fistula in the right arm, but it became infected 3 years ago and was no longer viable. Currently, he is receiving dialysis through an AV fistula in the left forearm. He presents with pain in the left hand and wrist. On examination, there is redness and a necrotic ulcer on the left middle finger. Power in his left hand is normal. He has no constitutional symptoms and is not receiving any drugs. He had undergone uneventful dialysis the day before.
What is the probable diagnosis?

A. Infected AV fistula
B. Infective endocarditis
C. Thrombosis and distal embolisation from the fistula
D. Distal hypoperfusion ischaemic syndrome (DHIS)
E. Unrelated local pathology

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman presents with pain in the right chest at the level of the fifth and sixth ribs. Tenderness is also present. There is no history of trauma. Chest X-ray demonstrates fractures of the fifth and sixth ribs and exuberant callus formation at the sites of healing fractures.
These findings are characteristic of osteoporosis due to which one of the following?

A. Long-term use of corticosteroids
B. Phenytoin
C. Primary hyperparathyroidism
D. Coarctation of the aorta
E. Long-standing hyperthyroidism

Correct Answer: A

A frail 86-year-old woman with metastatic renal cell carcinoma is admitted with acute confusion. She takes paracetamol and codeine for pain and has been on bendroflumethiazide for several years to treat hypertension. On examination, she is disorientated in time and place. She is clinically hypovolaemic but her blood pressure and heart rate are normal. Chest, cardiovascular, abdominal and neurological examinations are otherwise normal. There is no evidence of infection. Her blood results are as follows:
Creatinine 140 μmol/l
Urea 18.0 mmol/l
Sodium 129 mmol/l
Potassium 4.0 mmol/l
Corrected calcium 3.2 mmol/l
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Administer 2 l of 0.9% sodium chloride over 24 hours
B. Commence an infusion of pamidronate
C. Arrange urgent renal dialysis
D. Stop bendoflumethiazide
E. Encourage oral fluids and reassess in 24 hours

Correct Answer: A

A 6-year-old boy and his mother die in a car crash. Following these deaths, the boy’s 17-year-old brother starts playing with the dead boy’s toys.
This would most likely be an example of which of the following defence mechanisms?

A. Denial
B. Identification
C. Rationalisation
D. Reaction formation
E. Sublimation

Correct Answer: B

Mary is a 19-year-old army recruit who presents with bilateral anterior shin pain halfway through her basic military training. She complains of a vague, diffuse pain along the middle of her shin, with tenderness along the anterolateral surface of the tibia, and there is pain on resisted dorsiflexion. Although this pain is worse at the beginning of exercise, it decreases during training.
What is the next step in her management?

A. Radiographs of bilateral tibia/fibula
B. Bone scan
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
D. Ultrasound
E. Reassure the patient, advise them to rest and ice their shins after exercise

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old man attends the clinic for review. He has chronic cardiomyopathy with heart failure and is currently taking furosemide, spironolactone, ramipril, carvedilol and digoxin. He is stable with blood pressure of 115/70 mmHg, no clinical cardiac failure and an exercise tolerance of 200 m. His main complaint is that of breast tenderness.
Which of his medications is most likely to be responsible?

A. Furosemide
B. Ramipril
C. Digoxin
D. Carvedilol
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: E

A 39-year-old man presents with thick, demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scaling over the extensor surface of the elbows and knees. He has had these skin lesions on and off over the last 2 years. The lesions become less severe during summer, aggravate at the time of stress and recur at the site of skin trauma. Histopathological examination of the skin biopsy specimen shows epidermal hyperplasia and parakeratosis, with neutrophils inside the epidermis.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Lichen planus
B. Psoriasis
C. Seborrheic dermatitis
D. Lichen simplex chronicus
E. Tinea corporis

Correct Answer: B

A 68-year-old man is started on amiodarone for atrial fibrillation.
Which series of investigations should the general practitioner (GP) perform on this patient as a baseline?

A. Liver function tests (LFTs), urea and electrolytes (U&Es), thyroid function tests (TFTs) and chest X-ray
B. LFTs, U&Es, peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR)
C. TFTs, chest X-ray and pulmonary function test
D. LFTs, U&Es, TFTs and nerve conduction studies
E. Chest X-ray, LFTs, U&Es and visual field studies

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain which occurs after eating. On questioning, she also describes weight loss but explains that her abdominal pain prevents her from eating large amounts. Her past medical history includes stable angina and intermittent claudication secondary to peripheral arterial disease.
Examination of the abdomen reveals no abnormalities on inspection, generalised tenderness on palpation, no evidence of organomegaly and normal bowel sounds.
Routine blood tests including full blood count, urea and electrolytes and liver function tests are normal. CT angiography reveals an obstructed coeliac trunk and a stenosed but patent superior mesenteric artery.
Which organ is most likely to be ischaemic and contributing to this patient’s symptoms?

A. Stomach
B. Transverse colon
C. Descending colon
D. Jejunum
E. Ileum

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old man is admitted to hospital with exertional chest pain. He says this has only started in the last few days, mainly when walking up hills. The pain is not present at rest.
What is the gold standard investigation will you order for this patient among the following investigations?

A. Angiogram
B. Chest X-ray
C. Computed tomography (CT) coronary angiogram
D. Full blood count
E. Troponin

Correct Answer: C

A 20-year-old woman of African origin had a benign breast lump removed from her right breast. Two months later, there is a firm, 2 × 1.5 cm nodular mass with an intact overlying epithelium in the region of the incision and extends over the boundary of the incision.
On examination, the scar is firm but not tender, with no erythema. This mass is excised and microscopically shows fibroblasts with abundant collagen.
Which of the following mechanisms has most probably produced this series of events?

A. Development of a fibrosarcoma
B. Keloid formation
C. Poor wound healing
D. Foreign body response to suturing
E. Staphylococcal wound infection

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old man who lives alone is admitted to the Emergency Department by ambulance after he was found by his home help in a drowsy and confused state. It is understood that he likes to visit the pub and he is thought to consume excess alcohol. You find that he was admitted 3 weeks earlier after a fall while out drinking but was discharged the same evening. The home help tells you that he has been complaining of headaches and behaving a little oddly this week. On examination he is drowsy and confused, you note that he has evidence of a left-sided weakness. He is in atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 85 bpm. No evidence of cardiac murmurs.
Which of the following diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
B. Subdural haematoma
C. Right sided embolic stroke
D. Korsakoff's psychosis
E. Intracerebral tumour

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with a subacute red, swollen, hot right knee. He said he thinks he may have twisted it playing football, but he was not sure. You notice also that he has some scaly plaques on his elbows which may be psoriasis. You perform a joint aspiration and send it to the laboratory. The laboratory rings you with the preliminary results showing raised leucocytes with 92% polymorhopnuclear cells. The Gram stain was a reddish pink colour and microscopy showed the presence of diplococci.
What is the cause of this man’s arthritis?

A. Psoriasis
B. Trauma
C. Septic arthritis due to sexually transmitted disease
D. Unable to tell – requires further investigation
E. Septic arthritis with Staphylococcus

Correct Answer: C

A 23-year-old married shop assistant presents to the Emergency Department with a presumed seizure, where her hands and feet shook and she bit her tongue. This is the second such event in the past 4 months and she was due to see a neurologist in a fortnight’s time. Computed tomography (CT) brain was normal. Electroencephalogram (EEG) was normal, albeit not performed during the ‘seizure’ activity. Her doctor believes she has epilepsy and is keen to commence anticonvulsive therapy. She is sexually active and uses only condoms for protection.
Which one of the following drugs would be most suitable for this particular patient?

A. Carbamazepine
B. Sodium valproate
C. Lamotrigine
D. Phenytoin
E. Levetiracetam

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man who works as a waiter presents to his General Practitioner with complaints of swelling and pain in both the lower limbs which worsens by the end of the day. He also noted bulging of veins in both his thighs and calf region. On examination, he has varicose veins over the thighs and calf region.
What is the investigation of choice to make a diagnosis?

A. 24-hour urinary protein
B. Duplex ultrasound
C. Echocardiogram (ECHO)
D. Liver elastography
E. Renal function test

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old woman who lives alone in a campervan is brought to the Emergency Department by her daughter. She was found lying on the floor unconscious but later came around. She now complains of headache, nausea, difficulty breathing and feeling faint. She does not smoke, drink alcohol or take any recreational drugs.
Which of the following investigations is most likely to lead to a probable diagnosis of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain
B. Electrocardiogram (ECG) and measurement of cardiac enzymes
C. Measurement of arterial PO2 levels
D. Multi-wavelength oximetry analysis
E. Standard pulse oximetry

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old man and his wife, who have been struggling to conceive, are seen in a Fertility Clinic for results of investigations. His semen sample has shown azoospermia.
On further questioning, the man states he has a longstanding cough productive of purulent sputum.
Which of the following investigations would confirm the underlying diagnosis?

A. Karyotyping
B. Computed tomography (CT) thorax and sputum culture
C. Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) genetic screening and sweat test
D. Testicular biopsy
E. Nasal biopsy

Correct Answer: C

A 73-year-old man complains of right leg pain of 2 years’ duration. There is no history of falls or injury. In the past, he has been in hospital because of cardiac failure and he also takes inhaled bronchodilators and corticosteroids for obstructive airway disease. Examination shows mild tenderness of his right leg only. Routine blood tests show normal serum calcium and phosphate levels and vitamin D levels, but a markedly raised alkaline phosphatase level.
What is the most appropriate drug treatment for this man’s bone pain?

A. Paracetamol
B. Bisphosphonates
C. Calcium and vitamin D
D. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old man is scheduled for a cystoscopy for symptoms of nocturia and urinary frequency with poor stream (terminal dribbling). On examination, on the day of surgery, you notice he has an ejection systolic murmur radiating to the carotids and he describes getting very breathless on stairs.
How would you proceed?

A. Proceed with surgery as planned
B. Proceed with surgery under a spinal anaesthetic
C. Proceed with surgery, but give a dose of prophylactic antibiotics
D. Proceed with surgery, but ensure you put in an arterial line and a central line, and discuss with the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
E. Defer surgery until he is seen by Cardiology and an echocardiography report is available

Correct Answer: E

An 18-month-old baby has a 24-hour history of being generally unwell with a barking cough. His mother says he makes a loud noise when he breathes in and his symptoms are worse at night. He has a temperature of 38.5 °C.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asthma
B. Croup
C. Simple viral cough
D. Whooping cough
E. Bronchiolitis

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old man with a history of intravenous (iv) drug abuse 21 years ago is referred by his doctor with abnormal liver function tests. He has significantly raised alanine aminotransferase (ALT). He tests positive for hepatitis C RNA and genotyping reveals genotype 1 hepatitis C. Liver biopsy reveals lymphocytic infiltration with some evidence of early hepatic fibrosis with associated necrosis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this man?

A. Direct acting antivirals (DAAs)
B. Interferon gamma
C. Ribavirin
D. Pegylated (PEG)-interferon α and ribavirin
E. PEG-interferon α with ribavirin and a protease inhibitor

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old woman presented to the Heart Failure Clinic with shortness of breath. On examination, there is a loud pan-systolic murmur audible throughout her chest.
