The murmur is louder on inspiration than expiration. It is hard to differentiate where the murmur is loudest. She also has distended neck veins and a raised jugular venous pressure (JVP).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Aortic sclerosis
C. Pulmonary stenosis
D. Mitral regurgitation
E. Tricuspid regurgitation (TR)

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old male smoker presented with chronic dyspnoea. He used to work in the shipyard but now has a retired life with his dogs. He was under treatment as a case of COPD, but maximal therapy for COPD failed to bring him any relief. On re-evaluation, his chest X-ray showed fine reticular opacities in the lower zones. A CT scan of his thorax showed interstitial thickening, with some ground glass opacity in the upper lungs.
Pleural plaques were absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asbestosis
B. Asthma
C. Pneumoconiosis
D. Histoplasmosis
E. Respiratory bronchiolitis-associated interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD)

Correct Answer: E

An inpatient recovering from a first-time anaphylactic reaction to shellfish is being discharged.
Which of the following should be done at discharge?

A. Arrange for a blood test after one week for serum tryptase, immunoglobulin E (IgE) and histamine levels to assess biphasic reaction
B. Advise that anaphylactic reactions are not biphasic
C. Advise that one adrenaline auto-injector will be prescribed if the patient has a further anaphylactic reaction
D. Discharge to the General Practitioner with no adrenaline auto-injector
E. Discharge with two adrenaline autoinjectors

Correct Answer: E

A 23-year-old Caucasian woman complains of stiffness and pain in the neck, occiput, shoulders, thorax, low back and thighs. The pain is of achy quality and is worsened by fatigue. She has been under stress at her workplace. She has a habit of finishing everything perfectly. She complains that her sleep has been disturbed for many days. She has a known case of irritable bowel syndrome. On examination, you notice multiple tender points on her body. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are normal. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic fatigue syndrome
B. Polymyalgia rheumatica
C. Somatic symptom syndrome
D. Fibromyalgia
E. Polymyositis

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old Caucasian man complains of diarrhoea for the past 3 months. He also complains of fatigue and weight loss. He is not an alcoholic or drug abuser. He frequently visits southern India for business purposes. Investigations reveal mixed macrocytic anaemia. Serum folate levels and vitamin B12 levels are low. Stool examination is negative for ova and parasites. Small bowel intestinal biopsy reveals predominant mononuclear infiltration and villous destruction to a lesser extent. These changes are present throughout the small intestine.
Which one of the following interventions will most likely result in improvement of his diarrhoea and other symptoms?

A. Gluten-free diet
B. Broad spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline and folate
C. Pancreatic enzyme replacement
D. Double-strength trimethoprim and sulfamethaxozole
E. Antihelminthic drugs

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old woman presents at 12 weeks’ gestation to see the clinician. Her risk of developing Down syndrome was calculated as 1 in 10, and she was offered a diagnostic test. Chorionic villous sampling confirms Down syndrome. Following long discussions with her and her partner, she decides on termination of the pregnancy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A. No management required at present, reassess the patient in two weeks to allow her time to change her mind
B. Oral mifepristone
B. C. Oral mifepristone followed by vaginal misoprostol as an inpatient
D. Vaginal misoprostol
E. Surgical evacuation of products of conception

Correct Answer: C

A 13-year-old girl attends her general practice surgery with a 1-week history of a sore throat and a new-onset rash. The rash is on her trunk and consists of many small, erythematous, drop-like lesions in a symmetrical distribution.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atopic eczema
B. Guttate psoriasis
C. Pityriasis rosea
D. Pityriasis versicolor
E. Plaque psoriasis

Correct Answer: B

A 63-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of dyspnoea on exertion. She denies a history of cough, wheeze and weight loss but admits to a brief episode of syncope two weeks ago. Her past medical history includes, chronic kidney disease stage IV and stage 2 hypertension. She is currently taking lisinopril, amlodipine and atorvastatin. She is an ex-smoker with a 15-pack year history.
On examination it is noted that she has a low-volume pulse and an ejection systolic murmur heard loudest at the right upper sternal edge. The murmur is noted to radiate to both carotids. Moreover, she has good bilateral air entry, vesicular breath sounds and no added breath noises on auscultation of the respiratory fields. The patient’s temperature is recorded as 37.2°C, blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg, and a pulse of 68 beats per minute. A chest X-ray is taken which is reported as the following:
Investigation Result
Chest radiograph Technically adequate film. Normal cardiothoracic ratio. Prominent right ascending aorta, normal descending aorta. No pleural disease. No bony abnormality.
Which of the following most likely explains her dyspnoea?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Aortic regurgitation
C. Ventricular septal defect
D. Mitral regurgitation
E. Mitral stenosis

Correct Answer: A

A 56-year-old man who is a long-term cigarette smoker presents with nocturnal dry cough of 4 weeks’ duration. He has recently gone through a stressful life situation due to divorce and bankruptcy. He mentions a history of atopic diseases in his family. His symptom improves with omeprazole, one tablet daily taken in the morning.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Peptic ulcer disease
B. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease
C. Asthma
D. Psychogenic cough
E. Chronic bronchitis

Correct Answer: B

A 7-year-old boy is brought to see the General Practitioner (GP) by his mother, who is concerned about his behaviour at home and school. Over the past 12 months, his mother has noted problems with inattention, hyperactivity and impulsivity. Teachers have also been raising similar issues about his behaviour in school. His symptoms are affecting his performance in school and his relationship at home with his parents and siblings.
Which one of the following conditions is he most likely to be diagnosed with?

A. Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
B. Autism spectrum disorder
C. Learning difficulty
D. Learning disability
E. Oppositional defiance disorder

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old obese woman presents with a firm, 2 cm mass in her left breast. The overlying skin appears slightly bruised and erythematous, however the patient does not report any pain. There is no nipple discharge or axillary lymphadenopathy. The patient informs you that she was hit in the chest with a tennis ball during a tennis game approximately a month ago, at the time there was significant bruising. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasound confirms the presence of a rounded well-defined density, which has no microcalcifications, and reveals no lesions of the opposite breast.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Phyllodes tumour
B. Fibroadenoma
C. Focus of fat necrosis
D. Intraductal papilloma
E. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old lady with multiple myeloma attends the Oncology Day Hospital for her monthly infusion of intravenous zoledronic acid. She complains of neck pain and new weakness and paraesthesiae of her left hand and arm.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this lady?

A. Assess her analgesia and up-titrate to control her pain
B. Physiotherapy assessment for her hand weakness
C. Urgent blood cultures
D. Urgent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) whole spine
E. X-ray C-spine

Correct Answer: D

A 56-year-old man presents to his GP for a routine check up following his myocardial infarction (MI) 6 weeks ago. He looks unwell on examination, sweaty and clammy and reports feeling feverish constantly. His most recent blood tests show a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and anaemia.
Which of the following post-MI complication is most likely to occur in this man?

A. Myomalacia cordis
B. Ventricular aneurysm
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Dressler’s syndrome
E. Heart failure

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man with a past history of hypertension presents to you with lethargy and pruritus. He has the following blood test results from serum biochemistry:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 16.7 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 578 μmol/l 50–120 mmol/l
Calcium (Ca2+) Low
Phosphate High
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) Raised
Which of the following diagnoses fits the clinical picture best?

A. Chronic renal failure due to hypertension
B. Loop diuretic overuse
C. Primary hyperparathyroidism
D. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
E. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old woman with a previous history of multiple gallstones has developed jaundice as a result of a large stone obstructing the common bile duct.
Which of the following biochemical abnormalities will be seen in this patient?

A. Decreased bilirubin in the urine
B. Increased urobilinogen in the urine
C. Decreased stercobilin in the stool
D. Decreased plasma direct bilirubin
E. Decreased plasma conjugated bilirubin

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old man undergoes circumcision for phimosis. He requires local anaesthetic for a penile block. He weighs 60 kg. The maximum safe dose of lidocaine is 3 mg/kg, and 7 mg/kg when administered with adrenaline.
Which of the following is the safest choice of local anaesthetic for this patient?

A. 10 ml of 1% lidocaine with adrenaline 1 : 200 000
B. 25 ml of 1% Lidocaine
C. 18 ml of 1% Lidocaine
D. 15 ml of 1% Lidocaine with adrenaline 1:200,000
B. E. 25 ml of 1% Lidocaine with adrenaline 1:10,000

Correct Answer: C

A 79-year-old inpatient awaiting cardiovascular surgery who was speaking to nursing staff this morning, however, now has a decreased consciousness level. He has atrial fibrillation for which he takes warfarin, and osteoarthritis for which he takes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). He also has type 1 diabetes mellitus which is controlled using fast-acting insulin before meals and a long-acting analogue before bed. There is no other relevant history. Temperature 35.2 °C, heart rate (HR) 125 bpm, blood pressure (BP) 170/118 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) 22 breaths/minute, oxygen saturation (SaO2) 95% on air. Examination reveals weakness in all four limbs and a fine tremor. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 10/15 (E2, V3, M5).
Which of the following is the most likely cause of his decreased consciousness?

A. Hypoglycaemia
B. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleed
C. Stroke
D. Delerium tremens
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: A

This 15-year-old girl presents with the erythematous, itchy patches on both feet shown in the picture. The rest of her skin is clear and she has no rash elsewhere on her body. She is otherwise well and has nothing significant in her past medical history.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which of the following is the most likely causative factor?

A. A component of her footwear
B. Deficiency of vitamin C
C. Latex
D. Staphylococcus aureus
E. Trichophyton rubrum

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with swelling of her left arm accompanied by a dull ache. On clinical examination, her left arm is oedematous, though there is no erythema. She has otherwise been well. She has a past history of extensive breast surgery after being diagnosed with breast cancer last year.
What is the initial management for this patient most likely to consist of?

A. Antibiotics
B. Decongestive therapy
C. Laser therapy
D. Simple analgesia alone
E. Surgery

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old patient has been admitted for cholecystectomy. While you are writing up her drug chart, the patient informs the SHO that she is on digoxin for a heart condition.
With regard to digoxin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Digoxin is the treatment of choice for ventricular fibrillation (VF)
B. Intravenous digoxin cardioverts most cases of atrial fibrillation (AF)
C. Visual disturbance is a feature of digoxin toxicity
D. Hyperkalaemia potentiates digoxin toxicity
E. Digoxin is metabolised by the liver

Correct Answer: C

With regard to nail changes, which of the following statements is correct?

A. White nails are a feature of hyperalbuminaemia
B. Bacterial endocarditis is the most common cause of splinter haemorrhages
C. Ridges in the nails may be seen in psoriasis
D. Koilonychia is the result of vitamin B12 deficiency
E. Clubbing occurs in ischaemic heart disease

Correct Answer: C

A 33-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department as she has suddenly developed a blind spot in her left eye and pain on eye movements. On examination, colour vision, visual fields and visual acuity are all significantly reduced in her left eye. She also reports that she has had several episodes of transient paraesthesia in her right arm over the past few months and two episodes of urinary incontinence. A lumbar puncture is performed to investigate an underlying diagnosis.
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) analysis?

A. Low glucose
B. Oligoclonal bands immunoglobulin G (IgG)
C. Polymorphonuclear leukocytes
D. Positive Gram stain
E. Xanthochromia

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old dentist presents with an acute onset of widespread blistering of the skin. He is usually fit and well but has been taking regular ibuprofen for the past two days due to injuring his ankle when out for a run.
On examination, the patient has numerous tense bullae across the trunk and limbs. There is no oral involvement. The patient is reviewed by the dermatologist, who suspects a case of bullous pemphigoid.
In cases of bullous pemphigoid, which adhesive structure is disrupted by autoimmune mechanisms?

A. Desmosome
B. Hemidesmosome
C. Zonula occludens
D. Zonula adherens
E. Gap junction

Correct Answer: B

This 78-year-old man is receiving treatment for the chronic ulcer shown in the picture. The ulcer is painful when he is in bed. Hanging the leg out of bed gives some relief.
What sort of ulcer is shown?

A. Arterial ulcer
B. Marjolin’s ulcer
C. Neurotrophic ulcer
D. Rodent ulcer
E. Venous ulcer

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man, who has recently started a new relationship, presented with depression. He said that he had decreased libido, and this was causing problems in the relationship. The treating doctor decided to start him on testosterone, following some blood tests.
Which of the following routes is contraindicated for administering testosterone?

A. Oral
B. Transdermal
C. Intramuscular (im)
D. Intravenous (iv)
E. Buccal

Correct Answer: D

A screening test for a disease is performed on 500 people. A total of 444 people do not have the disease. Of those with the disease, 50 had a positive screening test result. A total of 445 patients had a negative screening test result.
What is the specificity of the screening test?

A. 89.3%
B. 90.9%
C. 98.7%
D. 98.9%
E. 99.8%

Correct Answer: D

An 80-year-old woman with dementia is deemed to lack capacity after a full assessment is carried out. Decisions will therefore need to be made on her behalf by a Court-Appointed Deputy in her best interests.
Which of the following is included under the Mental Capacity Act 2005?

A. Decisions relating to consent for making an adoption order
B. Decisions relating to consent for marriage or civil partnership
C. Decisions relating to her treatment of a mental disorder
D. Decisions relating to voting at an election
E. Decisions relating to her welfare

Correct Answer: E

You are about to prescribe fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) to a 45-year-old man who has just started a new relationship. He asks about common side-effects.
Which of the below is a common side-effect that it would be most important to council this patient about?

A. Sexual dysfunction
B. Sedation
C. Constipation
D. Urinary retention
E. Dry mouth

Correct Answer: A

A man with known angina currently managed on glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray presents to Accident and Emergency with crushing central chest pain. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST depression and flat T waves. He is managed as acute coronary syndrome without ST elevation.
Which one of the following options is most likely to be used in his immediate management?

A. Furosemide
B. Paracetamol
C. Warfarin
D. Simvastatin
E. Fondaparinux

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) and reports that she is unable to stop worrying. She has not been sleeping at night and is finding it difficult to concentrate on activities she used to enjoy. She is started on a new medication and referred for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT). A month later, she returns to her GP as she is feeling weak and lethargic and suffering from muscle cramps.
Her blood tests are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal range
Sodium 126 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 3.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 95 µmol/l 68–98 µmol/l
Calcium 2.40 mmol/l 2.05–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate 1.41 mmol/l 0.8–1.50 mmol/l
Which of the following medications is she most likely to have started?

A. Diazepam
B. Pregabalin
C. Propranolol
D. Sertraline
E. Zopiclone

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old Caucasian man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) for routine health screening. He has a background history of obesity (BMI 31 kg/m2), impaired glucose tolerance and he used to smoke. His blood pressure is 162/100 mmHg. It is the same in both arms. There is no renal bruit and he does not appear cushingoid. He does not take regular exercise. At his previous appointment his blood pressure was 168/98 mm/Hg and he has been testing his BP at home. Average readings are 155/95 mmHg. He does not drink alcohol. His father had a heart attack at age 58. Blood results are listed below:
Investigation Result Normal value
HbA1C 46 mmol/l < 53 mmol/mol (<7.0%)
Potassium 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5 mmol/l
Urea 7 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 84 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Total cholesterol 5.2 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
High-density lipoprotein (HDL) 1.1 mmol/l > 1.0 mmol/l
Low density-lipoprotein (LDL) 3 mmol/l < 3.5 mmol/l
Triglycerides 1.1 mmol/l 0–1.5 mmol/l
Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) 2 µU/l 0.17–3.2 µU/l
Free T4 16 pmol/l 11–22 pmol/l
What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

A. Lifestyle advice alone
B. Lifestyle advice plus commence fibrate
C. Commence ACE inhibitor
D. Commence beta blockade
E. Commence spironolactone

Correct Answer: C

A 6-year-old child is brought to the paediatrician by his parents for a follow-up examination after diagnosis of a genetically inherited disease. On examination, the paediatrician notes a yellow-brown coloration right around the iris.
With which type of renal dysfunction is the first-line treatment for this child’s condition most associated?

A. Membranous nephropathy
B. Minimal change disease
C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
D. Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
E. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman is brought to Accident and Emergency after being found near-unconscious by her husband. Her husband indicates that she has a long-term joint disorder that has been controlled with oral medicationand uses steroids excessively. She has recently been suffering from depression and has had poor compliance with medications. On examination, she is responsive to pain. Her pulse is 130 bpm and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. She is afebrile.
Basic blood investigations reveal:
Investigation Patient Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 233 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 129 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 93 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glucose 2.7 mmol/l <11.1 mmol/l (random)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Insulin overdose
B. Salicylate overdose
C. Addisonian crisis
D. Meningococcal septicaemia
E. Paracetamol overdose

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and jaundice. She is tachycardic and has rigors and a temperature of 38.2 °C.
Tests reveal: WCC 19.9 (high), C-reactive protein (CRP) 120 (high), amylase 120 (high), bilirubin 29 (high), alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 312 (high) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 34 (normal). Ultrasound scanning reveals a dilated common bile duct. She is aggressively and successfully resuscitated with fluids and antibiotics overnight.
What is the next best intervention on the following day?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen
B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
D. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
E. Ultrasound scan of the biliary tree

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 1-month history of developing breasts which are tender to touch. He has ischaemic heart disease and takes digoxin, warfarin and ramipril. He also reports taking daily aspirin for heartburn.
Which of the following most likely causes gynaecomastia?

A. Aspirin
B. Digoxin
C. Ramipril
D. Ranitidine
E. Warfarin

Correct Answer: B

In a city, the annual incidence of colon cancer is 59/A. C. 100 000. At the time of diagnosis, approximately 65% of all cases are ‘advanced’, with an annual case-fatality rate in this group of 50%. By contrast, if colon cancer is localised at the time of diagnosis, the five-year survival rate is B. 90%. In 2014, the population of this city was 444 000.
What is the five-year fatality rate (per A. C. 1000) among those with localised disease?

A. 10
B. 90
A. C. 100
D. 500
B. E. 900

Correct Answer: C

A 74-year-old woman is admitted with renal failure. She has a history of congestive heart failure and takes ramipril 10 mg daily and furosemide 80 mg daily.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 102 g/l 115–155 g/l
Platelets 180 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 143 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 520 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Chest X-ray: no significant pulmonary oedema
Peripheral fluid replacement is commenced and a right subclavian central line is inserted. She complains of pleuritic chest pain; saturations have decreased to 90% on oxygen via mask.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Subclavian artery haematoma
B. Iatrogenic pneumothorax
C. Developing pulmonary oedema
D. Lower respiratory tract infection
E. Costochondritis

Correct Answer: B

A 38-year-old woman presents with tiredness and difficulty sleeping. She is no longer deriving any pleasure from previously enjoyed activities, such as gardening. She has three children aged two, four and five years. Despite support from her husband, her symptoms have not resolved for six weeks.
The medication she is likely to be prescribed targets which neurotransmitter?

A. GABA
B. Serotonin
C. Dopamine
D. Noradrenaline
E. Acetylcholine

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department following a bar fight in which he was stabbed in the right chest. On arrival his blood pressure and pulse were normal but he had reduced air entry on the right side of his chest. His oxygen saturation on room air was 90%. A chest radiograph showed a haemopneumothorax on the affected side.
What is the next most appropriate step in his management?

A. Masterly inactivity / watchful waiting
B. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation
C. Prescription of antibiotics
D. Insertion of a chest drain
E. Exploratory thoracotomy

Correct Answer: D

A 38-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with symptoms of mood changes eight days after giving birth. She says she does not want the child and tells the GP that it is dying. She feels like crying all day. She has auditory and visual hallucinations instructing her to harm herself. She is otherwise well with no other significant medical history.
What is the diagnosis for this patient?

A. Adjustment disorder
B. Anxiety disorder
C. Postnatal blues
D. Postpartum psychosis
E. Schizoid disorder

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department referred by her general practitioner. She gives a history of intermittent vaginal bleeding and vague abdominal pain, having undergone the menopause some years earlier. You examine her and notice a distended and painful abdomen. She admits on further questioning to having been anuric for the past two days.
Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 7.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 28.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 810 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Electrocardiogram (ECG): broad QRS complexes with tented T-waves
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

A. Intravenous (IV) calcium gluconate under ECG monitoring
B. Salbutamol nebuliser
C. IV fluid rehydration
D. Oral calcium resonium
E. IV insulin/dextrose

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old ex-athlete with chronic hypertension presents with bilateral knee pain that he has been experiencing for the past three years. He has been having this dull aching knee pain which worsens on activity. He has tried analgesics, physiotherapy and intra-articular corticosteroid injection but did not seem to benefit from them. He is currently unable to perform his daily activities and spends most of the day having knee pain.
On examination, range of movement for both knees was 0–20 degrees, limited due to pain. Crepitus and joint line tenderness were elicited.
A bilateral knee X-ray was taken. It showed loss of joint space in the knees with subchondral cysts formation in the right knee.
What is the best long-term intervention for this patient?

A. Analgesics
B. Bilateral knee replacement
C. Intra-articular hyaluronan injection
D. Continue physiotherapy
E. Weight loss

Correct Answer: B

You are alone walking in the countryside when a middle-aged man collapses in front of you. There is nobody else around. You look, listen and feel, ensuring his airway is open. He is not breathing and is non-responsive. You phone for an ambulance.
What is the next step that you would take while waiting for the ambulance to arrive?

A. Begin chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute, giving two rescue breaths after every 30 compressions
B. Go into the nearest house and get somebody to assist you with chest compressions while you administer mouth-to-mouth
C. Begin ventilation at a rate of ten breaths per minute using mouth-to-mouth
D. Move the man into the rescue position
E. Give two rescue breaths, then begin chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of irregular periods and hot flushes. She gets a few episodes in the day, but manages to sleep well during the night. She does not report any mood disturbance and is otherwise well.
This is her first presentation, and she does not want hormone replacement therapy (HRT) as she read in the newspaper that this increases the risk of endometrial cancer.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?

A. Advice on lifestyle changes and review if symptoms worsen
B. Commence citalopram and review in three months
C. Commence fluoxetine and review in two weeks
D. Recommend St John’s wort that can be bought over the counter
E. Refer for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman presents to the Eye Casualty with a painful reduction in vision in her left eye over the last five hours. She has no complaints of any other symptoms.
On examination, her visual acuity is 6/6 in the right eye and 6/36 in the left. Colour vision was reduced in the left eye. Eye movements showed no diplopia, but the pain gets worse. Performance of the swinging torch test reveals that the left pupil dilates when the torch light is swung from the right eye to the left.
A dilated fundoscopy shows normal optic discs in both eyes. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the head is performed and shows some white matter lesions in two different places in the brain. A lumbar puncture (LP) and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showed oligoclonal bands.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Giant-cell arteritis
B. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia
C. Multiple sclerosis
D. Myasthenia gravis
E. Post-viral demyelination

Correct Answer: C

A 20-year-old man is referred to the Cancer Clinic for treatment, following the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), with favourable cytogenetic profiling. He complains of tiredness, loss of weight, decreased appetite and easy bruising.
What would be the most appropriate management for remission induction?

A. Asparaginase, dexamethasone and vincristine
B. Cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin and vincristine
C. Daunorubicin and idarubicin
D. Daunorubicin plus cytarabine
E. Midostaurin

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman with Crohn’s disease presented with abdominal pain and foul-smelling stools. She was found to be anaemic, and serum vitamin B12 was found to be ‘very low’. Earlier, she had had an enterocolic fistula due to Crohn’s disease that was treated surgically. Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth was suspected and a hydrogen breath test was done.
Which of the following should be observed before doing this test?

A. Extra exercise levels in the week before the test
B. Ensure dietary gluten in the preceding 6 weeks
C. Avoid smoking
D. Avoid brushing your teeth with high fluoride toothpaste before the test
E. Take bronchodilators before the test

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old Caucasian woman presents with complaints of diarrhoea, steatorrhoea and weight loss. Investigations reveal anaemia and metabolic bone disease. Small intestine biopsy showed severe villous atrophy, more in the proximal segments. The patient was started on a gluten-free diet and responded well for 1 year. Then her symptoms recurred, despite being on a gluten-free diet, and repeat biopsy shows changes similar to the previous one.
Which one of the following conditions has to be suspected in this patient?

A. Tropical sprue
B. Dermatitis herpetiformis
C. Collagenous sprue
D. T-cell intestinal lymphoma
E. Refractory sprue

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department (ED) with severe abdominal pain following being kicked in the abdomen during a rugby match. She has a recent history of glandular fever and is on the contraceptive injection. On assessment, she is pale, hypotensive and tachycardic. A bedside ultrasound focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) scan in the ED reveals free fluid in the abdomen.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bowel perforation
B. Gastric ulcer perforation
C. Ovarian cyst rupture
D. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
E. Splenic rupture

Correct Answer: E

A 26-year-old man presents to his general practitioner, complaining of worsening back pain and stiffness over the last 4 months. He denies leg pain, loss of bladder and bowel control or lower extremity weakness. He says that the back stiffness improves over the course of the day. On examination, the patient has normal muscle strength in the lower extremity and intact sensation. He has mild tenderness directly over the lumbar spine. The patient has decreased range of motion with hip flexion. X-ray of the spine reveals sacroiliitis, vertebral squaring and a ‘bamboo spine’.
Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

A. Positive rheumatoid factor
B. Positive antinuclear antibody
C. Positive human leukocyte antigen HLA-B27
D. Positive antidouble stranded deoxyribonucleic (DNA) antibody
E. Positive anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibody

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old woman visits the Emergency Department with severe sharp pain in the left groin and chronic lower back pain after falling in her garden. She is unable to walk. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 30 kg/m2. Her pulse is 78 bpm and regular, blood pressure (BP) 130/70 mm Hg. Fracture of the left neck of the femur is identified on X-ray and treated.
Routine laboratory results are below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Serum calcium concentration 2 mmol/l 2.15 – 2.6 mmol/l
Serum phosphate concentration 0.52 mmol/l 0.8 – 1.4 mmol/l
Parathyroid hormone level 72 pg/ml 11 – 54 pg/ml
Urea 4 mmol/l 2.5 – 7.1 mmol/l
Creatinine 70 μmol/l 60 – 110 μmol/l
What is the next most appropriate investigation?

A. Serum 25-hydroxy vitamin D (25(OH)D) levels
B. Serum protein electrophoresis
C. Ultrasonogram (USG) neck to assess parathyroid adenoma
D. Urine Bence Jones protein
E. 24-hour urinary calcium

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old man comes to the Accident and Emergency (A&E) with a painful shoulder injury that he sustained while playing hockey. You examine him and find that there is an anterior dislocation of his left shoulder.
What test must you do before and after relocation of the shoulder?

A. Blood pressure
B. Examine the radial pulse in the affected arm
C. Ultrasound of the affected limb to look for soft tissue injuries
D. Examine radial nerve function in the affected arm
E. Examine axillary nerve function in the affected arm

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old woman presents to the Rheumatology Clinic for adjustment of her disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to treat her rheumatoid arthritis. She is told she will need to have regular eye checks due to the side-effects of these medications and regular liver checks.
What combination of treatment is she most likely to be receiving as management?

A. Etanercept plus prednisolone
B. Methotrexate plus etanercept
C. Methotrexate plus hydroxychloroquine
D. Methotrexate plus sulfasalazine
E. Sulfasalazine plus hydroxychloroquine

Correct Answer: C

You are a general practice trainee at a surgery in London. A 12-year-old girl attends the surgery and requests the ‘morning-after pill’ following sexual intercourse with her 18-year-old boyfriend. She appears mature for her age and you assess her as being Fraser-competent. She says that there was an accident on this occasion and, in future, she will ensure her and her boyfriend use contraception. She does not want you to discuss emergency contraception or her relationship with her parents.
What is the best course of action?

A. Issue the patient with a prescription for emergency contraception and schedule a follow-up appointment with her to discuss family planning and sexual health
B. Issue a prescription for emergency contraception and refer the patient to social services, as well as informing the designated doctor for child protection and the police
C. Contact the patient’s parents to obtain some background details and your proposed course of action before prescribing emergency contraception and scheduling a follow-up
D. Refer the patient to social services as well as informing the designated doctor for child protection and the police but do not prescribe emergency contraception before discussing the matter with her parents
E. Prescribe emergency contraception and report the matter to the police to let them take action against the patient’s boyfriend

Correct Answer: B

You review a 54-year-old man who has type II diabetes. He is taking metformin 2 g per day and his HbA1c is 62 mmol/mol. You consider adding sitagliptin to his regime.
Which of the following fits best with the mode of action of sitagliptin?

A. It leads to an increase in activity of dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP-IV)
B. It leads to reduced levels of glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1)
C. It is an inhibitor of DPP-IV
D. It is a PPAR-gamma agonist
E. It is a glucokinase activator

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old woman came to the Emergency Department, complaining of back pain. She suddenly developed severe pain in her back, while lifting a heavy object in her garden. She has a history of restrictive lung disease for which she is taking steroids. She has also a history of stroke.
On examination, there is tenderness over the lower vertebrae. Muscle power is normal, with normal reflexes. A dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan of the lumbar spine showed a T-score of −2.6.
Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?

A. Calcitonin
B. Alendronate
C. Hormone replacement therapy
D. Strontium ranelate
E. Normal saline

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man with a head injury is brought to the Emergency Department. He has a large scalp haematoma above his right ear. He is confused as to the nature of the trauma he received. An accompanying witness tells the doctor that the casualty was cycling in traffic and suffered from a blow to the side of the head from the side view mirror of a passing bus. He was knocked off his bicycle and was unconscious for a few minutes, but he made a seemingly uneventful recovery. Initial neurological assessment is unremarkable, but skull X-ray demonstrates a linear fracture extending across the pterion of the skull on the right. Over the next 4 hours, he develops increasing confusion and weakness in the left upper and lower limbs, and his right pupil becomes dilated and unresponsive to light.
What is the most likely site of his intracranial lesion?

A. Extradural haematoma
B. Subdural haematoma
C. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
D. Bleed into the cerebellum
E. Intramedullary haemorrhage

Correct Answer: A

A 92-year-old woman with known vascular dementia presents to the Emergency Department after a routine blood test uncovered that the patient had a sodium level of 149 mmol/l. Her carer comments that the patient’s fluid intake has been minimal over the past week. The patient’s past medical history includes a previous lacunar stroke and peripheral vascular disease. Her regular medications are atorvastatin, ramipril, amlodipine and clopidogrel. She currently is fully dependent on the assistance provided by carers. The patient’s National Early Warning (NEWS) score is 0, and her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 15.
A physical examination does not reveal any source of infection. A bedside capillary glucose is recorded as 5.8 mmol/mmol. A full set of blood tests are repeated, reported as follows:
Full blood count and urea and electrolytes (U&Es):
Investigations Results Normal Values
Haemoglobin (Hb) 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 91 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets (Plt) 215 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 148 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 3.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 66 mmol/l 50–120 mmol/l
A routine chest X-ray and urinalysis are performed and show no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most suitable to correct the patient’s hypernatraemia?

A. Hypertonic saline infusion
B. 500 ml of 10% dextrose
C. Standard dialysis
D. 500 ml of 0.9% saline
E. Oral water

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old woman with a background history of renal stones and osteoporosis is found to have the laboratory results listed below. Her most recent bone density showed a T score of -3.2 in the femur and -2.7 in the spine (Normal greater than <1). She has no other symptoms and does not take any medications. Physical examination is normal. Sestamibi Technetium (99mTc) and ultrasound scan reveal a right-sided parathyroid nodule.
Investigation Result Normal range
Calcium 2.9 mmol/l 2.20–2.6 mmol/l
Phosphate 0.6 mmol/l 0.7–1.5 mmol/l
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) 80 ng/l 15–60 ng/l
Creatinine 72 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
24-hour urinary calcium : creatinine 0.03 <0.02
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Admit to hospital for IV hydration
B. Bisphosphonate therapy
C. Cinacalcet
D. Vitamin D
E. Parathyroid surgery

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old man presents to his general practice surgery following a recent diagnosis of metastatic prostate cancer. He is suffering from pain throughout his body, despite taking morphine tablets 30 mg twice a day. On examination, his chest is clear, and he has no neurological deficits. He denies any headache.
Which of the following metastases is the most likely in this patient?

A. Brain
B. Bone
C. Pancreas
D. Lung
E. Liver

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after smoking large amounts of heroin. He is unconscious and has pinpoint pupils and signs of respiratory depression.
Which of the following antidotes is the most appropriate for this patient?

A. Naloxone
B. Vitamin K
C. Lithium
D. Flumazenil
E. N-acetylcysteine (NAC)

Correct Answer: A

A medical student is researching the role of oncogenes in the development of various types of malignancies after taking a history from a patient who has a tumour that is associated with an oncogene.
In which one of the following would a mutation produce an oncogene?

A. BRCA1
B. Immunoglobulin E (IgE)
C. p53
D. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
E. Human epidermal growth receptor 2 (HER2)

Correct Answer: E

A 3-year-old boy who was brought in to the Emergency Department crying and clutching his elbow. He had injured it while playing with his father. His father had been swinging him around by his arms when he started crying and complaining that his elbow hurt. He is holding his elbow in slight flexion and the forearm is pronated. There is no obvious deformity or swelling over the elbow, but there was localised pain and tenderness on the lateral aspect. Radiographs are normal and there are no obvious fractures.
Which of the following is the next best course of action?

A. Reassure the parents that there is no fracture and only simple analgesia and rest are required
B. Splinting and immobilisation of the elbow for 4 weeks
C. Organise a bone scan to look for any other injury to the bone
D. Perform a closed reduction of a suspected radial head subluxation
E. Book the child for elbow arthroscopy to look for any further injury

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman presents to her GP with hypertension. Basic blood tests are performed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 148 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 2.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 75 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/
Chloride (Cl–) 100 mEq/l 96–106 mEq/l
What is the next most appropriate investigation?

A. Aldosterone levels
B. Aldosterone-to-renin ratio
C. MR angiogram of renal arteries
D. CT angiogram of renal arteries
E. 24 h urine metanephrine levels

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old man is referred to a Rapid Access Neurology Service due to severe headache. He gives a history of recurrent rapid-onset severe right-sided headache and eye pain. It sometimes wakes him up at night. He claims the eye itself becomes watery and red during the periods of pain. He also claims that side of his face feels hot and painful during episodes. They normally last 60 minutes. However, he says they can be shorter or longer. There is no significant medical history. He is a smoker. He is pain-free during the consultation and examination is non-contributory.
Which of the following is most likely to be of value in relieving pain?

A. Verapamil
B. Diclofenac
C. Oxygen
D. High-dose prednisolone
E. Amitriptyline

Correct Answer: C

A 67-year-old man visits his general practitioner, complaining of lethargy and light-headedness whenever he gets up from the lying/sitting position. His relatives are concerned because he has developed a change in his facial features. Investigations included the following results:
Serum:
Na+ 127 mmol/l (135–145 mmol/l)
K+ 5.9 mmol/l (3.5–5 mmol/l)
Short adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test:
Plasma cortisol:
0900 h 145 nmol/l (140–690 nmol/l)
30 min after ACTH: 150 nmol/l
60 min after ACTH: 150 nmol/l
0900 h ACTH: 5 ng/l (normal <50 ng/l)
With which of the following are these results consistent with?

A. Adrenal metastases
B. Conn’s syndrome
C. Abrupt withdrawal of corticosteroid therapy
D. Hypopituitarism
E. Cushing’s disease

Correct Answer: C

You are an F1 on a busy surgical job. You were up most of the night due to diarrhoea and vomiting (D&V). You feel you have food poisoning but know your team is short and need to be at work.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Tell your Registrar you’re not well and go home
B. Ask HR to arrange cover for yourself then go home
C. Ignore your symptoms putting other patients at risk
D. Take some Imodium and hope symptoms resolve
E. Leave without telling anyone

Correct Answer: B

A middle-aged woman, who is a singer, has had previous thyroid surgery and now requires another procedure due to recurrent thyroid carcinoma. After the operation, she notes her voice has changed; she is unable to hit the high notes when she sings. On flexible laryngoscopy, she is noted to have a left vocal cord that fails to elongate during phonation.
Which nerve has most likely been damaged?

A. External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
B. Hypoglossal nerve
C. Ansa cervicalis nerve
D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
E. Lingual nerve

Correct Answer: A

A 37-year-old man, who is a known case of hypertension and gout, presents to you with an acutely inflamed big toe of the right foot. He is taking indomethacin and allopurinol for gout. The patient is not satisfied with this treatment and wants some other treatment for the control of arthritis. The patient is started on colchicine. His pain and swelling respond after three doses of colchicine.
Which one of the following is the mechanism of action of colchicine in gout?

A. Inhibiting phospholipase A2
B. Inhibiting cyclo-oxygenase
C. Decreasing the breakdown of purines
D. Inhibiting monosodium urate-induced activation of neutrophils
E. Suppressing the proliferation of lymphocytes

Correct Answer: D

Patients with several forms of cardiac diseases require pacemakers in order to keep their heart beating regularly and as a result, this keeps the patient alive. Below are examples of types of pacemaker, numbered 1–3:

AAI
VVI
DDD
Match each pacemaker to the condition in which it would most commonly be used to treat?

A. AAI – ventricular systolic dysfunction; VVI – atrial fibrillation (AF); DDD – long QT syndrome
B. AAI – sinus node dysfunction; VVI – AF; DDD – second-degree heart block
C. AAI – AF; VVI – sinus node dysfunction; DDD – first-degree heart block
D. AAI – long QT syndrome; VVI – sinus node dysfunction; DDD – second-degree heart block
E. AAI – second-degree heart block; VVI – AF; DDD – long QT syndrome

Correct Answer: B

A baby girl is born prematurely and is found to have her abdominal contents protruding from the abdominal cavity. The contents are lined by the peritoneum. Her mother declined all antenatal scans.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gastroschisis
B. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TOF)
C. Myelomeningocele
D. Meningocele
E. Omphalocele

Correct Answer: E

A 20-year-old woman (weighing 55 kg) presents for an emergency laparoscopic appendicectomy. She was given a cup of tea with milk and some dry toast 2 hours ago by nursing staff. She has been vomiting. You decide to perform a rapid sequence induction.
Which one of the following drug regimes would you choose?

A. Fentanyl 100 micrograms, thiopentone 275 mg, suxamethonium 100 mg
B. Propofol 110 mg, suxamethonium 100 mg
C. Propofol 110 mg, rocuronium 25 mg
D. Thiopentone 275 mg, suxamethonium 100 mg
E. Thiopentone 275 mg, rocuronium 50 mg

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman was admitted to the psychiatric ward with paranoid delusions, auditory hallucinations and violent behaviour. There was no past medical history. She was diagnosed with schizophrenia and given intramuscular haloperidol regularly. Four days later, she became febrile and confused. The haloperidol was stopped, but 2 days later, she developed marked rigidity, sweating and drowsiness. She had a variable blood pressure and pulse rate. Creatine phosphokinase was markedly raised.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cerebral abscess
B. Meningitis
C. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
D. Phaeochromocytoma
E. Serotonin syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old woman was seen in the Dermatology Outpatient Clinic with a chronic ulcer on her left forearm. On enquiry by the consultant, she revealed that she suffered full-thickness burn at the site of the ulcer nearly 25 years ago. The consultant told the patient she had a Marjolin’s ulcer.
Which of the following statements best describes a Marjolin’s ulcer?

A. It is a sarcoma which develops in a scar
B. It grows rapidly
C. It is usually associated with secondary deposits in the regional lymph nodes
D. It is often painless
E. It is due to localised areas of fat necrosis

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman had an acute haemolytic reaction after taking penicillin. She presented with bipedal oedema and blood tests revealed a haemoglobin level of 69 g/l. Her peripheral blood picture revealed:
Picture courtesy: Dr R Paul, MCH, Kolkata
What is the structure marked with the yellow arrow?

A. Heinz bodies
B. Lymphocyte
C. Nucleated RBC
D. Eosinophil
E. Monocyte

Correct Answer: C

A middle-aged man presents with a painless lump in the right posterior triangle of his neck. He has an excision biopsy performed under general anaesthetic. Following this, he is unable to shrug his right shoulder.
Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged during surgery?

A. Cervical plexus
B. Hypoglossal
C. Accessory
D. Vagus
E. Long thoracic nerve of Bell

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidaemia, hypertension and angina presents to the Emergency Department with crushing substernal chest pain radiating down his left arm. He is sweating profusely. The pain is not relieved by rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST segment elevation in leads II, III and avF.
What is the most common cause of death in the first hour after symptom onset?

A. Emboli from a left ventricular thrombus
B. Cardiac tamponade
C. Arrhythmia
D. Ruptured papillary muscle
E. Pericarditis

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old obese woman presents with a gradual onset of severe hirsutism and clitoral enlargement. Her voice is deepened, and she has recently noted abnormal vaginal bleeding. Her last menses was four years ago. Her medical history is remarkable for type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed at the age of 48. She is being treated with metformin and glibenclamide. Serum androstenedione and testosterone concentrations are elevated. Ultrasound shows bilaterally enlarged, solid-appearing ovaries without cyst. A simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is found on biopsy.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adrenal tumour
B. Sertoli–Leydig cell tumour
C. Polycystic ovary cyst
D. Ovarian stromal hyperthecosis
E. Theca lutein cyst

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old student presents to the University Health Service within only a few weeks of arrival at university. He complains of a very severe sore throat, so that he can hardly swallow, and of fevers and lethargy. On examination, he has severe exudative pharyngitis with regional lymphadenopathy. The general practitioner prescribes amoxicillin, but he returns after a few doses with a maculopapular rash.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 138 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 11.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 190 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 46 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Monospot +ve
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Urea 10.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 78 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 19 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Streptococcus pneumoniae
B. Epstein Barr Virus (EBV)
C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
D. Toxoplasmosis
E. Viral hepatitis

Correct Answer: B

You review a 30-year-old woman with a history of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. She has started a new relationship and wants some advice on the best method of contraception.
An ultrasound scan from six months ago showed three subserosal fibroids ranging in size from 1 to 2 cm in maximal dimension, without uterine distortion.
Her medical history includes migraines with aura, which are well controlled at present.
Which of the following is the best suited method of contraception for this patient?

A. Barrier methods
B. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
C. Intrauterine copper device
D. Levonorgestrel intrauterine system
E. Progesterone-only pill

Correct Answer: D

A 18-year-old patient presents with purpura on his back, buttocks and extensor surface of his lower limbs. He has dipstick haematuria.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Haemophilia A
B. Henoch–Schönlein purpura
C. Idiopathic thrombocytopaenic purpura
D. Leukaemia
E. Thalassaemia trait

Correct Answer: B

An 87-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department (ED) via ambulance with central crushing chest pain. An electrocardiogram (ECG) in the ambulance shows 3 mm ST elevation in the anterior leads consistent with a STEMI. His wife says he has a history of ischaemic heart disease and congestive cardiac failure. He has a cardiac arrest in the ED secondary to ventricular fibrillation. Despite resuscitation using advanced cardiac life support, he dies. His wife asks what will happen to his body.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this deceased patient?

A. Fill in the death certificate stating cause of death in part 1 as cardiac arrest
B. Fill in the death certificate stating cause of death in part 1 as old age
C. Fill in the death certificate stating that a condition that may have contributed to the death (part 2) was heart failure
D. Fill in the death certificate stating cause of death in part 1 as coma
E. Refer to the coroner

Correct Answer: E

A 10-year-old boy has a 4 cm-diameter patch of alopecia in the right parietal region with another smaller similar area nearby. The skin in the patch is scaly and the few remaining hairs seem to have broken off near the scalp surface. His mother has noticed that the area of alopecia is extending. There is no scaling of the left scalp and there is no rash elsewhere on his body.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alopecia areata
B. Discoid lupus erythematosus
C. Psoriasis
D. Tinea capitis
E. Trichotillomania

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents at 29 weeks’ gestation very concerned as she has not felt her baby move at all since the night before. She has a history of coeliac disease. No fetal movements can be palpated. An ultrasound scan confirms fetal death. Blood investigations were performed: thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 10.5 μu/l (0.17–3.2 μu/l) and free thyroxine (fT4) 4 pmol/l (11–22 pmol/l). These were not performed at booking.
According to the national antenatal screening programme, which of the following groups of patients should be screened for thyroid disorders in pregnancy?

A. Any family history of thyroid disease
B. History of chronic kidney disease
C. History of hypertension
D. Thalassaemia carrier
E. Type 1 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner six weeks after being diagnosed with generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). He has had a few sessions of cognitive behavioural therapy, but his symptoms are still significantly affecting his daily life. He asks you about starting medication for his anxiety.
Which of the following drug classes is the first-line treatment for GAD?

A. Benzodiazepine
B. Pregabalin
C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)
D. Selective serotonin–noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI)
E. Tricyclic antidepressant

Correct Answer: C

A 41-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with four months of difficulty swallowing both liquids and solid food. He also complains of regurgitation of undigested food and retrosternal chest pain when this happens. He no longer looks forward to his meals and thinks he may be starting to lose weight. He has no other medical problems. He has never smoked or drank alcohol and denies drug use. He presented two months ago with similar symptoms and a different GP treated the patient with a proton-pump inhibitor (PPI), which his symptoms did not respond to.
Physical examination is normal. A recent chest radiograph appears to be normal. His electrocardiogram (ECG) does not show any ischaemic changes.
His observations and blood tests results are shown below:
Temperature 36.9 °C
Blood pressure 125/59 mmHg
Heart rate 65 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 14 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 96% (room air)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Achalasia
B. Acute coronary syndrome
C. Diffuse oesophageal spasm
D. Oesophageal carcinoma
E. Pill-induced oesophagitis

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with crushing substernal chest pain that radiates to the jaw. His past medical history is significant for poorly controlled hypertension and a 10-year history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST elevation, and a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is made. The patient undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stenting, and then is discharged from the hospital.
Six weeks later, the patient experiences fever, leukocytosis and chest pain that is relieved by leaning forwards. There is diffuse ST elevation in multiple ECG leads, and a pericardial friction rub is heard on auscultation.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of the patient’s current symptoms?

A. Acute fibrinous pericarditis
B. Reinfarction
C. Dressler’s syndrome
D. Ventricular aneurysm
E. Infectious myocarditis

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old chronic smoker was diagnosed with lung cancer 6 months ago following a presentation with shortness of breath, weight loss and haemoptysis. He now re-presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a 3-week history of worsening nausea and lethargy. While waiting to see the doctor, he experiences a seizure. He has a history of hypertension. Investigation results are as follows:
Investigations Results Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 120 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Serum osmolality 250 mOsmol/kg 280–290 mOsmol/kg
Urine osmolality 1500 mOsmol/kg 50–1200 mOsmol/kg
Haematocrit 27%
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Central diabetes insipidus
B. Epilepsy
C. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
D. Psychogenic polydipsia
E. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic secretion (SIADH)

Correct Answer: E

A patient with leukaemia receives etoposide.
How does this drug act?

A. Alkylating agent
B. Antimetabolite
C. Microtubule inhibitor
D. Topoisomerase I inhibitor
E. Topoisomerase II inhibitor

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old female presents to the general practitioner (GP) with concerns that her facial features have changed dramatically over the past five years, which she noticed when she was looking at some old pictures. She also mentions that her old shoes no longer fit, and that she feels that her hands are bigger too. The GP suspects that she may have acromegaly, and the patient is referred to the Endocrinology Department for further assessment and management.
With regard to acromegaly, which of the following statements is correct?

A. All cases are the result of a secreting pituitary tumour
B. Acromegaly occurs as a result of growth hormone (GH) deficiency
C. There is an increased risk of colon cancer
D. An enlarged upper jaw is typical
E. Arthropathy occurs as a result of autoimmune destruction of the joint

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old university student visits the General Practitioner (GP), as she has found a lump in her left breast. She noticed the lump while she was showering. It is not tender, and there are no other associated symptoms.
She is fit and well, with no past medical history to note. There is no family history of breast cancer, but the patient is very concerned that she may have the condition.
On examination, a 1 cm × 1 cm well-defined mass can be felt in the lower right quadrant of the left breast. The lump is smooth to palpate and is very mobile.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Fat necrosis of the breast
B. Fibroadenoma
C. Carcinoma of the breast
D. Breast abscess
E. Duct ectasia

Correct Answer: B

You are observing the repair of an inguinal hernia for the first time. The consultant asks you what forms the roof of the inguinal canal.
What is the roof of the inguinal canal is formed by?

A. The aponeurosis of the medial oblique
B. The lacunar ligament
C. The reflected inguinal ligament
D. The union of the transversalis fascia with the inguinal ligament
E. The arched fibres of internal oblique and transversus abdominis

Correct Answer: E

A 12-year-old boy presents with generalised itch for the past three days to his General Practitioner (GP). He reports it is keeping him awake at night. The GP notices linear burrows on the hands and finds evidence of excoriation throughout his abdomen and limbs. The GP suspects scabies as the cause.
Which of these is the first–line treatment for non-crusted scabies?

A. Clotrimazole 2% cream
B. Fusidic acid cream
C. Hydrocortisone 1% ointment
D. Oral flucloxacillin
E. Permethrin 5% cream

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old woman is being worked up for treatment-resistant hypertension. She has a past history of medullary thyroid carcinoma. Examination is non-contributory. As part of her work-up, hypercalcaemia of 2.8 mmol/l is found. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is slightly higher than the normal range.
What is the underlying condition?

A. Marfan’s syndrome
B. Multiple myeloma
C. Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1
D. Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A
E. Neurofibromatosis

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) with several months of difficulty swallowing both liquids and solid foods. He states he also often regurgitates undigested food. He no longer looks forward to his meals and is beginning to lose weight. He denies chest pain.
Physical examination is normal. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and chest X-ray are also normal. Blood tests reveal normal inflammatory markers and normal renal function. He has had a trial of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy, without relief of his symptoms. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed by the Gastroenterology team, which is also normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?

A. Amylase
B. Barium swallow
C. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest
D. Lateral cervical spine manometry
E. Oesophageal manometry

Correct Answer: E

A 20-year-old man fractured his hand during a street fight and was taken to the Emergency Department where X-rays were taken. A radiologist examined the films and observed a single fracture of the carpal bone that articulates with the majority of the base of the third metacarpal bone.
Which of the following bones was most likely fractured?

A. Trapezium
B. Pisiform
C. Hamate
D. Triquetrum
E. Capitate

Correct Answer: E

An 82-year-old patient is admitted with dysuria and confusion. She is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection (UTI) and treated with ciprofloxacin. After 3 days, she develops a profuse offensive diarrhoea. Her pulse is 82 bpm, blood pressure 140/78 mmHg and temperature 37.4 °C. Her abdomen is mildly tender throughout, but no guarding. Bloods show a white cell count of 28.7 × 109/l (was 11.6).
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A. Ulcerative colitis
B. Pyelonephritis
C. Clostridium difficile diarrhoea
D. Quinolone-resistant UTI
E. Overflow diarrhoea

Correct Answer: C

A surgeon prepares to excise the submandibular gland for a suspected malignancy. He incises the skin and the platysma in the neck below the gland, then proceeds to dissect the gland free of its bed. As he dissects the deep lobe, he notes the submandibular duct, which he mobilises, ligates and cuts anteriorly.
When cutting the duct, which of the following needs the most care to be taken to avoid damage?

A. The facial artery
B. The facial vein
C. The mandibular branch of the facial nerve
D. The lingual nerve
E. The lesser petrosal branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman presents with new-onset diabetes. She has no past drug or treatment history. Her fasting blood glucose is 7.3 mmol/l. Other significant medical history included occasional diarrhoea in the last 4 months, for which she took repeated courses of tinidazole. She also had an episode of severe leg pain three months ago, for which she takes warfarin. She is presently very depressed, as her brother has had renal calculus surgery, which has not gone well; he is in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with sepsis.
What is the most appropriate next test?

A. Colonoscopy
B. Genetic study
C. C-peptide assay
D. Blood test for Giardia antigen
E. Protein C assessment

Correct Answer: B

A patient attends the Emergency Department following a fall. She is 87 and lives alone. On arrival, she is stable, with no evidence of significant injury. Her lungs are clear, there is no sign of pedal oedema and she appears well hydrated. You are happy she has come to no harm from the fall. She reports that she has been getting more unsteady over the past few weeks. Routine blood tests reveal the following:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 111 g/dl 115–155 g/dl
White cell count (WCC) 4.7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 171 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 119 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 125 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
What may be the cause of her biochemical abnormality?

A. Citalopram
B. Congestive heart failure (CHF)
C. Dehydration
D. Lithium
E. Hyperaldosteronism

Correct Answer: A

A 16-year-old Scottish resident presents to your Scottish Emergency Department with a 12-hour history of acute right-sided abdominal pain. On examination, she has acute appendicitis. She is keen to proceed with the recommended surgery. You are unable to contact a parent or any other contact given by the patient.
What do you need in order to proceed?

A. A court order; the patient is not able to consent, and it is not possible to contact a responsible person
B. An assessment of competence. A 16-year old may have competence to consent to treatment
C. A social worker; social workers have the power to consent on behalf of a minor
D. Nothing; it is in the best interests of the person to have the surgery performed
E. Nothing; in Scotland, a 16-year-old person is deemed capable of consenting to treatment

Correct Answer: E

A middle-aged man is brought to the Emergency Department (ED), after being found unconscious in the town centre by members of the police. He is poorly kept, and a police handover reports that he has no fixed abode. He is well known to various members of ED. On arrival in ED, he is still unconscious. His airway is patent; he is saturating at 94% on room air, with a respiratory rate of 10 breaths/min. He is haemodynamically stable, with a temperature of 35.6 °C and small, constricted pupils. There appears to be an area of minor external bleeding and a scalp haematoma on the back of his head.
What is the most appropriate initial course of action?

A. Computed tomography (CT) head
B. Neurosurgical referral
C. Flumazenil 200 μg intravenously (IV)
D. Naloxone 400 μg intramuscularly (IM)
E. 15 litres of high-flow oxygen, non-rebreathe mask

Correct Answer: D

A medical student faints in the dissection room, falling straight backwards and hitting her head hard on the floor. She admits that she had no breakfast prior to attending dissection, and a well-meaning technician gives her a piece of chocolate. She complains that the chocolate tastes funny and vomits afterwards. Formal neurological assessment reveals anosmia, and computerised tomography (CT) of the head and neck reveals an anterior base of skull fracture affecting the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.
What is the level of interruption to the olfactory pathway likely to be?

A. The first-order sensory neurones
B. The second-order sensory neurones
C. The olfactory bulb
D. The olfactory tract
E. The piriform cortex of the frontal lobe

Correct Answer: A

A 17-year-old with a known peanut allergy presents to the Emergency Department after eating a protein bar that contains peanuts. On examination, she is showing signs of anaphylaxis.
Which of the following signs is most likely to present first in a patient with anaphylaxis?

A. Syncope
B. Hypotension
C. Stridor
D. Weak pulse
E. Runny nose, skin rash, swelling of the lips

Correct Answer: E

A 37-year-old man was in hospital for a routine appendectomy and was sedated and intubated for general anaesthesia, for which succinylcholine and halothane were used. One hour after the start of surgery, the anaesthetist noticed the patient’s temperature was 41 °C; blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg; pulse was 110 bpm.
Arterial blood gas (ABG) showed:
PaCO2 of 6.6 kPa (normal value <4.5 kPa)
pH of 7.2 (normal value 7.35–7.45)
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
B. Serotonin syndrome
C. Malignant hyperthermia
D. Acute dystonia
E. Meningitis

Correct Answer: C

During the post-take ward round, the consultant asks you to comment on the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the spine of the patient you are about to review, a 40-year-old male.
Which of the following symptoms is the patient most likely to experience?

A. Numbness in the saddle area and difficulty in micturition / incontinence
B. Pain and altered sensation in anterior thigh
C. Weakness of hip flexion
D. Exaggerated dorsiflexion of the ankle joint
E. Knee extension will be affected

Correct Answer: A

A boy has been referred because of bizarre behaviour at school. His teachers have reported that he alternates between very passive and very aggressive behaviours. At times, he cries and withdraws from sight when he thinks he is being slighted in some manner. At other times, he yells wildly and fights over the smallest of infractions. Upon further examination, you discover that the patient has been the victim of significant abuse at home.
Which one of the following defence mechanisms is he likely employing?

A. Identification
B. Dissociation
C. Sublimation
D. Reaction formation
E. Splitting

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man presents with severe headache, right periorbital pain and fever. He has a large infected lesion on his face beside his right nostril, which he confesses arose due to manipulation of an acne lesion. On clinical examination, he has right periorbital oedema. The examining physician suspects cavernous venous sinus thrombosis (CST).
Which of the following is a feature of CST?

A. Paralysis of the orbicularis oculi on the affected side
B. Third nerve palsy is the most common nerve paralysis
C. The most common infective agent is Staphylococcus epidermidis
D. Symptoms such as chemosis and ptosis are uncommon
E. Visual disturbance

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent dysphagia that has been worsening over the last year. During the episodes of dysphagia, she develops severe retrosternal chest pain. She has more difficulty swallowing liquids than solids.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Oesophageal dysmotility
B. Oesophageal cancer
C. Pharyngeal pouch
D. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)
E. Benign oesophageal stricture

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old type 2 diabetic who presents with an ulcerated lesion on his lower leg. You are unsure what type of ulcer it is.
Which of the following features is most commonly associated with a neuropathic ulcer, as opposed to an arterial ulcer?

A. Absent pulses
B. Loss of hair on the leg
C. Occurring in the mid-tibial area
D. Painful
E. Painless

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old man presents with haemoptysis over the last 2 days. He has had a productive cough for 7 years, which has gradually worsened. Over the last few winters, he has been particularly bad and required admission to hospital. Past medical history includes pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) at age 20. On examination, he is cyanotic and clubbed, and has florid crepitations in both lower zones.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asthma
B. Pulmonary fibrosis
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Lung cancer
E. Bronchiectasis

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old man in the United Kingdom presents with fever and cough. He smells strongly of alcohol and has no fixed abode. His heart rate was 123 bpm, blood pressure 93/75 mmHg, oxygen saturations 92% and respiratory rate 45 breaths per minute. Further history from him reveals no recent travel history and no contact with anyone with a history of foreign travel.
Chest X-ray revealed consolidation of the right upper zone.
Which of the following drugs is the most prudent choice in his treatment?

A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol
B. Co-trimoxazole
C. Phenoxymethylpenicillin
D. Meropenem
E. Azithromycin

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) feeling ‘run down’. She reports worsening fatigue and lethargy over the past few months. Her appetite is poor, but she is gaining weight, and she is going several days without opening her bowels. On examination, her skin is dry and cold. She has a painless midline neck swelling, which feels irregular and rubbery. The GP sends blood tests to investigate the cause of the patient’s symptoms.
What would you expect to see on the thyroid function tests?

A. TSH: high; free T4: low; free T3: low
B. TSH: low; free T4: low; free T3: low
C. TSH: low; free T4: high; free T3: high
D. TSH: high; free T4: normal; free T3: normal
E. TSH: low; free T4: normal; free T3: normal

Correct Answer: A

A 3-year-old boy is brought in by ambulance after his parents awoke in the middle of the night to a harsh coughing episode and noted he had difficulty breathing. He has been coryzal over the last 2 days but has never had any episodes like this before. The paramedics have given a salbutamol nebuliser, to some effect, but he continues to have very noisy breathing. Oxygen saturations are 94% on air, with a respiratory rate of 50.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Viral-induced wheeze
B. Croup
C. Asthma
D. Inhaled foreign body
E. Acute epiglottitis

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old military man presents with fever for 3 weeks, associated with fatigue, malaise, night sweats and unintentional weight loss of 5 lb. He also has a cough productive of greenish-yellow sputum with occasional blood streaks in it. His appetite is diminished. He denies chills, sore throat, rhinorrhoea, headache, dysuria or a change in bowel habit, skin rash and itching.
Three months ago, he was out of the country, but he cannot disclose additional information. He denies any previous similar episodes and does not recall recent contact with anyone ill. Past medical history is unremarkable. He has been taking over-the-counter medications for fever and cough, without any improvement. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks alcohol only on weekends. He is in a polygamous relationship. He rarely uses condoms.
On examination, he is alert and oriented. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Heart sounds are normal with no heart murmur, rub or gallop. Coarse crackles and rhonchi are noted over the middle lobe of the right lung. The left lung is clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. A purified protein derivative (PPD) skin test is placed, and a chest X-ray is ordered. A sputum sample is sent for culture, Gram stain and acid-fast staining.
What is the most likely mechanism underlying his manifestations?

A. Suppurative necrosis
B. Irreversible bronchial dilatation
C. Hypersensitivity reaction
D. Neutrophilic infiltration
E. Airway hyper-reactivity

Correct Answer: C

A 75-year-old woman has been diagnosed with a malignant lesion in the medial part of her right breast.
To which one of the following lymph node groups is this site most likely to drain?

A. Coeliac
B. Infraclavicular
C. Internal thoracic
D. Supraclavicular
E. Tracheobronchial

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old man of African origin has acute onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a dilated gall bladder with a thickened wall filled with calculi. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed. Post-operatively, the gall bladder was opened to reveal the presence of several multifaceted, 0.5- to 1-cm diameter, dark, greenish-black gallstones.
Which of the following underlying conditions is responsible for gallstone formation in this patient?

A. Hypercholesterolaemia
B. Sickle-cell anaemia
C. Crohn’s disease
D. Hyperparathyroidism
E. Primary biliary cholangitis

Correct Answer: B

A patient is transferred from a District General Hospital to the Burns and Trauma Centre. He arrives intubated. The history is that he was on some scaffolding holding a pole, which he touched onto an overhead powerline, causing electrocution. He fell backwards and was found to be in ventricular fibrillation (VF) arrest by paramedics, who resuscitated him with defibrillation. He has small burns on his hands and also his left foot. On arrival at the Trauma Centre, he has a full CT traumagram which showed no other injuries. His C-spine has been radiologically cleared. You are examining him, and you notice he has a swollen, tight left leg. The nurse brings you his blood gas, and you see he has a potassium level of 6.3 and he has mild metabolic acidaemia, with a pH of 7.21. His urine is tea-coloured (catheter in situ), with a creatine kinase (CK) level of 1232.
What is the best course of action?

A. Anticoagulate in case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
B. X-ray his left leg to check for a fracture
C. Perform fasciotomies on his left leg
D. Treat the potassium and check CK as he may have rhabdomyolysis
E. Elevate the limb and debride the burns

Correct Answer: C

A student is performing a dissection of the intracranial contents. She removes the cranial cap and meninges, mobilises the brain and cuts the spinal cord just below the foramen magnum to remove the brain from the cranial cavity. On inspection of the brainstem, she notes that there are a number of nerves emerging from the brainstem.
Which of the following is true of the emergence of the cranial nerves?

A. The trochlear nerve emerges from the anterior midbrain between the crura cerebri
B. The abducens nerve emerges from the posterior midbrain
C. The trigeminal nerve emerges from the pons close to its junction with the middle cerebellar peduncle
D. The hypoglossal nerve emerges behind the olivary nucleus of the medulla
E. The vagus nerve emerges between the pyramid and the olive of the medulla

Correct Answer: C

A patient with idiopathic pericarditis becomes increasingly unwell, with hypotension, jugular venous distension and muffled heart sounds on auscultation. Echocardiogram confirms a pericardial effusion.
At which of the following sites does this effusion occur?
