A. Between the visceral pericardium and the myocardium
B. Between the visceral pericardium and the parietal pericardium
C. Between the parietal pericardium and the fibrous pericardium
D. Between the fibrous pericardium and the mediastinal pleura
E. Between the fibrous pericardium and the central tendon of the diaphragm

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old woman, who is 15 weeks’ pregnant, attends the Emergency Department.
She is worried as she has spent some time babysitting her friend’s child, who has just been diagnosed with chickenpox. She is concerned regarding the possible impact on her pregnancy. She believes she may have had chickenpox as a child and is otherwise well.
On examination, there is no rash.
What is the most appropriate next step to manage this patient’s concerns?

A. Check varicella zoster immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies
B. Intravenous (IV) aciclovir
C. Oral aciclovir
D. Reassurance
E. Treat with varicella zoster immunoglobulin

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with patches of hypopigmented skin over both hands.
The lesions are well demarcated, flat and non-tender. She has a past medical history of hypothyroidism, for which she receives levothyroxine. She is finding the condition distressing, as people have been commenting at work.
Given the likely diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate initial treatment?

A. Camouflage make-up
B. No treatment required
C. Phototherapy
D. Topical corticosteroid
E. Topical tacrolimus

Correct Answer: D

Growth hormone (GH) is synthesised by anterior pituitary cells named as somatotrophs and stored in large amounts in the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis). GH is necessary for normal growth of the individual.
Which of the following statements accurately describes GH?

A. It is secreted continuously
B. Synthesis is stimulated by the action of somatostatin
C. Receptors have a limited distribution outside the central nervous system (CNS)
D. It stimulates cartilage and bone growth via somatomedin C
E. It has a proinsulin-like effect in addition to its other actions

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old man presents with generalised acute abdominal pain, with tenderness and rebound tenderness on examination.
Which of the following imaging investigations would be most sensitive for detecting pneumoperitoneum?

A. Supine abdominal radiograph
B. Erect abdominal radiograph
C. Erect chest radiograph
D. Supine chest radiograph
E. Lateral decubitus abdominal radiograph

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old man has been seen by his general practitioner (GP) with symptoms of moderate anxiety, including frequent panic attacks, feeling very tired all the time, poor appetite and a short temper. He is taking time off work, arguing with his family and friends and becoming increasingly isolated as a result of the symptoms. He has tried cognitive behavioural therapy but found no benefit. He would like to try medication, and the GP has agreed to start citalopram.
Which of the following should he be advised before starting the medication?

A. He will feel a significant improvement in his symptoms after one week of taking the medication
B. He will need to be seen every three months once he has started the medication for a review
C. There is a risk he will develop discontinuation symptoms if he abruptly stops taking the medication
D. The only side-effect he needs to be aware of is dyspepsia
E. There is an increased risk of suicidal thinking and self-harm for everyone starting a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with central crushing chest pain radiating to his arm and jaw. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST elevation in leads II, III and aVF, with reciprocal changes in I and aVL.
Which one of the following vessels is likely to be blocked?

A. Left circumflex artery
B. Left coronary artery
C. Right coronary artery
D. Posterior descending artery
E. Left anterior descending artery

Correct Answer: C

A lady brings her elderly husband to see you. She is concerned about his recent forgetfulness. She also discloses that he has been seeing things such as small children playing in the house. There is nil to note on examination, except for a mild resting tremor in the hands (right > left).
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alzheimer’s disease
B. Korsakoff’s dementia
C. Lewy body dementia
D. Multi-infarct dementia
E. Pick’s disease

Correct Answer: C

A radiologist viewing a routine chest X-ray in a 45-year-old man is surprised to see calcification of a valve orifice at the upper left sternum at the level of the third costal cartilage.
Which valve is this likely to represent?

A. The aortic valve
B. The mitral valve
C. The valve of the coronary sinus
D. The tricuspid valve
E. The pulmonary valve

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old teacher complains of lethargy and generalised aches and pains, especially in the shoulders and hands. She has been on sick leave from school for the past 4 months. The General Practitioner letter indicates a history of irritable bowel syndrome. She also states that he tried a short course of steroids and anti-inflammatory medication, with no effect. On examination: multiple tender points in various muscle groups. No discernible joint disease.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Polymyalgia
B. Polymyositis
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Fibromyalgia
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old woman with Crohn’s disease has a terminal ileal resection.
Which of the following is she at most risk of?

A. Microcytic hypochromic anaemia
B. Macrocytic normochromic anaemia
C. Osteomalacia
D. Angular stomatitis
E. Wernicke’s encephalopathy

Correct Answer: B

A 3-year-old boy is brought in by ambulance. His parents explain that he has had cold symptoms for the last 24 hours but is generally well. They describe him walking towards them in the park when he suddenly went floppy and all four limbs started shaking. This lasted for around 1 minute, during which time he did not respond to his name and his eyes were rolled back. He remained drowsy for the next 30 minutes or so in the ambulance but is now well, alert and active, moving all limbs normally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Reflex anoxic seizure
B. Meningitis
C. Epilepsy
D. Febrile convulsion
E. Hypoglycaemia

Correct Answer: D

You are with the on-call anaesthetist who is asked to assist with a distressed patient who has just walked into the Emergency Department. The anaesthetist is in the middle of an epidural but sends you down to see what is going on. The patient has been stung by a wasp while running, and his arm has become very swollen and red. He kept running, but within a few minutes he began feeling light-headed and experienced difficulty breathing. The nurses are getting some monitoring set up. He looks flushed and has stridor and tachypnoea. His first blood pressure is 76/40 mmHg and he is tachycardic at 150 bpm.
What is the best initial treatment?

A. Intravenous (IV) adrenaline 50 mg
B. 500 micrograms intramuscular (IM) 1 : 1000 adrenaline
C. Emergency intubation
D. Nebulised adrenaline
E. 500 mg im ephedrine

Correct Answer: B

A 66-year-old man with lung cancer arrives in the Emergency Department with shortness of breath and chest pain. He has no cough or sputum production. On auscultation, his chest sounds clear. His pulse is 110 bpm and irregularly irregular; his oxygen saturation is 86% on room air; his respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute.
Which investigation is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?

A. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
B. Computerised tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)
C. D-dimer test
D. Arterial blood gas (ABG)
E. Bronchoscopy

Correct Answer: B

An 86-year-old man is brought unconscious to the Emergency Department by the paramedics. His daughter reported that her father had been having slurred speech since he woke up and that he had fallen out of bed 2 days previously. Upon radiological examination, it was determined that the patient suffered from a subdural haematoma.
If untreated, which of the following will most likely be a complication?

A. Axonal tearing
B. Recurrent haemorrhage
C. Epidural haemorrhage
D. Berry aneurysm
E. Subarachnoid haemorrhage

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old woman attends with a history of oligomenorrhoea and menstrual irregularity (menses every 35–45 days). She has a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m2 and has had persistent acne since being a teenager.
On examination, there are brown, hyperpigmented areas in the creases of the axillae and around the neck.
Hormone levels have been performed, as shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Total testosterone 7 nmol/l 0.5–3.5 nmol/l
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) 15 IU/l 1–25 IU/l
Luteinising hormone (LH) 78 U/l 1–70 U/l
Which of the following ultrasound findings will confirm the diagnosis?

A. A single multilocular cyst in the right ovary, measuring 5 cm in maximal dimension
B. Ovarian volume of 5 ml
C. Five follicles per ovary, ranging in size from 2 to 9 mm
D. 12 follicles in the right ovary and seven follicles in the left, ranging in size from 2 to 9 mm
E. 12 follicles per ovary, each 1 mm in size

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old teaching assistant presents with a lump that she found in her right breast. She carried out a breast check after watching a programme about breast cancer and was concerned to find a lump in the right breast.
The lump is not tender, and she has no other associated symptoms. She has no family history of breast cancer.
On examination, there is a smooth 2 cm × 2 cm lump in the upper quadrant of the right breast. There are no overlying skin changes.
What would be the most appropriate management of this patient?

A. Reassurance and discharge
B. Review for reassessment in three months
C. Arrange excision of the lump
D. Refer to the Breast Clinic for further investigation
E. Ask the patient to return if she becomes symptomatic

Correct Answer: D

The ward nurses call you to come and see an adult female patient who is 24 h post-gastrointestinal surgery (hemicolectomy). The latest blood results are given below, along with the normal range:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 16 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 140 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Haemoglobin 140 g/l
Males: 135–175 g/l
Females: 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9 × 109/l 4–10 × 109/l
From these results, what is the single most likely diagnosis of the patient?

A. Post-operative nausea and vomiting
B. Bacterial diarrhoea
C. Intraoperative blood loss
D. Post-renal acute kidney injury
E. Over-treatment with intravenous fluids

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old woman with three children presents to the Gynaecology Clinic, having been referred by her general practitioner. Having completed her family and discussed her options with her husband, she has decided that she would like to be sterilised to avoid the risk of further pregnancy. During her visit, she enquires about the possible risks associated with a tubal ligation procedure.
Which of the following is a well-recognised possible outcome of tubal ligation?

A. Sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
B. Weight gain
C. Depression
D. Ectopic pregnancy
E. Increased abdominal cramps during menstruation

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue. He notices that he can hardly keep his eyes open during late afternoon, and his workmates have complained that when he presents at work, he seems to lose the thread, his voice dropping and becoming almost inaudible during his talk. His head drops towards the end of the day and he has trouble climbing the stairs at home. There is no muscle wasting or fasciculation; tone, sensation and reflexes are normal. His body mass index is 25 and his blood pressure is 142/72 mmHg.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 132 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 293 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 135 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Given the suspected diagnosis, which of the following is most likely to be positive?

A. Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA)
B. Anti-smooth muscle antibodies
C. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies
D. Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies
E. Rheumatoid factor

Correct Answer: D

An 81-year-old woman is seen in the Emergency Department after a ‘blackout’ while out shopping. On examination, she is now fully alert and orientated and looks well.

Apyrexial, CBG = 5.8 mmol/l
CV– HR 90–110 irregular, low volume
BP – 145/120 mmHg lying = standing
JVP – raised +5 cm
Apex beat – displaced to the mid-axillary line, diffuse
Heart sounds: 1 + S2 + loud pan-systolic murmur loudest at the apex, radiating to the axilla and at the lower left sternal edge. There is also a mid-diastolic rumble best heard at the apex
Chest – occasional bibasal crackles – clear with coughing
Mild peripheral oedema to the mid-calf

Given this presentation and the clinical findings, what is the most likely cause of her collapse?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Mixed aortic valve disease
C. Mixed mitral valve disease
D. Mitral stenosis
E. Mitral regurgitation

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old male patient presents with severe headache and pyrexia. He has no visible rash on examination. Lumbar puncture shows: protein 1.0 g/l, glucose 2.1 mmol/l (serum glucose 6 mmol/l), white cell count (WCC) 160/mm3, 90% polymorphs. Gram stain shows Gram-negative diplococci.
Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A. Pneumococci
B. Meningococci
C. Listeria species
D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
E. Haemophilus influenzae

Correct Answer: B

A 48-year-old man is referred to a neurologist by the general practitioner (GP) due to recent concerns with his speech. He has recently found it much harder to verbalise his thoughts and is finding this particularly frustrating. Despite this, there is no evidence to suggest a reduced comprehension of speech.
He struggles to repeat sentences and also struggles to repeat well-rehearsed lists (months of the year, numbers from one to ten). He is unable to name several common household objects presented to him. He also uses the incorrect tense when constructing his sentences and his general grammar is poor.
Imaging studies demonstrate the problem is located in the frontotemporal region of the brain.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Broca’s aphasia
B. Wernicke’s aphasia
C. Progressive non-fluent aphasia (PNFA)
D. Semantic dementia
E. Conductive (associative) dysphasia

Correct Answer: C

A baby appears normal at birth and is given to her mother for her first feed shortly thereafter. While feeding, she develops respiratory distress with choking and regurgitates much of the milk through her nose and mouth. The midwife halts the feed and asks for medical review.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Annular pancreas
B. Infantile pyloric stenosis
C. Duodenal atresia
D. Midgut malrotation with volvulus
E. Oesophageal atresia

Correct Answer: E

You are interested in determining whether seatbelt use has an impact on the severity of injuries incurred following a motor vehicle accident. You approach a doctor in the Emergency Department, and he suggests you design a study.
Which of the following study designs would be most appropriate?

A. Cohort study
B. Cross-sectional study
C. Randomised controlled trial
D. Case-control study
E. Case series

Correct Answer: D

You are an FY1 in a busy A&E department. In your haste to finish all the jobs in time, you attain a needle stick injury while taking blood samples from a patient. The patient is known as an IV drug user.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Report to the Occupational Health Department immediately
B. Run the injury under a cold tap and allow it to bleed
C. Confront the patient and demand to know what diseases he has
D. Go through the patients notes to find out his history in more detail
E. Leave work and go home

Correct Answer: B

An 87-year-old is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance following a fall at home. She has right-hip pain and limited range of movement in the right hip. On plain X-ray (AP lateral view), there is no obvious fracture of the right hip or pelvis. The patient is unable to weight-bear and is still in significant pain.
Which of the following is the gold-standard investigation for a suspected occult fracture?

A. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
B. Hip ultrasound scan
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
D. Positron-emission tomography (PET) scan
E. X-ray hip lateral view

Correct Answer: C

An 80-year-old woman with early-stage dementia is brought to see the General Practitioner (GP) by her son to discuss appointing a Lasting Power of Attorney.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding the Mental Capacity Act (MCA)?

A. All patients with severe learning disability or a brain injury can be assumed to lack capacity
B. Applies to people aged 18 years and over only
C. If a person lacks capacity to make a decision, the Act states that a decision should be made that is in their best interests
D. Relatives who have not been appointed as a Lasting Power of Attorney do not have a role in decision-making for people who lack capacity
E. There are four statutory principles in the MCA

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old male patient presents with dyspepsia of 4 weeks’ duration. Other than a 20-pack year history of smoking, he has no other medical history and reports no prescribed or over-the-counter medications. Endoscopy reveals features of gastritis and a solitary gastric ulcer in the pyloric antrum. A rapid urease test turned red, revealing a positive result.
What would be a suitable treatment for this patient?

A. Fluconazole
B. Omeprazole
C. Amoxicillin, clarithromycin and omeprazole
D. Prednisolone and azathioprine
E. Quinine and clindamycin

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a high-speed car accident. He is unconscious and barely responds to painful stimuli. He is intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. A chest X-ray shows fractures of multiple ribs and the sternum. His electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal. After two days, he remains unconscious with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 7. The heart rate is 80 bpm. Blood pressure is maintained at a normal level. Central venous pressure is also normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Further tests reveal a mildly elevated potassium, normal serum sodium, normal urea and creatinine and elevated serum troponin I concentration. The ECG shows a new right bundle branch block.
This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?

A. Pulmonary contusion
B. Pulmonary embolism
C. Adrenal ischaemia
D. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
E. Myocardial contusion

Correct Answer: E

A 4-year-old child presents to the Emergency Department (ED) having run into a door, while running around playing with his older brother. He started crying and screaming and then went to sleep about 1 hour later; after waking, he vomited twice. On examination, he has a swelling of 3 cm ´ 4 cm on his forehead. Central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral nervous system (PNS) examination is broadly normal, as are his eyes. His cervical spine is also normal. He then vomits again in the examination room.
What is the best course of action?

A. Do a CT brain scan within 1 hour to rule out an intracranial haemorrhage
B. Do a CT brain scan within 8 hours to rule out an intracranial haemorrhage
C. Observe him closely for at least 4 hours (after the injury)
D. Discharge him now
E. Speak to social services as there may be a child protection issue

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman from India presents to the general practice surgery, complaining of weakness and exhaustion after doing several chores around the house. The doctor notices periodic involuntary spasms of her left arm and several nodules under the skin. She immediately asks the patient whether she suffered from any illnesses as a child. The patient revealed that she had a severe throat infection in India as a child but was never treated for it.
Which of the following is more common and will most likely be revealed by auscultation of the heart?

A. A continuous machine-like murmur that is loudest at S2
B. A late systolic crescendo murmur with a mid-systolic click
C. A high-pitched ‘blowing’ diastolic decrescendo murmur
D. A crescendo–decrescendo systolic ejection murmur following an ejection click
E. An opening snap after S2, followed by a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old patient presents with double vision on looking to the right. On examination, there is impairment of abduction of the right eye when looking to the right. Otherwise eye movements are normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Right third cranial nerve palsy
B. Right sixth cranial nerve palsy
C. Left sixth cranial nerve palsy
D. Right fourth cranial nerve palsy
E. Left fourth cranial nerve palsy

Correct Answer: B

A 75-year-old man comes to clinic complaining of 8/10 back pain that started suddenly when he reached for his tea cup this morning. Upon questioning, you learn that he has been constipated for the past 6 months. His wife states that he has ‘just not been himself’ and he no longer enjoys taking the dog for a walk or playing with his grandchildren. Below is an X-ray of his skull.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Major depression with somatisation
B. Osteoporosis
C. Multiple myeloma
D. Paget's disease
E. Hyperparathyroidism

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old woman has had >10 very short relationships in the past year, all of which she thought were the love of her life. She is prone to impulsive behaviour such as gambling and binge eating, and she has dabbled in drugs. She also engages in self-harm.
Which of the following personality disorders most accurately describes her?

A. Borderline (or emotionally unstable) personality disorder
B. Histrionic personality disorder
C. Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder
D. Paranoid personality disorder
E. Schizoid personality disorder

Correct Answer: A

A 29-year-old man presents with a swelling under the left jaw that comes and goes but leaves a dull ache behind. The problem has been present for around 2 weeks and is getting worse. The pain is most noticeable at mealtimes. In the last day, the swelling has become fixed and he reports an unpleasant taste in his mouth. He smokes five cigarettes a day and drinks ten units of alcohol a week, usually on a Friday night. On examination, there is a smooth, tender swelling in the superior part of the left anterior triangle and, on inspection of the oral cavity, there is poor dentition and pus present just behind the lower incisors.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Dental abscess
B. Submandibular gland infection
C. Partial obstruction of the submandibular duct due to a stone
D. Mumps
E. Gingivostomatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 2-year-old girl is admitted to the Emergency Department with a fever. Her mother informs the admitting doctor that the child has had a temperature for two days, has been irritable, and is quite inactive. The child has also mentioned that her right leg has been sore, and has been reluctant to walk, although there has been no history of injury.
On examination, the child has a temperature of 38.5 oC, and the doctor notes an area of swelling and redness over the right shin. Following investigation, a diagnosis of acute osteomyelitis is made.
Which one of the following is true about acute osteomyelitis in children?

A. Spread from local cellulitis is the most common
B. Intravenous (IV) drug usage is an important risk factor
C. Salmonella species are the most common causative organism
D. The most common site is metaphyses of the femur
E. Bone scans can pick up abnormalities while X-rays cannot

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old man has suffered a left-sided pneumothorax. A chest drain has been inserted through the left fifth intercostal space at the mid-axillary line.
As well as the intercostal muscles, which other muscle is likely to have been pierced?

A. External oblique
B. Latissimus dorsi
C. Pectoralis major
D. Pectoralis minor
E. Serratus anterior

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old man presented with weakness and fatigue. On examination, he was emaciated with a body weight of 40 kg. Blood tests revealed:
Parameter Result Normal range
Haemoglobin 85 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 52 fl 76–98 fl
Mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) 23 pg/cell 25.4–34.6 pg/cell
Platelet count 600 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Albumin 31 g/l 35–55 g/l
Calcium 1.80 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
His peripheral blood showed some bluish-black bodies inside some of the red blood cells in keeping with Howell-Jolly bodies.
This patient should be referred to which one of the following departments?

A. Haematology Department
B. Nephrology Department
C. Hepatology Department
D. Gastroenterology Department
E. Neurology Department

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with diplopia, binocularly. He is known to have hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/9 in both eyes. There is a complete ptosis in his right eye. His right pupil appears of the same size as the left. His right eye is abducted and slightly depressed on primary gaze. His right eye movements are restricted in most directions except abduction.
What is the next step of investigation for this condition?

A. Blood tests including full blood count (FBC), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), lipids and blood glucose
B. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing for oligoclonal bands
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) head with magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)
D. Non-contrast computed tomography (CT) head
E. Orthoptic review with Hess charts

Correct Answer: A

An 18-year-old man attends the Emergency Department with severe testicular pain. He feels generally unwell and has a history of swelling of the scrotum for two days. On examination, the scrotum is oedematous, particularly on the right side, and extremely tender. He has a pyrexia of 38.4 °C and is tachycardic at 114 bpm. On general examination, swelling and tenderness at both angles of the jaw are noted.
What is the most likely cause for this presentation?

A. Chlamydia orchitis
B. Mumps
C. Renal cell carcinoma
D. Seminoma
E. Testicular torsion

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-day history of blurring of vision. He has a past medical history of hypertension, which is managed with amlodipine, ramipril, and indapamide, and type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/18 in both eyes with reduction in colour vision. There is no relative afferent pupillary defect. On direct fundoscopy, the optic discs margins are ill-defined and seem to be raised in both eyes. There are also some cotton-wool spots scattered around the retina in both eyes.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hypertensive retinopathy
B. Intracranial space-occupying lesion
C. Optic neuritis
D. Pre-proliferative diabetic retinopathy
E. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Correct Answer: A

A 4-year-old boy is referred to a paediatrician with a cystic mass on the right lateral aspect of his neck, just below the angle of the jaw. There is a small pit just in front of the lower anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, from which the mother reports discharge occurs intermittently.
This cyst arises due to failure of proliferation of the mesenchyme of which of the following?

A. First pharyngeal arch
B. Second pharyngeal arch
C. Third pharyngeal arch
D. Fourth pharyngeal arch
E. Fifth pharyngeal arch

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 1-day history of blurring of vision and headache. He tells you there is no pain on touching the scalp, or when eating and chewing food.
He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which is well controlled with metformin.
On further history taking, he tells you that his uncle died of brain cancer and he is afraid that he may have the same condition.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/18 in both eyes. On dilated fundoscopy, you see some arterioles narrower than others. There are also venules being compressed by arterioles. There is optic disc swelling in both eyes with some exudates lining up like a star at the macula. There is also some dot-and-blot and flame-shaped haemorrhages.
His vital observations are as follows:
Heart rate 80 bpm
Blood pressure 221/119 mmHg
Oxygen saturation 98% on room air
Respiratory rate 14 per minute
Temperature 37 °C
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
B. Giant-cell arteritis (GCA)
C. Hypertensive retinopathy
D. Intracranial space-occupying lesion
E. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Correct Answer: C

Histocompatibility is the process by which transplant grafts are accepted by the body without the instigation of an immune reaction.
What genes are determinant in the histocompatibility of human tissue?

A. Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs)
B. Major histocompatibility complex (MHC)
C. Antigen-dependent TFPI-regulator
D. PRSS16
E. MOXD1

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman with a previous macrosomic baby and a history of gestational diabetes presents in her second pregnancy. She is at eight weeks’ gestation and attends the midwife booking visit.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation in this patient for a diagnosis of gestational diabetes?

A. A 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) at 24–28 weeks
B. A 2-hour OGTT as soon as possible following the booking visit
C. Random serum glucose at booking
C. D. Random serum glucose at booking and at 24–28 weeks
E. HbA1c at booking and then at 24–28 weeks

Correct Answer: B

A 79-year-old man with heart failure and depression is found to have a sodium level of 130. He is asymptomatic, and his heart failure and depression are well controlled. He has mild pitting pedal oedema. He is on ramipril, bisoprolol, simvastatin and citalopram.
What is the best way to manage this patient?

A. Advise him to increase his salt intake
B. Administer intravenous saline over 1 hour and then recheck
C. Restrict his fluid input to 1.5 l/day and recheck in 3 days
D. Give oral magnesium supplementation
E. Stop his citalopram and recheck in three days

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old epileptic woman comes to clinic with her partner, describing multiple episodes of tonic–clonic seizures. They want to start a family in the next year and come in asking for advice. She currently manages her epilepsy with sodium valproate.
Which one of the following is the best recommendation for this woman’s management?

A. Refer to an epilepsy specialist for evaluation and recommendation of antiepileptic medication changes
B. Add levetiracetam to current medication
C. Stop sodium valproate and start phenytoin
D. Increase the dose of sodium valproate
E. Stop sodium valproate and add phenobarbital

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old man is seen in clinic. He complains of difficulty passing even soft stools. He has tried increasing dietary fibre and drinking more water, but this is not helping. His GP wishes to prescribe an oral medication that works by stimulating the gastrointestinal tract and softening the stool.
Which of the following medications would be appropriate?

A. Docusate
B. Bisacodyl
C. Lactulose
D. Mineral oil
E. Psyllium husk

Correct Answer: A

A 37-year-old woman has a history of excessive sweating, palpitations and weight loss for the past 6 months. She now has a headache. Her blood pressure is 230/130 mmHg, with a postural drop to 180/110 mmHg. Her pulse is bounding and 115 bpm, and she has a tremor and looks pale. The rest of the examination is normal.
Excess production of which of the following hormones is most likely to be the cause of this woman’s symptoms and signs?

A. Renin
B. Aldosterone
C. Cortisol
D. Thyroxine
E. Catecholamines

Correct Answer: E

This 22-year-old woman has had this rash for many years. It is present in a similar position on the other arm, the knees, around the umbilicus and in the natal cleft. She uses regular emollients, otherwise the skin becomes dry. It often improves when she is on holiday.
Which one of the following options contains pathological features typical of this condition?

A. Dermal oedema, mild eosinophilic infiltrate, and dilated lymphatic and small blood vessels
B. Epidermal spongiosis and microvesiculation, superficial dermal oedema, and perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate
C. Inflammatory infiltrate in the wall of dermal or subcutaneous vessels that may be neutrophilic, lymphocytic or granulomatous, often with red blood cell extravasation
D. Parakeratosis, acanthosis with elongation of rete ridges, prominent dermal capillaries, and an epidermal and dermal infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils
E. Subepidermal nonacantholytic unilocular blisters, mild dermal infiltrate including eosinophils

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman presented with photophobia and an enlarged left pupil, which showed a delayed and incomplete constriction to light. Accommodation was relatively normal. A pilocarpine test was positive and no other neurological abnormality was found.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anti-muscarinic drugs
B. Holmes-Adie pupil
C. Horner’s syndrome
D. Muscarinic agonists
E. Third cranial nerve palsy

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old carpenter complains of widespread pruritus for the last 2 weeks. He has no particular history of note, though is currently staying on his brother’s sofa due to relationship problems with his wife. He has noticed the itching is particularly bad at night. On examination, he has a number of linear erythaematous lesions on the backs of his hands and in between is fingers.
Given the likely diagnosis what is the most appropriate first-line treatment option?

A. 5% Hydrocortisone cream applied twice daily to his hands
B. Emollient cream to be applied regularly from neck down
C. Oral antihistamine
D. Permethrin cream applied from neck down for 8-14 h
E. Malathion cream applied from neck down for 24 h

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old woman presents with severe left lower quadrant abdominal pain of 10 hours’ duration. She is known to have chronic constipation. On examination, her temperature is 39.2 °C, and there is tenderness and guarding in the left iliac fossa. An erect chest radiograph shows free air under the diaphragm.
Which of the following does this patient most probably have?

A. Crohn’s disease
B. Perforation of a colonic diverticulum
C. Hirschsprung’s disease
D. Appendicitis
E. Pancreatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old man was admitted to hospital two weeks ago, having collapsed at home. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease and has suffered a myocardial infarction (MI) in the past. During admission, he was found to be short of breath and tachycardic, with an irregular heart rate. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a narrow complex tachycardia, with absent P waves. He is now medically fit for discharge.
What advice should you give to this patient about driving?

A. As his condition has been treated, he can return to driving as soon as he is ready
B. He will need to see his General Practitioner (GP) in two weeks to ensure he is fit to start driving
C. He will need to have been successfully treated for four weeks before he can start driving again
D. He will only be able to drive short distances initially, gradually increasing this over time
E. He should inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) and can commence driving after four weeks of successful treatment

Correct Answer: C

A patient is admitted to the Emergency Department after a road traffic accident, and is noted to have the following signs on examination:
respiratory rate 15 bpm
pulse 70 bpm
blood pressure 120/80
Glasgow Coma Score 3/15
nasal bleeding mixed with clear fluid
orbital haematoma (‘raccoon eyes’)
no other facial bruising.
What is the most likely underlying injury?

A. Anterior fossa skull fracture
B. Middle fossa skull fracture
C. Posterior fossa skull fracture
D. Paranasal sinus fracture
E. Depressed skull vault fracture

Correct Answer: A

You are asked to give a presentation to a group of second-year medical students about the different types of dementia and how they may present.
Which of the following is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia?

A. Late onset (70–80 years-old)
B. Personality and mood are unaffected
C. Confabulation and repetition
D. Bradykinesia
E. Rapid progressive loss of memory and cognitive abilities

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old woman is admitted following a paracetamol overdose. She ingested 20 500-mg tablets 8 hours ago. This is her first overdose. She has been a troubled teenager suffering from anorexia nervosa, and she is severely malnourished, weighing just 40 kg. She has been previously known to abuse laxatives. Her past medical history also includes asthma, for which she takes a long-acting corticosteroid inhaler. She also takes citalopram 20 mg once daily for depression.
Which one of the following puts her at increased risk for hepatotoxicity following paracetamol overdose?

A. Use of inhaled corticosteroids for her asthma
B. Her history of laxative abuse
C. Her history of anorexia nervosa
D. Her age
E. Use of citalopram

Correct Answer: C

A 54-year-old unemployed man with a history of chronic hepatitis B infection presents with jaundice and significant abdominal distention. The patient does not drink, and smokes ten cigarettes a day.
On examination, the patient is found to have ascites and hepatomegaly. The patient is admitted for further investigations; the results of one tumour marker test is suggestive of a possible hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
Which of the following tumour markers is usually raised in primary HCC?

A. CA-125
B. CA-19-9
C. Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
D. Alpha fetoprotein (AFP)
E. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)

Correct Answer: D

A 41-year-old woman presents regarding lesions on her hands. There are a number of pale lesions which have gradually increased in number over time, affecting both hands and appearing in clusters.
She has a background of ankylosing spondylitis, which is stable and managed with etanercept. They are not particularly bothersome, though she is concerned they may be linked to her ankylosing spondylitis.
On examination, you note the following:
Image courtesy of dermatologistoncall.com
There are further lesions covering both palms. In all, there are over a dozen lesions. There has been no response to treatment with topical salicylic acid.
What is the appropriate management for this patient?

A. Cryotherapy
B. Curettage and cautery
C. Do nothing
D. Oral isotretinoin
E. Stop etanercept

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old female trainee solicitor has had difficulty concentrating on her job for the past 2 months. She complains that the work area is too hot. She seems nervous and has a fine tremor. She has been eating more but has lost 4 kg in the past month. On physical examination her temperature is 37.8 °C, pulse 110 bpm, respiratory rate 18 per minute and blood pressure 145/85 mmHg. She has a wide, staring gaze and lid lag.
Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this woman?

A. Decreased plasma insulin
B. Increased thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
C. Decreased thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)
D. Increased adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
E. Increased calcitonin

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old woman presents with colicky right upper quadrant pain. On examination, you note jaundiced conjunctivae. There is tenderness in the right upper quadrant. An ultrasound scan of the biliary tree shows a stone lodged in the biliary tree, posterior to the superior (first) part of the duodenum.
In which part of the biliary tree is the gallstone most likely lodged ?

A. Left hepatic duct
B. Right hepatic duct
C. Common hepatic duct
D. Common bile duct
E. Cystic duct

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man is five days post-laparotomy for subacute intestinal obstruction secondary to underlying Crohn’s disease. He has suddenly become breathless and complains of pleuritic chest pain. On examination, the patient is confused and his chest is clear to auscultation. However, he is tachypnoeic and has a mildly raised jugular venous pressure (JVP).
Observations:
Blood pressure 97/70 mmHg
Heart rate 126 bpm
Respiratory rate 25 breaths per minute
Oxygen saturations 92% on room air
Arterial blood gas:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.53 7.35–7.45
Pa(CO2) 3.1 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Pa(O2) 8.3 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia and right bundle branch block.
Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.
Which is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

A. IV fluids, oxygen, enoxaparin (treatment dose), rivaroxaban
B. IV fluids, oxygen, IV unfractionated heparin
C. IV fluids, oxygen, rivaroxaban
D. IV fluids, oxygen, warfarin (for three months)
E. Thrombolysis

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old black woman presents with completely depigmented patches of skin on her hands and face.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pityriasis alba
B. Albinism
C. Melasma
D. Melanoma
E. Vitiligo

Correct Answer: E

A 23-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department with lower abdominal pain. On further questioning, she is also complaining of pain in her right shoulder.
Which investigation will be most useful in your further management of this patient?

A. Urea and electrolytes (U & Es)
B. Urine β-human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG)
C. Full blood count (FBC)
D. Erect chest X-ray
E. Abdominal X-ray

Correct Answer: B

A 67-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with a long-standing history of progressive neck pain and stiffness. She has recently developed pain down her right arm, associated with numbness and loss of grip strength. A diagnosis of spondylotic cervical myelopathy is suspected.
What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?

A. Cervical spine X-ray
B. Electromyography
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of brain
D. MRI of cervical spine
E. Nerve conduction studies

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to the Chest Clinic after being referred for a chronic cough by his general practitioner (GP). He reports a 9-month history of a dry cough associated with progressive shortness of breath. He has been treated multiple times with antibiotics with no significant improvement. He has never smoked and denies any haemoptysis. He used to work as a solicitor and has never been exposed to any environmental dusts or chemicals.
His GP requested a chest X-ray, which is reported as showing reticular shadowing affecting both lung bases.
On examination, he is clubbed and has fine-end inspiratory crackles. Heart sounds are normal. He is saturating at 94% on room air with a regular heart rate of 80 bpm and regular, and a respiratory rate of 20. There is no peripheral oedema.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bronchiectasis
B. Carcinoma of the lung
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Congestive cardiac failure (CCF)
E. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Correct Answer: E

A 49-year-old woman received a deep posterolateral laceration in her right neck in an automobile accident. The right shoulder is lower than the left shoulder and she cannot elevate her right shoulder against resistance. There is no increase in muscle tone under the medial upper border of the right shoulder when the patent attempts to shrug her shoulders.
Which nerve has been damaged by the laceration?

A. Spinal accessory nerve
B. Dorsal scapular nerve
C. Suprascapular nerve
D. Axillary nerve
E. Upper trunk of the brachial plexus

Correct Answer: A

A 50-year-old obese woman, recently returned from a holiday in Japan, presents with complaints of chronic diarrhoea, fatigue and greasy, bulky stools. She is a non-vegetarian and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Stool examination confirmed steatorrhoea. Investigations are normal, except for macrocytic anaemia. Elevated folic acid levels and reduced vitamin B12 levels were found in blood tests. Computerised tomography (CT) abdomen is normal, except for multiple diverticula in the jejunum.
What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s macrocytic anaemia?

A. Increased utilisation of vitamin B12 by bacteria
B. Acquired deficiency of intrinsic factor
C. Chronic pancreatic insufficiency
D. Dietary deficiency of vitamin B12
E. Fish tapeworm infestation

Correct Answer: A

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the General Practitioner (GP) by his mother. He has suffered an insect bite, and his mother is concerned about a small lump on the back of his hand.
Which of the following conditions is not pre-malignant?

A. Bowen’s disease
B. Dermatofibroma
C. Lentigo maligna
D. Leukoplakia
E. Actinic keratoses

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old woman experiences nausea and vomiting after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, resulting in an extended hospital stay.
Which of the following is a risk factor for post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in adults?

A. Male sex
B. Older age
C. Non-smoker
D. Pre-operative hospital stay
E. Intraoperative oxygen

Correct Answer: C

A 26-year-old woman with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea attends the clinic with her mother. She tells you that her mother has had a hysterectomy to treat menorrhagia, which found growths in the uterus. She is worried that the condition is hereditary, how this will affect her fertility and whether she is at risk of cancer.
Which of the following is most suitable for a definitive diagnosis of the condition described in this scenario?

A. Clinical examination
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
C. Full blood count
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
E. Ultrasound scan of the abdomen and pelvis

Correct Answer: E

A 96-year-old man is admitted to hospital having fallen at home. He is complaining of pain in the right groin on mobilising and is unable to weight-bear despite regular full-dose paracetamol and codeine. His pain is well controlled at rest, but he is feeling drowsy from the pain relief. A hip and pelvic X-ray has shown no cause for his discomfort.
What is the next most appropriate step in this patient’s management?

A. Continue current management and physiotherapy
B. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of hip and pelvis
C. Nuclear medicine bone scan
D. Oral morphine sulfate
E. Repeat hip X-ray while weight-bearing

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old previously healthy man is involved in an accident at work. He is brought to the Emergency Department where he is found to have superficial abrasions to the left side of chest and upper abdomen together with an obvious deformity of the left humerus. Radiograph of the left arm shows a displaced, mid-shaft humerus fracture. Neurovascular examination reveals radial nerve palsy together with absent peripheral pulses and a cool, clammy distal arm. He was given oral paracetamol at work while waiting for the ambulance to arrive. Pain score remains 9/10. Parameters are as follows:
Patient Normal
Temperature 36.8°C 36.1–37.2°C
Pulse 115 beats/min 60–100 beats/min
Blood pressure 145/93 mmHg <120/80 mmHg
Oxygen saturations 99% on room air 94–98%
Respiratory rate 24 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Which of the following is the most appropriate form of pain relief?

A. iv paracetamol
B. po diclofenac
C. sc pethidine
D. iv morphine
E. Inhaled Entonox (50% nitrous oxide, 50% oxygen)

Correct Answer: D

A 7-year-old girl is brought to her general practitioner by her mother because she is shorter than most of her classmates. She gets good grades and does well in school. She is below the fifth percentile for height for her age. On examination, she is short and has a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.
Which one of the following is karyotyping most likely to reveal?

A. 47,XXY
B. 45,XO
C. 47,XX+21
D. 47,XYY
E. Normal karyotype

Correct Answer: B

A 14-year-old boy was stabbed with a knife during a robbery attempt and taken to the Emergency Department of a local hospital. Physical examination revealed a single horizontal stab wound located on the skin 4 mm to the right of the umbilicus.
In which dermatome was the stab wound located?

A. T8
B. T9
C. T10
D. T11
E. T12

Correct Answer: C

A 42-year-old woman is pregnant with her first child. She is offered screening for chromosomal abnormalities and an ultrasound assessment. She decides to proceed with testing, which assesses nuchal thickness, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A), free beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin (β-hCG) and crown–rump length. She is told the pregnancy is high risk for Edward syndrome, and she and her partner are offered an amniocentesis.
Which one of the following statements regarding amniocentesis is correct?

A. It carries a 10–20% chance of miscarriage
B. It is associated with an increased risk of fetal limb defects
C. It is approximately 80% accurate
D. It cannot be carried out after week 15
E. It is usually carried out before week 10

Correct Answer: B

A 62-year-old woman complains of abdominal swelling, vomiting and weight loss. The patient reports that her symptoms have become progressively worse over the last 6 months. She has a 30-year smoking history. Computerised tomography shows bilateral ovarian tumours, in addition to a mass in the body of the stomach. Gastroscopy is performed, and a biopsy is positive for adenocarcinoma.
What are the likely histological features of the ovarian masses?

A. Follicles containing eosinophils
B. Signet ring cells
C. Transitional cells
D. Cells that resemble the endocervix
E. Spindle-shaped fibroblasts

Correct Answer: B

An 18-year-old girl mentions to you in your clinic that a friend of hers was recently diagnosed with Bell’s palsy and has some questions regarding it.
Which one of the following cranial nerves does Bell’s palsy primarily affect?

A. Cranial nerve III
B. Cranial nerve IV
C. Cranial nerve V
C. D. Cranial nerve VI
C. D. E. Cranial nerve VII

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman presents with backache over the past 5 days, which did not respond to over-the-counter analgesics. Pain is increasing in the night and is constant. It is not subsiding with rest. There is no history of trauma. She is a known diabetic and hypertensive. She had an episode of deep vein thrombosis 1 month ago and was on heparin for 3 weeks. She had no children and her husband passed away a year ago. Her current medications include captopril, metformin, warfarin, atorvastatin and aspirin 375 mg. X-ray of the spine shows a fracture of C6 vertebra.
Which one of the following is the most likely underlying disease causing the fracture at this vertebral level?

A. Post-menopausal osteoporosis
B. Heparin-induced secondary osteoporosis
C. Statin-induced myopathy
D. Renal osteodystrophy due to diabetic nephropathy
E. Metastatic carcinoma due to occult primary

Correct Answer: E

A mother is concerned about her 17 year-old son, who has recently become more reclusive and spends most days in his bedroom. He has stopped socialising with friends and has dropped out of college. He has also removed all the mirrors in his room as he believes that people are spying on him through the mirrors. The mother's brother has had schizophrenia in the past, and she is worried that her son is showing very similar symptoms.
Which of the following statements best characterises the aetiology of schizophrenia?

A. In a family with one schizophrenic parent, the risk of schizophrenia in a child is about 25%
B. Monozygotic twins show an 85% concordance for schizophrenia; in dizygotic twins, the concordance is 50%
C. Approximately 20 million people worldwide are reported to have schizophrenia with a prevalence of up to 1%
D. Family influences outweigh genetic contributions
E. Neurodevelopmental trauma reduces the risk of schizophrenia

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with difficulty walking and pain in the back of the ankle. He describes hearing a loud snapping sound halfway through completing a 10-km obstacle run. On examination, he has swelling at the back of the ankle and a positive Simmonds test. He is diagnosed with a ruptured Achilles tendon.
What is the most appropriate management of this patient to encourage healing of the injured tendon?

A. Below-knee plaster cast
B. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
C. Physiotherapy
D. Rest, ice, compression and elevation (RICE)
E. Surgical repair

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old woman presents to the Ophthalmology Clinic with a 2-week history of reduced vision in her right eye. She said that straight lines appear wavy and she notices that she has blurred vision in the centre of her right eye. She does not have any pain in either eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals a greyish-green discolouration of the retina and subretinal exudate. Fluorescence angiography reveals neovascularisation and exudation in the macular region.
What is the first-line treatment for this patient?

A. Laser coagulation
B. Photodynamic therapy
C. Supportive treatment with patient education and risk-factor-avoidance education
D. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor (bevacizumab, ranibizumab)
E. Visual and reading aids

Correct Answer: D

A 25-year-old man has an orchidectomy for a testicular lump. Following his procedure, histology shows cartilage and columnar epithelial cells.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Teratoma
B. Seminoma
C. Hamartoma
D. Epididymal cyst
E. Choriocarcinoma

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old woman was admitted to the Emergency Department after her flatmate reported that she was afraid that the government had implanted a radio in her brain that was telling her to kill herself.
Further evaluation revealed that she had many symptoms of schizophrenia and a decision was made to treat her with clozapine.
Which statement about this drug is correct?

A. It is a D1 agonist
B. It is a D4 agonist
C. It is a D2 agonist
D. It is a 5-HT2A agonist
E. It is a alpha1-adrenoceptor antagonist

Correct Answer: E

A 5-year-old boy with a history of eczema presents with a history of urticaria and angioedema immediately after eating Chinese food.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cows’ milk protein allergy
B. Peanut allergy
C. Chilli allergy
D. Acute exacerbation of eczema
E. Contact dermatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 76-year-old man reports recent passage of blood with stool and weight loss. Rectal examination demonstrates a suspicious lesion inferior to the pectinate line, concerning for malignancy. Next you palpate for lymphadenopathy.
Where would you expect to find enlarged lymph nodes?

A. Internal iliac
B. External iliac
C. Inguinal
D. Superior mesenteric
E. Inferior mesenteric

Correct Answer: C

A 22-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder gives birth to a baby boy at home. She received no prenatal care, but when she found out she was pregnant, she started taking prenatal vitamins that she got from the pharmacist. Her only medication is valproic acid. It is 2 days since the birth, and the mother has brought her baby to the Emergency Department because he has become impossible to arouse. On examination, the baby is estimated to have been born at 35 weeks’ gestation. The baby is afebrile, with stable vital signs. A head ultrasound through the fontanelle shows an intracerebral haemorrhage in the germinal matrix. There are no calcifications. Retinal examination does not show petechial haemorrhages. A full skeletal survey is negative.
What is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism underlying this baby’s haemorrhage?

A. Folate deficiency from valproic acid treatment
B. Congenital cytomegalovirus
C. Congenital toxoplasmosis
D. Vitamin K deficiency
E. Congenital herpes simplex virus

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man is recovering from an appendectomy in the surgical ward. He receives an antiemetic for nausea post-anaesthesia. Two hours later, he is found writhing in his bed, unable to speak. His arms and legs are flexed and rigid.
What medication would you give to treat his condition?

A. Metoclopramide
B. Ondansetron
C. Trazodone
D. Procyclidine
E. Domperidone

Correct Answer: D

A 77-year-old man is brought to see his general practitioner by his friend who has noticed that he is becoming increasingly forgetful and unsteady on his feet. Unfortunately his friend does not know anything about his previous medical history or whether he takes any medications. Routine investigations reveal:
Investigation Result Normal Value
Haemaglobin 103 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular value 103 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count 6.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 78 × 109/l 150–400 x 109/
Sodium 131 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 1.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatine 76 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Random blood sugar 5.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.5 mmol/l
Given these results, which is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A. Hypothyroidism
B. B12 deficiency
C. Myelodysplasia
D. Alcohol excess
E. Phenytoin toxicity

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old man falls and injures his thumb while skiing. On examination, there is significant pain and laxity of the thumb on valgus stress and weakness of the pinch grasp.
Which one of the following is the most likely injury?

A. Bennett fracture
B. De Quervain tenosynovitis
C. Radial collateral ligament (RCL) tear
D. Scaphoid fracture
E. Ulnar collateral ligament tear

Correct Answer: E

A 64-year-old woman presents to her gynaecologist with vaginal irritation and itching. On examination, the clinician notes a 3 cm by 2 cm lump extending from the left side of the vulva. A biopsy of the lump is taken for histological diagnosis.
Which of the following is the most common vulval carcinoma?

A. Malignant melanoma
B. Basal cell carcinomas
C. Squamous cell carcinomas
D. Bartholin’s gland cancer
E. Sarcoma

Correct Answer: C

A 38-year-old man is admitted to the Emergency Mental Health Ward. He is talking quickly, saying that he is the ‘new Jesus’ and that he can cure acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). With the help of his friends who are feeding him previously unknown 'top-secret' information.
Which of the following medications should be prescribed for this patient?

A. Diazepam
B. Citalopram
C. Olanzapine
D. Clozapine
E. Zopiclone

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman is at eight weeks’ gestation in her first pregnancy, with a body mass index (BMI) of 36.5 kg/m2. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and her sister had pre-eclampsia in both her pregnancies. She had deep vein thrombosis (DVT), following a long-haul flight to Australia last year.
Which of the following risk factors presenting in this patient’s history is considered a high-risk factor for the development of pre-eclampsia?

A. BMI of 36.5 kg/m2
B. Family history of a first-degree relative with pre-eclampsia
C. First pregnancy
D. Personal history of DVT
E. Type 2 diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: E

A 4-month-old baby presents unwell with shortness of breath. He has been having difficulty taking his feeds. On examination, it is noted there is a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal edge. A thrill is felt in the pulmonary area, with a rough ejection systolic murmur best heard in the same area. An ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy, with right axis deviation. The liver is palpable. Oxygen saturation gets 88% intermittently causing cyanotic spells.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Transposition of great vessels
B. Atrial septal defect (ASD)
C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
D. Coarctation of aorta
E. Tetralogy of Fallot

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old gardener presents to her General Practitioner with a 1-month history of pain when kneeling on her right knee. She is otherwise well and denies any fevers. On examination of the right knee, there is a mildly tender swelling, anterior to the patella, that is fluctuant. The knee is not red but is mildly warm to touch, with a good range of motion. She reports some discomfort on flexion of the knee.
What are the most likely findings of joint aspiration?

A. Clear/milky joint aspirate with normal microscopy and culture
B. Gram-positive cocci
C. Needle-shaped crystals with strong negative birefringence on polarised light microscopy
D. Purulent aspirate
E. Rhomboid-shaped crystals with weak positive birefringence on polarised light microscopy

Correct Answer: A

A 58-year-old patient presented to the Emergency Department at 0300 h. He awoke with tongue swelling that caused dysphonia and dyspnoea. Paramedics administered three doses of intramuscular adrenaline, with no improvement.
Nebulised adrenaline, intravenous hydrocortisone and antihistamines were given in the Emergency Department, with gradual resolution of his symptoms. He also reported two similar, but milder, episodes over the preceding year where he had self-treated with antihistamines, with no effect.
No triggers had been identified. He had been diagnosed with hypertension two years previously and commenced on cilazapril 5 mg and amlodipine 10 mg once daily. Other medical problems included a history of osteoarthritis and renal stones treated conservatively over 20 years ago. He had no history of food or drug allergies.
What is the most likely pathological mechanism underlying his presentation?

A. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
B. Kininase II inhibition
C. Mast cell degranulation
D. Mastocytosis
E. Tyrosine kinase inhibition

Correct Answer: B

A patient is recently diagnosed with a bleeding disorder after recently complaining of heavy periods. She is found to have a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (APTT) and prolonged bleeding time. Her indices are otherwise normal. The patient mentions that her mother’s side of the family has bleeding disorders. On acquiring the past medical history she gave no previous history of bruising or bleeding following a dental procedure or other minor surgical procedures.
Which one of the following bleeding disorders is most likely in this patient?

A. Giant platelet syndrome (Bernard–Soulier syndrome)
B. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia
C. Haemophilia A
D. Vitamin K deficiency
E. von Willebrand’s disease

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old male patient is admitted with a seizure and reduced conscious level. He had been generally unwell with a fever and headaches over the previous 48 h. Computed tomography (CT) brain scan was normal. Lumbar puncture reveals: protein 0.8 g/l, glucose 3.5 mmol/l (serum glucose 5 mmol/l), WCC (white cell count) 80/mm3, 90% lymphocytes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute bacterial meningitis
B. Viral meningitis
C. Viral encephalitis
D. Tuberculosis (TB) meningitis
E. Stroke

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old man presents to the general practitioner (GP) with hypertension which fails to fall into the normal range after three successive measurements at the practice nurse. These were 155/92 mmHg, 158/96 mmHg and 154/94 mmHg. He has a past history of some urinary tract infections as a child. The GP arranges some routine blood tests.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 187 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
USS Left kidney 8.4 cm and appears scarred.
Right kidney 10.3 cm
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Essential hypertension
B. Renal artery stenosis
C. Chronic reflux nephropathy
D. White coat hypertension
E. IgA nephropathy

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old retired electrician complains of increasing shortness of breath, weight loss and two episodes of haemoptysis over the past week. He is an ex-smoker of 40 pack years. On examination: stony dull right base, no breath sounds heard, decreased vocal resonance.
Which one of the following statements regarding mesothelioma is the most correct?

A. It is caused by asbestos and smoking
B. It has a 5-year survival of 15%
C. It is usually diagnosed by open biopsy
D. It may have a lag period of up to 45 years between exposure and diagnosis
E. It will cause a transudate pleural effusion

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old Asian man with ischaemic heart disease was treated with amoxicillin and clarithromycin for severe community-acquired pneumonia.
Which of his other concurrent medications is it most important to stop while he is taking the antibiotics?

A. Aspirin
B. Bisoprolol
C. Clopidogrel
D. Ramipril
E. Simvastatin

Correct Answer: E

A 52-year-old patient is reviewed in the Pre-Assessment Clinic prior to having elective surgery for varicose veins. He is fit and well; the only medical history of note is that the patient has hypertension, which is well controlled with lisinopril. The patient is examined as part of the assessment and the examining clinician notes that an early opening snap is heard during diastole on auscultating the heart.
Which of the following is most likely to be the cause of an early opening snap in diastole?

A. Ventricular septal defect
B. Mitral valve prolapse
C. Pulmonary stenosis
D. Right bundle branch block
E. Mitral stenosis

Correct Answer: E

A patient presents to the Emergency Department following a fracture dislocation of her ankle after a night out drinking vodka red-bulls. Her blood pressure is low at 90/50 mmHg. She insists that it is never normally that low.
Which one of these is a possible cause for this reading?

A. Incorrect cuff size (cuff too large)
B. Incorrect cuff size (cuff too small)
C. Alcohol and caffeine
D. White coat hypertension
E. Pain

Correct Answer: A

A 62-year-old man with a long history of alcohol abuse has suffered haematemesis (vomited blood). Endoscopy shows he has oesophageal varices.
Which of the following upper abdominal organs is most likely to be enlarged?

A. Gall bladder
B. Left kidney
C. Pancreas
D. Spleen
E. Stomach

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old student presents to the University Health Service with jaundice. He had been to a party three nights earlier and since then has been laid up in bed with flu-like symptoms. On examination, he has mild jaundice, but otherwise the examination is normal.
Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Bilirubin 62 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 21 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 15 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 320 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome
B. Gilbert's syndrome
C. Cholecystitis
D. Acute ethanol poisoning
E. Viral hepatitis

Correct Answer: B

A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension is referred by his general practitioner after noticing a mass in his scrotum. He described feeling a heavy, dragging sensation in his scrotum for about 2 weeks and then noticed a mass on self-examination. On examination, the patient had a non-tender, palpable mass on the left side of the scrotum, seemingly associated with the left testicle. Ultrasound of the scrotum demonstrated dilation of the left pampiniform plexus.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

A. Venous insufficiency of the inferior vena cava below the renal veins
B. Increased right renal vein pressure
C. Dilation of the superior mesenteric artery
D. Increased left renal artery pressure
E. Benign prostatic hyperplasia

Correct Answer: C

A 2-day-old baby born at term is rushed to the Neonatal Unit with vomiting green fluid and a distended abdomen. He was initially doing well after birth and was being breastfed. His parents report he has passed urine but not yet passed meconium. On examination, he appears pale, floppy and tachypnoeic.
What is the most likely cause of his deterioration?

A. Biliary atresia
B. Group B streptococcal sepsis
C. Haemolytic disease of the newborn
D. Hirschsprung’s disease
E. Necrotising enterocolitis (NEC)

Correct Answer: D

You review a 43-year-old man who is post-operative following a laparotomy. He complains of a lump in the middle of his abdomen. On examination, you note a mass arising from the site of surgical incision, which is reducible and reproducible when the patient coughs.
Which of the following is a risk factor for the development of an incisional hernia?

A. Being tall and thin
B. Sedentary lifestyle
C. Age less than 50 years
D. Wound infection
E. Post-operative nausea

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old man presents with a lump in the anterior of the neck. He has no symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Family members have commented that his voice has become very hoarse over the last few weeks. Fine-needle aspiration suggests papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
Which of the following statements is correct?

A. A hoarse voice suggests invasion of the larynx
B. The calcitonin level is typically raised
C. Most patients have distant metastases at presentation
D. Thyroidectomy is curative in most cases
E. Most cases are familial

Correct Answer: D

A 72-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner, complaining of unusual painful sensations affecting the left side of her face which later progressed to a painful vesicular rash. There has been a mild fever and feelings of malaise during the preceding few days. On examination, she has a well-demarcated vesicular rash which appears to affect only one portion of the left side of her face.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 115 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 28 mm/hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 140 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Herpes simplex
B. Herpes zoster
C. Impetigo
D. Solar keratoses
E. Malignant lentigo

Correct Answer: B

A worried mother brings her 3-year-old toddler to the Emergency Department with a ‘barking cough’. He has had ‘noisy breathing’ and a fever for the last 48 hours. He is eating and drinking, but less so than usual. He is passing urine regularly. There is no past medical history of note. On examination, he is alert, well and smiling. He is clearly coryzal. There is no stridor. Vital signs are normal. His chest is clear, with no evidence of recession. You diagnose croup.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. No treatment is required. Discharge home, with clear advice on the signs of worsening croup
B. Give nebulised adrenaline and a single dose of dexamethasone, and admit under paediatrics
C. Give nebulised adrenaline and admit under paediatrics
D. Give a single dose of Dexamethasone orally and admit under paediatrics
E. Give a single dose of dexamethasone orally, and discharge home with clear advice on the signs of worsening croup

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old woman complains of amenorrhoea and that she gets discharge from her breasts periodically. She is nulliparous and has not been in a sexual relationship for 18 months. She does not take any regular medications. She has had a regular menstrual cycle before. Examination of her breasts reveals no abnormality and she has normal secondary sexual characteristics.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A. Skull X-ray
B. Skull computed tomography (CT)
C. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
D. Prolactin level
E. Thyroid function tests

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old woman is seen by her general practitioner as she has been experiencing some troubling issues intermittently over the last few months. She complains of episodes of weakness, which occur with strange fast movements of her arms which she states are not voluntary. She also has a persistent tingling sensation, sometimes gets double vision, gets electric shocks down her arms and trunk when she flexes her neck, and has constipation.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate first line investigation for this condition:

A. Slit-lamp examination of the eyes
B. Colonoscopy
C. CT scan
D. MRI
E. Lumbar puncture

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman, who has been housebound for years because of difficulty mobilising, presents with worsening bone pain. She seems fragile on her feet but has no other specific concerns. Blood tests are carried out.
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/dl 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.5 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 230 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Calcium 1.99 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Phosphate 10 mmol/l 15–50 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 455 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Osteitis fibrosa cystica
B. Osteomalacia
C. Osteopetrosis
D. Osteoporosis
E. Paget’s

Correct Answer: B

A 15-year-old presents to the Emergency Department after experiencing acute-onset excruciating pain in his groin that developed while playing basketball. He has no significant past medical history and does not report trauma to the groin. On examination, the pain persists in his right testicle when it is elevated. Ultrasound with Doppler of the right testicle demonstrates decreased blood flow.
From which one of the following arteries does the vessel most likely occluded in this patient arise?

A. Right renal artery
B. Left renal artery
C. Internal iliac artery
D. External iliac artery
E. Directly from the aorta

Correct Answer: E

A 57-year-old man presents to the general practitioner (GP) with a 6-month history of increasing difficulty with swallowing solid foods. He does not have any problems with swallowing liquids. He has always been overweight but has lost 5 kg in the past few months. He attributes this eating a little less due to his swallowing difficulties. He has a past history of long-term heartburn and indigestion, which he has been self-treating with over-the-counter antacids. The GP is concerned that the patient may have oesophageal cancer.
Which one of the following statements with regard to oesophageal cancer is correct?

A. Barrett’s oesophagus is a pre-malignant condition that may lead to squamous carcinoma
B. Most cases are amenable to curative surgery at diagnosis
C. Achalasia predisposes to squamous carcinoma of the oesophagus
D. Dysphagia is a late manifestation
E. Squamous cell carcinoma most commonly occurs in the lower oesophagus

Correct Answer: C

A 78-year-old woman falls on an icy road and lands on her outstretched hand. She suffers a fracture to her distal wrist. On examination she has a classic dinner-fork deformity of her right wrist.
What is the most likely fracture sustained?

A. Colles’ fracture
B. Hangman’s fracture
C. Jefferson’s fracture
D. Monteggia’s fracture
E. Smith’s fracture

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old woman with known cystic fibrosis (CF) has very advanced lung disease with a forced expiratory volume at 1 second (FEV1) of 20% predicted and is admitted with a history of sudden-onset chest pain and breathlessness.
Observations reveal a temperature of 36.6 °C, respiratory rate of 26 breath/min, blood pressure of 136/72 mmHg, heart rate of 120 bpm and oxygen saturations on room air of 86%.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pulmonary embolism
B. Pulmonary exacerbation of CF
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Pneumothorax
E. Musculoskeletal chest pain

Correct Answer: D

A woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with her newborn baby for a 6-week check. She has read about changes to the vaccination schedule for children at eight weeks. Her child is well and there have been no concerns so far, in either the pregnancy or since birth.
Which of the following immunisations are currently included in the UK Childhood Vaccination Schedule at eight weeks?

A. Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG)
B. Hepatitis B
C. Hepatitis C
D. Meningitis C
E. Influenza

Correct Answer: B

An 82-year-old woman who lives in a care home is reported missing after breakfast. The care home actively tries to find her but is not able to for the next few hours. A police report is made, and later that day, the woman is found wandering two streets away from the care home. She is brought back to the care home, and the care home is concerned that she might try to get out again. The nurse caring for the patient reports that the woman has been trying to get out of the care home for the past few weeks but did not manage to do so, as they were able to prevent her on time. The care home wants to fit a lock to the patient’s room door to restrict her mobility during busy times of the day when limited staff are available to make sure she does not get out. The patient is medically stable, has a diagnosis of dementia, and is known to lack capacity to make a decision about her treatment and freedom.
Which of the following is the best course of action for this patient?

A. Nothing as the patient has autonomy and should be free
B. The patient can be restricted for 21 days under urgent DoLS authorisation
C. The patient is to be detained under the Mental Health Act 1983
D. The patient should be admitted to hospital
E. The patient can be restricted for seven days under urgent DoLS authorisation

Correct Answer: E

A 70-year-old man with severe emphysema attends his General Practitioner (GP) for annual review. He tells his GP that he has been progressively more breathless for the past six months and asks whether he would benefit from long-term oxygen.
Recent routine blood tests were normal. Respiratory examination reveals globally decreased air entry. Cardiovascular examination is normal.
Which of the following options describes an indication to prescribe this man long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT)?

A. Symptomatic desaturation on exertion
B. Severe breathlessness
C. PaO2 < 7.3 kPa when stable
D. PaO2 < 8.5 kPa when stable
E. Frequent acute exacerbations

Correct Answer: C

An 86-year-old retired school teacher has recently been diagnosed with mild Alzheimer’s dementia. Both herself and her two daughters are very keen to try any medication that is available to try and slow the rate of progression, to allow her to continue living independently in her own home for as long as possible.
Which of the following medications is used to slow the rate of progression of Alzheimer's disease?

A. Mirtazapine
B. Donepezil
C. Amantadine
D. Riluzole
E. Pyridostigmine

Correct Answer: B

A 38-year-old obese woman, with a history of type II diabetes mellitus, complains of weight gain during the past 3 years, despite her adherence to a balanced diet. She has diffuse skeletal pain. She is not married and does not have a sexual partner. Her family history is unremarkable. Her blood pressure is 160/105 mmHg. Her face is plethoric and round and she has hypertrichosis of the upper lip (hirsutism). There are purple striae on the abdomen and thigh, and mild wasting of the upper and lower limb muscles. Her full blood count shows a slight increase in the polymorphonuclear leukocyte count, without a left shift. Her haemoglobin is 180 (115–155 g/l).
Which of the following changes in serum calcium, phosphate and parathyroid hormone concentrations would you expect to find in this patient?
