A. Calcium - increased; phosphate - decreased; parathyroid hormone - increased
B. Calcium - decreased; phosphate - increased; parathyroid hormone - decreased
C. Calcium, phosphate and parathyroid normal
D. Calcium - decreased; phosphate - increased; parathyroid hormone - increased
E. Calcium - decreased; phosphate - decreased; parathyroid hormone - increased

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic after an insurance medical. He was noted to have an abnormal alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Past history includes obesity, hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia, which he manages with diet control. He denies any significant alcohol intake. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 31.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 139 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 394 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 143 mmo/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 85 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 150 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase 95 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Bilirubin 28 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Total cholesterol 6.8 mmol/l < 5.2 mmol/l
Triglycerides 3.8 mmol/l 0–1.5 mmol/l
Ultrasound of liver Increase in echogenicity
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Viral hepatitis
B. Alcohol-related cirrhosis
C. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
D. Wilson’s disease
E. Haemochromatosis

Correct Answer: C

Primary hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperparathyroidism are associated with loss of bone mass. But teriparatide, a derivative of parathyroid hormone (PTH), is used as treatment for severe osteoporosis.
In which one of the following ways is it helpful in osteoporosis?

A. By increasing bone remodelling
B. By having a direct anabolic effect on bone
C. By helping in calcium resorption from bone
D. By increasing synthesis of the active form of vitamin D
E. By decreasing excretion of calcium from the kidneys

Correct Answer: B

An elderly man presents to the Emergency Department with severe headache, nausea, vomiting and a painful, red right eye. He has reduced visual acuity in the right eye and normal visual acuity in the left eye. On examination, he had a stony hard eye with marked pericorneal reddening and a hazy corneal reflex. Tonometry revealed raised intraocular pressure.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Single dose of oral acetazolamide (500 mg) and then emergency referral to an ophthalmologist
B. Topical steroids
C. Urgent referral to a neurologist
D. Admit for immediate review by on call ophthalmologist. Topical pilocarpine, followed by a single dose of oral acetazolamide (500 mg) if there is a significant delay prior to specialist review
E. Urgent referral to an ophthalmologist. Topical tropicamide, followed by a single dose of oral acetazolamide (500 mg) if there is a significant delay prior to specialist review

Correct Answer: D

Thomas is a 4-year-old overweight boy brought in by anxious parents who are worried about his loud snoring and frequent interruptions in breathing which have been getting progressively worse. His parents have been receiving complaints from the school teachers about his disruptive and inattentive behaviour in class. On examination, Thomas has a short, thick neck and mildly enlarged tonsils but no other abnormalities.
What is the next best step in management?

A. Reassure his parents that snoring loudly is very normal in children his age and that his behaviour pattern will improve as he matures
B. Book the child for an elective adenotonsillectomy as a day procedure
C. Order an overnight polysomnographic study
D. Advise the parents to purchase a dental splint for their child to use overnight
E. Treat the child with intranasal budesonide

Correct Answer: C

You are asked by a nurse to review a 68-year-old woman on the Surgical Assessment Unit who is 1-day post-operative, having undergone a laparoscopic cholecystectomy procedure for cholecystitis. She has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. Blood tests taken earlier in the day indicated electrolyte disturbances with hyperkalaemia.
With which one of the following ECG changes is hyperkalaemia associated?

A. Peaked T waves
B. Narrowing of QRS complexes
C. Peaked P waves
D. Reduced PR interval
E. Atrial tachycardia

Correct Answer: A

An infant is born at 38 weeks’ gestation and is noted to have low Apgar scores following birth. During a comprehensive review by the neonatology team, an echocardiogram demonstrates very poor right ventricular function. The mother has a history of hypertension and bipolar disease requiring lithium therapy.
Which one of the following maternal medical complications may have contributed to the infant’s condition?

A. Heavy tobacco use
B. Prior deep venous thrombosis requiring anticoagulation with warfarin
C. Maternal hypertension requiring captopril use
D. Long-standing bipolar disorder therapy
E. Pelvic inflammatory disease with doxycycline use

Correct Answer: D

You are a final-year medical student in the Ophthalmology clinic and have been asked to review a patient’s optic discs and retina.
Which one of the following agents should be used to dilate the patient’s pupils?

A. Tropicamide
B. Cyclopentolate
C. Pilocarpine
D. Adrenaline
E. Tetracaine

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents to the clinic complaining of a burning sensation in her legs. Her legs are very sore and uncomfortable. On examination, there is a hard, tender, bulging of veins in both her thighs and the calf region, with hyperpigmentation and eczema of both the legs and ulcer over the medial malleolus.
Which of the following would prevent radiofrequency ablation being performed as an initial treatment for this patient?

A. Eczema of lower limbs
B. Hard painful veins
C. Hyperpigmentation of lower limbs
D. Pregnancy
E. Ulcer over the medial malleolus

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner with a painful red photophobic eye with some blurred vision. She denies any discharge, headache, nausea or vomiting. She has a history of inflammatory bowel disease; otherwise she is well.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Conjunctivitis
B. Episcleritis
C. Acute glaucoma
D. Uveitis
E. Keratitis

Correct Answer: D

A 72-year-old retired banker is referred to the Urology Clinic with a 3-month history of poor stream when passing urine. Over the past few weeks, the patient has also noticed some blood in his urine.
He is normally fit and well. The only medical history of note is type 2 diabetes, which is well controlled with diet alone.
On rectal examination, the patient is noted to have an enlarged, irregularly shaped prostate.
A raised level of which of the tumour markers below would be most commonly associated with carcinoma of the prostate?

A. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
B. Ca-125
C. Prostate specific antigen (PSA)
D. Ca 15-3
E. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

Correct Answer: C

A 14-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department after playing a game of football. During the game, he describes being tackled with a boot to the lateral aspect of his upper leg. X-ray examination reveals a fracture at the neck of the fibula.
Which structure is most likely to be affected by this injury?

A. Popliteal artery
B. Popliteal vein
C. Small saphenous vein
D. Common peroneal nerve
E. Tibial nerve

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old university teacher came back to the United Kingdom (UK) after 2 years in India. He had gone there on a spiritual quest and had stayed in various ashrams. He stayed with the local disciples and ate local food. While staying in India, he suffered from malaria twice, diarrhoea once and urinary tract infection once. After coming back to the UK, he complained of chronic diarrhoea. There was abdominal pain and the diarrhoea increased after intake of milk. Blood reports reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 92 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 109 fl 76–98 fl
Stool multiple specimens Negative
Blood for IgA Ttg Negative
HIV antibody Negative
White cell count (WCC) 8 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Which of the following tests would be most useful in diagnosing this patient?

A. Colonoscopy
B. Small intestinal biopsy
C. Lactose breath test
D. Serum vitamin B12 level
E. Small intestinal aspirate culture

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old man is tackled when playing rugby and falls heavily on his outstretched arm. Examination by the team doctor reveals that he has loss of contour of the left shoulder. He also has numbness of the C5 dermatome of the left shoulder (the ‘regimental badge area’).
Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged?

A. Axillary nerve
B. Radial nerve
C. Ulnar nerve
D. Median nerve
E. Musculocutaneous nerve

Correct Answer: A

This 32-year-old woman shows these pretibial skin lesions. They are shiny, atrophic patches, the centre of which has a yellow, waxy appearance with telangiectasia. The lesions have grown over the past 3 years. There are no lesions anywhere else on the body.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
With which of the following conditions are these lesions associated?

A. Diabetes mellitus
B. Familial hypercholesterolaemia
C. Graves’ disease
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Venous insufficiency

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old primip is being reviewed on day eight postpartum for unilateral breast pain. The pain started three days ago, and despite continuing to breastfeed, it has not improved. She feels generally ‘run down’, but she is eating and drinking well at present.
On examination, you notice an erythematous, firm and swollen area, in a wedge-shaped distribution, on the left breast. There is a small fissure of the nipple. Examination is painful.
Her observations are stable, and her temperature is 37.7 °C.
Given the above, which is the most appropriate first-line management?

A. Admit the patient to hospital for intravenous antibiotics and drainage
B. Advise her to continue breastfeeding and send a breast milk culture and treat if positive
C. Advise her to continue breastfeeding and start empirical antibiotics
D. Reassure the patient, advise her to continue breastfeeding and offer simple analgesia
E. Reassure the patient, ask her to continue expressing milk and review if there is no improvement in two days

Correct Answer: C

A 73-year-old patient presents with a 2-hour history of sudden-onset abdominal pain, accompanied by a bowel motion and vomiting. He has a past history of non-specific heart problems and takes antihypertensive medication. He has also had a previous appendicectomy performed 45 years ago.
Examination of the abdomen reveals a distended and generally tender abdomen with no guarding. There is a scar present in the right iliac fossa and bowel sounds are absent. Rectal examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) performed is shown below:
Given the clinical scenario, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Small bowel obstruction
B. Large bowel obstruction
C. Caecal volvulus
D. Mesenteric ischaemia
E. Ileus

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old woman has had trouble lactating in the first week after the birth of her second child. She breastfed her first child for nine months. She delivered at term. Six hours post-delivery, she had a heavy post-partum haemorrhage. She was given intravenous (IV) oxytocin and a blood transfusion.
Where is the lesion most likely to be found?

A. Cerebral cortex
B. Hypothalamus
C. Anterior pituitary
D. Posterior pituitary
E. Pituitary stalk

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman was rescued from a house fire. As a result, she suffered from burns on the whole of both legs and her right arm.
What percentage of her total body surface area (TBSA) has been affected?

A. 30%
B. 36%
C. 40%
D. 45%
E. 54%

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man presents with increasing unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. He also complains of vertigo. MRI of the brain is performed and is abnormal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Vestibular nerve schwannoma
B. Cochlear nerve schwannoma
C. Cholesteatoma
D. Otosclerosis
E. Glomus tumour of the middle ear

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old woman reports numbness and ‘pins and needles’ in her left leg that has been present for 48 h following the delivery of her second child. On examination, there is diminished sensation to light touch at the lateral aspect of her left thigh, extending from the iliac crest to the knee. There is no distal sensory loss. There is preserved motor function through all muscle groups of the affected limb. There is no weakness or sensory change in the opposite limb.
What is the most likely anatomical source for this woman’s presentation?

A. Femoral nerve
B. Sciatic nerve
C. Obturator nerve
D. L5 nerve root
E. Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve

Correct Answer: E

You are with the on-call anaesthetist who has been asked to see a 25-year-old man blue-lighted into the Emergency Department. The patient complains of being stung by a wasp while running and reports his arm becoming immediately swollen and red. He kept running but, within a few minutes, began to feel very light-headed and had difficulty breathing. On examination, the patient looks flushed and has a widespread wheeze on auscultation. Blood pressure 76/55 mmHg, heart rate 150 bpm, respiratory rate 32 breaths/minute.
Which of the following is the best initial treatment?

A. Oxygen, intravenous (IV) access, IV adrenaline 50 micrograms and awaiting response before proceeding further
B. Intramuscular (IM) 1 : 1000 adrenaline 500 micrograms
C. Emergency intubation
D. Nebulised adrenaline
E. Oxygen, IM ephedrine 500 mg, IV hydrocortisone 200 mg, IV chlorphenamine 10 mg

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department after attempting to end her life by jumping from a height. On examination, she is conscious and has significant bruising over the occiput region. She reports that her parents are recently divorced and it has caused significant strain on her current relationship and as a result, is failing to do well at work. She has no significant medical history, apart from an incident when she was 17 where she was admitted to the hospital after intentionally taking too many paracetamol.
Which of the following from the patient’s history is most associated with an increased risk of repeated attempts of self-harm/suicide?

A. Dissatisfaction with work
B. Previous attempted suicide
C. Parental divorce
D. Patient's age
E. Patient's strained relationship with partner

Correct Answer: B

A 47-year-old woman presents for her routine cervical smear. She cannot tolerate the insertion of the speculum, and on further questioning, she describes a few months’ history of dyspareunia and burning pain on insertion of tampons. It can last for a few hours after sexual intercourse. There is no vaginal discharge, and the skin appears unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

A. Lichen sclerosus
B. Lichen planus
C. Sexually transmitted infection
D. Provoked vulvodynia
E. Unprovoked vulvodynia

Correct Answer: D

A 72-year-old woman with metastatic carcinoma of the breast is admitted to your ward, as her family are finding it difficult to cope with her deterioration over the past two weeks. She appears drowsy and lethargic. She has known hepatic and bony secondary lesions.
Her admission blood tests are:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 7.9 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 98 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Calcium Ca2+ 3.13 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
PO43− 0.87 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Magnesium (Mg2+) 0.91 mmol/l 0.75 –1.00 mmol/l
Albumin 37 g/l 35–55 g/l
Haemoglobin 103 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 98.3 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 186 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this lady’s hypercalcaemia?

A. Intravenous (iv) pamidronate
B. No intervention
C. Intravenous (iv) normal saline
D. Radiotherapy
E. Oral prednisolone

Correct Answer: C

During a routine physical examination for a new job, a mid-systolic ejection murmur is detected in the left upper sternal border of a 25-year-old woman. Cardiac examination also reveals a prominent right ventricular cardiac impulse and wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a right axis deviation, and a chest X-ray shows enlargement of the right ventricle and atrium.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Mitral regurgitation
B. Mitral stenosis
C. Pulmonary valve stenosis
D. Aortic stenosis
E. Atrial septal defect

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man presents with increasing pain on the left side of the floor of the mouth. He has been in pain on and off for about 2 weeks, particularly during meals. However, the pain has increased significantly over the last 2 days. On examination, he is febrile at 38.2°C. There is a smooth swelling along the floor of the mouth. Intra-oral examination reveals poor dental hygiene and pus oozing into the floor of the mouth anteriorly.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Left submandibular gland infection
B. Dental abscess
C. Mumps parotitis
D. Left submandibular gland calculus
E. Ludwig’s angina

Correct Answer: A

A 12-year-old girl presents to the general practitioner (GP) with her mother. She is due for her human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination, and the patient’s mother has questions regarding the vaccine, Gardasil.
Which strains of HPV is Gardasil targeted against within the immunisation programme?

A. HPV 1 and 2
B. HPV 45
C. HPV 16 and 18
D. HPV 31 and 33
E. HPV 52 and 58

Correct Answer: C

A 31-year-old known insulin-dependent diabetic presents to the Emergency Department, feeling generally unwell and complaining of diarrhoea and vomiting. Their observations are within the normal range, and on examination they look pale and dehydrated.
A venous blood gas is performed which shows the following: pH 7.13, HCO3− A. 14, base excess −8.0. The result of the urea and electrolytes blood test are as follows: Na+ A. 140, K+ 4.0, Cl− 97, urea 4.5, creatinine 67.
What is the patient’s anion gap?

A. 14
B. 22
C. 30
D. 33
E. 36

Correct Answer: D

A young couple presents for infertility assessment. The man, a 21-year-old barman, has a history of recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections. Review of systems is remarkable for cough and shortness of breath on exertion. He often has copious, foul-smelling sputum, which is occasionally blood-tinged. His bowel habits are normal, except for intermittent constipation for a year. He has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome. He has never smoked and drinks alcohol occasionally, on weekends. His vital signs are within normal limits. His nasal mucosa appears congested. There is mild maxillary sinus tenderness on palpation. Scattered wheezing and crackles are noted on lung auscultation. Neurologic and abdominal examinations are otherwise normal. Semen analysis reveals abnormal sperm motility.
What is the most likely additional finding in this patient?

A. Pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhoea
B. Hepatitis and liver fibrosis
C. Lack of heart sounds on the left chest
D. Atopic allergy and asthma
E. Haematuria and glomerulonephritis

Correct Answer: C

This 28-year-old man has erythema, scaling, erosions and blistering around the toes with inter-digital involvement of the left foot only. He has no symptoms apart from pruritus. You suspect the cause may be an infection.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which organism, from the list below, is most likely to have caused this rash?

A. Candida albicans
B. Clostridium perfringens
C. Dermatophyte
D. Proteus
E. Staphylococcus aureus

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old woman presents to the pre-admission clinic for assessment prior to an elective right hemicolectomy. You find no adverse past medical history and examination is unremarkable. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is indicated in all pre-operative patients undergoing major surgery who are over the age of 65. The ECG is shown below.

After having reviewed the ECG, which is the next best step to take with this patient?

A. Refer the patient for an echocardiogram
B. Discuss the patient with the list anaesthetist
C. Cancel the patient’s procedure as her current cardiac condition is too risky to proceed with major surgery
D. No further assessment is required
E. Obtain an exercise treadmill stress test

Correct Answer: D

A 48-year-old woman sees her general practitioner, complaining of constipation and back pain over the past 6 months. Her husband, who accompanies the patient, also commented that his wife had been ‘acting strangely’ during the same time frame. On examination, a nodule is noted in the patient’s neck, just left of the midline. Later investigations showed sodium 140 (135–145 mmol/l), potassium 4.8 (3.5–5.0 mmol/l), chloride 100 (96–106 mmol/l), bicarbonate 24 (24–30 mmol/l), blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 4.3 (2.5–6.1 mmol/l), creatinine 88.4 (50–120 μmol/l), glucose 4.9 (<7 mmol/l), calcium 2.8 (2.2–2.6 mmol/l), magnesium 0.82 (0.75–1.0 mmol/l) and phosphorus 0.58 (0.70–1.40 mmol/l). Her parathyroid hormone level was also elevated. The patient underwent surgical therapy and developed hoarseness following the procedure.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s voice change?

A. Damage to the external laryngeal nerve
B. Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve
C. Damage to the spinal accessory nerve
D. Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve
E. Damage to the vagus nerve

Correct Answer: D

An 82-year-old man presents to the General Practice after seeing blood in the toilet bowl after passing a bowel motion. He is otherwise asymptomatic. You perform a digital rectal examination and note fresh blood in the rectum. While performing the examination, a regular, round mass is noted through the anterior wall of the rectum in the midline.
What is likely being palpated in the anterior rectum?

A. Urinary bladder
B. Sigmoid colon
C. Rectal tumour
D. Pubic symphysis
E. Prostate

Correct Answer: E

A patient is about to undergo a general anaesthetic to remove her appendix.
Which of the following best describes the essential monitoring devices for safe anaesthesia as outlined by the Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland (AAGBI)?

A. Capnography, pulse oximetry, ECG monitoring, invasive blood pressure monitoring (arterial line)
B. Capnography, pulse oximetry, ECG monitoring, non-invasive blood pressure monitoring, airway pressure alarms
C. Pulse oximetry, ECG monitoring, non-invasive blood pressure monitoring
D. Urinary catheter, pulse oximetry, ECG monitoring, non-invasive blood pressure monitoring
E. Capnography, airway pressure alarms

Correct Answer: B

A 37-year-old woman is referred for triple assessment of a lump in the left breast, and the lesion is found to be malignant.
Which of the following is the most common type of breast cancer?

A. Medullary breast cancer
B. Triple-negative breast cancer
C. Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC)
D. Papillary breast cancer
E. Inflammatory breast cancer

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman is taking 40 mg fluoxetine for depression. She is trying to conceive, and her psychiatrist has advised her to switch her antidepressant to sertraline.
Which one of the following regimes is correct for switching from fluoxetine to another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)?

A. Reduce fluoxetine gradually over two weeks, and wait 4–7 days after stopping fluoxetine before starting sertraline
B. Reduce fluoxetine gradually over two weeks, then start sertraline as soon as fluoxetine has stopped
C. Reduce fluoxetine to 20 mg, and cross-taper with low-dose sertraline for two weeks
D. Stop fluoxetine immediately, and start sertraline the following day
E. Stop fluoxetine immediately, wait 4–7 days, then start sertraline

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old man, who is a heavy drinker, presents with massive haematemesis. His vital signs are: pulse = 110 bpm, blood pressure = 80/40 mmHg, temperature = 36.8 °C and respiratory rate = 22 breaths per minute. On physical examination in the Emergency Department, he is noted to have gynaecomastia and caput medusae.
Which of the following conditions is most probably responsible for the haematemesis?

A. Hiatus hernia
B. Oesophageal varices
C. Mallory–Weiss tear
D. Barrett’s oesophagus
E. Oesophageal stricture

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old white man presents to his general practitioner because of progressive low back pain for the past three years. The pain is worse at night when he lies down and gets better as he moves around during the day, but it is not relieved by rest. A thorough history reveals that he has had three episodes of unilateral acute eye pain with photophobia and blurry vision in the past two years.
He saw an ophthalmologist for these symptoms and they resolved with steroids and some kind of eye drop. Plain films reveal some inflammatory and arthritic changes of the sacroiliac joints. His disease continued to progress, and plain films ten years later showed calcification of the anterior spinal ligament.
For which one of the following is the patient most likely positive?

A. HLA-B27
B. Rheumatoid factor
C. HLA-DR3
D. HLA-DR5
E. HLA-B8

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman exhibits worsening hearing in pregnancy. There is no family history of hearing loss. On examination, the tympanic membrane is intact and pure tone audiometry reveals a conductive hearing loss with a Carhart notch.
Where does the problem most likely occur?

A. Tympanic membrane
B. External auditory canal
C. Malleus
D. Incus
E. Stapes

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman says that she has pain in her groin and upper thigh. Upon examination, a lump is palpable below the inguinal ligament, lateral to its attachment to the pubic tubercle.
Through which of the following do you suspect that this may be a hernia passing?

A. Adductor hiatus
B. Femoral canal
C. Obturator canal
D. Deep inguinal ring
E. Superficial inguinal ring

Correct Answer: B

A 60-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 2-month history of a burning sensation in her chest after eating meals. She states that this ‘burning-like pain’ usually takes place after eating heavy meals and can keep her up at night. Although she has tried over-the-counter antacids, this has provided little relief.
The pain is retrosternal, with no radiation, and is not worsened by exertion. She denies pain or difficulty on swallowing. No weight loss is reported. She is concerned that she may be having a heart attack every time this happens as both of her parents died from coronary artery disease. She has no other medical problems and takes no regular medications.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows normal sinus rhythm with no ischaemic changes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)
B. Myocardial infarction (MI)
C. Pancreatitis
D. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD)
E. Pericarditis

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with acute abdominal pain which started about six hours ago. She claims the pain is in the lower abdomen and has been worsening gradually. She has not been able to pass urine since before the pain started.
Upon examination, vital signs are stable and suprapubic tenderness is present. There is no rebound tenderness, and the examining doctor does not find any signs of peritonitis. In addition, the doctor finds a large solid abdominal mass in the right lower quadrant. The patient said this mass had been there for a few years and has made it difficult to get pregnant. The patient also claims that she has heavy periods. She is due to have an operation for it in two months. A serum pregnancy test is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis requiring immediate treatment and admission?

A. Acute urinary retention
B. Appendicitis
C. Caecal tumour
D. Ovarian cyst
E. Uterine fibroid

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old man presents to the Ophthalmology Clinic complaining of blurry vision for objects that are both near and far. He experiences eye strain and his friends have noticed that he squints his eyes all the time. When performing retinoscopy, the reflex looks dimmer/brighter when alternating the axis of the light streak.
What is the first-line treatment for the most likely refractive error that this patient has?

A. Concave lenses
B. Convex lenses
C. Cylindrical lenses
D. Reading glasses
E. Refractive surgery

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old man experiences sudden right-sided chest pain while exercising. The pain persists in the Emergency Department, but he is not short of breath. There is no past medical history of note. Observations are recorded:
temperature 36.6 °C
heart rate (HR) 90 bpm
blood pressure (BP) 115/80 mmHg
respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths/minute
oxygen saturation (SaO2) 99%.
A chest X-ray reveals a 1.5 cm sliver of air in the pleural space of the right lung.
Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Admit for a trial of nebulised salbutamol and observation
B. Aspirate the air with a needle and syringe
C. Insert a chest drain
D. Consider prescribing analgesia and discharge home with information and advice
E. Insert a 16G cannula into the second intercostal space

Correct Answer: D

A 53-year-old woman undergoes a smear test, which reveals an ulcerated lesion on her cervix. The lesion was confirmed to be squamous cell carcinoma.
With which virus is this patient most likely infected?

A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
B. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
C. Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
D. Chlamydia trachomatis
E. Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner, complaining of a lump in her neck. She is a non-smoker and has no significant past medical history. On examination, there is a 2-cm firm, non-tender nodule on the left side of the anterior triangle of the neck, in the area of the thyroid.
Investigations:
Thyroid stimulating hormone: 2.5 mu/l (0.4–4.0 mu/l)
Fine-needle aspiration biopsy: partial papillary architecture with some thyroid follicles present. Thyrocytes are abnormally large with an abnormal nucleus and cytoplasm and frequent mitoses. Psammoma bodies are also demonstrated in the sample.
Which of the following fits best with the underlying diagnosis?

A. Non-toxic multi-nodular goitre
B. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
C. Medullary thyroid carcinoma
D. Follicular thyroid carcinoma
E. Solitary toxic nodule

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus, well controlled on insulin, attends the Fetal Medicine Clinic for a growth scan at 36 weeks. The scan has been unremarkable, and the consultant will discuss the mode and timing of delivery today. The baby is cephalic, and the placenta is posterior and high.
Which of the following statements regarding the mode and timing of delivery in patients with diabetes is correct?

A. In the presence of a macrosomic fetus, vaginal delivery is contraindicated
B. Delivery before 37 weeks is not advised in any scenario
C. Delivery is indicated by induction between 37+0 and 39+6 weeks’ gestation
D. Women with a previous Caesarean section should be advised to have a Caesarean section, as blood glucose can be better controlled
E. Women with gestational diabetes should give birth no later than 40+6 weeks’ gestation

Correct Answer: E

You are asked by a nurse to see a patient with a urine output of 25 ml/hour in the last hour. She is a 74-year-old lady who has just had a knee replacement. She is catheterised. The patient weighs 40 kg and is drinking fluids orally. Pulse is 76 bpm and blood pressure 134/78 mmHg. She is apyrexial. She has a past medical history of aortic valve stenosis.
What would you advise the nurse?

A. The patient is in multiorgan failure
B. The patient has normal urine output
C. The patient has reduced urine output due to ‘post-renal’ kidney failure
D. The patient has reduced urine output due to ‘pre-renal’ kidney failure
E. The patient requires intravenous (IV) fluids

Correct Answer: B

A neonate is born with purpuric skin lesions (blueberry muffin appearance). In the next few weeks it is discovered the baby has a ventricular septal defect, cataracts and hearing problems.
Which vertically transmitted pathogen is most likely to have caused this?

A. Measles
B. Parvovirus B19
C. Cytomegalovirus
D. Rubella
E. Varicella-zoster virus

Correct Answer: D

Your registrar has asked the scrub nurse to hand him the suture shown in the picture above. You recognise that polyglactin sutures are absorbable sutures and remember learning about them and their uses during your surgical term.
Which of the following procedures is your registrar performing that would require the use of these sutures?

A. Circumcision
B. Bowel anastomosis
C. Arterial anastomosis
D. Abdominal wall closure
E. Suturing hernia mesh to the inguinal ligament

Correct Answer: A

A 42-year-old man is on the orthopaedic ward recovering from fractures sustained in a road traffic accident six weeks ago. He has a severe left-sided comminuted tibia for which he had an external fixator placed. He has no known drug allergies.
Investigation Result Normal value
Heat rate (HR) 102 bpm 60–100 bpm
Blood pressure (BP) 109/75 mmHg 100–139/60–99 mmHg
Respiratory rate (RR) 20/min 12–20/min
SaO2 96% (FiO2= 21) >96% (FiO2= 21)
Temperature 38.9 °C 35–37.5 °C
On examination he is noted to have flushed cheeks and peripheries.
An X-ray of the left leg shows signs of osteomyelitis.
Which of the following antibiotic combinations should be prescribed first line while awaiting microbiology culture and sensitivity results?

A. Flucloxacillin and Gentamicin
B. Cefuroxime and linezolid
C. Ceftazidime and Vancomycin
D. Co-amoxiclav and ciprofloxacin
E. Piperacillin-tazobactam (tazocin) and metronidazole

Correct Answer: C

An 85-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history recurrent shortness of breath, bradycardia and episodic hypotension associated with syncope. She has a past medical history of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism. The findings in the investigation below are recurring.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

A. Amiodarone
B. Insertion of an AAI mode pacemaker
C. Insertion of a DDD mode pacemaker
D. Insertion of a VVI mode pacemaker
E. Verapamil + sotalol

Correct Answer: D

An HIV-1-positive man develops multiple raised purple lesions on his legs. His CD4 count is 96 cells/mm3 (> 600 mm3) and his viral load measures greater than 500 000 copies/ml.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Basal-cell carcinomas
B. Cryoglobulinaemia
C. Fixed drug eruption
D. Kaposi’s sarcoma
E. Melanoma

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old previously fit and well man with a 4-day history of feeling under the weather, not tolerating oral fluids and coryzal symptoms, is admitted via referral from his general practitioner. He is triaged by the senior Accident and Emergency (A&E) sister who does a set of observations that are mostly unremarkable, with the exception of a slight tachycardia (104 bpm), and performs a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG). She has also done a set of bloods, but the results are not back yet. She thinks the ECG appears slightly abnormal. She brings it to the A&E senior house officer who confirms that there is broadening of the QRS complexes, loss of P-waves and abnormal T-waves that appear large.
What is the most appropriate initial intervention?

A. 250 ml of NaCl stat
B. 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate
C. Salbutamol nebuliser, 5 mg
D. Get senior support
E. 10 units of Actrapid® with 50% dextrose

Correct Answer: B

A 59-year-old woman presents with warm, swollen, painful knuckles and large subcutaneous nodules near her elbows. She also complains of joint stiffness lasting more than an hour in the morning. Her proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are hyperextended and her distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints are flexed.
If the nodules were biopsied, which of the following would best describe their likely histological appearance?

A. Amorphous crystalline mass surrounded by macrophages
B. Fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading epithelioid cells
C. Cystic space caused by myxoid degeneration of connective tissue
D. Well-encapsulated nodule of polygonal cells within a tendon sheath
E. Darkly pigmented synovium with an exuberant, villous growth

Correct Answer: B

A patient is a frequent attendee at hospital with recurrent attacks of drowsiness, sweating, and palpitations. The blood glucose level during one of the episodes is 2.9 mmol/l. Recovery occurs in response to intravenous 10% dextrose. C-peptide levels are measured and are found to be below the normal range.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Phaeochromocytoma
B. Gastrinoma
C. Glucagonoma
D. Insulinoma
E. Factitious insulin use

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman presents with pain of the wrist and limited movement following a fall. She was out shopping and slipped on a wet patch of grass. She stretched out her arms to help break her fall and landed more heavily on the left hand than the right.
An X-ray of the affected side was taken, with the injury obtained shown.
What is the name of this fracture?

A. Smith
B. Colles'
C. Monteggia
D. Galeazzi
E. Greenstick

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner on the recommendation of the Community Psychiatric Nurse. He has recently been feeling unwell, with a sore throat and fever. He is currently taking clozapine for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
Which of the following investigations would be the most important to perform, given his recent symptoms?

A. Blood glucose
B. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
C. Full blood count
D. Liver function tests
E. Urea and electrolytes

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman was admitted to the Emergency Department with confusion. She has previously been diagnosed with a manic illness. There is no history of alcohol or drug abuse. On examination, she appears mildly jaundiced and has signs of chronic liver disease, including spider naevi and palmar erythema. Also noticeable is a brownish ring discoloration at the limbus of the cornea.
Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Bilirubin 130 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 85 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Ferritin 100 μg/l 10–120 µg/l
Which diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Wilson’s disease
B. Haemochromatosis
C. Alcohol-related cirrhosis
D. Viral hepatitis
E. Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Correct Answer: A

An 87-year-old man falls in a nursing home and is unable to weight-bear on his left leg. On arrival in the Emergency Department, he has a shortened and externally rotated left leg. His foot is warm and well perfused. He can move his toes. Capillary refill time is normal bilaterally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Fractured neck of femur
B. Greenstick fracture of the tibia
C. Hip dislocation
D. Knee dislocation
E. Pelvic ring fracture

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old man is brought to Accident and Emergency by his housemates, who found him vomiting, with a large number of empty packets of pain medication around him. They say the packets were all the same, but they are not sure which medication it was. The patient says his ears are ringing and he feels dizzy, but when asked which medication he took, he says he does not know. An arterial blood gas is obtained which shows the following:
Investigation Result Normal range
pH 7.52 7.35-7.45
paCO2 3.1 4.5-6.0 kPa
paO2 15.2 kPa 10.0-14.0 kPa
HCO3 18 mEq/l 22-28 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely medication the patient has taken?

A. Aspirin
B. Paracetamol
C. Ibuprofen
D. Codeine
E. Naproxen

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of an increasingly painful and swollen right eye. He complains of blurring of vision and pain, especially with eye movements, which are quite restricted.
On examination, the visual acuity is 6/18 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left. The periorbital area of the right eye is very swollen and erythematous. The eye itself is red and proptosed. The conjunctiva was chemosed. Eye movements in the right eye are quite restricted in all directions. There is relative afferent pupillary defect on the right.
Vital observations were as follows:
Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg
Heart rate 75 bpm
Respiratory rate 18 per minute
Oxygen saturation 98% on air
Temperature 37.9 °C
What is the most important step in your management plan to determine the cause of this patient’s eye problem?

A. Blood culture
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the orbit, sinuses, and brain
C. Full blood count, urea and electrolytes, and clotting profile
D. Intravenous cefuroxime
E. Intravenous flucloxacillin

Correct Answer: B

Which of the following molecules combines with the Fc portions of two adjacent immunoglobulin G (IgG) molecules to initiate the classical pathway of complement activation?

A. C1
B. C2
C. C3
D. C4
E. C5

Correct Answer: A

A 60-year-old woman attends the Gynaecology clinic, complaining of vaginal bleeding. She states that her menopause was at age 58 and that she has never been sexually active. She weighs 132 kg and is 5 ft tall. Further investigations confirm malignancy in the suspected organ.
What is the normal histologic appearance of the epithelial lining of this organ?

A. Cuboidal
B. Stratified squamous
C. Glycogen-containing stratified squamous
D. Simple columnar cells
E. Columnar ciliated cells

Correct Answer: D

A 5-year-old girl is exhibiting an unusually wide neck and swelling of her hands and feet. Karyotyping reveals monosomy X and 45X. Physical examination reveals mild aortic stenosis.
Which of the following congenital conditions is most likely associated with this patient?

A. Tetralogy of Fallot
B. Transposition of the great vessels
C. Post-ductal coarctation
D. Patent ductus arteriosus
E. Coarctation of the aorta

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man who presents to the general practitioner with generalised aches, bone pains, headaches and nerve entrapment syndromes that have been plaguing him for many years. His blood results showed an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, and his urine test had an elevated urinary hydroxyproline. The radiograph of his skull showed a combination of lysis and sclerosis with coarsened trabeculae.
Which medication should this patient be started on?

A. Opiate medication to relieve the pain
B. Oral bisphosphonates to inhibit osteoclastic activity
C. Chelation therapy
D. Antidepressant medication
E. Chemotherapy for osteosarcoma

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old man presents with decreased hearing on the right side and a constant ringing sound in his right ear. He also complains of losing his balance when walking and standing. He says that these problems started very recently and he had no problems in the past with his hearing. He presents to the Outpatient Department two months later where a full clinical examination is conducted. On examination, he is well orientated. Central nervous system (CNS) examination shows no abnormality, except for sensorineural hearing loss in his right ear. Examination of the sensory and motor systems reveals no abnormality. Examination of the other organ systems is normal. He has no past history of diabetes, hypertension or heart disease. Imaging studies show a small, well-circumscribed enhancing lesion on his right vestibular nerve. The Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Consultant gives him a description of the various treatments available for his condition.
What is the most appropriate management option to preserve this patient’s hearing?

A. Fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT)
B. Middle fossa approach
C. Observational approach
D. Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS)
E. Translabyrinthine approach

Correct Answer: A

A man is evaluated in the Emergency Department for acute-onset shortness of breath. The doctor notices that the patient’s jugular veins distend when he inspires, even while sitting upright.
Which of the following processes could explain this observation?

A. The patient has venous insufficiency
B. The patient has constrictive pericarditis
C. The patient is dehydrated
D. The patient is suffering from (hepatic veno-occlusive disease) Budd-Chiari syndrome
E. The patient has hepatic vein thrombosis

Correct Answer: B

A 77-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer is in hospice care. He is becoming weaker with loud audible breath sounds and a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. He has a very weak cough.
Which of the following medications may be of most benefit?

A. Saline nebuliser
B. Subcutaneous infusion of hyoscine hydrobromide
C. Intravenous dexamethasone
D. Intravenous morphine
E. Chest physiotherapy

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man attends his gastroenterologist as a result of recurrent diarrhoea. He also complains of sweating episodes and intermittent shortness of breath. Physical examination is significant for a murmur in the pulmonary valve. Urine testing is remarkable for a high level of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid content.
Which of the following substances is likely to be responsible for these findings?

A. Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)
B. Serotonin
C. Somatostatin
D. Nitric oxide
E. Ghrelin

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed and the results of pleural fluid analysis are as follows:
Pleural fluid Pleural fluid analysis Serum Normal value
Protein 2.5 g/dl 7.3 g/dl 6-7.8 g/dl
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 145 IU/l 350 IU/l 100-250 IU/l
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Nephrotic syndrome
B. Breast cancer
C. Heart failure
D. Pneumonia
E. Viral pleuritic

Correct Answer: C

A 20-year-old man collapses suddenly while standing waiting for a train. He is brought into the hospital where he continues to have a reduced level of consciousness, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 9 (E2 V3 M4). On examination it is noted he has pinpoint pupils, low oxygen saturations, and a respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min. He has a patent airway.
What is the most appropriate treatment to institute?

A. Intravenous (IV) fluids
B. Adrenaline
C. Naloxone
D. Intubation
E. Antibiotics

Correct Answer: C

A 78-year-old woman presents with lethargy. She has a history of Graves’ disease and thyrotoxicosis. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are found to be 7.3 μU/l (normal range: 0.17–3.2 μU/l). A full blood count is performed and reveals the following: haemoglobin (Hb) is low, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is high, platelet count is normal, white cell count (WCC) is normal.
What is the most likely cause of her anaemia?

A. Vitamin B12 deficiency
B. Hypothyroidism
C. Pernicious anaemia
D. Folate deficiency
E. Haemolysis

Correct Answer: B

An 82-year-old man is referred to rheumatology out-patients with increasing pain in the left leg. On examination, the left leg is slightly larger than the right and appears slightly deformed. An X-ray demonstrates cortical expansion and coarsening of trabeculae in keeping with Paget’s disease of bone.
What is likely to be found on serum biochemistry?

A. Normal ALP, normal calcium, normal phosphate
B. Normal ALP, raised calcium, normal phosphate
C. Raised ALP, raised calcium, normal phosphate
D. Raised ALP, raised calcium, raised phosphate
E. Raised ALP, normal calcium, normal phosphate

Correct Answer: E

A 73-year-old artist is brought in by her nephew, as she seems to be having episodes of confusion. The nephew goes on to describe a list of symptoms that the clinician feels is characteristic of Lewy body dementia (LBD).
Which of the following is characteristic of LBD?

A. Fluctuating course of confusion
B. Preservation of memory throughout the disease
C. Gait dyspraxia
D. Disinhibition
E. Executive function preserved in the early phase

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old medical student suspects that she may have coeliac disease, after reading up on the condition during her gastroenterology placement. She makes an appointment with her general practitioner (GP) to discuss her concerns, who orders routine blood tests, as well as specific coeliac serology as initial investigation.
Which one of the following conditions is most commonly associated with coeliac disease?

A. Lymphoma
B. Iron deficiency
C. Dermatomyositis
D. Osteopetrosis
E. Infertility

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man has been knocked off his motorbike. He is not badly hurt, but he struck his left wrist against a wall and this has raised a skin flap on the dorsal surface of his wrist. One of the tendons so exposed is that of the extensor pollicis longus and it can be seen changing direction round a bony projection.
Which one of the following does this bony feature represent?

A. Dorsal tubercle of the radius
B. Head of the capitate
C. Hook of the hamate
D. Styloid process of ulna
E. Tubercle of scaphoid

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman is brought into the Emergency Department confused and with a reduced conscious level.
On examination, she is tachypnoeic with a respiratory rate of 30/min. Oxygen saturations are 98%. Urgent blood gases are performed and show pH 7.04, pO2 16.0 kPa, pCO2 2.6 kPa, HCO3- 3 mmol/l.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asthma attack
B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Conn syndrome
E. Diazepam overdose

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man with long-standing insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus was on dialysis, secondary to end-stage renal disease (ESRD). Two months ago, he received a kidney transplant, with his old kidney left in place. The transplanted kidney is attached to the central circulation, mimicking natural circulation. There are absolutely no signs of rejection, and the kidney is working perfectly. The patient is surprised to find out that he no longer has ‘thin blood’ because it has been years since he has not required medical management for his anaemia.
Normalisation of which of the following parameters is most attributable to his new kidney and explains his recovery?

A. Renin
B. Aldosterone
C. Erythropoietin (EPO)
D. Serum iron
E. Phosphate

Correct Answer: C

A patient with rectal cancer is seen by the colorectal nurse specialist and is told about a special blood test to monitor their disease.
Which of the following is this most likely to relate to?

A. Alpha feto-protein (AFP)
B. CA-19-9
C. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
D. C-reactive protein (CRP)
E. CA-125

Correct Answer: C

The wife of a 72-year-old man has read an article about skin cancer and become concerned about the lesion on his back shown in the picture. He is not sure how long it has been present but he says it can catch on his clothes and on a couple of occasions it has bled. He does not mention any recent changes in appearance or growth.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Basal cell carcinoma
B. Malignant melanoma
C. Squamous cell carcinoma
D. Melanocytic naevus
E. Seborrhoeic keratosis

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old mid-level manager is referred by his company after a recent incident. He had been working on a huge deal that would seal his promotion and position in the firm. After months of negotiation, he was just about to close the sale when his client decided to back out of the deal because he had ‘bad karma’ over the prospect. Frustrated by the absurdity of the situation, your patient began yelling, stomping on the floor and banging on a desk until he broke it.
Which one of the following ego defences best describes his behaviour?

A. Identification
B. Dissociation
C. Sublimation
D. Reaction formation
E. Regression

Correct Answer: E

A 78-year-old man with aortic stenosis attended clinic for his yearly follow-up. His blood pressure was 110/90 mmHg. He had a slow-rising carotid pulse.
Which of the following symptoms confers the worst prognosis in aortic stenosis?

A. Chest pain
B. Cough
C. Palpitations
D. Orthostatic dizziness
E. Syncope

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old white man presents to his doctor with symptoms of fatigue and changes to his tongue that he is concerned about. He does not have any other symptoms.
The patient has been a strict vegan for nearly seven years and also suffers from Crohn’s disease. He takes immunomodulation therapy for Crohn’s disease. His observations are normal.
On examination of the mouth, a ‘beefy-red’ tongue is visualised. His neurological examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Folate supplementation
B. Magnesium supplementation
C. Oral steroids
D. Vitamin B12 supplementation
E. Vitamin D supplementation

Correct Answer: D

A 51-year-old woman presents with unrelenting generalised pruritus and yellowish skin discoloration for 3 weeks. The symptoms are gradually worsening. Past medical history is unremarkable. She is post-menopausal, lives with her husband and has a monogamous sexual relationship.
Vital signs are within normal limit. Skin and sclera are icteric. Abdomen is non-distended and non-tender. There is a mild hepatosplenomegaly. Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level is 250 iu/l, aspartate transaminase (AST) level 320 iu/l, alkaline phosphatase level 2500 iu/l, γ-glutamyl transpeptidase level 125 iu/l, total bilirubin level 51.3 μmol/l and direct bilirubin level 35.9 μmol/l. Hepatitis B and C serologic tests are negative. Serum titre of anti-mitochondrial antibody is elevated.
Which of the following medications would best help this patient in the long term?

A. Corticosteroid
B. Etanercept
C. Lamivudine
D. Ursodeoxycholic acid
E. Cholestyramine

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe lower abdominal pain for the last day. She reports that she has had some bloody vaginal discharge. She is currently sexually active. She has a fever of 38.1 °C. On examination, she has uterine tenderness and there is severe cervical motion tenderness.
What is the most important initial investigation in helping to reach a diagnosis?

A. Abdominal ultrasound
B. Cervical and urethral swab
C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
D. Full blood count
E. Pregnancy test

Correct Answer: E

You are looking into the genetic implications for developing Alzheimer’s disease as a part of a research paper.
Which of the following gene alleles is protective against developing Alzheimer's disease?

A. ApoE-e1
B. ApoE-e2
C. ApoE-e3
D. ApoE-e4
E. ApoE-e5

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old women with her 28-year-old partner have come to see you regarding the inability to conceive over the last year. She has regular cycles over 28 days.
Which test will best see if she is ovulating?

A. Basal body temperature
B. Day 2 luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH)
C. Day 21 progesterone
D. Endometrial biopsy
E. Cervical fern test

Correct Answer: C

Following presentation with a breast lump, a 53 year old female is referred to the 2 week wait suspected cancer breast clinic. Further investigation with biopsy reveals a breast carcinoma which is HER-2 positive.
Which of the following immunological therapies should be used?

A. Trastuzumab
B. Infliximab
C. Tamoxifen
D. Rituximab
E. Doxorubicin

Correct Answer: A

A man is being reviewed for a chronic cranial nerve lesion in the outpatient clinic. He has no facial weakness, and examination of the eyes reveals a full range of movement. He reports no difficulties with vision, smell, taste, hearing or balance, and facial and pharyngeal sensation is normal. His gag reflex is present and normal, and he can shrug his shoulders equally on both sides. His speech is slurred and indistinct, and on protruding his tongue, it deviates to the right side and there is notable fasciculation and atrophy of the musculature on the right.
With what are these findings most likely to be associated?

A. Upper motor neurone lesion of the right cranial nerve XII
B. Lower motor neurone lesion of the right cranial nerve XII
C. Upper motor neurone lesion of the left cranial nerve VII
D. Lower motor neurone lesion of the left cranial nerve VII
E. Lower motor neurone lesion of the right glossopharyngeal nerve

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman with clinical signs of hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, severe acne and pigmented areas of skin in the axillae) and multiple ovarian cysts, demonstrated on ultrasound scan of both ovaries, has been trying to conceive for six months, but her periods are irregular. She has lost 2 stones in weight and attends clinic for further advice on management.
Which of the following is the most appropriate step in this patient’s management?

A. Clomifene citrate
A. B. Clomifene citrate and metformin
C. Gonadotrophins
D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
E. Metformin

Correct Answer: A

A 73-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance. The patient is accompanied by his son. The patient is usually bed-bound due to a history of multiple strokes and he lies on a normal mattress at home. The patient is non-verbal due to expressive aphasia and severe autism. The son informs the emergency medicine team that the patient usually has carers four times a day for washing, feeding and repositioning. In the last two days, the son has noted that his father has become more irritable and is not eating as much as he usually would. The patient is able to swallow safely and has no drug allergies.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 37.2 °C
Blood pressure 156/78 mmHg
Heart rate 78 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 15 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
Physical examination reveals a sacral pressure ulcer, 3 cm in diameter, that is erythematous and draining a small amount of thick, white fluid. The wound is approximately 0.5 cm deep and does not extend to the bone. There is no necrotic tissue present. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows normal sinus rhythm with no ischaemic changes and QTc interval of 530 milliseconds. Blood test results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count 14.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein 40 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic for this patient’s infected pressure ulcer?

A. Ceftriaxone
B. Ciprofloxacin
C. Clarithromycin
D. Flucloxacillin
E. Nitrofurantoin

Correct Answer: D

In the last ten years, the UK bowel cancer screening programme has detected 25 000 cases of bowel cancer. Each year, 41 000 people are diagnosed with bowel cancer.
Approximately what percentage of bowel cancer cases are detected through routine screening?

A. 0.0D. 6%
B. 0.D. 6%
C. 3%
D. 6%
E. 60%

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old man is brought in by ambulance to the Emergency Department resuscitation area. As the driver of a car, he has been involved in a head-on collision with a lorry. He suffered a 5-min episode of loss of consciousness and now complains of a severe right temporal headache. His right pupil is slightly larger than his left pupil. You notice that:
his eyes open to speech
he is able to localise pain
he can talk properly after mildly agitating him, but he appears disorientated.
What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. 9
B. 10
C. 11
D. 12
E. 13

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old man sustained this injury to his left shoulder while playing rugby. He is noted to have loss of sensation over the left deltoid region.
Which of the following options is the most appropriate management of this injury?

A. Collar and cuff sling with analgesia
B. Broad arm sling with analgesia
C. Immediate manipulation and reduction under general anaesthesia in theatre
D. Immediate manipulation and reduction under sedation in Emergency Room resus
E. Immediate open operative treatment to prevent neurovascular deficit

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor, complaining of difficulty swallowing solid foods and liquids for the last two months. He states that food often ‘gets stuck’ in his oesophagus and is associated with retrosternal chest pain. There is no pain on swallowing. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications. He denies recent weight loss or night sweats.
Physical examination is normal. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals normal sinus rhythm, with no ischaemic changes. His blood tests are also normal. A diagnosis of diffuse oesophageal spasm is being considered.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?

A. Barium swallow
B. Chest X-ray
C. Lateral cervical spine radiograph
D. Oesophageal manometry
E. Troponin levels

Correct Answer: D

An 8D. 3-year-old woman comes to clinic for consideration of mastectomy for ductal carcinoma of the breast. Your consultant asks you to calculate her performance status. The woman tells you that she spends about a quarter of her day sitting in a chair. She is able to wash, dress and feed herself and has no carers. She says she feels a lot more tired than she did before she was diagnosed with breast cancer: she is unable to walk down to the shops at the end of her road or to dust her house as well as she would like. She is retired.
According to the World Health Organisation (WHO) classification system, what is her performance status?

A. 0
B. 1
C. 2
D. 3
E. 5

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after he finds that his right foot is ‘dropping’ as he walks. You examine his gait and find that he is unable to dorsiflex his foot, although plantar flexion is normal. On further examination, you also find that he has weakness of ankle eversion, and some loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of his calf. Full systemic examination reveals nothing else. He has no significant past medical history, apart from a distal tibial fracture, for which he had a plaster on until 3 days ago. He works as a builder and drinks about 40 units of alcohol a week.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Rheumatoid arthritis
B. Osteoarthritis
C. Common peroneal nerve palsy
D. Peripheral neuropathy
E. Lateral ligament complex injury of the ankle

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with Addison’s disease.
Which of the following is beneficial to prescribe for her in combination with hydrocortisone?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill
B. Progesterone only pill
C. Aspirin
D. Dexamethasone
E. Fludrocortisone

Correct Answer: E

A 37-year-old woman attends her general practice, requesting the combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP). Her past medical history is significant for pelvic inflammatory disease. Her obstetric history is positive for an ectopic pregnancy 1 year ago that was managed with methotrexate. She smokes 20 cigarettes per day. Her mother and sister carry the BRCA1 mutation and she does not wish to undergo genetic testing.
Why should you advise against this form of contraception?

A. History of pelvic inflammatory disease
B. Prior ectopic pregnancy
C. Previous use of methotrexate
D. Smoker
E. Possible BRCA mutation

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old woman, with a background of hypertension and atrial fibrillation who receives treatment with warfarin, suffers a devastating intracranial bleed. Unfortunately, while receiving maximum organ support on the Intensive Care Unit, she makes no recovery. She is assessed for brain death before consideration of withdrawal of organ support.
What medical personnel are required to diagnose brain death?

A. Two consultants competent in the assessment, conduct and interpretation of brainstem examinations
B. Two doctors, one of whom must be a consultant, both fully registered for at least five years and both competent in the assessment, conduct and interpretation of brainstem examinations
C. One intensive care consultant competent in the assessment, conduct and interpretation of brainstem examinations
D. One consultant and one intensive care specialist nurse, both competent in the assessment, conduct and interpretation of brainstem examinations
E. Three doctors, all fully registered for at least two years, all competent in the assessment, conduct and interpretation of brainstem examinations

Correct Answer: B

The pigmentation pattern displayed on this patient’s skin is also displayed on other parts of the skin.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which, of the list below, is the single most likely other condition that this patient may have?

A. Autoimmune thyroid disease
B. Carcinoma of the stomach
C. Malignant melanoma
D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
E. Type II diabetes mellitus

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old man is admitted to the Intensive Therapy Unit after a coronary artery bypass graft for a period of ventilation. He has a 30-pack year smoking history but successfully gave up some 3 years earlier. Unfortunately, weaning does not go as anticipated, and he cannot be weaned off the ventilator and is still in need of it 5 days later. There is evidence of right-sided bronchial breathing on auscultation. He is pyrexial with a temperature of 38.2 °C.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 174 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Haemoglobin 110 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 13.1 × 109/l (10.0) 4–11 × 109/l
Chest X-ray: bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, more marked on the right-hand side
Bronchial aspirates: mixed anaerobes
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Community acquired pneumonia
B. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
C. Infective pulmonary oedema
D. Ventilator acquired pneumonia
E. Pulmonary haemorrhage

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old woman sees an ophthalmologist for difficulties with her vision. She complains of blacking out of her peripheral vision and severe headaches. The ophthalmologist assesses her visual fields and records a finding of bitemporal hemianopia.
The site of the lesion in her optic pathway is likely to be at the level of the:

A. Optic nerve
B. Optic chiasm
C. Optic tract
D. Lateral geniculate nucleus
E. Primary visual cortex

Correct Answer: B

A term baby boy is found to have meconium ileus shortly after birth.
Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with meconium ileus?

A. Down syndrome
B. Myelomeningocele
C. Patau syndrome
D. Edward syndrome
E. Cystic fibrosis

Correct Answer: E

A 33-year-old man with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is admitted to Accident and Emergency unwell, pyrexic and short of breath. Your senior colleague is concerned this patient has Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.
Which one of the following clinical findings is most typical of this condition?

A. Cavitating lesions on chest X-ray (CXR)
B. Desaturation on exercise
C. Presence of cervical lymphadenopathy
D. Accompanying colourless frothy sputum
E. An obstructive pattern of pulmonary function tests (PFTs)

Correct Answer: B

A woman receives a letter in the post inviting her to her first NHS breast screening appointment.
Which of the following best describes the timing and frequency of the UK breast screening programme?

A. 25–64 years of age (five yearly)
B. 45–75 years of age (three yearly)
C. 50–70 years of age (three yearly)
D. 50–70 years of age (five yearly)
E. 60–74 years of age (two yearly)

Correct Answer: C

A mother presents her 6-month old to her General Practitioner (GP) concerned about the appearance of a raised red mark on her cheek. It is now 5 mm in diameter, has a very smooth outline and is a regular circular shape with consistent colour all over. It appeared around two weeks after birth and has gradually been increasing in size over the past few months. The baby was born at full term by normal vaginal delivery and has been generally very well.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Café-au-lait spot
B. Capillary malformation (port wine stain)
C. Infantile haemangioma (strawberry mark)
D. Malignant melanoma
E. Salmon patch (stork mark)

Correct Answer: C

A 13-year-old girl attends the GP with her mother. Her mother is concerned as she has noticed scratch marks on her daughter’s arms and after a long chat her daughter has admitted to cutting herself repeatedly. The GP agrees to refer the girl to CAMHS (Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services).
Which of the following is the most suitable intervention to reduce the risk of recurrence of self-harm?

A. Citalopram
B. Cognitive behavioural therapy
C. Counselling
D. Family therapy
E. Sertraline

Correct Answer: B

A 3-month-old child is brought to the Paediatric Outpatient Department by his mother. He has a history of recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections, recurrent diarrhoea, failure to thrive and numerous hospital admissions in the past. He has now developed mucocutaneous candidiasis. After initial examination, the Paediatric Consultant refers him to the Immunology Department for further management as he suspects possible human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
Which of the following is most likely to suggest a diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCIDS), rather than HIV in this child?

A. Absolute CD3 T-cell count of < 300/mm3
B. Elevated numbers of CD8+ T-cells
C. Lymphocytic proliferation activity to mitogens/antigens
D. Normal T-cell receptor excision circle (TREC) count
E. Thymic shadow in chest X-ray

Correct Answer: A

You are a Foundation Year 2 (FY2) doctor in the Paediatric Emergency Department and see an 8-month-old girl who has been brought in after an episode of rectal bleeding. Her parents tell you that she appears to be suffering from abdominal pain since this morning, drawing her legs up into the fetal position, and has eaten very little, which is unlike her. She vomited about three times and then passed bloody stools. When you ask for further details, the parents tell you that the stool was jelly-like red and very slimy. The parents started weaning the child 2 months ago and only give her baby food.
On examination, the child has right lower abdominal tenderness and her mucous membranes look dehydrated. Her capillary refill time is 4 seconds and you can vaguely feel some sort of mass in her right lower abdomen.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Campylobacter related gastroenteritis
B. Intussusception
C. Colon cancer
D. Hirschsprung’s disease
E. Pyloric stenosis

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with fever, abdominal pain and bright red, bloody bowel movements for the last 12 hours. She has also had multiple episodes of non-bloody vomiting for the last eight hours. She was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis two years ago and has been non-compliant with her management plan.
Her observations are as follows:
Temperature 38.3°C
Blood pressure 105/59 mmHg
Heart rate 105 bpm
Respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute
SpO2 99% (room air)
Examination demonstrates a diffusely tender and distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds.
Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step?

A. Abdominal X-ray
B. Abdominal ultrasound
C. Oesophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGD)
D. Colonoscopy
E. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the kidney, ureters and bladder

Correct Answer: A

A 21-year-old gang member was stabbed in the left upper quadrant and brought to the Emergency Department, with the knife still in his abdomen. A computerised tomography scan demonstrated that the tip of the knife pierced the superior border of the greater omentum at the junction of the body and pyloric antrum of the stomach.
Which of the following vessels is the artery that has been severed by the knife most likely to be a direct branch of?

A. Coeliac trunk
B. Hepatic artery proper
C. Gastroduodenal artery
D. Splenic artery
E. Short gastric artery

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old man with known cardiovascular disease presents with vertigo, difficulty swallowing and unsteadiness of gait. Neurological assessment reveals nystagmus with the quick phase towards the right side and ataxia of the right upper and lower limbs. He has no hearing loss. There is loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face, and the left side of the limbs and trunk. He has drooping of the right side of the palate on eliciting the gag reflex, and right-sided ptosis and miosis.
Which vessel is most likely to be affected by thromboembolism with this set of clinical findings?

A. The right anterior choroidal artery
B. The left anterior choroidal artery
C. The right labyrinthine artery
D. The right anterior inferior cerebellar artery
E. The right posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old man has just been admitted to the medical ward. Two days ago, he returned from a business trip and his history suggests he may have caught an atypical pneumonia. While examining the patient’s chest clinically, you try to determine whether the pneumonia is affecting one lobe in particular or is affecting the whole lung.
On the right side of the patient’s chest, which one of the following surface landmarks would be most likely to mark the boundary between the middle and lower lobes?

A. Fourth costal cartilage
B. Horizontal line at level of sternal angle
C. Horizontal line at level of nipple
D. Ninth costal cartilage
E. Sixth rib

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old healthy pregnant woman is about to give birth to her first child at 9-months gestation. The obstetrician decides to perform a caesarean section.
Which of the following abdominal surgical incisions will the obstetrician most likely use to perform the procedure?

A. Right subcostal incision
B. Median longitudinal incision
C. Transverse incision just below the umbilicus
D. McBurney’s point incision
E. Suprapubic incision

Correct Answer: E

A 26-year-old woman is being consented for a diagnostic laparoscopy for endometriosis. Aside from dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia and difficulty conceiving, she has no past medical history. She takes ibuprofen during menses, but does not take any other medication. She has never had surgery before, and appears nervous.
What common side-effect of laparoscopy should she be warned about before surgery?

A. Incontinence
B. Flatulence
C. Sciatic nerve damage
D. Shoulder pain
E. Pulmonary embolus

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old diabetic is found in an unresponsive state and is brought to the Emergency Department. On admission, the patient is found to have a body mass index (BMI) of 27 kg/m2, and a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is made.
With regard to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which of the following statements is correct?

A. Patients with DKA are at high risk of thromboembolism
B. DKA can be treated with oral hypoglycaemics
C. Respiratory acidosis is typical
D. Hypokalaemia is common at presentation
E. It often occurs in type II diabetes

Correct Answer: A

You are looking into the mechanisms of action of the currently available treatments for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
With regards to HIV, which of the following statements is true?

A. HIV is an adenovirus
B. HIV may be transmitted by oral sex
C. HIV is a DNA virus that uses reverse transcriptase to replicate
D. HIV leads to depletion of CD8 cells
E. HIV-2 is the most common form of HIV in the United Kingdom (UK)

Correct Answer: B

A 75-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with vomiting and central abdominal pain. He has vomited 12 times over the last 24 hours. He reports the vomit to be non-bilious but is beginning to have some small flecks of blood in it. He last moved his bowels three days ago and is no longer passing gas. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension and alcoholism. He has had a previous exploratory laparotomy for a perforated peptic ulcer two years ago.
His observations and blood tests results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Temperature 37.9 °C
Blood pressure 111/59 mmHg
Heart rate 97 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 21 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 98% (room air)
White cell count 15.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein 139 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Physical examination reveals a soft but distended abdomen. There is a central laparotomy scar present. There is moderate tenderness throughout the abdomen with no peritonism. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Rectal examination reveals no stool in the rectal vault, and no blood or melaena. The patient is cannulated and intravenous fluids are prescribed by the doctor.
Which of the following is the best next step in management?

A. Colonoscopy
B. Exploratory laparotomy
C. Intravenous proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy
D. Nasogastric tube insertion
E. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old man with psoriasis affecting the trunk and arms presents to his General Practitioner with persistent symptoms after eight weeks of using once-daily Betnovate® (potent steroid) plus a vitamin D analogue.
What is the next step in the management of this patient?

A. Continue potent steroid and vitamin D analogue for a further four weeks
B. Continue potent steroid alone
C. Refer to Dermatology
D. Start an ultra-potent steroid regime
E. Stop steroid treatment and continue vitamin D analogue twice daily

Correct Answer: E

Following a clinical trial assessing the effectiveness of a new vaccine for the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine versus the currently used vaccine. it is found that the results obtained were affected by a type 1 error.
With respect to biostatistics, which of the following statements is true with regard to type I error?

A. Can also be referred to as a false-negative error
B. Is represented by the Greek letter beta
C. Occurs when an investigator mistakenly concludes that there is no difference between two study populations when a difference exists
D. Decreasing the significance level increases the chance of a type I error being made
E. Occurs when the null hypothesis is rejected erroneously

Correct Answer: E

A 52-year-old clerk presented to the Outpatient Department with pain in her neck for a duration of six months. It started as dull pain initially, but she is now complaining of sensation of electric currents shooting down from her neck to her right hand.
On examination, her shooting-like pain worsens on neck flexion. She has numbness over C4/C5 dermatomes, over her right upper limb.
A cervical spine X-ray was ordered.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lhermitte phenomenon secondary to cervical spondylosis
B. Tension headache
C. Syringomyelia
D. Somatisation syndrome
E. Meningitis

Correct Answer: A

A patient attends the neurology clinic following a referral from the GP due to difficulty with eating and chewing food. A neurologist performs a cranial nerve assessment and suspects a lesion of the right trigeminal nerve.
Which of the following is a clinical feature of a trigeminal nerve palsy?

A. Paralysis of the right buccinator muscle
B. Hyperacusis
C. Loss of taste in anterior two-thirds of the tongue
D. Loss of taste in posterior third of the tongue
E. Bite weakness on the right

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a three-month history of pain and difficulty swallowing when eating solid foods and now also has difficulty swallowing thick soups. He also reports a 4 kg, non-intentional weight loss over the last two months. He has never choked or regurgitated on his food and he does not report any difficulty initiating swallowing. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and drinks approximately 3–4 pints of beer per day.
