He is unaware of family medical history as he was adopted.
His observations are shown below:
Temperature 36.9°C
Blood pressure 145/69 mmHg
Heart rate 65 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 17 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 99% (room air)
Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Achalasia
B. Bulbar palsy
C. Diffuse oesophageal spasm
D. Oesophageal carcinoma
E. Plummer–Vinson syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 38-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department in an intoxicated state. He is complaining that his left hand hurts. On examination, there is swelling and bruising on the hand, particularly at the base of the little finger. An X-ray of the left hand reveals a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this injury?

A. Falling onto the outstretched hand
B. Falling onto the back of the hand
C. Punching somebody
D. Trapping the hand somewhere
E. Dropping an object onto the hand

Correct Answer: C

An 88-year-old woman who lives in a nursing home has recently had a chest infection and is treated with co-amoxiclav for one week. Shortly after the antibiotic course is complete, the woman develops abdominal pain, watery diarrhoea and a temperature of 39.2°C. All other residents in the home are well. A stool sample is sent off as pseudomembranous colitis is suspected.
What is the most likely causative organism in this scenario?

A. Norovirus
B. Escherichia coli
C. Salmonella spp.
D. Clostridium difficile
E. Campylobacter spp.

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old female who is post-partum and on the oral contraceptive pill, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea and vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly and ascites.
What is the most likely cause for this?

A. Alcoholic cirrhosis
B. Pylephlebitis after acute appendicitis
C. Budd-Chiari syndrome
D. Splenectomy
E. Tricuspid valve incompetence

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) for a review of her cardiovascular risk. She is concerned due to a family history of premature ischaemic heart disease, although she feels well at present. She has a history of hypertension which is well controlled with bendroflumethiazide, amlodipine and lisinopril. She has never smoked and drinks only on special occasions.
On examination, her BMI is 30, heart rate is 80 beats per minute regular, and blood pressure is 128/86 mmHg. The GP assesses that the patient is at increased risk of developing heart disease and wishes to start another medication alongside the ones she is already taking.
What additional medication should be considered in this patient?

A. Atorvastatin
B. Metformin
C. Aspirin
D. Warfarin
E. Gliclazide

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 2-month history of weight loss, lethargy, palpitations, sweating and a lump in her throat. Her GP orders tests which show a suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Carbimazole
B. Thyroxine
C. Carbamazepine
D. Surgery
E. Radionuclide Iodine

Correct Answer: A

A 52-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic with involuntary lower and upper limb movements, which started 3 weeks ago. She has a medical history of schizophrenia and has been compliant with her medication for the past 3 months. She is taking haloperidol. On examination, her temperature is 37.5 °C, blood pressure 120/81 mmHg and pulse 98 bpm.
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A. Acute dystonia
B. Akathisia
C. Tardive dyskinesia
D. Malignant hyperthermia
E. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 52-year-old man with a long history of alcoholic cirrhosis complained of severe dysphagia and retrosternal ‘burning’ pain. During oesophagoscopy, the endoscopist advanced the endoscope until its tip reached the oesophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.
Which of the following vertebral levels did the tip of the endoscope most likely reach?

A. T7
B. T8
C. T10
D. T9
E. T12

Correct Answer: C

A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit after a car accident that has left her with a traumatic brain injury. The Consultant believes the patient has met all of the criteria for brainstem death testing and would like to confirm whether this has occurred.
Which of the following reflexes is most likely to be present, even when brainstem death has occurred?

A. Corneal reflexes
B. Gag reflexes
C. Pain reflexes
D. Pupillary reflexes
E. Spinal reflexes

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old woman presents to the Gastroenterology Clinic with constipation that has worsened over the past six weeks. She reports straining during defecation. She has a feeling of incomplete evacuation. She has two children who were born via vaginal delivery with no history of tears. She has had bladder suspension surgery. On examination, her abdomen is soft and non-distended with no palpable masses.
On digital rectal examination, she has an empty rectum. Her resting anal tone is weak but her squeeze tone is normal. She does not relax the puborectalis muscle or the external anal sphincter when simulating defecation; she also has 4-cm perineal descent with straining.
What is the most appropriate investigation to carry out next?

A. Abdominal ultrasound
B. Barium enema
C. Colonoscopy
D. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
E. Magnetic resonance defecography

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man is brought to Accident and Emergency by ambulance, complaining of abdominal pain. He says the pain is 8/10 in strength, radiates to the groin, iliac fossae and back and began suddenly half an hour ago. He cannot identify anything that prompted the pain and has not yet eaten today. He says he also feels dizzy and faint. The man has had two stents after a cardiac arrest in 2011. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia. He smokes 35 cigarettes a day but does not consume alcohol. On examination, the patient looks grey. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, heart rate 126 bpm, respiratory rate 28 breaths/minute and temperature 37.4 °C. He has widespread abdominal tenderness on light palpation. You cannot palpate any masses.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancreatitis
B. Pyelonephritis
C. Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
D. Myocardial infarction
E. Acute cholecystitis

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old woman is upset that she has acne vulgaris with papules, pustules and comedones. She had acne during her teenage years, and it has persisted since then. Her weight is normal, as are her periods, and there is no hirsutism.
Which one of the following is a likely aetiological factor in her case?

A. Bacteria
B. Combined oral contraceptive
C. Diet
D. Excess androgen
E. Poor personal hygiene

Correct Answer: A

A 47-year-old man presents with constant abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The pain came on suddenly. Examination of the abdomen reveals a central mass. You note that he has become clinically shocked.
He has a blood pressure of 76/45, heart rate 150, respiratory rate 28.
Which of these is the most important step in the definitive management of this patient?

A. Arrange a computed tomography (CT) scan
B. Crossmatch blood
C. Administer blood transfusion
D. Arrange for surgery
E. Take blood for amylase level

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old primiparous woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is at 12 weeks’ gestation and attended for her nuchal scan. She is currently on insulin treatment. Her HbA1c at booking was 34 mmol/mol (recommended at pregnancy < 48 mmol/mol).
Which of the following best describes antenatal management of women with pre-existing diabetes in pregnancy?

A. Women with diabetes should be advised to deliver by induction of labour or Caesarean section between 38 and 39+6 weeks’ gestation
B. Women with diabetes and prolonged labour should be offered an induction at 41+6 weeks’ gestation
C. All women with pre-existing diabetes should be offered retinal assessment at 16–20 weeks’ gestation
D. Women with diabetes should be offered serial fetal scanning from 26 weeks’ gestation every four weeks
E. Women with diabetes should be seen in the Joint Diabetes and Antenatal Clinic every one to two weeks throughout their pregnancy

Correct Answer: E

This 12-month-old boy has been brought to clinic by his mother because he has just developed the rash shown in the picture.
Credit: Dr H. C. Robinson/Science Photo Library
She cannot understand why it has appeared because he is otherwise quite well. Just over a week ago, he was mildly unwell. She says he had a slight cold and was probably febrile. His condition was not bad enough to seek medical advice.
Which one of the following could be caused by the illness that the child has?

A. Acute demyelinating encephalitis in this child
B. Bronchopneumonia in this child
C. Congenital deafness due to infection in pregnancy
D. Fetal death if a pregnant woman becomes infected
E. Rheumatic fever in this child

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old woman is referred by her General Practitioner to a Gastroenterologist after she presented with epigastric discomfort and has developed jaundice over several months. The patient denies any pain. She has also noted unintentional weight loss. Upon examination, there is no abdominal tenderness or mass felt. On serology, it is noted that she has recently developed diabetes.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancreatic carcinoma
B. Chronic Pancreatitis
C. Hepatitis
D. Gastritis
E. Hepatocellular carcinoma

Correct Answer: A

An 83-year-old woman presents in the Emergency Department with a 3-week history of increasing confusion and falls. Routine investigations reveal:
FBC: Hb 123 g/l, MCV 86 fl, WCC 7.9 × 109/l, platelets 478 × 109/l
U&Es: Na+ 109 mmol/l, K+ 4.9 mmol/l, urea 5.2 mmol/l, creatinine 76 μmol/l
Which of the following would clinically exclude a diagnosis of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)?

A. Capillary blood glucose = 4.5 mmol/l
B. Blood pressure (BP) = 120/70 mm Hg sitting; BP = 133/74 mm Hg standing
C. Resting pulse 66 bpm regular, good volume
D. Long term treatment with bisoprolol
E. Gross peripheral oedema and ascites

Correct Answer: E

A 53-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper anterior triangle of her neck. She says it has been there for ‘at least a few weeks’ and only started to bother after one of her colleagues pointed it out and asked what it was. She says she feels otherwise well in herself and denies any weight loss or fevers. She thinks her mother had a similar swelling removed, but does not recall the diagnosis. On examination, there is a small, non-tender, smooth, mobile lump. The overlying skin is unchanged in colour or temperature. You cannot move the skin over the top of the lump. The lump does not appear to move on swallowing, or tongue protrusion.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Thyroid carcinoma
B. Thyroid goitre
C. Sternocleidomastoid tumour
D. Sebaceous cyst
E. Lipoma

Correct Answer: D

A 20-year-old man presents with mild jaundice following a flu-like illness. During a review by a gastroenterologist, he has been told that a diagnosis of Gilbert’s syndrome is probable.
Which of the following test results most suggests this diagnosis?

A. Absence of bilirubin in the urine
B. Decreased serum haptoglobin concentration
C. Elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) activity
D. Increased reticulocyte count
E. Increased urinary urobilinogen excretion

Correct Answer: A

You are asked to see a 67-year-old man who has been admitted overnight following a road traffic accident. He sustained extensive bruising to his chest from the steering wheel. The nurses are concerned as he has become hypotensive and tachycardic. There is a history of a previous inferior myocardial infarction some 7 years ago, but nil else of note. On examination his BP is 90/50 mmHg, pulse is 95/min and regular. He looks peripherally shut down. There are muffled heart sounds and pulsus paradoxus.
Investigations – arterial blood gas - reveal:
Investigation Result Normal Value
pH 7.29 7.35–7.45
pO2 11.9 kPa 11.2–14.0 kPa
pCO2 6.1 kPa 4.7–6.0 kPa
ECG Widespread anterior T wave inversion
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cardiac tamponade
B. Myocarditis
C. NE. STEMI
D. Pericarditis
E. STEMI

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old man is admitted to your psychiatric ward in a state of distress saying that he knows for certain that his colleagues are plotting to have him dismissed from work. He says they are spreading malicious rumours about his sexuality and, with the help of the CIA, have bugged his office. In the first week of his admission, he is observed to be responding to unseen stimuli when alone in his room. His family state that he is a lovely lad who never gets into any trouble with drink or drugs. They are very worried because in the last 3 months he has told them he can hear people talking about him to each other when he lies in bed at night. He has no significant medical history.
Which one of the following courses of action would be most appropriate?

A. Commence chlorpromazine
B. Commence clozapine
A. C. Commence chlorpromazine with lorazepam and procyclidine as required
D. Commence olanzapine with lorazepam and procyclidine as required
E. Observe with sedation as required

Correct Answer: D

You are called to see a patient on the ward who has just had a partial thyroidectomy. The nurses were measuring his blood pressure on his arm which causes pain and cramp in his arm and hand. They ask you to review the patient. Examination of his arm is normal. He is otherwise completely stable.
What should you do?

A. Review later if reoccurs
B. Perform an urgent venous blood gas
C. Perform an electrocardiogram (ECG)
D. Nerve conduction studies of his arm in case of nerve pressure damage during surgery
E. Give IV fluids as may be dehydrated

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old girl visits her General Practitioner, following discussions in school about healthy eating. She noted her family had a strong history of cardiovascular disease and wanted to be investigated. The patient was found to have a fasting plasma cholesterol of 15 mmol/l.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of these results?

A. A deficiency of lipoprotein lipase
B. A deficiency of acyl CoA cholesterol acyltransferase (ACAT)
C. A deficiency of apo B-100
D. A high level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL)
E. A high level of lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT)

Correct Answer: C

A 64-year-old man with advanced-stage non-small cell lung carcinoma, following a full course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, is referred to the Surgical Department by his treating oncologist. Over the past two weeks, he has experienced difficulty breathing and pain on the right side of his chest. An X-ray and computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest are performed. The chest X-ray shows a massive right-sided pleural effusion with an ipsilateral mediastinal shift, and the CT scan shows mediastinal pleural thickening with focal nodular areas. Pleural aspiration is done and sent for laboratory investigations.
What is the most appropriate first-line treatment to improve the symptoms of this patient?

A. Pleurectomy
B. Pleurodesis
C. Pleuroperitoneal shunt
D. Radiotherapy
E. Thoracocentesis

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old woman comes to see you after being discharged from hospital following her first unprovoked seizure. She has a normal head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan and encephalogram (EEG) and has not been started on medication. You advise her she must inform the DVLA and should not drive.
Providing the patient remains seizure free, after what time period may she be able to return to driving?

A. Lifetime ban from driving
B. One month
C. One year
D. Six months
E. Straight away

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old man is admitted after a fall and a period of time on the floor. He has a long history of chronic illness and immobility, with medications for hypertension, cardiac failure and chronic chest disease. On examination, he is obese, with a blood pressure of 110/75 mmHg, a pulse of 100 bpm and a temperature of 38.5°C. Respiratory examination reveals evidence of right lower lobe consolidation. He has no signs of traumatic bone injury.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Chest X-ray Right lower lobe pneumonia
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 15.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 312 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 142 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.7 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 15.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 312 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Creatine kinase (CK) 1524 IU/l 23–175 IU/l
Catheter specimen of urine: Red/brown in colour.
+++ for blood.
No red cells on microscopy
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Gram-negative sepsis
B. Acute tubular necrosis due to hypotension
C. Rhabdomyolysis
D. Polymyositis
E. Acute myocardial infarction

Correct Answer: C

A patient has the following hepatitis B serologic test results:
HBsAg: negative
anti-HBc: positive
anti-HBs: positive
IgM anti-HBc: negative
Which of the following is true about the patient’s status to hepatitis B?

A. Acutely infected
B. Chronically infected
C. Immune due to hepatitis B vaccine
D. Immune due to natural infection
E. Susceptible to hepatitis B

Correct Answer: D

You are a fully registered doctor working in a small hospital in the Highlands of Scotland. You have been called to the reception where your patient being treated for acute Crohn’s disease appears very anxious. He is demanding to go home because he is hearing voices that are telling him that everyone in the hospital is going to kill him. The patient is making threats of harm towards his wife, not present, who ‘got’ him ‘into this.’ He is not currently violent towards staff. He does not appear septic.
What is your best course of action?

A. Allow the patient to go, since he has the right to leave at any time.
B. Call his wife and ask her to come to the hospital to deal with her husband.
C. Call the police, since the patient is clearly a risk to others.
D. Detain the patient under an Emergency Detention Certificate.
E. Sedate the patient with a tranquilizer in a cup of tea.

Correct Answer: D

A previously fit and healthy 32-year-old woman attended the GP surgery complaining of headache. It is a unilateral, throbbing headache that has lasted up to 24 h. She also describes some photophobia. There have been a few recurrent attacks over the last month. Neurological examination is unremarkable. She is currently taking the oral contraceptive pill.
Which of the following is most suitable to reduce the frequency of the headache she described?

A. Paracetamol
B. Zolmitriptan
C. Topiramate
D. Pizotifen
E. Propranolol

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a number of small fleshy nodules around and under his finger and toe nails. On further questioning it is noted that the patient has a history of difficult-to-control seizures.
What is the most likely underlying condition?

A. Neurofibromatosis I
B. von Hippel–Lindau disease
A. C. Neurofibromatosis II
D. Tuberous sclerosis
E. Sturge–Weber syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old patient with breast carcinoma is found to have a small (1.5 cm) tumour in the upper outer quadrant (OUQ) of her left breast. One local axillary node is positive, and no metastases are identified on imaging.
What is the correct TNM (Tumour, Nodes, and Metastases) staging for her?

A. T1, N0, M1
B. T2, N1, M0
C. T0, Nx, M0
D. T1, N1, M0
E. T1, N1, Mx

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old man presents to the Clinic with lower back pain and early morning stiffness which slowly improves throughout the day.
Examination reveals reduced forward flexion with positive Schober’s test. A lumbar sacral X-ray confirms changes consistent with ankylosing spondylitis.
Which of the following treatment options would be considered first-line management?

A. Etanercept
B. Ibuprofen
C. Methotrexate
D. Prednisolone
E. Sulfasalazine

Correct Answer: B

A 43-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia no longer reports hallucinations or delusions. However, he spends many hours doing nothing, has trouble reading a book or watching a film and rarely speaks spontaneously or fluently. His grooming is poor and he is socially withdrawn.
What is a positron emission tomography (PET) scan most likely to show?

A. Decreased metabolic activity in the temporal lobes, increased occipital lobe activity
B. Hypoactivity of the prefrontal lobes, enlarged cerebral ventricles
C. Hyperactivity of the prefrontal lobes
D. Symmetrical decrease in volume of ventricles
E. Unilateral increase in volume of fourth ventricle

Correct Answer: B

A new screening test for disease A is trialled on 250 random people. A total of 62 people had a positive test result. Only 32 of these patients were subsequently found to have the condition. A further eight patients with a negative screening test result were found to have the condition.
What is the sensitivity of this test?

A. 24.8%
B. 51.6%
C. 80.0%
D. 85.7%
E. 95.7%

Correct Answer: C

A 46-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department with a history of chronic alcoholism and several episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Examination shows dilatation of the superficial abdominal veins, enlarged breasts, palmar erythema and multiple small, dilated blood vessels on the face and trunk. Upon further investigation, a biopsy of the liver shows evidence of bridging fibrosis and cells with highly eosinophilic, irregularly shaped hyaline bodies close to the nucleus.
The observation of these inclusions indicates the origin of the cells from which one of the following embryonic structures?

A. Ectoderm
B. Yolk sac
C. Mesoderm
D. Endoderm
E. Neural crest

Correct Answer: D

A patient with chronic kidney disease has a creatinine of 350 μmol/l and has persistent proteinuria.
Which one of the following drugs is most likely of benefit to her renal prognosis?

A. Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors
B. Aspirin
C. Clopidogrel
D. Doxazosin
E. Methotrexate

Correct Answer: A

Which area of the brain is most likely damaged in a patient exhibiting hyperkinesis, euphoria, inappropriate behaviour, shallow emotional expression, childish humour with punning and word play (witzelsucht)?

A. Dominant parietal lobe
B. Posterior frontal cortex (Broca area)
C. Orbital, medial prefrontal cortex (magnocellular projections of the medial dorsal thalamus)
D. Superior and inferior occipital gyri
E. Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (parvicellular projections of the medial dorsal thalamus)

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old window cleaner presents to the Minor Injuries Unit, having fallen off the third rung of a ladder and hit his head on the pavement. He has been feeling well since the accident; there was no reported loss of consciousness and the patient is able to give you a full account of what happened. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 15/15. There is no neurological abnormality on examination. You note no external injury other than a bruise behind his left ear.
Select the most appropriate management option?

A. Admit the patient for neurological observation
B. Discharge the patient home with standard head injury advice
C. Observe the patient in the department for the next 2 hours and discharge home with standard head injury advice if there is no deterioration
D. Arrange an urgent CT head scan
E. Arrange an urgent MR brain

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old man is brought in by ambulance to the Emergency Department resuscitation area. As the driver of a car, he has been involved in a head-on collision with a lorry. You notice that:
his eyes open to pain
his elbows abnormally flex to pain
he talks with inappropriate words.
What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?

A. 7
B. 8
C. 9
D. 10
E. Unable to assess

Correct Answer: B

Following a bee sting, a 19-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with a swollen face and lips, accompanied by wheeze. He is finding it difficult to breathe and his blood pressure is 83/45 mmHg from a manual reading.
What should be done next?

A. Give 1 : 1000 IV adrenaline + IV hydrocortisone
B. Observe and arrange transfer to Casualty
C. Give IV hydrocortisone
D. Give 1 : 1000 IM adrenaline and repeat after 5 min if no improvement
E. Give 1 : 10 000 IV adrenaline + IV hydrocortisone

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old man, who has recently started university, is taken to the Emergency Department by his friends early on a Saturday evening. His friends report he has vomited several times and that he appears confused and ‘not himself’. On examination, the patient appears disorientated and unwell. His temperature is 37.4 °C, heart rate 120 bpm and regular, blood pressure 104/66 mmHg. He has dry mucous membranes and his breath smells like nail polish remover. The chest is normal on auscultation, and his abdomen is soft and appears to be non-tender. Capillary blood glucose is 27 mmol/l, and urine dip is strongly positive for glucose and ketones.
Arterial blood gas (ABG) results are given below:
Investigation Result Normal range
pH 6.9 7.35–7.45
paCO2 3.3 kPa 4.5–6.0 kPa
paO2 12.8 kPa 10.0–14.0 kPa
HCO3 8.5 mEq/l 22–28 mmol/l
Which is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Urgent toxicology screen
B. Oral rehydration with regular observations
C. Urgent computerised tomography (CT) brain
D. IV fluids and fixed-rate insulin infusion
E. IV fluids and variable-rate insulin infusion

Correct Answer: D

A 4-year-old boy with a confirmed peanut allergy is rushed to the Emergency Department with rapid-onset urticaria and angioedema, but no breathing difficulties.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Take blood samples, give oxygen, give broad spectrum antibiotics
B. Assess airway, breathing and circulation (ABC), give 0.01 ml/kg intramuscular (IM) adrenaline and monitor for signs of anaphylaxis
C. Assess ABC, give a dose of an appropriate antihistamine and monitor for signs of anaphylaxis
D. Give high-dose prednisolone, and prepare equipment for tracheostomy
E. Reassure the parents while monitoring the patient before allowing them to go home

Correct Answer: C

A 24-year-old known epileptic patient complains of a 4-day history of unsteadiness and altered vision. Colleagues have commented that he appears drunk while at work. He attended Neurology Outpatients 3 weeks previously. On examination today: wide-based gait, past pointing and intention tremor.
Which one of the following medications is most likely to be responsible?

A. Phenytoin
B. Sodium valproate
C. Carbamazepine
D. Atenolol
E. Gabapentin

Correct Answer: A

An 8-year-old boy has fallen on his outstretched right arm and sustained a displaced supracondylar fracture of his humerus. The fracture is reduced under anaesthesia and the limb immobilised in plaster. The following day, the fracture is reviewed. The boy’s fingers are cold. He is unable to extend his fingers fully, and there is pain in the forearm when passive extension of his fingers is attempted.
In addition to the humerus, which structure is most likely to have been injured by the fracture?

A. Basilic vein
B. Brachial artery
C. Extensor digitorum muscle
D. Radial nerve
E. Sympathetic trunk

Correct Answer: B

The inflammatory changes shown around the mouth of this 22-year-old woman are slightly painful.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which of these options is most likely to be a predisposing factor in this case?

A. Chronic hepatitis B infection
B. Crohn’s disease
C. Ill-fitting dentures
D. Scleroderma
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Correct Answer: B

A 75-year-old patient with hypertension is brought to his general practitioner by his wife because of haematuria. While taking the history, it becomes apparent that he has had blood in his urine for the past three months and it has gotten progressively worse. Now he also has right flank pain. He has lost 4.5 kg (10 lb) in the past month without trying. He denies dysuria, fever, nausea and chills. His family history is significant only for ‘heart problems’ in both parents. He has a 50-pack-year history, drinks an occasional beer and denies any history of illicit drug use. On examination, he is afebrile and his vital signs are stable. On deep palpation of his right upper quadrant, there is a firm, non-mobile mass.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic pyelonephritis with abscess formation
B. Partially obstructive renal calculus
C. Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
D. Prostate cancer with retroperitoneal metastases
E. Renal cell carcinoma

Correct Answer: E

A 36-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a lateral ankle injury. This injury occurred while playing football the previous day. He continued playing but noted some discomfort at the time and thereafter. He is able to weight-bear with minor discomfort. On examination, there is some swelling over the ankle, a small amount of bruising and minimal tenderness on palpation. There is full range of movement in the ankle joint. He has not taken any analgesia.
What is the best management of this man’s injury?

A. Refer for ankle X-ray
B. Orthopaedic referral
C. Advise immobilisation of the ankle for three to four weeks
D. Advise rest, ice, compression and elevation of the ankle for one to two days, followed by early mobilisation
E. Backslab immobilisation for ten days, followed by rehabilitation

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old woman has been admitted to a psychiatric ward for a sixth time. She is withdrawn, irritable, restless and afraid. She says that she has been depressed for about 7 weeks. She has insomnia, loss of appetite and weight loss. She also has suicidal ideation with a plan to overdose on medicine, which she has done in the past under the influence of commanding auditory hallucinations. She hears voices often even when she is not depressed, but they only talk of suicide when she is depressed. She was divorced 10 years ago and has trouble holding jobs due to her paranoia and odd behaviour.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Major depressive episode
B. Dysthymic disorder
A. C. Major depressive episode with mood congruent psychotic features
A. D. Major depressive episode with mood incongruent psychotic features
E. Schizoaffective disorder, depressed

Correct Answer: E

A concerned mother brings her 6-year-old son to the Emergency Department as she is worried about his left knee. The child injured his knee while playing in the garden, and the knee is now profoundly swollen and he is in a great deal of pain. The mother reports that the child easily bruises. The mother does not have any such problems but the mother’s brother had similar problems when he was young.
What is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism causing this boy’s symptoms?

A. Deficiency of a protein found in endothelial cells and released by endothelial damage
B. A translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22
C. Deficiency of a clotting factor in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation
D. Deficiency of a clotting factor in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation
E. Invasion of bone marrow by leukaemic cells

Correct Answer: C

During the medical post-take ward round, the on-call consultant is quizzing the junior members of the team on ways of differentiating between the different types of dementia by symptomatology.
Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Alzheimer's disease?

A. Pseudobulbar palsy
B. Emotional lability
C. Agnosia
D. Apathetic mood
E. Marche à petits pas

Correct Answer: C

Which cell of the immune system is genetically programmed to recognise virus-infected or malignantly transformed cells without interaction with the thymus gland?

A. Helper T cells
B. Suppressor T cells
C. Natural killer (NK) cells
D. Macrophages
E. B cells

Correct Answer: C

You are studying the different types of arthritides as a part of your rheumatology rotation.
Which of the following statements is true with regard to seronegative arthritides?

A. Cartilaginous joints are rarely affected
B. Symmetrical oligoarthritis is typical
C. Associated pulmonary fibrosis typically affects the lung bases
D. Enthesitis is typical
E. Scleritis is common

Correct Answer: D

A 52-year-old man with treatment-resistant dyspepsia was under investigation at the local hospital. During oesophago-gastro-duodenoscopy (OGD), the endoscopist advanced the endoscope until its tip reached the oesophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.
Which of the following vertebral levels did the tip of the endoscope most likely reach?

A. T7
B. T8
C. T10
D. T11
E. T12

Correct Answer: C

A 47-year-old woman is referred for further evaluation after an abnormal routine mammogram. Biopsy of a left breast mass shows high-grade malignant ductal epithelial cells with dark staining nuclei and several mitotic figures visible under high-power field. Necrosis and central calcification are noted and the basement membrane appears intact.
Based on the biopsy findings, which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lobular carcinoma in situ
B. Anaplastic carcinoma
C. Mucinous carcinoma
D. Comedocarcinoma
E. Inflammatory carcinoma

Correct Answer: D

You see a 43-year-old woman in clinic at the General Practice surgery where you are working as a Foundation Year 2 doctor. She has a diagnosis of moderate depression and would like to try an antidepressant alongside her cognitive behavioural therapy, which is due to begin in 2 weeks. She has no significant past medical history and is not on any prescribed or over-the-counter medications.
Which of the following antidepressant medications would be most appropriate as the first-line treatment?

A. Citalopram
B. Amitriptyline
C. Carbamazepine
D. Lithium
E. Phenelzine

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old woman is found outdoors during the early hours of the morning having fallen to the ground. She is confused and unsure of what has happened. She is admitted to hospital. An abbreviated mental test (AMT) is carried out and she scores 4/10. On examination she has crackles at the base of the right lung.
Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
C-reactive protein (CRP) 89 mg/l < 10 mg/l
White cell count (WCC) 15 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 11.4 × 109/l 5–7.58 × 109/l
The rest of her bloods, full blood count (FBC), urea and electrolytes (U&Es) and liver function test (LFT), were normal.
Observations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Respiratory rate 32 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Oxygen saturation 90% on air
Heart rate (HR) 88 beats/min 60–100 beats/min
Blood pressure (BP) 105/68 mmHg Hypertension: >120/80 mmHg*
Hypotension: <90/60 mmHg*
Temperature 39.1°C 1–37.2°C
*Should be based on the individuals clinical picture. Values are given as estimates for normal ranges.
What is the most appropriate management of this patient based on her CURB 65 score?

A. Discharge home without follow-up
B. Admit her to a general ward for treatment
C. Admit the patient and consider ITU
D. Discharge home with advice to see her GP the following day
E. Admit her to the hospital for observation

Correct Answer: C

A systematic review and meta-analysis is used to look at the effects on myocardial events, using a new cholesterol lowering medication. The analysis shows that the review has a high level of heterogeneity.
What analysis should next take place to determine the possible cause of the high levels of heterogeneity?

A. Random-effects meta-analysis
B. Fixed-effects meta-analysis
C. Sub-group analysis
D. Intention to treat analysis
E. Number needed to treat analysis

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman attends an Infertility clinic. She complains of irregular periods and has been unable to get pregnant for 18 months. On examination, she is obese (body mass index (BMI) 31) and is hirsute. Androgen levels are mildly elevated.
What is the most likely cause?

A. Anorexia nervosa
B. Hypothyroidism
C. Turner syndrome
D. Polycystic ovarian syndrome
E. Prolactinoma

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by her father after attempting suicide with an overdose of medication. Upon questioning, she says that she has recently broken up with her boyfriend and that he does not let her use cocaine and marijuana. This is the second time that they have broken up, and she tells you that she fights constantly with him. Hospital records show that she has been admitted to hospital many times and that she has had many previous suicide attempts. She admits to drinking heavily at weekends and to having had unprotected sex with multiple partners over the last year.
Which one of the following personality disorders best describes this patient?

A. Avoidant
B. Borderline
C. Dependent
D. Schizoid
E. Schizotypal

Correct Answer: B

A patient with advanced cancer of the pancreas and intractable pain is brought to the operating room for a neurolytic procedure under fluoroscopic guidance. The surgeon injects 20 ml of 50% alcohol in a retrocrural position, expecting the injection to spread in a cephalic direction to produce a splanchnic nerve neurolytic blockade.
Which of the following statements regarding the greater splanchnic nerve is true?

A. It consists of postsynaptic fibres
B. It arises from segments T10–11 of the thoracic cord
C. It is composed of mostly nonmyelinated axons
D. It passes to the coeliac ganglion
E. It carries parasympathetic fibres

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old woman attends the general practice surgery with a history of headache for the last few months. She describes it as ‘feeling like a tight band, all over her head’. It is present most days but has not stopped her from working. She feels fatigued as a result of this headache but has not experienced any nausea or vomiting. She takes occasional paracetamol and ibuprofen, which sometimes help.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic tension headache
B. Cluster headache
C. Trigeminal neuralgia
D. Migraine
E. Medication overuse headache

Correct Answer: A

A 69-year-old man attends the Emergency Department with a 3-day history of a warm, red, tender right lower leg. He thinks it is the result of banging his leg against a wooden stool at home. He has a past medical history of diabetes. He is unable to recall his drug history and is unsure of his allergies, although he recalls having ‘a serious reaction’ to an antibiotic as a child.
You diagnose cellulitis and prescribe an initial dose of flucloxacillin, which is shortly administered. Several minutes later, the nurse asks for an urgent review of the patient since the patient has become very anxious and has developed a hoarse voice. You attend the patient and note swelling of the tongue and lips. As you take the patient’s wrist to feel the rapid pulse, you also note cool fingers. A wheeze is audible on auscultation of the chest and patchy erythema is visible. You ask the nurse for observations and she informs you the respiratory rate is 29 and systolic blood pressure 90 mmHg. You treat the patient for an anaphylactic reaction, administering high-flow oxygen, intravenous (iv) fluid, adrenaline, hydrocortisone and chlorphenamine.
What is the dose of adrenaline you would use?

A. 0.5 ml of 1 in 1000 intramuscular (im)
B. 0.5 ml of 1 in 1000 iv
C. 1 ml of 1 in 10 000 im
D. 1 ml of 1 in 10 000 iv
E. 1.5 ml of 1 in 10 000 iv

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old woman complains of a 1-week history of seeing an 'arc of white light and some cobwebs' in her vision with eye movements in her right eye. She also mentions that her vision in the right eye is now very blurry. She has no recent trauma.
She is myopic in both eyes. She has no significant past medical history.
On examination, her vision is 6/18 in the right, 6/6 in the left. Both anterior segments are unremarkable. On dilated fundoscopy, the view of the right fundus seems to be blocked by some red and grey matter in the vitreous and the left fundus is unremarkable.
What is the next most appropriate management step in order to determine the underlying cause of the findings in the right fundus?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head
B. Examine the entire fundus with a slit lamp and Volk lenses
C. Examine the entire fundus with scleral indentation
D. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) of the macula
E. Ultrasound B-scan of the eye

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old housewife is becoming increasingly concerned that she may be developing Alzheimer’s disease, a condition that both her grandmothers had suffered from. She describes often having difficulty remembering where she last left her keys, and sometimes walks into a room and forgets why she had gone there in the first place. She would like to find out more about the early signs of the disease to see if they match her symptoms.
Which of the following is a common clinical feature of the early phase of Alzheimer's disease?

A. Retention of executive function
B. Episodic confusion
C. Disinhibition
D. Impulsivity
E. Bradykinesia

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old man has vague chest pain of 6 hours’ duration. Electrocardiographic (ECG) changes are non-specific, and cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Over the next 48 hours, the pain localises to the left side of the chest and becomes sharper, worse when lying supine and on inspiration. Pericarditis is diagnosed.
Which of the following statements is true regarding the pericardium?

A. The visceral layer of the serous pericardium derives from the embryonic endoderm
B. The fibrous pericardium is an ectodermal derivative
C. The fibrous pericardium adheres to the heart muscle
D. The transverse sinus of the pericardium can be found behind the major vessels emerging from the ventricles, but in front of the superior vena cava
E. The parietal layer of the serous pericardium is called the epicardium

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old woman attends the drop in sexual health service as she has been suffering with an offensive vaginal discharge. The discharge is thin and grey, and smells fishy. She has had unprotected intercourse with a man who is not a regular partner within the previous fortnight.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the appropriate treatment?

A. Metronidazole po bd 400 mg for 5–7 days
B. Azithromycin po 1 g STAT
C. Ceftriaxone im 500 mg STAT followed by oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 10–15 days
D. Ceftriaxone im 500 mg STAT plus azithromycin po 1 g STAT
E. Doxycycline po 100 mg bd for 7 days

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old man sees his GP for problems with hay-fever. He works as a heavy goods driver, and wants advice on which antihistamine he can take, as he is aware that some antihistamines can make you drowsy.
Which antihistamine would you suggest that the patient can safely use?

A. Diphenhydramine
B. Chlorphenamine
C. Cimetidine
D. Cinnarizine
E. Loratadine

Correct Answer: E

A 24-year-old woman presents to the Eye Casualty with a painful reduction in vision in her left eye over the last five hours. She has no complaints of any other symptoms. She is normally fit and well.
On examination, her visual acuity is 6/6 in the right eye and 6/36 in the left. Colour vision is reduced in the left eye. Eye movements show no diplopia, but the pain gets worse. Performance of the swinging torch test reveals that the left pupil dilated when the torch light swings from the right eye to the left. Dilated fundoscopy shows a swollen optic disc in her left eye.
What is the first-line treatment for this condition?

A. Glatiramer acetate
B. Interferon beta
C. Intravenous methylprednisolone
D. Natalizumab
E. Oral prednisolone

Correct Answer: C

Please have a look at the picture below:
This patient has been referred to the Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Outpatient Clinic with a slow-growing facial lump. He denies any other symptoms and is constitutionally well. A parotid swelling is confirmed by radiology.
Which of the following pathologies is he most likely to have?

A. Lymphoma
B. Parotid adenitis
C. Parotid abscess
D. Pleomorphic adenoma
E. Adenocarcinoma of the parotid

Correct Answer: D

A 23-year-old man is admitted to the surgical assessment unit after referral from his general practitioner (GP) for suspected appendicitis. The letter from the GP informs you that the patient has a fever and gives a ‘typical history’ of an acute appendicitis.
Below is a schematic diagram of a patient’s abdomen with areas labelled:
What is the typical history of an acute appendicitis?

A. A dull ache at 4, radiating to a sharp pain at 3 after a few hours
B. A sharp pain at 2, radiating through to the back after a few hours
C. A dull ache at 1, radiating to a sharp pain at 4 after a few hours
D. A dull ache at 2, radiating to sharp pain at 4 after a few hours
E. A sharp pain at 4 which does not radiate

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with dysmenorrhoea. She has a background of asthma and is unable to take ibuprofen, as it has previously triggered a severe asthma attack. She has an ultrasound scan which shows no underlying pelvic pathology.
Which of the following would be a suitable treatment for dysmenorrhoea in this patient?

A. Gabapentin
B. Mefenamic acid
C. Naproxen
D. Oral morphine
E. Paracetamol

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old man presents to his general practise complaining of a painful right ear, ongoing for several weeks with associated hearing loss. There is no significant discharge from his ear, and he has had no fevers. He mentions that his ear pain can also be felt in his jaw, and sometimes his jaw clicks. On examination, there is cerumen in his right ear, and the ear is not inflamed. Tympanic membrane is normal. His pain is recreated by moving his jaw.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Otitis externa
B. Cholesteatoma
C. TMJ dysfunction
D. Mastoiditis
E. Acute otitis media

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother. She reports that her daughter has not yet had her first period, although her two sisters both experienced menarche at the age of 12. She also reports a history of red-green colour blindness and an inability to smell. On physical examination, there is little axillary and pubic hair, and the patient is noted to be Tanner stage II.
Which one of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

A. ↑ gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH), ↓ luteinising hormone (LH), ↓ follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), ↓ oestrogen
B. ↑ GnRH, ↑ LH, ↑ FSH, ↓ oestrogen
C. ↓ GnRH, ↓ LH, ↓ FSH, ↑ oestrogen
D. ↑ GnRH, ↔ LH, ↔ FSH, ↓ oestrogen
E. ↓ GnRH, ↓ LH, ↓ FSH, ↓ oestrogen

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year old man has significant tics, but his language, memory and insight are only mildly to moderately impaired. He also has prominent depression and a butterfly pattern in the caudate nucleus on computed tomography (CT) scan.
Which is the most likely form of dementia in this patient?

A. Dementia due to Parkinson’s disease
B. Dementia due to Huntington’s disease
C. Vascular dementia
D. Dementia of the Alzheimer type
E. Dementia due to normal pressure hydrocephalus

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old woman, who has recently given birth to a baby girl, presents with a one-day history of increasing pain and swelling of the right breast. She has been breastfeeding her 2-week-old baby but has been experiencing some difficulty with the baby latching on properly at feeding times.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.1 °C and her blood pressure is 118/65 mmHg. Her pulse is 85 bpm and regular.
Examination of the breast reveals a large, wedge-shaped area of swelling and erythema on the right breast, which is tender to palpation. There is also some cracking and fissuring to the nipple area.
Which of the following options would be the most appropriate to manage this patient?

A. Advise to discontinue breastfeeding or expressing to rest the breast
B. Advise to continue breastfeeding and start oral flucloxacillin
C. Admit the patient to hospital for intravenous (IV) antibiotics
D. Advise to discontinue breastfeeding and start oral flucloxacillin
E. Advise that the patient avoids non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) analgesia while breastfeeding

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old woman attends her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of a 2-month history of hot flushes, worse at night, that interfere with her sleep and work. She tells you she is very tired and embarrassed at work; she sweats profusely when the attack occurs and she needs to take extra clothes with her to get changed. She is tearful and reports she has been avoiding sexual intercourse because it has become painful.
She is normally fit and well and takes no medication. She still has menses, but these have become very irregular, once every 2–3 months.
Following a lot of discussion, she decides to start hormone replacement therapy (HRT).
Which of the following would be the most appropriate HRT regime for this patient?

A. Oestradiol orally once daily
B. Oestradiol one tablet daily for a 3-month period, with norethisterone on the last 14 days
C. Oestradiol one tablet daily, with norethisterone on the last 14 days of the cycle
D. Oestradiol with norethisterone orally once daily
E. Oestradiol transdermal patch

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old obese patient, on post-operative day 2 after a gastric bypass operation for weight reduction, complains of sudden onset of severe right-sided chest pain accompanied by tachypnoea, tachycardia and desaturation. The pain is pleuritic in origin.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation for this patient?

A. Ventilation–perfusion scan
B. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
C. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
D. Chest radiograph
E. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old man on palliative chemotherapy for advanced lung cancer is brought to the Emergency Department by his wife as he has been feeling increasingly weak and lethargic over the past few days. His arterial blood gas results are below:

Investigation Result Normal range
pH 7.51 7.35–7.45
Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) 11.7 kPa > 11 kPa
Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) 5.5 kPa 4.7–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate (HCO3−) 29 mEq/l 22–26 mEq/l
Base excess +3 -2 to +2
Which of the following is most likely to cause this result?

A. Anxiety
B. Aspirin overdose
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Respiratory depression
E. Vomiting

Correct Answer: E

A patient with severe intermittent claudication undergoes an axillo-bifemoral bypass. Two days after the operation, he develops pain in the leg. Examination reveals a warm, erythaematous swelling in the groin.
What complication has occurred?

A. The graft has blocked
B. Anastomotic aneurysm
C. The graft has become infected
D. The graft has caused an embolism
E. Anastomotic leak

Correct Answer: C

A 39-year-old man has noticed progressive enlargement of his hands and feet over the past 3 years, resulting in increasing glove and shoe size. One year ago, a deepening of his voice was noted. His family has observed that he snores most of the time and he reports occasional episodes of daytime sleepiness. For 5 months, he has had progressive blurring of vision with associated headache and dizziness. Visual acuity examination shows 20/20-1. Visual field testing shows bitemporal hemianopias.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first line investigation to confirm a diagnosis in this man?

A. Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) with growth hormone assay
B. Insulin tolerance test
C. Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) measurement
D. Random growth hormone (GH) assay
E. Serum prolactin

Correct Answer: C

A 79-year-old woman is admitted with new-onset confusion. She is normally active and helps out in her local charity shop. When she failed to turn up at work, a colleague went to the patient’s house. Her colleague noted that the patient did not seem to recognise her when she opened the door and was talking incoherently, which prompted the colleague to call an ambulance.
Which of the following differentiates delirium from dementia?

A. Visual hallucinations
B. Impaired memory
C. Fluctuating level of consciousness
D. Dysarthria
E. Urinary incontinence

Correct Answer: C

A woman requires an episiotomy during labour. The incision should be made:

A. Posterior to the vagina, mediolaterally into the soft tissues of the perineum and the perineal skin
B. Posterior to the vagina, straight down the mid-line into the soft tissues of the perineum and the perineal skin
C. Anterior to the vagina, straight up the mid-line so that the incision lies mid-way between the vagina and the external urethral orifice
D. Anterior to the vagina, mediolaterally into the labium minus
E. One incision anterior to the vagina and one incision posterior to the vagina down the mid-line

Correct Answer: A

A 47-year-old man has been brought into Accident and Emergency, after being rescued from a fire in his home by firefighters. He has extensive burns across most of his torso and lower limbs; however, on assessment, his airway is patent and he currently has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 11. Paramedics have already been able to gain bilateral wide-bore access in both antecubital fossae. He weighs approximately 90 kg, and estimates from the paramedics are that 55% of his body is covered by burns, mostly second-degree, but with some areas of third-degree burns. His observations are:
Temperature 36.2 °C
Blood pressure 102/73 mmHg
Heart rate 112 bpm
Saturations 96% on room air
Respiratory rate 22 breaths/min
What would be the most appropriate initial method of fluid resuscitation?

A. Gelofusin 1 litre over 1 h
B. Hartmann’s 2 litre over 1 h
C. Maintenance fluids based on electrolyte losses
D. Maintenance fluids based on the Parkland formula
E. Maintenance fluids based on the amount of oral intake

Correct Answer: B

A 64-year-old moderately obese man is rushed to the Emergency Department. He complains of shortness of breath and severe chest pain. A physical examination suggests a pericardial tamponade, which is confirmed by an electrocardiogram (ECG) with total electrical alternans, and an echocardiogram showing pericardial effusion.
Which jugular vein is commonly the best measure of central venous pressure (CVP)?

A. Right anterior
B. Right internal
C. Right external
D. Left internal
E. Left external

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman is referred by her general practitioner to the Breast Outpatient Clinic, having found a lump in her left breast. On examination, she has a solid hard mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Axillary examination reveals no lymphadenopathy.
How should this lump be evaluated?

A. Triple assessment, including clinical examination, biopsy and breast computed tomography (CT) scan
B. Triple assessment, including clinical examination, biopsy and breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
C. Triple assessment, including clinical examination, biopsy and mammography
D. Triple assessment, including clinical examination, biopsy and ultrasound scan of the breast
E. Sentinel lymph node biopsy

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old Afro-Carribbean man presents to the Emergency Department with acute severe chest pain, fever and a cough, which he has had for five days. Examination revealed signs of jaundice and the spleen was not big enough to be palpable.
You take some basic observations:
Temperature: 38 °C
Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min
O2 saturation: 86%
Heart rate: 134 bpm (regular)
Blood pressure (lying): 134/86 mmHg
Blood pressure (standing): 132/90 mmHg
His initial investigation findings are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal
White cell count (WCC) 13.8 × 109/l 4–11.0 × 109/l
Neutrophils 7000 × 106/l 3000–5800 × 106/l
Lymphocytes 2000 × 106/l 1500–3000 × 106/l
Haemoglobin (Hb) 105 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 110 fl 76–98 fl
Platelets 300 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Troponin l 0.01 ng/ml < 0.1 ng/ml
D-dimer 0.03 μg/ml < 0.05 μg/ml
Arterial blood gas (ABG) showed type 1 respiratory failure with a normal pH. Chest X-ray showed left lower lobe consolidation.
The patient was treated successfully and is due for discharge tomorrow.
Upon speaking to the patient, he reveals that he has suffered two similar episodes this year.
Given the likely diagnosis, what medication should the patient be started on to reduce the risk of further episodes?

A. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)
B. Hydroxycarbamide (hydroxyurea)
C. Inhaled beclometasone
D. Oral prednisolone
E. Tuberculosis (TB) vaccination

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old man with a long history of angina has been suffering from an increased frequency of attacks with minimal exertion, despite being treated with sublingual glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) and propranolol. He is referred to a cardiologist who, after further assessment, feels that the patient meets the criteria for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
Which of the following is an indication for CABG?

A. Two-vessel disease
B. Persisting angina despite treatment with sublingual GTN
C. Angina with left ventricular dysfunction
D. Angina with normal exercise electrocardiogram (ECG)
E. Angina that has been managed conservatively for more than five years

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with a 6-day history of fever and irritability, with red eyes and reduced eating for the last 24 hours. On examination, he was noted to have dry and cracked lips, mild conjunctivitis and cervical lymphadenopathy.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most important investigation?

A. Throat swab
B. Antistreptolysin O titre (ASOT)
C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
D. Echocardiogram
E. Chest X-ray

Correct Answer: D

An 83-year-old nursing home resident with a history of hypothyroidism and heart failure, is brought to see you. She complains of dry, itchy skin which is worse on her legs. On examination, you find erythematous, dry skin on her legs with a bizarre pattern to it.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asteatotic eczema
B. Contact dermatitis
C. Lichen planus
D. Scabies
E. Venous ulceration

Correct Answer: A

A healthy 26-year-old woman wants to begin training for an upcoming sports event. She undergoes exercise stress testing.
Which of the following is most likely to occur in this woman’s skeletal muscles during exercise?

A. Decreased blood flow
B. Decreased metabolite concentrations
C. Increased arteriolar diameter
D. Increased oxygen concentration
E. Increased vascular resistance

Correct Answer: C

You are considering the effectiveness of a new blood test to diagnose ulcerative colitis and read a study evaluating its use in 200 people, ten of whom were diagnosed histologically as having the condition. The study reports that the blood test was appropriately positive in seven patients and appropriately negative in 188 patients.
What is the sensitivity for this blood test in diagnosing ulcerative colitis in this study?

A. 78%
B. 30%
C. 98%
D. 70%
E. 99%

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old man is admitted through the Emergency Department after his wife found him unresponsive in their bedroom. He was surrounded by empty packets of paracetamol and amitriptyline. On assessment, he is found to be hypotensive and tachycardic, with sluggish pupillary responses. A 12-lead ECG shows a wide-complex tachycardia (QRS complex 140 ms) with a large terminal R wave in the augmented Vector Right (aVR) lead. He is given treatment intravenously with treatment X. A repeat ECG reveals a sinus tachycardia with a QRS complex duration of 92 ms.
Which of the following is most likely to represent treatment X?

A. Adenosine
B. Amiodarone
C. Calcium gluconate
D. Magnesium sulphate
E. Sodium bicarbonate

Correct Answer: E

A 79-year-old woman has fallen and fractured the rib that contributes to the costal margin at the mid-axillary line on her left side.
Which of the following ribs forms the costal margin at the mid-axillary line?

A. Seventh rib
B. Eighth rib
C. Ninth rib
D. Tenth rib
E. Eleventh rib

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old man presents with a low-grade fever, myalgia and multiple itchy, red, oedematous skin eruptions. The symptoms started 3 days previously. The skin lesions are rather symmetrical and oval-shaped, and are distributed over the palms, soles and limbs. Some of the lesions show central clearing and contain vesicles or bullae. The patient denies recent use of any medication prior to the appearance of the skin rash. He recalls a history of allergic rhinitis and urticaria in his sister.
What is the most likely underlying mechanism in the pathogenesis of this patient’s illness?

A. Type I hypersensitivity reaction
B. Type II hypersensitivity reaction
C. Type III hypersensitivity reaction
D. Type IV hypersensitivity reaction
E. Granulomatous inflammation

Correct Answer: D

A 46-year-old woman who is known to have gallstones is waiting to be admitted for an elective cholecystectomy when she develops intermittent upper abdominal pain and becomes jaundiced. An ultrasound scan shows a gallstone posterior to the superior (first) part of her duodenum.
In which part of the biliary tree is the gallstone most likely to have lodged?

A. Common bile duct
B. Common hepatic duct
C. Cystic duct
D. Hartmann’s pouch
E. Right hepatic duct

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old woman attends her endocrinologist for review. She has a background history of primary hyperparathyroidism and prolactinoma. She undergoes genetic testing and received a diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome. She is considering conceiving a child and is wondering what the chances are that her child would also have MEN1. Her partner has no medical history.
What is the inheritance pattern for MEN1 syndrome?

A. Autosomal dominant
B. Autosomal recessive
C. X-linked dominant
D. X-linked recessive
E. It is not an inherited condition

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old woman comes to the General Practitioner (GP). She has taken an emergency appointment as her anxiety state has become a lot worse lately. She informs the GP it has been ongoing for several years now and she would like to try treatment.
Which is the best long-term management?

A. Haloperidol
B. Diazepam
C. Zopiclone
D. Sertraline
E. Amitriptyline

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath and new-onset confusion, he has an abbreviated mental test score (AMTS) of 9. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 32 breaths/minute and a blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg. Blood tests demonstrate his urea level to be 6 mmol/l.
Which of the following is a prognostic indicator of high mortality in this patient presenting with pneumonia?

A. New-onset confusion with AMTS of 9
B. Urea 6 mmol/l
C. Respiratory rate >30 breaths/minute
D. Blood pressure of 100 mmHg systolic and/or 70 mmHg diastolic
E. Age 64 years

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old lady undergoing chemo-radiotherapy treatment for breast cancer complains of poor appetite and nausea secondary to her treatment. She is finding it difficult to cope with her illness and has become depressed.
Which of the following may be the most suitable appetite stimulant for her?

A. Dexamethasone
B. Metoclopramide
C. Mirtazapine
D. Megestrol
E. Trazodone

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman went to see her general practitioner (GP), as she had been experiencing low mood, weight gain and irregular menses.
The GP decided to carry out some investigations, referring to the hospital:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium 150 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium 2.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Blood glucose (fasting) 7.7 mmol/l < 7 mmol/l
24-h urinary cortisol excretion 840 nmol/24 h
Plasma ACTH (0900 h) 132 ng/l 0–50 ng/l
Dexamethasone suppression test:
0800 h serum cortisol after dexamethasone 0.5 mg/6 h orally (po) for two days: 880 nmol/l (< 50 nmol/l).
0800 h serum cortisol after dexamethasone 2 mg/6 h PO for two days: 875 nmol/l (< 50 nmol/l).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cushing’s disease
B. Conn’s syndrome
C. Premature menopause
D. Paraneoplastic syndrome secondary to small cell carcinoma of the lung
E. Adrenocortical tumour

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man presents with a 1-hour history of severe central chest pain. There is no significant history. He is haemodynamically stable with a pulse of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 120/70 mmHg. An electrocardiogram shows 5 mm of ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V2–V4). He received aspirin (300 mg) in the ambulance and diamorphine (5 mg).
What would be the definitive therapy?

A. Clopidogrel (75 mg)
B. Enoxaparin
C. Glycoprotein IIb/IIa blocker
D. Percutaneous coronary intervention
E. Tissue plasminogen activator

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department by ambulance with chest pain that started 30 minutes ago. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) performed on arrival shows ST elevation in leads V1–V6. ST depression is noted in leads III and aVF. The nearest centre that can deliver primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is a 3 hour transfer time by road ambulance.
Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

A. Aspirin, clopidogrel, low-molecular-weight heparin, and admit to Coronary Care Unit (CCU)
B. Aspirin, clopidogrel, low-molecular-weight heparin, and transfer for PCI
C. Administer thrombolysis and transfer for PCI
D. Analgesia, and transfer for PCI
E. Unfractionated heparin, admit to CCU

Correct Answer: C

A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symmetrical polyarthritis affecting her fingers, wrists and elbows. She also reports significant morning stiffness which lasts for up to 90 minutes and is finding it very difficult to get up for work in the morning. There is a history of deep vein thrombosis during her third pregnancy, but no other significant past medical history. Her only medication of note is the oral contraceptive pill.
On examination, she has evidence of active synovitis affecting her wrists and the small joints of her fingers.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 193 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Rheumatoid factor Positive
Anti-nuclear factor Weakly positive
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
B. Anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome
C. Seronegative arthritis
D. Rheumatoid arthritis
E. Polymyalgia rheumatica

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man has an electrocardiogram (ECG) performed as part of a workplace medical.
What is the electrophysiological correlate of the T wave on a normal ECG?

A. Atrial depolarisation
B. Atrial repolarisation
C. Conduction delay through the atrioventricular node
D. Ventricular depolarisation
E. Ventricular repolarisation

Correct Answer: E

A patient is being treated with clindamycin for a soft tissue infection. He then develops bloody diarrhoea. His clinicians suspect he has developed a complication of treatment.
Which of the following statements is correct regarding what he has now developed?

A. The stool contains a toxin that kills cultured epithelial cells
B. Stool culture will grow anaerobic Gram-negative rods
C. Sigmoidoscopy will be normal
D. Oral metronidazole alone is not usually adequate to treat this condition
E. There is little patient-to-patient spread and standard infection control measures are sufficient

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman had chronic inflammatory disease that affected her spine, sacroiliac joints and large peripheral joints. X-rays confirmed a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis.
The majority of patients with this disease are positive for which one of the following molecules?

A. HLA-B27
B. HLA-B8
C. HLA-Cw6
D. HLA-DR4
E. HLA-DR2

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner troubled with excess hair growth on her face, back and arms. She has tried hair removal strategies and bleaching. However, she would like to consider treatment to prevent hair growth. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 31 kg/m2 and reports irregular periods, menstruating once every 6–8 months. Her recent blood tests revealed raised testosterone and luteinising hormone levels.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient, given the likely diagnosis?

A. Eflornithine
B. Metformin
C. Oral combined contraceptive pill
D. Progesterone-only pill
E. Topical minoxidil

Correct Answer: C

A patient who is known to have an extensive history of drug use and alcohol abuse is admitted to Accident and Emergency with haematemesis. He is haemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 68/38 mmHg and a heart rate of 147 bpm. He is very difficult to cannulate.
Which of the following would have the highest flow rate for haemodynamic resuscitation?

A. A 20-cm central line in the femoral vein
B. A 22G cannula in the external jugular vein
C. An 18G cannula in the antecubital fossa
D. A 20G cannula in the back of his hand
E. A 15-cm central line in the internal jugular vein

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old Indian woman presents to the Emergency Department with vomiting and central abdominal pain. She has vomited eight times over the last 24 hours. The vomit is non-bilious and non-bloody. She also reports that she has not moved her bowels for the last four days and is not passing flatus. She reports that she had some form of radiation therapy to her abdomen ten years ago in India for ‘stomach cancer’. There is no urinary urgency or burning on urination. She migrated from India to England two months ago. She reports no other past medical or surgical history.
Her observations and blood tests results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Temperature 36.9 °C
Blood pressure 155/59 mmHg
Heart rate 85 beats per minute
Respiratory rate 19 breaths per minute
Sp(O2) 96% (room air)
White cell count 8.9 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
C-reactive protein 36 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
The patient’s urine dipstick is negative for leukocytes and nitrites. Physical examination reveals a soft but distended abdomen. No abdominal scars are visible. There is mild tenderness throughout the abdomen. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Rectal examination reveals no stool in the rectal vault, and no blood or melaena.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute mesenteric ischaemia
B. Diverticulitis
C. Pyelonephritis
D. Small bowel obstruction
E. Viral gastroenteritis

Correct Answer: D

A 61-year-old man complains of dyspnoea, haemoptysis, and an unintentional 20 lb weight loss over the last 3 months. He reports a medical history significant for mild asthma controlled with an albuterol inhaler as needed. He takes no other medications and has no allergies. He has a 60 pack-year smoking history and has worked as a naval shipyard worker for 37 years. Examination reveals diffuse crackles in the posterior lung fields bilaterally and there is dullness to percussion one-quarter of the way up the right lung field. Ultrasound reveals free fluid in the pleural space.
Which one of the following set of test values is most consistent with this patient’s presentation?

(LDH: lactate dehydrogenase)
Option LDH plasma LDH pleural Protein plasma Protein pleural
A 180 100 7 3
B 270 150 8 3
C 180 150 7 4
D 270 110 8 3
E 180 100 7 2
A. Option A
B. Option B
C. Option C
D. Option D
E. Option E

Correct Answer: C

During a routine GP clinic, a mother attends with her 6 year old son who has worsening dry, itchy skin, mainly affecting the flexor surfaces, particularly on the arms. She has tried regular liberal use emollient cream with limited success.
What would be the most appropriate next step in management of the child’s eczema?

A. Prescribe hydrocortisone cream 1%
B. Suggest use of an emollient ointment
C. Short course of oral corticosteroids
D. Refer to the dermatology clinic
E. Watchful waiting

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with swelling and tenderness in his right scrotum. His urine dipstick is clear. There is swelling and tenderness, but the testes are not swollen. There was a gradual build-up of pain and a temperature over the past two days. He has a recent history of unprotected sexual intercourse.
Which is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Refer to surgeons for emergency surgery
B. Refer to the urology team for an intravenous urography (IVU)
C. Diclofenac and paracetamol and follow-up with the general practitioner (GP)
D. Azithromycin 1 g stat
E. Single-shot of ceftriaxone 1 g, followed by doxycycline 2 × 100 mg/day for two weeks

Correct Answer: E

A 78-year-old woman was admitted to hospital seven days ago with moderate symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia and was treated with amoxicillin. She has developed a fever, maculopapular skin rash and haematuria over the last two days. You suspect that her new symptoms may be due to acute tubulointerstitial nephritis caused by a reaction to the amoxicillin she was given.
Which of the following investigations would provide a definitive diagnosis?

A. Full blood count
B. Kidney biopsy
C. Kidney ultrasound
D. Serum urea and electrolytes
E. Urinalysis

Correct Answer: B

A 65-year-old man, with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presents to the Emergency Department with a painless sudden loss of vision in his right eye that had lasted for a few minutes. He describes the loss of vision as a curtain coming into his vision, and he could not see anything out of it for a few minutes before his vision returned to normal.
On examination, his acuity is 6/9 in both eyes. On dilated fundoscopy, there is a small embolus in one of the vessels in the right eye. The rest of the fundus is normal in both eyes.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Amaurosis fugax
B. Anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy
C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)
D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)
E. Retinal detachment

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after near-drowning. This occurred after he fell from a boat into a lake, while intoxicated with alcohol. He has no medical history. He is drowsy, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 9; his oxygen saturations are 80% on an inspired fraction of oxygen (FiO2) of 1.0 via a non-rebreather face mask.
Which of the following is part of the treatment algorithm for drowning?

A. Diuresis
B. Warming strategies for hypothermia
C. Avoid oxygenation
D. Prophylactic oral antibiotics
E. Prophylactic intravenous (IV) antiobiotics

Correct Answer: B

An overweight 13-year-old boy presents with left groin pain that has been getting progressively worse over the last few weeks, to the point that he is now unable to bear weight on his left leg. He has a Trendelenburg gait and, although there is no pain on palpation or any obvious swelling on examination, there is obligatory external rotation during passive flexion of the hip and limited range of movement, especially in internal rotation, abduction and flexion of the hip. Anteroposterior (AP) and frog-leg lateral radiographs of the hip and pelvis show that the Klein’s line does not intersect the femoral head.
What is the most appropriate treatment option for him?

A. Observation and follow-up, reassuring his parents that these are growing pains which will improve
B. Hip spica casting and no weight-bearing for 4 weeks
C. Limited weight-bearing on crutches for 2 weeks and analgesia
D. Hip arthroscopy and labral repair
E. In situ screw fixation

Correct Answer: E

A 21-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Department with weakness in both her upper and lower limbs. She has no history of fever or any co-morbidities (diabetes, hypertension or heart disease). She remembers that she used to frequently sprain her ankles as a child and she attributes this to her difficulty in walking in her early years. She says that her aunt has a similar weakness but is not under any treatment. On examination, she is found to have weak and atrophied muscles of her distal upper and lower limbs, with pes cavus deformity in her legs.
Nerve conduction studies (NCS) show severe slowing of conduction velocity in both the motor and sensory nerves.
Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease is suspected.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Ascorbic acid therapy
B. Gene replacement therapy
C. Multidisciplinary team therapy, rehabilitation and screening
D. Neurotrophin-3
E. Progesterone antagonist

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old woman presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with her husband, as she is becoming increasingly tired throughout the day. She has been started on donepezil for Alzheimer’s dementia (AD), and she has noticed modest improvement in cognitive function with this medication. However, her husband states that she has difficulty sleeping at night and is increasingly drowsy throughout the day.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Rivastigmine
B. Memantine
C. Risperidone
D. Tacrine
E. Trazodone

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with anorexia, fatigue, nausea and generalised pain. He has a medical history notable for palliate prostate cancer for which he has refused treatment, and remains independent. Routine blood results confirm your suspicions:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 91 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 125 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 3.2 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
You commence treatment with intravenous fluid resuscitation, intravenous calcitonin and one other intravenous infusion.
In which principal way, will this other intravenous infusion correct the biochemical abnormality?

A. Bind calcium in the bloodstream to enhance excretion
B. Decrease gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
C. Decrease renal reabsorption of calcium
D. Increase renal secretion of calcium
E. Inhibit the release of calcium from bones

Correct Answer: E

A 56-year-old secretary visits her GP as she has noticed that she is becoming increasingly breathless whilst running. She has always enjoyed running and usually runs 3 times a week. Over the past year she has noted that she can no longer manage the same distance that she has been accustomed to without getting breathless and needing to stop. She wonders if this is a normal part of ageing or if there could be an underlying medical problem.
Which of the following are consistent with normal ageing with respect to the respiratory system?

A. PaO2 <8.0 kPa
B. PaCO2 >6.5 kPa
C. Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) <200 l/min
D. O2 sats <91% on air
E. Reduction of forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) by 20–30%

Correct Answer: E

An 80-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents for a review of his home oxygen therapy. The following results are from his arterial blood gas (ABG):
Investigation Result Normal range
pH 7.34 7.35–7.45
pa(O2) 8.0 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pa(CO2) 7.6 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
HCO3- 36 mmol 24–30 mmol/l
Base excess +4 mmol −2 to +2 mmol
Which of the following best describes this man’s ABG results?

A. Respiratory alkalosis with partial metabolic compensation
B. Respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation
C. Respiratory acidosis with no metabolic compensation
D. Metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation
E. Metabolic alkalosis with partial respiratory compensation

Correct Answer: B
