A 68-year-old man, with CCF is admitted with SOB and a productive cough. Clinical findings, and a chest X-ray suggest a diagnosis of both pulmonary oedema and pneumonia. He is put on high flow oxygen and treated with furosemide, GTN spray and morphine, and started on antibiotics.
His breathlessness improves, and a repeat chest X-ray shows decreased pulmonary oedema. An ABG shows the following:
pH: 7.01 (normal 7.35–7.45)
p(CO2): 8 kPa (normal 4.5–6.0 kPa)
p(O2): 11 kPa (normal 10–14 kPa)
HCO3–: 18 mmol (normal 24–30 mmol/l)
base excess: 1.2 mmol/l (normal −2 to +2.0 mmol/l)
sodium: 142 mmol/l (normal 135–145 mmol/l)
potassium: 5.9 mmol/l (normal 3.5–5.0 mmol/l)
glucose: 7.5 mmol/l (normal 5–5.5 mmol/l)
lactate: 3.1 mmol/l (normal 2.2–5 mmol/l).
Based on the patient, which of the following does he have that is an indication for acute dialysis?

A. Hyperkalaemia
B. Metabolic acidosis
C. Raised lactate
D. Refractory pulmonary oedema
E. The patient does not require acute dialysis

Correct Answer: B

A medical student is about to start her onoclogy attachment and is revising around the area of tumour markers in diagnosis and monitoring of malignancy.
Which of the following tumour markers is correctly paired with the tumour with which it is associated?

A. CA 19-9 and breast cancer
B. Alphafetoprotein (AFP) and hepatocellular carcinoma
C. CA 15-3 and pancreatic cancer
D. CA 125 and lung cancer
E. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and testicular cancer

Correct Answer: B

A 26-year-old man comes to see you due to low mood. He reports that since losing his job two years ago, he struggles with motivation, does not sleep and no longer enjoys socialising with his friends.
He has no thoughts of self-harm or suicide. He scores 9 on the PHQ9, indicating mild-moderate depression.
What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?

A. Antidepressant medication
B. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) or low-intensity psychological therapy
C. Diazepam
D. Self-help advice and review in two weeks
E. Urgent referral to the Crisis Team

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with breathlessness, dry cough and intermittent wheeze.
Which of the following investigation results supports a diagnosis of asthma?

A. Fraction exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) 50 parts per billion (ppb)
B. Forced expiratory volume in 1 second/forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC ratio) ≥ 75%
C. A 10% or higher improvement in FEV1 following a nebulised bronchodilator
D. A 150 ml or higher improvement in FEV1 following a nebulised bronchodilator
E. Greater than 15% variability in peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) on monitoring

Correct Answer: A

A 27-year-old woman presents with a positive pregnancy test and brown vaginal discharge. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with an incomplete miscarriage at nine weeks’ gestation, which was medically managed with misoprostol. She reports passing big clots the day after and lightly bleeding since. An ultrasound scan reports a ‘heterogenous appearance of the endometrial cavity suspicious of retained products of conception’. Her heart rate is 102 bpm, blood pressure 102/78 mmHg and temperature 37.9 °C. Abdominal examination reveals a tender abdomen, with cervical excitation on vaginal examination.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?

A. Expectant management and review in 7–14 days
B. Oral mifepristone
B. C. Oral mifepristone followed by vaginal misoprostol
D. Surgical evacuation of products of conception
E. Vaginal misoprostol

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old woman living at a nursing home is brought to the Emergency Department, showing new-onset erratic behaviour. The nursing home staff reported that she was trying to eat the soil from the pot-plants and displaying inappropriate sexual behaviour towards the other residents. In the examination room, the doctor noticed a tendency to examine objects with her mouth. Past history reveals a stroke that occluded the anterior choroidal artery.
Which of the following structures is most likely damaged?

A. Amygdala
B. Hippocampus
C. Thalamus
D. Cingulate sulcus
E. Hypophysis

Correct Answer: A

A 2-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of diarrhoea and vomiting. He has drunk only small amounts and is becoming more lethargic. He has opened his bowels five times but has only passed urine once today. He is usually fit and well. His 4-year-old brother was unwell with the same symptoms a few days before but has since recovered well. On examination, he appears restless with sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes and capillary refill time (CRT) of 2 seconds, and he is tachycardic with a heart rate (HR) of 150 bpm.
What would be your assessment of his clinical fluid status?

A. Euvolaemic
B. No clinically detectable dehydration
C. Clinical dehydration
D. Clinical shock
E. Fluid overloaded

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old woman is admitted with an overdose. She is currently taking anti-depressants prescribed by her GP and painkillers for a chronic back complaint. Other past medical history of note includes hypertension. On examination she has a GCS of 7. Her pulse is 105/min regular and her BP is 85/60 mmHg. Her pupils are sluggish and dilated.
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 8.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 182 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
pH 7.15 7.35–7.45
pO2 8.1 kPa 10.5–13.5 kPa
pCO2 5.9 kPa 4.6–6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate 14 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Opiate overdose
B. Diazepam overdose
C. Tricyclic anti-depressant overdose
D. Serotonin reuptake inhibitor overdose
E. Nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibitor overdose

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old is on the Labour Ward, giving birth to her first child. It is a long labour and she has a vaginal delivery, with a healthy baby boy born 30 min ago with physiological management of the third stage so far. The midwife calls you, as the placenta has not been delivered yet. Her observations are stable and blood loss is minimal.
What would be the best next step in management?

A. Full obstetric emergency team resuscitation
B. Commence a Syntocinon® infusion
C. Observe for 30 min and then initiate intramuscular (im) Syntocinon® and breastfeeding
D. Observe for 60 min with im Syntocinon® and breastfeeding
E. Go to theatre for surgical removal under general anaesthesia

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man, who is a heavy smoker, was seen in the Surgical Outpatient Clinic, complaining of severe pain in both legs, even at rest. On examination, he had chronic ulceration of his toes.
Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?

A. Buerger’s disease
B. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
C. Kawasaki’s disease
D. Polyarteritis nodosa
E. Takayasu’s arteritis

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old electrician presents with a 3-month history of cough and weight loss. On further questioning, the patient tells you that he has had some episodes of haemoptysis. He has a long history of hypothyroidism, which is well managed with thyroxine 100 µg daily. He has no other medical history of note. The patient smokes ten cigarettes a day. A physician carries out blood tests and orders an X-ray, which shows signs of possible asbestosis. A computed tomography (CT) scan is ordered to investigate further.
Which of the following is the typical CT scan finding of asbestosis in the lung?

A. Diffuse fibrotic bands with ground glass opacity
B. Irregular linear shadows with hilar lymphadenopathy
C. Cavitation of upper zones
D. Honeycombing of the lung with parenchymal bands and pleural plaques
E. Parenchymal nodules and lower zone emphysema

Correct Answer: D

A patient has been diagnosed with a melanoma on his right hand, which measures 1.5 cm. He is booked in to have surgery to remove it.
During the excision biopsy what margin size will be taken?

A. 2 mm
B. 3 mm
C. 4 mm
D. 1 cm
E. 2 cm

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man with a previous diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) is seen by you 2 days after having undergone a total thyroidectomy. He complains to you of cramps in his calves and thighs and of tingling around his lips. You examine him and find Chvostek’s sign and Trousseau sign to be positive. Investigations show his serum calcium to be 2 mmol/l and his serum phosphate to be 1.8 mmol/l.
Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A. Acquired hypoparathyroidism
B. Pseudohypoparathyroidism
C. Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
D. Renal failure
E. Vitamin D deficiency

Correct Answer: A

A 72-year-old woman is brought to the hospital, complaining of shortness of breath and a feeling of extreme weakness and epigastric pain. She states that the symptoms began about 45 minutes ago, while she was going to use the toilet, and that they have not subsided since then. The woman is sweating profusely and has a heart rate of 145 bpm and a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is ordered, and the results show elevated ST segments in consecutive leads and Q waves.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of this woman’s condition?

A. Coronary vasospasm
B. Completely occlusive thrombus
C. Coronary artery stenosis
D. Partially occlusive thrombus
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old nulliparous woman attends her General Practice for a routine cervical smear. Her previous smear was negative; she is on the combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) and had one episode of gonorrhoea treated three years ago.
On examination, the practice nurse notices a soft, pea-sized, fluctuant lump on the posterior vestibule by the opening of the vagina. There is some minor labial swelling, and it is non-tender.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Bartholin cyst
B. Bartholin abscess
C. Haematoma
D. Infected epidermal cyst
E. Lipoma

Correct Answer: A

A 29-year-old first-time mother had a normal vaginal delivery at term. The baby’s birthweight was 2 200 g. She wanted to breastfeed but is wondering whether she should supplement feeds with formula to help the baby’s growth.
Which of the following best applies to the World Health Organization (WHO) recommendations for feeding in low-birthweight infants?

A. Low-birthweight infants should be exclusively breastfed for the first eight months of life
B. Low-birthweight infants should receive daily oral vitamin A supplementation
C. Low-birthweight infants should receive daily vitamin D, calcium and phosphorus supplementation
D. Low-birthweight infants who are not clinically stable should commence feeding as soon as they are born
E. Low-birthweight infants who cannot be fed their mother’s breast milk should be fed donor human milk

Correct Answer: E

As a part of a special study module, a group of medical students are looking into the changes in life expectancy over the past 100 years.
What is the life expectancy for a woman in the UK?

A. 65–69 years
B. 70–74 years
C. 75–79 years
D. 80–84 years
E. 85–89 years

Correct Answer: D

A 40-year-old man, who is human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive, attends the Emergency Department. He has become increasingly drowsy and confused over the past few days, complaining of a severe headache and neck stiffness. On examination, he is pyrexial at 38.2 °C and drowsy, and his blood pressure is 155/85 mmHg with a pulse of 99 bpm. He appears to have weakness on his left side.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin (Hb) 113 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 12.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets (PLT) 203 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) opening 23 cm H2O 6–20 cmH2O
CSF protein Raised < 0.45 g/l
CSF glucose 80% of serum level 2.5–3.9 mmol/l
(two-thirds plasma value)
Cryptococcal antigen Positive
How would you best treat this patient?

A. Oral fluconazole
B. Intravenous (iv) amphotericin B
C. iv benzylpenicillin
D. iv cefotaxime
E. iv corticosteroids

Correct Answer: B

A 7-year-old girl presents with a 1-day history of abdominal pain. Her mother reports that the pain woke the child up this morning, with one episode of vomiting this afternoon, and she has since lost her appetite. She has had no fever or diarrhoea. There is no history of foreign travel and no ill contacts. On examination, the temperature is 37.5 °C and heart rate (HR) 123 bpm, and there is generalised abdominal tenderness, with no guarding or rigidity. Urine dip is negative, and blood tests show white cell count (WCC) of 15 with C-reactive protein (CRP) of 10.
What would the next best step in management be?

A. Laparotomy
B. Laparoscopy
C. Abdominal X-ray
D. Discharge with oral analgesia
E. Nil by mouth, intravenous fluids and review

Correct Answer: E

An 80-year-old man is reviewed by his General Practitioner for chest pain. The man describes the pain as crushing in nature, which is worse on exertion, especially when walking up the stairs in his house. It is generally relieved by rest. However, he has had a few episodes of the same pain when watching TV. This has been getting more frequent over the last two weeks. He is otherwise fit and healthy, with no other medical background.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Prescribe glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray, two puffs sublingual, and send home
B. Prescribe ramipril and simvastatin
C. Provide lifestyle advice, including exercise recommendation
D. Refer to hospital for admission for observation and urgent elective angiogram
E. Send for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

Correct Answer: D

A 15-year-old student attends the Emergency Department with headache, neck stiffness and photophobia. On examination, a purpuric rash is evident on the trunk and limbs.
For which of the following conditions is the patient at risk?

A. Zollinger–Ellison syndrome
B. Osler–Weber–Rendu disease
C. Fitz–Hugh–Curtis syndrome
D. Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome
E. Cushing syndrome

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man with a past medical history of obesity, hypertension and hyperlipidaemia presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden-onset chest pain. After your initial history and examination, you conclude that there is a 40% chance that this patient is experiencing an acute myocardial infarction. An electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac enzymes are performed to further evaluate his condition.
This estimate (40%) is defined as which of the following?

A. Odds ratio
B. Prior probability
C. Posterior probability
D. Likelihood ratio
E. Prevalence

Correct Answer: B

A 7-year-old boy presents with colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea over the past 3 days. The child’s mother reports that the diarrhoea is associated with passage of blood and mucus. He also had arthralgia of the knees, elbows, ankles, and wrists. On examination, there is an obvious palpable purpuric rash on his extremities. Investigations revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 115–140 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 15 × 109/l 5.5–15.5 × 109/l
Platelet count 350 × 109/l 150-–400 × 109/l
BUN (blood urea nitrogen) 6.3 mmol/l 1.8–6.4 mmol/l
Serum creatinine 89.3 μmol/l 20–80 μmol/l
Urine analysis shows: Microscopic haematuria and proteinuria 1+
After a few days the child recovered completely without any treatment.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute bacillary dysentery
B. Haemolytic uremic syndrome
C. Idiopathic thromobocytopenic purpura
D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
E. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old retired librarian presents to her General Practitioner complaining of a feeling of fullness in her vagina. She states that this feeling is present at all times. On further questioning she also has a 1-year history of urinary frequency and has been treated for urinary tract infections in two instances in the past year. She has never smoked and is teetotal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cystocele
B. Rectocele
C. Bartholin cyst
D. Vaginal cancer
E. Bladder cancer

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 2-month history of fatigue. The patient says that her symptoms have been gradually getting worse and they are limiting her activities such as playing badminton. She denies any recent abnormal bleeding and has not lost any weight. The patient has healthy diet consisting of meat and vegetables. She does not smoke or drink any alcohol. The GP requests some blood investigations, the results of which are shown below.
Her blood tests indicate she is anaemic:
Investigations Results Normal range
Haemoglobin (Hb) 98 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 66 fl 76–98 fl
Based on the blood results, which of the following is the most likely of her anaemia?

A. Iron deficiency
B. Vitamin B12 deficiency
C. Chronic liver disease
D. Aplastic anaemia
E. Alcohol excess

Correct Answer: A

A 4-year-old boy with an otherwise unremarkable medical history develops an ulcer in his ileum.
What is the most likely congenital birth defect leading to his condition?

A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula
C. Gastroschisis
D. Meckel’s diverticulum
E. Omphalocele

Correct Answer: D

Vaccines are one of the greatest advancements in medicine within the last 100 years and have resulted in an exponential decrease in infant mortality.
At what age do children receive the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine?

A. 8–10 months, one off
B. 12–14 months and three years
C. 8–10 months and two years
D. Two years, one off
E. Three years, one off

Correct Answer: B

A 64-year-old retired bus driver is admitted to the Emergency Department with end-stage renal disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy.
Which of the following is most likely histological finding on biopsy of this patient’s kidney?

A. Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodules
B. Immune complex deposition
C. Rouleaux formation
D. Clear cells
E. Mesangial amyloid deposits

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old man presented with progressive dyspepsia and weight loss. Endoscopy revealed a stenosing lesion that bled easily. A biopsy and histopathological examination revealed adenocarcinoma of the oesophagus.
Which of the following is the most likely aetiological factor?

A. Achalasia
B. Alcohol
C. Excessive fruit and vegetable consumption
D. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD)
E. Helicobacter pylori

Correct Answer: D

This 60-year-old man has erythematous scaly plaques, like the one shown in the picture, elsewhere on the scalp. He has had a scaly scalp in the past, but he thinks it has never been as bad as it is now. He had a myocardial infarction 9 months ago and now takes aspirin, atenolol, ramipril and simvastatin.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
B. Tinea capitis
C. Discoid lupus erythematosus
D. Lichen simplex chronicus
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: E

While on call overnight on orthopaedics, you are bleeped to see a patient you do not know. They are 2 days post-operative from a left total hip replacement procedure. They appear drowsy and confused. On examination, they are tachycardic, and an electrocardiogram (ECG) shows peaked T-waves and a wide QRS complex. You take an arterial blood gas (ABG) which reveals a potassium level of 6.4 mmol (normal 5–5.0 mmol/l).
What is the most appropriate initial management action for this patient?

A. Bleep the on-call registrar
B. Give 30 ml of 10% calcium gluconate by slow intravenous (IV) injection
C. Give 10 units of Actrapid® in 100 ml of 20% glucose over 10–15 ml IV
D. Give 50 ml of 15% calcium gluconate by slow IV injection
E. Give oral calcium resonium 15 mg

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man presents for his 6-week post-myocardial infarction (MI) check-up. He was discharged without medication. He has a total cholesterol of 9 mmol/l, with triglycerides of 1.2 mmol/l. He is a non-smoker with a blood pressure of 145/75. His father died of an MI aged 43.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A. Ezetimibe
B. Dietary advice
C. Low-dose atorvastatin
D. High-dose atorvastatin
D. E. High-dose atorvastatin and ezetimibe

Correct Answer: D

An 18-year-old man has been stabbed by a narrow blade that has passed directly posteriorly through the lower half of the body of the sternum.
Which one of the following structures is most likely to have been pierced?

A. Inferior vena cava
B. Left atrial appendage
C. Left ventricle
D. Right atrium
E. Right ventricle

Correct Answer: E

A 31-year-old teacher with type II diabetes is 5-months pregnant with her first child. Following reviewing the patient in prenatal clinic, you are interested to find out more about stages of fetal development.
During the fifth (gestational) month of human development, which organ is the most active site of formation of formed elements of the blood?

A. Yolk sac
B. Spleen
C. Lymph nodes
D. Liver
E. Bone marrow

Correct Answer: E

A 47-year-old electrician presents to the Emergency Department after suffering an electrical injury while at work. He had a current-induced dysrhythmia and has been in hospital for the last 24-hours. His current continuous echo cardiogram monitoring shows no abnormality, his respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute and he is comfortable at rest. He is normovolaemic.
Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is the patient most at risk of developing?

A. Hypokalaemia
B. Hyperkalaemia
C. Hyponatremia
D. Hypernatremia
E. Hypophosphatemia

Correct Answer: B

You are called to see a 78-year-old man on the ward who was admitted yesterday with agitation and distressing hallucinations that were thought to be due to delirium secondary to a urinary tract infection (UTI). The nurses are worried that he now appears to be very confused with rigid movements and shaking of his hands. His wife mentions in passing that he had been experiencing episodes of confusion, sleep difficulties, visual hallucinations and abnormal movements before this admission also.
Which of the following drugs is most likely to have caused this man’s deterioration?

A. Clonazepam
B. Donepezil
C. Haloperidol
D. Memantine
E. Rivastigmine

Correct Answer: C

A 31-year-old man of Jamaican origin is admitted with complaints of severe diarrhoea (>10 stools/day), crampy abdominal pain and vomiting since 1 week. Ultrasonography of the abdomen revealed cholecystitis. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography was suggestive of cholangitis, papillary stenosis and pancreatitis. Stool examination revealed non-inflammatory diarrhoea and oocysts, which stained positive with acid-fast stain.
Which one of the following investigations should be undertaken with this patient?

A. Chest X-ray, sputum for acid-fast bacteria (AFB) staining, Mantoux test
B. Anti-nuclear antibody
C. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
D. Cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA)
E. Hypoglycin assay for Jamaican vomiting sickness

Correct Answer: C

A 17-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after getting involved in a fight. He describes being punched on his right ear. Since then, he has been unable to hear from that ear. He remembers the entire episode and has had a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of 15, conversing coherently and lucidly throughout. He has mild headache and has not vomited or been drowsy at all.
On examination, he has no focal neurological signs, and his cervical spine is not painful or tender. Fundoscopy shows a normal retina. The only abnormality is a ruptured right tympanic membrane with a tiny amount of blood.
What is the most appropriate course of action?

A. Refer him urgently to Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) for a tympanoplasty
B. Refer him as an outpatient to ENT for a tympanoplasty
C. Obtain a neurosurgical opinion
D. Do a computerised tomography (CT) scan of his head
E. Give him a week’s course of co-amoxiclav, and advise him to keep his ear dry and to see his general practitioner in 6 weeks

Correct Answer: E

A 25-year-old man with a history of asthma and ulcerative colitis presents with an itchy, red rash in the right and left popliteal regions. He is a bank cashier and continuously scratches the back of his knees when he is at work. This is the second time he has suffered from such a popliteal rash. He states that previously he has had similar skin conditions affecting his anterior wrist and antecubital areas. On examination, both popliteal areas are erythematous with slight oedema and weeping. There are some overlying vesicles and papules.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
B. Atopic dermatitis
C. Dermatitis herpetiformis
D. Lichen planus
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: B

A patient presents with lethargy, weight loss and fainting episodes. In the Emergency Department, a postural drop in blood pressure is noted of >20 mmHg systolic from the supine to the standing position. Blood glucose is 2.9 mmol/l and Na+ is 122 mmol/l.
Which of the following is the patient’s condition due to?

A. Decreased cortisol; decreased aldosterone
B. Increased cortisol; increased aldosterone
C. Increased cortisol; decreased aldosterone
D. Decreased cortisol; increased aldosterone
E. Decreased cortisol; normal aldosterone

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old man presents to the Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Outpatient Department with a constant hissing sound in his right ear. There is no previous history of trauma, ear infections, fever or any significant past medical illness. He feels that he is unable to bear this constant sound and it is the reason for his low mood and lack of interest in his daily activities. On examination, his vital signs are normal; he is afebrile and has no discharge or pain in the external ear canal, as well as no hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals normal findings and an intact tympanic membrane. He is not on any prescription medications.
What is the most appropriate treatment of choice in this patient?

A. Counselling combined with sound generators
B. Dexamethasone
C. Hearing aid
D. Masking
E. Nortriptyline

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old woman who is a life-long smoker complains of drooping of the eyelid on the left side. On examination, there is ptosis of the left eyelid and a small pupil that reacts to light but does not dilate. The right eye is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Left third cranial nerve palsy
B. Left fifth cranial nerve palsy
C. Left seventh cranial nerve palsy
D. Right Horner syndrome
E. Left Horner syndrome

Correct Answer: E

You are asked to see a 24-year-old man who suffered from a severe allergic reaction in response to a blood transfusion after a road traffic accident. His past medical history includes recurrent otitis media as a child and two bouts of pneumonia. There was one admission in the previous year for Giardia infection.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 135 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 352 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Immunoglobulins slightly decreased
Spirometry mild obstructive pattern
Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Severe combined immunoglobulin deficiency
B. IgM deficiency
C. IgG deficiency
D. IgE deficiency
E. IgA deficiency

Correct Answer: E

This 58-year old woman presents with the skin changes shown in the pictures. There is some erythema of the cheeks, neck, upper chest and upper limbs. There are prominent nail fold capillaries visible. The rash is mildly pruritic. She has well-controlled hypertension and takes ramipril. She also takes simvastatin. She is otherwise well but recently has found it difficult to raise her legs when climbing the stairs.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Dermatomyositis
B. Drug toxicity
C. Lichen planus
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Correct Answer: A

A 60-year-old man was working on a ladder, painting a wall, and suffered a fall in which he dislocated his right shoulder. Shoulder X-rays demonstrated an anterior dislocation, but otherwise no fracture. His shoulder is reduced easily without any complications and post-reduction radiographs are satisfactory. At his 2-week follow-up clinic with his general practitioner, he notes that he has a lot of difficulty in abducting his right arm. His right arm shows no neurovascular defects, with full sensation and good radial pulses.
Which of the following imaging modalities will best confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

A. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the shoulder
B. Computed tomography (CT)–intravenous (iv) contrast of affected limb
C. Repeat shoulder X-rays
D. Electromyography (EMG)
E. Bone scan

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old student has a persistent cough. He admits to using marijuana almost every day. His lungs have an unusually high number of pulmonary macrophages, cells dedicated to phagocytosis and destruction of foreign materials entering the lungs.
Which leukocyte in this man’s peripheral blood can become a pulmonary macrophage?

A. Neutrophils
B. Basophils
C. Mast cells
D. Platelet
E. Monocyte

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old man with a previous history of hypertension, asthma and porphyria is admitted to the hospital for emergency surgery. His blood pressure and asthma are well managed.
What is the best choice of anaesthetic induction agent for the rapid sequence induction (RSI) procedure?

A. Fentanyl
B. Ketamine
C. Methohexital
D. Propofol
E. Thiopental

Correct Answer: D

A 73-year-old retired electrical engineer had a gradual decline in initiating and performing voluntary movements. His face was expressionless and he had tremors, which were particularly obvious when he was sat idle watching tv. He also showed a marked decrease in blinking frequency but had no evidence of dementia.
Which is the most likely diagnosis associated with these symptoms?

A. Parkinson’s disease
B. Alzheimer’s disease
C. Huntington’s disease
D. Hemiballism
E. Ballism

Correct Answer: A

A 27-year-old dentist presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a week’s history of severe pain on defecation, associated with streaks of fresh red blood on the tissue on wiping and spots of blood in the toilet pan. The patient also complains of pain around the anal area, which lasts for a few hours after each bowel movement. He has suffered from constipation for a few weeks, and he attributes this to a recent change in diet.
He is otherwise well and has had no abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting or weight loss. He has no family history of gastrointestinal conditions.
The doctor attempts a rectal examination, but this is abandoned due to pain.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Anal fissure
B. Colorectal malignancy
C. Perianal abscess
D. Crohn’s colitis
E. Thrombosed pile

Correct Answer: A

A 59-year-old woman has been suffering with stiffness in both hands, wrists and ankles for over 18 months. Following serological testing and radiological imaging, she was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. Her rheumatologist has made the decision to commence her on methotrexate therapy. She has a past medical history significant of gout, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes and chronic kidney disease stage 2.
Which of the following should be performed prior to commencement of methotrexate?

A. Full blood count (FBC), liver function tests (LFTs), estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), chest X-ray and electrocardiogram (ECG)
B. FBC, LFTs, urea and electrolytes (U&Es), eGFR, chest X-ray and spirometry
C. FBC, LFTs, TFTs, ECG and spirometry
D. FBC, LFTs, eGFR, thyroid function tests (TFTs), chest X-ray and ECG
E. FBC, LFTs, U&E and chest X-ray

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old woman is brought in by her son because ‘she is acting wild again’. She drinks moderately about once a week. She is not sleeping much, talks incessantly about plans to read the great books and has made many impulsive and irrational purchases. She reports hearing voices but refuses to discuss this issue when questioned by the admitting psychiatrist. She begins a task but does not complete it, all the while making lists of things to be done. She has been starting tasks and not finishing them. She had a similar episode 4 years ago. She also has depressive episodes several times over the last few years and recovered in between them.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Schizophreniform disorder
B. Schizophrenia, paranoid type
C. Schizoaffective disorder
D. Bipolar, manic, with mood-congruent psychotic features
E. Substance-induced psychosis

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old white woman presents with abdominal pain, radiating to the back, retching and vomiting. She is in a monogamous relationship with her boyfriend.
On examination, epigastric tenderness is present. Investigations revealed elevated triglyceride levels > 11.3 mmol/l (0–1.5 mmol/l). Computerised tomography (CT) abdomen was done, which was suggestive of acute pancreatitis.
Which one of the following is true about hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis?

A. Oral contraceptive usage is not a risk factor for hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis
B. Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII does not predispose to hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis
C. Diabetic patients are not at increased risk for hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis
D. High serum amylase and serum lipase levels may indicate hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis
E. Alcoholics have reduced incidence of hypertriglyceridaemia-induced pancreatitis

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old woman visits her General Practitioner, asking for contraception. She has suffered from extremely heavy periods, has a previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and smokes 15 cigarettes a day. She is currently sexually active and has a new partner. She does not plan to have any children currently but is keen to consider a family in the future. She works long hours as a busy lawyer and admits her diet and lifestyle are often erratic.
Which of the following options is the most suitable contraception for her?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill
B. Depo injection containing progesterone (Depo-Provera®, also known as medroxyprogesterone acetate)
C. Hysterectomy
D. Intrauterine system (IUS) coil
E. Progesterone only pill

Correct Answer: D

A 12-year-old boy is rushed to hospital after losing consciousness after a football game. During the game, he had fallen and struck his head on the ground. He was briefly dazed but was able to continue playing. About an hour after his fall, he started becoming drowsy before becoming unresponsive. He is diagnosed with an epidural haematoma and referred for immediate surgical evacuation.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding epidural haematomas?

A. Epidural haematomas do not cross the suture lines of the skull
B. Epidural haematomas can occur deep to the pia mater
C. The middle meningeal artery is rarely involved
D. They are often precipitated by a ‘sentinel headache’
E. Epidural haematomas appear as crescent-shaped lesions on computerised tomography (CT) of the head

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old patient is about to be discharged from hospital with a course of diazepam to help with anxiety symptoms.
Which feature of the history is the most important to ask about?

A. Family history of self-harm
B. Family history of anxiety
C. Past history of depression
D. Family history of depression
E. Presence of alcohol dependence

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old man is being assessed in the Emergency Department following a high-speed collision in his car. He has multiple fractures of the lower limbs and posterior dislocation of the right hip. The examining doctor wishes to ascertain whether he has any vascular injury. He begins by assessing the pulses in the limbs.
Which of the following is correct regarding lower limb arteries?

A. The femoral artery pulsation is best felt over the distal femur on the medial aspect of the thigh
B. The dorsalis pedis pulse is typically palpable medial to the tendon of the extensor hallucis longus only
C. The dorsalis pedis artery is a terminal branch of the posterior tibial artery
D. The anterior tibial artery lies between the tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus in the anterior compartment of the leg
E. The fibular (peroneal) artery is typically a direct branch of the popliteal artery

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old man complains of severe epigastric pain and nausea. He has not opened his bowels in 3 days. However, prior to this, they were opening normally. He has a past history of coronary stents inserted after a myocardial infarction (MI) 8 years ago. He has been asymptomatic since. He takes aspirin for his cardiac condition and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for knee arthritis. He has not consumed any alcohol over the last 2 years, following his episode of acute gastritis.
Examination reveals some mild tenderness over the epigastrium but no guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. An erect chest X-ray (CXR) and abdominal X-ray do not reveal any abnormality. Blood gases taken are unremarkable with a normal lactate. Routine blood tests (full blood count (FBC), urea and electrolytes (U&E), liver function tests (LFTs)) are unremarkable, with a normal amylase. Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy is performed and some gastric erosions are seen.
Which of the following diagnoses is the most important to rule out for this patient?

A. Acute gastritis
B. Duodenal ulcer
C. Pancreatitis
D. Ischaemic bowel
E. Myocardial infarction

Correct Answer: E

A 38-year-old man visits his general practitioner (GP) to discuss symptoms that have been bothering him for over a year but that are gradually getting more intrusive in his everyday life. He has been having obsessional thoughts about his house being burgled and compulsively checks the locks ten times before he leaves the house each day. Before going to bed, he also has an extensive checking routine, which takes him an hour to complete. His relationship is becoming strained, and he avoids going out to work or meeting friends. He is keen to avoid medication but is willing to try other treatment options.
What is the most appropriate psychological method of management for obsessive–compulsive disorder (OCD)?

A. Counselling
B. Exposure response prevention (ERP) and cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
C. ERP and psychoanalysis
D. Eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing (EMDR)
E. Transactional analysis

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old woman gave birth to her second child via Caesarian section and is now at post-operative day 2. She reports vague complaints of weakness and fatigue throughout her body, most notably in her face. She complains of double vision, having a hard time keeping her eyes open, and some difficulty swallowing. She denies pain and any shortness of breath. Of note, she had a similar episode after the birth of her first child.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS)
B. Myasthenia gravis (MG)
C. Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR)
D. Parkinson’s disease
E. Lupus

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old anatomy student presents with diarrhoea and weight loss. The patient complains of increased frequency of loose motions associated with cramping abdominal pain for six weeks, with an accompanying 5 kg weight loss. He opens his bowels anywhere from three to six times daily, the stool frequently has mucus in it, but no blood. The patient has no recent history of foreign travel and has had no ill contacts. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. The patient is referred to Gastroenterology for further investigation. A colonoscopy and biopsy of an affected area of bowel reveals ulcerative colitis.
Which of the following is an extra-intestinal clinical feature associated with inflammatory bowel disease?

A. Aortic aneurysm
B. Bilateral symmetrical deforming arthropathy of the hands
C. Heberden’s nodes
D. Prostatitis
E. Sacroiliitis

Correct Answer: E

A 67-year-old man has presented with jaundice. He is not in pain. The patient’s general practitioner reports that he thought he could feel a palpable gall bladder.
The intersection of which of the following features best describes the site at which the fundus of the gall bladder is most likely to be palpable?

A. Anterior axillary line and the transpyloric plane
B. Lateral edge of right rectus abdominis muscle and the costal margin
C. Linea alba and the transpyloric plane
D. Mid-clavicular line and the transpyloric plane
E. Mid-clavicular line and a horizontal line through the umbilicus

Correct Answer: B

An 85-year-old woman presented to the Emergency Department with severe dyspnoea. Chest X-ray revealed an opaque right hemithorax. She had never had any occupational exposure to asbestos. Her husband worked in a shipyard 40 years ago, but he did not have any lung complaints. She has never smoked. On examination of the thorax, there was decreased movement of the right side, with absent breath sounds and intercostal fullness.
What is the most likely cause of the radiological finding?

A. Tuberculosis
B. Lung collapse
C. Pneumonectomy
D. Mesothelioma
E. Massive consolidation

Correct Answer: D

A 56-year-old publican presents to the clinic for review. Over the past few months, he has developed tender nodules at the base of his right ring and little fingers. Most recently, he has begun to develop tendon thickenings which have caused his ring finger to curl inwards towards the palm. He has a past history of hypertension for which he takes ramipril and amlodipine.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 109 g/l 135–175 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 105 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 5.0 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 170 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase 85 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 38 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Albumin 32 g/l 35–55 g/l
Which of the following is the risk factor most strongly associated with the development of his hand condition?

A. Smoking
B. Ramipril
C. Amlodipine
D. Alcohol consumption
E. Work-related injury

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man with a long history of alcohol excess presents with fatigue and malaise. Liver function tests are found to be abnormal, and after specialist referral, he is diagnosed with alcohol cirrhosis.
What is the primary pathophysiological process in alcoholic cirrhosis?

A. Deposition of excess lipids in hepatocytes
B. Increase in portal blood pressure
C. Hepatocyte cell death caused by prolonged exposure to alcohol
D. Fibrosis resulting in disruption of normal liver architecture
E. Sclerosis of the intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old woman is referred by her general practitioner for investigation of a headache. On further questioning, she reports a 2- to 3-week history of worsening left-sided pain which is most noticeable when she brushes her hair. She also reports that, more recently, she has noticed blurred vision in her left eye. On examination, she has stiffness of her upper limbs, as well as tenderness to palpation over her left scalp and earlobe. Her past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism.
Which is the diagnostic test of choice?

A. Arterial biopsy
B. Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis
C. Computed tomography (CT) of the brain
D. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the brain
E. Serum erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)

Correct Answer: A

A 20-year-old primiparous patient is seen at home by the community midwife for a routine antenatal visit. She is 34 weeks pregnant and has had an uneventful pregnancy to date. On examination, she is well and has a symphysis fundal height of 33 cm. Her blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg and she has 2++ protein in the urine.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic hypertension
B. White-coat hypertension
C. Normal for pregnancy
D. Pre-eclampsia
E. Pregnancy-induced hypertension

Correct Answer: D

A fourth-year medical student is taking part in a bedside teaching session and is asked to auscultate the patient's heart. The student proceeds to place the stethoscope over the patient's fourth left intercostal space just lateral to the sternum.
A stethoscope placed as described would be best positioned to detect normal heart sounds associated with which heart valve?

A. Aortic
B. Pulmonary
C. Thebesian
D. Mitral
E. Tricuspid

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year-old woman attends a new patient health check at the General Practice surgery she has recently joined. She mentions she occasionally gets episodes of palpitations and light-headedness and has done so for several years. Her pulse is currently regular, with a rate of 70 bpm, and her blood pressure is 110/76 mmHg. A full blood count is sent, which comes back as normal. The general practitioner requests an electrocardiogram (ECG), which shows a widened QRS complex with a slurred upstroke and a shortened PR interval.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. First-degree heart block
B. Ebstein’s anomaly
C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
D. Mobitz type II atrioventricular block
E. Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe bilateral pneumonia, which is found to be secondary to Legionella. He is hypoxic and drowsy and has an acute kidney injury. He is intubated and ventilated and transferred to the Intensive Care Unit. Despite optimal organ support, his respiratory system continues to deteriorate, requiring high fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) (0.8) to maintain oxygen saturations of 88–92%. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. A diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is made.
Which of the following is a recognised component of the management strategy for ARDS?

A. Standard ventilation with high tidal volumes
B. Low positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
C. Lung-protective ventilation
D. Positioning at 45 degrees
E. Mechanical ventilation with high tidal volume

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of a hoarse voice for a few weeks. She had a thyroidectomy 10 years ago. Upon examination, there are reduced breath sounds in the left upper lobe. She has a history of 80 pack years, quitting five years ago. Chest X-ray was done and there was a left upper left lobe opacity.
Which cranial nerve is most likely to have been affected?

A. Vagus
B. Trigeminal
C. Facial
D. Glossopharyngeal
E. Hypoglossal

Correct Answer: A

An 85-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department complaining of shortness of breath. On examination, you note that his trachea is central and there is reduced chest expansion on the left with a stony dull percussion note and reduced breath sounds.
What is the diagnosis?

A. Pneumothorax
B. Pleural effusion
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Pneumonia
E. Pulmonary oedema

Correct Answer: B

A 70-year-old woman with obesity and type II diabetes presents describing symptoms of stress incontinence.
Which of the following is the first-line treatment for urinary stress incontinence?

A. Colposuspension
B. Duloxetine
C. Pelvic floor muscle training
D. Pudendal nerve stimulation
E. Radiotherapy

Correct Answer: C

A couple attends for genetic counselling. The husband suffers from haemophilia A. The wife has had genetic screening and is not a carrier of the haemophilia gene. They are considering having children.
If they have a son, what are the chances that he will have haemophilia A?

A. 1 in 2
B. Zero
C. 1 in 4
D. 1 in 1
D. E. 1 in 100

Correct Answer: B

During a surgical rotation, a Foundation Year 1 (FY1) doctor was asked to identify anatomic structures on a single magnetic resonance image of the abdomen taken in the transverse plane through the xiphoid process.
Which of the following structures would occupy the largest area on the observed image?

A. Inferior vena cava
B. Liver
C. Kidneys
D. Spleen
E. Stomach

Correct Answer: B

A 75-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a right-sided headache associated with diplopia, binocularly. He is known to have hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus.
On examination, his visual acuity is 6/9 in both eyes. There is a ptosis of his right eye. His right pupil appears larger than the left. His right eye is abducted on primary gaze. His right eye movements are restricted in most directions except abduction.
Which one of the following is the most important cause you need to rule out in this condition?

A. Anterior-communicating artery aneurysm
B. Demyelination
C. Microvascular ischaemia
D. Posterior-communicating artery aneurysm
E. Space-occupying lesion

Correct Answer: D

At birth, a baby boy is noticed to have small bowel contents herniating through a defect in the midline of the abdominal wall. The small bowel is not encased in a peritoneal sac. His mother declined all antenatal scans.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Gastroschisis
B. Hirschsprung's disease
C. Meconium ileus
D. Midgut volvulus
E. Omphalocoele

Correct Answer: A

A previously healthy 68-year-old man collapsed while playing with his grandchildren. Although he quickly regained consciousness and became fully alert, his family called an ambulance. The emergency medical team found no abnormalities on the electrocardiogram. Physical examination was unremarkable. However, the patient was admitted to the Coronary Care Unit of the local hospital. During the evening, the patient was noted to have a fast rhythm with a wide complex on his monitor, followed by hypotension and loss of consciousness.
After electrical cardioversion with 200 watt-seconds of direct current, which one of the following may possible therapy include?

A. Intravenous propranolol
B. Digitalis
C. Amiodarone
D. Intravenous diltiazem
E. Epinephrine

Correct Answer: C

You are called by the nurse in charge of the ward to review a patient who has been newly admitted from her nursing home with pneumonia and confusion. Whilst washing her, the nurses have noticed a pressure sore near her sacrum and have asked for you to assess it. On examination you find a 4cm round wound lateral to the sacrum with some surrounding erythema. It is approximately 1-2cm deep. There is subcutaneous fat visible in the wound bed with some slough, but no bone, muscle or tendon is exposed.
What grade of pressure sore would this be compatible with?

A. EPUAP Grade/Stage I
A. B. EPUAP Grade/Stage II
A. B. C. EPUAP Grade/Stage III
A. D. EPUAP Grade/Stage IV
E. EPUAP Grade/Stage V

Correct Answer: C

A normally fit and well 30-year-old man is admitted to Accident and Emergency with a 4-hour history of palpitations. He has no chest pain and a National Early Warning Score (NEWS) score of 0. On examination, the only positive finding is of an irregularly irregular pulse. An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirms that the patient is in atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient has no significant past medical history and is on no regular medication. On investigation, his bloods (thyroid function tests (TFTs), full blood count (FBC), urea and electrolytes (U&Es), liver function tests (LFTs) and coagulation screen) are normal and a chest X-ray (CXR) is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

A. Intravenous (IV) adenosine
B. IV flecainide
C. Anticoagulation therapy with heparin and plan for elective cardioversion
D. Trial of b-blocker (sotalol), give anticoagulation and review in 1 week
E. Send home with a 24-hour three-lead ECG tape and review in 1 week

Correct Answer: B

A 63-year-old man presents with a cough and drooping of his eyelid. He also complains of dryness affecting one side of his face. On questioning, he has no other significant health problems but admits to a long-standing smoking history.
What is the most appropriate next investigation?

A. Chest X-ray
B. Sputum sample
C. Bronchoscopy
D. Spirometery
E. Computed tomography-positron emission tomography (CT-PET) scan

Correct Answer: A

A 1-year old boy is diagnosed with having a genetic condition that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Of the following diseases, which is best described as being inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern?

A. Type 1 von Willebrand’s disease
B. Familial polyposis coli
C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
D. Haemophilia B
E. Cystic fibrosis

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman is referred by her general practitioner for investigation of a breast lump. A breast malignancy is suspected.
What is the best initial imaging modality to use in this patient?

A. Ultrasound scan (USS) breast
B. Chest X-ray
C. Computed tomography (CT) chest
D. X-ray mammography
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) chest

Correct Answer: D

Examine the photomicrograph of normal human bone marrow below.
Into which cell in the peripheral blood will these cells ultimately differentiate?

A. Neutrophil
B. Basophil
C. Eosinophil
D. Erythrocyte
E. Adipocytes

Correct Answer: D

A 10-year-old boy has haematuria, hearing loss, and poor eyesight due to lens dislocation. Further tests make the diagnosis of Alport syndrome.
In most cases, this disease is due to a molecular defect in which kind of collagen?

A. Type I
B. Type II
C. Type III
D. Type IV
E. Type VII

Correct Answer: D

A 21-year-old pregnant woman presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a 5-day history of redness, grittiness and stickiness of both eyes. She complains of some whitish-yellow discharge on her lids, especially when she wakes up in the morning.
On examination, her vision is 6/6 in both eyes. The conjunctivae are diffusely injected with some mild chemosis. There is no fluorescein uptake on the cornea.
What is the first-line treatment for this patient’s eye condition?

A. Artificial tears
B. Eye shield
C. Topical chloramphenicol eye drops
D. Topical fusidic acid eye drops
E. Topical steroid eye drops

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old man was stabbed with a knife and brought to the Emergency Department with the knife still in the left posterolateral side of his body. The knife entered the intercostal space between the left ninth and tenth ribs, 10 cm posterior to the mid-axillary line.
Which of the following structures was most likely the first to be damaged by the knife?

A. Pancreas
B. Left kidney
C. Stomach
D. Gallbladder
E. Spleen

Correct Answer: E

An 80-year-old man with chronic COPD presents for a review of his home oxygen therapy. The following results are from his arterial blood gas (ABG):
pH 7.37 (normal range 7.35–7.45)
pa(O2) 7.6 (normal range 10–14 kPa)
pa(CO2) 8 (normal range 4.0–6.0 kPa)
HCO3 37 (normal range 22–26 mmol)
base excess +6 (normal range −2 to +2 mmol).
Which of the following best describe this man’s blood gas result?

A. Partial compensation for respiratory alkalosis secondary to chronic respiratory disease
B. Partial compensation for respiratory acidosis secondary to chronic respiratory disease
C. Compensation for respiratory acidosis secondary to chronic respiratory disease
D. Compensation for respiratory acidosis secondary to acute respiratory disease
E. Compensation for metabolic acidosis secondary to chronic respiratory disease

Correct Answer: C

Which of the following patients would most benefit from hospice care involvement?

A. A 40-year-old woman with relapsing–remitting multiple sclerosis
B. A 60-year-old man with colorectal carcinoma stage T2N1M0
C. A 65-year-old woman with end-stage dementia
D. A 80-year-old man with stage 2 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
E. A 90-year-old man with prostate cancer stage T3N1M0

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man undergoes genetic testing after he develops colorectal cancer at the age of 40. His mother also had colorectal cancer at a similar age and died from the disease. He undergoes genetic testing and is found to have classic familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) coli. He has a 3-year-old son.
If his son has inherited classic FAP and does not undergo prophylactic surgery, what is the likelihood he will develop colon cancer?

A. Over 90%
B. Almost 70%
C. Approximately 50%
D. Approximately 10%
E. < 1%

Correct Answer: A

A 49-year-old woman with primary sclerosing cholangitis complains of a 2 week history of pain under her right rib cage and 2 days history of yellow skin and pale stools. She has also lost 2 stone over the last 6 months.
Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following tumour markers would be the relevant investigation?

A. AFP
B. CA 19–9
C. CEA
D. CA 125
E. CA 15–3

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old office worker and father of two presents with back pain. This started after lifting some heavy boxes at the weekend. The pain was initially limited to his lower back but now he has shooting pains radiating down the back of his thigh, the lateral aspect of his leg and into the lateral border of his right foot. The pain can wake him at night if he moves suddenly but does not otherwise disturb his sleep. He is well, with no past medical history of note. He reports no lower limb weakness, disturbance of sphincter function, nor any saddle symptoms. Examination reveals a tender lumbar spine, numbness to the lateral border of the right foot and pain on straight leg raise at 40 degrees on the right. There is no limb weakness.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Give analgesia and refer for physiotherapy while arranging a magnetic resonance (MR) scan of the lumbar spine
B. Give analgesia and refer for physiotherapy and review after 4 weeks to arrange onward referral to a spinal surgeon or musculoskeletal medicine specialist if no better
C. Give analgesia and recommend bed rest for 2 weeks, with a review after this to arrange physiotherapy if the pain is no better
D. Give analgesia and refer for physiotherapy, with a review after 8 weeks to consider onward referral to a spinal surgeon or musculoskeletal medicine specialist if no better
E. Give analgesia and, in view of the presence of night pain, arrange an urgent MR spine

Correct Answer: D

An 89-year-old woman is seen for recent-onset confusion. She was in her usual state of health until she was noted to be confused and agitated at dinner yesterday. This morning, she was alert and oriented, but later in the evening, she was entirely confused, agitated and belligerent. She was then brought into the Emergency Department by ambulance. Further history reveals no previous episodes of confusion, but a few days of frequency of urination.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of her confusion?

A. Alzheimer’s dementia
B. Vascular dementia
C. Pyelonephritis
D. Urinary tract infection (UTI)
E. Pseudodementia

Correct Answer: D

A 24-year-old man with a documented harsh ejection systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation collapses and dies while participating in an athletic event. His father and uncle also died suddenly in their thirties. The cause of death is determined to be an obstruction of the ventricular outflow tract due to an abnormality in the ventricular septum.
Which of the following is the correct diagnosis of this disorder?

A. Mitral stenosis
B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
C. Restrictive cardiomyopathy
D. Dilated cardiomyopathy
E. Ventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: B

A 39-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department (ED) after being involved in a motor vehicle accident, in which he was thrown from a motorcycle. In the ED, the patient is non-responsive. Neurological examination demonstrates intact pupillary and corneal reflexes; however, the remainder of the examination cannot be completed. Twenty minutes later, computerised tomography (CT) demonstrates uncal herniation of the right temporal lobe, and the patient is rushed to surgery.
Which of the following changes in physical examination findings is most consistent with this patient’s presentation?

A. Left pupillary dilation
B. Right pupillary constriction
C. Right pupil deviated medially
D. Left pupil depressed and abducted
E. Right pupillary dilation

Correct Answer: E

A 46-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 2-day history of erythema around his right eye and restricted eye movements. He has been suffering with sinusitis for the past week. On examination of his right eye, he has erythema surrounding the eye, proptosis, painful and restricted eye movements and reduced visual acuity. Examination of his left eye is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation?

A. Computed tomography (CT) orbit, sinuses and brain
B. No further imaging required
C. Ophthalmic ultrasound
D. Optical coherence photography (OCT)
E. X-ray skull bones

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of pain and swelling affecting the right knee and left ankle.
On further questioning, he complained of dysuria and had woken with both eyes ‘stuck together’ for the last three days. He thinks that his urinary symptoms may be linked to the unprotected sex he had three weeks ago.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Syphilis
B. Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) infection
C. Reactive arthritis
D. Trichomoniasis
E. Escherichia coli infection

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old man with multiple sclerosis has been taking methadone for relief of painful muscle spasms. He has found it difficult to come to terms with his condition, and chronic pain has made him depressed. His general practitioner has prescribed him amitriptyline at night as an antidepressant and to aid sleep. He comes to clinic for a check-up, and a routine ECG is performed.
Which abnormality on ECG could be caused by a drug–drug interaction for this patient?

A. Atrial flutter
B. Atrial fibrillation
C. First-degree heart block
D. Long QT syndrome
E. Supraventricular tachycardia

Correct Answer: D

A 43-year-old alcoholic presents to the Emergency Department with retrosternal chest pain, shortness of breath and pain on swallowing after a large drinking session the night before. He reports having vomited several times this morning, after which the pain started. He denies any blood in the vomit and has no melaena. On examination, he is febrile and tachypnoeic and has a heart rate of 110 bpm. A chest X-ray reveals a left-sided pneumothorax and air within the mediastinum.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management to treat the underlying cause of his symptoms?

A. Antibiotics to treat infection
B. Chest drain insertion
C. Proton pump inhibitor (PPI)
D. Urgent endoscopy
E. Urgent surgery

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old cleaner is found to have a T-score of -2.7 following a DXA scan for assessment of bone density after obtaining two separate fractures over the course of one year. She is started on bisphosphonate therapy once weekly alongside a vitamin D supplement.
On which cell type do bisphosphonates act?

A. Renal tubular cells
B. Osteoblasts
C. Osteocytes
D. Osteoclasts
E. Intestinal mucosal cells

Correct Answer: D

A 42-year-old man presents to his general practice with an itchy rash on his arm. On examination, you note polygonal, violaceous papules on the inner aspect of his forearm. Some of these papules have coalesced to form plaques. He has no past medical history of skin diseases and is currently not taking any medications.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Scabies
B. Lichen sclerosus
C. Atopic dermatitis
D. Plaque psoriasis
E. Lichen planus

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old housewife with longstanding psoriasis attends her General Practitioner (GP) practice with increasing joint pains for the past three months.
Following examination, the GP suspects possible psoriatic arthropathy and refers the patient to the rheumatologist.
Which one of the following is a severe form of presentation of psoriatic arthropathy?

A. Proximal interphalangeal joint predominant
B. Ankylosing spondylitis
C. Osteoarthritis-like
D. Arthritis mutilans
E. Symmetrical oligoarthritis

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old endurance athlete, who has been training for an ultra-marathon, presents with exertional knee pain that is localised over the lateral femoral condyle that is relieved by rest. On examination, there is no instability of the knee, but there is point tenderness over the lateral femoral condyle and joint crepitus. The pain is reproduced with a single leg squat. Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral knee X-rays are normal, with no fracture or joint space narrowing.
What is the best treatment option for this patient?

A. Rest, ice, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and simple analgesia, followed by physical therapy and training modification
B. Proceed to corticosteroid injections to relieve pain
C. Knee arthroscopy to exclude any other joint pathology
D. Operative surgical excision of the ITB
E. Lateral femoral condyle osteotomy and bone shaving

Correct Answer: A

A 3-year-old child is brought to the surgery with a 2-day history of coryzal illness with cough and a high fever (when checked at home, it was 39.2 °C). She has been more ‘clingy’ than normal and off her food, although fluid intake is good. Her mother reports she has a rash, which started this morning.
Temperature is 37.9 °C. Heart rate is 124 bpm. Respiratory rate is 26 breaths/min. Capillary refill time is 2 s centrally. On examination, she is smiling but cries when not sitting on her mother’s lap; her tonsils are enlarged but without any exudates present. Her tongue is pale with red spots all over. You cannot feel any cervical lymph nodes. Chest examination is normal. There is a red blanching rash over the neck and torso.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Penicillin V orally for 10 days
B. Delayed antibiotics (penicillin V orally for 10 days) to be commenced if not improving in the next 24 h
C. Advice on management of sore throat but no antibiotic prescription
D. Admission to the local paediatric ward for observation of the rash
E. Review in the surgery in 24 h to decide if antibiotics are required

Correct Answer: A

A 24-year-old woman attends Breast Clinic with a two month history of a painful lump near the left nipple. The pain does not vary with menstrual cycles. She is worried because her grandmother was recently diagnosed with breast cancer, aged 79. She smokes 6–10 cigarettes a day and drinks 10 units of alcohol per week. On examination, there is a 3 cm smooth periareolar lump. It is tender and there is overlying skin erythema, which the patient says has been present for two weeks. The patient is able to express pus discharge from the nipple.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Periductal mastitis
B. Fibrocystic disease
C. Fibroadenoma
D. Breast cancer
E. Paget’s disease of the nipple

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man presents to Emergency Department with progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and has recently been waking up at night feeling short of breath. He has a pansystolic murmur found on auscultation, as well as coarse bilateral bibasal crackles found on auscultation. His echocardiogram reveals a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and severe mitral regurgitation. Cardiologists recommend that he commences certain medications to improve both his symptoms and long-term outcomes until he has definitive treatment of his valvular pathology.
Which one of the following medications has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with the described condition?

A. Furosemide
B. Aspirin
C. Nifedipine
D. Carvedilol
E. Digoxin

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old builder presents with a rash that troubles the patient on both hands. He thinks cement may be causing the issue because he finds he improves when he is on holiday. He claims when he comes back within a few days the rash gets worse again.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most likely mechanism for the development of this rash?

A. Autoimmune disease
B. Psoriasis
C. Type III hypersensitivity
D. Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity
E. Type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity

Correct Answer: E

A 10-year-old boy attends the GP with his mother. He has been avoiding school for the past few weeks and not going out with any friends. This is very out of character, as he was previously very sociable and outgoing, with a keen interest in playing football with his friends after school.
Which of the following is recommended for treatment of social anxiety in children and young people?

A. Fluoxetine
B. Group or individual cognitive behavioural therapy
C. Mindfulness-based intervention
D. Sertraline
E. St John’s wort

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old woman presents to the Sexual Health Clinic after having unprotected sexual intercourse with a colleague following a night out two weeks previously. Although she is asymptomatic, she is very worried that she may have caught a sexually transmitted infection. She is so concerned that she has been unable to sleep at night and is unable to concentrate on her work as a trainee accountant.
With regard to sexually transmitted infections, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Chlamydial infection is usually symptomatic
B. Gonorrhoea can be diagnosed, and antibiotic sensitivities tested from an endocervical swab
C. The classic lesion of secondary syphilis is the chancre
D. Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) typically causes genital herpes
E. The treatment of choice for chlamydial infection is metronidazole

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old patient presents with progressive weakness of the arms and legs over 1 week. Three weeks earlier, she had an episode of diarrhoea lasting 5 days. Examination confirms distal weakness and ‘glove-and-stocking’ sensory loss.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Multiple sclerosis (MS)
B. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
C. Guillain–Barré syndrome
D. Diabetic neuropathy
E. Acute intermittent porphyria

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department, following his return from a holiday in the United States a few days previously. He had noticed some swelling of his left leg, and today he has developed weakness of the right-hand side of his body.
Which of the following would be used to confirm the underlying cardiological diagnosis in this patient?

A. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
B. Chest X-ray
C. Carotid Doppler
D. Transoesophageal echocardiogram
E. Ventilation–perfusion scan

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhoea. She says that her stools float and are difficult to flush away. Blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
Potassium (K+) 3.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Corrected calcium 2.08 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Albumin 29 g/l 35–55 g/l
Haemoglobin 91 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 89 fl 76–98 fl
Coeliac disease is suspected.
Which of the following is the initial investigation of choice?

A. Anti-gliadin
B. Small bowel biopsy
C. Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-TTG)
D. Magnesium level
E. Faecal fat assay

Correct Answer: C

You are a junior doctor in paediatrics. You have been asked to help on the Postnatal Ward to perform newborn examinations.
Which statement is true regarding the Ortolani manoeuvre?

A. A negative test in any baby negates the need for any further investigation
B. It is performed by adducting the hip while applying pressure on the knee
C. Parents can be reassured that a negative test excludes all hip problems in their child
D. It relocates a dislocation of the hip joint if this has been elicited during the Barlow manoeuvre
E. It tests for anterior dislocation of the hip

Correct Answer: D

An 82-year-old woman is transferred from a nursing home with a change in behaviour, insomnia and fever. Staff in the nursing home state that over the last five days, she has appeared confused and agitated and seems to be having visual hallucinations, as she has been talking and gesturing to people who are not present in the room. She has a past medical history of Lewy body dementia. On clinical examination, she is not orientated to time, place or person. She is mildly agitated. Her blood pressure is 110/58 mmHg, pulse 98 bpm and temperature 38.1 °C. Urinalysis is positive for nitrites and leukocytes.
Which of the following management plans should be considered as initial treatment for delirium?

A. Sedate with haloperidol, provide a suitable care environment
B. Sedate with olanzapine, provide a suitable care environment
C. Sedate with haloperidol, nurse in a dimly lit room, orientate frequently
D. Treat the underlying cause, ensure effective communication and reorientation, provide reassurance for people diagnosed with delirium, provide a suitable care environment
E. Treat the underlying cause, nurse one-to-one in a single room

Correct Answer: D

A 25-year-old intravenous drug abuser is found to have a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge at the fifth costal cartilage.
Disease at which one of the following anatomical sites is the most likely cause of the murmur?

A. Aortic valve
B. Interatrial septum
C. Interventricular septum
D. Mitral valve
E. Tricuspid valve

Correct Answer: E

A 63-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 4-month history of erectile dysfunction. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m², a background of hypertension and he has a 40-pack-year smoking history. He has no other symptoms and feels well in himself.
Which of the following is an important first-line investigation for erectile dysfunction?

A. C-reactive protein (CRP)
B. Glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c)
C. Ultrasound abdomen
D. Urea and electrolytes
E. Urine dip

Correct Answer: B

A 2-month-old baby boy has just been registered with the surgery. His parents have recently come to the UK from South Sudan, having sought asylum. He was given a BCG vaccination, while his family were awaiting entry to the UK.
Which immunisations should he now be offered?

A. C. Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b, hepatitis B, rotavirus and meningitis B
B. C. Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b, hepatitis B, Pneumococcus, rotavirus and meningitis C
C. Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b, hepatitis B
C. D. Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b, hepatitis B and meningitis C
C. E. Diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenzae type b, hepatitis B, Pneumococcus and rotavirus

Correct Answer: A

A 34-year-old, nutritionally deplete patient requires insertion of a nasogastric tube (NGT) to commence enteral feeding.
What is the best precaution to take before starting the feeding regimen?

A. Aspirate 10 ml from the tube and observe the appearance of the tube aspirate
B. Insert 50 ml of air and auscultate over the stomach (‘whoosh test’)
C. Observe for the presence of respiratory distress, as its absence is a reliable indicator of correct placement
D. Chest radiograph
E. Abdominal radiograph

Correct Answer: D

One of the following diuretics works by inhibiting the co-transport of Na+/K+/2Cl- in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
Which is the appropriate answer?

A. Furosemide
B. Bendroflumethiazide
C. Spironolactone
D. Acetazolamide
E. Mannitol

Correct Answer: A

Mrs Rose brings her 3-year-old toddler into the clinic and is anxious and distressed that her child has ‘flat feet’. She has been advised that he should have an early operation and to buy expensive orthotics to reverse this condition. On examination, he is a happy toddler who is running around with full mobility and in no pain. The foot is only flat with standing and you note that the arch reconstitutes with toe walking and foot hanging.
What advice would you give Mrs Rose about her son?

A. He should have an early operation with Achilles tendon or gastrocnemius fascia lengthening
B. He should have a calcaneal lengthening osteotomy
C. He should not have the operation but should wear orthotics
D. Reassure her that in asymptomatic patients, the arch will normally redevelop with age and resolve spontaneously
E. He should be given bed rest and partial weight bearing to prevent the condition from progressing

Correct Answer: D

A 37-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling, blood-tinged diarrhoea. She was well until 3 days ago, when she developed abdominal discomfort with frequent bowel movements. Her blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, pulse rate 90 bpm, respiratory rate 14 breaths/min and body temperature 38.1 °C. She is alert and oriented. There is mild abdominal tenderness, especially in the right lower quadrant, without rigidity or guarding. A tender mass is palpated in the right lower quadrant. Multiple erythematous and tender patches are noted over the anterior lower leg. A stool sample is sent for examination of red cells, leukocytes, bacteria, ova and parasites and for culture.
Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this condition?

A. Escherichia coli
B. Campylobacter
C. Yersinia enterocolitica
D. Salmonella
E. Vibrio vulnificus

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old woman underwent a total thyroidectomy for follicular carcinoma of the thyroid gland. Within a day of surgery, she is noted to have tingling sensations and neuromuscular irritability.
Which of the following serum laboratory tests should be ordered immediately to determine further therapy for this woman?

A. Calcitonin
B. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
C. Total thyroxine (T4)
D. Ionised calcium
E. Parathyroid hormone

Correct Answer: D

A patient presents to his general practitioner with loss of vision in the right upper quadrant of his visual field of both eyes.
Where in the visual circuit in the brain is the patient most likely to have a lesion?

A. Right optic nerve
B. Left inferior optic radiation
C. Right parietal optic radiation
D. Complete left occipital lobe
E. Optic chiasm

Correct Answer: B

A 58-year-old man who has been admitted to hospital after a fall resulting in a fractured intracapsular neck of femur. He has been consented for a hemiarthroplasty and is third on the list for the following morning. He is currently on warfarin; however, he has been administered with vitamin K which has normalised his international normalised ratio (INR) before surgery. He has many co-morbidities, including atrial fibrillation, previous transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) and type 2 diabetes mellitus, and he takes an extensive list of medications. The senior house officer has been asked to review his medications before surgery tomorrow. He is currently haemodynamically stable, normocardic and apyrexial.
Which of the following medications is safe to take on the day of surgery?

A. Ramipril
B. Metformin
C. Digoxin
D. Aspirin
E. Gliclazide

Correct Answer: C

You have been asked to insert a central line under ultrasound for an intravenous (iv) drug user whom your colleagues have been unable to cannulate. The patient has a groin abscess requiring incision, drainage and iv antibiotics.
Regarding the ultrasound probe, which one of the following statements is correct?

A. Piezoelectric crystals are used to detect the signal only
B. Penetration is increased at higher frequency
C. Penetration is increased at low frequency
D. Resolution is reduced at higher frequency
E. Resolution is increased at low frequency

Correct Answer: C
