A 64-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with chest pain that started 3 hours ago. The patient reports that he first noticed pain while lying in bed. The pain is 6/10 in intensity and worse with deep inspiration but improved on leaning forward. His medical history is significant for long-standing diabetes mellitus and a myocardial infarction 4 weeks ago, for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient recovered uneventfully. He smokes 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Auscultation of the chest reveals a friction rub. Serum inflammatory markers are elevated, whilst serial troponins are stable.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Papillary muscle rupture
B. Ventricular aneurysm
C. Reinfarction
D. Pericardial tamponade
E. Dressler syndrome

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with severe, sudden-onset lower abdominal pain of 2 hours’ duration and vaginal bleeding. The pain is becoming steadily worse. On examination, she is apyrexial, tachycardic and hypotensive, and has tenderness in the lower abdomen with guarding and rebound. She has had a positive pregnancy test in the past week and reports that her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Ultrasound scan reveals haemoperitoneum and right tubal rupture. The patient has been advised laparotomy for ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
What part of the fallopian tube due to Ectopic pregnancies is most likely to rupture?

A. Ampulla
B. Fimbrial end
C. Isthmus
D. Cornua
E. Interstitial part

Correct Answer: C

A first-time mother who is currently exclusively breastfeeding her infant, now four months old, is considering a phased return back to work and she is wondering about breastfeeding recommendations.
Which of the following best describes the World Health Organization (WHO) breastfeeding recommendations?

A. Exclusive breastfeeding for four months, followed by a combination of foods and breastfeeding for up to one year of age
B. Exclusive breastfeeding for four months, followed by a combination of foods and breastfeeding for up to two years of age
C. Exclusive breastfeeding for six months, followed by a combination of foods and breastfeeding for up to one year of age
D. Exclusive breastfeeding for six months, followed by a combination of foods and breastfeeding up to two years of age
D. E. Exclusive breastfeeding for six months, followed by a combination of foods and breastfeeding up to two years of age or beyond

Correct Answer: E

A 97-year-old gentleman is admitted for an incarcerated hernia. He has a past medical history of chronic kidney disease stage 3, secondary to hypertension, and a background of transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) and osteoarthritis of both knees.
He has four good twitches on train of four testing (normal response), following which reversal of his muscle relaxant was given. Intraoperatively, he received a total of 100 micrograms of fentanyl, 20 mg of morphine and 1 g of paracetamol for pain. He has an arterial line in situ. Blood gas prior to finishing the procedure showed a pH of 7.35, PaCO2 of 5.4 kPa, HCO3− of 21 mmol/l, with a blood sugar of 7.2.
You attempt to wean him off ventilation, but 20 minutes later he still does not want to breathe unsupported or wake up.
What should your next course of action be?

A. Wait a little longer, he is old
B. Give 100 ml of 10% glucose intravenously (iv)
C. Give naloxone 100 micrograms iv
D. Give a second dose of muscle relaxant reversal
E. Re-sedate and take for a computed tomography (CT) head

Correct Answer: C

A 71-year-old retired plumber is admitted with progressive shortness of breath, haemoptysis and weight loss. He is a smoker of 25 pack years.
On chest X-ray (CXR), a focal mass is seen peripherally in the left lower lobe.
Serum biochemistry:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 136 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Corrected Ca2+ 3.32 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Urea 6.8 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 76 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Albumin 38 g/l 35–55 g/l
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alveolar cell bronchial carcinoma
B. Mesothelioma
C. Tuberculosis
D. Squamous cell bronchial carcinoma
E. Small (oat) cell bronchial carcinoma

Correct Answer: D

A 34-year-old man with schizophrenia has been known to the mental health services for several years with a remitting and relapsing course of disease. His consultant, in conjunction with the patient’s Community Psychiatric Nurse (CPN), decides to commence clozapine. As part of the prescription, he is enrolled into the Clozapine Monitoring Service programme.
Which one of the following statements most accurately reflects the main reason for enrolment?

A. Due to a limited budget for this medication
B. To monitor the white cell count
C. To monitor liver function tests
D. To allow audit of the drug to be recorded
E. To monitor renal function

Correct Answer: B

An 8-year-old boy is admitted to hospital because of marked shortness of breath, a rash involving erythaematous macules with a central clearing on the torso and extensor surfaces of the limbs and bilateral swollen and painful hips and left knee joint. He is also febrile. Chest radiograph is performed with shows cardiomegaly, alveolar oedema and upper lobe venous diversion. He is transferred to intensive care for aggressive treatment.
Which of the following is most likely present in his recent medical history?

A. Meningitis
B. Penicillin-based treatment
C. Cyanosis and exertional chest pain
D. Pharyngitis
E. Urethritis

Correct Answer: D

A 42-year-old man presents to his GP with a painless neck lump. He has a previous history of hyperparathyroidism. On examination the lump is irregular and fixed at his thyroid. He is very concerned about cancer, as his father passed away in his 50s with a phaeochromocytoma.
Based on these findings, what is the most likely thyroid cancer this patient could have?

A. Anaplastic
B. Follicular
C. Lymphoma
D. Medullary
E. Papillary

Correct Answer: D

A 42-year-old Afro-Caribbean man presents with fever, dry cough and joint pains. On examination, his chest is clear. He has multiple tender, warm, erythematous nodules on both shins. Chest radiograph shows prominent hila bilaterally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Mycoplasma pneumonia
B. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
C. Tuberculosis (TB)
D. Sarcoidosis
E. Pulmonary fibrosis

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman presents for review of her longstanding chronic kidney disease (CKD). She has a past medical history of high blood pressure, type II diabetes and high cholesterol. Her recent estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is 35.
Which stage of CKD is most appropriate to classify her as?

A. Stage 1
B. Stage 2
C. Stage 3b
D. Stage 4
E. Stage 3a

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man is admitted with severe shortness of breath during the early hours of the morning. Past history of note includes difficult-to-manage hypertension, for which he now takes amlodipine 10 mg, indapamide 1.5 mg and doxazosin 8 mg. He failed a trial of ramipril 1 year earlier due to a rise in his creatinine of 40% at the 1-week post-initiation stage. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 185/100 mmHg and a pulse of 100 bpm regular and is in frank pulmonary oedema. When you review his old notes, you find this is the second episode during the past 6 months. Echocardiography has shown a preserved ejection fraction. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Phaeochromocytoma
B. Renal artery stenosis
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Nephritic syndrome
E. Renal vein thrombosis

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old woman from the UK presents with lethargy, and dizziness when she gets out of bed in the mornings and stands from sitting. She has noticed that her appetite has been reduced for the last month but has not noticed any weight loss. On examination you notice that she has an area of hypopigmented skin on her back, but hyperpigmented skin around her mouth, and you suspect a diagnosis of Addison’s disease.
What is the most common cause of Addison’s disease in the UK?

A. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
B. Tuberculosis
C. Autoimmune destruction
D. Adrenal haemorrhage
E. Metastatic cancer

Correct Answer: C

A 64-year-old mother of four presents to the Gynaecology Clinic, having been referred by her general practitioner. She describes a dragging sensation and the feeling of a lump in her vagina. In addition, she also reports several embarrassing incidences of incontinence following coughing and sneezing. The clinician performs an examination which reveals a cystourethrocele. Both medical and surgical treatment options are discussed with the patient.
Which of the following surgical procedures could be treatment options for this patient?

A. Anterior colporrhaphy
B. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy
C. Vaginal hysterectomy
D. Sacrocolpopexy
E. Sacrospinous fixation

Correct Answer: A

A patient attends the Neurology clinic following a referral from the general practitioner due to difficulty with eating and chewing food. A neurologist performs a cranial nerve assessment and suspects a lesion of the right-sided trigeminal nerve.
Which of the following is a clinical feature of a trigeminal nerve palsy?

A. Paralysis of the right buccinator muscle
B. Loss of right eye blinking control
C. Loss of taste in anterior two-thirds of the tongue
D. Loss of taste in posterior third of the tongue
E. Bite weakness

Correct Answer: E

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal-recessive condition. It is commonly diagnosed following birth, although in extremely rare cases it can present for the first time in adolescence and adulthood.
A teenager would like genetic counselling. His mother and brother both have PKU. The teenager himself does not have PKU.
What is the chance that he is a carrier of the disease?

A. 0%
B. 25%
5A. 0%
D. 75%
10A. 0%

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old man is referred to a Fertility Clinic because he and his wife are having difficulty conceiving a child. They have been trying for 4 years. Laboratory semen analysis reveals a low sperm count with low motility.
In which of the following structures does spermatogenesis occur?

A. Ductus deferens
B. Epididymis
C. Seminiferous tubules
D. Prostate gland
E. Spermatic cord

Correct Answer: C

A 67-year-old woman has undergone a radical hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for endometrial carcinoma.
She is attending her follow-up clinic to receive her results, and the consultant reports that the tumour was found to involve the right fallopian tube and ovary, but the vagina and parametrial tissue were free of tumour. All nodes submitted were negative for carcinoma. No distant metastases were present.
According to the above description, how would you stage the tumour using the TNM 8 classification?

A. T1a N0 M0
B. T1b N0 M0
C. T2 N0 M0
D. T3a N0 M0
E. T3b N0 M0

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old man attends the Emergency Department having tripped down some stairs. He is unable to weight-bear and is tender over the lateral malleolus. An ankle radiograph reveals a fracture of the lateral malleolus at the level of the syndesmosis, associated with a fracture of the medial malleolus. There is no associated tibial fracture.
According to the Weber classification of ankle fractures, what type of fracture has occurred?

A. Weber A
B. Weber B1
C. Weber B2
D. Weber C
E. Weber D

Correct Answer: C

A 68-year-old man presents with severe left lower abdominal pain, his third attack in the past 2 years. He admits to intermittent dark red blood loss per rectum (PR) and diarrhoea. He generally has a poor diet and dislikes fruit and vegetables. On examination, he has a temperature of 38.2 °C and a tachycardia of 95 bpm, with a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg; his body mass index is 32. There is well-localised left iliac fossa tenderness.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 110 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 14.5 × 109/l (N 11.0) 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 280 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 10.0 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 145 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 64 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Colonic carcinoma
B. Inflammatory bowel disease
C. Irritable bowel syndrome
D. Gastroenteritis
E. Diverticulitis

Correct Answer: E

Transplantation is a life-saving surgical intervention which can give a patient an entirely new lease of life. However, there are significant risks associated with transplantation. Some of which are allograft reactions.
What is the pathophysiological mechanism of hyper-acute allograft rejection?

A. Lymphocyte, killer T-cell and cytokine activation
B. Class II human leukocyte antigen (HLA) antibody activation, monocyte adhesion and thrombosis
C. Class I HLA antibody activation, granulocyte adhesion and thrombosis
D. Donor major histocompatibility complex (MHC) I antigens react with host CD8 resulting in direct cytotoxic damage
E. Interstitial fibrosis

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old women presents to the breast clinic with a fixed lump in her breast. She has no children and is a smoker.
What is the next best course of action?

A. It is most likely a fibroadenoma. Send home and follow-up in 1 month
B. Triple test of clinical examination, ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration
C. Clinical examination and biopsy
D. Mammogram and return to clinic if appropriate for further tests
E. Admit for lumpectomy and histology

Correct Answer: B

A 61-year-old man is admitted at the request of his concerned family due to increased confusion. This has occurred over the past 3 months and has become steadily worse. He was living independently and had been an active local councillor. Now he is unable to identify his family members.
Examination findings: pleasantly confused, intermittent jerky movements of both upper arms.
The following investigations were performed:
CT brain: normal
Dementia screen: normal
Which one of the following diagnostic tests will assist most in diagnosis?

A. Doppler ultrasound of carotids
B. Electroencephalogram
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain
D. Muscle biopsy
E. Bone marrow biopsy

Correct Answer: B

A 21-year-old woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) with a history of a 2-day of headache, which had been increasing in severity despite taking painkillers. She has no past medical history of note. The pregnancy to date has been uneventful, although she mentions to the ED doctor that her hands and feet have become increasingly swollen over the past week or so. The patient’s blood pressure at her last midwife appointment two weeks ago was 118/76 mmHg.
On examination, the patient’s blood pressure is 160/112 mmHg, heart rate 110 beats per minute and her temperature is 37.1°C. Urine dipstick reveals protein +++.
What is the most appropriate medication to treat her?

A. Magnesium sulphate
B. Atenolol
C. Aspirin
D. Amlodopine
E. Ramipril

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old retired tennis professional comes to the doctor’s office, complaining of right shoulder pain for the last few months. He also mentions that overhead movement of the shoulder increases the pain. On examination, he has weakness and pain on abduction and forward flexion of the shoulder.
Which of the following muscles of the rotator cuff is most likely to be affected?

A. Infraspinatus
B. Supraspinatus
C. Subscapularis
D. Deltoid
E. Teres minor

Correct Answer: B

An elderly patient who is being treated in the Critical Care Ward is in acute hepatic failure and is currently being maintained on a ventilator. It is unclear whether or not they have irreversible brain damage. Tests are performed to investigate whether or not the patient is brain dead.
Which of the following is used to confirm cardiorespiratory death as opposed to brain death?

A. Apnoea testing
B. Asystole on electrocardiogram (ECG)
C. Lack of corneal reflex
D. Lack of Laryngeal reflex
E. Lack of pupillary reflex

Correct Answer: B

A 42-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department. He has a known past medical history of cystic fibrosis diagnosed when he was 20 years old after recurrent respiratory tract infections. He works as a gardener, but over the last few days has been finding it difficult to maintain his business due to increasing shortness of breath. He has also had a temperature of 38.5 °C, with increased sputum production. His wife has noticed that his breathing has been more laboured. A sputum culture has grown Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s symptoms?

A. Amoxicillin
B. Ciprofloxacin
C. Co-amoxiclav
D. Flucloxacillin
E. Metronidazole

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic active hepatitis B presents with abdominal distension and bilateral ankle oedema, worsening over the previous 2 weeks. Three months ago, he was admitted for bleeding oesophageal varices, which was treated endoscopically. There was shifting dullness without tenderness on abdominal examination, and splenomegaly was also noted. His serum albumin concentration was diminished. Prothrombin time was elevated.
Which one of the following diuretics will best help this patient?

A. Furosemide
B. Acetazolamide
C. Bumetanide
D. Thiazide
E. Spironolactone

Correct Answer: E

A 33-year-old primiparous woman with a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m2 presents at 26 weeks’ gestation for her 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), as she is at high risk of developing gestational diabetes. Her results are as follows:
Fasting plasma glucose 7.3 mmol/l
2-hour plasma glucose 10.8 mmol/l
Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

A. Lifestyle advice and metformin
B. Lifestyle advice and insulin
C. Lifestyle advice and review in two weeks
D. Lifestyle advice, metformin and insulin
E. Lifestyle advice only

Correct Answer: B

A father brings his 8-year-old son to see you at the General Practice surgery where you are working as a Foundation Year 2 doctor. The son had a runny nose and sore throat for the past few days but then developed bright red rashes on both his cheeks. He now has a raised itchy rash on his chest, that has a lace-like appearance, but feels well. He has no known long-term conditions and has been developing normally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Impetigo
B. Parvovirus infection
C. Pityriasis rosea
D. Scarlet fever
E. Urticaria

Correct Answer: B

A 37-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department complaining of severe breathlessness following a house fire. He has also vomited twice and has a headache and dizziness.
On examination, he is tachypnoeic, has good air entry, and oxygen saturations are recorded at 100% on air. He is drowsy, but the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 15, with a normal neurological examination and no signs of head injury.
What is the first step in your management?

A. High-flow oxygen
B. Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulphate combination therapy
C. Hyperbaric oxygen
D. Nebulised salbutamol and ipratropium
E. Metoclopramide

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old known alcoholic is brought by ambulance after being found unconscious on the road on a Sunday afternoon. He has a superficial laceration in the right frontal region. He is admitted for observation over the bank holiday weekend. Admission chest X-ray is normal. Before discharge on Tuesday morning, he is noted to be febrile and dyspnoeic. Blood tests reveal neutrophilia and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. A chest X-ray demonstrates consolidation in the right lower zone of the lung.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
B. Tuberculosis (TB)
C. Aspiration pneumonia
D. Staphylococcal pneumonia
E. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old man is due to undergo repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A magnetic resonance (MR) angiogram is obtained, which shows extensive stenosis along the abdominal aorta and extending into the common iliac arteries. Additionally, stenosis of the external iliac arteries is noted bilaterally, most notably on the left.
Which of the following arteries usually originates directly from the external iliac artery?

A. The profunda femoris
B. The superficial epigastric artery
C. The superficial circumflex iliac artery
D. The deep external pudendal artery
E. The inferior epigastric artery

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension and depression has an ongoing history of severe pins and needles in her hands upon waking in the morning. The patient has worked as a stenographer for the last 25 years, and this sensation has been growing in intensity over the past 7 years.
Which of the following findings would be expected, given this patient’s condition?

A. Flattening of the thenar eminence
B. Numbness over the medial aspect of the ring finger
C. Inability to abduct the thumb
D. Numbness over the proximal palm
E. Normal sensation over the radial aspect of the ring finger

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman presents to the General Practice Clinic. She has been feeling unwell over the last few days with nasal discharge, sneezing, fatigue and a cough. Her 5-year-old son recently recovered from very similar symptoms. On examination today, her pulse rate is 60 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute and temperature 37.1 °C.
What is the most likely causative organism for her symptoms?

A. Adenovirus
B. Enterovirus
C. Influenza virus
D. Respiratory syncytial virus
E. Rhinovirus

Correct Answer: E

A 65-year-old woman is brought to Emergency Department (ED) by her son. He informs you that she has been increasingly confused over the last couple of days and she has started sweating profusely. When you take a history from the patient you note significant confusion, and a Mini-Mental State Examination is difficult to complete due to her lack of ability to maintain attention to your questions. Examination reveals a bluish discoloration of her toes and finger tips bilaterally, as well as a petechial rash on the left side of her anterior abdominal wall.
You collect a set of observations, which are as follows:
Temperature 39.8 °C
Blood pressure (BP) 98/66 mmHg
Heart rate 124 bpm
Respiratory rate 22 breaths/min
pa(O2) 88%
After taking the observations, you note that she is documented as having visited her General Practitioner (GP) three days ago for dysuria, following which she was provided with a prescription of antibiotics.
The patient’s blood results are given below:
Investigation Result Normal range
White cell count (WCC) 16.0 × 109/l 4.0–11.0 × 109/l
Neutrophils 9900 × 106/l 3000–5800 × 106/l
Lymphocytes 4000 × 106/l 1500–3000 × 106/l
Red cell count (RCC) 4.4 × 1012/l Male 4.6–6.2 × 1012/l
Female 4.2–5.4 × 1012/l
Platelets 110 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
D-Dimer 1.8 μg/ml < 0.5 μg/ml
Prothrombin Test (PT) 16 s 10.6–14.9 s
Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 38 s 23.0–35.0 s
Fibrinogen 160 mg/dl 125–300 mg/dl
You present these findings to your registrar and she decides that the patient is most likely suffering from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
Following initial ED assessment how should you manage this patient?

A. Blood cross-match, urine output monitoring, 500 ml 0.9% saline stat, serum lactate measurement, blood and urine cultures, empirical IV antibiotics and titration of oxygen to ≥94%
B. Recombinant human activated protein C and a blood cross-match
C. Therapeutic dose low molecular weight (LMW) heparin, emergency blood transfusion of O-negative (universal donor) blood, urine output monitoring, 500 ml 0.9% saline stat, serum lactate measurement, blood and urine cultures, empirical IV antibiotics and titration of oxygen to ≥94%
D. IV infusion of tranexamic acid and a bolus of platelets
E. Prophylactic dose unfractionated heparin, human activated protein C, urine output monitoring, 500 ml 0.9% saline stat, serum lactate measurement, blood and urine cultures, empirical IV antibiotics and titration of oxygen to ≥94%

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old man is referred by his general practitioner due to complaints of headache, fatigue and weakness. Recently, he had a nosebleed that only stopped after the application of compression for a long time. He also suffered from pneumonia the previous month. He has no family history of a bleeding disorder. On examination, he has pallor, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Investigations reveal that he has a low haemoglobin level, a low white blood cell count and a low platelet count; numerous blast cells are visible on peripheral blood film. Bone marrow biopsy reveals 30% of blast cells. The blood film is shown below.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
B. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia
C. Chronic myeloid leukaemia
D. Hairy cell leukaemia
E. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)

Correct Answer: E

A 16-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with an acutely hot and swollen knee joint. The problem started about a day ago. His temperature is now 38.2°C and blood cultures have already been taken and sent off. Upon examination the knee is very tender and there is reduced movement due to the pain. This is the first presentation of this kind for this patient and he has no significant past medical history.
What should your next step be?

A. Aspirate knee joint and send for cell count, microscopy and culture
B. Blood cultures
C. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
D. Ultrasound of the knee
E. Arthroscopy and wash-out of the joint

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old man presents to Accident and Emergency with vomiting and severe upper abdominal pain, which came on suddenly an hour ago. On examination, he is unwell, tachycardic and tachypnoeic, with a temperature of 38.0°C. His blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg. He localises the pain to his upper abdomen, with some radiation to the back. His abdomen is generally tender, with bowel sounds present. There is no blood in his vomit. He is unable to provide further history due to the pain and nausea, but he is known to Accident and Emergency due to many previous admissions with alcohol intoxication. He has previously been normotensive, is a non-smoker and has not been treated for any other conditions.
Given the information obtained so far, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute pancreatitis
B. Aortic dissection
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Bleeding oesophageal varices
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: A

A 23-year-old man is diagnosed with schizophrenia and medical management is initiated by the Community Psychiatry team. Four days later, he presents to the Emergency Department with a temperature and severe muscle rigidity. The patient’s mother notes that he has been confused, and at times seems to be drowsy. He has also developed a tremor and seems to be having difficulty walking. Following assessment, a diagnosis of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is made.
NMS is a serious side-effect of neuroleptic drugs.
Which of the following is true regarding NMS?

A. No cases have been associated with the use of clozapine
B. Once it occurs, the chance of survival is minimal
C. The best treatment is a switch to a higher-potency neuroleptic drug
D. It is associated with all known neuroleptic drugs
E. It is associated only with the use of high potency neuroleptic drugs

Correct Answer: D

A 60-year-old woman is actively dying in hospice care; her family are concerned as she is no longer eating and drinking. They are worried that this will cause her pain and discomfort.
Which of the following side-effects is related to dehydration resulting from poor oral intake and is the most important to treat in an actively dying patient?

A. Hunger
B. Pain
C. Low urine output
D. Drowsiness
E. Xerostomia

Correct Answer: E

A 67-year-old man presents with bilateral ankle oedema. On examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated at 7 cm above the sternal angle and there are large V waves. On auscultation of the heart, a soft pan-systolic murmur is audible at the left sternal edge.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Tricuspid regurgitation
B. Tricuspid stenosis
C. Pulmonary stenosis
D. Mitral regurgitation
E. Mitral stenosis

Correct Answer: A

An 87-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP). She has had 23 urinary tract infections (UTIs) in the last 12 months, four of which resulted in hospital admission. She has capacity and declines further hospital visits for imaging of her urinary tract and does not want any further blood tests.
Her estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) was 37 three weeks ago. Her most recent mid-stream urine (MSU) result is shown below. She is currently asymptomatic but reports that she would like the problem addressed so she does not suffer from an infection again.
Urine microbiology, culture and sensitivity (MC&S):
Escherichia coli > 108 colony-forming units (cfu)/ml
White cell count > 5–99 × 108/ml
Trimethoprim – sensitive
Nitrofurantoin – sensitive
Cefalexin – sensitive
Amoxicillin – resistant
What is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Nitrofurantoin 50 mg ON
B. Trimethoprim 100 mg ON
C. Cefalexin 500 mg twice daily (bd)
D. Amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily (tid) for two weeks, then repeat urine MC&S
E. Trimethoprim 200 mg bd for two weeks, then repeat urine MC&S

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old male smoker presents with a 6-hour history of gradual-onset central chest pain. The chest pain is worse on inspiration and relieved by leaning forward. He reports recently suffering a fever which he attributed to a viral illness. He has no significant past medical history; however, both his parents suffered from ischaemic heart disease in their early 60s. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals PR depression and concave ST-segment elevation in most leads. He is haemodynamically stable.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Morphine, oxygen, nitrates, aspirin and clopidogrel
B. Urgent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
C. Thrombolysis
D. Ibuprofen
E. Pleural aspiration

Correct Answer: D

A patient is admitted with wheeze and an urticarial rash, which began 10 min after ingestion of amoxicillin for a chest infection.
Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?

A. Type 1
B. Type 2
C. Type 3
D. Type 4
E. Type 5

Correct Answer: A

A 19-year-old man is brought in by ambulance to the Emergency Department after a motorcycle accident. He appears confused and shocked. His heart rate is 135 bpm and his blood pressure is 80/45. Oxygen is given and intravenous lines are inserted, bloods taken, and fluids started. A secondary survey notes abdominal tenderness which is generalised with guarding. A urinary catheter is inserted and the residual urine is heavily bloodstained. The remainder of the urine output rate is decreased to 10 ml/h.
Using the information obtained in the scenario and assuming this man weighs 70 kg, estimate how much blood has been lost:

A. 500 ml
B. 750 ml
C. 1000 ml
D. 1300 ml
E. 1600 ml

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old White man presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of bloody nasal discharge, facial pain, cough, fever, weight loss, anorexia, haematuria, and arthralgia over the past three months. On examination, the patient has saddle nose deformity and purpuric rash on the lower extremities. Investigations revealed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 90 mm/h 0-10 mm in the 1st hour
Haemoglobin 10 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 19 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 500 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Red blood cells 3.0 million cells/mcl 4.7–6.1 million cells/mcl
Serum IgA level Elevated
Serum creatinine 194.5 μmol/l 50-120 μmol/l
c-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) is positive
Biopsy of upper airway tissue reveals granulomatous inflammation with necrosis
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. IgA nephropathy
B. Goodpasture syndrome
C. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
D. Tuberculosis
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old woman is complaining of gradually increasing epigastric pain during and after eating. The pain started 1 month ago, is mild to moderate and does not radiate to the back. The pain is sometimes severe enough to wake her up at night. She denies any regurgitation, dysphagia or weight loss. There is no tenderness on abdominal palpation. No lymphadenopathy is detected. A stool guaiac test is negative.
Which of the following findings is most likely to explain the patient’s symptoms?

A. Reduced plasma glucose
B. Decreased serum sodium
C. Elevated serum calcium
D. Decreased serum ferritin
E. Elevated serum potassium

Correct Answer: C

A 58-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) after presenting with ‘indigestion’ in the past six months. She has been using over-the-counter treatments with no benefit. She experiences a burning-type sensation which can be present most of the time in her epigastric region. She has lost about 4 kg in weight in the past four months. She denies dysphagia, reports no melaena and denies any nausea or vomiting.
On examination, her abdomen is soft and non-tender with no palpable masses.
What is the next step in management?

A. Begin treatment with omeprazole 20 mg once daily (OD) and review in one month
B. Helicobacter faecal antigen stool test and treatment if positive
C. Refer urgently as a suspected gastro-oesophageal cancer to be seen in two weeks
D. Request a barium swallow and follow up with results
E. Request an ultrasound abdomen

Correct Answer: C

While administering antibiotics to a 34-year-old surgical patient, she develops wheeze, lip swelling and pallor. Blood pressure is measured at 70/38 mmHg.
Which of the following must be urgently administered?

A. 1:1000 IM adrenaline
B. 1:10,000 IM adrenaline
C. 1:10,000 IM noradrenaline
D. im glucagon
E. Intravenous (iv) noradrenaline

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with cough, blood in his sputum and a 3- to 4-cm right-sided supraclavicular lymph node. On examination, you note the right side of his face is dry and his right eyelid is drooping.
Which of the following is the most likely site of the patient’s pathology?

A. Brachial plexus
B. Phrenic nerve
C. Sympathetic chain
D. Trigeminal nerve
E. Vagus nerve

Correct Answer: C

The following blood results were obtained from a 58-year-old man:
Plasma:
Investigation Result Normal Value
Total Ca2+ 2.80 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Albumin 40 g/l 35–55 g/l
PO43− 0.25 mmol/l 0.70–1.40 mmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 170 iu/l 30–130 IU/l
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) 8 ng/l 10–65 ng/l
With which of the following are these results consistent?

A. Primary hyperparathyroidism
B. Chronic renal failure
C. Squamous cell lung cancer
D. Post-thyroidectomy
E. Pseudohypoparathyroidism

Correct Answer: C

A 66-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to his general practitioner (GP) with increased wheeze and breathlessness and a dry cough. He can speak in full sentences.
On examination, his observations show the following:
Temperature 37.4 °C
Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute
Blood pressure 135/72 mmHg
Heart rate 95 bpm
Oxygen saturations 95% on room air
He has global expiratory wheeze.
What is the most appropriate management for this man?

A. Oral amoxicillin
A. B. Oral amoxicillin and prednisolone
C. Prednisolone
D. Refer to hospital medical team for admission
E. Request chest X-ray before prescribing any treatment

Correct Answer: C

A 69-year old man is investigated by the respiratory team for worsening shortness of breath and cough over the past 9 months. He has never smoked, and is usually fit and well. The only significant history of note is that he has taken up pigeon racing since retiring. Following investigation the patient is diagnosed with interstitial pneumonia.
Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with interstitial pneumonia?

A. Haemophilus
B. Klebsiella
C. Streptococcus
D. Staphylococcus
E. Mycoplasma

Correct Answer: E

A 4-year-old boy who has recently been diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is seen in a specialist clinic with his mother. She asks the doctor if there is a treatment to slow the progression of the disease.
Which treatment slows the progression of muscle weakness in DMD?

A. Gene therapy
B. Immunoglobulin therapy
C. Methotrexate
D. Rituximab
E. Steroids

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman has been referred to the Infertility Clinic with her partner. They have been trying to conceive for almost one year now, having regular unprotected intercourse.
Initial investigations, including thyroid function tests and mid-luteal phase progesterone and prolactin, are normal. Semen analysis is also normal. No sexually transmitted infections were detected on testing. The patient reports regular periods and a history of endometriosis.
Which of the following is the next most appropriate investigation?

A. Basal body temperature chart
B. Cervical smear
C. Hysterosalpingography
D. Laparoscopy and dye
E. Luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) testing

Correct Answer: D

Which of the following disorders is correctly paired with its treatment?

A. Epilepsy and amitriptyline
B. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and hydroxychloroquine
C. Atrial fibrillation (AF) and amlodipine
D. Type 1 diabetes (T1DM) and gliclazide
E. Hepatitis C and lamivudine

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old woman presents to the GP to discuss her pregnancy. She has asthma and would like to discuss the risk of her child developing asthma. She has smoked since the age of 15-years old but has cut down to ten a day since being pregnant.
What is the most effective action she can take to reduce the risk of her baby developing asthma?

A. Avoid alcohol
B. Avoid caffeine
C. Avoid eating peanuts
D. Stop smoking
E. Take folic acid

Correct Answer: D

A mother attends her GP to discuss concerns she has about her 14-year-old son. Since the age of two, he has had a lot of routines, such as how he dresses in the morning and which way he walks to school, and is very rigid about following them. He does not cope at all well with changes to the routine. He struggles to make friends and seems very uncomfortable in social situations. Apart from going to school, he avoids meeting children; he has been to a few birthday parties, but he was very clingy to his mother and demanded to be taken home after a few minutes. On examination, the GP is unable to build a rapport with the boy, as he refuses to speak and will not maintain eye contact. He appears fidgety and gets up and down out of his chair on several occasions to try and leave the room. You suspect a diagnosis but advise his mother that more assessment will be needed to confirm a diagnosis.
Which one of the following could be a sign to support your diagnosis?

A. Lack of social smile by age four weeks
B. Less than ten spoken words by age two years
C. Mainly parallel play aged two years
D. Separation anxiety from parents or carers at age ten months
E. Temper tantrums at age 18 months

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset palpitation and chest pain that began 1 hour ago. The palpitation is constant and is not alleviated or aggravated by anything. She is worried that something serious is happening to her. She recently experienced conflict at home with her husband and left home the previous day to stay with her sister. She denies any medication or recreational drug use. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits, except for a heart rate of 180 bpm. Electrocardiography shows narrow QRS complexes that are regularly spaced. There are no visible P waves preceding the QRS complexes. Carotid sinus massage results in recovery of normal sinus rhythm.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atrial flutter
B. Atrial fibrillation
C. Atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia
D. Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia
E. Sinus tachycardia

Correct Answer: C

A 76-year-old retired gardener is referred to the Dermatology Clinic with a 2-month history of an ulcerated lesion on the right ear. He explains that the lesion was initially a small white lump which was present for many months, which then broke down into the ulcer.
On examination, a 0.5 cm ulcerated lesion is noted on the right pinna, with a rolled pearly edge. Closer inspection with a dermatoscope shows some telangiectasia around the edge. The dermatologist suspects that the lesion is a rodent ulcer.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding rodent ulcers?

A. They are squamous cell carcinomas
B. They are basal cell carcinomas
C. They only occur on the face
D. They show epithelial pearls
E. They metastasise via the bloodstream

Correct Answer: B

A 56-year-old woman is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for bacterial pneumonitis. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and is managed on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxaemia for three days. Her cardio-metabolic and respiratory parameters are well maintained. The Foundation Year One doctor on the ward notices that she has become agitated and forcefully tries to remove the intubation tubing. The nurses on the ward are alerted and her sedation medications are increased.
Which of the following is the next step of management in this patient?

A. Clear the airway with suction and carry out a quick clinical history and examination
B. Disconnect the ventilator from the patient and manually ventilate through an air bag
C. Monitor and correct sedation levels
D. Order urgent investigations (chest X-ray, electrocardiogram, serum electrolytes, arterial blood gases)
E. Start high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV)

Correct Answer: B

A 47-year-old woman presents her General Practitioner (GP) for a routine follow-up appointment. The patient suffers from type 1 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, obesity, ischaemic heart disease and chronic kidney disease. Her diabetes and hypertension have been poorly controlled, and her kidney function has been deteriorating over the past year. Her estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is now 19 ml/min/1.73 m2. The GP has explained to the patient that she will most likely be needing dialysis in the next six months. The GP also advises the patient that she could be offered to be put on a kidney transplant list and that this will avoid the need for dialysis and improve her quality of life for many years to come.
Which of the following would be most in favour of this patient having a renal transplant?

A. Age below 60
B. Chronic kidney disease
C. Long-standing history of diabetes
D. Multiple co-morbidities
E. Needing dialysis in the next six months

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old man presents with a 4-year history of postural instability, frequent falls and cognitive decline. He has hypomania, bradykinesia of the left upper limb, brisk reflexes, particularly on the left-hand side, occasional myoclonus and a shuffling gait. He is unable to copy simple hand gestures with his left hand. Upon examination the patient is found to have some sensory loss and apraxia.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease
B. Alzheimer’s disease
C. Supranuclear gaze palsy
D. Sporadic Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD)
E. Corticobasal syndrome

Correct Answer: E

A 54-year-old man presents with a fistula in ano. On examination of the anus, the Consultant tells you that he is looking for where the fistula is in relation to a certain anatomical landmark.
To which landmark is he referring?

A. Anal margin
B. Pectinate line
C. Ischial spines
D. Internal anal sphincter
E. Puborectalis

Correct Answer: B

An 86-year-old retired teacher is started on donepezil after receiving a diagnosis of mild Alzheimer’s dementia, to halt progression of disease. She is warned about the potential side-effects she may suffer as a result of starting the medication.
Which of the following is a common side-effect of donepezil?

A. Constipation
B. Atrial fibrillation
C. Hypertension
D. Hallucination
E. Drowsiness and sedation

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old G2P1 (pregnancies/gestation 2, deliveries/childbirth 1) attends the clinic at 37 weeks’ gestation, complaining of ongoing nausea and vomiting for most of the pregnancy.
Blood tests show:
Investigation Result Normal value
Sodium (Na+) 132 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 70 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 3.2 mmol/l 2.5–6.1 mmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase 17 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate aminotransferase 14 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Serum bile acids 7 μmol/l 0.3–9.8 μmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 213 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Urine dipstick is negative for nitrates, protein and ketones.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Reassure the patient and follow up in 1 week
B. Arrange admission for intravenous (iv) hydration
C. Urgent ultrasound of the liver
D. Arrange induction of labour
E. Commence colestyramine

Correct Answer: A

You have been referred a 15-year-old boy who appears very upset by his parents’ ongoing divorce. He has begun to engage in self-injurious behaviour by banging his head against walls at times of stress. His intelligence quotient (IQ) has been assessed by his school as 60.
With which of the following is this score most consistent?

A. Around the population mean
B. Low end of normal range
C. Mild learning disability
D. Moderate learning disability
E. Severe learning disability

Correct Answer: C

An 85-year-old woman was admitted to a medical ward in Scotland a week ago, after a fall. This is her second admission due to a fall in the last 3 months. She is known to have mild dementia, hypertension and osteoporosis with previous hip fracture.
She lives alone in her own home, with the bathroom and bedroom upstairs. She has poor balance, but refuses to use a walking aid as she doesn’t want people to think that she is an ‘old woman’. Her Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) was 23/30.
The team recommend a move into sheltered housing, which she declines. After a week in hospital, you are called to see the patient, who insists on going home. A discharge plan of ‘meals-on-wheels’ and a package of care including a community alarm and twice-daily visits have been arranged, but she firmly declines these offers as well:

A. Detain her under the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003, since she is clearly a danger to herself
B. Ignore her wishes since, by making these demands, she clearly has no understanding of the seriousness of the situation
C. Make every effort to get her to stay in hospital at least until the morning, and then arrange discharge in an orderly way
D. Ignore her demands because of the potential for bad publicity if anything happens to her following discharge
E. Conceal a sedative in a cup of tea and wait for the morning when someone else can make the decision

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old woman presented to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset headache, beginning 14 hours ago, that she described as ‘an explosion’ and ‘the worst headache of her life’. She denies any vomiting or recent trauma and has not lost any weight. Upon examination, she has no cranial nerve abnormalities. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head reveals no abnormality. She does not have any significant past medical history or family history. The pain has settled down with codeine, and she now wishes to go home.
What is the best next management for this patient?

A. Discharge home
B. Overnight observation
C. Lumbar puncture
D. Repeat CT head in morning
E. Prescribe analgesia

Correct Answer: C

A 66-year-old man presents to the General Surgical Outpatient Clinic with a 4-week history of altered bowel habit. There is no history of rectal bleeding, although faecal occult blood testing is positive. He denies any other symptoms from the abdominal point of view, and his general examination is otherwise unremarkable.
You discuss this case with the patient and agree that the next best step would be to undergo a colonoscopy and some blood tests. The results are shown below:
Bloods:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 112 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 205 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Urea 4.5 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 71 mmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Sodium (Na+) 135 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Endoscopy Report:
The endoscope was passed to the caecum without complication. The caecum was identified with confidence as the ileocaecal valve and appendicular orifice were seen and also confirmed with transillumination. There are multiple diverticulae seen in the sigmoid colon. A large ulcerated and haemorrhagic lesion resembling a tumour was found at the splenic flexure. Multiple biopsies were taken and sent for histology. Small polyp found in ascending colon, snared without complication.
Follow-up with histology results in General Surgery Clinic in one week. Histology to be discussed at the next gastrointestinal multidisciplinary meeting.
The histology results come back as adenocarcinoma of the colon involving the splenic flexure. Further staging reveals no initial metastatic disease.
Which of the following is the next best course of action?

A. Proceed to left hemicolectomy
B. Proceed to transverse colectomy
C. Proceed to extended right hemicolectomy
D. Proceed to chemotherapy only
E. Proceed to preoperative neoadjuvant chemotherapy and surgery

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) accompanied by her partner. She was convinced to see her GP by her partner after having had difficulty sleeping for the past week. The patient has been very active at night and has been working relentlessly on her new architecture project, saying that it is going to be a 'revolutionary masterpiece'. When further questioned, the patient does admit feeling very energetic and has been spending quite a lot of money on new materials for her project. Her partner is worried that this might be a relapse of the patient’s known psychiatric condition. She is currently taking olanzapine and had just been started on fluoxetine about six weeks ago for low mood. She has no significant family history. The couple had been actively trying to get pregnant for the past six months.
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

A. Reduce the fluoxetine dose
B. Switch olanzapine to quetiapine
C. Stop the fluoxetine
D. Add lithium
E. Stop both fluoxetine and olanzapine

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old woman presented with abdominal swelling, pain and constipation for 5 days. She also complained of generalised aches and pains and feelings of thirst. She had recently been diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer which had recurred. She has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome and hypothyroidism. Her regular medications include paracetamol and thyroxine. Her general practitioner (GP) had started her on codeine yesterday. On examination, she appeared dehydrated and had a soft, but mildly distended, abdomen. Thyroid function tested 2 weeks ago was normal.
What is the most likely cause of her presentation?

A. Drug-induced constipation
B. Hypercalcaemia
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Irritable bowel syndrome
E. Malignant bowel obstruction

Correct Answer: B

The following blood results were obtained from a 55-year-old woman:
Plasma:
Total Ca2+: 1.80 mmol/l (2.12–2.65 mmol/l)
Albumin: 40 g/l (35–50 g/l)
PO43−: 2.0 mmol/l (0.8–1.5 mmol/l)
Alkaline phosphatase: 120 iu/l (30–150 iu/l)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH): 75 ng/l (15–65 ng/l)
With which of the following are these results consistent?

A. Primary hyperparathyroidism
B. Primary hypoparathyroidism
C. Post thyroidectomy
D. Pseudohypoparathyroidism
E. Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old type 1 diabetic undergoes fundoscopy as part of his annual follow-up. His HbA1c is 9.5% (81 mmol/mol). Fundoscopy reveals haemorrhages, cotton-wool spots and the presence of new vessels.
What is the next step in his management?

A. Continue yearly follow-up
B. Refer to ophthalmology for specialised follow-up
C. See 6-monthly instead of annually thereafter
D. Urgent referral to ophthalmology
E. See within 3 months and aim for HbA1c of <6.5%

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old man is one day post-operative, following an inguinal hernia repair. He has become extremely nauseated and is vomiting. He is complaining of general malaise and lethargy. His past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus; you perform a capillary blood glucose which is 24 mmol/l and capillary ketone level is 4 mmol/l. A venous blood gas demonstrates a pH of 7.28 and a potassium level of 5.7 mmol/l.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the best initial immediate management in this patient?

A. 0.9% saline intravenously (IV)
B. Start fixed-rate insulin infusion
C. 10% dextrose IV
D. Start sliding-scale insulin infusion
E. 0.9% saline with 40 mmol/l potassium IV

Correct Answer: A

A 60-year-old patient presents with acute severe abdominal pain and the following blood results:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 135 g/l
Female: 115–155 g/l
Male: 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 19 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 141 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 20 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 90 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Calcium 1.8 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) 767 IU/l 50–120 IU/l
Albumin 29 g/l 35–50 g/l
Amylase 1500 U/l < 200 U/l
What is the most appropriate transfer location for ongoing care?

A. Intensive care as an inpatient
B. Discharge into the community and general practitioner review in 1 week
C. Operating theatre
D. General surgical outpatient review in 1 week
E. General medical ward as an inpatient

Correct Answer: A

Which of the following syndromes is correctly paired with an associated congenital cardiac defect?

A. Turner syndrome and coarctation of the aorta
B. Kartagener syndrome and bicuspid aortic valve
C. Marfan syndrome and ventricular septal defect (VSD)
D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and VSD
E. Congenital rubella syndrome and dextrocardia

Correct Answer: A

Which of the following respiratory conditions is most likely to cause these blood gases: pH 7.38, pO2 6.2 kPa, pCO2 9.2 kPa, HCO3– 44 mmol/l?

A. Pulmonary embolism (PE)
B. Pneumonia
C. Asthma
D. Pulmonary fibrosis
E. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath on exertion. He also notes he has been bruising more easily of late. He is noted to be in sinus tachycardia but otherwise is haemodynamically stable. Examination reveals conjunctival pallor and hepatosplenomegaly. No definite lymphadenopathy is palpable. A full blood count is performed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 69 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 0.7 × 109/l 4.0–11.0 × 109/l
Platelets 14 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Blood film is reported as a leukoerythroblastic picture with teardrop-shaped erythrocytes. A bone marrow aspirate is attempted, but this is unsuccessful.
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Advanced prostate cancer
B. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
C. Myelofibrosis
D. Acute myelocytic leukaemia
E. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML)

Correct Answer: C

An 86-year-old man, who lives alone, has been brought in by his son to see his General Practitioner. His son is concerned that his father describes seeing monsters outside his window at night. This has occurred a number of times over the past few months. It becomes apparent that he also has difficulty undertaking normal activities of daily living, seemingly due to an inability to plan ahead or multitask. For eight months, he has had some memory difficulties such as remembering appointments and people. On examination, it is noted he walks slowly and has developed a kyphotic posture, with poor arm swing.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alzheimer’s disease
B. Pick’s dementia
C. Lewy Body dementia
D. Vascular dementia
E. Old age changes

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department feeling generally unwell, with fever and a cough. She had chemotherapy for her breast cancer 4 days ago. There are no known drug allergies. On examination:
Investigation Result Normal value
Blood pressure (BP) 108/70 < 120/80 mmHg
Heart rate (HR) 101 60–100 beats/min
Respiratory rate (RR) 26 12–18 breaths/min
Sats 96% on air 94–98%
Temperature 38.7ºC 36.1–37.2°C
There is some scattered crepitations at the right lung base. You check on the system and see that bloods were done 2 days ago, and showed:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 120 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 3.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Neutrophils 0.8 × 109/l 1.7–7.5 × 109/l
Lymphocytes 1.5 × 109/l 1.0–4.5 × 109/l
Eosinophils 0.6 × 109/l 0.0–0.4 × 109/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate next-step management?

A. Wait for today's blood results and call haematology team for advice
B. Start IV piperacillin with tazobactam (Tazocin)
C. Start IV meropenem
D. Urgent chest X-ray (CXR)
E. Start Filgrastim (G-CSG) injection

Correct Answer: B

In a pre-operative assessment clinic, a 70-year-old man is found to be in atrial fibrillation. This diagnosis is confirmed on B. 2A. 4 h tape. The man tells you he has never had any problems with his heart before. Over the past two months he lost the sight in his right eye a couple of times. Each time this loss of vision lasted less than an hour. He tells you he has type II diabetes and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), but does not take medications for anything else. He is normotensive and an echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction >D. 6C. 5%.
What is this man’s CHAB. 2DSB. 2-VASC score?

A. 4
B. 2
C. 5
D. 6
E. 3

Correct Answer: A

A 76-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of right upper quadrant pain. She has a past medical history of hypercholesterolaemia and obesity. On clinical examination, she is alert and has a temperature of 38.6 °C, a heart rate of 90 bpm, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 112/90 mmHg and oxygen saturations of 98% on room air. She has tenderness in her right upper quadrant. Murphy’s sign is positive.
Her blood test results are listed below:
Investigation Result Normal value
White cell count 3 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Blood glucose 7.9 mmol/l 4–10 mmol/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 44 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Which of the following does this patient have?

A. Appendicitis
B. Acute pancreatitis
C. Septic shock
D. Sepsis
E. Urosepsis

Correct Answer: D

A floppy 2-week-old neonate presented with vomiting, weight loss and circulatory collapse. Blood tests demonstrated hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia. Further tests confirmed metabolic acidosis and hypoglycaemia. The paediatrician noticed that the penis was enlarged and the scrotum pigmented. The child was treated with both a glucocorticoid and a mineralocorticoid.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Addisonian crisis
B. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
C. Conn syndrome
D. Cushing syndrome
E. Thyrotoxic crisis

Correct Answer: B

A middle-aged man presented to his General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-month history of epigastric pain and weight loss. He mentions that he tried over-the-counter antacids which provided some relief initially, but the pain has got worse. He decided to see his GP after realising he had lost about 5 kg. He denies any vomiting or loose stools. He has never had problems with his stomach before and he has no significant family history. Endoscopy and biopsy are performed; histology shows active inflammation.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Helicobacter pylori gastritis
B. Invasive carcinoma
C. Duodenal ulcer
D. Crohn's disease
E. Gastrointestinal stromal tumour

Correct Answer: A

A 25-year-old woman comes into the Emergency Department (ED) with severe abdominal pain, which started suddenly about 2 hours ago. She had an appendicectomy 8 years ago. She has not had any recent per-vaginal (PV) bleeding, her last menstrual peiod was seven weeks ago. On examination, she has right iliac fossa tenderness and guarding. She is also now complaining of right shoulder tip pain.
Observations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Heart rate 120 beats per minute 60–100 beats per minute
Blood pressure 115/85 mmHg <120/<80 mmHg
Respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths per minute 12–20 breaths per minute
O2 saturation 100% 94–99%
Temperature 37.4°C 36.5–37.5°C
What is the likely diagnosis?

A. Ruptured ectopic
B. Ovarian torsion
C. Appendicitis
D. Irritable bowel syndrome
E. Inflammatory bowel disease

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of bilateral knee pain, despite taking paracetamol on an as-required (PRN) basis.
Her recent knee X-rays show evidence of moderate degenerative changes and she is referred for physiotherapy at her request.
While awaiting physiotherapy, what additional treatment would be most appropriate to start?

A. Acupuncture
B. Capsaicin cream
C. Co-codamol
D. Glucosamine
E. Topical non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs)

Correct Answer: E

A 60-year-old woman is discharged following an uncomplicated renal transplant for end-stage renal failure from hypertension. She received a kidney with 4 out of 6 mismatched human leukocyte antigen (HLA) and is taking the appropriate medications. Twenty-five days post-operatively, she developed watery loose stools, followed by a skin rash that is itchy, painful and red. On examination, she has a red-violet rash affecting her hands and feet.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 280 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.0 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 15.1 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 170 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 54 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 165 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Bilirubin 62 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Viral gastroenteritis
B. Acute viral hepatitis
C. Graft-versus-host disease
D. Azathioprine toxicity
E. Sjögren syndrome

Correct Answer: C

A 56-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease receives crossmatched, O-negative whole blood because of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and severe hypotension. Before transfusion, he was lethargic and his haemoglobin concentration was 70 g/l. Within the first hour of transfusion, the patient’s general status improves. But 4 hours later, he develops a fever of 39.4 °C, shaking chills and nausea. He denies back pain.
What is the most likely cause of this condition?

A. Antibody-mediated lysis of donor’s red blood cells
B. Ig E-mediated hypersensitivity against donor’s blood proteins
C. Recipient’s white blood cells reacting against donor’s blood cells
D. Donor’s white blood cell reacting against recipient’s blood cells
E. Recipient’s anti-HLA antibody reacting with donor’s white blood cells

Correct Answer: E

It is your first weekend on call as an F1. You are busy and overwhelmed with jobs. The nurses on a ward bleep you to come and see a patient who has spiked a temperature. You feel the patient has an infection and prescribe the patient antibiotics without checking the patient’s allergies. You discover on the post-take ward round the next day that the patient is allergic to penicillin and note you had prescribed the patient co-amoxiclav.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Ignore the error, as the patient is fine
B. Create a Datix form
C. Cross off the prescription and pretend it never happened
D. Admit the error to your team
E. Stop the medication running immediately and inform the patient

Correct Answer: E

A 34-year-old man has recently undergone emergency surgery. A stoma has been created as a result of the surgery and is sited in the right iliac fossa, as shown in the picture.
What is the stoma shown an example of?

A. Loop colostomy
B. End colostomy
C. Loop ileostomy
D. End ileostomy
E. A mucous fistula

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 1-day history of sudden loss of vision in the left eye. He complains of recent new-onset headache, particularly painful when combing his hair in the morning. He also has pain in his jaw when eating his meals.
His past medical history includes polymyalgia rheumatica, hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
On examination, his vision is 6/9 in the right eye, 6/60 in the left eye. Palpation of the temporal arteries reveals that they are non-pulsatile. The left pupil, on swinging torch test, dilates when the light is swung from the right to the left. On dilated fundoscopy, a swollen optic disc and some surrounding disc haemorrhages in the left can be seen. The rest of the retina looks normal bilaterally.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Amaurosis fugax
B. Anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy
C. Optic neuritis
D. Papilloedema
E. Retinal detachment

Correct Answer: B

A 32-year-old man presented complaining of headaches and sweating, and was found to be hypertensive. Investigations confirmed the diagnosis of a phaeochromocytoma. He was treated with phenoxybenzamine before surgery.
What is the pharmacological property of phenoxybenzamine that makes it the most suitable treatment for a phaeochromocytoma?

A. Irreversible α-adrenoceptor antagonist
B. Irreversible α- and β-adrenoceptor antagonist
C. Reversible α-adrenoceptor agonist
D. Reversible α-adrenoceptor antagonist
E. Reversible β-adrenoceptor antagonist

Correct Answer: A

A 30-year-old woman undergoes diagnostic imaging as she is suffering with constipation. This reveals a sigmoid volvulus.
Which of the following arteries are the arteries that supply blood directly to this part of the colon most likely direct branches of?

A. Ileocolic artery
B. Inferior mesenteric artery
C. Left common iliac artery
D. Superior mesenteric artery
E. Abdominal aorta

Correct Answer: B

A 73-year-old woman is admitted to hospital following a fall in her kitchen. She landed heavily on her hand and is now in a considerable amount of pain.
An X-ray is taken and the doctor in the Emergency Department reviews her with the results.
The X-ray shows a classical example of which of the following fracture types?

A. Colles’ fracture
B. Smith’s fracture
C. Barton’s fracture
D. Galeazzi fracture
E. Monteggia fracture

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a concern regarding an inherited condition. His grandson of five years of age has been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis. He says that there are no other sufferers of the condition in the family.
What are the chances of him carrying the affected allele?

A. 1 in 2
B. 1 in 4
C. 1 in 8
D. 1 in 16
A. E. 1 in 25

Correct Answer: A

A 79-year-old man presents to his general practitioner, complaining of trouble seeing the television. He has a past history of hypertension, but nil else of note.
Investigations:
Fasting plasma glucose: 6.8 mmol/l
Fundoscopy: Evidence of bilateral drusen affecting the fovea
Visual field testing: Bilateral central visual field loss
Fluorescein angiography: Bilateral retinal neovascularisation, with evidence of exudates
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Hypertensive retinopathy
B. Diabetic retinopathy
C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
D. Retinitis pigmentosa
E. Chronic angle closure glaucoma

Correct Answer: C

A 61-year-old man presents with increasing shortness of breath on exertion. On examination, bibasilar wet pulmonary crackles are noted with mild bilateral lower limb pitting oedema. His jugular vein is slightly distended. An S4 sound is audible on cardiac auscultation. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows evidence of left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy. Chest radiography shows bilateral interstitial oedema without cardiomegaly.
Which one of the following findings is most likely to be found in this patient?

A. Impaired LV relaxation – increased LV end-diastolic pressure – normal LV end-systolic volume
B. Impaired LV contraction – increased LV end-diastolic pressure – normal LV end-systolic volume
C. Impaired LV relaxation – normal LV end-diastolic pressure – normal LV end-systolic volume
D. Impaired LV contraction – increased LV end-diastolic pressure – increased LV end-systolic volume
E. Impaired LV contraction – decreased LV end-diastolic pressure – decreased LV end-systolic volume

Correct Answer: A

A test with a known sensitivity of 98% and a specificity of D. 99% for the detection of a given disease is performed on a population of 10 000 patients, of whom 0.1% are known to have the disease.
If a person in this population receives a positive test result, what is the probability that they actually have the disease in question?

A. 89%
B. 100%
C. 8.9%
D. 99%
E. 9.9%

Correct Answer: C

A patient with a history of type II diabetes mellitus presents with the following painful lesion on the lateral aspect of his ankle. An ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) has been done and has come back as 0.5.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Optimal diabetic control and -layered compression stockings
B. Optimal diabetic control and commencement on an antiplatelet and a statin
C. Optimal diabetic control and management of cardiovascular risk factors, and foot X-ray
D. Appropriate consent taken for a right below-knee amputation
E. Optimal diabetic control and angioplasty

Correct Answer: E

A 3-year-old child is brought to the General Practice by his mother. She informs you that her son has had a fever and has not been as active during play sessions. She decided to bring him into the surgery when he erupted in a rash two days ago. On examination, he has a vesicular rash which is widely disseminated and intensely pruritic. He has a temperature of 38 °C. You diagnose him with a common childhood infection. The next day, a patient, who is 13 weeks’ pregnant, reports that she briefly baby sat for the child before she knew about his infection. She has no recollection of having the infection as a child and she is well in herself.
Given that the patient has been exposed to the infected child, what is the next best step in her management?

A. Varicella zoster vaccine
B. Check for varicella antibodies
C. Administer immunoglobulins to rubella
D. Administer acyclovir
E. Watch and wait

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes becomes pregnant.
Which of the following statements is correct?

A. There is an increased risk of polyhydramnios
B. Her treatment should be changed to oral hypoglycaemics because insulin is teratogenic
C. Fetal microsomia frequently occurs
D. The mortality rate from diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in pregnancy is similar to that in non-pregnant patients
E. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are the treatment of choice for hypertension during pregnancy

Correct Answer: A

Examine the following arterial blood gas results:
pH – 7.2
p(O2) – 16.3 kPa
p(CO2) – 3.9 kPa
HCO3– – 16 mmol/l
SaO2 – 94% on high-flow oxygen
Which of the following clinical scenarios best fits the arterial blood gas results shown above?

A. Pneumonia
B. Cardiogenic shock
C. Chronic furosemide ingestion
D. Hyperventilation
E. Bowel ischaemia

Correct Answer: E

A 55-year-old man, with a history of chronic alcohol abuse, presents to the Emergency Department with pain in the right and left upper quadrants. He has had bouts of abdominal pain in the past year. For the past month, he has had more frequent and worsening abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals right upper and left upper quadrant pain with guarding. An abdominal plain film radiograph reveals no free air, but there is an extensive peritoneal fluid collection, along with dilated loops of the small bowel. An abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a 6- to 7-cm cystic mass in the tail of the pancreas.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancreatic pseudocyst
B. Islet cell adenoma
C. Acute pancreatitis
D. Metastatic carcinoma
E. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma

Correct Answer: A

You are the FY1 working on a busy medical ward. You overhear the nurses speaking about the daughter of one of your patients in a derogatory way. This upsets you as you have built a good rapport with the patient and her family.
Which of the following is the most appropriate action?

A. Interrupt the nurses and tell them to keep quiet
B. Speak to the nurses quietly at a later time
C. Inform the patients family immediately and ask them to request a ward change
D. Speak to the Ward Sister about what you overheard
E. Start shouting at the nurses

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old man presents for review. He has suffered intermittent bouts of abdominal pain and had three admissions over the past 2 years for unexplained abdominal bleeding. Apparently his mother died of pancreatic carcinoma some years ago. On examination, he has increased pigmentation and freckling on his face, particularly around his mouth.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 105 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.8 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 310 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Small bowel barium follow-through: multiple small bowel polyps
Hamartomatous polyps visualised on endoscopy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pancreatic carcinoma
B. Coeliac disease
C. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
D. Peutz–Jeghers syndrome
E. Cowden's disease

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents at 27 weeks’ gestation with a 2-day history of dysuria, urinary frequency and mild lower abdominal pain. A urine dipstick was performed, showing 2+ blood, and is positive for nitrites. There is no glycosuria or proteinuria. The patient has previously had an allergic reaction to trimethoprim.
Which of the following is the best antibiotic for the treatment of this patient?

A. Cefalexin
B. Co-amoxiclav
C. Erythromycin
D. Nitrofurantoin
E. Trimethoprim

Correct Answer: D

A 62-year-old man presents to clinic for regular follow-up of his psoriasis. This had previously been well controlled after phototherapy six months ago; however, he has recently deteriorated.
His current treatment regime includes topical calcipotriol (Dovonex), topical coal tar ointment and topical hydromol ointment, in addition to amoxicillin for a recent respiratory infection. He is otherwise fit and well.
On examination, he has an erythematous rash covering much of his torso, with widespread plaques on his limbs and neck. The rash is tender and warm, though he appears to be shivering. There are no oral lesions. His heart rate is 101 bpm, blood pressure is 91/45 mmHg and temperature is 37.7 °C.
What is the most important next step in this man’s treatment?

A. Arrange hospital admission
B. Commence ciclosporin orally
C. Commence methotrexate orally
D. Discontinue amoxicillin
E. Repeat phototherapy

Correct Answer: A

A 28-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department by air ambulance after being involved in a road traffic accident. According to witnesses this was a high-impact car crash and the other passenger in the car has unfortunately already passed away. The man is unconscious when he arrives, and initial assessment reveals a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 9. He has some minor facial injuries and is bleeding from his nose.
Which of the following is appropriate in the initial management of traumatic brain injury?

A. Intubation if GCS falls below 6
B. Head-up tilt to 15 degrees
C. Permissive hypotension
D. Maintain pCO2 4.5 kPa
E. Fluid resuscitation with saline and albumin

Correct Answer: D

A 26-year-old man presents with intermittent sharp central chest pains for the last 48 h. The pain is worse on exertion and when he lies supine. He denies any breathlessness. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows widespread ST elevation.
Which of the following is most likely?

A. Ischaemic heart disease
B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
C. Pulmonary embolism
D. Left ventricular aneurysm
E. Pericarditis

Correct Answer: E

A E. 50-year-old woman attends for preoperative assessment for gall bladder surgery. She has a past medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure, both well controlled on medication. She smokes approximately ten cigarettes per day and drinks A. 1B. 2 units of alcohol per week. On examination, she has a Mallampati score of B. 2 and her body mass index (BMI) is C. 3E. 5 kg/mB. 2. The rest of her physical examination and preoperative assessment are normal.
What American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score would she be awarded pre-surgery?

A. 1
B. 2
C. 3
D. 4
E. 5

Correct Answer: B

A mother brings her 2-year-old daughter to her General Practitioner. She has noticed that when her daughter gets tired, her left eye appears to deviate to the left. The child is referred to an ophthalmologist for further tests.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess strabismus?

A. Cover test
B. Ishihara test
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain
D. Retinal photography
E. Tonometry

Correct Answer: A

A 71-year-old man was being considered for testosterone therapy for decreased libido. He is a diabetic on 60 units of insulin daily. He has nocturia (three episodes per night) but otherwise has no urinary complaints. His mother died of breast cancer at 56 years old. He drinks 16 units of alcohol per week and is a keen gardener.
His blood tests reveal:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haematocrit 0.34 0.35–0.55
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) 4.5 μg/l 0–4.0 μg/l
Platelets 160 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 138 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Which of the following is a contraindication to starting testosterone therapy in this man?

A. Urinary symptoms
B. PSA level
C. Haematocrit level
D. Diabetes history
E. Family history

Correct Answer: B

An 11-year-old patient is brought to the general practitioner by his parents because he has been disruptive at school. His teachers report that he does not pay attention in class, bullies other classmates and takes their food during lunchtime without their permission. One teacher also reported that the patient was seen hurting the class hamster.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Oppositional defiant disorder
B. Major depression
C. Conduct disorder
D. Antisocial disorder
E. Manic episode

Correct Answer: C

A study is designed to find the risk factors associated with the development of Alzheimer’s disease before the age of 65 years. A group of 100 patients with Alzheimer’s disease <65 years of age is compared to a group of 80 age- and gender-matched individuals without Alzheimer’s disease. A table of odds ratios for four studied risk factors is shown below:
Ratio/confidence A. Age B. Family history C. Educational level D. History of head trauma
Odds ratio 4.5 3.5 0.5 1.6
95% confidence interval 0.5–8.5 1.5–5.5 0.3-1.1 1.2-2.0
Which of the following is the most important risk factor identified in this study?

A. Age
B. Family history
C. Educational level
D. History of head trauma
E. There is insufficient data to answer

Correct Answer: B
