A 25-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner, complaining of weakness of the left side of her face, which has worsened over the last 2 days.
Which of the following signs or symptoms would be most consistent with a diagnosis of Bell’s palsy?

A. Deviation of the tongue to the left on tongue protrusion
B. Sparing of function of the forehead muscles and eye closure
C. Loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the left-hand side of the tongue
D. Weakened voluntary facial movements but normal spontaneous movements
E. Inability to close both the right and the left eye

Correct Answer: C

A 28-year-old primip presents on day seven postpartum with unilateral breast pain. The pain started two days ago and is not accompanied by any other symptoms. She is struggling with breastfeeding and thinks her baby is not feeding long enough.
On examination, you notice an erythematous, firm and swollen area, in a wedge-shaped distribution, on the right breast. The nipple appears normal.
Her observations are stable, and she is apyrexial.
Given the above, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Breast abscess
B. Cellulitis
C. Engorged breasts
D. Full breasts
E. Mastitis

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old man attended his general practice to ascertain his cardiac risk. He had a strong positive family history of ischaemic heart disease, and his fasting plasma low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was 9.9 mmol/l. He was started on simvastatin 40 mg nocte.
What is the mechanism of action of simvastatin?

A. Bile acid sequestration
B. Decreases de novo cholesterol synthesis
C. Increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels
D. Inhibits pancreatic lipase
E. Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR)-α receptor agonist

Correct Answer: B

While working in the Obstetric Outpatient Department, a concerned patient wishes to discuss pre-eclampsia with you. She is 28 years old; this is her second pregnancy with the same partner, and she has a child who is four years old. The patient has a body mass index (BMI) of 17 and known hypertension. She is worried about her risk of pre-eclampsia after hearing about it from her friends.
Which of the following in her history represents a risk factor for pre-eclampsia?

A. Age < 30 years
B. Second pregnancy
C. Low BMI
D. 5 years since last pregnancy
E. Known hypertension

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man, who underwent colorectal surgery for a bowel tumour 4 days ago has now developed breathlessness.
What is the single most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute bronchitis
B. Pulmonary embolism
C. Myocardial infarction
D. Pulmonary oedema
E. Surgical emphysema

Correct Answer: B

A 66-year-old woman presents, as she is worried about the possibility of having bowel cancer. She has a 6-month history of bloating and abdominal discomfort, alongside unintentional weight loss. Her cousin has recently been diagnosed with bowel cancer, and this has prompted her presentation.
Which one of the following is a red flag symptom for colorectal cancer?

A. Weight loss
B. Bloating
C. Having a cousin with diagnosed bowel cancer
D. Abdominal pain
E. Abdominal distension

Correct Answer: A

A new biomarker test is developed to detect breast cancer at early stages. The company that developed the test conducted a randomised study to compare the new test to the current standard of care – mammography – among women over 50. They concluded that breast cancer patients whose cancer was identified by the biomarker lived, on average, 1.5 years longer than those whose cancers were identified by mammography. Subsequently, additional independent studies showed that there was truly no difference in survival between the two groups.
Which of the following biases is most likely to have occurred?

A. Selection bias
B. Lead time bias
C. Measurement error
D. Insensitive test
E. Confounding

Correct Answer: B

A 14-year-old patient reports on his own to your surgery in Scotland for a blood test for urea and electrolytes and a full blood count. The appointment was booked when he attended for a consultation yesterday.
Can you proceed with the test?

A. No – there must be an adult present
B. No – there must be a parent present
C. No – there must be a relative present
D. Yes – it is only a small procedure so it doesn’t matter
E. Maybe – it depends upon assessment of his capacity to consent

Correct Answer: E

A 22-year-old basketball player collapsed during a game and died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm. The athlete died from the consequences of a genetic defect called Marfan’s syndrome.
Which extracellular matrix protein is altered in this disease?

A. Type I collagen
B. Fibronectin
C. Integrin
D. Laminin
E. Fibrillin-1

Correct Answer: E

A 68-year-old man is recovering from hip surgery on the ward. He has had an indwelling catheter for several days. In the last 24 hours, he has been noted to have some ‘dizzy spells’ by nurses where he becomes confused and agitated. He has been seen talking to himself, mumbling incoherent ideas, and at other times he seems distracted and disorientated, forgetting where he is. He has a new fever and is tachycardic. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. You suspect he is suffering from delirium.
Which one of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

A. A frozen and/or mask like facial expression
B. Structural changes in the brain
C. Leukocytes and nitrites on mid-stream urine sample dipstick
D. Progressive decline in cognitive function
E. Irreversible changes to cognition

Correct Answer: C

A 25-year-old woman is six weeks pregnant in her first pregnancy. She has got clinical hypothyroidism for the last five years and takes 50 micrograms of levothyroxine daily. She denies any symptoms and feels well in herself. You perform thyroid function tests, the results of which are found below:
Free thyroxine (fT4) 19 pmol/l (11–22 pmol/l)
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 1.9 μu/l (0.17–3.2 μu/l)
Which of the following best describes the next step in this patient’s management?

A. Continue on the same dose of levothyroxine at present as the patient is euthyroid
B. Increase levothyroxine by 25 mcg and repeat thyroid function tests in two weeks
C. Irrespective of changes in pregnancy, the patient should return to pre-pregnancy dosing immediately post-delivery
D. Reduce levothyroxine by 25 mcg as there is a physiological increase in fT4 early in pregnancy
E. Thyroid function tests should be performed in the first and second trimesters

Correct Answer: B

A 63-year-old man, with a history of chronic, poorly controlled hypertension, is brought to the Emergency Department following sudden-onset tearing chest pain with radiation to the back and abdomen. He has prominent shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 80/45 mmHg. He is confused and tachypnoeic, with an arterial oxygen saturation of 80%. A diastolic decrescendo murmur was noted on the left sternal border. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST segment elevation in some contiguous leads. On chest X-ray, the left hemithorax is opaque and the mediastinum is widened. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) image shows a false lumen and a double-barrelled appearance of the descending aorta.
Which of the following arteries is most likely to be involved in this condition?

A. Superior mesenteric artery
B. Inferior mesenteric artery
C. Coeliac artery
D. Right renal artery
E. Left renal artery

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman complains of recurrent, unpleasant and intrusive thoughts penetrating her mind for the last six months. She thinks that her hands are dirty and frequently washes them with alcohol and disinfectants to feel better. Treatment with fluvoxamine is started.
What is the mechanism of action and principle side-effect of this medication?

A. Selective inhibition of serotonin reuptake – weight gain
B. Non-selective inhibition of norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake – weight gain
C. Selective inhibition of serotonin reuptake – anorgasmia
D. Non-selective inhibition of norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake – dry mouth
E. Neuronal norepinephrine release – insomnia

Correct Answer: C

A 3-year-old boy with confirmed coeliac disease requires a 1-month prescription for gluten-free staple foods.
What would be the most appropriate prescription for gluten-free staple foods?

A. 1 kg bread + 750 g pasta + 1 kg oats = 10 units
B. 2 kg bread + 1500 g pasta + 2 kg oats = 20 units
C. 2 kg bread + 1000 g pasta + 2 kg oats = 18 units
D. 1 kg bread + 750 g pasta + 1 kg oats + 600 g biscuits/crackers = 13 units
E. 1 kg rice + 1 kg bread + 2 kg potatoes = 4 units

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old dinner lady is diagnosed with osteopenia with a normal bone mineral to bone matrix ratio, following investigation at the Fracture Clinic.
Osteopenia with a normal bone mineral to bone matrix ratio is usually due to which of the following?

A. Osteomalacia
B. Osteoporosis
C. Osteitis deformans
D. Osteopetrosis
E. Osteitis fibrosa cystica

Correct Answer: B

A 52-year-old man presents to the outpatient surgical clinic with a history of mixed fresh and dark blood clots per rectum and a change in bowel habits to loose stool. His father died of colorectal cancer in his 60s. On examination, the abdomen is unremarkable. Digital rectal examination (DRE), proctoscopy and rigid sigmoidoscopy are normal.
Which one of these is the next step in this man’s management?

A. Colonoscopy
B. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis
C. Examination under anaesthesia
D. Endoanal ultrasound
E. Flexible sigmoidoscopy

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-year history of a progressively worsening rash on her face, characterised by dark-coloured lesions with periodic background scaling, burning and pruritus. Physical examination reveals well-defined patches of flaky skin which is yellow and dry on the scalp. There is also flaking in the nasolabial folds, eyebrows and behind the ears. The patient’s eyelids are also red and inflamed. They report itchiness and discomfort.
Given the likely diagnosis of this patient, what is the most appropriate treatment?

A. Clotrimazole
B. Emollients
C. Ketoconazole
D. Soap and water
E. Topical steroids

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old man with a tumour of the left submandibular gland proceeded to surgery. During surgery on the left submandibular gland the lingual nerve is injured.
Which of the following is the patient most likely to complain of postoperatively?

A. Deviation of the tongue to the right
B. Deviation of the tongue to the left
C. Loss of taste sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the left side of the tongue
D. Loss of taste sensation over the posterior third of the left side of the tongue
E. Loss of general sensation over the posterior third of the left side of the tongue

Correct Answer: C

An 87-year-old man attends the GP practice with grandson, who is concerned about his grandfather’s health and states that he has not been himself lately. For the past few months, he has had a reduced appetite and is spending most of his time in bed, despite waking up early each day. He is forgetting simple things like his newborn great-granddaughter’s name, appointments and conversations he has recently had, and seems uninterested in most things. He denies any visual or auditory hallucinations. He has a medical history of well controlled hypertension. His wife passed away several years ago. He scores 20 on a Mini-Mental State Examination.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alzheimer’s disease
B. Vascular dementia
C. Normal ageing
D. Normal grief reaction
E. Depression

Correct Answer: E

An 18-year-old man has been stabbed in his left upper abdomen, immediately below the costal margin in the mid-axillary line.
Which one of the following organs is most likely to have been injured?

A. Colon
B. Left kidney
C. Small intestine
D. Spleen
E. Stomach

Correct Answer: A

A 63-year-old retired post-office worker presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with a two-week history of bleeding from the right nipple. He is otherwise well, with hypertension being the only medical history to note, which is well controlled on ramipril.
On examination of the right breast, the doctor notes some oozing of blood from the right nipple, with an underlying 2 cm × 2 cm fixed mass on palpation of the right areola.
With regard to breast cancer in men, which of the following statements is the most accurate?

A. The most common primary symptom of breast cancer in men is bleeding from the nipple
B. The is an increased risk of breast cancer in men with Klinefelter syndrome
C. Breast cancer is one the top five most common cancers in men
D. Breast cancer is more common in younger men than in older men
E. A family history of breast cancer is not relevant to men

Correct Answer: B

A 5-year-old boy developed a heart murmur after an untreated sore throat. He was ultimately diagnosed with rheumatic fever (RF).
Which one of the following organisms was most likely to be responsible for the child’s illness?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Klebsiella pneumoniae
C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae
D. Group B Streptococcus
E. Streptococcus pyogenes

Correct Answer: E

A 6-year-old girl is taken to see the General Practitioner (GP) by her parents. The school has raised concerns about her behaviour and advised the parents to seek advice from the GP. She is performing well academically but seems to struggle in socially engaging with other children.
The parents report that she was born by normal vaginal delivery at term and met all of her speech and motor milestones. However, they have always been aware that she is different to her older siblings, as she has never made any friends or engaged in any imaginary play. She does not play with her siblings. She lines up all her toys and becomes very distressed if anyone touches the line. She has to eat the same meals every day and take the same route to school or will become very distressed. She struggles in school holidays and at weekends to cope with the change in routine.
With which of the following diagnosis would the signs and symptoms in this child be most consistent?

A. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
B. Autism spectrum disorder
C. Learning disability
D. Obsessive–compulsive disorder (OCD)
E. Rett syndrome

Correct Answer: B

A junior doctor is called to perform a chest drain for a simple (non-progressive) right-sided pneumothorax.
If she wishes to avoid injuring important organs or neurovascular elements, where should she insert the drain?

A. The top of the eighth intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
B. The bottom of the eighth intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
C. The top of the fifth intercostal space in the mid-axillary line
D. The bottom of the fifth intercostal space in the mid-axillary line
E. The top of the second intercostal space in the mid-axillary line

Correct Answer: D

A patient who has been attending your GP surgery with a worsening depressive episode on a background of known depression presents with occasional suicidal thoughts and is finding it difficult to cope with some daily activities despite use of psychological therapies and regular consultation with the GP. You agree to trial use of an antidepressant.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice?

A. Paroxetine
B. Citalopram
C. Amitriptyline
D. Lorazepam
E. Selegiline

Correct Answer: B

An 80-year-old man is on warfarin for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He has been referred to the Medical Admissions Unit from the Community Warfarin Clinic with an international normalised ratio (INR) of 9.0. He has recently completed a course of antibiotics that were prescribed by his general practitioner.
Which of the following antibiotics is most likely to have resulted in the raised INR?

A. Amoxicillin
B. Trimethoprim
C. Clarithromycin
D. Nitrofurantoin
E. Rifampicin

Correct Answer: C

A patient’s arterial blood gas shows the following:
pH 7.30
O2 13 kPa
CO2 3.0 kPa
HCO3− 15.0 mmol/l
Which of the following does the above blood gas picture represent?

A. A respiratory acidosis
B. A compensated respiratory acidosis
C. A metabolic acidosis
D. A partially compensated metabolic acidosis
E. A compensated respiratory alkalosis

Correct Answer: D

A General Practitioner is called to the nursing home to see a 75-year-old man with dementia and severe pruritus.
On examination, he has excoriations over his trunk and limbs. There is some scaling over his palms, most prominently in the web spaces.
Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atopic eczema
B. Chronic kidney disease
C. Diabetes
D. Iron-deficiency anaemia
E. Scabies infestation

Correct Answer: E

A 59-year-old school teacher with a history of gallstone disease is listed for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for removal of a common bile duct stone found during an episode of biliary colic.
For which of the following conditions would ERCP be the most useful diagnostic investigation?

A. Alcoholic cirrhosis
B. Hereditary hemochromatosis
C. Gilbert syndrome
D. Hepatocellular carcinoma
E. Pancreatic duct strictures

Correct Answer: E

These lesions next to the eye are long-standing. There are similar lesions next to the other eye.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
Which, of the list below, is the single most likely abnormality to be found in a blood test?

A. Increased bilirubin
B. Increased cholesterol
C. Increased fasting glucose
D. Increased thyroid stimulating hormone
E. Increased uric acid

Correct Answer: B

The picture is typical of this patient’s rash. It is mainly found on the scalp, eyebrows, nasolabial fold, upper sternum and back. On the scalp, there is diffuse dandruff-like scaling. The condition is mildly pruritic and is worse in winter and early spring. He is 48 years old and has had the rash for several years.
Courtesy of Wellcome Images
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Atopic dermatitis
B. Nummular dermatitis
C. Psoriasis
D. Seborrhoeic dermatitis
E. Pityriasis versicolor

Correct Answer: D

A loud systolic murmur, which extends into diastole and is ‘machinery-like’ in quality, is found in an infant at his 6-week check-up. The murmur radiates to the back between the scapulae. His first heart sound is normal; the second sound is obscured by the murmur. He has bounding pulses. His mother reports that he is asymptomatic.
Which of the following is correct of this condition?

A. There is no treatment for this condition
B. This condition is likely to occur with increased frequency in those with hyaline membrane disease of the lungs
C. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the affected structure
D. This condition is due to failure of closure of a fetal vessel derived from the fourth aortic arch
E. The underlying diagnosis is Tetralogy of Fallot

Correct Answer: B

An 80-year-old man with colorectal carcinoma, Dukes stage D, has severe pain from bony metastases. He has undergone courses of radiation therapy and intravenous infusion of bisphosphonates, which have failed to control his pain. He is currently taking regular paracetamol and ibuprofen. When previously given opiate analgesia, he became very drowsy and poorly responsive. His pain score is 9/10 at rest and he becomes very distressed when being moved by nursing staff.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

A. Advise relaxation techniques
B. Arrange another course of radiotherapy
C. Give an increased dose of intravenous bisphosphonate
D. Give stronger nonsteroidal medications to avoid the risk of sedation and respiratory depression
E. Give the patient opiate medications to control the pain despite the risk of sedation

Correct Answer: E

A 59-year-old-man presents to his General Practitioner complaining of a short history of constipation associated with rectal bleeding. He also complains of a loss of appetite and intermittent abdominal pain over the last few months. His blood results are shown below:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 98 g/l 130 – 180 g/l
Mean corpuscular value (MCV) 93 fl 80 –100 fl
What is the most appropriate investigation to perform to diagnose this patient?

A. Abdominal X-ray
B. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
C. Colonoscopy
D. Colonic transit study
E. Thyroid function test

Correct Answer: C

A 35-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with blurring of her vision and pain on eye movement. The GP suspects that she may have optic neuritis.
Which of the following signs is most likely to be present on examination?

A. Cherry-red spot on fundoscopy
B. Erythema around the affected eye
C. Increased intraocular pressure
D. Reduced colour vision
E. Vesicles around the affected eye

Correct Answer: D

An 85-year-old retired labourer presents to his General Practitioner with generalised pains in the hands. Following a discussion he notes that the pain is worse in the morning and after continued movement.
Which of the following clinical signs in the hands suggests osteoarthritic changes in the hand?

A. Arachnodactyly
B. Heberden nodes
C. Claw hand
D. Dupuytren’s contracture
E. Trigger finger

Correct Answer: B

An 85-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of recurrent shortness of breath, bradycardia and episodic hypotension associated with syncope. She has a past medical history of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism.
The findings in the investigation below are recurring.
What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

A. Amiodarone
B. Insertion of an AAI mode pacemaker
C. Insertion of a DDD mode pacemaker
D. Insertion of a VVI mode pacemaker
E. Verapamil + sotalol

Correct Answer: D

A 28-year-old Welsh Guard returning from operational duty overseas has experienced 6 months of nightmares and intrusive recollections of his military experiences. He avoids stimuli that remind him of his tour of duty. He is emotionally detached and sleep-disordered, cannot seem to concentrate and startles dramatically when he hears loud noises. He is also abusing alcohol.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute stress disorder
B. Generalised anxiety disorder
C. Panic disorder with agoraphobia
D. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
E. Somatisation disorder

Correct Answer: D

Which one of the following structures contains white and red pulp, and functions to trap foreign substances carried in the blood?

A. Thymus
B. Heart
C. Lymph node
D. Spleen
E. Thyroid gland

Correct Answer: D

A 36-year-old woman in her fifth pregnancy has been diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 28 weeks and presents for a fetal growth scan, as per the gestational diabetes protocol. She has had three normal vaginal deliveries, but the last time, she needed an elective Caesarean section for breech presentation. The sonographer calls you into the room to see the patient because the placenta is seen to involve more than half of the myometrium.
Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?

A. Placenta accreta
B. Placenta increta
C. Placenta percreta
D. Placenta praevia
E. Vasa praevia

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old man presented to the hospital, accompanied by the police after having had a fight in a casino. The casino manager called the police when the man refused to leave after he had spent almost 24 hours gambling. The patient ran out of money and was harassing other clients, trying to borrow money from them and telling them that he will return it after he had won and invested the prize money. The patient has no known next of kin and refuses to engage with the attending doctor. He threatens to assault the medical staff and is eventually put under urgent mental health Section 4. A review of his medical notes reveals that the only medication on which he has been is lithium for a known psychiatric illness, but he has not been in touch with his general practitioner for the past two months.
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

A. Check the lithium levels
A. B. Check the lithium levels and consider adding olanzapine
C. Start haloperidol
D. Stop lithium and start olanzapine
E. Start risperidone

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old music teacher who presented to her General Practitioner (GP) with a skin lesion on her forearm. On examination, the lesion is a 4-mm red, raised lesion with multiple scratch marks surrounding it. The GP wishes to refer Mrs Green to a local dermatologist.
Which of the following descriptions most accurately describes this lesion?

A. Erythematous macule with excoriation
B. Erythematous macule with lichenification
C. Erythematous nodule with lichenification
D. Erythematous papule with excoriation
E. Plaque with lichenification and multiple telangiectasias

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to review a 37-year-old man who has had two episodes of pancreatitis. On reviewing his notes, the surgeons noticed that he appeared to have had a serum calcium of 3.2 mmol/l when it was checked at the general practice surgery a few weeks before the latest episode. Urinary calcium excretion is markedly reduced.
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Hyperparathyroidism
B. Pseudohypoparathyroidism
C. Hypoparathyroidism
D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia
E. Paget’s disease

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old woman, with a history of ulcerative colitis, presents with a history of heavy, painful periods. She reports regular periods, lasting seven days.
During the first three days, she has to wear both a tampon and sanitary pads and has to take time off work due to the embarrassment of flooding and dizziness. She declined contraception, as she is trying for a baby.
A pelvic ultrasound revealed two small fibroids (< 3 cm in size) in the uterus, and a full blood count was as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 95 g/l 115–155 g/l
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 73 fl 76–98 fl
White cell count (WCC) 7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets (PLT) 390 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Iron 12 μg/dl 50 to 170 µg/dl
Ferritin 5 μg/l 10–120 μg/l
Which of the following is the best first–line treatment for this patient’s menorrhagia?

A. Ferrous sulfate
B. Mefenamic acid
C. Myomectomy
D. Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena®)
E. Tranexamic acid

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old woman attends for her cervical smear as per the NHS cervical screening programme. She is found to have low-grade dyskaryosis. The laboratory performed a reflex high-risk human papillomavirus (HR-HPV) test on the cytology sample. The HPV sample returned as negative.
When should the patient have a repeat cervical smear?

A. Three months
B. Six months
C. 12 months
D. Three years
E. Five years

Correct Answer: E

A 33-year-old woman presenting with haematuria underwent a kidney biopsy. Light microscopy was inconclusive and the specimen was referred for electron microscopy.
For which of the following renal diseases is electron microscopy essential for diagnosis?

A. Thin membrane disease
B. Lupus nephritis
C. Anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) disease
D. IgA nephropathy
E. Churg–Strauss syndrome

Correct Answer: A

A woman with known ulcerative colitis presents to Accident and Emergency with a flare-up. She tells you that she is passing eight stools a day with blood and has severe nausea with abdominal pain at present. She normally takes oral mesalazine to control her condition. On examination, the patient is cool peripherally, with a heart rate of 120 bpm and blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg. Blood tests are done and relevant findings shown below.
Investigation Result Normal value
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 32 mm/hour < 20 mm/hour
Albumin 34 g/l 35–50 g/l
Temperature 37.9 °C 36.1–37.2 °C
Haemoglobin 98 g/l 115–155 g/l
Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

A. Add a topical aminosalicylate (suppository or enema) to current medications and review in 7 days
B. Admit to hospital and give topical aminosalicylates and analgesia
C. Add azathioprine to control the flare-up and iron supplements for anaemia. Review in 7 days
D. Refer immediately to the colorectal surgery team for emergency colectomy
E. Admit to hospital for intravenous (IV) corticosteroids, fluids and monitoring

Correct Answer: E

You see an 87-year-old lady in clinic. Over the past 3 months, her family believes she is becoming more forgetful. She has also noticed a tremor in her right hand and is generally ‘slowing down’. She takes amlodipine for hypertension and a daily aspirin of her own volition. She has recently been treated for a urinary tract infection by her general practitioner. She also complains of confusion and seeing spiders climbing the walls of her bedroom. She has no other urinary complaints. Her abbreviated mental test score is 5/10. Lying and standing blood pressures are 138/76 and 127/70, respectively.
Select the most likely diagnosis from the list below:

A. Parkinson's disease
B. Alzheimer's disease
C. Vascular dementia
D. Multisystem atrophy
E. Lewy body dementia (LBD)

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner. She has been smoking ten cigarettes every day for the past 12 years and would like help to stop smoking. She has no relevant past medical history, but she is currently ten weeks pregnant.
Which of the following smoking cessation options is the most appropriate first-line recommendation for this patient?

A. Behavioural therapy
B. Bupropion
C. Clonidine
D. Nicotine replacement therapy
E. Varenicline

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old woman is seen by her general practitioner with a history of incontinence. The ‘final straw’ was when she wet herself after running for the bus last week. Usually it has just been a small leak when she coughs or laughs, so she did not want to trouble anyone. She has no abdominal pain and her last period was 2 years ago. She has two children, who were both big babies and born by vaginal delivery. Examination is unremarkable. Urine dipstick NAD.
What is the best option for management?

A. Pelvic floor muscle training
B. Arrange a pelvic ultrasound scan
C. Start oxybutynin
D. Arrange urodynamic studies
E. Bladder training

Correct Answer: A

A 58-year-old man presents for a follow-up appointment with the hepatologist. The patient underwent a liver transplant four weeks ago for hepatocellular carcinoma and has since been recovering well. He is currently taking prednisolone and tacrolimus for immunosuppression. The patient has been feeling well since the operation and is wondering why he is having blood tests every two weeks. The doctor informs the patient that the blood tests are to monitor for side effects of the immunosuppressive medications he is taking.
Which of the following adverse effects is most commonly seen in patients who are taking tacrolimus?

A. Gingival hyperplasia
B. Hirsutism
C. Nephrotoxicity
D. Osteoporosis
E. Psychosis

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old woman on Ramipril is referred by the GP to the hospital medical admission unit department due to her high potassium levels.
Which of the following electrocardiogram (ECG) changes is associated with hyperkalaemia?

A. Short P–R interval
B. Tall T waves
C. Narrow QRS complexes
D. Peaked P-waves
E. U-waves

Correct Answer: B

A 48-year woman is brought by ambulance to the Emergency Department after she complained of black stools and abdominal pain since last night. She denies any fresh blood in her stool and has not noted any unintentional weight loss.
Her past medical history includes osteoarthritis for which she has been taking regular ibuprofen, and essential hypertension which is well controlled with candesartan. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a gastric ulcer with active bleeding.
Which one of the following vessels provides a major blood supply to the patient’s affected region of the gastrointestinal tract?

A. Superior mesenteric artery
B. Splenic artery
C. Coeliac trunk
D. Artery of Drummond
E. Inferior mesenteric artery

Correct Answer: C

A 48-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of an increasingly painful and swollen right eye. He complains of blurring of vision and pain, especially with eye movements, which were quite restricted. He has no past medical history and is allergic to penicillin.
On examination, the visual acuity is 6/18 in the right, 6/6 in the left. The periorbital area of the right eye is very swollen and erythematous. The eye itself is red and proptosed. The conjunctiva is chemosed. Eye movements in the right eye are quite restricted in all directions. There is relative afferent pupillary defect on the right. Fundoscopy shows a swollen optic disc in the right eye. Computed tomography (CT) scan shows diffuse orbital infiltrate and proptosis.
Vital observations are as follows:
Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg
Heart rate 75 bpm
Respiratory rate 18 per minute
Oxygen saturation 98% on air
Temperature 37.9 °C
What is first-line management for this patient?

A. Cefuroxime intravenously (IV)
B. Clindamycin and ciprofloxacin IV
C. Co-amoxiclav IV
D. Drainage of the orbit
E. Tazocin® IV

Correct Answer: B

A 30-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department following a fall off a ladder. She was witnessed to have lost consciousness at the scene and remained confused with the ambulance personnel. She is complaining of a headache and has vomited three times. Her eyes are open to voice and she is able to squeeze your hand using both hands, when asked, and wiggle her toes. She is confused about what has happened and does not remember falling. Her pupils are equal and reactive.
How would you manage this patient?

A. Admit for neuro observation
B. Discuss with neurosurgery
C. Computed tomography (CT) head scan within 1 h
D. CT head scan within 8 h
E. Discharge home

Correct Answer: C

A 37-year-old man weighing 100 kg was pulled from a house fire. He was intubated by the HEMS team at the scene for airway compromise (nasal soot, singed facial hair and a change in voice). He has sustained full-thickness burns to his face, anterior torso and full legs. The specialist registrar (SPR) has asked you to calculate this man’s fluids requirements for the first 24 hours.
Which of the following is the correct volume to the nearest litre?

A. 10 litres
B. 15 litres
C. 20 litres
D. 25 litres
E. 27 litres

Correct Answer: E

A 61-year-old postman visits his GP as he is becoming increasingly breathless and tired whilst running. He has always enjoyed running and usually runs 3 times a week. Over the past year he has noted that he can no longer manage the same distance that he used to be able to without getting breathless and needing to stop. He wonders if this is a normal part of ageing or if there could be an underlying medical problem.
Which of the following are consistent with normal ageing with respect to the cardiovascular system?

A. Reduced VO2 max
B. Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 25–35%
C. Stroke volume 25–35%
D. Blood pressure = 76/54 mmHg
E. Blood pressure = 188/112 mmHg

Correct Answer: A

A 70-year-old lady has been diagnosed as being vitamin B12-deficient with a B12 level of < 50 pmol/l (160–900 pmol/l) and a haemoglobin (Hb) level of 80 (115–155 g/l). It is not diet-related.
Which is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg on alternate days indefinitely
B. Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg intravenously (iv) three times a week for two weeks and then monthly
C. Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg im three times a week for two weeks and then 1 mg im 3-monthly
D. Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg im three times a week for two weeks and then oral 1 mg hydroxocobalamin
E. Hydroxocobalamin 1 mg subcutaneously three times a week for two weeks, monthly for three months and then 3-monthly

Correct Answer: C

A 19-year-old woman became concerned that she might be pregnant after having unprotected sex two weeks after the end of her last period. She missed her next period, and now a month after the sexual encounter, she buys a home pregnancy test kit.
Which hormone in the urine does the colorimetric assay in these test kits detect?

A. Luteinising hormone (LH)
B. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
C. Progesterone
D. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) subunit β
E. hCG subunit α

Correct Answer: D

A 14-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with pain in the ankle associated with swelling and bruising after a football-related inversion injury.
Which of the following examination findings would suggest that an ankle X-ray is required?

A. Inability to weight-bear and pain over the lateral malleolus
B. Inability to weight-bear and pain in the mid foot
C. Inability to weight-bear alone
D. Pain in the malleolar zone alone
E. Pain in the mid foot, with bony tenderness at the base of the first metatarsal

Correct Answer: A

A 69-year-old woman attends the anticoagulation clinic for an INR check. She is on life-long warfarin for atrial fibrillation. Previously the INR was stable however it came back as 5.0 today.
Which of the following is most likely the causative agent for this INR?

A. Grapefruit juice
B. St John’s wort
C. Carbamazepine
D. Sulphonylureas
E. Smoking

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man is referred to the Cardiology Clinic for a check-up. On cardiac auscultation, an early systolic ejection click is found. A blowing diastolic murmur is also present and best heard over the third left intercostal space, close to the sternum. S1 and S2 heart sounds are normal. There are no S3 or S4 sounds. He denies any shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness or episodes of fainting.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Mixed aortic stenosis and regurgitation
B. Aortic regurgitation
C. Bicuspid aortic valve with significant calcification
D. Bicuspid aortic valve without calcification
E. Aortic stenosis and flow murmur

Correct Answer: D

A 2-year-old child is brought by his father to the general practice surgery with a 3-day history of fever, irritability and left ear pain, which suddenly became more severe 12 hours ago and then resolved with the onset of a discharge from the left ear. On examination, you find a tympanic membrane with a central perforation.
What is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Commence oral antibiotics and review after 6 weeks to ensure the perforation is healing
B. Advise pain relief only and review after 6 weeks to ensure healing
C. Refer to the acute Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) clinic for assessment
D. Commence oral antibiotics and refer routinely to ENT for follow-up
E. Commence gentamicin and dexamethasone ear drops, and review after 6 weeks to ensure the perforation is healing

Correct Answer: A

A 64-year-old man with a confirmed diagnosis of grade IIIb adenocarcinoma is listed for lung resection, following a completed course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The oncologist, chest physician and thoracic surgeon are planning a multidisciplinary team meeting, following preoperative investigations for his surgery.
Which of the following findings would most likely put him in a high-risk stratification for the lobectomy procedure?

A. A preoperative forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) of > 2.0 litres
B. Myocardial infarction episode six weeks ago
C. Predicted post-operative (PPO) FEV1 and PPO DLCO ≥ 60%
D. Preoperative FEV1 and diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ≥ 80%
E. Shuttle walk test (SWT) of > 400 m, with no desaturation during the test

Correct Answer: B

A 45-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden-onset blurring of vision in both eyes as well as light sensitivity. He is a known type II diabetic with blood sugars well maintained with diet control.
His observations are as follows:
Temperature 36.6 °C
Blood pressure (BP) 191/127 mmHg
Heart rate 80 bpm
Respiratory rate 19
O2 saturations 99% on room air
On dilated fundoscopy, both optic discs are swollen with widespread flame-shaped haemorrhages and cotton-wool spots.
What is the first-line management of this condition?

A. Intravenous (IV) labetalol
B. Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) injection
C. Oral amlodipine
D. Pan-retinal photocoagulation
E. Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray

Correct Answer: A

A 67-year-old man developed acute kidney injury secondary to rhabdomyolysis, following his first marathon. He is initiated on haemodialysis due to uraemic pericarditis.
Which one of the following symptoms or signs would signal a cardiac tamponade?

A. Pleuritic chest pain
B. Confusion
C. Pericardial rub
D. Pericardial knock
E. Pulsus paradoxus

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man has a history of chronic cough and shortness of breath. Most recently he has begun to suffer from an annoying red/purple nodular rash affecting both shins. There is no past medical history of note apart from mild asthma, for which he has been prescribed a salbutamol inhaler by his General Practitioner, and he continues to smoke ten cigarettes per day. On examination his BP is 135/72 mmHg, pulse is 75/min and regular. There is mild wheeze on auscultation of the chest. He has a number of red/purple nodules affecting both shins.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 129 g/l 135–175 g/l
White Cell Count (WCC) 10.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 201 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) 65 mm/1st hour 0–10 mm in the 1st hour
Sodium (Na+) 138 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 103 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Corrected Calcium (Ca2+) 2.82 mmol/l 2.20–2.60 mmol/l
Chest X-Ray Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A. Asthma
B. Bronchial carcinoma
C. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
D. Primary hyperparathyroidism
E. Sarcoidosis

Correct Answer: E

While considering the mode of action of different forms of contraception, researchers focus on the cell structure of the sperm.
Regarding the copper intrauterine device (IUD), what cellular structure is targeted by its mode of action?

A. Mitochondria
B. Nucleus
C. Golgi apparatus
D. Cell wall
E. Centrioles

Correct Answer: C

You are on an anaesthetic attachment in Day Surgery and are reviewing patients preoperatively. You review a 22-year-old man who is having an elective knee arthroscopy. He has not had a general anaesthetic before, but he tells you that his father had problems following suxamethonium anaesthetic, and he had to have a muscle sample sent off to find out the cause, which came back positive. His father is still alive.
Which of these is his father’s most likely diagnosis?

A. Anaphylaxis
B. Prolonged paralysis
C. Raised intraocular pressure after suxamethonium administration
D. Malignant hyperthermia
E. Hyperkalaemia

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of a painful and swollen left knee. He is pyrexial. He has rheumatoid arthritis and which was recently diagnosed and is being managed with NSAID and low-dose oral corticosteroid.
He mentions that he developed a painful right ear and saw his general practitioner five days ago who told him he had an infected ear and prescribed antibiotics. His left knee is swollen, red, tender and slightly flexed. A diagnosis of septic arthritis is made.
What is the most likely causative organism in this case?

A. Escherichia coli
B. Haemophilus influenzae
C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
D. Staphylococcus aureus
E. Streptococcus pyogenes

Correct Answer: D

You are an orthopaedic surgeon practicing in Scotland. A 15-year-old patient turns up to an appointment on his own. The appointment was booked by his mother.
Can you proceed with the investigations and treatments?

A. No – a 15-year-old patient is not competent yet. However, a quick phone call to one of the parents and their verbal consent is enough to proceed
B. No – a 15-year-old patient is not competent yet. However, the fact that the mother booked the appointment means that you can proceed
C. No – a 15-year-old patient is not competent yet. You need to ask him to come back with one his parents
D. Yes – you can proceed, as the age of competency is 15 in Scotland
E. Maybe – you need to assess the patient’s competency to consent for himself on an individual basis

Correct Answer: E

A patient, a retired lecturer, attends your dermatology clinic in Scotland. She asks if her friend can sit in the room whilst the consultation takes place. During the consultation, you note that she is unable to retain some information, does not remember her phone number, and repeats several things in a way that makes it seem she does not remember that she has already told you. She lives on her own, has driven her car to the appointment and, whilst in the appointment, answers her mobile phone in a confident manner. You feel that her dermatological condition would benefit from phototherapy.
Can the patient consent to this?

A. It requires a psychiatrist to assess her competence to make a decision
B. It depends upon your assessment of her competence to make a decision
C. It depends on whether she agrees with what you want to do
D. It depends on whether or not her friend thinks she has competence to make the decision
E. No – it is clear that she is beginning with dementia, and cannot make decisions for herself

Correct Answer: B

A homeless alcoholic man was brought to the Emergency Department by the police when he was found disoriented in the street. The Emergency Department recognises him as he has been brought in numerous times before. He appears malnourished and smells of alcohol. On examination, he is confused and ataxic. On eye examination, he has normal pupillary responses and a horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze.
Which one of the following vitamin deficiencies is likely responsible for the patient’s condition?

A. Vitamin A
B. Vitamin B3
C. D. Vitamin B12
D. Vitamin B1
E. Vitamin K

Correct Answer: D

A 64-year-old man who is a smoker presents with gradual-onset shortness of breath, over the last month. Chest radiograph shows a right pleural effusion.
What would be the most appropriate next investigation?

A. Computerised tomography (CT) of the chest
B. Bronchoscopy
C. Pleural aspirate
D. Echocardiogram
E. Spirometry

Correct Answer: C

Liver biopsy of a 30-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hepatic dysfunction shows 5- to 40-µm eosinophilic, round globules within the periportal hepatocytes. The globules are surrounded by a halo and are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant.
What is the most likely constituent of these globules?

A. Glycogen
B. Protein
C. Proteoglycan
D. Glycolipid
E. Glycoprotein

Correct Answer: E

A study is conducted to determine the risk of acquiring a disease during a 1-year study period. Only men are susceptible to the disease, which can be diagnosed using four basic clinical criteria.
In a population of 100 000 people aged 50 years, ten men met all the criteria. The men : women ratio was 1 : 1. An additional 90 men demonstrated mild symptoms but failed to meet the full criteria.
From these data, what is the risk of a 50-year-old man (in percentage) of being diagnosed with this disease (during a 1-year period)?

A. 0.02%
B. 0.01%
C. 0.2%
D. 0.4%
E. Cannot be determined with the information provided

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old Asian woman presents with complaints of palpitations, shortness of breath on moderate exertion and a painful and tender knee. On auscultation, she has a mid-diastolic murmur with a loud S1. On echocardiography, she is found to have valvular heart disease with a normal left ventricular ejection fraction.
What is the most likely valvular disease?

A. Mitral regurgitation
B. Mitral stenosis
C. Aortic regurgitation
D. Aortic stenosis
E. Ventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old woman presented with persistent morning headaches and vomiting. A CT scan shows a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe. Assessment of her visual fields reveals a defect.
What is the most likely defect?

A. Bitemporal hemianopia
B. Homonymous hemianopia
C. Homonymous inferior quadrantinopia
D. Homonymous superior quadrantinopia
E. Unilateral visual loss

Correct Answer: D

A 2-year-old boy with a 2-day history of coughing is brought in by his mother. The cough is non-productive in nature. On examination, he has no accessory muscle usage and is afebrile. On auscultation, he is noted to have a right-sided wheeze.
What is the most likely cause of this?

A. Bronchiolitis
B. Pneumonia
C. Inhaled foreign body
D. Asthma
E. Croup

Correct Answer: C

A 50-year-old man presented to his General Practitioner (GP) with a progressive-onset blurring of vision in his right eye. He had cataract surgery on the same eye three years ago.
His visual acuities were 6/9 in his right eye and 6/18 in his left eye. He mentioned that wearing his reading glasses made no difference.
Which one of the following diagnoses would explain the symptoms in his right eye?

A. Anterior capsule opacification
B. Hypermetropia
C. Myopia
D. Posterior capsule opacification
E. Presbyopia

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man is being examined for infertility. He has a low sperm count and a mobile mass in his left scrotum. Ultrasound reveals dilated veins of the pampiniform plexus.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Inguinal hernia
B. Cryptorchidism
C. Benign prostatic hyperplasia
D. Varicocele
E. Prostatic adenocarcinoma

Correct Answer: D

A patient presents to the General Practice (GP) Clinic, seeking advice regarding driving following two unprovoked seizures in 24 hours.
What advice to you give the patient regarding their ability to drive their car?

A. They are fit to drive and do not have to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Authority (DVLA), unless they have a further seizure
B. They must inform the DVLA and will be unfit to drive for at least six months
C. They must inform the DVLA and will be unfit to drive for at least five years
D. They are fit to drive, unless they have another seizure, but must inform the DVLA
E. They will be fit to drive following an assessment by a DVLA medical examiner

Correct Answer: B

A 29-year-old man presented with decreased libido. He had found out, from a magazine, about the hormone testosterone and had ordered a test through an Internet-based laboratory. His level came out as ‘low’. His other history included morphine addiction for the last 3 years. Only recently, he has joined a detoxification clinic and was being maintained on methadone orally. He was a smoker of 10–12 cigarettes per day.
Which of the following is the best advice to give to him?

A. Start oral testosterone
B. Start intramuscular (im) depot testosterone weekly
C. To come back once his detoxification regimen is over
D. Stop smoking
E. Have his follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinising hormone (LH) levels checked

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks’ pregnant, presents to her general practitioner (GP). She is concerned about flu-like symptoms, lethargy, conjunctivitis and a diffuse macular rash, shown below:
She states that she missed numerous childhood vaccinations, as her parents were worried about complications. You are worried that she may have rubella.
Which of the following is most appropriate for diagnosis of rubella?

A. Clinical diagnosis
B. Platelet count
C. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing
D. Rubella immunoglobulin G (IgG)
E. Skin biopsy

Correct Answer: C

A gynaecologist is performing a hysterectomy for leiomyomata and menorrhagia on a 46-year-old woman. Once under anaesthesia, the patient is catheterised, and the surgeon makes a Pfannenstiel’s incision transversely, just superior to the pubic symphysis. After opening the parietal peritoneum, he identifies the uterus and makes a shallow, transverse incision in the visceral peritoneum on the anterior uterine wall, and then pushes this downwards to expose the lower uterus.
What is the most likely reason for this?

A. The ureters typically run superior to the uterine artery, and the artery needs to be pushed down for safe ligation
B. The bladder is reflected downwards with the peritoneum
C. The sigmoid colon is displaced out of the operating field using this manoeuvre
D. The ovarian arteries are displaced in this way
E. The uterine tubes are displaced downwards in this way

Correct Answer: B

A 9-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department, having fallen on an outstretched hand. He is in significant pain and unable to move the arm. An X-ray reveals a fracture of the distal radius, with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. The ulna itself is not fractured.
What type of injury has this patient most likely sustained?

A. Bankart fracture
B. Colles fracture
C. Galeazzi fracture-dislocation
D. Monteggia fracture
E. Smith's fracture

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman presents with her son, who is two months old and was diagnosed a few days following birth with an anterior tongue tie. She is still struggling to establish enough feeding due to poor latch and a poor seal, even though she is alternating between breastfeeding and bottle feeding of expressed milk. She has been reviewed by the health visitor twice who is satisfied with her breastfeeding technique. The baby was over the 50th centile at birth and now has dropped to the 25th centile.
Given the above, what is the next most appropriate step in the management of this child?

A. Continue conservative management and review at six months of age
B. Convert to bottle feeding
C. Refer for frenotomy under general anaesthesia
D. Refer for frenotomy under no anaesthesia
E. Refer to a breastfeeding specialist for support with breastfeeding

Correct Answer: D

You are researching the effects of ageing on the various body systems as part of your geriatrics rotation.
Which of the following are consistent with normal ageing with respect to the endocrine system?

A. Low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinising hormone (LH) in both men and women in early post-menopausal period
B. Azospermia in men
C. Increased incidence of auto-immune disease
D. Low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in men and women
E. Low morning cortisol in men and women

Correct Answer: C

A 34-year-old woman, who has received a 3-unit blood transfusion following a Caesarean section, begins to feel unwell with a fever and chills 3 or 4 days later. There are no obvious signs of active bleeding. On examination, you note that she is mildly jaundiced.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Pre-transfusion haemoglobin (Hb) 87 g/l 115–155 g/l
Post-transfusion Hb 94 g/l 115–155 g/l
Platelets 195 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.4 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 140 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Bilirubin 95 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 54 IU/l 5–30 IU/l

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A. Bacterial sepsis
B. Delayed transfusion haemolysis
C. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
D. Further haemorrhage
E. Cholestasis of pregnancy

Correct Answer: B

An 81-year-old man has presented with a 5-month history of increasing shortness of breath associated with a wheeze (particularly on exertion), fatigue, ankle swelling, palpitations and a recently developed persistent cough.
He is a lifelong smoker and is now concerned that he may have lung cancer or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal Values
Haemoglobin (Hb) 120 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.2 × 109/l 4–11.0 × 109/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 2 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 35 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) 40 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Albumin 28 g/l 35–55 g/l
Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) 1500 pg/ml < 400 pg/ml
A chest X-ray is shown below.
What is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Antibiotics, oxygen therapy and intravenous (IV) fluids
B. Insertion of a cardioverter defibrillator
C. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, beta-blocker and loop diuretic, monitor blood pressure and electrolytes regularly; referral to a cardiologist
D. Salbutamol inhaler, ipratropium inhaler and smoking cessation advice; referral to a respiratory physician
E. Salbutamol nebulisers, ipratropium nebulisers, oxygen therapy and smoking cessation advice; referral to a respiratory physician

Correct Answer: C

A previously healthy 25-year-old actress complains of chronic pain in her right big toe. The woman reports that she wears high-heeled shoes ‘all the time’ but that it is becoming increasingly difficult to put such shoes on her right foot. Examination reveals erythema of the medial aspect of the right big toe and a large bony protuberance is observed in this area. The toe also appears to point toward the other toes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis (anatomical basis)?

A. Bunion (first metatarsophalangeal joint)
B. Bunion (first interphalangeal joint)
C. Fracture (first distal phalanx)
D. Gout (first interphalangeal joint)
E. Gout (first metatarsophalangeal joint)

Correct Answer: A

A 45-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a painful lesion on the inside of her mouth for the past five days. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin.
On examination of the mouth, an oval-shaped, shallow ulcer with a peripheral rim of erythema is present. It is tender on palpation. No other lesions are visualised. The patient does not have lymph node enlargement and is otherwise well.
Which of the following options is the most appropriate step in the management of this patient?

A. Biopsy of the lesion
B. Epstein–Barr virus testing
C. Immediate specialist referral
D. Oral steroids
E. Topical steroids

Correct Answer: E

A 3-week-old boy presents with vomiting, jaundice and dehydration. Investigations reveal hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis.
What is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Correction of metabolic derangements
B. Feeding jejunostomy
C. Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy
D. Total parenteral nutrition
E. Upper GI endoscopy

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old alcoholic is admitted following a fall. He has a large laceration on the side of his head and a collateral history is given by a passer-by to the paramedics. He is opening his eyes when asked to by the nurses. He responds to questioning, but only with garbled noises that cannot be understood. The patient withdraws from a trapezius squeeze.
Which one of the following is the correct Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assessment?

A. E3V2M4
B. E2V3M4
C. E3V3M3
D. E2V2M4
E. E2V2M5

Correct Answer: A

A 54-year-old woman who underwent Hartmann’s procedure six hours ago has started to complain of abdominal pain and light-headedness. On assessment, she has a blood pressure of 80/40 mmHg, a heart rate of 120 bpm, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, oxygen saturations of 98% and a temperature of 36.7 °C. She appears drowsy and pale, and the radial pulse is difficult to detect. Her abdomen appears rigid and is painful to palpate, and a bleed is suspected.
What type of shock is this patient most likely to have?

A. Anaphylactic
B. Cardiogenic
C. Hypovolaemic
D. Neurogenic
E. Septic

Correct Answer: C

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents. He has been suffering from a sore throat over the past few days, and now his parents have noticed that he has become increasingly drowsy and is complaining of a headache and neck stiffness. On examination, he is pyrexial at 38.2 °C. He has marked signs of meningism.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 15.2 × 109/l 5.0–12.0 × 109/l
Platelets 110 ×109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 29–53 µmol/l
Lumbar puncture Gram positive diplococci identified
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Neisseria meningitides
B. Mycoplasma pneumoniae
C. Haemophilus influenzae
D. Streptococcus pneumoniae
E. Listeria monocytogenes

Correct Answer: D

A 78-year-old woman has been admitted in a dehydrated and confused state to the Emergency Department. She has a history of cervical carcinoma. Her bloods are markedly abnormal: K+ of 7.2 mmol/l (NR 3.5–4.9), Cr 450 μmol/l (NR 60–110) and urea 31.2 mmol/l (NR 2.5–7.5). You repeat the serum potassium and it is still markedly raised.
Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial management in this case?

A. Arrange continuous ECG monitoring and consider giving 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate intravenous (IV)
B. Arrange an urgent renal ultrasound scan
C. Consider a third blood sample to confirm hyperkalaemia
D. Give IV salbutamol therapy
E. Give 250 mg furosemide IV to reduce the potassium concentration

Correct Answer: A

A mother brings her 2-day-old baby to the Paediatrician for a baby check. The baby’s mother is concerned about a birthmark on the baby’s face, the appearance of which is shown below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Dermal melanocytosis
B. Epidermal naevi
C. Infantile haemangioma
D. Naevus flammeus
E. Naevus simplex

Correct Answer: D

A 49-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with chest tightness. His blood pressure is 200/105 mmHg and heart rate is 70 bpm. His femoral pulses cannot be felt. Echocardiography reveals cardiomegaly and a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 34%. The patient also has a N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) of 25,000 pg/mL. As a result of the patient’s hypertension and high levels of NT-proBNP, he undergoes coronary angiography to exclude cardiac ischaemia. There is no evidence of myocardial ischaemia, but there are significant arterial findings.
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on coronary angiography of this patient?

A. Aortic aneurysm
B. Calcified arteries
C. Patent foramen ovale
D. Stenotic arteries
E. Thickened arteries

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old man presents to his GP with increasing back pain and shortness of breath. A lumbar spine radiograph reveals multiple osteolytic lesions and prompts further investigation – the patient is found to have mild anaemia, thrombocytopenia, hypercalcaemia and a raised creatinine. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal band of protein.
What is likely to be seen on blood film analysis?

A. Schistocytes
B. Howell Jolly bodies
C. Spherocytes
D. Blasts
E. Rouleaux formation

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old woman is referred by her general practitioner because of irregular and unpredictable menstrual cycle and headaches. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain demonstrates a midline lesion. Investigations reveal that her prolactin level is 2314 ng/ml (2–29 ng/ml). A decision is made to commence medical treatment.
Manipulation of which mediator is used to reduce the prolactin level?

A. Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
B. Dopamine
C. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH)
D. Somatostatin
E. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)

Correct Answer: B

A 46-year-old woman who is being treated for breast cancer has collapsed and has been brought to the Emergency Department. When she regains consciousness, she reports a 3-day history of chest pain, shortness of breath and reduced exercise capacity. On auscultation, there is a loud pulmonary second heart sound. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows right axis deviation and tall R-waves with T-wave inversion in V1–V3. The chest radiograph is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension
B. Angina
C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
D. Ventricular tachycardia
E. Multiple pulmonary emboli

Correct Answer: E

A 59-year-old man is being evaluated for a thyroid nodule. Ultrasound reveals a 1.5-cm solitary nodule located in the left lower lobe. Fine-needle aspiration reveals hypochromatic empty nuclei devoid of nucleoli, and psammoma bodies.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Lymphoma of the thyroid
B. Medullary thyroid carcinoma
C. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
D. Papillary thyroid carcinoma
E. Follicular thyroid carcinoma

Correct Answer: D

A 74-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner accompanied by his wife. She is concerned that he has had a very sudden deterioration in his memory, compared to a few months ago. This has been accompanied by difficulty paying attention and concentrating. She is also worried that he has become incontinent of urine and has started to walk with much smaller steps. His past medical history notably includes myocardial infarction (MI) one year ago, as well as hypertension and diabetes. There is no family history of any similar symptoms.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Alzheimer’s disease
B. Frontotemporal dementia
C. Huntington’s disease
D. Lewy body dementia
E. Vascular dementia

Correct Answer: E

A 35-year-old woman is referred to the Neurology Clinic with a history of droopy eyelids over the past 6 months. She has intermittent double vision, which is of a variable nature. She has noticed that from time to time she has trouble swallowing her food. On examination, she has mild weakness of eyelid closure bilaterally and mild lower facial weakness. There is mild weakness of neck flexion and bilateral shoulder abduction. Reflexes are normal throughout, as is the remainder of the examination.
Electromyography is performed. Repetitive nerve stimulation (right abductor pollicis brevis muscle) results in a 30% decrease in the compound motor action potential (CMAP). Single-fibre electromyography shows the presence of normal fibre density and jitter.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Guillain–Barré syndrome
B. Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome
C. Autoimmune myasthenia gravis
D. Congenital myasthenia gravis
E. Polymyalgia rheumatica

Correct Answer: C

A 65-year-old man suffering from painless, asymmetrical cervical lymphadenopathy and night sweats was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma. He was referred to oncology outpatients for treatment.
Which of the following is the most appropriate chemotherapy regimen to treat Hodgkin’s lymphoma?

A. R-CHOP
B. FOLFOX
C. FEC
D. ABVD
E. CMV

Correct Answer: D

A 58-year-old man is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit from the Coronary Care Ward. He has suffered from an acute myocardial infarction two days earlier. On examination, he is profoundly unwell with a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. He has crackles throughout his lung fields, with markedly decreased oxygen saturations; he has no audible cardiac murmurs. He is intubated and ventilated, and catheterised.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 121 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 5.8 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 285 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 128 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 6.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 195 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Troponin T 5.8 ng/ml <0.1 ng/ml
Urine output 30 ml in the past 3 h
ECG – consistent with a myocardial infarction 48 h earlier
Chest X-ray – gross pulmonary oedema
Which of the following fits best with the clinical picture?

A. High dose dopamine is likely to preserve renal function
B. An intra-aortic balloon pump may be of benefit       
C. Chance of death is likely to be less than 10%
D. Nesiritide reduces mortality and improves renal function in this situation
E. Nitrate therapy is likely to be the initial management of choice

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old backpacker had started a climbing expedition to Mount Everest. He had flown from the United Kingdom the previous day. To avoid the adverse weather forecast, he and his colleagues left the base camp the next day. They reached an altitude of 6000 m on day four. He complained of light-headedness and infrequent dull headaches, which he blamed on his dehydration. The next day, he set out on his own, only to be found by the search party ten hours later. He was found to be rather confused, unable to walk in a straight line, irritable and feeling very tired. His symptoms dramatically improved after a course of dexamethasone and resting in a portable hyperbaric chamber.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute mountain sickness (AMS)
B. Alcohol intoxication
C. High-altitude cerebral oedema (HACE)
D. High-altitude pulmonary oedema (HAPE)
E. Hypoglycaemia

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a six-month history of ringing in her ear and hearing loss. This began after a two-week inpatient stay for a soft tissue infection complicated by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bloodstream infection. She was managed with flucloxacillin and then gentamicin and vancomycin. The tinnitus is bilateral.
Ear and neurological examinations are normal.
What is the likely underlying cause of this patient’s tinnitus?

A. Bloodstream infection
B. Hyperlipidaemia
C. Ménière’s disease
D. Otosclerosis
E. Ototoxic medication

Correct Answer: E

A 51-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) complaining of a cough which started one week ago. The patient denies bringing up any sputum or blood. She has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus, essential hypertension and psoriasis.
There is no recent travel history and she has not been in contact with anyone with similar symptoms. She mentions that she was recently prescribed a new medication.
Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?

A. Angiotensin-receptor blockers
B. ACE inhibitors
C. Corticosteroids
D. Hydralazine
E. Ciclosporins

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old man asks to see you because he does not feel his normal self. Things have not been right following his divorce 6 months ago. Over the last 4 weeks, he has felt low for most of each day, especially in the mornings when he wakes up early. He has lost all interest in his usual activities. He has not been to any matches at the football club where he is a season ticket holder. It has occurred to him a couple of times that he would be better off just swallowing a bottle of tablets and getting away from it all, but he does not think he would do it because his parents have been there supporting him when he needed it. There is no significant medical history or previous psychiatric history.
Which one of the following treatments would be most suitable?

A. Fluoxetine
B. Imipramine
C. Lithium
D. Electroconvulsive therapy
E. Phenelzine

Correct Answer: A

A 31-year-old man presents to the General Practitioner (GP), complaining of unilateral painful red eye. On examination, he is found to have reduced visual acuity, photophobia, eye watering and a poorly reactive pupil. He is diagnosed with suspected uveitis.
What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Chloramphenicol
B. Conservative management with pain relief
C. Same-day referral to an Ophthalmologist
D. Topical steroids alone
E. Urgent (within two weeks) referral to an Ophthalmologist

Correct Answer: C

A 47-year-old woman is brought to the Emergency Department (ED) after being involved in a car accident. She is alert and receives initial resuscitation in the ED. She has an open fracture of the right tibia and is seen by the orthopaedic surgery team.
Later during the day, she undergoes an intramedullary nailing procedure for fixing her fractured tibia. Seven days after the surgery, the patient complains of gradually worsening severe pain in the right leg.
Upon examination, she is found to be febrile and the wound area is not markedly erythematous and there is no discharge from the wound site. There is no right calf tenderness and no swelling. Blood tests reveal a raised white cell count and inflammatory markers, and a blood culture grows Staphylococcus aureus. An X-ray and leg Doppler ultrasound imaging reveal no subcutaneous gas. An urgent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) report prompts the surgeon to take this patient urgently back to theatre.
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Cellulitis
B. Deep vein thrombosis
C. Necrotising fasciitis
D. Osteomyelitis
E. Surgical wound infection

Correct Answer: D

A 35-year-old woman, mother of three, presents on day eight postpartum with difficulties breastfeeding. She has exclusively breastfed her other two children. She tells you her baby has problems latching, is feeding for a long time and is always hungry. She has sore nipples as a result of the poor latch.
On examination, you notice that the baby cannot bring his tongue past the lower lip and there is restriction in movement. On lifting the tongue, it acquires a heart shape with a central notch, but you cannot visualise the frenulum.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anterior tongue tie
B. Cleft lip
C. Cleft palate
D. Posterior tongue tie
E. Upper lip tie

Correct Answer: D

A 39-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and wheezing. He does not smoke and denies any recreational drug use. There is cirrhosis of the liver on ultrasound. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is diagnosed, and he receives a liver transplant.
Which of the following types of emphysema is he at increased risk of developing?

A. Compensatory
B. Interstitial
C. Centriacinar
D. Paraseptal
E. Panacinar

Correct Answer: E

A 20-year-old man complains of generalised swelling that has affected the legs, arm and face, worsening over the last 3 weeks. Blood tests show: urea 14.8 mmol/l, creatinine 190 μmol/l, Na+ 138 mmol/l, K+ 4.2 mmol/l, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 20 iu/l, bilirubin 16 μmol/l, albumin 19 g/l, total cholesterol 9.2 mmol/l, prothrombin time (PT) 10 s.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cirrhosis of the liver
B. Nephrotic syndrome
C. Nephritic syndrome
D. Anorexia nervosa
E. Cystic fibrosis

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old student is brought by his flatmates to the University Health Service with headache, neck stiffness and a petechial rash. There is a past history of infection with Neisseria meningitidis four and ten years earlier. He is immediately referred to the local general hospital.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 14.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 310 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 5.4 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 190 μmol/l 50–120 μmol/l
Lumbar puncture: neutrophils +++
Which of the following is the most likelydiagnosis?

A. C1 deficiency
B. C2 deficiency
C. C4 deficiency
D. Membrane attack complex (MAC) formation deficiency
E. IgA deficiency

Correct Answer: D

A 31-year-old woman who has three children comes to the general practice surgery complaining of lethargy and an inability to cope. She has previously been treated with citalopram after the birth of her first child for a period of around 6 months. The only medication history of note includes depo progesterone for contraception, and she admits this is making it difficult for her to lose her ‘post-baby belly’. On examination, her blood pressure is 142/72 mmHg and her body mass index is 29. There are no other significant findings.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 124 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.7 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 234 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 140 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.2 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) 4.5 µU/l 0.17–3.2 µU/l
Free T4 13.2 pmol/l 11–22 pmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hypothyroidism
B. Thyrotoxicosis
C. Depression
D. Sick euthyroid syndrome
E. Sub-clinical hypothyroidism

Correct Answer: E

A 77-year-old man presents with urinary hesitancy and dribbling. He was examined by his General Practitioner two weeks ago, and on per rectum examination, he was noted to have a smoothly enlarged prostate.
What is the most appropriate next investigation?

A. Biopsy
B. Serum prostate-specific antigen
C. Ultrasound scan
D. Urinalysis
E. Urodynamics

Correct Answer: B

A newborn girl had cystic hygroma and significant oedema. By the time she was 14 years old, she had a short stature, a webbed neck and a broad, shield-like chest. She did not develop secondary sexual characteristics at the age-appropriate time.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Turner syndrome
B. Klinefelter’s syndrome
C. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome
E. 5-α reductase deficiency

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old woman attends the clinic with amenorrhoea for 1 year and a milky discharge from both breasts. She does not take any medications. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which of the following tests should be done next?

A. Thyroid function tests
B. computerised tomography (CT) scan
C. Visual field tests
D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
E. Mammogram

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old woman attends the Endocrine Clinic for follow-up of type II diabetes. A decision is made to commence treatment with a glitazone.
Which of the following statements is correct about this medication?

A. There is an association with lactic acidosis
B. The mechanism of action involves increasing levels of adiponectin
C. Inhibition of the intestinal brush border occurs
D. Glitazones stimulate endogenous insulin release
E. Glitazones have a similar structure to amylin

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old patient is due to undergo a skin graft following a burns injury.
Which of the following is an advantage of a split skin graft over a full-thickness skin graft?

A. Greater chance of graft survival
B. Less contraction following grafting
C. Greater resistance to trauma
D. Better cosmetic appearance
E. Lower risk for pigment change

Correct Answer: A

A 34-year-old woman is on day four postpartum, following an emergency Caesarean section for severe pre-eclampsia. She feels well in herself and is mobilising and breastfeeding well. Her blood pressure has not normalised yet and is 158/106 mmHg today. Urinalysis is negative for protein. Following a long discussion, you decide that she is ready for discharge and can be managed in the community.
Which of the following is correct regarding postnatal hypertension?

A. Women who are discharged and are still hypertensive should have their blood pressure checked every other day in the community until targets are achieved
B. If blood pressure is found to be > 150/100 mmHg in the community, the patient should be referred back to hospital
C. The blood pressure should be checked at least once every two weeks until the woman discontinues antihypertensive treatment
D. The general practitioner (GP) at the 6-week postnatal check should convert all women with chronic hypertension (before pregnancy) back to their pre-pregnancy antihypertensive.
E. The GP at the 6-week postnatal check should stop antihypertensives in all women who required medical treatment in pregnancy

Correct Answer: A

A 68-year-old patient with known heart failure is receiving intravenous fluids on the ward. You get a call from one of the ward nurses to say he is becoming increasingly short of breath. You examine the patient and request an urgent chest X-ray.
Which of the following features on the chest X-ray would be most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary oedema?

A. A cardiothoracic ratio of 0.5
B. Patchy perihilar shadowing
C. Patchy shadowing bilaterally in the lower zones
D. Prominent lower zone vessels
E. Narrowing of the carina

Correct Answer: B
