A neonate born with trisomy 21 begins to vomit shortly after his first feed. The emesis is green and occurs after each subsequent feeding. His abdomen is also distended, most noticeably in the epigastrum. A baby-gram demonstrates a ‘double bubble’ in the abdomen.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Duodenal atresia
C. Biliary atresia
D. Tracheoesophageal fistula
E. Imperforate anus

Correct Answer: B

A 9-year-old boy tripped while playing outside. He outstretched his arms to brace himself against the ground and immediately grabbed his right elbow in pain. He was taken to the Emergency Department and an X-ray revealed a right humeral supracondylar fracture.
Which of the following deficits is this child most likely to suffer?

A. Atrophy of the biceps brachii muscle
B. Loss of sensation to the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand
C. Weakness of wrist flexion of the left hand
D. Weakness to the right index finger
E. Loss of sensation to the dorsum of the right hand

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with shortness of breath which started suddenly one hour ago. She is also complaining of chest pain and had an episode of haemoptysis in the ED. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals no ischaemic changes. She has a heart rate of 85 bpm and blood pressure of 134/83 mmHg. The patient was on a flight from Dubai to the UK yesterday. She suffers from type I diabetes mellitus which is well controlled. She had a tonsillectomy two years ago and her brother suffers from asthma. She started the combined oral contraceptive pill six months ago and has insulin for her diabetes but takes no other medications.
Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most significant risk factor?

A. Diabetes
B. Asthma
C. Tonsillectomy two years ago
D. Family history of malignancy
E. Combined oral contraceptive pill

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old woman has a postpartum haemorrhage four hours after delivery of her first child via elective Caesarean section. The patient is resuscitated and bloods are sent off for urgent analysis.
Test results reveal: increased prothrombin time, increased active partial thromboplastin time, low haemoglobin (Hb), normal white cell count (WCC) and low fibrinogen.
What is the most likely cause of these results?

A. HELLP syndrome
B. Warfarin overdose
C. Disseminated intravascular coagulation
D. Haemolytic uraemic syndrome
E. Thrombotic thrombocytopaenic purpura

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old man is admitted to Emergency Department (ED) with epigastric pain and small volume coffee-ground vomiting. He had a history of peptic ulcers, and another ulcer is suspected.
What initial first-line investigation is most appropriate to check if the ulcer might have perforated?

A. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis
B. Erect chest X-ray
C. Supine chest X-ray
D. Ultrasound abdomen
E. X-ray abdomen

Correct Answer: B

A 34-year-old woman presents with greasy, foul-smelling diarrhoea of 3 weeks’ duration. She has nausea and bloating but denies fever, chills and blood in the stool. She has lost 4 pounds over the last weeks. Her appetite is less than usual. She reports no oral ulcers, joint pain and skin rash or abdominal pain. Family and past medical history are non-contributory. She had been to Mexico on holiday last month. Examination of faecal materials reveals motile, flagellated, binucleated pear-shaped trophozoites.
What is the treatment of choice of this condition?

A. Diloxanide
B. Emetine
C. Chloroquine
D. Iodoquinol
E. Metronidazole

Correct Answer: E

A 42-year-old man presents with a one–hour history of sudden-onset severe headache and vomiting. He is normally fit and well and has no medical history to note. He is a smoker and drinks socially.
The FY2 doctor examining the patient is concerned that he may have had a subarachnoid haemorrhage.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line investigation to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

A. MRI scan
B. CT angiogram
C. Fundal examination
D. CT scan without contrast
E. Lumbar puncture

Correct Answer: D

A 19-year-old university student complains of a 2-month history of tiredness and weight loss. On further questioning the patient tells you that he has been excessively thirsty and has also been passing urine many times during the day and night. The patient is investigated further and is diagnosed with having type 1 diabetes mellitus.
Which of the following is lacking in this condition?

A. Alpha-islet cells
B. Beta-islet cells
C. Gamma-islet cells
D. Delta-islet cells
E. Epsilon-islet cells

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man complains of palpitations and dizzy spells. Echocardiography reveals the presence of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM).
Which one of the following will be observed on echocardiography?

A. Systolic posterior motion of the mitral leaflet
B. Symmetrical septal hypertrophy
C. Reduced left ventricular outflow tract gradient
D. Reduced left ventricular cavity size
E. Mitral stenosis

Correct Answer: D

A 50-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the Emergency Department following a high-speed road traffic incident. He was ejected from the vehicle and sustained a severe head injury. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is E1 V1 M2. Other injuries include an unstable pelvic fracture (secured with a binder) and bruising to his anterior chest wall. His heart rate is 100 bpm with a blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg. Additional history from a family member includes:

Allergy – penicillin
Past medical history – hypertension, high cholesterol
Drug history – bisoprolol.
Which one of the following would be the fluid of choice for supporting his blood pressure?

A. 1 l of crystalloid (0.9% sodium chloride)
B. l of Hartmann’s
C. 1 l of warmed crystalloid (0.9% sodium chloride)
D. Packed red blood cells (through a fluid warmer)
E. 1 l of 5% dextrose

Correct Answer: D

A 69-year-old retired gardener is under the Palliative Care team due to advanced carcinoma of the stomach. He is prescribed ondansetron to help manage symptoms of nausea and vomiting, and the patient would like to know what side-effects the medication may have.
Which of the following is a common side-effect of ondansetron?

A. Constipation
B. Cough
C. Diarrhoea
D. Palpitations
E. Skin rash

Correct Answer: A

As a part of a haematology rotation, a final-year medical student is asked to give a PowerPoint presentation to the team about a 19-year-old patient who presented with sickle-cell crisis.
With regard to sickle-cell disease, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Sickle cells occur as a result of the production of an abnormal alpha (α) chain in haemoglobin
B. Splenomegaly is usually seen in adults with sickle-cell disease
C. It is most common in individuals of Mediterranean descent
D. Aplastic crisis can be precipitated by parvovirus B19
E. Spherocytes are usually seen on the blood film

Correct Answer: D

A 33-year-old patient with a chronic skin condition is under annual review with the Dermatology team. At her review appointment, the patient mentions that she has been experiencing episodes of new skin lesions appearing in areas where she has scratched, often appearing in straight lines. The doctor examines a typical lesion, and notes that they are examples of Koebner phenomenon.
In which one of the following conditions is the Koebner phenomenon MOST likely to be seen?

A. Eczema
B. Pityriasis rosea
C. Rosacea
D. Cellulitis
E. Psoriasis

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old man is in the Neurosurgical Intensive Care Unit (ICU) after sustaining a subarachnoid haemorrhage. He underwent surgery for management of occlusive hydrocephalus that occurred as a complication of his bleed. He now has an intraventricular pressure monitor in place to measure his intracranial pressure.
Which one of the following statements is true regarding intracranial pressure?

A. Intracranial pressure is normally <5 mmHg in healthy adults
B. Intracranial pressure is higher in children than in adults
C. Intravenous mannitol is used to decrease intracranial pressure
D. Administration of hypertonic saline 23.4% increases intracranial pressure
E. Lateral rectus palsy is pathognomonic of raised intracranial pressure

Correct Answer: C

A 27-year-old primigravida presents at ten weeks’ gestation with persistent nausea and vomiting. She reports this is mostly in the morning but has affected her a lot, as she is struggling to attend work. She can manage oral fluids, but she struggles mostly with eating. She has tried avoiding certain foods and has followed some conservative advice she found on the National Health Service (NHS) website, including ginger, and they have not helped. Her examination is unremarkable. Her documented pre-pregnancy weight is 58 kg, and today she weighs 63 kg. The patient is keen to try some medication.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A. Cyclizine
B. Hydrocortisone
C. Metoclopramide
D. Ondansetron
E. Thiamine

Correct Answer: A

A 12-year-old boy with a history of hayfever and eczema was brought to the Emergency Department, feeling unwell after being stung by a bee. The attending doctor immediately gave this boy a shot of adrenaline (epinephrine).
Which of the following is adrenaline injected to treat?

A. Local immune complex formation
B. Interleukin release from macrophages
C. Binding of anti-receptor antibody
D. Complement activation
E. Systemic anaphylaxis

Correct Answer: E

A 48-year-old woman presents with a neck swelling. The lump is smooth, non-tender and in the midline of the neck, just below the cricoid cartilage. A thyroglossal cyst is suspected.
Which of the following features is most indicative of this condition?

A. Rises when patient protrudes her tongue
B. Remains immobile when patient swallows
C. It is tender
D. Associated with lymphadenopathy
E. Middle-aged onset

Correct Answer: A

As part of a learning exercise, a student drew a small black square and a black circle, 4 inches horizontally apart, on a piece of white paper. The student then held the paper at arm’s length and closed his left eye, while focusing on the black square, which was to the left of the black circle, with his right eye. He moved the paper slowly towards him until the black circle disappeared.
Which of the following anatomical structures is responsible for the disappearance of the black circle?

A. Optic disc
B. Macula lutea
C. Fovea centralis
D. Dilator pupillae
E. Sphincter pupillae

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man is seen at cardiology out-patients 6 weeks after an anterior myocardial infarction. His wife tells you that she cannot sleep at night as he is incessantly coughing and clearing his throat.
Which drug is likely responsible?

A. Amiodarone
B. Atenolol
C. Perindopril
D. Atorvastatin
E. Candesartan

Correct Answer: C

An otherwise fit and well 88-year-old man presents with troublesome varicose veins affecting both lower limbs. He has no skin changes or ulcers but did have an episode of painful superficial thrombophlebitis a year previously.
Concerning varicose veins, which of the following are indications for referral to vascular surgery from primary care?

A. Presence of ulceration
B. Troublesome symptoms (such as leg aching and ankle swelling) associated with varicose veins
C. Superficial (not deep) thrombosis
D. Venous eczema
E. Any of the above

Correct Answer: E

A study is carried out to compare the effectiveness of a new blood test for diagnosing respiratory tuberculosis (TB) infection, compared to the current gold standard investigation of sputum microscopy. The study involved 412 patients with suspected TB. During the study, sputum microscopy was unavailable for ten of the patients, resulting in them only having the new blood test.
As all patients did not receive both investigations, of what bias is this study most at risk?

A. Spectrum bias
B. Verification bias
C. Follow-up bias
D. Reporting bias
E. Response bias

Correct Answer: B

A 28-year-old Afro-Caribbean woman presents to clinic. She is worried about her appearance, as she seems to be losing hair, has a rash across her face and has mouth ulcers. She also complains of joint pains and has been taking paracetamol and ibuprofen regularly to combat the pain. This is her second visit to clinic and she has already had some immunology sent off by the registrar. You note that dsDNA antibody is positive.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Rheumatoid arthritis
B. Polymyositis
C. Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
D. Systemic sclerosis
E. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Correct Answer: E

A 72-year-old woman with chronic congestive cardiac failure and renal impairment complains of a red, hot, swollen toe of sudden onset. This has occurred on a number of occasions. Her current medications include aspirin and azathioprine. The diagnosis is felt to be gout and she is prescribed colchicine.
What is the most likely side-effect for the patient?

A. A rash
B. Increased joint discomfort
C. Palpitations
D. Diarrhoea
E. Polydipsia

Correct Answer: D

A 22-year-old motorcyclist was brought to the Emergency Department following a road traffic accident (RTA). On examination, he had a large bruise on his right arm with the inability to move his arm. A radiograph of the right arm revealed a fracture involving the surgical neck of the humerus.
Which artery is such a fracture most likely to injure?

A. The subscapular artery
B. The circumflex scapular artery
C. The radial recurrent artery
D. The brachial artery
E. The posterior humeral circumflex artery

Correct Answer: E

A 62-year-old Caucasian man with type II diabetes is seen for annual review. His blood pressure is 174/99 mmHg, and his 24-hour urine collection reveals modestly increased albuminuria (microalbuminuria). Blood results show Na+ 140 mmol/l, K+ 4.0 mmol/l, urea 4.2 mmol/l and creatinine 75 μmol/l.
Which of the following medications would be the most appropriate to use first line to treat the hypertension?

A. Bendroflumethiazide
B. Atenolol
C. Amlodipine
D. Furosemide
E. Ramipril

Correct Answer: E

A 45-year-old man who is an accountant seeks treatment for fainting spells, dizziness, palpitations and pressure in his chest. During these 5- to 10-minute spells, he worries about fainting and death. He takes an inefficient route to work, hoping to avoid crossing busy streets because he fears being run over by a car after fainting. He avoids public speaking and works at home late into the night, which makes these attacks more frequent.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Panic disorder with agoraphobia
B. Somatisation disorder
C. Hypoglycemia
D. Paroxysmal atrial tachycardia
E. Specific phobia

Correct Answer: A

You are the junior doctor on call. The nurses ask you to come and review a patient, as he is acting ‘odd’. His eyes are open spontaneously, he is localising to pain and he is making incomprehensible sounds.
What is this patient’s Glasgow Coma Score (GCS)?

A. 15
B. 14
C. 11
D. 6
E. 7

Correct Answer: C

A 40-year-old woman recently had a UTI, which was found to be positive for Proteus mirabilis.
Of what composition of renal calculi is the patient at increased risk?

A. Calcium oxalate
A. B. Calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate (mixed)
C. Urate
D. Magnesium ammonium phosphate
E. Cystine

Correct Answer: D

A 27-year-old Romanian immigrant presents to his general practitioner, complaining of firm and tender reddish-blue raised nodules on the front of both shins. These have been present for a number of months. He has also lost weight and suffered from a chronic cough since the beginning of the year. On examination, there are multiple red/purple, firm, painful lesions affecting both shins. Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 105 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 220 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.5 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 110 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Chest X-ray Calcified hilar lymph nodes,
area of upper lobe fibrosis in the right lung
Induced sputum Acid- and alcohol-fast bacilli seen
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for his rash?

A. Erythema infectiosum
B. Erythema multiforme
C. Erythema nodosum
D. Superficial thrombophlebitis
E. Insect bites

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old patient comes to the general practitioner, complaining of a darkening of his urine, most noticeable early in the morning. He has no family history of a bleeding disorder. Recently, he was hospitalised for deep venous thrombosis of his right leg. On examination, his heart and lungs are clear. Blood tests reveal anaemia, high levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), high bilirubin levels and a high reticulocyte count.
Which one of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
B. Loss of spectrin in the red blood cell membrane
C. Vitamin B12 deficiency
D. Phosphatidylinositol glycan A defect in red blood cells
E. Immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody against red blood cells

Correct Answer: D

A 94-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after falling outside his home. His carers, who visit three times a day, report that the patient becomes aggressive when prevented from going outside and he also refuses to be accompanied. The patient has no next-of-kin, and he was formally diagnosed with dementia last year. He has a past medical history of hypertension. He is now medically fit for discharge from hospital, but he lacks capacity to make a decision regarding his treatment and his place of residence. It is proposed that an application is made under the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS), in his best interests, to prevent the patient from wandering outside. The ward manager says that this cannot be done, as the patient does not meet all the criteria.
Which of the following is preventing a DoLS from being authorised for this patient?

A. The patient resides in his own home
B. The patient does not have an advance decision about his treatment
C. The patient lacks capacity for decisions regarding treatment
D. The patient is above 18 years of age
E. The patient suffers from dementia

Correct Answer: A

A 32-year-old patient presented to his General Practitioner with a lump in his neck. Following assessment, he is referred and a biopsy is taken. The histology shows pleomorphic giant cells which have binuclear cells.
What is the most likely disease?

A. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
C. Tuberculosis (TB)
D. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
E. Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV)

Correct Answer: A

A 47-year-old man who has just undergone a gastrectomy is told he will suffer from vitamin B12 deficiency.
What is the most likely physiological explanation?

A. Lack of storage ability
B. Achlorohydria
C. Failed gastric emptying
D. Loss of intrinsic factors
E. Increased upper GI gut transit

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old woman with small-cell lung cancer has a serum sodium concentration of 121 mmol/l.
Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A. Bone metastases
B. Liver metastases
C. Sodium-reduced water drinking
D. Sodium-restricted diet
E. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

Correct Answer: E

A 63-year-old man presents to the Surgical Clinic with a 2-week history of jaundice. He reports no recent weight loss, although he does not feel as hungry in the last month as he used to previously. He denies any symptoms of abdominal pain, change in bowel habit or nausea. His past medical history is unremarkable, apart from a single acute episode of alcoholic pancreatitis over 30 years ago. He is a 20-pack-year smoker who has been tee-total for the last 15 years.
On examination, your patient is comfortable at rest. However, he is brightly jaundiced. Examination of the abdomen is unremarkable and there are no areas of tenderness or masses palpable.
You organise some blood tests to be done and the results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 114 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 9.1 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 258 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.1 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Urea 6.3 mmol/l 2.5–6.5 mmol/l
Creatinine 118 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Bilirubin 218 μmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Alkaline phosphatase 890 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Gamma-Glutamyl transferase (GGT) 760 μU/l 5–30 IU/l
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST ) 540 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Albumin 31 g/l 35–55 g/l
U/S scan shows a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary tree, however the examination is limited due to excess bowel gas. You feel that the results and ultrasound findings need further investigating.
Given the clinical scenario above, which of the following options is the best next step?

A. Computed tomography (CT) scan
B. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
C. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
D. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC)
E. Abdominal laparoscopy and proceed to cholecystectomy

Correct Answer: C

A 60-year-old woman presents with upper arm stiffness and pain. She says that it has come on recently and suddenly and she is not able to lift her arms above her head. It is worse in the morning. On further questioning, she admits to feeling lethargic and low in mood. Blood investigations reveal a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.
Which is the most appropriate management plan?

A. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and paracetamol, and review in a week
B. Prednisolone 15 mg a day and reduce according to inflammatory marker results
C. Physiotherapy
D. Orthopaedic referral
E. Steroid injections

Correct Answer: B

A 24-year-old man with a 12-year history of type I diabetes presents with a 1-day history of vomiting and a 4-day history of myalgia and sore throat. He appears dehydrated, BP 120/74 mmHg, pulse 101 bpm, temperature 37.9 °C, oxygen saturation 97% on room air. There is mild erythema in his throat and nil else to find on clinical examination. The following are his laboratory investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
pH 7.12 7.35–7.45
Ketones 5 mmol/l <0.6
Glucose 32 mmol/l 4–10 mmol/l
Potassium 4.2 mmol/l 3.5–5 mmol/l
Bicarbonate 10 mmol/l 24–30 mmol/l
Base excess -5 mEq/l −2 to +2 mEg/l
C-reactive protein (CRP) 22 mg/l 0–10 mg/l
White Cell Count (WCC) 12.7 × 109/l 4-11
Which of the following initial treatment plans should be commenced?

A. IV fluids, potassium supplementation, IV insulin
B. IV insulin, IV fluids, IV antibiotics
C. Subcutaneous rapid acting insulin, IV fluids, potassium supplementation, oral antibiotics
D. IV antibiotics, subcutaneous long acting insulin
E. Subcutaneous long acting insulin, IV 10% dextrose, potassium supplementation

Correct Answer: A

A 33-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 5-day history of painless rectal bleeding. The patient describes episodes of bright red bleeding when opening his bowels, which occurs as streaks on the toilet paper and in the toilet bowel. The blood is not mixed into the stool. This has occurred every time he opens his bowels since the onset of symptoms. He does not notice any pain when this happens, although he does have some itching and irritation around the anal area afterwards. He is otherwise well, with no change in bowel habit and no weight loss.
On rectal examination, the doctor notes the presence of a fleshy protrusion at the 7 o’clock position, present on straining, but recedes into the anus when the patient stops straining.
Which of the following management options would be a viable option in this scenario?

A. Mebendazole
B. Topical lidocaine ointment
C. Incision and drainage
D. Sphincterotomy
E. Injection sclerotherapy

Correct Answer: E

A 29-year-old woman with epilepsy, associated with generalised tonic–clonic seizures, presents with her partner to her routine Epilepsy Clinic appointment. She is currently on the combined oral contraceptive pill, but she wishes to start trying for a baby. She is currently taking sodium valproate and has been seizure-free for one year.
Which of the following is the most appropriate antiepileptic medication for this patient to take during the pre-conception period and pregnancy?

A. Continue sodium valproate
B. Stop sodium valproate and commence ethosuximide
C. Stop sodium valproate and commence lamotrigine
D. Stop sodium valproate and commence levetiracetam
E. Stop sodium valproate and commence phenytoin

Correct Answer: C

A 45-year-old woman with type II diabetes is sent urgently to the Emergency Department by her General Practitioner (GP). The patient had seen her GP that morning and described an episode of chest pain that she had experienced the day before. The GP suspected the pain was due to gastro-oesophageal reflux but had performed an electrocardiogram (ECG) and sent a troponin level to be certain. The ECG was normal, but the troponin level came back that afternoon as raised. The GP rang the patient and advised her to go to Accident and Emergency, given the possibility of reduced sensitivity to the symptoms of a myocardial infarction (MI) in this diabetic patient.
Patient Normal range
High-sensitivity troponin T 20 ng/l <14 ng/l
What action should be taken, based on this test result?

A. Repeat troponin level
B. Safety-netting and return to the GP
C. Admission to Coronary Care Unit (CCU)
D. Administer thrombolysis
E. Alanine transaminase (ALT) level

Correct Answer: A

A 15-year-old girl is diagnosed with rheumatic fever after presenting with a 3-day history of fever and polyarthralgia. The patient’s mother is concerned about any potential lasting damage to the heart.
Which of the following is the most common cardiac sequela of rheumatic fever?

A. Aortic sclerosis
B. Mitral stenosis
C. Pulmonary regurgitation
D. Tricuspid regurgitation
E. Ventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: B

A 33-year-old woman of chinese origin presents to the Respiratory Physician after referral by her General Practitioner. She has a productive cough with mucopurulent sputum which has sometimes had tinges of blood in it. She has recently developed shortness of breath. Her medical history reveals a period of shortness of breath and a productive cough 12 months ago and she had several episodes of pneumonia when she was a child.
Which investigation is the gold standard for confirming the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Autoimmune panel
B. Bronchoscopy
C. Chest X-ray
D. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chest
E. Pulse oximetry

Correct Answer: D

A 54-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) with a 3-day history of increased urinary frequency and urgency, followed by two episodes of urinary incontinence.
Her past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus (treated with metformin) and diverticular disease. She does not smoke but admits to drinking one bottle of wine every evening.
Her heart rate is 104 bpm, and abdominal examination reveals non-specific lower abdominal discomfort. Perineal sensation and anal tone are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s incontinence?

A. Alcohol excess
B. Constipation
C. Diabetes mellitus
D. Oestrogen deficiency
E. Urinary tract infection

Correct Answer: E

A 40-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner (GP) with generalised aches, particularly in his knees when he walks. He also feels like his muscles are weaker now despite doing the same amount of exercise as he has always done. The GP comments on how the patient is wearing long sleeves and trousers despite it being summer, and the patient says that he does not like the sun.
The GP does a blood test and identifies low levels of calcium and phosphate.
Which of the following metabolic bone conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Osteitis fibrosa cystica
B. Osteomalacia
C. Osteopetrosis
D. Osteoporosis
E. Paget’s disease

Correct Answer: B

A 63-year-old woman develops a urinary tract infection (UTI) for which she is treated with amoxicillin. She has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin, and atrial fibrillation for which she takes warfarin. She has been drinking several glasses of cranberry juice each day, as she was told it can help prevent UTIs. At a routine appointment, her international normalised ratio (INR) is 6.
By what mechanism does cranberry juice affect the INR?

A. Inhibitor of warfarin metabolism
B. Reduced intestinal binding of warfarin
C. Increased enzymatic activity
D. Hyperglycaemia-mediated inhibition
E. Prevention of clotting factor production

Correct Answer: A

You are asked to see a 76-year-old woman on the Surgical Assessment Unit who is complaining of abdominal pain.
Which of the following is not an indication for an abdominal X-ray?

A. Suspected foreign body
B. Clinical suspicion of obstruction
C. Abdominal foreign body
D. Constipation
E. Investigation of suspected gallstones

Correct Answer: E

A 20-year-old intravenous drug user (ivDU) presents with a painful, swollen right knee. Examination reveals pyrexia and joint effusion. Frank pus is aspirated.
Which is the most likely infecting organism?

A. Staphylococcus aureus
B. Pseudomonas spp
C. Escherichia coli
D. Haemophilus influenzae
E. Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Correct Answer: A

A 44-year-old man is referred to the Hepatology Clinic with mild elevations in levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and aminotransferases. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity. He does not drink alcohol and has never used drugs in the past.
Physical examination is significant for obesity and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies reveal a negative hepatitis panel and normal iron studies. Antibodies for autoimmune liver disease are also normal.
His aminotransferase, ALP and autoimmune liver results are shown below.
Investigations Results Normal value
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 62 IU/l 10–40 IU/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 69 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 150 IU/l 30–130 IU/l
Anti-hepatitis C virus antibody negative
Hepatitis A Immunoglobulin G (IgG) negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen, surface antibody and core antibody negative
Antinuclear antibody titre 1 : 40
Anti-smooth muscle antibody negative
Antimitochondrial antibody negative
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A. Azathioprine
B. Liver transplant
C. Naltrexone
D. Oral steroids
E. Weight loss

Correct Answer: E

A study is designed to statistically test the hypothesis that a particular drug lowers blood pressure. A group of healthy volunteers enrolled in the study. Each participant’s blood pressure is measured prior to administration of the drug. One hour after the drug, the blood pressure for each participant is rechecked.
Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate for testing the hypothesis that the drug lowers blood pressure?

A. Binomial test
B. Chi-squared test
C. Paired t-test
D. Regression analysis
E. Unpaired t-test

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old man with atrial fibrillation attended the Cardiology Clinic prior to electrophysiological ablation.
Which of the following pathological changes is LEAST common in atrial fibrillation?

A. Fourth heart sound
B. Apical–radial pulse deficit
C. Left atrial thrombus
D. Reduction of cardiac output by 20%
E. Symptomatic palpitations

Correct Answer: A

A 36-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner with a 6-month history of erectile dysfunction. He also reports that he has noticed galactorrhoea and is experiencing headaches, usually upon waking in the morning. He has no significant past medical history. His blood test results are as follows:
Investigation(s) Result Normal range
Haemoglobin (Hb) 144 g/l 130–180 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 4.5 × 109/l 3.5–11 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 137 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 3.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.3 mmol/l
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 3.5 mU/l 0.27-4.2 mU/l
Prolactin 5679 mU/l 86-324 mU/l
Which of the following further investigations should be requested?

A. 24-hour urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA)
B. Chest X-ray
C. Computed tomography (CT) adrenal glands
D. CT pituitary
E. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) pituitary

Correct Answer: E

You are a FY2 doctor working in a district general hospital in Scotland. You have recently detained your 21-year old patient who was admitted a flare up of ulcerative colitis . He was demanding to go home because he is hearing voices that are telling him that everyone in the hospital is going to kill him. He tells you that his mother is the instigator and needs to be punished for her actions. You do note that he is delirious secondary to sepsis. You have contacted a psychiatrist, who has told you that she will be there within the next 6 hours. The patient is sitting peacefully in bed, making no attempts to leave, but appears to be responding to auditory hallucinations and talking about harming his mother.
You wish to give the patient a sedative. Can you do this?

A. Yes, but the patient must consent
B. Yes, the patient does not have to consent
C. Yes, as long as it approved by the psychiatrist
D. Yes, as long as his wife consents
E. Yes, it is urgently needed

Correct Answer: A

A 38-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and weight loss. He was found to be suffering from coeliac disease. A small intestinal biopsy was done, which was reported as: ‘Mucosa shows blunting of villi with crypt hyperplasia; intraepithelial lymphocytes ++’.
What is the stage of the disease?

A. 0
B. I
B. IB. I
B. IB. IB. I
B. E. IV

Correct Answer: D

A 63-year-old man who consumes over-the-counter multivitamins on a daily basis presents with sudden-onset right flank pain with radiation to the groin. He has nausea and vomiting. Urinalysis shows microscopic haematuria. There are square, envelope-shaped crystals in the urine.
Excessive intake of which of the following vitamins may result in this condition?

A. Vitamin B1
B. Vitamin B6
A. C. Vitamin B12
D. Vitamin C
E. Vitamin E

Correct Answer: D

A 41-year-old lady presents to you in the breast clinic for follow-up. She presented to the clinic last week with a 3-week history of a left breast lump and was seen and investigated by the consultant. She now attends to find out the results of those investigations and what the next step in management is. Her results are as follows:
mammogram: left breast M4 – probably malignant lesion; right breast M1
ultrasound: left breast U2 – probably benign lesion.
Which of the following is the next best step to take for this patient?

A. Repeat the tests after a month
B. Have the films re-reported with a second radiologist
C. Reassure the patient that although the mammogram showed M4, the ultrasound done after that has reassured us that nothing serious is present
D. Proceed to biopsy of the lesion
E. Arrange a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan

Correct Answer: D

A 68-year-old male patient presents to the Emergency Department with a rash. He has a history of fever and fatigue for three days, but in the last 12 hours has developed a rash. He is very anxious and in severe pain. The rash is mostly facial and truncal, and is a mixture of target lesions and blisters. His tongue and lips reveal severe mucosal desquamation. You recognise this as a severe but rare complication of one of his medications.
Which is the most likely culprit?

A. Amoxicillin
B. Candesartan
C. Diltiazem
D. Fluoxetine
E. Prednisolone

Correct Answer: A

You have just received a 75-year-old man into the resus room who had a witnessed collapse after complaining of chest pain. There was no pulse and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was performed at the scene. CPR is ongoing upon patient arrival in the Emergency Department. Pulse check demonstrates no palpable central pulse and there is no respiratory effort. A 3-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates no coordinated electrical activity or recognisable complexes, looking very much like a wandering flat line.
What is the most appropriate management of this patient?

A. Immediate direct current (DC) shock at 300 J, then continue CPR
B. 1 mg of adrenaline 1 : 1000 intramuscularly (im), and continue CPR
C. Commence external pacing via pads
D. 1 mg of adrenaline 1 : 10 000 intravenously (iv), and continue CPR
E. 3 mg of atropine iv, and continue CPR

Correct Answer: D

A concerned mother brings her 15-year-old daughter to see you because she has noticed in the last three months she is increasingly irritable, aggressive and withdrawn. She will refuse to go to school, misses her ballet and violin classes and does not go out with her friends. The symptoms seem to last for a couple of weeks and then abruptly resolve. They recommence a few days later. This has severely impacted on her education and function.
The patient denies any physical symptoms, loss of weight or change in appetite. She has regular periods, every 28 days. Her observations are normal, and examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Depression
B. Hypothyroidism
C. Hyperthyroidism
D. Mild premenstrual syndrome (PMS)
E. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder

Correct Answer: E

A 58-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department accompanied by his wife because of a sudden onset of incoherent speech. Physical examination shows right-sided weakness in the upper and lower extremities, a right facial droop, and a loss of sensation of the upper and lower extremities. An initial computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows no acute changes. Treatment with a tissue plasminogen activator is initiated.
Which of the following arterial territories is most likely compromised by this neurologic event?

A. Posterior cerebral artery
B. Anterior cerebral artery
C. Middle cerebral artery
D. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
E. Basilar artery

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old man visits his General Practitioner (GP) complaining that his right hand and forearm have not been feeling normal lately. He describes a feeling of numbness and tingling on the back of his hands and especially around his thumb, index and middle finger area. He has also been experiencing a weakness in his elbow and wrist.
On examination, the GP notes that power is reduced on elbow extension and wrist extension on the right. The other limbs were neurologically intact. The man does not remember having any injury to the right arm and does not play any extreme sports. He works as a security agent and often sleeps on a chair during his break when working night shifts. X-ray of the right wrist, elbow and shoulder show no obvious fractures.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A. Erb’s palsy
B. Cubital tunnel syndrome
C. Klumpke’s palsy
D. Carpal tunnel syndrome
E. Radial nerve palsy

Correct Answer: E

A 27-year-old man is found talking incoherently, confused and aggressive outside the local shopping centre late at night. Apparently, he has attended the Emergency Department on two previous occasions, one when he made a number of cuts to his forearms with a knife, and another when he was drunk and disorderly. When you question him in the Emergency Department, he tells you that he is a spy, that the TVs in the local department store are reading his thoughts and that voices are telling him to kill his mother as she is informing on him. He mentions that this has been going on for two months. He rambles when you talk to him and seems to have created a number of new words to describe his mission.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 131 g/l 135–175 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 7.6 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 203 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 139 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.9 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 130 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 25 IU/l 5–30 IU/l
Bilirubin 31 µmol/l 2–17 µmol/l
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Manic episode
B. Endogenous depression
C. Drug induced psychosis
D. Alcohol intoxication
E. Schizophrenia

Correct Answer: E

A 50-year-old woman presents with 6 months of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath. She describes it as ‘coming on suddenly without warning’. They have woken her at night before. She describes the attacks as a ‘tightness’ in the chest and says that they are associated with tingling in her fingers. The episodes resolve in a few minutes by themselves. She is otherwise medically fit and well. She smokes 15 cigarettes per day and has a family history of asthma. Examination is normal, and the peak expiratory flow rate is normal for her age and height.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Acute asthma attacks
B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
C. Left ventricular failure
D. Anaemia
E. Panic attacks

Correct Answer: E

An 81-year-old woman is seen in the Emergency Department after a ‘blackout’ while out shopping. On examination, she is now fully alert and orientated and looks well.
Apyrexial, CBG = 5.8 mmol/l
CV – HR 89 irregular, low volume
BP – 145/120 mmHg lying = standing
JVP – not raised
Apex beat – undisplaced and ‘forceful’ in character
Heart sounds: 1 + soft S2 + soft ejection systolic murmur loudest in the right second intercostal space, possible fourth heart sound heard
Chest: occasional bibasal crackles – clear with coughing
No peripheral oedema
Given this presentation and the clinical findings, what is the most likely cause of her collapse?

A. Aortic stenosis
B. Aortic regurgitation
C. Mixed mitral and aortic valve disease
D. Mitral stenosis
E. Mitral regurgitation

Correct Answer: A

A 40-year-old man comes to the surgery for some advice. He has booked a long-haul flight to New Zealand and is concerned about deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He is fit and well, with no previous history of note.
What would be the most appropriate advice to give him?

A. 300 mg of aspirin, flight stockings and ankle exercises
B. 75 mg aspirin, flight stockings, ankle exercises and no alcohol
C. No aspirin, ankle exercises, aisle seat and no alcohol
D. No aspirin, flight stockings, ankle exercises, aisle seat
E. Aspirin, walk up and down the aisles and plenty of water

Correct Answer: C

Consider the picture shown of the back of a 27-year-old man.
What is the most likely problem that he has presented with?

A. Allergic rhinitis
B. Bullous pemphigoid
C. Contact allergic dermatitis
D. Erythema multiforme
E. Sensitivity to wasp stings

Correct Answer: C

A 72-year-old woman is brought to her General Practitioner by her husband who has noted that her hearing on the left side has been progressively diminishing for the past eight months. Additionally, she also complains of an unsteady gait and of not being able to walk properly and leaning more towards the left side. On referral to the Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Department, the Consultant conducts a detailed clinical examination and finds nystagmus and dysdiadochokinesia, in addition to sensorineural loss in her left ear.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation for this patient?

A. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
B. Otoscopy
C. Plain computerised tomography (CT) scan
D. Pure tone audiometry (PTA)
E. Vestibular colorimetric test

Correct Answer: A

In a retrospective analysis of 600 patients referred to the local Tuberculosis (TB) Clinic over a 3-year period with suspected TB, 40 of these patients were found to have TB. All of these patients underwent testing with an assay called ‘TB-RED-SPOT’, as well as chest radiography and sputum microbiology. Of the patients diagnosed with TB, 36 had a positive TB-RED-SPOT assay result. Of the patients without TB, 14 had a positive ‘TB-RED-SPOT’ assay result.
Which of the following statements is true regarding the outcome of this analysis?

A. The sensitivity of the TB-RED-SPOT assay for TB is 90%
B. The specificity of the TB-RED-SPOT assay for TB is 99%
C. The positive predictive value of the TB-RED-SPOT assay is <50%
D. The sensitivity of the TB-RED-SPOT assay for TB is 72%
E. The negative predictive value of the TB-RED-SPOT assay is <90%

Correct Answer: A

A 51-year-old man attends his General Practice for routine assessment of type 2 diabetes. He was diagnosed with diabetes nine months ago and has been treated with metformin 1 g twice daily. His body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2. His laboratory test results are as follows:
Investigation Result Normalrange
HbA1C 64 mmol/mol < 53 mmol/mol (<7.0%)
Creatinine 78 µmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 90 ml/min > 90 ml/min
Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice for this patient’s diabetes management?

A. Acarbose
B. Basal bolus insulin regimen
C. Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP4) inhibitor
D. Sulfonylurea
E. Pre-mixed insulin 70 : 30

Correct Answer: C

An 89-year-old man with metastatic squamous cell lung cancer is admitted with lower respiratory tract infection on a background of recurrent infection. He is not undergoing any active cancer treatment. He lives at home alone. The admitting consultant discusses his wishes with regards to his future care. The consultant assesses the patient, notes that he has capacity and the patient asks for a ‘do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation’ (DNACPR) form, which is filed in his medical notes. He is adamant that he does not want CPR; however, his daughters arrive and are extremely angry when they hear he has signed a DNACPR. They meet the consultant and express their wishes for the DNACPR order to be revoked and for the patient to undergo resuscitation in the event of cardiopulmonary arrest.
Which of the following is true with regards to the DNACPR order?

A. It is permanent and cannot be revoked
B. It should be maintained
C. His daughters can apply to be his lasting power of attorney and then revoke the DNACPR
D. His daughters can enforce revoking of the DNACPR order
E. The treating consultant should consider cancelling the DNACPR

Correct Answer: B

A 62-year-old man is seen in the geriatric clinic for review. He has developed a symmetrical tremor and bradykinesia. His general practitioner is concerned that he may have developed Parkinson’s disease. He has a long medical history and is on various medications. You are concerned that his presentation may be related to a drug-induced effect, rather than a primary neurological disease.
Which of the following is most likely to be the cause?

A. Cyclizine
B. Gabapentin
C. Metoclopramide
D. Simvastatin
E. Tramadol

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man, a patient who has had chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) for last 3 years, presented with increasing fatigue and frequent fevers. His peripheral blood count was repeated and the pathologist found numerous cells of a particular type as shown here:
Department of Histology, Jagiellonian University Medical College
What is the significance of the increased number of these cells in CML?

A. Increasing anaemia
B. Transformation to acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
C. Accelerated phase of the disease
D. Superadded infection
E. None of the above

Correct Answer: C

A 15-year-old girl presents with a 3-day history of fever and polyarthralgia. She has widespread aches in multiple joints, including the hips, wrists and knees. She is normally fit and well, and the only medical history to note was eczema as a child, which she has now grown out of. The patient’s mother mentions that she did have a sore throat around two weeks ago, which was self-limiting. From the history and examination findings, the examining doctor feels that the patient is likely to have rheumatic fever.
Which of the following is most likely to be the cause of rheumatic fever?

A. Gamma-haemolytic Streptococcus
B. Group A Streptococcus
C. Group B Streptococcus
D. Streptococcus pneumoniae
E. Streptococcus viridans

Correct Answer: B

A 36-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner (GP) as her 39-year-old sister has recently been diagnosed with breast cancer and she is very concerned that there is a chance that she may also develop the condition. Her mother died from breast cancer aged 40.
The patient would like to be referred for genetic testing to find out if she is also at risk of the disease.
In which of the following genes are mutations most commonly associated with inherited breast cancer?

A. Adenomatous polyposis coli (APC)
B. Polycystic kidney disease 1 (PKD1)
C. Delta F508
D. RAS
E. BRCA2

Correct Answer: E

A 28-year-old man is brought in to the Emergency Department by ambulance after receiving an electrical injury. He was injured at a construction site after accidentally touching a 25 000 V AC overhead line. He is awake and alert and has visible patch burns to his right arm. His blood pressure is 125/74 mmHg, and his heart rate is 132 bpm, with an irregularly irregular rhythm. He has no past medical history. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals an irregular rhythm with absent P waves.
What initial treatment would you provide for his arrhythmia?

A. Direct current (DC) cardioversion
B. Intravenous (IV) fluids through a wide-bore cannula
C. IV heparin infusion
D. Flecainide
E. Left atrial catheter ablation

Correct Answer: D

A 20-hour-old neonate requires a detailed examination on the Postnatal Ward. It was a forceps delivery at 41+2 weeks’ gestation. The detailed examination is normal, except you notice slight reduced tone in the left arm and reduced Moro reflex on the left. The arm is resting in the waiter’s tip position. The examination is otherwise normal.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Cranial ultrasound scan
B. Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
C. Refer to Paediatric Neurology
D. Refer to physiotherapy
E. Shoulder X-ray

Correct Answer: D

A 75-year-old woman presents with the left forefoot X-ray shown below.
What is the most likely contributing factor to the deformity seen on the X-ray?

A. Congenital
B. Trauma
C. Osteoarthritis
D. Shoe-wearing
E. Connective tissue disease

Correct Answer: D

A 70-year-old woman has mild dementia and suffers a fall at her home in Scotland. She is in significant pain and has total external rotation of her left leg that is highly suggestive of a fractured neck of femur. You are her GP and have been called out, and arrive to find an ambulance in attendance. You and family and friends that she trusts all try and fail to get her to get into the ambulance. There is no welfare attorney or guardian with power to consent on her behalf. You are satisfied that she lacks capacity and that if treatment is not given, she will be left with pain and deformity.
How do you proceed?

A. Apply to a Sheriff or Justice of the Peace for grant of a warrant to remove her to hospital
B. With her friends and family, physically place her in the ambulance
C. Tell her that it is not an ambulance, but a taxi to take her somewhere nice
D. Call a psychiatrist to make an assessment for an emergency treatment order
E. Accept her decision, since she must be assumed to be capable of making her own decisions

Correct Answer: A

A 53-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) after her friends told her that her skin and eyes have become yellow. She says that she has noticed this too, but over the past month it has become worse. Her clothes have become loose lately. Her past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, dyslipidaemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (D. COPD).
She has a 30-pack-year smoking history and consumes approximately 30 units of alcohol per week. In the past, the patient has had repeated admissions to the hospital for episodes of pancreatitis and she mentions that the surgeon explained to her that her pancreas has become scarred from these repeated episodes and is likely to cause her ongoing abdominal pain.
Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient’s most likely diagnosis?

A. Chronic pancreatitis
B. Obesity
C. Hypertension
D. COPD
E. Acute pancreatitis

Correct Answer: A

A 26-year-old woman is diagnosed with a phaeochromocytoma.
The urine levels of which of the following will be most likely high in this patient?

A. Metanephrines
B. Dehydroepiandrosterone
C. Pregnanetriol
D. Cortisol
E. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man attends for his first abdominal aortic aneurysm screening. He is found to have an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.3 cm. He is seen routinely by a regional vascular centre that made the decision not to perform an elective repair. He has been advised to stop smoking, reduce his blood pressure through antihypertensive medications and to attend surveillance appointments.
How often should the patient receive surveillance abdominal ultrasounds?

A. Every month
B. Every three months
C. Every six months
D. Every 12 months
E. Every 24 months

Correct Answer: B

A 27-year-old gardener who is normally fit and well presents to his general practitioner with a 2-day history of worsening generalised abdominal pain, associated with nausea and some loose motions. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 37.9 °C. His heart rate is 90 bpm and regular, and his blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Examination of the abdomen reveals generalised tenderness. Of note, the patient is found to have a positive Rovsing sign.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A. Pyelonephritis
B. Abdominal aortic aneurysm
C. Splenic rupture
D. Pancreatitis
E. Appendicitis

Correct Answer: E

A 7-year-old boy has been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus. This condition is associated with defective β cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans.
With which kind of capillary are the pancreatic islets of Langerhans closely associated?

A. Continuous
B. Discontinuous, unfenestrated
C. Fenestrated
D. Discontinuous, fenestrated
E. Sinusoidal

Correct Answer: C

This 30-year-old man has developed a rash on the palms of his hands and sides of his fingers. It started 2 weeks previously without any obvious cause. It initially caused burning, but now there is an intense local itch that keeps him awake at night. There is no evidence of any rash elsewhere on the body. Otherwise he is well. He works as a solicitor.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Asteatotic eczema
B. Bullous pemphigoid
C. Contact dermatitis
D. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease
E. Pompholyx (dyshidrotic eczema)

Correct Answer: E

A 32-year-old woman with a history of Crohn’s disease presents for review with left loin pain consistent with renal colic. On examination she has a large midline abdominal scar consistent with small bowel resection. Plain abdominal X-ray reveals multiple renal calculi.
What type of renal calculi fit best with this clinical picture?

A. Uric acid stones
B. Cystine stones
C. Calcium oxalate stones
D. Calcium carbonate stones
E. Magnesium carbonate stones

Correct Answer: C

A 55-year-old woman presents complaining of lethargy, weight gain, dry hair and skin, cold intolerance, constipation and more recently low mood.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Hyperthyroidism
B. Hypercalcaemia
C. Hypothyroidism
D. Addison’s disease
E. Cushing’s disease

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man presents to his general practitioner (GP) with worsening right foot drop over the last three months. He also states that he has begun to drop objects that he was previously able to lift with ease. He does not have any other medical conditions.
Examination reveals bilateral lower limb weakness, which is worse on the right side and is associated with hyperreflexia. Examination of the upper limb is significant for left arm weakness, in particular the muscle groups innervated by the median and ulnar nerves.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Cerebrovascular accident
B. Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS)
C. Inclusion body myositis
D. Motor neurone disease (MND)
E. Syringomyelia

Correct Answer: D

A 55-year-old man, with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), is admitted to hospital with sudden-onset shortness of breath. His oxygen saturation levels are 82%, respiratory rate (RR) 25 breaths/min (normal 12–18 breaths/min), his trachea is central, he has reduced breath sounds in the right lower zone. Chest X-ray reveals a 2.5 cm translucent border at the base of the right lung.
Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most appropriate management?

A. Intrapleural chest drain
B. Observe
C. Intubation
D. Non-invasive ventilation (NIV)
E. Needle aspiration

Correct Answer: A

A 55-year-old woman has a small cell lung cancer. Her serum sodium level is 128 mmol/l on routine testing (136–145 mmol/l).
What is the single most likely cause for the biochemical abnormality?

A. Diuretics
B. Polydipsia
C. Primary adrenal insufficiency
D. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
E. Vomiting

Correct Answer: D

A 45-year-old man with a long-standing history of extensive psoriasis affecting the trunk, arms, buttock and nail beds is seen for review in Dermatology Outpatients. He has previously completed a course of phototherapy, with minimal improvement, and has shown no benefit on methotrexate for the past 12 months.
What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?

A. Further course of phototherapy
B. Hydroxychloroquine
C. Infliximab
D. Rituximab
E. Topical tacrolimus

Correct Answer: C

Researchers conducted a case-control study examining the relationship between poor diet and coronary artery disease. They enrolled cases from cardiac wards in hospitals and controls from General Practice surgeries in a single city. Diet for the past 10 years was assessed using an in-person interview in the setting where the patients were enrolled. After conducting the study, researchers found that, on average, the dietary interview with cases lasted 30 minutes longer than the interview with controls. In addition, the information collected from cases was much more detailed.
Which type of bias has most likely occurred?

A. Selection bias
B. Berkson’s bias
C. Loss to follow-up
D. Observer bias
E. Attrition bias

Correct Answer: D

A 43-year-old woman who is 21 weeks pregnant presents with abdominal pain associated with a loss of appetite and nausea. On examination, the patient is apyrexial, with a blood pressure of 122/80 mmHg and a heart rate of 92 bpm. Palpation of the abdomen reveals tenderness at McBurney’s point. Urine dip reveals a trace of glucose.
Which of the following investigations would be the test of choice to diagnose the patient’s condition?

A. Full blood count (FBC) with urea and electrolytes and liver function tests (LFTs)
B. Ultrasound abdomen
C. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen
D. Computed tomography (CT) abdomen
E. Ultrasound KUB (kidney ureter bladder)

Correct Answer: B

An 8-year-old boy is seen, having fallen off his skateboard and knocked out an adult front tooth one hour ago. He presents to the Emergency Department, with his parents asking if this can be reimplanted. He is otherwise well and has a normal examination, except for the missing tooth.
What is the most appropriate initial management?

A. Dental orthopantomogram (OPG) X-ray
B. Discard the tooth and organise an urgent dental implant
C. Place the tooth in milk and await dental input
D. Rinse the tooth in cool water and reinsert into the empty socket
E. Scrub the tooth in cool water and reinsert into the empty socket

Correct Answer: D

A 32-year-old man attends his General Practice worried about inherited diseases. His grandfather had difficulty walking from the age of 65 and his father developed the same symptoms at the age of 42.
In inheritance patterns, what is the mechanism responsible for the earlier onset from generation to generation?

A. Mosaicism
B. Incomplete penetrance
C. Genetic imprinting
D. Translocation of a chromosome
E. Anticipation

Correct Answer: E

A weight-lifter presents with pain over the anterior arm following a failed attempt at a lift. He felt a snap near his elbow joint, following which the limb became painful and he noticed a distinct swelling 2-3 cm above his elbow. His physiotherapist diagnoses a distal biceps tendon rupture.
Which of the following movements will be abolished?

A. Flexion at the elbow and pronation of the forearm
B. Flexion at the elbow and supination of the forearm
C. Extension at the elbow and supination of the forearm
D. Flexion and abduction at the shoulder
E. Extension and adduction at the shoulder

Correct Answer: B

A 25-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner complaining of a thick, cottage-cheese like vaginal discharge with a yellowish colour. The patient says that the discharge started about two days ago. There is no history of blood in the discharge, however she does have pain upon urination. Following a physical examination, the patient does not have any pain and there were no masses felt.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Normal discharge
B. Gonorrhoea
C. Candida albicans
D. Chlamydia
E. Bacterial vaginosis

Correct Answer: C

A sexually active woman has forgotten two of her combined contraceptive pills. The pills have been missed in the third week of the packet (days 15–21).
What is the most appropriate advice?

A. The most recent pill should be taken immediately and continue with the remaining pills. Condoms should be used until seven consecutive pills have been taken and omit the pill-free interval week. Start the new pack.
B. Both missed pills should be taken and extra precautions used for the next seven days. Continue the pack as usual.
C. The most recent pill should be taken. There is no need for extra precautions provided the woman omits the pill-free week and starts the new pack immediately.
D. There is no indication for emergency contraception if the preceding seven pills prior to the missed pills have been taken correctly.
E. The missed pills should not be taken. Continue the packet as usual but use condoms for the next seven days.

Correct Answer: A

A 49-year-old woman presents with erythematous scaly plaques on her elbows and knees and scattered smaller plaques elsewhere on her body and scalp. Removal of scale reveals tiny punctate bleeding points.
Damage to which layer of the skin is responsible for skin scaling to occur?

A. Epidermis
B. Dermo–epidermal junction
C. Papillary dermis
D. Subcutis
E. Epidermal appendages

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man was recently diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). His GP is about to start him on tamsulosin.
Which one of the following best describes the side-effects he may experience?

A. Urinary retention + nausea
B. Dizziness + postural hypotension
C. Urinary urgency + insomnia
D. Erectile dysfunction + reduced libido
E. Urgency + erectile dysfunction

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old female banker was brought into the Emergency Department by her family. They report a 3-day history of depression. She is now complaining of agitation, headache, confusion, fever, sweating and diarrhoea. The family claim she has been down lately and refused to go work after a big fight with her boyfriend. She is taking fluoxetine. The family found empty bottles of fluoxetine and sertraline on the floor of her flat. On examination, she is agitated and sweating; her blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg, pulse 100 bpm, respiratory rate 14 and temperature 39 °C.
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A. Malignant hyperthermia
B. Acute dystonia
C. Serotonin syndrome
D. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
E. Akathisia

Correct Answer: C

A 62-year-old man with long-standing multiple sclerosis (MS) is admitted due to increasing problems with his care in the community. He is bed-bound with a spastic paraparesis. He is noted to have a permanent 14-gauge urinary catheter in situ and has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. The family informs the nursing staff that this has not been changed for some time. Your senior colleague wishes for the catheter to be replaced due to recurrent UTI's.
Which one of the following statements is the most accurate?

A. The catheter should be decreased from a 14- to a 16-gauge when replaced
B. Given the paraparesis local anaesthetic gel is not essential
C. A male chaperone is required
D. A single dose of prophylactic gentamicin is advisable
E. The catheter will need replacing again in 9 months time

Correct Answer: D

You are called to attend a 30-year-old man who is in cardiac arrest on one of the wards. On arrival, the patient has defibrillator pads attached and someone is performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A rhythm strip displays ventricular fibrillation during a CPR pause.
What is the most appropriate management?

A. Continue CPR at 30 : 2 with interval checks
B. Give adrenaline 1 : 1000 intravenously (IV)
C. Give one further round of CPR, followed by safe direct current (DC) shock
D. Safely DC shock immediately
E. Stop resuscitation

Correct Answer: D

A 30-year-old man is brought in by ambulance to the Emergency Department after a night out. His friend said he had taken some unknown substance in a club. On examination, patient looks dry. He has a GCS 13/15 and pupils are dilated and divergent. He also had a palpable bladder on abdominal examination:
Investigation Result Normal value
Heart rate (HR) 112 bpm 60–100 beats/min
Blood pressure (BP) 120/70 mmHg < 120/80 mmHg
Respiratory rate (RR) 18 breaths/min 12–18 breaths/min
Sats 96% on air 94–98%
An electrocardiogram (ECG) was done which showed sinus tachycardia with a prolonged QTc of 580 ms.
What Is the mostly likely drug he has taken to cause this presentation?

A. Amitriptyline
B. Cocaine
C. Sertraline
D. Morphine
E. Diazepam

Correct Answer: A

A 48-year-old woman with a history of intermittent ringing sound in her left ear for the last four months presents to the Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) Outpatient Department. She describes the ringing sound to be pulsatile in nature. She has no history of fever, hearing loss, trauma or any recent ear infections. Her past medical history includes a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis under remission for the past year. Clinical examination of the head and neck is unremarkable.
Which is the most appropriate investigation which will help to reach a final diagnosis in this patient?

A. Audiometry
B. Computerised tomography (CT) (contrast-enhanced) scan of the temporal bone
C. Magnetic resonance angiography
D. Tympanometry and otoscopy
E. Weber’s test

Correct Answer: B

A 23-year-old man has suffered with significant bloody diarrhoea for 3 days, which is causing him significant concern. He is otherwise well. Stool microscopy and culture return positive for Shigella, and a diagnosis of dysentery is made.
What the is appropriate antibiotic therapy of choice?

A. No antibiotic
B. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg po bd for 1 day only
C. Azithromycin 500 mg po od for 3 days
D. Metronidazole 500 mg po bd for 7–10 days
E. Erythromycin 250 mg po qds for 5–7 days

Correct Answer: B

A 50-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner (GP) as she has been feeling low for some time. She complains of episodes lasting around three minutes where she is suddenly very anxious and hyperventilates. On further questioning, the GP finds that this has been getting worse over the past two months. The patient would like to know if there are any medications available that could help her.
What is the mechanism of action of monoamine oxidase inhibitors?

A. Build up of neurotransmitter in synaptic cleft
B. Increased synaptic clearance
C. Hyperpolarisation of the neurone membrane
D. Reduced re-uptake of neurotransmitter
E. Antibody to acetylcholine receptor

Correct Answer: A

A 35-year-old woman is being reviewed in the Psychiatry Clinic after attempting suicide two weeks ago. She had cut her wrist at home and was brought to the hospital after her mother found her unconscious. She was successfully resuscitated, received a blood transfusion, and was discharged after a few days in hospital. This had been her third suicide attempt in the past two years. She works in retail and suffers from bipolar disorder since her teenage years. She is currently single after having had unsuccessful relationships in the past. She consumes a moderate amount of alcohol and smokes around ten cigarettes a day. She is currently taking lithium for her mental illness. She is otherwise fit and healthy and does not suffer from any medical conditions.
Which one of the following will form part of the long-term risk management for this patient?

A. Avoid the discussion of a crisis plan
B. Comprehensive psychosocial assessment of needs and risks
C. Informing the patient that confidentiality will always be maintained
D. Prescribing psychiatric medications to reduce self-harm
E. Use of risk assessment tool to predict future risk

Correct Answer: B

A 31-year-old woman gives birth to a 36-week gestational age male neonate. Within 5 hours after delivery, the neonate demonstrates excessive respiratory efforts and tachypnoea. There is grunting and intercostal retraction.
A chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary oedema with a ground-glass appearance.
Which of the following findings are most likely to have been noted on antenatal examination of the mother?

A. Serum total calcium of 1.75 mmol/l
B. Positive indirect Coombs’ test
C. Fasting blood sugar of 14.0 mmol/l
D. Elevated titres of anti-nuclear and anti-SSA antibodies
E. Elevated total thyroxine concentration

Correct Answer: C

An 86-year-old man, who is confused and aggressive, is admitted to the Medical Admission Unit. He is unable to give any history due to confusion. His wife had taken him to the general practice surgery yesterday due to increased confusion, and trimethoprim was prescribed to treat a urinary tract infection. From a previous discharge letter, you ascertain that he has a background of Alzheimer’s dementia, atrial fibrillation (AF), ischaemic heart disease and osteoarthritis. His wife reports that he is normally forgetful but is much more confused than usual.
On examination, his pulse is 124 bpm (irregularly irregular), blood pressure 134/74 mmHg, oxygen saturation (SaO2) 95% (on 28% oxygen), respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute and temperature 38.4 °C. He has crepitations and increased vocal resonance at the right lung base, with an area of bronchial breathing above this. Neurological examination of the upper and lower limbs is normal.
Chest X-ray (CXR): focal consolidation, right base
Electrocardiogram (ECG): AF with rapid ventricular response
Urine dip: protein ++, otherwise NAD
Blood results are pending.
What is the most likely cause of this patient's acute deterioration?

A. Urinary tract infection
B. Community-acquired pneumonia
C. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
D. Progression of Alzheimer’s disease
E. Myocardial infarction

Correct Answer: B

A 40-year-old man complains of tiredness for the last six months. He has no previous medical history and otherwise feels very well in himself, but over the last few months, he feels like he could fall asleep at any time and has once fallen asleep at his work. He snores loudly in bed. He smokes 20 cigarettes per day and drinks about 40 units of alcohol per week. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 31.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Anaemia
B. Chronic fatigue syndrome
C. Obstructive sleep apnoea
D. Diabetes
E. Depression

Correct Answer: C

A 44-year-old man is admitted to Accident and Emergency (A&E) with an acute onset of severe epigastric pain and haematemesis of bright red blood. He has a history of heavy alcohol consumption for many years. On examination, he has cool extremities and guarding over the epigastric region. He has a large ascitic abdomen and multiple spider naevi on his neck and cheek. He is haemodynamically unstable, and fluid resuscitation is commenced.
Given the likely diagnosis, what medication is it most important to start?

A. Clopidogrel
B. Propranolol
C. Omeprazole
D. Terlipressin
E. Tranexamic acid

Correct Answer: D

A 25-year-old woman presents to the Renal Clinic for review. She has suffered from two recent urinary tract infections, and asymptomatic haematuria has been noted on urine dipstick testing on two separate occasions. She reports costovertebral angle tenderness on a few occasions in the past year. On examination, there is no residual tenderness today. Her blood pressure is 145/92 mmHg.
Investigations:
Investigation Result Normal value
Haemoglobin 119 g/l 115–155 g/l
White cell count (WCC) 6.2 × 109/l 4–11 × 109/l
Platelets 256 × 109/l 150–400 × 109/l
Sodium (Na+) 145 mmol/l 135–145 mmol/l
Potassium (K+) 4.8 mmol/l 3.5–5.0 mmol/l
Creatinine 100 μmol/l 50–120 µmol/l
Abdominal plain X-ray Multiple pre-calyceal calcifications
affecting both kidneys, with a
‘bunch of grapes’ appearance
Which of the following diagnoses fits best with this clinical picture?

A. Recurrent urinary tract infection
B. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
C. Renal tuberculosis
D. Medullary sponge kidney
E. Reflux nephropathy

Correct Answer: D

A 59-year-old man presents to the doctor with a week history of frank haematuria. He has no other symptoms to note and is otherwise well although he has been a little tired. He has a history of hypertension which is well controlled on with perindopril. He smokes 10 cigarettes a day and has done so since his teens.
Examination of the abdomen reveals no abnormalities. A dipstick test of the urine reveals blood +++.
The patient is especially concerned that he may have a kidney tumour, as his father died from the condition over 20 years ago.
Which of the following malignancies of the kidney the most common in the adult population ?

A. Primary renal lymphoma
B. Renal cell carcinoma
C. Transitional cell carcinoma
D. Renal sarcoma
E. Nephroblastoma

Correct Answer: B

A 54-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of inability to control urine and inability to walk. She also complaints of dull back ache for a week prior to the onset of weakness. She has a recent travel history to India to visit her family and has been complaining of weight loss, night sweats and generalised lethargy for the past three months.
She is haemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 130/60 mmHg and pulse rate of 86 bpm. She is afebrile.
Neurological examination revealed loss of anal tone and perianal sensation. She also had hyperreflexia of bilateral patellar reflex. An urgent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) thoracolumbar spine was ordered. Multiple ring-enhancing collections were seen at the epidural regions of L1/L2 causing cord compression.
What is the most immediate management that should be carried out?

A. Intravenous (IV) antibiotics
B. Urgent decompressive laminectomy
C. Commencement of anti-TB medications
D. Fluid resuscitation
E. IV immunoglobulins

Correct Answer: B

A 79-year-old man is currently receiving end-of-life care due to advanced lung cancer. He has been suffering from intermittent episodes of vomiting, reflux and early satiety thought to be due to autonomic dysfunction causing gastric stasis. He has a history of Parkinson’s disease.
What pharmacological option would be most appropriate to prescribe for this patient?

A. Cyclizine
B. Dexamethasone
C. Domperidone
D. Haloperidol
E. Metoclopramide

Correct Answer: C

A 36-year-old man vomits bright red blood after an alcohol binge. A bleeding duodenal ulcer is suspected.
Which one of the following vessels is the most likely source of the blood?

A. Gastroduodenal artery
B. Left gastric artery
C. Left gastroepiploic artery
D. Right gastroepiploic artery
E. Short gastric arteries

Correct Answer: A

You are unable to intubate a 65-year-old male patient, with a history of ischaemic heart disease (taking aspirin and clopidogrel) and reflux, for an emergency DHS for his neck of femur fracture. You gave a thiopentone and suxamethonium rapid sequence induction. You have repositioned the patient, tried to insert a bougie and changed to a McCoy blade without success. The patient has started to desaturate to 88%. You cannot ventilate via a face mask, as the patient has a large face and a thick beard. You are unable to achieve any tidal volume and keep losing your seal.
What should your next course of action be?

A. Deliver 100% oxygen and wake the patient up
B. Insert a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) and attempt to ventilate the patient
C. Use a videolaryngoscope to secure a definitive airway
D. Attempt a fibreoptic intubation to have a direct view of the cords
E. Have another go at intubation using a long blade

Correct Answer: B

A 64-year-old man reports to Accident and Emergency after complaining of chest pain and some shortness of breath which is predominantly worse on the right side. His symptoms have been present for approximately 24 hours; however, it has been worse since waking up this morning. He reports that the pain is worse on inspiration and that he has had no previous chest pain. The patient is almost bed ridden due to obesity but he has no previous respiratory issues. He is currently undergoing treatment for newly diagnosed prostate cancer. There is a high index of suspicion that this man may have a pulmonary embolus (PE). His observations are:
Temperature 36.5 °C
Blood pressure 136/82 mmHg
Heart rate 124 bpm
Saturations 94% on room air
His 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia and nil else.
What would be the most appropriate initial step in the management of this case?

A. Computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiography
B. Rivaroxaban
C. Thrombolysis with alteplase
D. Intravenous (IV) unfractionated heparin
E. Chest X-ray

Correct Answer: B

A 35-year-old man with known human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the Emergency Department with a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He also has a fever and mentions the presence of a non-productive cough which has been getting worse over the past week.
On examination, the patient is febrile with a temperature of 38.2 oC, pulse is 92 bpm and regular, and his blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg.
The patient seems breathless at rest, with an oxygen saturation of 96% in room air. However, a chest examination reveals no abnormalities. The examining doctor orders tests, including a CD4 count, arterial blood gases (ABGs), and a chest X-ray; she lists Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) as one of the possible differential diagnoses.
With regard to PJP, which of the following statements is true?

A. All patients with PJP have an abnormal chest radiograph
B. Occurs at a higher rather than lower CD4 count
C. Only occurs in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
D. Can be successfully treated with co-trimoxazole
E. PJP is diagnosed by blood culture

Correct Answer: D

This 72-year-old woman complains of disturbance in vision and is found to have a visual field defect in the eye shown. She is known to suffer from hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia and type II diabetes mellitus. She is found to have a carotid bruit on the same side. The changes found on fundoscopy in the affected eye are shown.
What is the diagnosis in this case?

A. Acute glaucoma
B. Optic neuritis
C. Retinal artery occlusion
D. Retinal detachment
E. Retinal vein occlusion

Correct Answer: C

A 43-year-old man with dyspepsia and a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease presents with intractable watery diarrhoea and weight loss. He has multiple gastric and duodenal peptic ulcers, which are poorly responding to medications such as antacids and omeprazole. Gastric acid output and serum gastrin level are elevated. Serum gastrin level fails to decrease following a test meal. On abdominal computerised tomography (CT) scan, no masses are found in the pancreas or duodenum.
