Which one of the following drugs is useful for this patient?

A. Bromocriptine
B. Pergolide
C. Somatostatin antagonist
D. Leuprolide
E. Octreotide

Correct Answer: E

A 66-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with chest tightness. The tightness started about a day ago, however today it is worse and associated with shortness of breath and dizziness.
Upon examination, there is a slow rising carotid pulse and systolic murmur which radiates to carotids 3/6. Examination is otherwise unremarkable with no calf tenderness. The patient does not have any significant past medical history apart from type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension which are both well controlled.
What is the best diagnostic investigation?

A. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
B. Exercise tolerance
C. Echocardiogram
D. D-dimer
E. Coronary angiogram

Correct Answer: C

A 32-year-old former intravenous (iv) drug abuser is sent by his general practitioner to outpatient clinic with deranged liver function tests (LFTs). He is asymptomatic, but on examination, 4-cm hepatomegaly is noted. Blood tests reveal he is hepatitis C-positive. The hepatitis C RNA viral load is significantly elevated.
What investigation would be most important to guide future management of his hepatitis C?

A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test
B. Ultrasound scan abdomen
C. Hepatitis C genotype
D. Chest X-ray
E. Urine drug screening

Correct Answer: C

A 29-year-old woman with essential hypertension, treated with once-daily ramipril, presents at her booking visit at eight weeks’ gestation. She has a history of asthma that is well treated with inhalers and depression, but she is currently on no antidepressants. There is no other medical history of note. Her blood pressure in clinic today is 145/89 mmHg.
How should this patient’s hypertension be managed in pregnancy?

A. Continue ramipril at current dose
B. Continue ramipril, but increase the dose
C. Discontinue antihypertensive treatment as blood pressure drops in the first trimester
D. Stop ramipril and start labetalol
E. Stop ramipril and start nifedipine

Correct Answer: E

A 75-year-old man complains to his General Practitioner (GP) regarding difficulty swallowing. It has occurred in the last four weeks, primarily with solid foods, not liquids, which he describes as getting ‘stuck’.
His past medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis of the knees, for which he takes amlodipine 5 mg OD and paracetamol 1 g as required respectively. He does not drink alcohol but has a 20-pack year smoking history.
On examination, he appears well at rest and has a normal body habitus. Abdominal examination is largely unremarkable, except for some mild epigastric discomfort.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A. Emergency hospital admission
B. Proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and review in a month
C. Routine outpatient gastrointestinal appointment
D. Refer to gastroenterology for OGD (oesophago-gastro-duodenoscopy) under the 2-week wait criteria
E. Acute specialist care of the elderly clinic referral

Correct Answer: D

A 65-year-old man has had pain in the right shoulder for several weeks. During the examination, the shoulder is passively abducted by the doctor. Passive abduction is full but painful and is particularly painful between about 70 and 120 degrees of abduction. The patient then lowers the arm slowly, but when it reaches 90 degrees, the arm drops to the side.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Adhesive capsulitis
B. Biceps tendinitis
C. Rotator cuff tear
D. Rotator cuff tendinitis
E. Subacromial bursitis

Correct Answer: C

An 18-year-old male student spontaneously disrobed while watching a film. He saw wavy lines on the screen and then reported a brief episode of mental blankness, followed soon after by a headache and extreme fatigue.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

A. Generalised tonic clonic epilepsy or bilateral tonic clonic epilepsy
B. Partial complex seizure or Focal Impaired Awareness epilepsy
C. Schizophreniform disorder
D. Migraine behavioural syndrome
E. Exhibitionism

Correct Answer: B

A 19-year-old man presents with fevers two weeks after returning from his gap year holiday in Kenya. The patient also complains of nausea and abdominal pain, with episodes of shivering and muscle pains. He initially felt that he may have had a viral illness, but the symptoms have worsened. He did take anti-malarial tablets while away but frequently forgot to take the doses as prescribed.
Which one of the following statements about malaria is true?

A. Malaria is spread by the bite of the female Aedes mosquito
B. Plasmodium malariae causes the most severe form of malaria
C. Artemisinin combination therapy is the treatment of choice for falciparum malaria
D. Thrombocytosis is commonly seen in malaria
E. Chloroquine alone is the treatment for vivax malaria

Correct Answer: C

A 4-year-old boy is brought to his General Practitioner as his parents are concerned about his walking. Up until three months ago, he was developing normally. However, they have now noted he struggles to get up from the floor or climb stairs. On examination, he is noted to exhibit Gowers’ sign and has large, bulky calf muscles. His mother recalls having an uncle who passed away at a very early age but does not recall what from.
What is the most likely cause of his walking problems?

A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
B. Emery–Dreifuss muscular dystrophy
C. Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy
D. Myotonic dystrophy
E. Polymyositis

Correct Answer: A

A 65-year-old man presents with acute onset of pain and swelling of his right first toe. There is no history of trauma. Past medical history is significant for alcoholism, congestive heart failure (CHF) and atrial fibrillation. Examination is unremarkable, aside from a swollen, erythematous and tender big toe.
Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?

A. Colchicine
B. Allopurinol
C. Broad-spectrum intravenous (IV) antibiotics
D. Treatment-dose low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)
E. Relocation of displaced fracture

Correct Answer: A

A 39-year-old woman, mother of three children, presents to the General Practitioner (GP) with a history of menorrhagia. She reports regular periods, lasting five days, and denies any dysmenorrhoea.
She uses ten pads per day for the first two days and often gets flooding, which she finds troublesome at work. She explains that she wants symptomatic control and contraception.
A full blood count (FBC) and pelvic ultrasound are normal.
Which of the following is the best suited first-line management option for this patient?

A. Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP)
B. Intrauterine device (copper coil)
C. Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena®)
D. Mefenamic acid
E. Tranexamic acid

Correct Answer: C

A 33-year-old woman attends the surgery following two positive pregnancy tests. She wants advice on how to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She is medically fit, takes folic acid and smokes 30 cigarettes per day.
You know that for the safety of the pregnancy, it is important that she stops smoking as soon as possible, so you use motivational interviewing techniques to address her smoking.
Which of the following is the first step?

A. Use a numerical scale to ask how important it is for her to stop smoking
B. Establish rapport and find out whether she wants to change
C. Explain and advise why smoking is harmful in pregnancy
D. Try to break down any resistance to stopping shown by the patient
E. Use a numerical scale to assess her confidence to quit smoking

Correct Answer: B

A 4-year-old boy presents to his general practitioner with fever and ear pain for the last 4 days. He is diagnosed as having left otitis media and was started on a course of oral amoxicillin. Over the next 24 hours, he develops high fevers and rigors, so presents to the Emergency Department. On examination, there is purulent fluid draining through the left tympanic membrane and he is also noted to have enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Further examination reveals left axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy, with an enlarged spleen and liver and multiple bruises on his extremities. Blood results are pending.
What is the most likely diagnosis to explain all his symptoms?

A. Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
B. Left otitis media with sepsis
C. Non-accidental injury (NAI)
D. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)
E. Kawasaki’s disease

Correct Answer: D

You are asked to see a patient who has not opened their bowels for several days. Their abdomen is distended, and they describe cramping abdominal pain that comes and goes. A supine abdominal X-ray is performed to identify features of bowel obstruction and suggest the location of the obstruction.
Which of the following is more characteristic of the large bowel, rather than the small bowel, on an abdominal X-ray?

A. Located towards the centre of the abdomen
B. Valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares)
C. Haustral folds
D. Normal maximum diameter of 3 cm
E. Air–fluid levels in obstruction

Correct Answer: C
